item.title: The config directory
item.content:encoded: <p>For simple Hugo sites, a single configuration file is usually all you’ll need. However, for bigger projects, with large configurations, it’s often a good idea to split your <code>hugo.toml</code> file into multiple files using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/configuration/introduction/#configuration-directory" target="_blank" rel="noopener">configuration directory</a>.</p> <p>The config directory is helpful for managing how your config behaves across different environments, as well as for organising multilingual menus, params, modules, build options and various other site configuration settings.</p> <p>In this post we’re going to look at how it works.</p> <h2 id="create-a-config-directory">Create a <code>/config</code> directory</h2> <p>To get going, you’ll need to create a <code>./config</code> directory at the root of your project. Then add a sub directory called <code>_default</code> inside.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-bash" data-lang="bash"><span class="line"><span class="cl">config/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">└── _default/ </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next, create a file called <code>hugo.toml</code> inside the <code>_default</code> folder for your default configuration.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-bash" data-lang="bash"><span class="line"><span class="cl">my-project/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">└── config/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> └── _default/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> └── hugo.toml </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now, head back to the <code>hugo.toml</code> file found at the root of your project and copy everything that typically lives at the top of the file. Then paste it into your new default config file found at <code>config/_default/hugo.toml</code>.</p> <p>Assuming you’re working with a fresh Hugo project, then you’ll most likely be copying over the following three lines of TOML data:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">baseURL</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;http://example.org/&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">languageCode</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;en-gb&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">title</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;My New Hugo Site&#39;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>It’s important to note that <code>config/_default/hugo.toml</code> will now override your original config file. So you might as well transfer everything across and delete the original file from the root of your project.</p> <p>In theory, you could then use <code>config/_default/hugo.toml</code> for the whole of your config. For example:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">baseURL</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;http://example.org/&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">languageCode</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;en-gb&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">title</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;My New Hugo Site&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Home&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;About&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/about&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">params</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">subtitle</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Reference, Tutorials, and Explanations&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">params</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">contact</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">email</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;info@example.org&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">phone</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;+1 206-555-1212&#39;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>But, storing all of your configuration inside <code>config/_default/hugo.toml</code> kind of defeats the point of using the config directory altogether.</p> <p>You’re likely here because you’re configuration is large and unwieldy. Or you’re looking to create environment specific configs (which we’ll get to shortly). So the best option is to split up your configuration to make it easier to manage.</p> <h2 id="create-individual-files-for-each-root-object">Create individual files for each root object</h2> <p>The idea is to create a file for each root object found in your original config file. When creating a new file, it’s important to name the file after the root configuration key.</p> <p>For example, let’s say you have a bunch of params stored under the <code>[params]</code> root configuration key. That means you’ll need to create a new file called <code>params.toml</code> inside <code>config/_default/</code>, where those particular configuration settings will live.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-bash" data-lang="bash"><span class="line"><span class="cl">my-project/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">└── config/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> └── _default/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> ├── hugo.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> ├── params.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> ├── menus.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> └── pagination.toml </span></span></code></pre></div><p>As you can see above, the same goes for any other root configuration keys you might have in your original config file. You can find a list of <a href="https://gohugo.io/configuration/introduction/#configuration-directory" target="_blank" rel="noopener">all the possible configuration keys</a> in the Hugo Docs.</p> <h2 id="omit-the-root-key">Omit the root key</h2> <p>When you add configuration content to each file, make sure you omit the root key from the file. The name of the file replaces the root key.</p> <p>For example, where you menu configuration in your original <code>hugo.toml</code> file might have looked like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Home&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;About&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/about&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Your <code>./config/_default/menus.toml</code> file should look like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Home&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;About&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/about&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Almost exactly the same, except the file no longer contains the <code>[menus]</code> root key at the top of the file.</p> <h2 id="configure-languages-and-localised-files">Configure languages and localised files</h2> <p>Using the config directory for multilingual websites involves storing configuration settings across various files.</p> <p>The first step is to add base language settings inside <code>config/_default/hugo.toml</code>. This tells Hugo what the default language should be when someone lands on your website. For example:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">baseURL</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;http://example.org/&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">languageCode</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;en-gb&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">title</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;My New Hugo Site&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c"># Language base settings</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">defaultContentLanguage</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;en&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">defaultContentLanguageInSubdir</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="kc">false</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">disableDefaultLanguageRedirect</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="kc">false</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">disableLanguages</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="p">[]</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You can read more about <a href="https://gohugo.io/configuration/languages/#base-settings" target="_blank" rel="noopener">language base settings</a> in the Hugo Docs.</p> <p>The next step is to create a new <code>languages.toml</code> file in the <code>_default</code> directory. This file will contain any settings usually found under the <code>languages</code> key.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-bash" data-lang="bash"><span class="line"><span class="cl">my-project/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">└── config/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> └── _default/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> ├── hugo.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> ├── params.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> ├── menus.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> ├── pagination.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> └── languages.toml </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Your <code>config/_default/languages.toml</code> file might look like this, for example:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">languages</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">en</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">contentDir</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;content/english&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">languageName</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;English&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">languageCode</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;en-GB&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">languageDirection</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;ltr&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">languages</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">de</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">contentDir</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;content/deutsch&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">languageName</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Deutsch&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">languageCode</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;de-DE&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">languageDirection</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;ltr&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice, just as before, the <code>[languages]</code> root configuration key has been omitted.</p> <p>With languages configured, files can now be localised to become language specific.</p> <p>For example, if your site supports English and German, you might wish to translate menu items for each language. To do this, you’ll need to create two files for the different menus. One for English translations and one for German. You’d name each file <code>menus.&lt;language&gt;.toml</code>, using a valid BCP 47 language tag in the file name.</p> <p>Consider the following, for example:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-bash" data-lang="bash"><span class="line"><span class="cl">my-project/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">└── config/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> └── _default/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> ├── hugo.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> ├── params.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> ├── languages.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> ├── menus.en.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> └── menus.de.toml </span></span></code></pre></div><p>See <a href="https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5646#section-2.1" target="_blank" rel="noopener">RFC 5646</a> for more details on how to construct language tags.</p> <p>Your <code>config/_default/menus.en.toml</code> might look like this, for example:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;About&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/about&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Services&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/services&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Contact&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/contact&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">30</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>While your <code>config/_default/menus.de.toml</code> file might look like this, for example:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Über Mich&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/ueber-mich/&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/about&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Leistungen&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/leistungen/&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/services&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Kontakt&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/Kontakt/&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/contact&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">30</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Simple stuff!</p> <h2 id="working-with-different-environments">Working with different environments</h2> <p>Adding configuration settings for different environments involves setting up sub directories for each environment.</p> <p>First create a sub directory named after each environment, then add environment specific configuration files to the respective sub directory.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-bash" data-lang="bash"><span class="line"><span class="cl">my-project/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">└── config/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> ├── _default/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> │ ├── hugo.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> │ ├── languages.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> │ ├── params.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> │ ├── menus.en.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> │ └── menus.fr.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> ├── production/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> │ ├── hugo.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> │ └── params.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> └── staging/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> ├── hugo.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> └── params.toml </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Hugo will continue to use your <code>_default</code> configuration, then merge the non-default environment settings on top for the respective environment. That means you don’t need to include default settings in your non-default environment files. Only include settings specific to the environment.</p> <h3 id="conditionally-render-analytics-based-on-environment">Conditionally render analytics based on environment</h3> <p>To give you an example of how this works, let’s say you wish to implement <a href="https://usefathom.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Fathom Analytics</a> on a website. A typical way to do this is to add the Fathom Site ID under the <code>[params]</code> configuration key in your <code>hugo.toml</code> file.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">params</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">fathom_id</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;ZYSUYIBA&#39;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>From here you might open either your <code>baseof.html</code> template or perhaps a <code>head.html</code> partial, depending on where your site <code>&lt;head&gt;</code> is stored. Then, somewhere inside the <code>&lt;head&gt;</code>, you can render the Site ID in the script tag that Fathom provides.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ $fathomId := .Site.Params.fathom_id }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ with $fathomId }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">script</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://cdn.usefathom.com/script.js&#34;</span> <span class="na">data-site</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ . }}&#34;</span> <span class="na">defer</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">script</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The issue with this approach is that the script tag will render and send tracking data to Fathom, no matter the environment. But, you don’t really want to render the script tag when working in development, as this will skew the tracking data.</p> <p>To solve this problem, the next step would be to exclude the Fathom related config from <code>config/_default/hugo.toml</code>, which happens to be the config file used for development.</p> <p>Taking this step will prevent the the Site ID rendering in the script tag. Therefore, when you run <code>hugo server</code> and work on the site locally, no data will be sent back to Fathom and you’re production data will remain unaffected by your work.</p> <p>But you’ll still need to make sure the tracking script and Site ID render for the production website. To make that happen you can move the Fathom related config to <code>config/production/hugo.toml</code>:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">params</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">fathom_id</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;ZYSUYIBA&#39;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You could then update the template with some conditional logic, so the script tag only renders when the environment is set to <em>production</em>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ $fathomId := .Site.Params.fathom_id }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ if eq hugo.Environment &#34;production&#34; }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ with $fathomId }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">script</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://cdn.usefathom.com/script.js&#34;</span> <span class="na">data-site</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ . }}&#34;</span> <span class="na">defer</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">script</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now you can include the specific environment flag when running the <code>hugo</code> command.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="l">hugo --environment production</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>This will build the site with your default configuration, then merge any production environment settings on top.</p> <p>It’s worth noting that you can also set the environment when using <code>hugo server</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="l">hugo server --environment production</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>This will help you check everything is set up and working correctly, locally in a browser.</p> <h3 id="configuring-base-urls-for-staging-and-production">Configuring base URLs for staging and production</h3> <p>Another good use case for the config directory is to control the <code>baseurl</code> of your website across different environments.</p> <p>For example, let’s say you’re deploying a site using <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cloudcannon</a>. Once your site has built, Cloudcannon automatically provides <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/what-is-a-testing-domain/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a testing domain</a> so you can see your site live on the web.</p> <p>To configure your site, so that it renders as expected and nothing breaks during deployment, the first thing to do is add this testing domain as the value of <code>baseurl</code> inside <code>config/staging/hugo.toml</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">baseurl</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;https://crimson-piano.cloudvent.net/&#34;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next, you’ll need to <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/configure-your-environment-variables/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">configure the environment variable</a> in your Cloudcannon project site settings. That way, Cloudcannon will know the correct build command to run when deploying the site.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>hugo --environment staging </code></pre><p>Now, whenever you push your changes, Cloudcannon will redeploy your website and replace the <code>baseurl</code> found inside <code>config/_default/hugo.toml</code> with the testing domain found inside <code>config/staging/hugo.toml</code>.</p> <p>Of course, if you also have a production version of your project on Cloudcannon, then the domain for that project (most likely a custom one) should populate the <code>baseurl</code> field inside your <code>config/production/hugo.toml</code> file.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">baseurl</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;https://fancy-custom-domain.com/&#34;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Just as you did with your staging site, you’ll also need to configure the environment variable in your Cloudcannon project site settings.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>hugo --environment production </code></pre><p>Simple stuff, made easy by the configuration directory.</p> <h2 id="summary">Summary</h2> <p>That was a quick look at how organising your configuration using the config directory. This approach is particularly helpful when working with different environment settings, or simply when you wish to make a large config file more manageable.</p> <p>The final thing to point out is that you don’t have to use TOML for your config files, as I have done in this post. You may prefer to use the YAML or JSON format, both of which are perfectly valid. If, however, you wish to expose your configuration settings to a content management system like Cloudcannon (see <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/hugo-menus-in-cloudcannon/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">How to set up a Hugo menu in Cloudcannon</a> for more on this), then you may, in fact, need to use YAML or JSON, as the TOML format isn’t supported.</p>

item.title: Inserting products into posts
item.content:encoded: <p>There are times when you might wish to insert content from one page into the content of another. This could be any type of content really, but to give you a better idea of what I mean by this, take the project I’m currently working on as an example.</p> <p>In this project, my client wants to be able to insert content from product pages intermittently into the content of blog posts.</p> <p>Here’s how this content is organised in the Hugo project:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-bash" data-lang="bash"><span class="line"><span class="cl">content/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> products/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> product-name.md </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> posts/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> blog-post-one.md </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice I have a content collection (or <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/sections/#article" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Section</a> in Hugo terminology) set up for <em>products</em> and another collection for <em>posts</em>. Each collection contains markdown files which store the content for individual products and posts, respectively.</p> <p>So how would we go about inserting products into posts?</p> <h2 id="shortcodes-and-the-sitegetpage-method">Shortcodes and the <code>.Site.GetPage</code> method</h2> <p>If you’re already thinking <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/shortcodes/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Shortcodes</a> then you’re on the right track.</p> <p>Shortcodes are a useful mechanism in Hugo which allow you to insert templating logic into the content of markdown files, whilst abstracting the complexity of that templating logic, so as not to expose it to content editors.</p> <p>Hugo conveniently also includes the <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/site/getpage/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">.Site.GetPage</a> method, which allows you to get hold of a specific page you pass to it as an argument. This is perfect for inserting page content from a content file stored in one section into the page from another.</p> <p>For <code>.Site.GetPage</code> to function correctly, it requires the logical path of the content to be passed as the argument. That is, the path relative to the content folder minus the file extension. For example:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">with</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">GetPage</span> <span class="s">&#34;/products/love-me-do-light-nourishing-oil&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">do</span> <span class="nx">something</span> <span class="nx">with</span> <span class="nx">page</span> <span class="nx">content</span><span class="o">...</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Here’s what that looks like in my <code>product.html</code> shortcode, which can be found in the <code>layouts/shortcodes</code> folder:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">title</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Get</span> <span class="s">&#34;title&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">page</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Get</span> <span class="s">&#34;path&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">with</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">GetPage</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">page</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h2</span> <span class="nx">class</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;h3&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="nx">with</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">title</span> <span class="p">}}{{</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}{{</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">}}{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="o">...</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice that instead of hard coding the page path as in the previous example, I’m now passing it to the shortcode using the <code>path</code> key, which is stored in a variable. This make the shortcode infinitely more useful.</p> <p>As you can see by how the shortcode is used in a content file, it’s now possible for content editors to pass any content file as the path.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">&lt;</span> <span class="nx">product</span> <span class="nx">title</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Love Me Do Light Nourishing Oil&#34;</span> <span class="nx">path</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;products/love-me-do-light-nourishing-oil&#34;</span> <span class="p">&gt;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p><em><strong>Note</strong>: Hugo will try to render shortcodes even when they’re found within codeblocks, as above. So I’ve left a space between <code>{{</code> and <code>&lt;</code>, and likewise <code>&gt;</code> and <code>}}</code>, simply to prevent Hugo from rendering the shortcode. These spaces should be removed in production use cases.</em></p> <p>This solves our problem, but we can’t expect content editors to manually type out the relative path of a product. At this point we need to consider our CMS configuration.</p> <p>I use <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cloudcannon</a> to allow my client to edit the content on their websites. So the next step is figuring out how to make this shortcode play nice with Cloudcannon. That way content editors will be able to insert pages from one collection into pages in another, without ever touching any code.</p> <h2 id="configuring-cloudcannon">Configuring Cloudcannon</h2> <p>In Cloudcannon, shortcodes are rendered using <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/what-is-a-snippet/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Snippets</a>. Cloudcannon has excellent documentation on how to set up <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/snippets-using-hugo-shortcodes/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Snippets using Hugo Shortcodes</a>, so I won’t cover that in detail here.</p> <p>What I will say is that you need to configure a <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/snippets-using-hugo-shortcodes/#custom-hugo-shortcodes" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Custom Hugo Shortcode</a> using the <code>hugo_shortcode_named_args</code> template for this to work correctly. Then you want to <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/populate-a-select-input/#collections" target="_blank" rel="noopener">populate the options of a select input with pages from a collection</a>.</p> <p>We can do this by adding an <code>_inputs</code> configuration for <code>path</code>, to the shortcode configuration.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nt">_inputs</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">path</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">select</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Choose a product</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Choose a product from the products collection.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">options</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">values</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">collections.products</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>But we’re not quite there yet. Without any further configuration, Cloudcannon will insert the file relative to the site root, including the file extension. For example:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-bash" data-lang="bash"><span class="line"><span class="cl">/content/products/product-name.md </span></span></code></pre></div><p>If you remember, Hugo’s <code>.Site.GetPage</code> method requires that the path is relative to the content folder, rather than to the site root. It’s also necessary to remove the file extension from the path. For example:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-bash" data-lang="bash"><span class="line"><span class="cl">/products/product-name </span></span></code></pre></div><p>So we need to configure how Cloudcannon handles the path. In other words, we need to remove the content folder and file extension from the path.</p> <p>The solution is to add the <code>value_key</code> field to our <code>_input</code> configuration and make sure the value is set to <code>url</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nt">_inputs</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">path</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">select</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Choose a product</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Choose a product from the products collection.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">options</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">values</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">collections.products</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">value_key</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">url</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># Use relative path that the file would appear at once site is built</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now consider the full snippet configuration:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nt">_snippets</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">product</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">template</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">hugo_shortcode_named_args</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">inline</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">false</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">preview</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">text</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Product</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">subtext</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Insert a product from the products collection.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">definitions</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">shortcode_name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">product</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">named_args</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">source_key</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">title</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">editor_key</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">title</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">string</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">editor_key</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">path</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">string</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">_inputs</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">text</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Heading</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Give your product a heading.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">path</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">select</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Choose a product</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Choose a product from the products collection.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">options</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">values</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">collections.products</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">value_key</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">url</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># Use relative path that the file would appear at once site is built</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>With the full configuration in our <code>cloudcannon.config.yml</code> file, content editors can now insert content from product pages found inside the <em>products</em> collection into the body of post pages found in the <em>posts</em> collection.</p> <p>A special thanks to Ryan at Cloudcannon for helping get this final part set up correctly.</p>

item.title: 2025 in Review
item.content:encoded: <p>I spent the final day of 2025 skiing with friends in Leogang, Austria. And what a day we’ve had. Fresh snow, clear blue skies, empty slopes and the best of company.</p> <p>I’m not sure I’ve ever skied at this time of year or celebrated NYE abroad, so it’s been a real treat and the perfect way to wrap up a relatively decent year.</p> <p>Using <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/year-in-review/">the same format as usual</a>, here are my reflections on the past 12 months – what went well, what didn’t go so well and what I learnt in the year twenty twenty five.</p> <h2 id="what-went-well">What went well?</h2> <p>Let’s start with the positives.</p> <h3 id="work">Work</h3> <p>I have a couple of retainer clients that I’ve built a strong relationship with over the years. Thanks, in part, to our work together, their businesses are going from strength to strength and this year was another good year.</p> <p>As freelancer, these are the type of clients I look for. Ongoing work, a motivated team, great communication, invoices paid on time. These clients keep my business afloat, so I’m extremely grateful for their ongoing commitment and trust in me to deliver. If this sounds like your company and you need web design/development help in the new year, then I’d love to hear from you.</p> <p>Outside of client commitments, my focus has been on couple of projects. First is <a href="https://studioeryn.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ERYN</a>, my web development agency website. Which I decided to put more time into to better articulate the services I offer. I plan to launch a v2 of the website in the new year. The second project is <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical Hugo</a>, the Hugo course I’ve been working on for some time now. Following a couple of rewrites, I’m pleased to say that the first season is now ready to go. All that’s left to do is figure out some kind of launch strategy.</p> <h3 id="personal-site-and-newsletter">Personal site and newsletter</h3> <p>I managed to publish 16 posts, all in the first 6 months of the year. The reasons for which will become clear later. I covered a range of stuff, mostly technical writing on subjects like accessibility, the IndieWeb, Obsidian, Cloudcannon, CSS and, of course, Hugo. I also wrote a few posts on health, which I’d like to continue with. I haven’t posted much on the current state of the web, AI and so on. Perhaps I should be more vocal in this respect, but with so many amazing commentators already covering these subjects and so much noise in between, I just haven’t felt the need.</p> <p>A big change I made this year was <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/evolution-of-now-pages/">turning my Now page into a blog</a> so I could post regular updates whilst keeping a record of previous ones. After struggling to find a way to integrate general life updates to my personal site, this has proven to be an ideal solution. With the help of a reminder in my calendar, I’ve managed to publish a monthly update for most of the year. I also joined <a href="https://nownownow.com/p/CQvw" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Nownownow</a> and got some great feedback from <a href="https://sive.rs/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Derek</a> and a few others about the new format of <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/now/">my now page</a>.</p> <p>My newsletter has been ticking along nicely since way back in 2017. It never really grows, but that’s hardly the point. There’s a been a few iterations to the format in that time, but I’m happy with where it’s at and I’ve been fairly disciplined with the schedule. In August <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/now/25-08-05/#what-im-working-on" target="_blank" rel="noopener">I switched from Mailchimp to Brevo</a> and haven’t looked back.</p> <h3 id="ditching-social-media">Ditching social media</h3> <p>I’ve never got on well with social media. After years feeling bad about not having an active presence, it’s been a real relief to see so many others turning their back on some of these platforms.</p> <p>In August I finally got round to deleting my tweets from the Twitter/X accounts I still have access to. <a href="https://cyd.social/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyd</a> made the process super easy. I’ll keep these accounts active to prevent others adopting them, although I suspect that’s unlikely to happen. Facebook and Instagram are up next. Currently I have no plans to switch to Mastodon, Bluesky or any other alternatives. I’m quite happy with zero social media presence. Email is enough for me. And on that note&hellip;</p> <h3 id="connecting-via-email">Connecting via email</h3> <p>One of my favourite things about publishing words on the web is the connections made as a result.</p> <p>This year I’ve had a number of conversations via email with some great people, many of whose work I really admire. Some of these interactions have simply been an exchange of gratitude, others have resulted in sharing ideas and processes via video call and one or two have lead to work or collaborations.</p> <p>Whatever the case, every single conversations has been incredibly positive and encouraging. Reaffirming my belief that you really don’t need social media to make connections and stay connected.</p> <p>Whenever you discover someone online and find their work interesting or helpful, I highly recommend reaching out via email, even if it’s just to say thanks for putting it out there. It’s so easy to do and it’s always massively appreciated. Plus, you never know what door it may open or where it might lead.</p> <h3 id="travel">Travel</h3> <p>I packed quite a bit of travel into 2025, all within Europe.</p> <p>In March I organised <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/now/25-03-15/">another ski trip</a>, once again to La Plagne in France, this time for 15 of us, one or two of who were first-timers. We were blessed with the ultimate conditions: fresh overnight snow and sun during the day. Couldn’t ask for much more. It was brilliant trip.</p> <p>I made two trips to see family in Warwickshire, once over the Easter weekend and again for a few days last week. In keeping with traditional British eccentricity, this time we went to see <a href="https://www.chippingnortontheatre.com/events/beauty-and-the-beast" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Beauty and the Beast at the Pantomime</a> and found a handful of cozy pubs to wind down in. Much to the disapproval of certain family members, we also made it to <a href="https://thefarmersdogpub.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Farmer’s Dog</a>. That’s Jeremy Clarkson’s pub for those of you who haven’t been watching Clarkson’s Farm. The beer is actually surprisingly good!</p> <p>I also spent a good bit of time in Germany this year. Visiting Hamburg on two separate occasions, Kappeln, Bonn and Mainz, for the first time. In November, a bunch of us spent <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/now/25-11-16/">a weekend in Berlin</a>, celebrating the launch of <a href="https://lnk.to/Morpho" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Matt’s new album</a>, which we designed the artwork for.</p> <p>In the summer we met friends in Athens, then spent time on the beach in Agistri and Poros, which has become a real favourite place to relax and make new friends.</p> <p>I’m currently in Anger, a small German town not too far from Salzburg. We’re here seeing in the new year with a friend we made in Cape Town a few years back.</p> <h3 id="health">Health</h3> <p>I ran two half marathons this year. The <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/now/25-06-29/">Hamburg Hella Halbmaraton</a> in June and the <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/now/25-09-15/">Kallithea Half Marathon</a> in September. My goal was to run sub 2hrs, which I managed on a very hot day in Athens with 8 minutes to spare. I also ran seven 5k parkruns across two different parks. Setting a new PB of 21:38 in August. I’m hoping to improve on these times in 2026.</p> <p>I’ve found a steady rhythm with yoga, settling on our local studio, which recently had a refurb and is now a rather nice space to practice. Teachers have come and gone, but I’ve managed to stick with it.</p> <p>My brother and I had a good run with indoor skiing, making the trip up from London to Milton Keynes Snozone on six separate occasions. You never really know what to expect from the snow park until you get there, but it’s currently the best option for wannabe freestyle skiers living nowhere near the mountains. We’ve managed to get the rigmarole of treking across London with ski gear down to a fine art.</p> <p>This year I made a conscious effort to introduce weight training to my morning routine. I’m told I need to lift heavier weights still, but you’ve gotta start somewhere. Perhaps that’s something to work on in the new year.</p> <h3 id="house">House</h3> <p>Two years since our move and we’re still working on renovating our house. I guess that’s to be expected when working full-time and doing the majority of the work yourself.</p> <p>This year our focus has been the kitchen, employing the help and expert knowledge of <a href="https://www.grantsplastering.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Grants Plastering</a> to re-plaster the original Victorian walls with traditional lime plaster. Grant is a top guy and knows a hell of a lot about the correct way to look after historic buildings.</p> <p>After 6 months of drying time, we took on the challenge of decorating ourselves, using breathable <a href="https://earthbornpaints.co.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Earthborn Paints</a>. R had the great idea of using a spray gun to paint the cabinets, which turned out to be a ton of fun and much quicker than using a brush. One leak and a broken boiler later, we can finally see light at the end of the tunnel. It hasn’t been the cheapest project ever, but we’ve learnt a lot and hopefully it will be well worth the investment.</p> <p>Next up is laying new flooring in the office.</p> <h3 id="learning">Learning</h3> <p>I prioritised learning in 2025 and managed to work through three courses.</p> <p>The first was Andy Bell’s <a href="https://piccalil.li/complete-css/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Complete CSS</a>, which I highly recommend if you want to learn how to communicate with designers, plan projects and use a methodology to improve the way you write CSS.</p> <p>The second was Compound Content from <a href="https://visualizevalue.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Visualize Value</a>, a practical SEO course that teaches how to harness the power of organic traffic to sell your products or services. I learnt a lot.</p> <p>The third was Jack McDade’s <a href="https://radicaldesigncourse.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Radical Design Course</a> which I enjoyed for Jack’s unique style and approach to design projects. Unfortunately I didn’t manage to finish it as work got busy. Perhaps I’ll pick up where I left off in the new year.</p> <p>I grabbed four more courses during Black Friday sales, which I’m excited to get going with in 2026:</p> <ul> <li>Sarah Soueidan’s <a href="https://practical-accessibility.today/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical Accessibility</a>.</li> <li><a href="https://csswizardry.gumroad.com/l/eihdtmcwf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Everything I Have Done to Make CSS Wizardry Fast</a> from Harry Roberts.</li> <li>Scott Jehl’s <a href="https://scottjehl.com/learn/webcomponentsdemystified/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Web components Demystified</a>.</li> <li><a href="https://lets-go.alexedwards.net/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Let’s Go</a> from Alex Edwards.</li> </ul> <p>Let’s see how it goes.</p> <h3 id="reading">Reading</h3> <p>I read <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/reading/#2025" target="_blank" rel="noopener">16 books this year</a> which isn’t too bad by my standards. I tried to keep my interests broad, reading books on Web Accessibility, Ethics, Economics, Finance, Sci-Fi or History. And my mind open, by reading about certain esoteric/fringe topics, such as out of body experiences, zero point energy and UFO’s, which fascinate me.</p> <p>I also read countless articles, mostly concerning design, web development and the current state of tech. Cory Doctorow’s work on <a href="https://pluralistic.net/tag/enshittification/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Enshitification and the post-American internet</a> and Ed Zitron’s work on the <a href="https://www.wheresyoured.at/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AI bubble</a> probably being the most stand out stuff I read. I also enjoyed posts published by the brilliant <a href="https://www.404media.co/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">404 media</a>, and <a href="https://kottke.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Jason Kottke</a>, who never fails to share an endless stream of interesting content.</p> <h2 id="what-didnt-go-so-well">What didn’t go so well?</h2> <p>As ever, some things didn’t go quite so well this year. Here are a few of the things that spring to mind.</p> <h3 id="work-1">Work</h3> <p>Had a bit of a howler with some of my project-based client projects.</p> <p>A couple of clients ghosted, one had their business go under, another I had to let go due to problems with paying invoices and a lack of alignment. I didn’t win much new business, though I didn’t exactly try hard to find it. Much of that was due to focusing on projects with retainer clients and personal side projects.</p> <p>I plan on assessing and hopefully clarifying my offering in the new year. Then dedicating more time to sales and marketing, and solving the pitfalls in my client qualifying process.</p> <h3 id="blogging">Blogging</h3> <p>Blogging on my personal site took a back seat from the summer onwards. As much as I wanted to write, I realised I had to prioritise writing content for <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical Hugo</a> if I ever wanted to get it out there. In that sense it’s paid off.</p> <p>Now I need to figuring out how best to resume writing here on my personal site, whilst also writing Season 2 of Practical Hugo. It’s not going to be easy, but I’m sure as hell up for the challenge.</p> <h3 id="meditation">Meditation</h3> <p>2025 was an inconsistent year for meditation. I started the year well, then tailed off as the year progressed. In November and December I didn’t meditate at all. I’m blaming that on a disrupted routine mostly caused by renovation work on our kitchen.</p> <p>I still find meditation really valuable when I actually do it, so I’d like to find a way to keep it going even when my morning routine is affected. Although that’s easier said than done when life gets busy and priorities shift.</p> <h3 id="de-googling">De-googling</h3> <p>I’ve done a good bit of work to reduce <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/de-googling/">my dependencies on Google</a> in recent years. However this year, Docs, Sheets and Drive have all crept back into my workflow.</p> <p>I’ve been using Docs mostly for discovery documents I share with clients, for the simple reason that it’s great for collaboration and most people know how to use it. I’ve started using Sheets for budgeting and project time tracking. I also used it in a client project, to <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/generate-pages-from-google-sheets/">generate web pages from Sheets data</a>, which an SEO agency my client partnered with had prepared. Google Drive, of course, is kinda unavoidable when you’re working with either Docs and Sheets.</p> <p>Until I can find better alternatives, it looks like I’m stuck with these tools for now. I’m fairly strict with my criteria for when I will allow myself to use them, so I’m hoping this will help kerb any serious dependencies, that may prove difficult to unpick at some point further down the line.</p> <h2 id="what-did-i-learn">What did I learn?</h2> <p>In no particular order, here are a few things I learned this year:</p> <ul> <li>Change happens quietly.</li> <li>Slow progress is still progress.</li> <li>Buy less new and more using Vinted.</li> <li>Focus comes from refining and letting go.</li> <li>Double the time you think it’s going to take, unless you already know how long it takes.</li> <li>Use a spray gun to paint woodwork, it’s 10x faster and the finish is much better.</li> <li>Avoid most “smart” tech.</li> <li>Stop trying to do something original and copy what’s already working.</li> <li>Lift heavier weights.</li> </ul> <h2 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping up</h2> <p>There’s plenty of reasons to feel uncertain and despondent right now. Be it recent world events, the enshitification of what feels like everything, the whole AI bubble thing, the lack of a Chelsea manager&hellip;the list goes on.</p> <p>In spite of all this, for me personally, it’s still been a fairly positive year. Not necessarily my most successful year financially. But certainly one in which I travelled a lot, stayed relatively healthy, found focus with side projects, made slow steady progress with client work, let go of things that were holding me back and gained a little more clarity over what I’m actually doing with my life.</p> <p>So I’m ending the year feeling fit, happy, positive and full of gratitude. I have a rough plan for where I’ll focus my energy in 2026 and that, I think, given everything else that’s going on in the world, is more than I can ask for.</p>

item.title: Hugo Version Manager
item.content:encoded: <p>If your site uses an old version of Hugo and you’re happy with the features it offers, then you can happily stick with it as long as you like. Hugo will continue to work without any issues. This is one of the many great things about working with Hugo. There’s no real need to upgrade your version, that is, unless you want to.</p> <p>If you do want the latest features, however, then you’ll need to upgrade Hugo to the latest version. In the past, <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/upgrading-hugo-warnings-breaking-changes/">upgrading Hugo</a> was a global affair. Update the Hugo binary and your version of Hugo updates everywhere, in every project. Although the process was fairly straight forward, it often meant <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/breaking-changes-upgrading-hugo/">fixing breaking changes</a> by working through each of your projects, one by one. Personally, I never experienced any major issues when upgrading Hugo, but the process always took some time.</p> <p>I now run and manage ~20 Hugo websites. And, that doesn’t include the various tools and demo projects that I’ve also built with Hugo. With every new site I create, the thought of upgrading becomes that little bit more daunting. And, process of upgrading Hugo becomes that little bit more time consuming.</p> <p>The good news is that these issues have now been resolved. Thanks to long-time Hugo contributor Joe Mooring, we now have a fantastic little command line interface (CLI) tool called <a href="https://github.com/jmooring/hvm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo Version Manager</a>.</p> <p>Similar to other versions managers, <code>hvm</code> allows you to download and manage multiple versions of Hugo and switch between them on a project-by-project basis. If you manage any more than a handful of Hugo sites, then this is extremely helpful. It means you can continue to use old versions of Hugo in older projects, whilst using newer versions in newer projects. No further need to worry about what might break when you upgrade Hugo.</p> <p>Once <code>hvm</code> is installed and configured, all it takes is a <code>.hvm</code> file containing the version number you wish to use in the root of your project. Run the <code>hugo</code> command and Hugo will install and use that version in that particular project.</p> <p>If you need a hand getting <code>hvm</code> set up and working on your machine, then I highly recommend reading <a href="https://navendu.me/posts/hugo-version-manager/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Using Hugo Version Manager (hvm) to Switch Between Different Hugo Versions</a> by Navendu Pottekkat.</p>

item.title: Animating native Lazy Loading (as a progressive enhancement)
item.content:encoded: <p>Native lazy loading is well supported across all major browsers and has been since December 2023. This means there’s no longer any need to use third-party JavaScript plugins to defer non-critical resources from loading until they reach the viewport. Just slap the <code>loading=&quot;lazy&quot;</code> attribute onto images and iframes, and your browser will take care of the rest.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> <span class="na">loading</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;lazy&#34;</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image.jpg&#34;</span> <span class="na">alt</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">iframe</span> <span class="na">loading</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;lazy&#34;</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;video-player.html&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">iframe</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>With one less third-party script, we have one less potential point of failure. We’ve simplified our codebase and created a more resilient website. What’s not to like about that?</p> <p>There are, of course, a ton of performance benefits to lazy loading, but we won’t get into those today. Instead, I want to talk about a subtle feature missing from native lazy loading. And that’s those buttery smooth fade-in animations you’d tend to get with certain third-party scripts. My personal favourite being the once invaluable <a href="https://github.com/aFarkas/lazysizes" target="_blank" rel="noopener">lazysizes</a> from Alexander Farkas.</p> <h2 id="animated-fade-in-how-it-works">Animated fade-in, how it works</h2> <p>Typically these type of fade-in effects are handled by a few lines of CSS and a little DOM manipulation. The trick is a simple one. Hide the the element by default, then add a <code>lazyloaded</code> class via JavaScript when the resource is ready to load.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-css" data-lang="css"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">lazyload</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">opacity</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">lazyloaded</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">opacity</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">transition</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="k">opacity</span> <span class="mi">300</span><span class="kt">ms</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Unfortunately, there’s no default fade-in when using native lazy loading. But it’s easy to implement a similar effect without reaching for any third-party plugins. There is, however, a right way and a wrong way to go about it.</p> <h2 id="make-it-work-with-html-first-aka-progressive-enhancement">Make it work with HTML first (a.k.a progressive enhancement)</h2> <p>The important thing to remember is to provide an acceptable baseline experience for every website visitor, regardless of their device, internet connection or browser preferences. The best way to achieve that is to consider the effect as a <a href="https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/using-progressive-enhancement" target="_blank" rel="noopener">progressive enhancement</a>, instead of the default experience, and not something that depends on JavaScript. So what does that look like?</p> <p><a href="https://www.kryogenix.org/code/browser/everyonehasjs.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">When JavaScript fails</a>, as <a href="https://piccalil.li/blog/a-handful-of-reasons-javascript-wont-be-available/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">it often does</a>, resources should load as normal, without a fade-in effect if necessary. Ultimately, they shouldn’t be hidden because JavaScript is unable to apply a class that changes the opacity. When JavaScript is functional and circumstances allow for it, then and <em>only</em> then should the fade-in take effect.</p> <p>With this approach, all bases are covered. Everything functions with HTML-only and none of our resources are dependent on JavaScript to load.</p> <p>Ok. So how do we build this sort of thing? To make it happen we can use the Intersection Observer API along with a simple technique know as <em>cutting the mustard</em>.</p> <h2 id="cutting-the-mustard">Cutting the mustard</h2> <p><a href="https://responsivenews.co.uk/post/18948466399/cutting-the-mustard" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cutting the mustard</a> is a simple trick, made popular by the BBC, that can be used to check if a browser is able to offer a modern JavaScript experience.</p> <p>There are a few different methods, but the one I like most I learned from <a href="https://www.matuzo.at/blog/html-boilerplate/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Manuel Matuzović</a>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c">&lt;!-- See https://www.matuzo.at/blog/html-boilerplate/ --&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">script</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;module&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">documentElement</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">remove</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;no-js&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">documentElement</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;js&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">script</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>It works by adding a simple script to the <code>&lt;head&gt;</code> of your HTML documents. If the browser supports JavaScript modules (and thus other modern JS), then a class called <code>.no-js</code> is removed from HTML element and a<code>.js</code> class is added in its place.</p> <p>Now we’re in a position to write Javascript and CSS that only applies <em>if</em> the <code>.js</code> class is present on the document.</p> <h2 id="write-your-state-based-styles">Write your state-based styles</h2> <p>I’m using the same styles used by <a href="https://github.com/aFarkas/lazysizes" target="_blank" rel="noopener">lazysizes.js</a> out of habit and familiarity.</p> <p>The <code>.lazyload</code> class can be applied to any <code>&lt;img&gt;</code> or <code>&lt;iframe&gt;</code> elements you wish to hide.
