Once we’ve written our JavaScript, the <code>.lazyloaded</code> class will replace the <code>.lazyload</code> class, revealing the element.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-css" data-lang="css"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c">/* Animate the lazyloading if JavaScript is enabed and .js class has been added to the HTML document */</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">js</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">.lazyload</span> <span class="err">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">opacity</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">lazyloaded</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">opacity</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">transition</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="k">opacity</span> <span class="mi">300</span><span class="kt">ms</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="err">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You’ll notice the only difference is that our styles are nested within the <code>.js</code> class. We’re doing this so that our styles will only apply if our <em>cutting the mustard</em> script runs and adds the <code>.js</code> class to the HTML document. If this happens, we know that the browser is in a position to parse modern JavaScript and therefore it’s acceptable to hide the elements we want to <em>lazyload</em> using <code>opacity: 0</code>.</p> <p>Of course, if the <code>.js</code> class isn’t applied to the document, because JavaScript isn’t functional, then any element with the <code>.lazyload</code> class applied will be unaffected by these styles and therefore remain visible.</p> <p>With that we have an acceptable experience for both JavaScript enabled and non-JavaScript enabled browsers.</p> <p>Before we move on, let’s not forget to add the <code>lazyload</code> class to any non-critical elements that we want the brower to lazyload:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;lazyload&#34;</span> <span class="na">loading</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;lazy&#34;</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image.jpg&#34;</span> <span class="na">alt</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">iframe</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;lazyload&#34;</span> <span class="na">loading</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;lazy&#34;</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;video-player.html&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">iframe</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="apply-class-when-resources-hit-the-viewport">Apply class when resources hit the viewport</h2> <p>Now we have our <em>cutting the mustard</em> script and styles in place, the final step is to write the JavaScript which removes the <code>.lazyload</code> class and adds the <code>.lazyloaded</code> class, so that elements fade in.</p> <p>Something else we need to consider is when we actually want elements to fade in. Given that we want this effect to apply to lazy loaded resources, it makes sense that resources should fade in as they hit the viewport and are loaded by the browser.</p> <p>This we can do with JavaScript’s <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Intersection_Observer_API" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Intersection Observer API</a>.</p> <p>The first thing to do is grab any <code>&lt;img&gt;</code> or <code>&lt;iframe&gt;</code> elements found in the document.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-js" data-lang="js"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">imgs</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelectorAll</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;img&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">iframes</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelectorAll</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;iframe&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next, we’ll create a new observer to detect when these elements intersect with the viewport. Our intersection observer takes two arguments; a callback function and some options.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-js" data-lang="js"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// Element observer </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">elObserver</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="k">new</span> <span class="nx">IntersectionObserver</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">elObserverCallback</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">elObserverOptions</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Let’s tackle the callback function next.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-js" data-lang="js"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// Callback function </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">elObserverCallback</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">elToWatch</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">elObserver</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// For each element to watch, grab element to watch </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elToWatch</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">forEach</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">elToWatch</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// If the element is intersecting </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="k">if</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">elToWatch</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">isIntersecting</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Remove lazyload class </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elToWatch</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">target</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">remove</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;lazyload&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Add lazyloaded class </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elToWatch</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">target</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;lazyloaded&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Stop watching element when in viewport </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elObserver</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">unobserve</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">elToWatch</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">target</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">})</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>First we pass in the elements we want to watch; <code>elToWatch</code>, then the action we want to perform, the element observer; <code>elObserver</code>. For each element in the document, we want to grab that element then do something. We can do this using a foreach statement. Inside our statement, we’ll check if our element is intersecting the viewport. If this returns true, then we’ll remove our <code>lazyload</code> class and add our <code>lazyloaded</code> class instead. Finally, when all that’s done, we stop watching the element using the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IntersectionObserver/unobserve" target="_blank" rel="noopener">unobserve</a> method.</p> <p>Now let’s run the card observer on our elements.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-js" data-lang="js"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// Run observer on images </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="nx">imgs</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">forEach</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">img</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Call intersection observer and observe image </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elObserver</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">observe</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">img</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">});</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// Run observer on iframes </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="nx">iframes</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">forEach</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">iframe</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Call intersection observer and observe iframe </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elObserver</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">observe</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">iframe</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">});</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>We’ll need to create a forEach statement to loop through all elements. Then for each element, we call our intersection observer, <code>elObserver</code>, and observe the element using the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IntersectionObserver/observe" target="_blank" rel="noopener">observe</a> method. We’ll need to do this for both our <code>&lt;image&gt;</code> and <code>&lt;iframe&gt;</code> elements.</p> <p>Finally, let’s add our options, which we passed in to our intersection observer earlier as as the second argument.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-js" data-lang="js"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// Element options </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">elObserverOptions</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Fade in when 25% of element is in view </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">threshold</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="mi">25</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Here we’re using <code>threshold</code> to delay the <code>lazyloaded</code> class from being applied until 25% of the element is in view. That way, the fade effect will be nice and obvious for anyone viewing our website.</p> <p>And here’s our complete code.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-js" data-lang="js"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">imgs</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelectorAll</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;img&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">iframes</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelectorAll</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;iframe&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// Callback function </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">elObserverCallback</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">elToWatch</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">elObserver</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// For each element to watch, grab element to watch </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elToWatch</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">forEach</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">elToWatch</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// If the element is intersecting </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="k">if</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">elToWatch</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">isIntersecting</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Remove lazyload class </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elToWatch</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">target</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">remove</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;lazyload&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Add lazyloaded class </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elToWatch</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">target</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;lazyloaded&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Stop watching element when in viewport </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elObserver</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">unobserve</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">elToWatch</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">target</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">})</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// Element options </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">elObserverOptions</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Fade in when 25% of element is in view </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">threshold</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="mi">25</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// Element observer </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">elObserver</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="k">new</span> <span class="nx">IntersectionObserver</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">elObserverCallback</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">elObserverOptions</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// Run observer on images </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="nx">imgs</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">forEach</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">img</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Call intersection observer and observe image </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elObserver</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">observe</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">img</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">});</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// Run observer on iframes </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="nx">iframes</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">forEach</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">iframe</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Call intersection observer and observe iframe </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elObserver</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">observe</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">iframe</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">});</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>And, that’s it!</p> <h2 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping up</h2> <p>We now have a solution to animate native lazy loaded resources with a simple fade-in effect. We’ve provided an acceptable baseline experience (visible resources) for browsers without JavaScript capabilities and used progressive enhancement to show our effect only when JavaScript is available.</p> <p>To see the various techniques used in this post in action, make sure you check out <a href="https://elegant-bublanina-3b0aae.netlify.app/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the demo project</a>. Don’t forget to disable JavaScript in your browser Inspect settings to see how resources behave without JavaScript capabilities. You can also find all the code from this post over on <a href="https://github.com/harrycresswell/animating-native-lazy-loading" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GitHub</a>.</p> <p>To learn more about working with the Intersection Observer API, I highly recommend watching Chris Pennington’s excellent video <a href="https://youtu.be/sRrNgeXBHBA?si=gE7joxbVZK8Fyted" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Fade Images on Scroll with JavaScript</a> from his YouTube channel, Coding in Public.</p>

item.title: How to set up a Hugo menu in Cloudcannon
item.content:encoded: <p>There are <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/menus-in-hugo/">various ways to create menus in Hugo</a>. But, in most cases, Cloudcannon won’t automatically detect these menus and make them editable in its interface.</p> <p>I can understand why this decision may have been made. Cloudcannon supports a bunch of static site generators (not just Hugo), each, I assume, with its own opinions on how menus should function. It’s my guess that creating a “one size fits all” approach for managing menus isn’t an easy problem to solve.</p> <p>Whatever the actual reasons may be, this doesn’t change that fact that clients usually want the ability to update menu items from within their CMS. So we need a solution that makes it possible to edit menus from Cloudcannon.</p> <h2 id="assess-the-options">Assess the options</h2> <p>A popular way to create menus in Hugo is to set them up directly in the site configuration file - <code>config.toml</code> or <code>hugo.toml</code><sup id="fnref:1"><a href="#fn:1" class="footnote-ref" role="doc-noteref">1</a></sup>. This is usually what I do for simple sites, like my own.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">baseurl</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;https://harrycresswell.com/&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">languageCode</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;en-gb&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">title</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Harry Cresswell&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Index&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;/&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">5</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Writing&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;/writing/&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Links&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;/links/&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">15</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Topics&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;/topics/&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>With a set up like this, the most obvious option would be to expose the entire config file to Cloudcannon. But that might not be the best idea.</p> <p>Config files tend to contain settings you wouldn’t want content editors to have access to. The site <em>title</em>, <em>languageCode</em> and <em>permalinks</em> all being good examples. Additionally, although you can create Hugo configuration files in TOML, YAML or JSON, Cloudcannon only supports YAML and JSON. So if your config file is TOML, you may find that you run into issues.</p> <p>Ok, so if the config file option is off the table, then what else could we do?</p> <p>An alternative option is to move your menu configuration to a data file. Then you could expose it in Cloudcannon, in the <em>Site Navigation</em>, as a data <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/what-is-a-collection/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Collection</a> .</p> <p>In theory, this sounds like a good idea, but there’s a serious issue with this approach.</p> <p>Using the <code>.Data</code> object to store a menu config means we can’t then make use of Hugo’s powerful menu functionality. <code>.Site.Menus</code> becomes something like <code>.Data.menus.somemenu</code>. And we no longer have access to methods – like <code>.Children</code>, <code>.Name</code>, <code>.Identifier</code>, <code>.Params</code> – which are only available to the <code>.Menus</code> object. This is a problem.</p> <p>So what’s should we be doing instead?</p> <h2 id="use-the-config-directory-for-your-menus">Use the config directory for your menus</h2> <p>The simple solution I’ve found is to move menus to a <a href="https://gohugo.io/configuration/introduction/#configuration-directory" target="_blank" rel="noopener">configuration directory</a>, which is typically used in Hugo projects to organise larger configurations.</p> <p>This approach involves creating a <code>config</code> folder at the root of the project, adding a <code>_default</code> folder within it, setting up a <code>menus</code> folder within that, then adding your menu YAML files.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-text" data-lang="text"><span class="line"><span class="cl">my-project/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">└── config/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> ├── _default/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> │ ├── hugo.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> │ ├── menus/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> │ │ ├── menus.en.yaml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> │ │ └── menus.de.yaml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> │ └── params.toml </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> └── production/ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> └── params.toml </span></span></code></pre></div><p>A side benefit of the config folder approach is that it’s nice and easy to create different menu translations for multilingual sites. Notice the <code>.en</code> and <code>.de</code> extensions in the file name for English and Deutsch, respectively.</p> <p>When authoring the menu file itself, there are two important things to remember.</p> <ol> <li>Cloudcannon doesn’t recognise TOML, so ensure menus are created in YAML.</li> <li>Make sure you <a href="https://gohugo.io/configuration/introduction/#omit-the-root-key" target="_blank" rel="noopener">omit the root key</a> from the file, as Hugo takes this from the file name when using a configuration directory.</li> </ol> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nt">main</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Index&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="m">5</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Writing&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;/writing/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="m">10</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Links&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;/links/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="m">15</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Topics&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;/topics/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="m">20</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>With the menu set up in your Hugo project, the next step is to make the menu editable for content editors. To do this we need to expose it to the Cloudcannon interface.</p> <h2 id="create-a-menu-collection-in-cloudcannon">Create a menu collection in Cloudcannon</h2> <p>As we identified earlier, it probably makes the most sense to add menus as a data <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/what-is-a-collection/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Collection</a>. That way, they’re easy to access from the sidebar site navigation in Cloudcannon. But before we do that, first we have to tell Cloudcannon about any menus we might have and where to find them.</p> <p>Inside your <code>cloudcannon.config.yaml</code> file, add <code>collections_config</code> if it doesn’t already exist. Then set up a <code>menus</code> key and include the <code>path</code> to your menus folder, relative to the root of your Hugo project.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nt">collections_config</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">menus</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># Accepts Google icon keys as value</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">icon</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">menu</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># Folder where the files in this collection are stored</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">path</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">config/_default/menus</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># Disable add buttons to prevent creation of files or folders</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">disable_add</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">disable_add_folder</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>Pay close attention to indentation, as this is important for Cloudcannon to understand your configuration. Notice we’ve also set <code>disable_add</code> and <code>disable_add_folder</code> as <em>true</em>. This will prevent content editors from being able to create new menus <em>and</em> new folders, within the menus collection.</p> <p>With that, Cloudcannon is aware of our menu and knows where to find it.</p> <h2 id="adding-your-menu-to-the-site">Adding your menu to the site</h2> <p>The next thing to do is to <a href="https://non-unified.cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/configure-your-site-navigation/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">configure your site navigation</a> so Cloudcannon displays your menus and they’re easy to find.</p> <p>My preference is to display menus under the Data section in the <em>Site Navigation</em>. We can do this by setting up <code>collection_groups</code> (if it doesn’t exist already), then adding the <code>menus</code> collection we configured earlier under the Data heading.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nt">collection_groups</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">heading</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Collections</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">collections</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="l">writing</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="l">pages</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">heading</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Data</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">collections</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="l">menus</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>With the above configuration in place, Cloudcannon will discover your menus and display an item called <em>Menus</em> in the site navigation that links to your menus.</p> <h2 id="customising-menu-item-array-inputs">Customising menu item array inputs</h2> <p>In your Cloudcannon site, click on <em>Menus</em> in the site navigation, then click on your Menu file to open your menu. The data view will open and you will see your menu items.</p> <p>Cloudcannon has used the format of the existing menu to correctly determine that it’s an <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/array-inputs/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">array input</a>. In other words, a list of <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/what-are-inputs/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">inputs</a>. Without describing these inputs Cloudcannon does it’s best to correctly render the fields it finds. In my case, those fields are <code>name</code>, <code>url</code> and <code>weight</code> - the three keys that currently make up each menu item.</p> <p>As the creator of the website, there’s a high chance you’re familiar with these terms and what they refer to, but you can’t expect content editors to have the same level of understanding. With this in mind, it makes sense to configure collection specific <code>_inputs</code> under your <em>menus</em> <code>collection_config</code>, which describe each input <em>type</em> and its intended purpose. We can do this by adding the name of the input, then using the the <code>type</code> and <code>comment</code> keys, respectively. In a Cloudcannon config, <code>type</code> determines how the interface is structured for the input and <code>comment</code> adds a visible text description beneath the input name in the interface.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nt">collections_config</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">menus</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># Accepts Google icon keys as value</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">icon</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">menu</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># Folder where the files in this collection are stored</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">path</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">config/_default/menus</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># Disable add buttons to prevent creation of files or folders</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">disable_add</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">disable_add_folder</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># custom inputs only associated with this collection</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">_inputs</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># _inputs found within each menu item array</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">text</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Add the name of the menu item.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">url</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">URL that this menu item should link to.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Order</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">number</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Order menu item should appear in the menu.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now each input type has been explained, we need to give Cloudcannon a template of sorts, so it knows how to populate the array, whenever a new menu item is added.</p> <h2 id="tell-cloudcannon-how-to-populate-new-menu-item-array-inputs">Tell Cloudcannon how to populate new menu item array inputs</h2> <p>This part isn’t essential, as Cloudcannon will always fallback to using the previous entry to populate new array items. But it will give you more control, as we’ll find out later when we look at how to add submenus.</p> <p>As per the Cloudcannon docs: ”A <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/array-inputs/#structured-arrays" target="_blank" rel="noopener">structured array</a> allows your team to select a predefined template to populate the inputs.” So the next step is to create a structured array.</p> <p>To do this, add a new key under the <code>_inputs</code> key that matches the name of your menu in your Hugo config. My menu is called <code>main</code>, so that’s the key I’m using.</p> <p>Next add <code>type: array</code> and another key called <code>options</code> one tab indentation in. Make another indentation underneath <code>options</code> and add a key called <code>structures</code>. The value for this key needs to be <code>_structures</code> followed by <code>.</code>, then your menu name. In my case, <code>_structures.main</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nt">collections_config</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">menus</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># Accepts Google icon keys as value</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">icon</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">menu</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># Folder where the files in this collection are stored</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">path</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">config/_default/menus</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># Disable add buttons to prevent creation of files or folders</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">disable_add</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">disable_add_folder</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># custom inputs only associated with this collection</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">_inputs</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># _inputs found within each menu item array</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">text</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Add the name of the menu item.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">url</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">URL that this menu item should link to.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Order</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">number</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Order menu item should appear in the menu.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">main</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">array</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">The main menu found at the very top of the site.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">options</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># Reference the array item in _structures.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">structures</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">_structures.main</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>What we’re doing here is referencing a <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/what-is-a-structure/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">structure</a> (a template) used to determine how our menu array should be populated. We haven’t defined it yet so we’ll need to do that next.</p> <p>Structures are defined underneath the <code>_structures</code> key and can be defined at any level of the <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/using-the-configuration-cascade/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">configuration cascade</a>. Here I’ve defined a structure for my <code>main</code> menu at the <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/structures-in-the-configuration-cascade/#define-a-structure-at-the-collection-level" target="_blank" rel="noopener">collection level</a>. This makes sense as this structure is only used by my menus collection.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span
