class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="m">5</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Writing&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;/writing/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="m">10</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Links&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;/links/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="m">15</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Topics&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;/topics/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="m">20</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Cloudcannon&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">parent</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Topics&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;/topics/cloudcannon/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="m">5</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>Assuming you have a menu set up similar to this in your templates, then there are a few extra steps we can take to offer an acceptable editing experience in Cloudcannon.</p> <p>First, we’ll add a new key called <code>submenu</code> to any child items. This will be a boolean (true/false) with a value of <code>true</code>. This has no impact in respect of Hugo, but will give us more control over the editing interface in Cloudcannon.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nt">main</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Index&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="m">5</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Writing&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;/writing/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="m">10</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Links&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;/links/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="m">15</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Topics&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;/topics/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="m">20</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Cloudcannon&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">submenu</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">parent</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Topics&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;/topics/cloudcannon/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="m">5</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>The next step is to add two new <code>_inputs</code> to our <code>cloudcannon.config.yaml</code> file. These inputs describe <code>submenu</code> and <code>parent</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nt">collections_config</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">menus</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># Accepts Google icon keys as value</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">icon</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">menu</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># Folder where the files in this collection are stored</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">path</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">config/_default/menus</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># Disable add buttons to prevent creation of files or folders</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">disable_add</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">disable_add_folder</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># custom inputs only associated with this collection</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">_inputs</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># _inputs found within each menu item array</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">text</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Add the name of the menu item.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">submenu</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Is submenu item</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">switch</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Enable if menu item is part of a submenu.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">parent</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">text</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Parent menu item that submenu is a descendant of.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># If submenu switch is enabled, then show this hidden field.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">hidden</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s1">&#39;!submenu&#39;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">url</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">URL that this menu item should link to.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Order</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">number</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Order menu item should appear in the menu.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">main</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">array</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">comment</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">The main menu found at the very top of the site.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">options</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># Reference the array item in _structures.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">structures</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">_structures.main</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>Before me move on, there are a couple of things to note here.</p> <p><em>Submenu</em> has been given the type <code>switch</code>, so that the input appears as a switch-style checkbox in the editor. With this in place, any menu items in the configuration that have <code>submenu: true</code> will show an enabled switch in Cloudcannon. And, content editors will need to enable this switch for any new items they add which are part of a submenu.</p> <p><em>Parent</em> is a text input, and should be configured in Cloudcannon by typing the name of the parent menu item, just as we did in our menu configuration file in Hugo. You’ll see we’ve added <code>hidden: '!submenu'</code> to hide this input unless the <em>submenu</em> switch is enabled. This is a simple way to keep the editor clear of extra inputs until they are required.</p> <p>Now we’ve explained our inputs, Cloudcannon will render them in the editor correctly.</p> <p>The final step is to update our menu structure to include <code>submenu</code> and <code>parent</code>. I’ve added these just below <code>name</code>, as this is the order I want them to appear in the array whenever a new menu item is added.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c"># STRUCTURES</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">_structures</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="c"># See _structures.main in menus specific _inputs</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">main</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">values</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">value</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">submenu</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">parent</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">weight</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now, whenever new items are added to a menu in the Cloudcannon editor, the template used to populate the array will include our new <em>submenu</em> switch and the <em>parent</em> field. But, the <em>parent</em> input will remain hidden until the <em>submenu</em> switch is enabled by whoever is editing content.</p> <h2 id="final-thoughts">Final thoughts</h2> <p>As we’ve seen, there’s nothing too complicated about getting Hugo menus to play nice with Cloudcannon. Though, certain approaches are more suitable than others.</p> <p>In my experience, Config directory menus seem to be the way to go. They definitely provide the most flexibility, especially if you plan on working with the <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/menu-entry/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">methods available to the Menu object</a>. Just remember to author your menu files in YAML so Cloudcannon can understand them.</p> <p>That‘s all I know about setting up Hugo menus in Cloudcannon. If you have any of your own experiences that you’d like to share, then drop me an email, it would be great to hear from you.</p> <div class="footnotes" role="doc-endnotes"> <hr> <ol> <li id="fn:1"> <p><code>config.toml</code> and <code>hugo.toml</code> are two different names for the same configuration file. The latter is the name used in later Hugo versions.&#160;<a href="#fnref:1" class="footnote-backref" role="doc-backlink">&#x21a9;&#xfe0e;</a></p> </li> </ol> </div>

item.title: Subscribe to RSS feeds by topic
item.content:encoded: <p>I assume not everyone wants to read everything I write about (I certainly wouldn’t blame you for that). Personally, whenever I subscribe to someones content via RSS, it’s often because I’m interested in a specific topic they write about.</p> <p>With this in mind, I’ve listed feeds for each topic I write about over on my <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/feeds/">feeds</a> page. So you now have the option of only subscribing to the topics that interest you. No more clogging your RSS reader with the stuff I write that doesn’t interest you.</p> <p>Hugo generates RSS feeds for each taxonomy automatically, so getting this to work is much easier than you might think.</p> <h2 id="creating-a-shortcode-that-loops-through-taxonomies">Creating a shortcode that loops through taxonomies</h2> <p>The solution I went with was to create a simple shortcode file in the <code>/shortcodes</code> directory called <code>topic-feeds.html</code> with the following code inside:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range .Site.Taxonomies.topics }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Page.Permalink }}/feed.xml&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .Page.Title }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This loops through each topic, displays the topic name which is linked to the corresponding RSS feed. Perhaps there’s a more elegant way to handle this, but it works well enough for now.</p> <h2 id="including-the-shortcode-on-the-feeds-page">Including the shortcode on the /feeds page</h2> <p>The final step was to include the shortcode in my <code>feeds.md</code> file.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-markdown" data-lang="markdown"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="gu">## Topic feeds </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="gu"></span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">If you’re only interested in certain [<span class="nt">topics</span>](<span class="na">/topics/</span>) I write about, then subscribe to those feeds and only receive posts on those topics. </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">/* Note: Remove square brackets for valid shortcode syntax, these prevent the shortcode from rendering for the purposes of this demo. */ </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{[<span class="p">&lt;</span> <span class="nt">topic-feeds</span> <span class="p">&gt;</span>]}} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>And, that’s that! You can now <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/feeds/#topic-feeds">subscribe to my content by topic</a>.</p> <p>There’s a couple of other things too&hellip;</p> <h2 id="a-few-updates-to-the-names-of-topics">A few updates to the names of topics</h2> <p>Whilst I was at it, I’ve made some subtle changes to how content on my site is organised. Apologies if this has caused mayhem in your RSS reader.</p> <p>So what’s changed exactly?</p> <p>Firstly, the topic once called ”Hugo course” is now <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/topics/side-projects/">side projects</a>. I have <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/things/">a few different side projects</a> on the go right now, so this felt like a sensible move. Any side project related posts can now be found here.</p> <p>Secondly, the topic once called ”Daily” is now called [/topics/updates/]. I was struggling with the name <em>Daily</em>, mainly because the frequency of these posts are far from a daily. I also want to try and get back into posting short-form updates about what I’m currently working on and what’s changed on this site (like this one). So “Updates” feels like a much clearer name for content of this nature.</p>

item.title: CSS Naked Day
item.content:encoded: <p>The 9th April is <a href="https://css-naked-day.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CSS Naked Day</a> which is all about promoting <a href="https://www.w3.org/standards/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">web standards</a>.</p> <p>The idea is that for one whole international day each year, anyone who wants to get involved has the chance to strip their websites of CSS, show off their semantic <code>&lt;body&gt;</code> and lay bare to all their proper use of HTML, semantic markup and good hierarchy structure.</p> <p>It’s an event that’s been on my radar for years, but I must admit that this is the first year I’m actually giving it a go. A little website skinny dipping? Why the hell not. How embarrassing can my HTML possibly be?</p> <p>Inspired by <a href="https://holzer.online/articles/2025/06-04-naked-css-day/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Fabian Holzer’s client-side script that automates CSS removal</a>, I thought I’d try something similar. But instead of using JavaScript, I’m doing it directly in my templates using some of <a href="https://gohugo.io/quick-reference/functions/#time" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo’s time functions</a>.</p> <p>Here is the logic that now lives inside my <code>&lt;head&gt;</code>, including a nice little reminder about what this is all about, for anyone who lands on my site when the actual day comes around.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Get current time */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">now</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">time</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Now</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Set CSS Naked Day start date/time UTC+14:00 */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">begin</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">time</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">AsTime</span> <span class="s">&#34;09 Apr 2025&#34;</span> <span class="s">&#34;Etc/GMT-14&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Set CSS Naked Day end date/time UTC-12:00 */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">end</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">time</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">AsTime</span> <span class="s">&#34;10 Apr 2025&#34;</span> <span class="s">&#34;Etc/GMT+12&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* If $now is &gt;= $begin and &lt;= $end */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nf">and</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">ge</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">now</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">begin</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">le</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">now</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">end</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">p</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="nx">mark</span><span class="p">&gt;</span><span class="nx">It</span><span class="err">’</span><span class="nx">s</span> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">a</span> <span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://css-naked-day.org/&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span><span class="nx">CSS</span> <span class="nx">Naked</span> <span class="nx">Day</span><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> <span class="nx">somewhere</span> <span class="nx">in</span> <span class="nx">the</span> <span class="nx">world</span><span class="p">!&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">mark</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">Include</span> <span class="nx">styles</span><span class="o">...</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>It’s by no means perfect, but gets 95% of the way there. One slight inconvenience, which I’m yet to find a solution for, is that I’ll have to remember to update the year in my <code>$begin</code> and <code>$end</code> variables if I want this logic to function year after year.</p> <p>The other downside of doing this inside your templates using a static site generator, is that you also need to trigger a build in order for it to work. My site is currently hosted by Netlify, so it’s easily done by setting up a <a href="https://docs.netlify.com/configure-builds/build-hooks/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">build hook</a> and using a service like Zapier, IFTTT or even GitHub Actions to send an HTTP post request at specified times.</p> <p>Whether this is approach is a good idea or not I’ll leave for you to decide, but it does remove the need for client-side JavaScript which is always a good thing.</p> <hr> <p><strong>10-04-25 update</strong>: It’s all a little too late given that this years event is already over, however I managed to find a solution for having to update the year manually.</p> <p>The trick is to get hold of the current year using <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/time/now/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">time.Now.Year</a>, then use the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/fmt/print/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">fmt.Print</a> function to turn it into a string. Now it’s possible to pass the string version of the year into the start date string using <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/fmt/printf/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">fmt.Printf</a>. This makes the date dynamic, so the logic will function year after year, without any further updates.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Get current time to determine whether it’s CSS Naked Day */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">now</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">time</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Now</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Get current year so we can update logic for each year */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">year</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">time</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Now</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Year</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Convert year from integer to string so we can pass it to the printf function */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">yearString</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">print</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">year</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Set start date and pass $yearString to make it dynamic */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">startDate</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">printf</span> <span class="s">&#34;09 Apr %s&#34;</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">yearString</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Set end date and pass $yearString to make it dynamic */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">endDate</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">printf</span> <span class="s">&#34;10 Apr %s&#34;</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">yearString</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Update start date to include correct timezone (UTC+14:00) */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">start</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">time</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">AsTime</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">startDate</span> <span class="s">&#34;Etc/GMT-14&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Update end date to include correct timezone (UTC-12:00) */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">end</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">time</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">AsTime</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">endDate</span> <span class="s">&#34;Etc/GMT+12&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* If $now is &gt;= $start and &lt;= $end */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nf">and</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">ge</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">now</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">start</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">le</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">now</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">end</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">p</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="nx">mark</span><span class="p">&gt;</span><span class="nx">It</span><span class="err">’</span><span class="nx">s</span> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">a</span> <span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;/writing/css-naked-day/&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span><span class="nx">CSS</span> <span class="nx">Naked</span> <span class="nx">Day</span><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> <span class="nx">somewhere</span> <span class="nx">in</span> <span class="nx">the</span> <span class="nx">world</span><span class="p">!&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">mark</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">Include</span> <span class="nx">styles</span><span class="o">...</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>There you have it. A native Hugo script to automate the removal of CSS when CSS Naked Day comes around each year. The only downside is that we’ll have to wait another year to see this in action.</p>

item.title: Making time for yourself
item.content:encoded: <p>Friends and family often ask if I still do my weekly sessions, even though I‘m feeling good these days and thankfully have for a while.</p> <p>I still go, I tell them, but now every other week, instead of every week. Often that comes as a surprise and is usual met with a follow up question. Something along the lines of; “But you’re feeling fine now right, how comes you still go?”</p> <p>Until now, I’ve struggled to give a clear answer to explain the reasons why I continue going. However, in todays session I got some clarity.</p> <p>Every week we block out time in our calendars dedicated to meeting the needs of others. Clients, bosses, colleagues, family, and so on. But, other than perhaps the odd bit of physical exercise, we often fail to do the same for ourselves.</p> <p>Talking therapy, counselling, or whatever you wish to call it, is blocking 50 minutes of time each week (or every other week in my case) for yourself. It’s a massive help during times of crisis, but it’s also invaluable when you’re feeling great, too.</p> <p>When I’m feeling good, I typically use therapy as a general check-in. A chance to reflect on what I’ve been up to and whether I’m heading in the right direction. It’s time I dedicate to helping myself navigate the world. Time to get some clarity on whatever occupies my mind and figure out the appropriate steps forward.</p> <p>However good I feel, I always leave sessions with a fresh perspective on things and clear idea of where to head next. I’d recommend it to anyone, whether in crisis or not.</p> <p>Here in the UK, at least, it seems many people still view therapy as something only for those who are in a seriously bad way. People on a knifes edge. Crazies, struggling to keep their shit together. From what I’ve seen, this stigma continues to persist, particularly in men. It’s a shame, as they have no idea what they’re missing out on.</p>

item.title: Rendering links in Hugo projects using Cloudcannon’s Rich Text Editor
item.content:encoded: <p>Cloudcannon’s Rich Text Editor, like most rich text editors, allows you to format – or ”markup” – your content via the <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/rich-text-editor-reference/#wysiwyg-toolbar" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WYSIWYG toolbar</a>, found at the top of the <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/documentation/articles/what-are-rich-text-editors/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Rich Text Editor</a>.</p> <p>The various formatting options found in the toolbar can be enabled, disable, and configured from inside your <code>cloudcannon.config.yml</code> file. All you need to do is add your options under the <code>_editables</code> key.</p> <p>By default, the following text formatting options are enabled:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nt">_editables</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">content</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">blockquote</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">bold</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">format</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">p h1 h2 h3 h4 h5 h6 pre address div</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">italic</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">link</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">strike</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">subscript</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">superscript</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">underline</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>Providing your project includes a basic CSS file that contains global styles for your typical text formatting options, then most of the options above will work without issue.</p> <p>However, when working with Hugo, you may run into issues when attempting to format text content using Cloudcannon’s <code>link</code> option. When using a Rich Text Editor, you’ll find it’s possible to select text and create an anchor link to another webpage. But, when you save your changes and your site has rebuilt, if you view your page in a browser, you will notice that the link has been stripped from the text.</p> <p>If this is the case, then open your browsers Inspect tool and navigate to the offending element to identify the problem.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">&#34;Here’s &#34; </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c">&lt;!-- raw HTML omitted --&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">&#34;a link to my website&#34; </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c">&lt;!-- raw HTML omitted --&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Here you’ll find the code typically used to create a link has been replaced with two <code>&lt;!-- raw HTML omitted --&gt;</code> comments, which surround the text you are trying to turn into a link.</p> <p>The reason for this is because, behind the scenes, Cloudcannon’s <em>link</em> option inserts HTML into markdown<sup id="fnref:1"><a href="#fn:1" class="footnote-ref" role="doc-noteref">1</a></sup>. However, Goldmark – the markdown engine used by Hugo – disallows HTML in Markdown files, by default. Goldmark does this to prevent possible breaking changes, where, for example, an editor with little experience authoring HTML may accidentally insert a <code>&lt;div&gt;</code> and forget to close it with a closing tag (<code>&lt;/div&gt;</code>), which could in theory break the layout of the page.</p> <p>Assuming you are happy to expose these potential risks to content editors, then the simple solution to this problem is to add the following to the root of your <code>hugo.toml</code> (or <code>config.toml</code>) configuration file.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c"># Allow HTML in markdown (use with caution)</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">markup</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">goldmark</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">renderer</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">unsafe</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="kc">true</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This tells Goldmark to allow the rendering of any potentially “unsafe” HTML that may be added to markdown files - links included. With these two lines added to your Hugo configuration, Cloudcannon’s Link formatting option will work as expected.</p> <p>Happy linking!</p> <div class="footnotes" role="doc-endnotes"> <hr> <ol> <li id="fn:1"> <p><strong>02-03-25</strong>: Since publishing this post and sharing it with the Cloudcannon community, Ross Phillips has offered further insights about <a href="https://community.cloudcannon.com/t/rendering-links-in-hugo-projects-using-cloudcannon-s-rich-text-editor/197/2?u=harrycresswell" target="_blank" rel="noopener">how Cloudcannon handles links in Markdown</a>. Basically, Cloudcannon will try to save links in Markdown, however, if anchor elements have attributes that cannont be preserved using Markdown, then HTML is used instead.&#160;<a href="#fnref:1" class="footnote-backref" role="doc-backlink">&#x21a9;&#xfe0e;</a></p> </li> </ol> </div>

item.title: Using Hugo to turn Airtable data into Markdown files for Obsidian
item.content:encoded: <p>Airtable is a fantastic tool. I’ve used it for years, mainly to bookmark useful design and development resources, good typefaces and websites I like. But, the more I use <a href="https://obsidian.md/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Obsidian</a>, the more appreciate the importance of Steph’s <a href="https://stephango.com/file-over-app" target="_blank" rel="noopener">file over app</a> philosophy and the fast, resilient, secure nature of <a href="https://www.inkandswitch.com/local-first/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">local-first software</a>.</p> <p>Don’t get me wrong, cloud apps still have their place in my workflow. When there’s a need to collaborate with others then I’ll continue to use them. But for managing content that only I need access to, I see few reasons to depend on cloud-first software <sup id="fnref:1"><a href="#fn:1" class="footnote-ref" role="doc-noteref">1</a></sup>.</p> <p>Why gate your content behind an internet connection if you don’t really need one? Why store your data in a centralised database, at the mercy of a company you have zero control over? SaaS companies come and go, <a href="https://killedbygoogle.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">it’s happened in the past</a> and it will happen again. What’s to say they won’t take your content with them?</p> <p>To make strides against this sort of thing happening, I’ve been working on a tool that takes data from an Airtable base and turns it into Markdown files. The goal is to move these files to a folder on my local machine, which I can then access using Obsidian. Local-first, file over app! If Obsidian ever disappears, then at least I’ll still have my Markdown files.</p> <p>Like with most things I build, I doing this with Hugo, because it’s great at generating markdown files from a variety of data sources.</p> <p>The rest of this post details how to build a tool like this for yourself.</p> <h2 id="preparing-the-data-for-hugo">Preparing the data for Hugo</h2> <p>The first step is to export an Airtable base so we have some data to convert to Markdown files. Airtable doesn’t make it all that obvious how to export data, so here are the steps to do this manually:</p> <ol> <li>Open the Data view of a database in Airtable that you want to export data from.</li> <li>In the top nav, next to where it says <em>Views</em>, click on the view, for example <em>Grid view</em> to reveal the contextual dropdown menu.</li> <li>From the menu click <em>Download CSV</em>.</li> <li>Save the exported <code>.csv</code> file to your desktop.</li> </ol> <p>The next step is to convert the CSV data to JSON data. This will arguably will make life easier when working in Hugo. Again, we can do this part manually.</p> <p>Head to <a href="https://csvjson.com/csv2json" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CSVJSON</a>, then where it says <strong>Upload a CSV file</strong>, click the <em>Choose file</em> button and select the <code>.csv</code> file you just saved to your desktop.</p> <p>With the CSV data now loaded into the textarea on the left-hand side, scroll down the page and click the big blue <em>Covert</em> button, found below the textarea. This will convert your CSV data to JSON and populate the right-hand side textarea with the data. Hit the big blue <em>Download</em> button below the textarea to download a <code>.json</code> version of your Airtable data.</p> <p>The final step is to set up a new Hugo project, then add the JSON file to the <code>assets/data</code> folder. That way, we can work with it from within a template.</p> <h2 id="building-a-template-that-generates-markdown-files">Building a template that generates markdown files</h2> <p>Now we have our data in a Hugo project ready to work with, the goal is to turn this JSON data into markdown files that can be used in Obsidian. Along with generating the files themselves, we also need to consider how to handle the data associated with each file. In the context of our Airtable database, this is the data found in each row of the table.</p> <p>Obsidian has a feature it calls <a href="https://help.obsidian.md/Editing&#43;and&#43;formatting/Properties" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Properties</a>, which can be added to the top of a note to add structured data to it. This is just a fancy name for front matter data, which you will already be familiar with if you’ve ever used Hugo before. Properties are stored as YAML data, so when we generate our Markdown files, we will need to convert the data associated with them to YAML front matter.</p> <p>Before we get into all that, though, first we need to create a layout template.</p> <h3 id="create-a-layout-template">Create a layout template</h3> <p>In a Hugo project, open the layouts folder and create a new template called <code>index.html</code>.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>touch layouts/index.html </code></pre><p>Inside <code>index.html</code>, initialise a <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/collections/dictionary/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">dictionary</a> (<code>dict</code> for short) by assigning it to a variable, in this case called <code>$data</code>. This creates an empty map which we’ll use to hold the data.</p> <h3 id="grab-the-data-from-your-data-file">Grab the data from your data file</h3> <p>Next, set up another variable, <code>$path</code>, to hold the path to your data. As we added our JSON data file to the <code>assets/data</code> folder, the path should be <code>data/the-name-of-your-file.json</code>. In my case, the name of my file is <code>nicesites.json</code></p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">data</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">dict</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">path</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="s">&#34;data/nicesites.json&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now it’s time to grab the actual data so we can do stuff with it. We can do this using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/resources/get/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">resources.Get</a> function, which returns a global resource from a given path.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">with</span> <span class="nx">resources</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Get</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">path</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">with</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">transform</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Unmarshal</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">data</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">errorf</span> <span class="s">&#34;Unable to get global resource %q&#34;</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">path</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The given path, in this case, is the value of our <code>$path</code> variable, which holds the data. We’re using <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/go-template/with/#article" target="_blank" rel="noopener">with</a> to execute this code based on whether or not the data exists. If it doesn’t exist, Hugo will log an error, which is handled by <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/fmt/errorf/#article" target="_blank" rel="noopener">fmt.Errorf</a>.</p> <p>With the data available, we pipe it to the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/transform/unmarshal/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">transform.Unmarshal</a> function, which ensures serialised data (a byte stream) is converted into a data structure Hugo can work with – JSON. Our <code>$data</code> variable is then reassigned with the unmarshaled data.</p> <h3 id="range-through-the-data">Range through the data</h3> <p>Now we’ve unmarshaled the data, the next step is looping through the <code>$data</code> object and store each item in the object so we can manipulate it. We can do this by passing <code>$data</code> to the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/go-template/range/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">range</a> function.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">data</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Validate and store the data */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">object</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Render data in the browser for debugging */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">pre</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="nx">debug</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Dump</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">object</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">pre</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You’ll notice we’re storing this data in a new variable called <code>$object</code>, then using <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/debug/dump/#article" target="_blank" rel="noopener">debug.Dump</a> to render this data in the browser. You don’t have to render data in the browser, but it can be helpful to see the data your working with.</p> <p>Don’t forget to run <code>hugo server</code> to see your code in the browser.</p> <div class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>A couple of things to point out here.</p> <p>In each item in the object above, you’ll notice a field called <em>category</em>. In Airtable, this corresponds to a <a href="https://support.airtable.com/docs/single-select-field" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Single Select field</a>. The value of <em>category</em> in each item is <code>[[websites]]</code>. This is just a preference for how I want the category property to behave in Obsidian. In Obdisian, anything in double square brackets (<code>[[]]</code>), creates a link to another note. So, once these Markdown files have been created and moved over to Obsidian, this will allow the ability to click through to a note called <em>Websites</em> from any of these Markdown files,</p> <p>The second thing to notice is that the <em>tags</em> field in each item above, is a comma-delimited (comma-separated) string. I’m not exactly sure why the <a href="https://support.airtable.com/v1/docs/multiple-select-field" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Multiple select filed</a> in Airtable formats data in this way. But, it means we will need to do some work in our template, to convert these tag strings to an array. That way, our YAML will be formatted correctly and we’ll be able to work with our tags in Obsidian.</p> <p>While we’re at it, I’d like to make it possible to add new tags to each item directly from this tools we’re building in Hugo. So let’s tackle these things next.</p> <h3 id="add-new-tags-format-as-yaml-and-merge-back-into-original-object">Add new tags, format as YAML and merge back into original object</h3> <p>First we need to get hold of the tags in our object. Then we can add new tags and format them correctly.</p> <p>Still inside the range (that part is very important), first we create a new variable called <code>$tags</code>, then assign it with the value <code>.tags</code> (the name of the key in our object) . If you’ve called your tags something else in Airtable, then you would store that key name instead of <code>.tags</code></p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Grab tags and format lowercase for Obsidian */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">tags</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">tags</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">lower</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Optionally see shape of data in the browser */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">pre</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="nx">debug</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Dump</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">tags</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">pre</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You’ll notice I’m using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/strings/tolower/#article" target="_blank" rel="noopener">strings.ToLower</a> pipe (alias <code>lower</code>) to make sure all the tags are lowercase. Again, this is a personal preference for how I like things set up in Obsidian.</p> <p>If you wish to, use the <code>debug.Dump</code> function again to see the shape of the data in the browser:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>&#34;big type&#34; &#34;minimal,sans serif,illustration&#34; &#34;low tech&#34; &#34;illustration,whimsical,scroll-based,animation,big type,sans serif&#34; </code></pre><p>You’ll see we’ve now got hold of just the comma-separated strings, instead of the entire data object. This is exactly what we want.</p> <h4 id="create-slices-from-tag-strings">Create slices from tag strings</h4> <p>The next thing to do is turn these comma-separated strings into slices, so we can add our new tags. We can do this using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/strings/split/#article" target="_blank" rel="noopener">strings.Split</a> function, which will split each tag string by the comma delimiter and return a slice of those tags.</p> <p>To make this happen, first we set up a new variable called<code>$tagsSlice</code>, then pass <code>$tags</code> to the <code>split</code> function and include a comma delimiter as the argument.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Convert comma-seperated tags string into a slice */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">tagsSlice</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">split</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">tags</span> <span class="s">&#34;,&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Optionally see shape of data in the browser */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">pre</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="nx">debug</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Dump</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">tagsSlice</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">pre</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Again, we can use the <code>debug.Dump</code> function to see how the shape of our data changes when using split function.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>[ &#34;big type&#34; ] [ &#34;minimal&#34;, &#34;sans serif&#34;, &#34;illustration&#34; ] [ &#34;low tech&#34; ] [ &#34;illustration&#34;, &#34;whimsical&#34;, &#34;scroll-based&#34;, &#34;animation&#34;, &#34;big type&#34;, &#34;sans serif&#34; ] </code></pre><p>Great, we now have arrays of slices. We’re making progress here.</p> <hr> <p><strong>Quick tip</strong>: Where the <code>split</code> function creates a slice from a string, <code>delimit</code> does the exact opposite, creating a string from a slice. So if you ever need to convert a slice to a string, use the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/collections/delimit/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">collections.Delimit</a> function.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Convert back to a comma-separated string */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">tagsString</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="nx">delimit</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">tags</span> <span class="s">&#34;,&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Which would createe the following:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>&#34;big type&#34; &#34;minimal,sans serif,illustration&#34; &#34;low tech&#34; &#34;illustration,whimsical,scroll-based,animation,big type,sans serif&#34; </code></pre><hr> <h4 id="add-new-tags-to-each-slice">Add new tags to each slice</h4> <p>In my case, I want to add an extra tag called <em>references</em> to each slice. To do this, first set up a new variable called <code>$newTags</code>, then pipe <code>$tagsSlice</code> to the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/collections/append/#article" target="_blank" rel="noopener">append</a> function and pass in a value as the argument. In my case that value is <code>references</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Append a new tag to the tags slice */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">newTags</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">tagsSlice</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">append</span> <span class="s">&#34;references&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>If you wanted to append multiple tags to the slice, you could do that just as easily by appending a slice of two values, to the slice.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Append a slice of more than one new tag to the tags slice */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">newTags</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">tagsSlice</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nf">append</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">slice</span> <span class="s">&#34;websites&#34;</span> <span class="s">&#34;references&#34;</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Optionally see shape of data in the browser */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">pre</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="nx">debug</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Dump</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">newTags</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">pre</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Again, using <code>debug.Dump</code> we can see that our new tag <em>references</em> has been appended to each slice.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>[ &#34;big type&#34;, &#34;references&#34; ] [ &#34;minimal&#34;, &#34;sans serif&#34;, &#34;illustration&#34;, &#34;references&#34; ] [ &#34;low tech&#34;, &#34;references&#34; ] [ &#34;illustration&#34;, &#34;whimsical&#34;, &#34;scroll-based&#34;, &#34;animation&#34;, &#34;big type&#34;, &#34;sans serif&#34;, &#34;references&#34; ] </code></pre><p>At this point our tag data is in the correct shape and our new tag(s) are appended to the original slice. Perfect.</p> <h4 id="merge-tags-slice-back-into-original-object">Merge tags slice back into original object</h4> <p>The next step is to merge our tags back into the original data object, which is stored in the <code>$object</code> variable. We can do this using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/collections/merge/#article" target="_blank" rel="noopener">collections.Merge</a> function, which merges two or more maps.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Merge newTags back into orginal object */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">updateObject</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">merge</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nf">object</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">dict</span> <span class="s">&#34;tags&#34;</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">newTags</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Optionally see shape of data in the browser */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">pre</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="nx">debug</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Dump</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">updateObject</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">pre</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>First we create a new variable called <code>$updateObject</code>, then pass <code>$object</code> – which holds the original data object – to the merge function. It’s important that <code>$object</code> is the first argument as this is the data we want to merge our tags <em>into</em>. Next, as our tags are a slice, we need to turn them into a map (a key-value pair). We can do this by creating a dictionary and passing <em>tags</em> as the key and our <code>$newTags</code> data as the value. That way, merge will work as expected and our tag data will be correctly formatted in JSON, as an array of tags held in a key called <code>tags</code>.</p> <p>Again, using <code>debug.Dump</code> we can see that our tags data is formatted exactly as intended.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-json" data-lang="json"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nt">&#34;category&#34;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;[[Websites]]&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nt">&#34;description&#34;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;New Interface Lovers&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nt">&#34;name&#34;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Lovers Magazine&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nt">&#34;tags&#34;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">[</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="s2">&#34;big type&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="s2">&#34;references&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">],</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span That way, it will be formatted correctly when we generate our markdown files for Obsidian.</p> <p>First, let’s set up a variable called <code>$lang</code> that holds the language we want to transform our data into. As Obsidian uses YAML for front matter properties, we’ll set the value to <code>yaml</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Set lang you want data as, e.g. yaml, toml, json or xml */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">lang</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="s">&#34;yaml&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next, we’ll set up another variable called <code>$transformData</code>, then assign it with our updated data object, <code>$updateObject</code>. The final step is to pipe it to the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/transform/remarshal/#article" target="_blank" rel="noopener">transform.Remarshal</a> function and pass in our <code>$lang</code> variable, so Remarshal knows what language to transform our data to.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Transform data to the specified format */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">transformData</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">updateObject</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">transform</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Remarshal</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">lang</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Render data in the browser for debugging */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">pre</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="nx">debug</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Dump</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">transformData</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">pre</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Once again, let’s use <code>debug.Dump</code> so we can take a look in the browser and see how our data has changed.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>&#34;category: &#39;[[Websites]]&#39;\ndescription: New Interface Lovers\nname: Lovers Magazine\ntags:\n- big type\n- references\nurl: https://www.loversmagazine.com/\n&#34; &#34;category: &#39;[[Websites]]&#39;\ndescription: \&#34;\&#34;\nname: Offscreen Mag\ntags:\n- minimal\n- sans serif\n- illustration\n- references\nurl: https://www.offscreenmag.com/\n&#34; &#34;category: &#39;[[Websites]]&#39;\ndescription: \&#34;\&#34;\nname: Low Tech Magazine\ntags:\n- low tech\n- references\nurl: https://solar.lowtechmagazine.com/\n&#34; &#34;category: &#39;[[Websites]]&#39;\ndescription: \&#34;\&#34;\nname: Vitamin\ntags:\n- illustration\n- whimsical\n- scroll-based\n- animation\n- big type\n- sans serif\n- references\nurl: https://vitamin2.ch/\n&#34; </code></pre><p>Ok, looks a little crazy at first glance, but for the most part everything is good. Our data has been transformed to strings of YAML which is exactly what we want.</p> <p>Those <code>\n</code>’s littered all over the place are nothing to worry about. All they do is create a new line, which is what we would expect when this YAML ends up as front matter in our markdown files.</p> <p>The only thing we need to figure out is how to add delimiters, a.k.a the three dashes (<code>---</code>), which signify the beginning and end of YAML front matter.</p> <p>The goal is to format our data like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nn">---</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">category</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s1">&#39;[[Websites]]&#39;</span><span class="w"> class="nn">---</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>Let’s tackle this next.</p> <h3 id="add-yaml-delimiters-to-validate-frontmatter">Add YAML delimiters to validate frontmatter</h3> <p>The <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/fmt/printf/#article" target="_blank" rel="noopener">fmt.Printf</a> function can help us out here. It allows you to format the structure of a string by adding additional content. Exactly what we need to add delimiters to our YAML.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Add dashes for YAML delimiters */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* ---\n adds the opening YAML delimiter followed by a newline (\n). */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* %s acts as a placeholder for the value of $transformData. */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* \n--- adds another newline followed by the closing YAML delimiter. */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Note: if $lang is set to TOML, change `---` to `+++`. */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">yamlContent</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">printf</span> <span class="s">&#34;---\n%s\n---&#34;</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">transformData</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Render data in the browser for debugging */</span><span class="p">}}</span> class="nx">Dump</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">yamlContent</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">pre</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The comments in the code above should help explain what each part does.</p> <p>Now let’s take a look at our strings in the browser using <code>debug.Dump</code>.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>&#34;---\ncategory: &#39;[[Websites]]&#39;\ndescription: New Interface Lovers\nname: Lovers Magazine\ntags:\n- big type\n- references\nurl: https://solar.lowtechmagazine.com/\n\n---&#34; </code></pre><p>Notice the three dashes have now been added to the beginning and end of each string, meaning our YAML front matter is formatted correctly.</p> <p>Now we’re in good shape to generate some markdown files.</p> <h3 id="generate-markdown-files">Generate Markdown files</h3> <p>OK, we’re on the home straight here. All that’s left to do now is to turn this data into markdown files.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Generate the target path and filename */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span
