class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">filename</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">printf</span> <span class="s">&#34;nicesites/%s.md&#34;</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">urlize</span> <span class="p">.)</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Create resource from the string */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">resource</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">resources</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">FromString</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">filename</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">yamlContent</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">file</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">resource</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">RelPermalink</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Log an error or handle missing .Name appropriately */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">errorf</span> <span class="s">&#34;Missing .Name for data: %v&#34;</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">object</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Let’s quickly run through this code so we understand what’s going on.</p> <p>First we create a condition using <code>with</code>, where our code will only run if a value of <code>name</code> exists. Note, <em>name</em> is one of the keys in our data, which is taken from our Airtable database. If <code>name</code> doesn’t exist, then we get Hugo to log an error using the <code>errorf</code> function.</p> <p>Assuming our code will return <em>truthy</em> and therefore execute, the next step is to create a file name for each markdown file. To do this, we set up a variable called <code>$filename</code>, then once again use the <code>printf</code> function to create the path to our file. In the example above, we specify a folder name called <code>nicesites</code>, then use <code>%s</code> which acts as the placeholder for the data we pass in. Notice all we’re passing in is the dot (<code>.</code>), as <code>with</code> binds the context to whatever you pass to it. As we passed <code>.name</code> to <code>with</code>, that means the dot contains the data held in <code>.name</code>, which will be used to create our file name. We’re using <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/urls/urlize/#article" target="_blank" rel="noopener">urls.URLize</a> (alias <code>urlize</code>) to ensure names are formatted in lowercase and multiple words are connected by dashes (a.k.a kebabcase).</p> <p>The final step is to create the markdown file itself, which we can do using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/resources/fromstring/#article" target="_blank" rel="noopener">resources.FromString</a> method. First we pass in the target path, <code>$filename</code>, then the strings we want to turn into resources, <code>$yamlContent</code>. <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/resource/relpermalink/#article" target="_blank" rel="noopener">RelPermalink</a> publishes the resource and returns its relative permalink.</p> <p>Ok, that it. We’re ready to generate our pages.</p> <p>From the root of your project, run the <code>hugo</code> command to generate a public folder.</p> <p>Now head to your public folder, found at the root of your project. Inside you will find a new folder. It my case, that folder is called <em>nicesites</em>. Inside that folder you’ll find a markdown file for each row in your Airtable database.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>public/ nicesites/ 099-supply.md 500.md accolade.md adaptable.md ... </code></pre><p>Inside each markdown file you’ll find YAML front matter data corresponding to the data within each row.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/f_jpg,q_auto:best,w_600/v1741023302/hc/obsidian-nicesites-database-folder.jpg" loading="lazy" alt="My Nicesites DB in Obsidian" /> </picture> <figcaption>My Nicesites DB in Obsidian</figcaption> </figure><p>I consider this type of data <em>reference</em> data, as it’s not created by myself. So to distinguish it from other notes in my Obsidian vault, surprisingly enough, I keep it in a folder at the root of my vault called <em>references</em>.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>references/ nicesites/ 📓 nicesites DB 099-suppy 500 accolade adaptable ... </code></pre><p>I also like to distinguish my DB notes from regular notes by prefixing the file name with an emoji. This ensures my databases sit at the top of the folder they reside in and are easy to access. I also suffix the file name with the letters “DB” for a little extra clarity.</p> <p>I’m a few weeks in with this new system and so far it’s been fun to work with.</p> <h2 id="final-words">Final words</h2> <p>The goal of this project was to convert Airtable data into Markdown files, for use in Obsidian. However, there’s nothing stopping you from using these Markdown files elsewhere.</p> <p>You could even turn your Markdown files into web pages, should you wish to. That’s one of the benefits of building this tool with a static site generator like Hugo.</p> <p>The first step would be to move your Markdown generating template to a <code>/prebuild</code> folder. You would then need to move into the prebuild folder to run the <code>hugo</code> command when generating your pages. Once you’ve done this, you can mount the folder generated in your <code>prebuild/public</code> folder to your <code>/content</code> folder.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c"># mount directory into project</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="p">[</span><span class="l">module]</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="l">module.mounts]]</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="l">source = &#39;content&#39;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="l">target = &#39;content&#39;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="l">module.mounts]]</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="l">source = &#39;prebuild/public/[your-folder-name]&#39;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="l">target = &#39;content/[your-folder-name]&#39;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>As mentioned in my previous Hugo post, Regis Philibert’s <a href="https://www.thenewdynamic.com/article/toward-using-a-headless-cms-with-hugo-part-2-building-from-remote-api/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">pre-build and mount method</a> will take you though this step-by-step.</p> <p>Don’t forget to create some regular layout templates in your <code>/layouts</code> folder. That way you can actually generate web pages.</p> <p>Ok, that’s all for now. You can find all the code used in this project over on <a href="https://github.com/harrycresswell/airtable-hugo-markdown" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Github</a>.</p> <div class="footnotes" role="doc-endnotes"> <hr> <ol> <li id="fn:1"> <p>Marina Stanisheva gives a good breakdown of <a href="https://blog.connecterapp.com/local-first-vs-cloud-first-49e7433cde8a" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Local-first vs. Cloud-first</a> software.&#160;<a href="#fnref:1" class="footnote-backref" role="doc-backlink">&#x21a9;&#xfe0e;</a></p> </li> </ol> </div>

item.title: Silence and action
item.content:encoded: <p>I’ve written before about how <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/sleep-on-it/">space, time and sleep, can help give you a fresh perspective on things</a>. In a similar vein, today I want to talk about how silence and meditation can be used as an effective tool for solving problems and making progress.</p> <p>Take this morning, for example. As per usual, I sat down to meditate for a few quiet minutes. No plan, no guidance and zero expectations about what might come up.</p> <p>Within a few minutes something comes up. The solution to a problem I’ve been struggling with, in a client project I’m working on. Something tells me that I solved a similar problem a while back. With not too much effort I could repurpose that work for this particular project.</p> <p>This isn’t the first time I’ve found solutions through meditation and I’m sure it won’t be the last. What I find fascinating is that in most cases like this, I never sit down to consciously reflect on the problem I’m experiencing. I just sit there, wait, and see what turns up. In these quiet moments, I seem to reveal memories buried deep within my mind. Things I already know that are usually obscured by the typical distractions of everyday life. The silence somehow allows them to resurface.</p> <p>In <a href="https://youtu.be/TUMjnmfsPeM?si=6slNcdZVvril__Cx&amp;t=4220" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a fantastic conversation about copywriting with David Perell</a>, Harry Dry shares a similar idea - which he calls Silence and Action – where he wakes up and for some time will just sit there in silence. Other times, he’ll take a walk, most often alone, in silence, without any form of entertainment. No scrolling social media or doing things that might cloud his head and turn the day to drudge. Harry uses these moments as a chance to collect his thoughts and give himself the best possible shot at creating something good.</p> <p>What I like about Harry’s approach is that it shows meditation doesn’t have to mean sitting on the floor, legs crossed, wondering when your 10 minutes are up. It can also mean getting outside in nature. Or, really, any way you can find a quiet moment to create space and clarity in your mind.</p> <p>Often, all it takes is a few quiet minutes of distraction-free time to solve a problem and find the most appropriate way forward. A clear mind makes it easier to reflect and recover what you already know. It’s in moments like these where we make sense of things and the good stuff can be found.</p>

item.title: Generate pages from Google Sheets using Hugo’s Content Adapters
item.content:encoded: <p>For a long time, building pages from remote data sources felt like one of those killer features that was missing from Hugo<sup id="fnref:1"><a href="#fn:1" class="footnote-ref" role="doc-noteref">1</a></sup>. A hard pill to swallow, made worst by the fact that the Eleventy community have had this feature, as standard, from day one.</p> <p>Lucky for us, all this changed with the release of <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/content-adapters/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Content Adapters</a> in Hugo <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/upgrading-hugo-warnings-breaking-changes/">0.126.0</a>. Now, with a few lines of code in a go template (.gotmpl), it’s possible to dynamically generate pages from remote data sources – like JSON, CSV, TOML, YAML and XML.</p> <p>The Hugo Docs have a great example of <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/content-adapters/#example" target="_blank" rel="noopener">how to generate pages from remote JSON data</a> using a content adapter, but there’s not much written about working with other data types, from remote places elsewhere on the web.</p> <p>With that in mind, I thought I’d show you how to use content adapters to dynamically generate pages from CSV data held in a Google Sheet. But, before we get into the build, first it might help to learn more about the recent client project that this post is based on.</p> <h2 id="a-quick-overview-of-the-project">A quick overview of the project</h2> <p>My client operates in various states and counties across the USA. Part of their marketing effort is to create targeted, location-based, landing pages for each county, in each state. As you can imagine, creating all these page is a fair amount of work.</p> <p>To make this process easier, the data for each page is stored in a single Google Sheet, where each row in the sheet holds the content for each page.</p> <p>The goal of the project was to use this sheet to generate pages for each location. Fortunately, each page required the exact same design and layout, meaning all that actually need to change, page-to-page, is the content itself.</p> <p>The project presented a few challenges to consider. For example, my client needed the ability to regularly update each page from the sheet. And, also, control whether pages would publish on their website, or not. Ultimately using Google Sheets as a content management system for this part of their website. The thinking behind this was that it would be much easier to manage these pages on mass, from a single sheet, rather than individually, via a traditional CMS.</p> <p>Ok. Now we have a rough idea of the project requirements, let’s look at how to make it happen.</p> <h2 id="create-a-google-sheet-with-some-data-in-it">Create a Google sheet with some data in it</h2> <p>To kick things off, the first step is to create a Google Sheet with some data in it. For the purposes of this post, I’ve made <a href="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/11uVKGlWucpT31cc_by595yOaNSW_qpa4B1mTvP8nW5k/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank" rel="noopener">an example sheet</a> with a couple of entries in it.</p> <p>The next step is to publish your Sheet to the web. That way Hugo can work with the data. To do this, open your Google Sheet, then head to <code>File &gt; Share &gt; Publish to web</code> from the top menu. This will open a modal called <em>Publish to the web</em>. From here, find the <em>Link</em> tab. It should be the one already selected. From the Link tab, select <strong>Entire Document</strong> and change the format from <em>Web page</em> to <strong>Comma-seperated values (.csv)</strong>.</p> <p>Below those two selects you’ll find a URL for the sheet. You’ll need this URL to get hold of the data, when you build your content adapter.</p> <h2 id="create-a-content-adapter-to-generate-pages">Create a Content Adapter to generate pages</h2> <p>A Content Adapter is a Go template used to generate pages. It has access to all the usual functions as a regular layout template. But, there are some differences to consider, from your typical layout template.</p> <h3 id="keep-content-adapter-templates-in-the-content-folder">Keep Content Adapter templates in the /content folder</h3> <p>First of all, unlike regular layout templates, content adapter templates live in the content folder, inside the section you wish to create pages for. As explained in <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/content-adapters/#overview" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Content adapters in the Hugo docs</a>:</p> <blockquote> <p>“When a content adapter creates a page, the page’s <a href="https://gohugo.io/getting-started/glossary/#logical-path" target="_blank" rel="noopener">logical path</a> will be relative to the content adapter.”</p> </blockquote> <p>For our project, we want to build pages under the path <code>/locations</code>, one level down from the root domain. That means creating a <code>locations</code> folder with a content adapter template inside.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>content/ locations/ _content.gotmpl </code></pre><p>Unlike layout templates, you’ll notice the file extension is <code>.gotmpl</code> instead of <code>.html</code>. Don’t forget, if you want your content adapter to work, prefix the file name with an underscore, and always name the file <code>content</code>.</p> <p>With your content adapter file set up, the next thing to do is open the file you’ve just named <code>_content.gotmpl</code> and add the code required to build your pages.</p> <h3 id="get-the-data-from-your-sheet-and-store-it-in-a-variable">Get the data from your Sheet and store it in a variable</h3> <p>First, initialise a <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/collections/dictionary/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">dictionary</a> (<code>dict</code> for short) by assigning it to a variable, in this case called <code>$data</code>. This creates an empty map which we’ll use to hold the data.</p> <p>Next, copy that URL from earlier, that one found in your Google Sheet’s <em>Publish to web</em> settings, then assign it to another variable. In this case a variable called <code>$url</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Get remote data. */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">data</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">dict</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">url</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="s">&#34;https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vTdSubfXxQx6-2Lqiforf1ySbEloD4arxbPkSAA8TWifYRwq9xMQda4G63kaV_JKpgxBFW-VIpR7Ugu/pub?gid=0&amp;single=true&amp;output=csv&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now it’s time to grab the actual remote data. You can do this using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/resources/getremote/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">resources.GetRemote</a> function.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">with</span> <span class="nx">resources</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">GetRemote</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">with</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Err</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">errorf</span> <span class="s">&#34;Unable to get remote resource %s: %s&#34;</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">data</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">transform</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Unmarshal</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">errorf</span> <span class="s">&#34;Unable to get remote resource %s&#34;</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The code above looks more complicated than it actually is. All we’re doing here is passing our <code>$url</code> to the function and using <code>with</code> to make the code inside execute base on a condition. In plain english, that condition says something like; ”if data exist at the URL provided, then our expression is <em>truthy</em> and the code will execute. If the expression returns <em>falsy</em>, because there’s no data, then we will get an error message in our terminal”.</p> <p>As per the Hugo Docs:</p> <blockquote> <p>“Error handling is essential when using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/resources/getremote/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><code>resources.GetRemote</code></a> function to capture remote resources such as data or images.”</p> </blockquote> <p>So, the code within the expression makes sure we handle any errors correctly.</p> <p>Now, if the expression returns <em>truthy</em> (as we expect it to), then the empty map we previously assigned to the <code>$data</code> variable will update to include the data found at our URL.</p> <p>Great! We now have our data stored somewhere. Notice we only have to pass in the Dot (<code>.</code>) for this to work. This is because <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/go-template/with/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">with</a> changes the context (the data available to us) to whatever is passes into it – in this case the data found in our <code>$url</code>.</p> <p>You’ll also notice we’re applying a <a href="https://gohugo.io/quick-reference/glossary/#pipeline" target="_blank" rel="noopener">pipe</a> to our data in the form of <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/transform/unmarshal/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">transform.Unmarshal</a>. If you’re new to this function, then what it does is to convert serialised data (a byte stream) into a data structure Hugo can work with. In our case, that means CSV data to JSON.</p> <h3 id="range-through-the-data-and-generate-pages">Range through the data and generate pages</h3> <p>With the code from the previous section in our content adapter template, we now have our data assigned to the <code>$data</code> variable, in a format we can work with.</p> <p>The next step is to loop through each item in the <code>$data</code> object (each row in our Sheet), then store all the values (each column in each row) so we can pass the data to a layout template.</p> <p>We can do this using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/go-template/range/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">range</a> function.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="nx">after</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">data</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">title</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">0</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">slug</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">body</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">keyword</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">3</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">city</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">4</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">state</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">5</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">publish</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">6</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">imageUrl</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">7</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">imageAlt</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">8</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice we’re including the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/collections/after/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">After</a> function, and passing it a value of <code>1</code>. This tells range to begin looping through our data object <em>after</em> the first item. In plain english, and in the context of our sheet, that means “ignore the first row in the sheet”. This is an important step, as we don’t want Hugo to generate a page from the top row in our sheet, which only exists to label the data in our sheet. This is simply there for our own reference, so we understand the data found in each column, when we look at the sheet.</p> <p>Next, let’s talk about all those variables. Each one stores the data found in each column of the sheet, so to make life easier, it makes sense to give them the same name as you have in your sheet. Use <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/collections/indexfunction/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Index</a> to return each value, where 0 is the first column, 1 the second, 2 the third, and so on. Don’t forget to include the Dot as it holds the data object!</p> <p>With each value stored in a variable, it’s time to generate our pages and pass the data to the Page object. This will allow us to use the data in a layout template.</p> <p>We can generate pages use the <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/content-adapters/#addpage" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AddPage</a> method. However, first we need to map our data to the method, so our templates can access the data.</p> <h3 id="mapping-data-to-the-addpage-method">Mapping data to the AddPage method</h3> <p>Still inside the range function, first set up a <code>dict</code> to map the data you want to make available when you use <code>.Content</code> in your layout templates. This is equivalent to the markdown you’d usually write in the body of markdown files. For the sake of clarity, it makes sense to assigned this to a variable called <code>$content</code>.</p> <p>Next, we need to specify the <code>mediaType</code>, in this case <em>text/markdown</em> and a <code>value</code>, which is the data itself. I want the data held in the <code>$body</code> variable to be accessible using <code>.Content</code>, so this is the value I’m using.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="nx">after</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">data</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">title</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">0</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">slug</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">body</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">keyword</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">3</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">city</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">4</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">state</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">5</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">publish</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">6</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">imageUrl</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">7</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">imageAlt</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">8</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span Then we set up another map for our Params. In this case, I only have an image alt. Both these maps then get passed to our <code>$resource</code> map, where we also build the <code>path</code> to the resource. Our indexed <code>$slug</code> builds the first part of the path, then we give the resource itself the name cover and use <code>.MediaType.SubType</code> to define the image format.</p> <p>With that, our content adapter is set up and ready to generate pages.</p> <p>At this point, you probably will have realised that content adapters don’t create the page layout itself. Let’s look at that next.</p> <h2 id="build-a-singlehtml-layout-template-to-render-the-data">Build a <code>single.html</code> layout template to render the data</h2> <p>As we’re generating single pages with our content adapter, we’ll need to create a <code>single.html</code> layout template. So I’ll create a folder in the layouts directory that’s also called <code>locations</code>. Next I’ll create the <code>single.html</code> template inside this new folder.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>layouts/ locations/ single.html </code></pre><p>Now we have a layout template for our content adapter, we’re ready to pull the data into the template and render our pages.</p> <h3 id="setting-up-variables-to-store-your-data">Setting up variables to store your data</h3> <p>I like to set up variables at the very top of my templates. Just as you might do with any other page resource found inside a page bundle.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>It’s worth pointing out that templating pages generated using content adapters doesn’t end with the <code>single.html</code> template. You can also create a <code>list.html</code> template to design the layout of the list view your pages inherit. This works exactly as you’d expect, so in the interest of brevity, I’ll leave that for you to explore further.</p> <h2 id="dealing-with-final-challenges">Dealing with final challenges</h2> <p>Before I wrap this one up, I’ll briefly explain how we solved the challenges this particularly project presented, which I touched on earlier.</p> <h3 id="adding-cache-busting-to-refresh-the-data-with-every-site-build">Adding cache busting to refresh the data with every site build</h3> <p>As mentioned, my client needed the ability to update each page, directly from the sheet where the data is stored. Essentially, using Google Sheets as a content management system.</p> <p>The main challenge with making regular updates via a Sheet is that Google caches requests to Sheets. This means that if we keep making requests to the same URL, then any updates made to the sheet won’t necessarily be visible and we’ll continue to see the previously cached data.</p> <p>The solution is to cache bust the sheet by appending a random string to the original URL. This creates a unique request and pulls in the latest data from the sheet.</p> <p>Consider the following updates to my <code>_content.gotmpl</code> file:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">seed</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">now</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Unix</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">randUrl</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">printf</span> <span class="s">&#34;&amp;rando=%s&#34;</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">printf</span> <span class="s">&#34;%.10s&#34;</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">sha256</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">seed</span><span class="p">))</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">printf</span> <span class="s">&#34;%s%s&#34;</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">printf</span> <span class="s">&#34;%s&#34;</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">with</span> <span class="nx">resources</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">GetRemote</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">randUrl</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">with</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Err</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">errorf</span> <span class="s">&#34;Unable to get remote resource %s: %s&#34;</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">data</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">transform</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Unmarshal</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">errorf</span> <span class="s">&#34;Unable to get remote resource %s&#34;</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>First we create a <em>seed</em> using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/time/now/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">time.Now</a> function. This returns the current time as a Unix timestamp, which for our purposes provides a random set of numbers we can work with. Next we pass our <code>$seed</code> value to the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/crypto/sha256/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">crypto.SHA256</a> function. This generates a random string which we append to the original URL provided by Google Sheets. This random string is stored in our <code>$randUrl</code> variable. Finally, we pass <code>$randUrl</code> to the GetRemote function instead of the original URL.</p> <p>For more on this method, check out <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_PlDMok-yUg" target="_blank" rel="noopener">How to use Google Sheets as source data for Hugo SSG content</a>. Bryan explains this stuff far better than I ever could.</p> <h3 id="conditionally-generate-pages">Conditionally generate pages</h3> <p>The second challenge we faced during this project was figuring out a way to control whether pages publish on the live website, or not.</p> <p>The rather rudimentary solution we came up with was to add a <em>Publish</em> column to the sheet, where possible values are either <em>yes</em> or <em>no</em>. With this we could create a condition in the <em>_content.gotmpl</em>, where the AddPage function only runs (and so creates the page) <em>if</em> the value of <code>$publish</code> is <em>true</em>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nx">eq</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">publish</span> <span class="s">&#34;yes&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">AddPage</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">page</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In case you had wondered, this explains why the following line of code exists within the Range function we use to loop through the data in the sheet.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">publish</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">index</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="mi">6</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Perhaps there’s a better way to approach this problem, but it’s effective and work just fine for now.</p> <h3 id="triggering-a-site-build-from-google-sheets">Triggering a site build from Google Sheets</h3> <p>The final challenge was to create an easy way for the client to trigger a site build once they’ve made changes to the Google Sheet. This is a crucial step, as without it we wouldn’t be able to generate new pages or update any existing content on the site, as data in the sheet changes.</p> <p>Getting this set up and working involved the following steps:</p> <ol> <li>Create a button in the sheet.</li> <li>Create a script that triggers a build.</li> <li>Assign the script to your button.</li> <li>Set up a build hook with your deployment service (Netlify etc).</li> </ol> <p>Spreadsheet.dev has <a href="https://spreadsheet.dev/buttons-in-google-sheets" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a great post on creating buttons in a Google Sheets</a> (step 1). This post also covers step 2 – how to create a script via <strong>Extensions →Apps Script</strong> - and step 3 – assigning a script to the button.</p> <p>The script required to trigger the build will look something like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">function</span> <span class="nx">runBuild</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">UrlFetchApp</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">fetch</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&#34;https://api.netlify.com/build_hooks/67af30cf8435ff6927017aef?clear_cache=true&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="s1">&#39;method&#39;</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">&#39;post&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">});</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Where the URL in the script is the build hook provided by the deployment service (step 4), in this case Netlify.</p> <p>Keep in mind, when you first click your button, you will need to grant the required authorisation for the script to run. Following this, the script will run anytime the button is clicked, which will trigger the build hook and re-deploy the website.</p> <h3 id="troubleshooting-issues">Troubleshooting issues</h3> <p>Debugging a content adapter isn’t always easy, as before you build a layout template, you won’t see any output or error messages in the browser.</p> <p>A quick and dirty way around this problem is to temporarily move your content adapter code to am existing layout template. Then use the <a href="https://gohugo.io/troubleshooting/inspection/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">debug.Dump</a> function again to inspect your data object.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">with</span> <span class="nx">resources</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">GetRemote</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">with</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Err</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">errorf</span> <span class="s">&#34;Unable to get remote resource %s: %s&#34;</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">data</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">transform</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Unmarshal</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">pre</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="nx">debug</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Dump</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">data</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">pre</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">errorf</span> <span class="s">&#34;Unable to get remote resource %s&#34;</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>While this won’t generate your pages, it will return the data object. From here you can figure out the shape of your data.</p> <h2 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping up</h2> <p>Well done if you’ve made it this far. The good news is that you can now use Google Sheets as a CMS for your Hugo websites. Exciting times!</p> <p>I’ve put together a <a href="https://github.com/harrycresswell/hugo-content-adapters" target="_blank" rel="noopener">repository</a> and <a href="https://hugo-content-adapters.netlify.app/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">demo site</a> to accompany this post. Hopefully this will help you hit the ground running.</p> <p>I want to wrap this one up by pointing out an important distinction to make when building pages using content adapters. And, that is that these pages are <em>dynamically</em> generated. In other words, content adapters will not create a bunch of markdown files in your content folder. This can feel a little strange at first, as, with Hugo, we’re used to working with markdown files and building pages statically. But, if you’re familiar with dynamic website tools, then this shouldn’t be too much to wrap your head around.</p> <p>If, for whatever reason, you do want to create markdown files from remote data sources, then I recommend looking into Regis Philibert’s <a href="https://www.thenewdynamic.com/article/toward-using-a-headless-cms-with-hugo-part-2-building-from-remote-api/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">pre-build and mount method</a>. I’ve been using this approach to generate Markdown files for Obsidian from Airtable data. It’s super useful, but more on that another day.</p> <div class="footnotes" role="doc-endnotes"> <hr> <ol> <li id="fn:1"> <p>This isn’t entirely true, as we did have some clever work arounds. Notably the <a href="https://www.thenewdynamic.com/article/toward-using-a-headless-cms-with-hugo-part-2-building-from-remote-api/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">pre-build and mount method</a> which I mention in the conclusion of this post.&#160;<a href="#fnref:1" class="footnote-backref" role="doc-backlink">&#x21a9;&#xfe0e;</a></p> </li> </ol> </div>

item.title: Planning meals
item.content:encoded: <p>There’s nothing worse than finishing work, feeling tired, then having to figure out what to cook for dinner. It’s a real pain and often leads to bad decisions.</p> <p>I’ve written before about <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/sunday-meal-prep/">how I use meal prepping to stay healthy</a> throughout the week. In a similar vein, today I want to talk about how I go about planning meals, so we never have to think too hard about what to cook during the week.</p> <p>The key to planning what you eat, I’ve realised, starts by owning a handful of quality cookbooks, which contain healthy, easy-to-cook meals that taste great.</p> <p>My favourite cookbooks right now are:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://ottolenghi.co.uk/products/flavour-cookbook" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Flavour by Ottolenghi</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/43501560-one" target="_blank" rel="noopener">One pot, pan, planet by Anna Jones</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/203017792-easy-wins" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Easy Wins by Anna Jones</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/38882366-deliciously-ella" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Plant-based Cookbook by Deliciously Ella</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/52894119-deliciously-ella-making-plant-based-quick-and-easy" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Quick and Easy by Deliciously Ella</a></li> </ul> <p>We usually buy our fruit and veg from the local market on Saturday mornings. So on either Friday evening or Saturday morning, we’ll have a quick look through our cookbooks, then pull out a handful of recipes that we fancy eating the following week.</p> <p>Using Apple Notes, one of us will note down the recipe name, the name of the cookbook and page number the recipe can be found on. Then we extract the ingredients for each recipe into Apple Reminders, where we keep a shared shopping list. Currently we do this manually, but you could easily use something like <a href="https://support.apple.com/en-gb/HT212630" target="_blank" rel="noopener">iPhone’s Live Text feature</a>, to take a picture of a recipe and have your phone extract the text. Once the ingredients are in our shopping list, we’re ready to head down to the market and grab what we need.</p> <p>Each evening, we’ll pick one of the recipes we’ve written down in Apple Notes to cook. Often recipes will serve at least four people, so that leaves us with plenty of leftovers to use for lunch the following day.</p> <p>What I love about this approach is that it takes the hassle out of figuring out what to eat every night. It’s super efficient too, as you generally only end up buying what you need for the week. No more dealing with forgotten vegetables rotting at the back of the fridge.</p> <p>On another note, it makes me wonder why services like Hello Fresh even exist. It’s fun to pick your own recipes and actually leave the house to buy your own ingredients. Just as Manu points out that <a href="https://manuelmoreale.com/indieweb-carnival-on-the-importance-of-friction" target="_blank" rel="noopener">friction is important in the digital world</a>, it’s also important in the physical world, too.</p>

item.title: Semantic headings on list pages
item.content:encoded: <p>Creating semantic headings can be tricky business. This is especially true when you find the need to render all the content of your pages on a list page (a page that lists pages). Often we only see page titles and summaries on a list page, which usually cause little to no issue. But, as soon as you throw a few h2’s and h3’s into the mix, correct heading heirachy tends to fly straight out the window.</p> <p>The solution I’ve found is to use a little Regex. But before we get into that, first let me give you an example to help illustrate the problem.</p> <h2 id="the-problem">The problem</h2> <p>Below I have a basic markdown file containing a page title stored in YAML front matter and markdown content, mostly organised under level two headings (h2). When writing Markdown, level two headings are indicated by adding a double hash (##) before the heading. The reason we start with level two headings in the content, is that the title will take the top-level heading (h1). And, only one h1 can be used per page.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-md" data-lang="md"><span class="line"><span class="cl">--- </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">title: The title of our page </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">--- </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">Some intro </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="gu">## Some heading level 2 </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="gu"></span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">Some content </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="gu">## Another heading level 2 </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="gu"></span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">More content </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Before we look at the list page, first lets consider a simple <code>single.html</code> template that we might use, in a Hugo project, to render this page.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">define</span> <span class="s">&#34;main&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">div</span> <span class="nx">class</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;flow&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Content</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>As you might expect, the output this <code>single.html</code> template generates for our page presents no issues whatsoever. All headings are semantically correct.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">body</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">div</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;flow&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>The title of our page<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Some intro<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>A heading level 2<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Some content<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Another heading level 2<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>More content<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">body</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now let’s consider the <code>list.html</code> page template, that we might use to render our page alongside other pages within the same collection or section.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">define</span> <span class="s">&#34;main&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Pages</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">div</span> <span class="nx">class</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;flow&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Content</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The problem isn’t immediately obvious as we look at our list template. But, the output that our list template generates tells a different story.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Posts<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">div</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;flow&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>The title of our page<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Some intro<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>A heading level 2<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Some content<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Another heading level 2<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>More content<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">div</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;flow&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>The title of another page<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Some intro<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>A heading level 2<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Some content<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Another heading level 2<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>More content<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You’ll notice that the <code>&lt;h1&gt;</code> is now occupied by the title of our list page – in this case, <em>Posts</em> – and no longer the title of our pages. This makes sense, as we want to describe the contents of the whole page, using the top-level heading.</p> <p>You’ll also notice that the title of our pages are now wrapped in <code>&lt;h2&gt;</code> tags. This is semantically correct, as they are no longer the top-level heading like on a single page, but instead the level two subheadings of our list page. One indentation down, if you like, in the structure of content.</p> <p>Herein lies the problem. As our page titles are now <code>&lt;h2&gt;</code>’s, that means the <code>&lt;h2&gt;</code>’s found within the content of the page are no longer semantically correct. In this case, they should, in fact, be <code>&lt;h3&gt;</code>’s. As level three subheadings would provide the correct structure to our content<sup id="fnref:1"><a href="#fn:1" class="footnote-ref" role="doc-noteref">1</a></sup>.</p> <p>So how do we solve this problem?</p> <p>The simple solution is to programatically change the <code>&lt;h2&gt;</code>’s in our page content to <code>&lt;h3&gt;</code>’s. But, of course, only in our list template. We don’t want to change them in the actual markdown file, as this would skew the semantics on the single page.</p> <h2 id="the-solution">The solution</h2> <p>I must admit, I’m no expert at creating regular expressions. However, Hugo has a few helpful Regex functions that even a novice like me can get some use out of.</p> <p>One of these functions is <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/strings/replacere/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">strings.ReplaceRE</a>, which can be used to replace all occurrences of some part of a string (indicated using a regular expression) with a replacement pattern.</p> <p>Consider the following updates to our list template.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">define</span> <span class="s">&#34;main&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Pages</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">div</span> <span class="nx">class</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;flow&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Content</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">replaceRE</span> <span class="s">&#34;h2&#34;</span> <span class="s">&#34;h3&#34;</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">safeHTML</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You’ll notice we’re now <a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/introduction/#pipes" target="_blank" rel="noopener">piping</a> the <code>.Content</code> method – which is used returns our page content – to the replaceRE function. We pass two arguments to the function, the <em>pattern</em> we’re looking to replace (in this case <code>h2</code>) and the value, or <em>replacement</em>, we want to replace the pattern with (in this case <code>h3</code>). Finally, as ReplaceRE converts our content into a string, we need to use the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/safe/html/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">safeHTML</a> pipe to return our content as HTML, instead of a string.</p> <p>With that, the level two subheadings in the content of our pages are now level three subheadings, but only in our list templates. They remain level two subheadings in our content files and on single pages. Exactly what we want!</p> <p>Those of you creating anchor tags for your headings, may prefer to use the following – slightly more intimidating – few lines of code to make that happen:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">h2toh3</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Content</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">replaceRE</span> <span class="s">&#34;h2&#34;</span> <span class="s">&#34;h3&#34;</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">safeHTML</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">h2toh3</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">replaceRE</span> <span class="s">&#34;(&lt;h[2-9] id=\&#34;([^\&#34;]+)\&#34;.+)(&lt;/h[2-9]+&gt;)&#34;</span> <span class="s">`${1}&amp;nbsp;&lt;a class=&#34;heading-anchor&#34; href=&#34;#${2}&#34; aria-label=&#34;Anchor&#34;&gt;#&lt;/a&gt; ${3}`</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">safeHTML</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Here we get into some real head scratching regex. But I’ll leave that for you to try and make sense of.</p> <p>For those that are interested, you can find an implementation of what we’ve discussed in this post over on <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/now/">my /now page</a>.</p> <div class="footnotes" role="doc-endnotes"> <hr> <ol> <li id="fn:1"> <p>I recommend <a href="https://webaim.org/techniques/headings/#visualonly" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WebAIM’s article on headings</a> for further reading on how to correctly structure your content with headings.&#160;<a href="#fnref:1" class="footnote-backref" role="doc-backlink">&#x21a9;&#xfe0e;</a></p> </li> </ol> </div>

item.title: The evolution of /now pages
item.content:encoded: <p>It was interesting to read about <a href="https://rknight.me/blog/on-transient-slash-pages/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the evolution of Robb’s /now page</a>. How he’s moving away from a transient, impersonal page of data towards something more meaningful.</p> <p>On a related note, I completely agree with <a href="https://chriscoyier.net/2025/01/04/slash-pages/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Chris’ thoughts on slash pages</a>. I found myself nodding along in agreement, to these few lines in particular:</p> <blockquote> <p>“I think it makes more sense to me to write about what I carry around <em>right now</em> and if I did it again later, it doesn’t have to replace what I’ve written before. It would be interesting and worth preserving each time.”</p> </blockquote> <p>On <a href="https://shoptalkshow.com/647/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ShopTalkShow episode 647</a>, Chris shares another concern he has with slash pages. How does anyone ever see them if they aren’t syndicated (for example via RSS)? It’s true, they’d be far more visible as blog posts.<sup id="fnref:1"><a href="#fn:1" class="footnote-ref" role="doc-noteref">1</a></sup></p> <p>I’ve been keeping <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/now/">my own /now page</a> since 2017. I’ve made countless updates to it since then. Now I think about it, it’s a real shame there’s no record of what I wrote previously. If you had nothing better to do and were really that interested, then I suppose you could trawl through my Github commits. But who in their right mind could be bothered to do that?</p> <p>This brings me to <a href="https://www.zinzy.website/now/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Zinzy’s /now page</a>, which I’m a big fan of. What I like most about it is that it feels as if you’re getting a quick glimpse into what’s happening in Zinzy’s life, at that particular moment. I like how each update is organised by date and how previous updates are preserved as an archive - just like how a regular blog works.</p> <p>It would be fun to try something similar with my own /now page. Make it feel more like a bunch of quick journal entries. This approach definitely makes the whole now page thing way more personal and interesting.</p> <p>In my head, I picture myself posting these updates from a chairlift in the Alps. Or whilst out on a hike with friends. Perhaps I’m overestimating how interesting my day-to-day life actually is. I suppose we’ll find out soon enough. Whatever the case, with the demise of Big Social, it feels like the right sort of time to make this happen.</p> <p>I expect the key to making it work is figuring out a simple system that makes posting these “now” updates as frictionless as possible. Realistically, that’s the only way I’m likely to stick with it, but I guarantee that’s easier said than done.</p> <p>Before I get too deep in the weeds with that, the first step is to change how my /now page functions. Make it act more like a blog which lists recent updates, and less like a boring transient page which rarely ever gets updated.</p> <div class="footnotes" role="doc-endnotes"> <hr> <ol> <li id="fn:1"> <p><a href="https://notes.neatnik.net/2025/01/everything-is-a-web-page" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Adam</a> and <a href="https://coryd.dev/posts/2025/most-pages-are-actually-posts/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cory</a> also have some interesting thoughts on which pages to syndicate.&#160;<a href="#fnref:1" class="footnote-backref" role="doc-backlink">&#x21a9;&#xfe0e;</a></p> </li> </ol> </div>

item.title: Sunday meal prep
item.content:encoded: <p>Trying to get into the whole food prep thing. The goal is to always have healthy options to pull out of the fridge throughout the week. I tend make unhealthy decisions when I’m short on time and there’s nothing convenient to eat, so preparing a few versatile things helps to solve this problem.</p> <p>For the last couple of weeks we’ve made a bunch of spreads and dips on a Sunday afternoon. Usually a humous, a romesco and some sort of pesto that will go well with anything, from veggie sticks to pasta. We also roast some cashews and almonds and make cacao-based energy balls to replace unhealthy sweet snacks, which I often crave towards the end of the day.</p> <p>Recently I learnt how important it is to <a href="https://youtu.be/3esF-pNAM9c?si=cOlIV89BCnkhbja0&amp;t=1771" target="_blank" rel="noopener">start the day with a savoury meal</a> (spoiler: it helps to reduce your blood glucose spikes which can lead to all sorts of disease). So yesterday we prepared all the ingredients for breakfast burritos with a bit of a healthy twist – scrambled tofu, homemade baked beans, guacamole, kimchi and spinach and chickpea flour pancakes.</p> <p>I have to say, it felt kinda weird eating a burrito for breakfast on a Monday, And part of me missed the usual porridge topped with seeds, fruit and nuts. But it was tasty nonetheless and I’m sure I can get into it.</p> <p>Hopefully we can keep this up, but let’s see how it goes. At some point I’d like to get another glucose monitor to see if this new approach to breakfast actually makes a difference.</p>

item.title: Blog questions challenge
item.content:encoded: <p>Thought I’d give the Blog Questions Challenge a go, having seen <a href="https://kevquirk.com/blog/blog-questions-challenge" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Kev</a>, <a href="https://www.lkhrs.com/blog/2025/blog-questions-challenge/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Luke</a> and <a href="https://manuelmoreale.com/blog-questions-challenge" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Manu</a> share theirs.</p> <p>I’m also not on Bear Blog, so I’m using the questions Kev adapted from <a href="https://blog.avas.space/bear-blog-challenge/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Ava’s original ones</a> for my own.</p> <h2 id="why-did-you-start-blogging-in-the-first-place">Why did you start blogging in the first place?</h2> <p>Around 2017, I started taking notes on the design and web dev stuff I was learning. Mostly so I had something to refer back to when I forgot what I’d learnt. Around the same time, I read Shawn’s post <a href="https://www.swyx.io/learn-in-public" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Learn In Public</a> or one similar, I can’t quite remember. Following that, it seemed sensible to publish these notes as posts on my site.</p> <p>Through the process I discovered that I quite enjoyed writing – how it helps you slow down and deepen your understanding of the things you’re writing about – so I kept it going. I realised this doesn’t just apply to technical posts, but also writing about life in general. That’s when I started posting about various other topics.</p> <h2 id="what-platform-are-you-using-to-manage-your-blog-and-why-did-you-choose-it">What platform are you using to manage your blog and why did you choose it?</h2> <p><a href="https://gohugo.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo</a> hosted on <a href="https://www.netlify.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Netlify</a>.</p> <p>I chose Hugo because I wanted to use a simple, open-source tool, that required minimal maintenance and that I could stick with long-term.</p> <p>What I love about Hugo is that it’s pretty much just Markdown files and a few basic templates. It doesn’t get much simpler than that. You don’t need any extra dependencies to run a Hugo site, so they can be super easy to maintain. I’ve used Hugo for the past 8 years and have no plans on switching anytime soon.</p> <p>I chose Netlify because it was one of the few options I knew of at the time, that could deploy a site from commits pushed to a Github repository. It was also super easy to set up and cost nothing. There may well be a bunch of better options these days, but I haven’t had any issues yet, so I’ve stuck with it.</p> <h2 id="have-you-blogged-on-other-platforms-before">Have you blogged on other platforms before?</h2> <p>Way back when I took more photos I used a bunch of different tools, like <a href="https://www.flickr.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">flickr</a>, <a href="https://www.tumblr.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Tumblr</a>, <a href="https://www.koken.me/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Koken</a> and <a href="https://wordpress.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Wordpress</a>.</p> <p>I had a brief spell using Medium, but since I’ve been writing I’ve mostly used Hugo.</p> <h2 id="how-do-you-write-your-posts-for-example-in-a-local-editing-tool-or-in-a-paneldashboard-thats-part-of-your-blog">How do you write your posts? For example, in a local editing tool, or in a panel/dashboard that&rsquo;s part of your blog?</h2> <p>These days all my posts start life in <a href="https://obsidian.md/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Obsidian</a>. I create a new note, then add my post template. The template adds some front matter to help organise the note, when I’m done with it later.</p> <p>For more general posts, I tend to just hammer out some words. For technical posts, I usually get a rough outline down first, then expand on that.</p> <p>Most of this happens at my desk, but Obsidian is synced with my other devices via iCloud, so I can also work on posts from my iPhone when I’m on the move.</p> <p>Once I have a rough draft, I’ll read through it, make edits and check for any obvious mistakes. Once I’m happy with it, I open the local copy of my site using <a href="https://code.visualstudio.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">VS Code</a>. Then I create a new markdown file and copy and paste the markdown from Obsidian into the new file. Next I run the local server and read through it in a browser.</p> <p>When I look at a post in a browser, I usually spot a bunch more ways to improve it. I make these changes in VS Code.</p> <h2 id="when-do-you-feel-most-inspired-to-write">When do you feel most inspired to write?</h2> <p>Usually in the mornings, when I have a fresh head.</p> <p>Often I’ll think of something I want to write about when I’m out for a run or in the shower. Or when I find a post in <a href="https://netnewswire.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">my RSS reader</a> and I feel like I have something to say about it.
