These posts often end up on <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/links/">my links page</a>.</p> <h2 id="do-you-publish-immediately-after-writing-or-do-you-let-it-simmer-a-bit-as-a-draft">Do you publish immediately after writing, or do you let it simmer a bit as a draft?</h2> <p>I tend to publish the day after I’ve written something. I like to read through a post the following morning, with a fresh pair of eyes. Then make some final edits, before pushing it live.</p> <p>I often go back to posts I’ve already published. Usually the day after. I always seem to find a ton of ways to improve a post, as I read through the live version.</p> <h2 id="whats-your-favourite-post-on-your-blog">What&rsquo;s your favourite post on your blog?</h2> <p><a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/menus-in-hugo/">Menus in Hugo</a>, because it’s the one most people have contacted me about or thanked me for.</p> <p>Or <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/okr-in-obsidian/">OKR in Obsidian</a>, because it’s the one that’s had the biggest impact on how I work.</p> <h2 id="any-future-plans-for-your-blog-maybe-a-redesign-a-move-to-another-platform-or-adding-a-new-feature">Any future plans for your blog? Maybe a redesign, a move to another platform, or adding a new feature?</h2> <p>No plans to switch platforms or take on a full-blown redesign. I mostly just chip away at it and try to make small incremental improvements.</p> <p>I do have a few things on my todo list though:</p> <ul> <li>Adding an about page</li> <li>Adding a bookmarks page</li> <li>Adding a photos section</li> <li>Adding a graveyard for dead projects</li> </ul> <p>I tend to move at a sloth-like pace, but hopefully I can tackle these things in 2025.</p>

item.title: Running in the elements
item.content:encoded: <p>Mornings are generally dark and gloomy, here in the UK, at this time of year. It’s never easy getting up and out for a run. In recent years, I’ve become somewhat of a fair-weather runner. If there’s any chance of rain, I tend to sack it off altogether, roll out my mat and do some yoga instead.</p> <p>This morning, rain seemed inevitable. Overcast, low dark clouds, all the usual signs. It was only a matter of time before a celestial downpour. For whatever reason I decided to brave it anyway. Perhaps the start of a new year has given me the extra motivation I needed.</p> <p>Within a few minutes of being out there, the wind picked up and, to no surprise, it began to rain. Soon enough it was hammering it down. Thirty seconds later I was completely sodden. I usually feel miserable when I’m caught in the rain and soaked to the bone, but today I decided to embrace it instead.</p> <p>Not sure exactly why, but I began to imagine what it must be like coming from a place where rain rarely ever falls. How would it feel if this was the first rain you’d felt in years? Or, maybe even your first ever experience of the stuff?</p> <p>In a word, it must feel <em>incredible</em>.</p> <p>I spent the final part of my run with this in mind. Trying to appreciate the cold, wet, wind and rain, beating my body and face. Out there in the elements, totally drenched, it felt amazing.</p> <p>I stopped avoiding puddles as I made my way home. In these sorts of conditions, it makes little difference, so I splashed right through them. It felt just like being a kid again. Outside in the rain, jumping in puddles, having the best of times.</p> <p>I came through the front door, dripping wet, with the biggest smile on my face.</p> <p>We’re fortunate to have “bad” weather like this in abundance here in the UK. It’s worth trying to appreciate it more.</p>

item.title: 2024 in Review
item.content:encoded: <p>With another year almost over, I’ve spent these final few days looking back at the past 12 months. Here are some of those reflections in writing - what went well, what didn’t go so well and what I learnt in the year 2024.</p> <p>For those interested in how I approach these end of year reflections, check out <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/year-in-review/">a year in review</a>. Perhaps this will give you some inspiration to start writing your own, if you don’t already.</p> <p>With that said, let’s get right to it.</p> <h2 id="what-went-well">What went well?</h2> <h3 id="general">General</h3> <p>It’s been just over a year since I moved into a new house. After initially struggling with the idea of moving, I now feel this is one of the best decisions I’ve ever made. I love the house and couldn’t be happier in this leafy part of south-east London. It’s been slow progress with the renovation work, but I’m super happy with the improvements we’ve made and I’m excited to continue the work in the new year.</p> <p>Now we have a house, we also have a bit more space, including an office room, which has been a total game changer considering we used to work together in our one-bedroom flat. More space means we’ve been able to have a bunch of friends and family staying throughout the year. It’s nice to be in a position to offer our home to others. We’ve also hosted a handful of dinners, which have been really fun.</p> <p>In a similar vein, Rebekka and I hosted a big party for her 30th birthday in October. I’ve always shied away from the idea of celebrating birthdays in a big way, but I’ve really come round to the idea. I realise it’s important to celebrate things. Whether it’s a birthday or just something that’s going well in your life. It’s also a great excuse to get friends and family together in the same room, which doesn’t happen often enough.</p> <p>On another note, it’s been a great year for Chelsea FC fans. After a change in ownership, a complete rebuild and a difficult couple of seasons, it seems like we’re finally back on track. This is my 27th (I think) season going to Chelsea games with my dad. I’m proud of that commitment. Supporting a team and watching football is a strangely addictive thing. We’ve often contemplated the point of it all, but we keep coming back because there’s nothing quite like it. The shared highs and lows, celebrating with other fans, the feeling of belonging to a community. I’ve sat with the same group for the most part of my life - many I now consider friends. The main thing we have in common is our continued commitment to a football club. How bizarre. I laugh with my dad that it’s too late to give up now.</p> <p>My streak on Duolingo is almost at 1 whole year. I’m proud of that achievement. I’ve struggled to practice German consistently in previous years, so this is a huge step in the right direction. I’ve toyed with the idea of getting private lessons, but that hasn’t happened yet. Perhaps I’ll look into this again in the new year. But, as someone who snail paces through life, I’m in no particular rush.</p> <p>I always had a book on the go this year and I’ve read some interesting stuff. Some fiction, some non-fiction. Books about finance, physics and economics. Some esoteric. Some eye-opening. Some just really entertaining. I like to keep an open mind and, as such, I’m open to reading all sorts of things. However functional and pragmatic, or wacky and out there, the subject matter may seem.</p> <h3 id="work">Work</h3> <p>This year has been my most successful year freelancing since setting up my business. A big part of that I owe to the help I’ve had from Rebekka and Ben. Right now I have a good mix of regular clients and a handful of projects already lined up 2025. There’s much still to do, such as launching <a href="https://studioeryn.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">my studio website</a>. But things are heading in the direction I want them to, which is, without doubt, the most important thing.</p> <p>Things haven’t been too bad for personal projects either. In January <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/introducing-cu-css/">I launched cu.css</a>, the CSS starter I use for both client and personal projects. In recent years, I’ve been working hard to formalise my approach to designing and coding websites. <em>cu.css</em> has been a big part of this journey. Methodologies like CUBE CSS and Utopia – which <em>cu.css</em> is heavily based on – have not only helped me create leaner, more performant websites, but have also helped to remove the uncertainty around the way I want to be doing things. The result of which is becoming a more efficient and productive web developer.</p> <p>I’m also very close to launching the first season of <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical Hugo</a>. Since I’m not in a position to commit 100% of my time to it, this one has been a long time coming. Thanks to all of you who have been waiting patiently since signing up for the pre-release. I hope it will be worth the wait and a useful resource for the Hugo community.</p> <h3 id="travel">Travel</h3> <p>In March I organised a ski trip to La Plagne in France for group of 10. I’d never organised a group trip like this before so I was kinda nervous about how it was going to pan out. Thankfully it couldn’t have gone any smoother. Everyone had a blast, including the beginners, most of whom were on skis for the first time. We’re going for round 2 in 2025, so that’s gotta be a good sign.</p> <p>I was in Germany on three separate occasions this year. At the end of March we were in Bremen, then in September and December back in Hamburg. I’m very fond of Hamburg, having lived there in the past. So it was fun to spend time there with my family and check out restaurants and sights I hadn’t been to or seen before.</p> <p>In September I took 2 weeks off to travel around Croatia, where Rebekka and I first met, almost 10 years ago. We spent time in Split, Brač, Korčula and Dubrovnik. Croatia is a beautiful place. I‘ll try not to leave it so long before I visit again.</p> <p>The rest of my year was mostly spent at home in London. However we did manage a few trips to various other parts of the UK: Rye, Wiltshire, Warwickshire, St Leonards and Dorset.</p> <h3 id="health">Health</h3> <p>I’m struggling to recall being sick at all this year, except for a cold in January. For most the year I’ve felt really good. I’ve made sure to rest when I’ve not felt my best and always tried to get plenty of sleep. I’ve also exercised consistently and been mindful about what I put in my body – trying to eat a variety of healthy food often. A while back, <a href="https://www.netflix.com/tudum/articles/stutz-the-tools" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Phil Stutz introduced me to the Life Force model</a>, so I try to prioritise work on my physical body (sleep, nutrition and exercise) as much as possible.</p> <p>It’s been a good year for running. I went for my first Parkrun on Christmas Day last year and subsequently went for a bunch more throughout the year. In May I ran the Hackney Half Marathon for the first time. I’m not sure I’ve ever had so much fun running. I have another half coming up next year, this time in Hamburg, which I’m excited about. Signing up for a race is a great way to find some focus with your training. I’d like to do more interval training in 2025 and try to improve my 5K time.</p> <p>I‘ve had another consistent year of yoga. R and I go to a classes 2-3 times per week. Since my favourite teacher took a year out, we’ve branched out to trying new studios and new teachers. It’s been fun to explore London more and experience other teaching styles. Hopefully we can continue this adventure in the new year and perhaps do a little more strength training. Everyone (particularly my PT sister) keeps telling me it’s important, especially as we grow older.</p> <p>I went bouldering with friends a bunch of times this year. I’d like to go more as it’s such a great way to catch up whilst doing something that’s good for your body. It’s just so damn expensive in London these days.</p> <h2 id="what-didnt-go-so-well">What didn’t go so well?</h2> <p>It wasn&rsquo;t a great year for publishing blog posts. I tend to start the year well, then hit a wall towards the middle of the year (typically when I’m really busy with work). I struggled to find a balance between writing course content and writing blog posts. I want to make a real effort to commit, at least, an hour each day to writing. Even when work, and life in general, gets busy.</p> <p>I didn’t complete any courses this year. I dipped in and out of <a href="https://visualizevalue.com/products/compound-content" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Compound Content</a> from Visualise Value, but I didn’t finish it. I want to change this in the new year. I picked up <a href="https://piccalil.li/complete-css/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Complete CSS</a> and <a href="https://radicaldesigncourse.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Radical Design</a> during the Black Friday sale. So if I can complete Compound Content and see these two through before this time next year, then I’ll be happy and feel like I’m not stagnating.</p> <p>I’ve made a considerable effort with digital decluttering in recent years, but I didn’t make a huge amount of progress this year. I’m still working through my old Notion bookmarks, but it always gets relegated down the todo list in favour of other more pressing tasks. I also need to add YouTube and Spotify to my todo list, as I realise I’ve created a real mess with playlists. I probably need to think more about my system and perhaps be more strict with myself when I comes to sticking with my time blocks.</p> <p>I had big plans to ski in Milton Keynes in preparation for this ski years season, but I failed miserably. Perhaps lugging skis across London is just too much effort to do regularly. With a group of friends who are now also keen to ski more regularly, perhaps we‘ll be able to hold each other accountable in 2025. We’ll see.</p> <h2 id="what-did-i-learn">What did I learn?</h2> <p>In no particular order, here are a few things I learned this year:</p> <ul> <li>Organising events is fun.</li> <li>Push yourself outside of your comfort zone, you might even enjoy it.</li> <li>The right decision is usually found within, not by following what works for others.</li> <li>Let your values dictate your actions.</li> <li>Be generous with your time and knowledge.</li> <li>Play long term games. The things you stick with the longest are typically the most rewarding. Relationships, side-projects, investing, interests and hobbies all apply here.</li> <li>Share your space, offer it to those in need.</li> <li>Reality is the product of relationships and interactions, without which there is nothing.</li> <li>Rich is what you see (income, fast cars, etc). Wealth is what you don’t see (years of boring saving and investing).</li> <li>Everything is paranormal until we understand it, at which point it becomes normal.</li> <li>Consider all life experiences, even the ones that seem implausible or difficult to comprehend.</li> </ul> <h2 id="final-words">Final words</h2> <p>All in all, 2024 has been a positive year and I’m happy with how it turned out.</p> <p>I worked hard, but also took it at my own pace. I’ve tried to manage my expectations and let go of the mindset that I should always be achieving more. As a result, it’s been the first year in a while where I never felt too stressed.</p> <p>I now realise how important it is to appreciate where you’re at in life, rather than constantly striving for more. When life it going well, acknowledge (or celebrate) it. It will help you realise that you’re doing ok.</p> <p>Writing these reflections continues to be a great way to spot progress, however slow or insignificant it sometimes feels. Looking back over past years is also a great way to benchmark progress against yourself, instead of comparing yourself others.</p> <p>As in previous years, it’s the sum of the things I’ve stuck with the most, and new things I’ve pushed myself to try, that turned out to be the most rewarding.</p> <p>Anyway, hopefully this has be as helpful to read as it has been for me to write. And, I wish you all a healthy and prosperous start to the year 2025.</p>

item.title: Exploring Hugo’s new starter theme and updates to the `new site` command
item.content:encoded: <p>As part of the Hugo v0.118.0 release, the Hugo team made some improvements to both the <code>hugo new site</code> and <code>hugo new theme</code> commands.</p> <p>The big change, as <a href="https://discourse.gohugo.io/t/creating-new-site-and-theme-skeletons-with-v0-118-0-and-later/46018" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Joe has pointed out</a>, is that <code>hugo new theme</code> command now creates a functional theme with sample content. The new theme demonstrates some of the typical features of Hugo, so it’s a great way to learn how Hugo works and a helpful starting point for theme development.</p> <p>In this post I run through these improvements and explain some of the more advanced features that you’ll find in the new starter theme. But, before we get to that, first let’s take a brief look at the updates to the <code>hugo new site</code> command.</p> <h2 id="running-the-hugo-new-site-command">Running the <code>hugo new site</code> command</h2> <p>Running <code>hugo new site [site-name]</code> from the command line will set up a new site, as expected, but with a handful of notable improvements.</p> <p>Firstly, the documentation returned to the terminal has been improved with clearer steps and more emphasis on creating a new theme.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>Congratulations! Your new Hugo site was created in /Users/harrycresswell/code/hugo/hugo-new. Just a few more steps... 1. Change the current directory to /Users/harrycresswell/code/hugo/hugo-new. 2. Create or install a theme: - Create a new theme with the command &#34;hugo new theme &lt;THEMENAME&gt;&#34; - Or, install a theme from https://themes.gohugo.io/ 3. Edit hugo.toml, setting the &#34;theme&#34; property to the theme name. 4. Create new content with the command &#34;hugo new content &lt;SECTIONNAME&gt;/&lt;FILENAME&gt;.&lt;FORMAT&gt;&#34;. 5. Start the embedded web server with the command &#34;hugo server --buildDrafts&#34;. See documentation at https://gohugo.io/. </code></pre><p>Open the site skeleton that Hugo generates and you’ll notice the directory structure is similar to before. All the project files and folders you’ll be familiar with remain, however there are two updates.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>- archetypes - default.md - assets - content - data - i18n - layouts - static - themes - hugo.toml </code></pre><p>Hugo now includes the <code>/i18n</code> folder, which is used to store <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/lang/translate/#translation-tables" target="_blank" rel="noopener">translation tables</a>. You’ll only find a need to use this folder when working with <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/multilingual/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">multilingual mode</a>, for sites that offer more than one language.</p> <p>In case you were wondering, <strong>i18n</strong> is a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Numeronym" target="_blank" rel="noopener">numeronym</a> which stands for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationalization_and_localization" target="_blank" rel="noopener">internationalization</a>.</p> <p>The <code>archetypes/default.md</code> file has also changed slightly. The value for the front matter <em>title</em> is now generated using <code>.File.ContentBaseName</code> instead of <code>.Name</code>, which was used previously.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>+++ title = &#39;{{ replace .File.ContentBaseName &#34;-&#34; &#34; &#34; | title }}&#39; date = {{ .Date }} draft = true +++ </code></pre><p>Reading the docs, it seems <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/page/file/#contentbasename" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ContentBaseName</a> will generated the title of the content from the name of the containing directory. That is, if the page is a <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/page-bundles/#branch-bundles" target="_blank" rel="noopener">branch bundle</a> (/some-directory/_index.md) or a <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/page-bundles/#leaf-bundles" target="_blank" rel="noopener">leaf bundle</a> (/some-directory/index.md). See <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/page-bundles/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">page bundles</a> for more. If the page is neither, the title will be generated using <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/page/file/#translationbasename" target="_blank" rel="noopener">TranslationBaseName</a>, which takes the file name, excluding the extension and language identifier.</p> <p>The rest of the files and folders either remain empty or as they were before the v0.118.0 release.</p> <p>With the updates to <code>hugo new site</code> covered, let’s now take a look at the <code>hugo new theme</code> command.</p> <h2 id="running-the-hugo-new-theme-command-pre-hugo-v01180-upgrade">Running the <code>hugo new theme</code> command pre Hugo v0.118.0 upgrade</h2> <p>Until Hugo v0.118.0, running <code>hugo new theme [theme-name]</code> from the command line would set up a new theme directory inside <code>/themes</code>, consisting of a basic theme structure and mostly empty files.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>my-site/ - archetypes/ - default.md - layouts/ - _default/ - baseof.html - list.html - single.html - partials/ - footer.html - head.html - header.html 404.html index.html - static/ - css/ - js/ - LICENCE - theme.toml </code></pre><p>There were, however, two files that weren’t empty. The <code>_default/baseof.html_</code> file, which demonstrated how to include partial templates and register a block. And the <code>theme.toml</code> file, which offered an example theme file configuration.</p> <p>We won’t bother exploring these legacy files, instead let’s jump ahead to the improvements.</p> <h2 id="running-the-hugo-new-theme-command-with-hugo-v01180-or-later">Running the <code>hugo new theme</code> command with Hugo v0.118.0 or later</h2> <p>Following an upgrade to Hugo v0.118.0 or later, running <code>hugo new theme [theme-name]</code> now sets up a fully functional theme with sample content.</p> <p>Here’s the new theme directory structure:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>my-theme/ - archetypes/ - default.md - assets/ - css/ - main.css - js/ - main.js - content/ - posts/ - post-3/ - bryce-canon.jpg - index.md _index.md post-1.md post-2.md _index.md - data/ - i18n/ - layouts/ - _default/ - baseof.html - home.html - list.html - single.html - partials/ - head/ - css.html - js.html - footer.html - head.html - header.html - menu.html - terms.html - static/ - favicon.ico - hugo.toml - LICENCE - README.md - theme.toml </code></pre><p>The two parts of the new theme I want to focus on most are content structure and layout templates, however before we get into that let’s quickly run through the directory structure, so we know what’s what.</p> <h2 id="understanding-the-directory-structure">Understanding the directory structure</h2> <p>The <code>/archetypes</code> folder, used for content templates, now contains a working <em>default.md</em> archetype template, instead of an empty <em>default.md</em> file, as before. This archetype template is no different from the template Hugo generates when running the <code>hugo new site</code> command and will generate the front matter for any file created using <code>hugo new content [name]</code>, however this one is obviously specific to the theme, whereas the one at the root of the project isn’t.</p> <p>The <code>/assets</code> folder, which is used store files to be processed with Hugo Pipes, now contains two sub folders – <em>css</em> and <em>js</em>. The <em>css</em> folder contains a <code>main.css</code> file containing basic styles and the <em>js</em> folder a <code>main.js</code> file, which simply logs <em>“This site was generated by Hugo”</em> to the console. We’ll get to how the theme consumes these files shortly.</p> <p>The <code>/content</code>folder, which is used to store page content, contains a various content files and folders, which we’ll look at in detail later.</p> <p>Both the <code>/data</code> folder – used to store files of structured data much like a conventional database – and the <code>i18n</code> folder – used to store translation tables for multilingual mode sites (as discussed earlier) – are empty, so we’ll skip over these.</p> <p>The <code>/layouts</code> folder contains a <em>_default</em> folder, which stores bunch of <em>default</em> layout templates. It also contains a <em>partials</em> folder, which stores partial layout templates. We’ll look at these templates in more detail shortly.</p> <p>The <code>/static</code> folder – used to store any static asset that don’t require processing by Hugo – contains a <code>favicon.ico</code> file, which creates a favicon visible in browser tabs, usually to the left of the site name.</p> <p><code>hugo.toml</code> contains the theme configuration, including the menu item which we’ll also look at later.</p> <p>The <code>LICENSE</code> file contains the standard MIT License template.</p> <p>The <code>README.md</code> file contains a few headings to help you get started writing a readme.</p> <p>The <code>theme.toml</code> file contains information about the theme.</p> <p>Ok, let’s tackle the content folder.</p> <h2 id="content-structure-and-page-bundles">Content structure and page bundles</h2> <p>Inside the <code>/content</code> folder we find an <code>_index.md</code> file at the root. This file supplies this content to the <a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/homepage/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">homepage template</a> found at <code>layouts/_default/home.html</code>. You’ll see from the <a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/lookup-order/#home-page" target="_blank" rel="noopener">homepage lookup order</a> that <code>home.html</code> is more specific than <code>index.html</code>, but otherwise the two templates are pretty much interchangeable. In other words, they do the same thing – render the homepage.</p> <p>In the root of the <code>/content</code> folder you’ll find a <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/sections/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">content section</a> called <em>posts</em>. We know this is a content section primarily because it contains an <code>_index.md</code> file, which, in this case, is used to add content to a page on our site found at <code>/posts</code>.</p> <p>The <code>/posts</code> folder also contains two other files; <code>post-1.md</code> and <code>post-2.md</code> and a folder called <code>/post-3</code>. This demonstrates that you can either store your post content as simple markdown files in the root of a content section, or instead create <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/page-bundles/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">page bundles</a>, as we see with <code>post-3</code>.</p> <p>One advantage of using page bundles is that we can keep resources associated with a specific page alongside the markdown file used for the content of the page. An example of this is the <code>bryce-canyon.jpg</code> file, found inside the <code>post-3</code> folder. These <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/page-resources/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">page resources</a> can be accessed using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/page/resources/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Resources</a> method (not to be confused with <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/resources/get/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">resources functions</a>) and can be processed in a variety of ways.</p> <p>Together, the contents of the <em>posts</em> section form a <a href="https://gohugo.io/quick-reference/page-collections/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">collection</a> of posts. Collections are rendered as a list using <a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/lists/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">list templates</a>.</p> <p>Open <code>layouts/_default/list.html</code> and you’ll see this in action:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ define &#34;main&#34; }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .Title }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ .Content }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range .Pages }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .RelPermalink }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .LinkTitle }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ .Summary }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The default list template is used to list content found within content sections at a URL path that matches the name of the content section. The pages in the content sections are stored in the Page object, so that’s why we find <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/page/pages/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Pages</a> passed to the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/go-template/range/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Range function</a>, which loops through the object and returns a collection of regular pages within the current section.</p> <p>As <code>posts</code> is the only content section inside the default theme content folder, by default the list template is only used to list out the content within this section. The result is a list of blog posts found at <code>/posts</code> in the browser.</p> <h2 id="date-localization">Date localization</h2> <p>Opening <code>layouts/_default/single.html</code> you’ll find an example of date localization.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ $dateMachine := .Date | time.Format &#34;2006-01-02T15:04:05-07:00&#34; }} {{ $dateHuman := .Date | time.Format &#34;:date_long&#34; }} &lt;time datetime=&#34;{{ $dateMachine }}&#34;&gt;{{ $dateHuman }}&lt;/time&gt; </code></pre><p>Here we find a human readable date and a date specifically for crawlers. Both are generated using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/time/format/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">time.Format function</a> which returns the date/time found in the front matter of markdown files as a formatted and localized string.</p> <p>What this means is that should you decide to expand on the theme by adding <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/multilingual/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">multilingual mode</a>, dates will render in the correct language, depending on what languages you set up in the site configuration. See the <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/multilingual/#dates" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Date localization</a> docs for more.</p> <h2 id="taxonomies">Taxonomies</h2> <p>Inside the <code>terms.html</code> partial you’ll find the code used to render tags on single post pages.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- /* </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">For a given taxonomy, renders a list of terms assigned to the page. </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">@context {page} page The current page. </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">@context {string} taxonomy The taxonomy. </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">@example: {{ partial &#34;terms.html&#34; (dict &#34;taxonomy&#34; &#34;tags&#34; &#34;page&#34; .) }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">*/}} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- $page := .page }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- $taxonomy := .taxonomy }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- with $page.GetTerms $taxonomy }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- $label := (index . 0).Parent.LinkTitle }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ $label }}:<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- range . }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .RelPermalink }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .LinkTitle }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Let’s break this down so we understand what’s happening here.</p> <p>At the top of the partial file, right below where you see the commented code, two variables have been set up which store the values <code>.page</code> and <code>.taxonomy</code>.</p> <p>As you can see from the commented <code>@example</code> at the top of the <code>single.html</code>, the values of these two variables are being passed into the partial using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/collections/dictionary/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Dictionary or “dict” function</a>, which creates a map of key-value pairs. In this case, the value of <code>.taxonomy</code> is <code>tags</code>, which is the name of the taxonomy found in the front matter of each <em>post</em> markdown file. The value of <code>.page</code> is simply the dot (<code>.</code>), which holds the context of the page (the data available to it). Without these two variables we have no data to work with in the partial, so they are both very important.</p> <p>Directly below where these two variables have been declared we find both variables used.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{- with $page.GetTerms $taxonomy }} ... {{- end }} </code></pre><p>Here, <code>$page</code> gives the <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/page/getterms/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GetTerms</a> method access to the page context. This step is important, as GetTerms is a page method, so it requires the page context in order to work. <code>$taxonomy</code> passes the <code>tags</code> data to the method, so it has data to work with.</p> <p>If this were directly inside the <code>single.html</code> template (where the context is already set to Page by default) and not within a partial, then you could achieve the same results with the following:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{- with .GetTerms &#34;tags&#34; }} ... {{- end }} </code></pre><p>Ok. Now that <code>terms.html</code> has access to the page context and the <code>tags</code> data stored in the front matter of the posts, it can render some content.</p> <p>Inside the <code>with</code> statement, where the context has now changed to <code>tags</code>, first we find the following:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{- $label := (index . 0).Parent.LinkTitle }} </code></pre><p>Here, a variable has been set up called <code>$label</code> which stores the key associated with the <code>tags</code> data. In other words, the word “Tags”.</p> <p>To grab the key, first the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/collections/indexfunction/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Index function</a> is used to get hold of the first value found in the tags data. Notice the dot (<code>.</code>) after the word <em>index</em>, this is important as it holds the tags data.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ index . 0 }} // Page(/tags/red) </code></pre><p>Remember, in programming, the first value in an array is 0 and not 1, so 0 is used. If you have a look at the front matter of each post you will find that, in each case, this value is “red”. But “red” isn’t what we’re after here, the goal in fact is to render the key (“Tags”).</p> <p>With the <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/page/parent/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Parent page method</a>, it’s possible to get the Page object of the parent section. In other words <code>tags</code> instead of <code>/tags/red</code>.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ (index . 0).Parent }} // Page(/tags) </code></pre><p>But this would return <code>Page(/tags)</code>, which isn’t formatted quite right. Instead we want “Tags” as plain text, in title case. This is where the <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/page/linktitle/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">LinkTitle</a> page method comes in.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ (index . 0).Parent.LinkTitle }} // Tags </code></pre><p>Now all that’s left to do is call the variable to render the content, which we find here:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>&lt;div&gt;{{ $label }}:&lt;/div&gt; // Tags: </code></pre><p>The final bit of logic in this partial should be fairly familiar.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- range . }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .RelPermalink }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .LinkTitle }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Here, the Range function loops through the <code>tags</code> data and renders the relative permalink and the title. Simple stuff.</p> <p>Now let’s turn our attention to scripts and styles.</p> <h2 id="css-and-javascript-inclusion">CSS and JavaScript inclusion</h2> <p>The theme skeleton includes both the CSS and JavaScript in the <code>&lt;head&gt;</code>.</p> <p>Opening the <code>baseof.html</code> template, we can see that the contents of the <code>&lt;head&gt;</code> is included as a partial.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">head</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ partial &#34;head.html&#34; . }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">head</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>If we open the <code>head.html</code> partial we can see that the CSS and JavaScript have also been included as partials, but this time as <a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/partials/#cached-partials" target="_blank" rel="noopener">cached partials</a>.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ partialCached &#34;head/css.html&#34; . }} {{ partialCached &#34;head/js.html&#34; . }} </code></pre><p>This means Hugo will cache the result, which will significantly improve performance. It only makes sense to cache partials if they don’t need to be re-rendered.</p> <p>If we open up <code>partials/head/css.html</code>, we find the following code used to render CSS.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- with resources.Get &#34;css/main.css&#34; }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- if eq hugo.Environment &#34;development&#34; }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">link</span> <span class="na">rel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;stylesheet&#34;</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .RelPermalink }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- else }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- with . | minify | fingerprint }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">link</span> <span class="na">rel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;stylesheet&#34;</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .RelPermalink }}&#34;</span> <span class="na">integrity</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Data.Integrity }}&#34;</span> <span class="na">crossorigin</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;anonymous&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/resources/get/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">resources.Get</a> function returns a global resource from the given path, which in this case is <code>css/main.css</code>. For this to work correctly, resources need to be stored in the <code>/assets</code> folder.</p> <p>If we head to the <code>/assets</code> folder, we find <code>css/main.css</code> as expected:</p> class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">none</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Heading back to <code>partials/head/css.html</code>, the next bit of logic to wrap our heads around is the <em>if else</em> statement.</p> <p>Here, the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/hugo/environment/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">hugo.Environment</a> function is used to qualify whether the current environment is <em>development</em> or not. In other words, is <code>hugo server</code> currently running a local development server? If this statement evaluates <em>true</em>, then the CSS is rendered without any processing. If the statement evaluates <em>false</em>, then the CSS will be <a href="https://gohugo.io/hugo-pipes/minification/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">minified</a> and <a href="https://gohugo.io/hugo-pipes/fingerprint/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">fingerprinted</a> with a hash string, which is useful for cache busting when caching assets. Exactly the sort of processing what we want in production.</p> <p>If we open up <code>partials/head/js.html</code>, we find a very similar approached used used to render JavaScript:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- with resources.Get &#34;js/main.js&#34; }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- if eq hugo.Environment &#34;development&#34; }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- with . | js.Build }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">script</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .RelPermalink }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">script</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- else }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- $opts := dict &#34;minify&#34; true }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- with . | js.Build $opts | fingerprint }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">script</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .RelPermalink }}&#34;</span> <span class="na">integrity</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{- .Data.Integrity }}&#34;</span> <span class="na">crossorigin</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;anonymous&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">script</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>And similar to the CSS, if we head to the <code>/assets</code> folder, we find <code>js/main.js</code>, as expected:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>console.log(&#39;This site was generated by Hugo.&#39;); </code></pre><p>The main difference here is that JavaScript is processed using <a href="https://gohugo.io/hugo-pipes/js/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">js.Build</a>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- with . | js.Build }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">script</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .RelPermalink }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">script</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>It also shows how to abstract options to a variable, then include them in a statement:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{- $opts := dict &#34;minify&#34; true }} {{- with . | js.Build $opts | fingerprint }} ... </code></pre><p>Which is just another way to express the following:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{- with . | js.Build | minify | fingerprint }} ... </code></pre><p>With the CSS and JavaScript covered, let’s turn our attention to partials.</p> <h2 id="partial-templates">Partial templates</h2> <p>We’ve already touched on cached partials, which are used to render the CSS and JS partials in the theme. These partials are cached because they presumably don’t need to be re-rendered.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ partialCached &#34;head/css.html&#34; . }} {{ partialCached &#34;head/js.html&#34; . }} </code></pre><p>There are two other approaches to partials used in the theme which we haven’t looked at yet – how to work with regular partials (that don’t need to be cached) and how to work with inline partials.</p> <p>Regular partials are used when templates need to be re-rendered, usually because of content changes. For example, you wouldn’t want to cache a partial that contained the code that renders the <code>&lt;head&gt;</code> section of your website, because the chances are high that the <code>&lt;title&gt;</code> will change on a page-by-page basis.</p> <p>In this case, you would include the partial as a regular partial include (without the word <code>Cached</code> prepending the word partial):</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ partial &#34;head.html&#34; . }} </code></pre><p>Other than that, there isn’t much difference between the two. Partial templates still live in the <code>layouts/partials</code> folder and everything works exactly the same.</p> <p>Inline partials are different. As the name suggests, Inline partials don’t live inside their own named file within the <code>layouts/partials</code> folder, but instead live inline within the template in which they are used.</p> <p>We can see an example of an inline partial inside the <code>menu.html</code> partial.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>// Include the partial code {{- partial &#34;inline/menu/walk.html&#34; (dict &#34;page&#34; $page &#34;menuEntries&#34; .) }} // Define the partial code {{- define &#34;partials/inline/menu/walk.html&#34; }} ... {{- end }} </code></pre><p>I’ve taken the code above directly from this file and simplified it to show how inline partials work.</p> <p>First the partial is defined with the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/go-template/define/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">define function</a>, then named within dumb quotes. Following this, the code to be added as a partial is included (which I’ve omitted here for clarity). Finally, as this is logic it’s important to close it out with <code>{{ end }}</code> at the end. You’ll notice this works in the exact same way as <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/go-template/block/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">defining a block</a>.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>// Define the partial code {{- define &#34;partials/inline/menu/walk.html&#34; }} S... {{- end }} </code></pre><p>Now the partial is defined, it can be included anywhere in the same template as you would a regular partial.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>// Include the partial code {{- partial &#34;inline/menu/walk.html&#34; (dict &#34;page&#34; $page &#34;menuEntries&#34; .) }} </code></pre><p>It’s important to remember that template namespace is global, so you need to make sure that the names of your partials are unique to avoid conflicts.</p> <p>Now we’ve warmed up, let’s tackle what’s possibly the most complicated part of this starter theme – the logic found inside the <code>menu.html</code> template.</p> <h2 id="menus">Menus</h2> <p>In a project using the Hugo starter theme, run <code>hugo server</code> then head to http://localhost:1313/ in a browser and you’ll see the menu right below the site title at the top of the page.</p> <p>Assuming you haven’t changed any of the menu items from their defaults, the menu consists of three links; Home, Posts and Tags. The code responsible for this menu of links can be found in the <code>menu.html</code> partial.</p> <h3 id="including-the-menu-and-passing-data-to-the-partial">Including the menu and passing data to the partial</h3> <p>Before we jump into the <code>menu.html</code> partial, first let’s take a look inside the <code>header.html</code> partial, as this is where the <code>menu.html</code> partial is included in the templates.</p> <p>Open the <code>header.html</code> partial and you’ll find the following line of code:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ partial &#34;menu.html&#34; (dict &#34;menuID&#34; &#34;main&#34; &#34;page&#34; .) }} </code></pre><p>If you read the previous section on partials then the code above will look familiar. To render the partial, the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/partials/include/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">partial function</a> is used followed by the name of the partial within double quotes.</p> <p>In this instance, we also find the following appended to the code:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>(dict &#34;menuID&#34; &#34;main&#34; &#34;page&#34; .) </code></pre><p>So what’s going on here?</p> <p>In Hugo projects, the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/collections/dictionary/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Dictionary function</a> – or its alias form <em>dict</em>, as we see here – can be used to return a map of given key-value pairs. When used in a partial include like this, <em>dict</em> passes a map of key-value pairs into the partial (in this case <code>menu.html</code> ), so that the data is available to use from inside the partial. In this case, the first key in the map is <code>menuID</code> which holds the value of <code>main</code> and corresponds to the menu ID used to identify the menu items found within the <code>hugo.toml</code>:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Home&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Posts&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/posts&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Tags&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/tags&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">30</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Of course, if, for example, we had a <em>footer</em> menu instead of a <em>main</em> menu, then the value of <code>menuID</code> would be <em>footer</em>.</p> <p>Passing the menu ID to the partial is important as it allows the <code>menu.html</code> partial to render the <em>main</em> menu items. Without specifying ”main” Hugo wouldn’t find any menu items to render on the page.</p> <p>The second key in the <em>dict</em> map is <code>page</code> and this holds the dot (<code>.</code>) as its value. In this case, the dot passes the current page context to the <code>menu.html</code> partial. Without passing the page context to the partial, it wouldn’t be possible to work with any of the <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/pages/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">page methods</a> from inside the partial. So menu features which typically require page methods, such as labelling the current page item as “active”, wouldn’t be possible.</p> <p>Now we have a grasp of how to include the menu and passing data to the partial, let’s head over to the <code>menu.html</code> partial itself and figure out how this menu is working.</p> <h3 id="rendering-the-inline-menu-partial">Rendering the inline menu partial</h3> <p>At the top of the <code>menu.html</code> partial, right below the commented code, you will notice two variables have been declared. Both of which should look familiar. The first variable, <code>$page</code>, stores the page context and the second, <code>$menuID</code>, stores the menu ID (main). These are storing the data passed into the partial via the dict function, as we just discovered.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{- $page := .page }} {{- $menuID := .menuID }} </code></pre><p>Now it’s possible to work with this data anywhere within the <code>menu.html</code> template.</p> <p>Directly below these two variable definition we find the following code:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- with index site.Menus $menuID }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- partial &#34;inline/menu/walk.html&#34; (dict &#34;page&#34; $page &#34;menuEntries&#34; .) }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This is used to render the navigation, part of which has been abstracted to an inline partial, which we will look at shortly.</p> <p>Before we do that, first let’s get a better understanding of what’s going on in the code above.</p> <p>Here, the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/go-template/with/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">With function</a> is used to render the code inside the expression <em>if</em> <code>site.Menus</code> and <code>$menuID</code> returns <em>true</em>. We know there are menu items in the <code>hugo.toml</code> file and that the partial has access to <code>$menuID</code>, as it’s been passed in, so we expect the expression to return <em>true</em>. If, let’s say, the menu items were removed, along with the menu ID, then we would expect the expression to return <em>false</em> and nothing inside the expression would render. Essentially, the With function creates a conditional statement and changes the context to whatever is passed to it.</p> <p>Notice the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/collections/indexfunction/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Index function</a> is also included. This is used to return the value of <code>$menuID</code>.</p> <p>Another way to think about this is the following:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{- with index site.Menus &#34;main&#34; }} </code></pre><p>Without the Index function, it would only be possible to return a hard coded value, as you’ve probably seen in menus found in other themes:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{- with site.Menus.main }} </code></pre><p>While this approach works just the same, the issue is that it wouldn’t allow for reusability of the <code>menu.html</code> partial (for example if we decided to also add a footer menu to our site some time in the future), so that’s why we find the <code>$menuID</code> stored in a variable.</p> <p>Before I digress any further, let’s turn our attention to the code that the With statement renders:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- partial &#34;inline/menu/walk.html&#34; (dict &#34;page&#34; $page &#34;menuEntries&#34; .) }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Here we find a <code>&lt;nav&gt;</code> element and nested <code>&lt;ul&gt;</code> which is typically used in most menus. The main difference to what you usually might expect is that the code we’d typically find within the <code>&lt;ul&gt;</code> element has been abstracted into an inline partial called <code>inline/menu/walk.html</code>. Remember the one we looked at in the partials section earlier?.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{- partial &#34;inline/menu/walk.html&#34; (dict &#34;page&#34; $page &#34;menuEntries&#34; .) }} </code></pre><p>Before we look at the code within this inline partial, first let’s take a look at the data that’s passed to the inline partial, again via <em>dict</em>, a.k.a the Dictionary function.</p> <p>The first key in the dict map is <code>page</code>, which holds the value of our <code>$page</code> variable. If you remember, <code>$page</code> holds the page context. By passing the page context to the inline partial, page methods can be used within it. It can be confusing when we get into partial inception like this, but the important thing to remember is that data and/or context needs to be passed to every partial that requires it. That includes inline partials.</p> <p>The second key in the <em>dict</em> map is <code>menuEntries</code>, which is an arbitrary name used to describe the value it holds - the dot (<code>.</code>).</p> <p>It’s important to note that the With function binds context (the dot) to the expression. What this means is that as soon as you use With, the context changes to whatever you pass in to the function. In this case, the context is no longer Page, but instead <code>site.Menus</code>, and more specifically the <code>main</code> menu. So the value of <code>menuEntries</code> actually holds the structured main menu data that we find inside the <code>hugo.toml</code> file. The inline partial now has access to the main menu data.</p> <p>Ok, it’s the final push. Now let’s look at the inline partial itself.</p> <h3 id="defining-the-inline-menu-partial">Defining the inline menu partial</h3> <p>We’ve already looked at how to define an inline partial in the partials section of this post, so I won’t go over that again. What we‘re interested in now is the code inside the partial definition found in the <code>menu.html</code> partial.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- define &#34;partials/inline/menu/walk.html&#34; }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- $page := .page }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- range .menuEntries }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- $attrs := dict &#34;href&#34; .URL }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- if $page.IsMenuCurrent .Menu . }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- $attrs = merge $attrs (dict &#34;class&#34; &#34;active&#34; &#34;aria-current&#34; &#34;page&#34;) }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- else if $page.HasMenuCurrent .Menu .}} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- $attrs = merge $attrs (dict &#34;class&#34; &#34;ancestor&#34; &#34;aria-current&#34; &#34;true&#34;) }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- $name := .Name }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- with .Identifier }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- with T . }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- $name = . }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span><span class="na">-</span> <span class="na">range</span> <span class="err">$</span><span
