class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span><span class="na">-</span> <span class="na">with</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="na">v</span> <span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span><span class="na">-</span> <span class="na">printf</span> <span class="err">&#34;</span> <span class="err">%</span><span class="na">s</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">%q&#34;</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="na">k</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="na">v</span> <span class="err">|</span> <span class="na">safeHTMLAttr</span> <span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span><span class="na">-</span> <span class="na">end</span> <span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span><span class="na">-</span> <span class="na">end</span> <span class="na">-</span><span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ $name }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- with .Children }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- partial &#34;inline/menu/walk.html&#34; (dict &#34;page&#34; $page &#34;menuEntries&#34; .) }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Quite a bit of complicated looking code here, but it’s fairly straight forward once you get your head around it. I’ll do my best to walk you through it.</p> <p>Before we begin, the important thing to realise is that all this code is actually doing is rendering the menu list items, the links within these list items and child menu items (should they exist). The brunt of complexity in this code is the logic which builds the link attributes and translates the name of the menu item (should you decide to set up multilingual mode on your site).</p> <p>To make sense of all this, let’s start at the top of the partial definition, on the line right below where we find the define function in use.</p> <p>Here we find a variable called <code>$page</code>, which stores the value <code>.page</code>, a.k.a the the page context, which has been passed into the partial via the dict function found in the partial include we looked at previously.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code> {{- $page := .page }} </code></pre><p>If you follow <code>.page</code> backwards you’ll notice that it’s been passed all the way down from the <code>header.html</code> partial, where the context is Page. With page context stored inside <code>$page</code>, it’s now available to the inline partial.</p> <p>Next we find a <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/go-template/range/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Range function</a>, which is used to iterate over collections, in this case <code>.menuEntries</code>.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{- range .menuEntries }} ... {{- end }} </code></pre><p>If you remember from the previous section, <code>.menuEntries</code> stores the <em>main</em> menu data, which was also passed into the inline partial via the dict function in the partial include. So here Range is iterating over the menu items found in the <code>hugo.toml</code> config file, similar to how a <em>forEach</em> might in JavaScript.</p> <p>Now the context has changed to the menu items, all data associated with the menu items is available. The item <code>name</code>, <code>identifier</code> and <code>URL</code>, for example, can all be used inside the inline partial.</p> <p>With that in mind, let’s look at the next chunk of code in the inline partial.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{- $attrs := dict &#34;href&#34; .URL }} {{- if $page.IsMenuCurrent .Menu . }} {{- $attrs = merge $attrs (dict &#34;class&#34; &#34;active&#34; &#34;aria-current&#34; &#34;page&#34;) }} {{- else if $page.HasMenuCurrent .Menu . }} {{- $attrs = merge $attrs (dict &#34;class&#34; &#34;ancestor&#34; &#34;aria-current&#34; &#34;true&#34;) }} {{- end }} </code></pre><p>This is the logic that determines which attributes should be added to the<code>&lt;a&gt;</code> element found further down in the partial definition. We’ll look at this anchor tag in more detail, but first let’s breakdown this logic.</p> <p>On the first line in the code above a variable called <code>$attrs</code> has been declared which stores <code>.URL</code> as the value.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{- $attrs := dict &#34;href&#34; .URL }} </code></pre><p><a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/menu-entry/url/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">URL</a> returns the relative permalink of the page associated with the given menu entry. In this case, the Dictionary function (dict) is used to create a map with a key called “href” used to label the URL. The reason for this is that <code>href</code> is the HTML attribute used to render URL’s in links, so by providing <em>href</em> as the key, Hugo will be able to build the link attributes correctly.</p> <p>Next we find the logic itself:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{- if $page.IsMenuCurrent .Menu . }} {{- $attrs = merge $attrs (dict &#34;class&#34; &#34;active&#34; &#34;aria-current&#34; &#34;page&#34;) }} {{- else if $page.HasMenuCurrent .Menu . }} {{- $attrs = merge $attrs (dict &#34;class&#34; &#34;ancestor&#34; &#34;aria-current&#34; &#34;true&#34;) }} {{- end }} </code></pre><p>Which we might interpret in plain english as the following:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ if this evaluates true }} {{ do this }} {{ otherwise, if this evaluates true }} {{ do this instead }} {{ end }} </code></pre><p>In the first part of the logic, <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/page/ismenucurrent/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">IsMenuCurrent</a> is used to check if the current page matches the current menu item. Notice <code>IsMenuCurrent</code> is appended to the <code>$page</code> variable from earlier. This is important as <code>IsMenuCurrent</code> is a page method, so will only work within the Page context. <code>$page</code> provides the context.</p> <p>OK, so if the statement on the first line in the code above evaluates <em>true</em>, then the <code>$attrs</code> variable is reassigned with a new value:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{- $attrs = merge $attrs (dict &#34;class&#34; &#34;active&#34; &#34;aria-current&#34; &#34;page&#34;) }} </code></pre><p>Notice <code>=</code> is used to assign a new value to the variable, whereas when the variable was initialised, <code>:=</code> was used. This is an important distinction – <code>:=</code> is used to initialise a variable and <code>=</code> is used to update or reassign its value.</p> <p>So what is the value that’s being assigned? It’s two more attributes; a <code>class</code> with the value of <code>active</code> and <code>aria-current</code> with the value of <code>page</code>. As before, both are passed as a map of key-value pairs, using the Dict function. Notice the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/collections/merge/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Merge function</a> is used to merge this new map with the original <code>$attrs</code> map, rather that replace it entirely.</p> <p>Again, in plain english we might interpret this as the following:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ if the current page matches the current menu item }} {{ update $attrs from `dict &#34;href&#34; .URL` to `dict &#34;href&#34; .URL &#34;class&#34; &#34;active&#34; &#34;aria-current&#34; &#34;page&#34;` }} {{ otherwise, if this evaluates true }} {{ do this instead }} {{ end }} </code></pre><p>Now let’s take a stab at the second part of this logic. This should be much easier, now that we have a good grasp of what’s going on in the first part.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{- else if $page.HasMenuCurrent .Menu . }} {{- $attrs = merge $attrs (dict &#34;class&#34; &#34;ancestor&#34; &#34;aria-current&#34; &#34;true&#34;) }} ... </code></pre><p>Here, we we find an else statement with a new condition. This is what will happen if the first statement evaluates <em>false</em>. This time, the <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/page/hasmenucurrent/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">HasMenuCurrent</a> is passed to check whether the page matches the page associated with one of the child menu entries. If this statement evaluates <em>true</em>, then similar to how we saw before, <code>$attrs</code> is updated to include a slightly different map of key-value pairs, then merged with the original <code>$attrs</code> map.</p> <p>Let’s look at this in plain english once again:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ if the current page matches the current menu item }} {{ update $attrs from `dict &#34;href&#34; .URL` to `dict &#34;href&#34; .URL &#34;class&#34; &#34;active&#34; &#34;aria-current&#34; &#34;page&#34;` }} {{ otherwise, if the page matches the page associated with one of the child menu entries }} {{ update $attrs from `dict &#34;href&#34; .URL` to `dict &#34;href&#34; .URL &#34;class&#34; &#34;ancestor&#34; &#34;aria-current&#34; &#34;true&#34;` }} {{ end }} </code></pre><p>At this point you may have realised that, by default the starter theme doesn’t have any child menu entries. So you’d be right in thinking that the second part of this logic won’t ever evaluate <em>true</em>.</p> <p>That is, unless we add a child menu item to the menu configuration found in the <code>hugo.toml</code> file. Take the below for example.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Posts&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/posts&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">identifier</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;posts&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Post 1&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">pageRef</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/posts/post-1&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">parent</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;posts&#39;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice we’ve added an <code>identifier</code> key to one of the menu items, in this case the <code>posts</code> item. The value matches the name of the item, but could be anything. Next we add a new menu item and add a <code>parent</code> key to it with a value that matches the <code>identifier</code> of the menu item we want it to be the child of.</p> <p>With this new menu configuration in place, the second statement in the logic in question will now evaluate <em>true</em> for the <em>Posts</em> menu item.</p> <p>It’s important to realise that, at this stage, all the logic is doing is updating the value of <code>$attrs</code> variable, depending on how each statement evaluates. The attributes haven’t been applied to the link tag yet, where we would usually expect to find them. We’ll get to the part where this happens shortly.</p> <p>First, let’s take a brief look at the following code, found inside the <code>menu.html</code> partial, directly below the logic we’ve just addressed.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{- $name := .Name }} {{- with .Identifier }} {{- with T . }} {{- $name = . }} {{- end }} {{- end }} </code></pre><p>First we find a new variable, <code>$name</code>, which stores the value of <code>.Name</code>. As we’re still inside the Range, the current context is still <code>.menuEntries</code> (our menu items). Therefore, it’s clear that <code>.Name</code> is the name of our menu item, taken from our menu object in <code>hugo.toml</code>.</p> <p>Next we find a <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/go-template/with/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">With function</a> which changes the context to whatever is passed into it and will execute if the expression returns <em>true</em>. In this case, <code>.Identifier</code> is passed in. By default, no menu item in the menu configuration includes an <code>Identifier</code>, so this is our first clue to what’s happening here – absolutely nothing, unless an Identifier is added to any of the menu items.</p> <p>Within this logic we find another With function. This time the dot (a.k.a the current context) is passed in, which remains unchanged – the <code>.Identifier</code>. Here the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/lang/translate/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Translate function</a> is used (in its alias form “T”) to translate the Identifier value, should it exist. Here’s our second clue – this logic will only execute if we decided to set up a <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/content-adapters/#multilingual-sites" target="_blank" rel="noopener">multilingual site</a> and create translation tables for our content. You can learn more about <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/lang/translate/#simple-translations" target="_blank" rel="noopener">creating simple translations</a> in the Hugo docs, so I won’t go into any more detail about that now. All we need to understand right now is that <code>.Identifier</code> is used to identify the content to be translated.</p> <p>Finally, if the two With expressions evaluate <em>true</em>, then the value of the <code>$name</code> variable is reassigned (using <code>=</code>) to the translated menu item.</p> <p>As with the <code>$attrs</code> variable, which we looked at earlier, it’s important to realise that all this logic does is conditionally update the value of the <code>$name</code> variable. It’s doesn’t actually manipulate or apply anything to the HTML found in the theme. Instead, it simply prepares these variables so they are ready to be used.</p> <p>Now we’ll look at how these variables are actually applied to the HTML in the theme. To do that, let’s consider the list item and everything found within it.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span><span class="na">-</span> <span class="na">range</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="na">k</span><span class="err">,</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="na">v</span> <span class="na">:</span><span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">$attrs</span> <span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span><span class="na">-</span> <span class="na">with</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="na">v</span> <span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span><span class="na">-</span> <span class="na">printf</span> <span class="err">&#34;</span> <span class="err">%</span><span class="na">s</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">%q&#34;</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="na">k</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="na">v</span> <span class="err">|</span> <span class="na">safeHTMLAttr</span> <span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span><span class="na">-</span> <span class="na">end</span> <span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span><span class="na">-</span> <span class="na">end</span> <span class="na">-</span><span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ $name }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- with .Children }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- partial &#34;inline/menu/walk.html&#34; (dict &#34;page&#34; $page &#34;menuEntries&#34; .) }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The first thing to point out is we’re still inside the Range here and the context is still <code>.menuEntries</code> (the menu items). So we’re expecting this code to return a list item for each menu item in the menu configuration found inside <code>hugo.toml</code>.</p> <p>Let’s take a closer look at the anchor tag in the code above.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span><span class="na">-</span> <span class="na">range</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="na">k</span><span class="err">,</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="na">v</span> <span class="na">:</span><span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">$attrs</span> <span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span><span class="na">-</span> <span class="na">with</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="na">v</span> <span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span><span class="na">-</span> <span class="na">printf</span> <span class="err">&#34;</span> <span class="err">%</span><span class="na">s</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">%q&#34;</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="na">k</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="na">v</span> <span class="err">|</span> <span class="na">safeHTMLAttr</span> <span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span><span class="na">-</span> <span class="na">end</span> <span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span><span class="na">-</span> <span class="na">end</span> <span class="na">-</span><span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ $name }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>First we find the logic which builds the link attributes held in the <code>$attrs</code> variable. For this to work, <code>$attrs</code> is passed into the Range function which <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/go-template/range/#maps" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ranges over the map</a> of data and stores it in two variables <code>$k</code> and <code>$v</code>. We can assume these variables represent the <em>key</em> and the <em>value</em>.</p> <p>The With function then changes the context to the value and is used to ensure this code only executes if a value exists. If the With expression evaluates <em>true</em>, the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/fmt/printf/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">fmt.Printf function</a> is then used to format the attributes correctly. It’s worth taking a look at <a href="https://pkg.go.dev/fmt#hdr-Printing" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Go’s Fmt package</a>, specifically the printing verbs <code>%s</code> and <code>%q</code> to better understand how this is comes together.</p> <p>With the attributes formatted correctly, the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/safe/htmlattr/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">safeHTMLAttr function</a> is piped to declare that the key-value pairs are safe HTML attributes and ensure everything renders without errors.</p> <p>The final thing to note in the anchor tag is the <code>$name</code> variable, which is used to render the link text. Simple stuff.</p> <p>All that’s left to look at now before we wrap up this breakdown of the <code>menu.html</code> partial is the following:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- with .Children }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- partial &#34;inline/menu/walk.html&#34; (dict &#34;page&#34; $page &#34;menuEntries&#34; .) }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{- end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The big give away here is the <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/menu-entry/children/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Children function</a>, which is used to return a collection of child menu entries, should any exist. As we established earlier, no child menu items exist in the theme by default, so we don’t expect this code the execute. However, should we add child menu items to the theme, then this code would run and build a nested unordered list containing existing child list items.</p> <p>Notice that these potential list items are rendered via the inline partial that we’ve just been dissecting. What this tells us is that you can include an inline partial within itself, again performing a partial inception of sorts, should the need present itself, as it has here. This is a great example of why it makes sense to build partials with flexibility and reusability in mind.</p> <p>The <code>menu.html</code> partial is easily the most complicated part of the Hugo starter theme, so don’t stress too much if you’re still struggling to get your head around it. I’ve written about <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/menus-in-hugo/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">working with menus in Hugo</a> in detail, so check that post out if you’re looking for a slightly easier implementation.</p> <h2 id="final-words">Final words</h2> <p>Great effort if you’ve made it this far. I wasn’t planning on writing over seven thousand words about Hugo improvements but here we are.</p> <p>I want to wrap this one up by saying that it’s great to see more emphasis on building themes from scratch, or at least, building sites by using a functional barebones theme as a starting point. It might seem like a trivial thing, but this is a big step in the right direction for Hugo development.</p> <p>Before now, installing a theme from <a href="https://themes.gohugo.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo Themes</a> often felt like the recommended next step after setting up a new site. While this might make sense if you want to get a Hugo site up and running quickly, personally I’m not sure if it’s always the most sensible approach. Existing Hugo themes are typically built by experienced developers. Often they’re complex and not the most beginner friendly.</p> <p>If you really want to learn Hugo then nothing beats building your own theme. My hope is that these changes will encourage more of us to do just that.</p> <p>Hopefully this post has helped you get your head around some of the complexities of the default starter theme and has provided you with some encouragement to give theme development a go.</p> <p>If you spotted any mistakes whilst reading this post then please let me know and I will do my best to rectify them.</p>

item.title: Slash pages and /slashes
item.content:encoded: <p><a href="https://rknight.me/blog/slash-pages/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">“Slash pages”</a> is a great phrase for root-level pages usually found on personal websites. I’m into it.</p> <p>Well done to <a href="https://calebhearth.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Caleb Hearth</a> and <a href="https://shellsharks.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Shellsharks</a> for coining the phrase. Also Brandon for building <a href="https://slashpages.net/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">slashpages.net</a>, which lists the most common slash pages and provides a clear definition:</p> <blockquote> <p>Slash pages are common pages you can add to your website, usually with a standard, root-level slug like /now, /about, or /uses. They tend to describe the individual behind the site and are distinguishing characteristics of the IndieWeb.</p> </blockquote> <p>Annie’s idea of creating <a href="https://weblog.anniegreens.lol/2024/05/a-slashes-page-for-my-slash-pages" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a slashes page for your slash pages</a> is also really clever.</p> <p>It’s not always clear which slash pages exist when you visit a website. Unless they’re all listed in a navigation somewhere – which invariably they aren’t. So listing them on their own dedicated page is extremely helpful.</p> <p>Now we can add our <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/slashes">/slashes</a> page somewhere in our site navigation instead.</p> <p>I like this idea a lot. It give visitors a quick way to access all the slash pages on your site (some of which may otherwise be missed). It also solves the problem of cluttering your navigation with too many links. Great stuff.</p> <p>Thanks to <a href="https://manuelmoreale.com/slashes" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Manu</a>, for putting me onto this, and <a href="https://www.brycewray.com/posts/2024/06/slash-pages-existing-new/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Bryce</a> for encouraging me to revisit my existing slash pages and prune back the dead growth.</p>

item.title: AI-free, human-generated
item.content:encoded: <p>It’s encouraging to see folks declaring their work <em>AI-free</em> or <em>human-generated</em>, in some form or another.</p> <p>Jared White has pledged that <a href="https://www.whitefusion.studio/#stop-publicizing-progress-without-committing-to-ethics" target="_blank" rel="noopener">everything his web design studio creates will be 100% AI-free</a> going forward:</p> <blockquote> <p><strong>Our pledge to you in 2024 and beyond:</strong> 100% <mark>AI-free</mark> productions. All the solutions we provide are of the finest <mark>human-grade quality</mark>. We’re not afraid of <em>progress</em>! But we’re not buying the <em>bullshit</em>. Read more about our <a href="https://www.whitefusion.studio/ai-ethics" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AI Ethical Framework</a> we’ve laid out which presents the minimum threshold required for us to evaluate any “generative AI” toolchain.</p> </blockquote> <p><a href="https://vhbelvadi.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Venkatram</a> has taken another approach, by adding the following statement to the footer of his website:</p> <blockquote> <p>Climate friendly and completely AI-free.</p> </blockquote> <p><a href="https://weblog.anniegreens.lol/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Annie Sturdivant</a> has done something similar, also adding a statement in the footer of her website:</p> <blockquote> <p>Handcrafted by a human.</p> </blockquote> <p><a href="https://notbyai.fyi/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Not by AI</a> takes this idea a step further by offering a “produced by a human” badge that you can add to your work. You’ll qualify as long as your work isn‘t generated by AI or at least 90% of it is created by humans.</p> <blockquote> <p>“Not By AI badges are created to encourage more humans to produce original content and help users identify human-generated content.”</p> </blockquote> <p>According the the <a href="https://notbyai.fyi/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Not by AI</a> website, this is important because:</p> <blockquote> <p>Artificial Intelligence (AI) is trained using human-created content. If humans stop producing new content and rely solely on AI, online content across the world may become repetitive and stagnant.</p> </blockquote> <p>Makes sense. Though you may argue that AI will simply augment human creativity – just like any other creative tool – rather than stagnate it. I suppose that depends on the degree to which we embrace it.</p> <p>What you can’t argue with is the detrimental impact that AI is having on the environment. Powering AI server farms and training AI data models consumes a sickening amount of energy, with studies warning that <a href="https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-67053139" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the AI industry could consume as much energy as a country the size of the Netherlands by 2027</a>.</p> <p>There’s also the ethical implications of <a href="https://english.elpais.com/economy-and-business/2024-01-01/the-hidden-labor-force-behind-chatgpt-the-drama-of-the-ghost-workers.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AI companies exploiting ghost workers</a> to moderate content. The legal implications of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2024/jan/08/ai-tools-chatgpt-copyrighted-material-openai" target="_blank" rel="noopener">stealing copywrited material to train AI models</a>. And the opportunity cost of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2024/mar/27/ai-apocalypse-could-take-away-almost-8m-jobs-in-uk-says-report" target="_blank" rel="noopener">loosing your job to AI</a>. The list goes on.</p> <p>For these reasons, I’m right behind this “AI-free” idea and what it stands for.</p> <p>I like moving slowly, doing difficult things that take time and effort. There’s no better feeling than using your fallible head and hands to create original work. Ultimately, it’s rewarding. Work to be proud of.</p> <p>Can the same be said of the generative AI <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slop_%28artificial_intelligence%29" target="_blank" rel="noopener">slop</a> that’s currently polluting the web? Probabaly not.</p> <p>Anyway, I hope to see this “AI-free” trend continue to grow. I’ll return to this post to document more examples, as and when I find them.</p> <hr> <p><strong>27th Aug 24</strong>: <a href="https://piccalil.li/about/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Piccalilli</a> commits to being an AI-free publication:</p> <blockquote> <p>We maintain that quality by focusing on web standards technology and a guaranteed commitment that <mark>we will never publish content written by large language models or other flavours of “AI”</mark>.</p> </blockquote> <p><strong>31st August 25</strong>: <a href="https://dbushell.com/2025/06/18/ai-policy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">David Bushell</a> breaks down some of the reasons his work is AI free in a <a href="https://dbushell.com/ai/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AI Policy</a>.</p> <p><strong>10th September 25</strong>: Derek Sivers has a short statement in the footer of his website that reads:</p> <blockquote> <p>Everything here is written by me, personally, not an AI.</p> </blockquote> <p>He also links to his <a href="https://sive.rs/ai" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AI manifesto</a> page, which details how he uses generative AI/LLM tools in his work.</p>

item.title: Upgrading Hugo to 0.126.1
item.content:encoded: <p>Last week I upgraded Hugo from <a href="https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/releases/tag/v0.115.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener">v0.115.0</a> to <a href="https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/releases/tag/v0.126.1" target="_blank" rel="noopener">v0.126.1</a>. With all the Hugo sites I manage (for myself and clients), I was half expecting a few breaking changes to fix as a result of the update.</p> <p>But this is Hugo we’re talking about here and <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/breaking-changes-upgrading-hugo/">I’ve been pleasantly surprised in the past</a> at how few issues you tend to run into when upgrading versions. So I was feeling somewhat confident this time round.</p> <p>Luckily, all sites were unscathed by <a href="https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/releases?page=3" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the documented breaking changes of v.0.123.0</a>, but there were a few warning and other minor things to fix, which I’ll run through in this post, along with the solutions.</p> <h2 id="fixing-the-siteisserver-warning">Fixing the <code>.Site.IsServer</code> warning</h2> <p>Following the upgrade, when running <code>hugo sever</code> Hugo displayed the following warnings in the terminal.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>WARN Site.IsServer was deprecated in Hugo v0.120.0 and will be removed in a future release. Use hugo.IsServer instead. </code></pre><p>With <code>.Site.IsServer</code> now depreciated, the simple update, as suggested, is to use <code>hugo.IsServer</code> instead.</p> <h2 id="fixing-the-author-key-warning">Fixing the <code>Author</code> key warning</h2> <p>Another warning shown when running <code>hugo server</code> was the following:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>WARN The author key in site configuration is deprecated. Use params.author.name instead. </code></pre><p>With author key now been depreciated, adding something like the following to your configuration file won’t be possible in upcoming releases.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">Author</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Harry Cresswell&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">github</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;https://github.com/harrycresswell&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">linkedin</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;https://linkedin.com/in/harrycresswell/&#34;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Instead, Hugo wants you to treat author as a param:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">params</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">params</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">author</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Harry Cresswell&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">github</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;https://github.com/harrycresswell&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">linkedin</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;https://linkedin.com/in/harrycresswell/&#34;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Inside your templates, what was once this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ with .Site.Author.name }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">meta</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;author&#34;</span> <span class="na">content</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ . }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Become this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ with .Site.Params.author.name }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">meta</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;author&#34;</span> <span class="na">content</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ . }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>With the warnings out of the way, there were two minor issues I ran into following the upgrade.</p> <h2 id="finding-an-alternative-for-filepath">Finding an alternative for <code>File.Path</code></h2> <p>I haven’t quite worked out the reasons why yet, but for some reason Hugo v0.126.1 doesn’t seem to like the use of <code>.File.Path</code>.</p> <p>I was using it on one of my sites to conditionally render a partial on certain pages.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nx">eq</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">File</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Path</span> <span class="s">&#34;colour/_index.md&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">partial</span> <span class="s">&#34;colors.html&#34;</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I couldn’t seem to fix the issue using either the <code>.File</code> or <code>.Path</code> method, so I’ve resorted to using <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/resource/relpermalink/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">RelPermalink</a> to check the relative permalink instead.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nx">eq</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">RelPermalink</span> <span class="s">&#34;/logo/&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">partial</span> <span class="s">&#34;logos.html&#34;</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I actually prefer the solution above. It achieves the exact same results and it’s easier to make sense of.</p> <h2 id="custom-params-on-language-top-level">Custom params on language top level</h2> <p>The final issue I ran into was another depreciation which caused a build error. This time encountered when serving sites which use Hugo’s <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/multilingual/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Multilingual mode</a>.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>ERROR deprecated: config: languages.en.languagenameshort: custom params on the language top level was deprecated in Hugo v0.112.0 and will be removed in Hugo 0.127.0. Put the value below [languages.en.params]. See https://gohugo.io/content-management/multilingual/#changes-in-hugo-01120 </code></pre><p>Similar to the Author key above, Hugo now wants us to move <code>languageNameShort</code> from the top level of the language config to the param level.</p> <p>In other words, something like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">languages</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">languages</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">en</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">languageName</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;United Kingdom&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">languageCode</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;en-gb&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">languageNameShort</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;uk&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">contentDir</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;content/en&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Needs to be rewritten like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">languages</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">languages</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">en</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">languageName</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;United Kingdom&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">languageCode</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;en-gb&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">contentDir</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;content/en&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">languages</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">en</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">params</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">languageNameShort</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;uk&#34;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Nothing too challenging about that.</p> <h2 id="final-words">Final words</h2> <p>I’m always impressed at how straight forward it is to maintain Hugo websites and upgrade to the latest releases of the Hugo binary. This is testament to Hugo and its built-in features, which typically means there’s little need to rely on third party dependencies.</p> <p>I don’t always upgrade Hugo to the latest version, but there were two new features released in v0.126.0 that I’m keen to check out. The first is the long-awaited <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/content-adapters/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Content Adapters</a>, which allows you to build pages from a remote data source. The second is the introduction of the <a href="https://gohugo.io/getting-started/configuration-markup/#extras-extension" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Goldmark Extras extension</a>, which enables inserted text, mark text, subscript and superscript. A subtle improvement to markdown authoring, but one I’m particularly excited about. Now I no longer have to misuse <code>&lt;em&gt;</code> to add text highlighting in markdown content. Instead, I can ==surround text in two sets of equal signs== to create <mark>highlighted text</mark>.</p>

item.title: Reducing CSS
item.content:encoded: <p>Since formalising <a href="https://cu.harrycresswell.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">my CSS boilerplate</a>, I’ve come to realise that many CSS problems that I’d typically solved with unique component based styles (using BEM or similar), can actually be solved using a handful of reusable styles.</p> <p>For this I have <a href="https://cube.fyi/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CUBE CSS</a> and techniques from <a href="https://every-layout.dev/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Every Layout</a> to thank.</p> <p>With this in mind, last week I set out to rewrite the CSS on my personal site with the aim of cleaning up redundant styles and make some general improvements. In the process I managed to reduce the file size of my stylesheet by 33% – all with virtually zero change to the overall design.</p> <p>Maybe this isn’t much to shout about when it concerns some low-traffic personal website, but this would be a big deal for a commercial website. Savings like this can improve site speed, increase conversion and ultimately lead to more sales. And all it took was a simple audit of my styles and a slight rethink about how I write CSS.</p> <p>Let me explain what’s changed and how I’ve managed to achieve the exact same results from 134 fewer CSS rules.</p> <h2 id="removing-unused-styles">Removing unused styles</h2> <p>First I combed through my Hugo templates and CSS files to remove any unused styles, most of which were probably the remnants of some previously abandoned feature.</p> <p>Maybe I could have used a tool to help with this step, but with a modest amount of styles, I decided to keep things simple and do this bit by hand.</p> <p>The process involved working through my stylesheets and comparing them with my template files to see which classes were no longer being used, then removing any unused styles. Nothing glamorous, just good old grunt work.</p> <h2 id="improving-site-wide-variables-by-adopting-utopia">Improving site wide variables by adopting Utopia</h2> <p>Next I set out to improve the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/:root#declaring_global_css_variables" target="_blank" rel="noopener">global variables</a> which permeate through the rest of my CSS.</p> <p>First I converted all SASS variables to <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Using_CSS_custom_properties" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CSS custom properties</a>. Next I changed my Utopia fluid type scale <a href="https://github.com/harrycresswell/harry/commit/b5202cbaf11450413a137a07d698306248ac5b15" target="_blank" rel="noopener">from CSS locks to CSS Clamp</a>.</p> <p>Following this, I ditched my old SASS based spacing system in favour of, you guess it, a fluid responsive scale using <a href="https://utopia.fyi/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Utopia</a>.</p> <p>Now, both type and spacing on my site resizes fluidly depending on viewport width or device. To make this happen, Utopia makes heavy use of the Clamp function, providing a scale of Custom Properties.</p> <p>For type:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-css" data-lang="css"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">:</span><span class="nd">root</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--step--1</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">clamp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">0.8889</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">0.8455</span><span class="kt">rem</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.2168</span><span class="n">vi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--step-0</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">clamp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">0.9024</span><span class="kt">rem</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.4878</span><span class="n">vi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.25</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--step-1</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">clamp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">1.125</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">0.9543</span><span class="kt">rem</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.8537</span><span class="n">vi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.5625</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--step-2</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">clamp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">1.2656</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">0.9973</span><span class="kt">rem</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">1.3415</span><span class="n">vi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.9531</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--step-3</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">clamp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">1.4238</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.0267</span><span class="kt">rem</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">1.9855</span><span class="n">vi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">2.4414</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--step-4</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">clamp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">1.6018</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.036</span><span class="kt">rem</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">2.8292</span><span class="n">vi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">3.0518</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>And for space:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-css" data-lang="css"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">:</span><span class="nd">root</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--space-3xs</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">clamp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">0.25</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">0.2283</span><span class="kt">rem</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.1087</span><span class="n">vi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">0.3125</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--space-2xs</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">clamp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">0.4565</span><span class="kt">rem</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.2174</span><span class="n">vi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">0.625</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--space-xs</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">clamp</span><span class="mf">0.3261</span><span class="n">vi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">0.9375</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--space-s</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">clamp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">0.913</span><span class="kt">rem</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.4348</span><span class="n">vi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.25</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--space-m</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">clamp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">1.5</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.3696</span><span class="kt">rem</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.6522</span><span class="n">vi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.875</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--space-l</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">clamp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.8261</span><span class="kt">rem</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.8696</span><span class="n">vi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">2.5</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--space-xl</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">clamp</span><span class="mf">1.3043</span><span class="n">vi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">3.75</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--space-2xl</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">clamp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">3.6522</span><span class="kt">rem</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">1.7391</span><span class="n">vi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">5</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--space-3xl</span><span class="p">:</span> <span <p>With the additional switch to using <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_logical_properties_and_values" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Logic Properties</a> where possible, all this good work resulted in far fewer lines of CSS.</p> <h2 id="move-as-much-css-a-possible-to-global-styles">Move as much CSS a possible to global styles</h2> <p>After improving my variables, the next step was to move as much of my CSS as possible to global styles.</p> <p>Global styles aim to broadly style as much as possible. This is done by targeting HTML elements, using <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Type_selectors" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Type selectors</a>. The result of creating global styles is HTML that looks great without any additional classes. This is the exact approach used by classless CSS frameworks like <a href="https://watercss.kognise.dev/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Water.CSS</a>, <a href="https://concrete.style/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Concrete.css</a> and <a href="https://simplecss.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Simple.css</a>.</p> <p>Notable improvements to my global styles include removing the margin from headings, which is now handled using the <code>.flow</code> utility. But more on that later.</p> <p>Similarly, I’ve also managed to ditch many of the utility classes I was using to create the various link styles on my site. improve reusability of code between projects. For example, not all website projects I work on will use forms, so by keeping the CSS used for forms inside a <code>_form.scss</code> partial, I can easily remove form styles for that particular project.</p> <p>It’s worth mentioning that this is the only feature I now require SASS for – to break my CSS into partial files, then import them all into a <code>main.scss</code> file.</p> <h2 id="solve-common-layout-problems-with-intrinsically-responsive-and-reusable-layout-compositions">Solve common layout problems with intrinsically responsive (and reusable) layout compositions</h2> <p>One of the biggest improvements I’ve made to my CSS was adopting the concept of Compositions from <a href="https://every-layout.dev/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Every Layout</a> and <a href="https://cube.fyi/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CUBE CSS</a>.</p> <p>Compositions are skeletal styles that create flexible layouts containers for content. Importantly, they are reusable, not tied to any specific context and don’t depend on the use of media queries. Instead, they adapt and reconfigure themselves to fit any context or device.</p> <p>In the past, I’d often handle layout problems like this on the component level. For example, to style my navigation layout I might have created a component like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-css" data-lang="css"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">Nav</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">display</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">flex</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">gap</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nb">calc</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nf">var</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">--</span><span class="kc">space</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">*</span><span class="mf">1.5</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Then, to style the layout of page pagination items I might create another component with very similar styles:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-css" data-lang="css"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">Pagination</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">display</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">flex</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">flex-wrap</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">wrap</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This would result in lots of repetition, where I’d have several different components, each with virtually the same CSS.</p> <p>With compositions, I can avoid this repetition by creating context agnostic layouts. These layouts can be used in any context that requires such a layout.</p> <p>Take the <code>.cluster</code> composition as an example, which creates flex items which <em>cluster</em> inline, until space no longer permits.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-css" data-lang="css"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">cluster</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">display</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">flex</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">flex-wrap</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">wrap</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">gap</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">var</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">--</span><span class="kc">space</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nf">var</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">--</span><span class="kc">space</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">xs</span><span class="p">));</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">justify-content</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">var</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">--</span><span class="n">cluster</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="kc">horizontal</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">alignment</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">flex-start</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">align-items</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">var</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">--</span><span class="n">cluster</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="kc">vertical</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">alignment</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">center</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I’m now using <code>.cluster</code> to create a flexible layouts for my <em>navigation</em>, <em>page pagination</em>, <em>taxonomy tags</em> and <em>post author</em> component. Using one CSS class, I can now tackle many similar layout problems found in various different places.</p> <h2 id="use-utility-classes-for-specific-problems-that-global-styles-and-compositions-dont-solve">Use utility classes for specific problems that global styles and compositions don’t solve</h2> <p>In a utility-first approach, utility classes make up the majority of styles and are the primary method of applying styles to HTML. If you’ve used Tailwind before, then you will be familiar with this approach.</p> <p>To be clear, I’m not using utility classes in this way.</p> <p>Instead, I use utility classes is to solve specific problems that my compositions or global CSS styles don’t solve. In other words, they aren’t the first thing I reach for, but something to lean on when nothing else solves the problem.</p> <p>Two such utilities have made a big impact in reducing the amount of CSS my site design requires. Both solve problems concerning the space between elements.</p> <p>The first is the <code>.flow</code> utility, which creates consistent space and rhythm between elements.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-css" data-lang="css"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">flow</span> <span class="o">&gt;</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">margin-top</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">var</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">--</span><span class="n">flow</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="kc">space</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="kt">em</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This technique was popularised as <a href="https://every-layout.dev/layouts/stack/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Stack</a> layout by Heydon Pickering and Andy Bell in Every Layout. It works by applying margin to direct sibling elements. Flow is incredibly useful for creating space between prose elements, for example the headings and paragraphs found in a blog post.</p> <p>With liberal use of <code>.flow</code>, I’ve been able to remove the styles I’d typically use to create space between elements. For example, I no longer need to litter my base styles with the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_selectors/Selectors_and_combinators#next-sibling_combinator" Consider my old <code>.Hero</code> styles as an example:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-css" data-lang="css"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">Hero</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">padding-top</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">6</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">padding-bottom</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">6</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>With the reusable <code>.region</code> utility, I can achive the exact same results in a variety of places. For example, my <em>site header</em>, <em>site footer</em> and <em>newsletter signup form</em> all rely on the <code>.region</code> class for their vertical spacing.</p> <p>With considered use of utilities I’ve been able to make some big reductions in the amount of CSS required to style my site. However, utilities don’t always provide the solution, particularly when it comes to more complex UI.</p> <h2 id="create-blocks-and-combine-with-utilities-for-more-complex-pieces-of-ui">Create blocks (and combine with utilities) for more complex pieces of UI</h2> <p>According to <a href="https://cube.fyi/block.html#block" target="_blank" rel="noopener">cube.fyi</a>: “A block is a skeletal component or organisational structure. the default vertical alignment of <code>flex-start</code> with <code>flex-end</code>.</p> <p>By using this approach, I’ve been able to simplify the complexity of most of the block components on my site. And, in certain cases, I’ve managed to remove the need to create block classes entirely. This has obviously lead to a considerable reduction in the amount of CSS required to style my website.</p> <h2 id="create-exceptions-for-state-and-style-modifiers">Create Exceptions for state and style modifiers</h2> <p>According to <a href="https://cube.fyi/exception.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">cube.fyi</a>, “An exception is a deviation from the rules outlined in a block“, however, personally, I’m also using exceptions for deviations in compositions and – in the case of links (see global styles section above) – global styles.</p> <p>In my CSS, exceptions deal with changes in state or style of an element. They replace BEM/SUITCSS modifiers. For example, with SUITCSS, I might have modified the default button style by adding a <code>Button--secondary</code> class.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Button Button--secondary&#34;</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;#&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Reply by email<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This modifier class would have changed the button style from the default style to a secondary style.</p> <p>Using CUBE CSS Exceptions, however, it’s possible to achieve the same results using data attributes which override or extend the default styles.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;button&#34;</span> <span class="na">data-variant</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;secondary&#34;</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;#&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Reply by email<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>While this doesn’t necessarily reduce the amount of CSS I’m writing, it certainly reduces the number of classes required and improves clarity in my templates. It also, to quote the <a href="https://cube.fyi/exception.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">cube.fyi</a> docs again, “provides a useful hook for both CSS and JavaScript.”</p> <p>But, the real magic happens when combining exceptions with compositions. Remember, compositions create flexible layout without the need for media queries to adapt to different contexts. And with fewer media queries, the amount of CSS required to solve layout problems is greatly reduced.</p> <p>For example, the CSS for the grid layout I use on certain case study pages now looks like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-css" data-lang="css"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">grid</span> class="kc">auto</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="kc">fill</span><span class="p">),</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nf">minmax</span><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Whereas, before I achieved the same results with a mix of BEM style <em>block</em>, <em>element</em> and <em>modifier</em> classes, along with breakpoints to handle the layout change from smaller to larger viewports.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-css" data-lang="css"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">grid</span><span class="o">[</span><span class="nt">data-layout</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="nv">--grid-min-item-size</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">clamp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">16</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">50</span><span class="kt">vw</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">26</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">grid</span><span class="o">[</span><span class="nt">data-layout</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">&#39;25x4&#39;</span><span class="o">]</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--grid-placement</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">auto</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">fit</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">--grid-min-item-size</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">clamp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">20</span><span class="kt">vw</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">26</span><span class="kt">rem</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>That’s a couple of lines of CSS for each layout, and not a media query in sight.</p> <h2 id="summary">Summary</h2> <p>There’s no doubt that adopting the <a href="https://moderncss.dev/contextual-spacing-for-intrinsic-web-design/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">principles of intrinsic web design</a> and using modern CSS techniques can make a huge contribution towards reducing CSS. Fortunately, these two aspects of web development often go hand in hand, which makes the future look promising.</p> <p>Additionally, much of this stuff has already been formalised into practical solutions. For that we have various clever folk in our industry to thank.</p> <p>If you’re serious about writing better CSS and less of it, then <a href="https://every-layout.dev/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Every Layout</a> by Andy Bell and Heydon Pickering is a fantastic place to learn about flexible, algorithmic layout design. Likewise, <a href="https://utopia.fyi/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Utopia</a> from James Gilyead and Trys Mudford, in my view, is <em>the</em> place to learn about and generate fluid responsive type, space and grid systems, which do away with breakpoints. Finally, when it comes to writing and organising CSS sensibly, there are few better approaches to turn to than Andy’s <a href="https://cube.fyi/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CUBE CSS</a>.</p> <p>Much of my understanding of modern CSS techniques I owe to these guys.</p>

item.title: Digital clean up day
item.content:encoded: <p>In case you missed it, March 16th 2024 was <a href="https://www.digitalcleanupday.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Digital Clean Up Day</a>, a global initiative aimed at raising awareness about digital pollution, encouraging individuals and companies to declutter and organise their online presence.</p> <p>So why is this important and what’s in it for us?</p> <h2 id="the-impact-of-digital-clutter">The impact of digital clutter</h2> <p>Notifications piling up, a disorganised desktop, an overflowing inbox, hundreds of open browser tabs – at some point, we’ve all felt overwhelmed by the digital stuff we accumulate.</p> <p>When we’re disorganised we struggle to focus, we loose things, we repeat ourselves, we loose track of the task at hand and our productivity slows.</p> <p>In <a href="https://www.nngroup.com/articles/simplicity-vs-choice/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Simplicity Wins over Abundance of Choice</a>, Hoa Loranger talks about how excess of choices often leads to fatigue and impacts our decision making.</p> <blockquote> <p>“As the number of choices increases, so does the effort required to collect information and make good decisions.”</p> </blockquote> <p>Hoa’s article primarily concerns user experience, but the same is true of digital clutter – it’s difficult to avoid decision paralysis when too many options are on the table. All that chaos creates inefficiency and negatively impacts mental wellbeing. Over the long term it can lead to chronic stress and anxiety.</p> <p>And then there’s the physical impact.</p> <p>Digital hoarding, as it’s commonly know, is a direct product of using software which makes it easy to accumulate files, and not so easy to delete them. All this data requires vast amounts of computing power to process, which depletes batteries faster and reduces the lifespan of our digital devices, as a result.</p> <p>Let’s not forget that all these files need to be stored somewhere, too. Many of the apps we use rely on cloud storage to store the files we create, and this has to be paid for. The more digital clutter we create, the more we find ourselves paying for extra storage space to accommodate. And this incessant need for storage has a detrimental impact on the environment.</p> <p>As Gerry McGovern puts it in <a href="https://gerrymcgovern.com/books/world-wide-waste/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The World Wide Waste</a>:</p> <blockquote> <p>“Digital is physical. Digital is not green. Digital costs the Earth. Every time I download an email I contribute to global warming. Every time I tweet, do a search, check a webpage, I create pollution. Digital is physical. Those data centers are not in the Cloud. They’re on land in massive physical buildings packed full of computers hungry for energy. It seems invisible. It seems cheap and free. It’s not. Digital costs the Earth.”</p> </blockquote> <p>This is the sad and unfortunate realisation that most of us are now facing, so what can we do about it?</p> <h2 id="organising-your-life-with-a-digital-declutter">Organising your life with a digital declutter</h2> <p>Digital decluttering helps to reduce digital distractions and reveal what’s important.</p> <p>As Iryna Komazova writes in <a href="https://www.worldcleanupday.org/post/embracing-simplicity-the-indubitable-benefits-of-reducing-digital-clutter" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Embracing simplicity: the indubitable benefits of reducing digital clutter</a>:</p> <blockquote> <p>“Reducing digital clutter is synonymous with prioritizing what truly matters”.</p> </blockquote> <p>With fewer distractions it is easier to focus. With less stuff competing for our attention, productivity improves and we feel less stress and anxiety.</p> <p>But digital decluttering doesn’t just positively impact our productivity and personal wellbeing. It also improves our finances and helps to reduce the impact digital is having on the planet.</p> <p>Less clutter requires less computing power and less storage space, which reduces the negative impact to our wallets <em>and</em> the environment.</p> <h2 id="how-to-clean-up-your-digital-presence">How to clean up your digital presence</h2> <p>Reducing digital clutter can be a time consuming process. But for the aforementioned reasons, it’s well worth the effort. Here are a few ideas of how you might make a start decluttering your digital existence.</p> <p>Clean up your smartphone by deleting unused apps and delete large media files sent in group chats. Move older photos onto an external hard drive. I tend to do this at the beginning of each year, only keeping the previous years worth of photos and videos on my device.</p> <p>Clean out your mailbox(s) by organising any emails you need to keep hold of in folders and archiving or deleting old emails which are no longer needed.</p> <p>Clean up your hard drive by organising active projects into folders and deleting old files or moving them to an external hard drive.</p> <p>You might also consider deleting the data from any web apps you no longer use and closing your accounts.</p> <p>As I wrote about previously, there’s plenty of <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/software-that-encourages-deletion/#software-to-help-you-delete-existing-data" target="_blank" rel="noopener">software to help you delete existing data</a> from social media, cloud storage and hard drives.</p> <p>I’d also recommend reading <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/40672036-digital-minimalism" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Digital Minimalism</a> by Cal Newport, if you haven’t already. In the book, Cal offers a full 30-day plan to help you digitally declutter. What’s interesting about Cal’s approach is that it’s less about cleaning up digital artefacts and more to do with learning how to be intentional about the technology you use. There’s plenty to take from it.</p> <h2 id="what-im-doing-to-clean-up-my-digital-presence">What I’m doing to clean up my digital presence</h2> <p>I’m currently working on decluttering my Notion account, with the aim to eventually move all content out of the app, so I can close my account. For a long while I used Notion for everything, so unfortunately this isn’t a small task.</p> <p>Where possible, I’m trying to reduce my dependency on apps which rely on cloud storage or make it difficult to control your data. Instead, favouring applications which use local storage or give me more control over the data I create. I’ve written more about this in <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/software-that-encourages-deletion/#software-that-prioritises-local-data-storage" target="_blank" rel="noopener">software that encourages local storage</a>.</p> <p>A while back I stumbled across Steph Ango’s <a href="https://stephango.com/file-over-app" target="_blank" rel="noopener">File over app</a> philosophy:</p> <blockquote> <p>“If you want to create digital artefacts that last, they must be files you can control, in formats that are easy to retrieve and read.
