Use tools that give you this freedom.”</p> </blockquote> <p>This makes a lot of sense from the perspective of ownership, resilience and sustainability. Data that you control is typically much easier to organise and manage.</p> <p><a href="https://obsidian.md/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Obsidian</a>, the Markdown based writing app, of which Steph is the founder, follows the <em>File over app</em> philosophy. I’m using it for pretty much everything that I once used Notion for – note taking, bookmarking, project management, you name it. All this now happens in plain-text files inside an Obsidian vault (folder) on my local machine.</p> <p>One of the many things I like about this approach is that working with plain-text files makes decluttering a simple task. I can either delete files I no longer need or move files that I’ve archived to an external hard drive for safe keeping. Working with markdown files locally also means no vendor lock-in. You’re in full control of your data which has many positive implications for privacy and security.</p> <p>My goal moving forward is to only use cloud storage for active project files – files I need to access to regularly on multiple devices. Any past projects, which I no longer consider active, or files I need access to infrequently, will all live on an external hard drive.</p> <p>I have plans to wipe the data from my inactive social media accounts (that’s pretty much all of them) and close all my accounts. But I’m not sure exactly when this will happen as I already have a lot on my plate with this project.</p> <h2 id="final-thoughts">Final thoughts</h2> <p>The problem with digital clutter is that it’s so much easier to create than clean up. To get on top of the problem we really need to start <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/software-that-encourages-deletion/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">rethinking how we design software</a> and move away from the patterns currently used.</p> <p>Sadly, for most of my life online I’ve given little thought to the impact digital clutter is having, both to myself and the environment. I wish I had become aware sooner, as over the years I’ve created my fair share.</p> <p>But awareness counts for something, at least, and a digital declutter is a good place to start. To make any reasonable progress, I’ve found it helps to dedicate a regular block of time in my calendar to the task. To me, my weekly declutter is time well spent. It helps me feel clearer, calmer and more focused with my work. It’s also helping me to slow down and think more intentionally about the technology I choose to use. Hopefully, in time, this ritual will turn into a habit.</p>

item.title: Software that encourages deletion
item.content:encoded: <p>In <a href="https://css-irl.info/design-patterns-that-encourage-junk-data/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Design Patterns that Encourage Junk Data</a>, Michelle talks about the huge amount of data we accumulate and the impact storing it in “the cloud” is having on the environment. Frighteningly most of that data is junk.</p> <p>As Michelle writes:</p> <blockquote> <p>It’s estimated that <a href="https://volume.lboro.ac.uk/digital-waste-polluting-the-planet" target="_blank" rel="noopener">up to 88%</a> of the data stored in the cloud is ROT (Redundant, Obsolete or Trivial) data, or <a href="https://www.gartner.com/en/information-technology/glossary/dark-data" target="_blank" rel="noopener">“dark data”</a>: data collected by companies in the course of their regular business activities, but which is not used for any other purpose. It all amounts to a lot of junk data that has no purpose, that will never be needed or looked at again.</p> </blockquote> <p>Reading Hidde’s follow up post, <a href="https://hidde.blog/links/design-that-encourages-deletion/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Design that encourages deletion</a>, got me thinking:</p> <ul> <li>Which existing design patterns may offer a solution to this problem?</li> <li>And, what software currently exists that encourages deletion of data, or where data deletion is a primary feature of the product?</li> </ul> <p>Here are some thoughts and a few software examples.</p> <h2 id="software-where-data-self-destructs">Software where data self-destructs</h2> <p>Ephemeral data storage – that is, apps which automatically destroy data after a certain period of time – isn’t a new concept. Most of us are familiar with the self-destructing nature Snapchat videos and Instagram Stories. But what lesser-known apps exist that also focus on ephemeral data storage?</p> <p><a href="https://privnote.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Privnote</a> is a browser based note-taking tool that allows you to send notes that will self-destruct after being read.</p> <p><a href="https://safenote.co/upload-file" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Safenote</a> allows you to share files with end-to-end encryption and a link that expires automatically, “so you can keep what you share privately and make sure your stuff doesn&rsquo;t stay online forever”, as Safenote puts it.</p> <p><a href="https://1ty.me/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">1ty.me</a> allows you to send one time self-destructing links for sharing sensitive information like passwords and log in details.</p> <p><a href="https://getconfide.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Confide</a> is a messenger app with which you can send end-to-end encrypted, self-destructing and screenshot-proof messages. Messages disappear forever after they are read once, making them as private and secure as the spoken word.</p> <p>We seem to see the self-destructing data pattern mostly often used in communication software and, for obvious reasons, these tools are mostly promoted for their privacy/security benefits. But what other types of software could utilise this design pattern?</p> <p>What’s great about self-destructing data is that it takes the burden off the end-user, meaning there’s no need to “clean up” the data you create. Instead, the responsibility is passed to the software creator. This isn’t without its pitfalls, of course, but perhaps slightly more resilient than expecting responsible data housekeeping from end-users.</p> <h2 id="software-to-help-you-delete-existing-data">Software to help you delete existing data</h2> <p>For those that <em>do</em> have the time, energy and inclination to clean up the redundant data they create, then there’s lots of apps out there that help do just that. Here are a few that come to mind.</p> <p><a href="https://redact.dev/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Redact</a> is a desktop app which can help you automatically clean up your old posts from services like Twitter, Reddit, Facebook and Discord.</p> <p><a href="https://tweetdeleter.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Twitter Deleter</a> is another option to help you delete old posts from Twitter.</p> <p>Tools that help you remove data exposed by third-party companies also come to mind. These solutions are mostly marketed around reclaiming your privacy. But, in reality, through the process you’re also removing your data from potentially many datacenters.</p> <p><a href="https://incogni.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Incogni</a>, <a href="https://helloprivacy.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hello Privacy</a> and <a href="https://www.optery.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Optery</a> all fall into this category.</p> <p><a href="https://volume.lboro.ac.uk/digital-waste-polluting-the-planet/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">How digital waste is polluting the planet</a> (referenced by Michelle above), suggests that much of this redundant data not only stems poor data housekeeping/management, but also the accumulation of duplicate data.</p> <p>Tools such as <a href="https://www.ccleaner.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CCCleaner</a>, <a href="https://macpaw.com/gemini" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Gemini 2</a> and <a href="https://dupeguru.voltaicideas.net/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DupeGuru</a> can help you identify duplicate files and remove them from both your local machine and cloud storage.</p> <p>Whilst these apps are all useful in their own right, they only help us deal with the redundant data we’ve already accumulated (or lost control of).</p> <p>So I have to agree with Michelle and Hidde here – if we want to reduce the environmental impact of data storage, then we have to consider how data is handled from the design stage. Part of that might mean designing sofware that doesn’t actually store data in the first place. After all, if we don’t store data, then there’s nothing to delete.</p> <h2 id="software-that-prioritises-local-data-storage">Software that prioritises local data storage</h2> <p>Perhaps we should be asking ourselves whether we even need store all our data in ”the cloud”, then choose the software we use accordingly?</p> <p>Ross Wintle’s <a href="https://notes.veryuseful.app/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">JSON: Notes</a> app uses local storage to store data directly in the browser, so data never even hits a datacenter in the first place.</p> <p><a href="https://usethyme.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Thyme</a>, a simple time logging tool – which I recently discovered via Ross’s post <a href="https://rosswintle.uk/2024/02/a-manifesto-for-small-static-web-apps/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">A manifesto for small, static, web apps</a> – also uses local storage to store data directly in the browser. What’s interesting about Thyme is that whilst the app stores your data in the browser by default, you <em>can</em> use cloud storage to sync your data across devices should you wish to. With this pattern, data storage is opt-in rather than the default, which seems like a clever solution. This also means that, by default, you don’t need to create an account to use the app, which is pretty cool in and of itself. The downside of this approach is that the browsers cache can be cleared at anytime, so it’s only really useful for fleeting or ephemiral data, that doesn’t need to be stored long-term.</p> <p>I don’t have a wide list of examples of software that falls into this category, but hopefully you get the idea. For many of the apps we use, it’s possible that we don’t even need to store our data permanently. Relying on local storage may, in fact, be more than enough for our needs. And that doesn’t necessarily mean relying on the browsers local storage. There’s something to be said for storing data on your local machine, too.</p> <p><a href="https://obsidian.md/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Obsidian</a>, the local-first Markdown editor, comes to mind here. It’s just a bunch of Markdown files, which sit on your machine until you decide to back your data up on a hard drive or pay for cloud storage. <a href="https://www.icloud.com/notes" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Apple Notes</a>, <a href="https://culturedcode.com/things/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Things</a>, <a href="https://museapp.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Muse</a>, <a href="https://actualbudget.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Actual</a> and <a href="https://superhuman.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Superhuman</a> are some other good examples of popular local-first apps, which just use the Cloud to sync data between devices or for collaboration purposes.</p> <p>Perhaps it’s time to favour desktop apps (local-first) over web apps (cloud-first)? Or, where possible, opt for web apps that prioritise browser-based local storage?</p> <p>Whatever the case, making local data storage the default and cloud data storage an opt-in, might well increase the friction of creating redundant data in the Cloud.</p> <p>Would software designed with this approach in mind help us make progress in discouraging junk data?</p> <h2 id="final-thoughts">Final thoughts</h2> <p>Some fairly rough ramblings there, but hopefully enough to spark some ideas.</p> <p>I will do my best to keep this post updated with any new software I come across which encourages the deletion of data. In the meantime, if you have any thoughts on this topic or if you know of any software I’ve missed then please let me know and I’ll add them in.</p>

item.title: Adding a “last updated” date to posts
item.content:encoded: <p>I often find myself updating posts I’ve previously published. Usually this happens when I re-read what I’ve written and think of a better way to say it. Or when I discover more about the subject and I feel a supplement is relevant. Sometimes it’s when my process changes, which typically outdates the post, compared to the way I’m currently doing things.</p> <p>Whatever the case, these updates happen frequently. They keep the content on my personal site somewhat evergreen, which I like and feel is important. But it‘s not always clear to readers when content has changed.</p> <p>To solve this, I’d eventually like to add some form of footnotes to document the exact changes. But as an interim solution, I’m adding a date to these posts (or pages) which specifies when the content was updated. You’ll find this “updated” date just beneath the published date on certain pages on my site, such as on my <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/app-defaults/">app defaults</a> post.</p> <p>If you also build your site using <a href="https://gohugo.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo</a>, then adding this fuctionality is straight forward to automate. In this post I’ll explain how it works.</p> <h2 id="understanding-publishdate-and-lastmod">Understanding <code>.PublishDate</code> and <code>.Lastmod</code></h2> <p>Getting a “Last updated” date set up on your pages requires two Hugo page methods – <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/page/publishdate/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">PublishDate</a> and <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/page/lastmod/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Lastmod</a>.</p> <p><code>.PublishDate</code> returns the publish date of your content, whereas <code>.Lastmod</code> returns the date a page was last modified.</p> <p>Consider the following code found in my <code>single.html</code> template.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ $published := .PublishDate | time.Format &#34;:date_medium&#34; }} {{ $updated := .Lastmod | time.Format &#34;:date_medium&#34; }} </code></pre><p>First, we grab the published date and assign it to a variable, in this case the variable is called <code>$published</code>. Then, we use the <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/page/lastmod/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Lastmod</a> method to grab the date the page was last modified. Again, the value is stored in a variable, this time called <code>$updated</code>.</p> <p>It’s important to note, by default, Hugo will look for a value for both <code>publishDate</code> and <code>lastmod</code> set in the front matter of a page:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>--- title: A new post publishDate: 2024-02-01T00:40:04-07:00 lastmod: 2024-02-05T00:40:04-07:00 --- Some post content. </code></pre><p>This may be convenient depending on your needs, but personally I’d rather automate this step, if I can. That way I don’t have to remember to manually change the <code>lastmod</code> value in the front matter, every time I update a page.</p> <p>Assuming you’re using Git to manage your project and your code is stored in a repository – Github or similar – then this is a simple problem to solve.</p> <p>With the following added to your <code>hugo.toml</code> config file, you can forget about adding <code>lastmod</code> values to your front matter altogether.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-Toml" data-lang="Toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">enableGitInfo</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="kc">true</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now your <code>lastmod</code> date will derive from the last git commit of a given page. See the <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/page/gitinfo/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Gitinfo</a> method for more details.</p> <h2 id="comparing-publishdate-and-lastmod">Comparing <code>.PublishDate</code> and <code>.Lastmod</code></h2> <p>The final step in getting this working is to compare <em>publishDate</em> with <em>lastmod</em>. Then return the date the page was last modified (when the last commit was made), should the two values differ.</p> <p>Let’s head back to our <code>single.html</code> file, for an example:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ $published := .PublishDate | time.Format &#34;:date_medium&#34; }} {{ $modified := .Lastmod | time.Format &#34;:date_medium&#34; }} {{ if ne $published $modified }} &lt;span&gt; Updated: {{ $modified }} &lt;/span&gt; {{ end }} </code></pre><p>Notice we’re using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/go-template/if/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">if</a> function and the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/collections/where/#operators" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ne comparison operator</a>, to check whether the two values are “not equal to” each other. <em>if</em> returns a boolean value (<code>true</code> or <code>false</code>), so if this statement holds <code>true</code>, then we return the value of <code>$modified</code>, in other words, our last modified date.</p> <h2 id="formatting-time-to-the-day-not-the-second">Formatting <code>time</code> to the day, not the second</h2> <p>Notice both <code>date</code> and <code>lastmod</code> consist of <a href="https://pkg.go.dev/time#time" target="_blank" rel="noopener">time</a> values, which, when generated, will return values to the nearest second, by default.</p> <p>Here’s that example content file once again.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>--- title: A new post publishDate: 2024-02-01T00:40:04-07:00 lastmod: 2024-02-05T00:40:04-07:00 --- Some post content. </code></pre><p>Therefore, it’s important to format dates to the day, rather than second. Doing so will ensure the comparison is between days “not equal to“ each other, rather than seconds “not equal to“ each other. That way, the <em>if</em> condition won’t always return <code>true</code> when comparing that the two values do not match.</p> <p>We can achieve this by using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/time/format/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">time.format</a> method as a pipe, so we get consistent dates, to the day.</p> <p>Let’s consider those variables once again:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ $published := .PublishDate | time.Format &#34;:date_medium&#34; }} {{ $modified := .Lastmod | time.Format &#34;:date_medium&#34; }} </code></pre><p>Using <code>:date_medium</code> returns something like: <code>Jan 27, 2023</code>, which is what we’re looking for.</p> <p>Now our <em>if</em> statement is checking that the day differs, rather than the seconds – exactly what we want. As a result, the “last updated” date will only show on content updated days later than the publish date, rather than seconds later.</p> <h2 id="summary">Summary</h2> <p>It’s worth mentioning, whilst I’ve used <code>publishDate</code> in the context of the examples in this post, you could quite easily compare <code>lastmod</code> with the value of <code>date</code>, using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/page/date/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Date</a> method instead.</p> <p>In other words, this works just as well:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>--- title: A new post date: 2024-02-01T00:40:04-07:00 lastmod: 2024-02-05T00:40:04-07:00 --- Some post content. </code></pre><p>With you front matter using a <code>date</code>, as above, your template might look like this:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ $published := .Date | time.Format &#34;:date_medium&#34; }} {{ $modified := .Lastmod | time.Format &#34;:date_medium&#34; }} {{ if ne $published $modified }} &lt;span&gt; Updated: {{ $modified }} &lt;/span&gt; {{ end }} </code></pre><p>Ok, that’s all for this one.</p>

item.title: OKR in Obsidian
item.content:encoded: <p>I’ve tried various methods to stay on track and reach my goals, but OKR is the only goal setting framework I’ve really managed to make work.</p> <p>A large part of that success I put down to using OKR with <a href="https://obsidian.md/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Obsidian</a>. The <del>note taking and knowledge management</del> writing app which has become a major part of my workflow. Obsidian has a community plugin called Periodic Notes, which combined with templates, checklists and reoccurring reminders, really brings this OKR workflow together.</p> <p>Here’s a little bit about OKR and how I‘m making it work in Obsidian.</p> <h2 id="okr-a-goal-setting-framework">OKR: a goal setting framework</h2> <p>OKR consists of Objectives and Key Results.</p> <p>The first step is to set clear objectives that you wish to accomplish. In other words, the goals you want to achieve. They should be significant, concrete, clearly defined, aspirational and motivating.</p> <p>You may decide to only use OKR for your work, in which case you would typically create one objective per calendar quarter. However, you may also wish to use OKR for your personal life too, in which case you would create one objective per life area, so two objectives in total per quarter.</p> <p>The next step is to break these objectives into key results. Key results are benchmarks or milestones that lead you towards achieving your objectives. They should be specific and measurable, so you can easily track your progress and reflect on your success.</p> <p>Each objective typically consists of 3-5 key results, which are often written out below the objective. However, another popular approach is to use the following statement:</p> <p>I will (Objective) as measured by (Key Results).</p> <p>OK, so how does this work in Obsidian?</p> <h2 id="how-im-using-okr-in-obsidian">How I’m using OKR in Obsidian</h2> <p>The key to making OKR work in Obsidian is the <a href="https://github.com/liamcain/obsidian-periodic-notes" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Periodic Notes</a> plugin, which helps you plan your OKRs across quarterly, weekly and daily notes. All of which are created from templates.</p> <p>Head to <code>Settings &gt; Community Plugins &gt; Browse</code> to install the plugin.</p> <p>You will also need to ensure the <a href="https://help.obsidian.md/Plugins/Templates" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Templates</a> Core Plugin is enabled. To do this, head to <code>Settings &gt; Core Plugins &gt; Templates</code>, then toggle the switch to active the plugin.</p> <h3 id="the-quarterly-note">The quarterly note</h3> <p>At the beginning of each quarter I create a quarterly note.</p> <p>With the aformentioned plugins installed, you can do this in Obsidian by using the shortcut <code>Cmd+P</code> to open the command palette, then by typing <em>quarterly</em>, followed by <code>Enter</code>.</p> <p>The Periodic Notes plugin generates a new note for the quarter using my <code>quarterly</code> template:</p> <h4 id="templatesquarterlymd">templates/quarterly.md</h4> <pre tabindex="0"><code># {{title}} ## Objectives _The overall goals you want to accomplish in this quarter._ ### Professional **Objective**: #### Key results _How you will achieve your objective._ ### Personal **Objective**: #### Key results _How you will achieve your objective._ ## Weekly _Add links to weekly notes here._ ## OKR quarterly review ### Have you completed your key results? ### If you haven’t completed your key results, why was this? ### Did your key results lead to the overall objective? ### What did you learn this quarter? </code></pre><p>Inside this note I list one <em>professional</em> objective and one <em>personal</em> objective for the quarter. For each objective I create key results which bring me closer to achieving the objective.</p> <p>There’s also a section where I list my weekly notes for reference, but more on this later.</p> <p>At the end of each quarter I answer the questions in the <em>OKR quarterly review</em> section. This helps me reflect on my progress over the quarter and gets me thinking about the upcoming quarter. I have a reoccurring reminder set up in my calendar that reminds me to complete my quarterly review.</p> <p>Here‘s an example of my <em>2024-Q1</em> quarterly note:</p> <h4 id="journalquarterly2024-q1md">journal/quarterly/2024-Q1.md</h4> <pre tabindex="0"><code># 2024-Q1 (Jan - Mar) ## Objectives _The overall goals I want to accomplish in this quarter._ ### Professional **Objective**: Move my business in a product direction. #### Key results _How you will achieve your objective._ ![[24-Q1 ERYN Launch SCSS starter]] ![[24-Q1 ERYN Make SCSS starter post launch improvements]] ![[24-Q1 PH Complete module 1 (up and running) content]] ![[24-Q1 PH Rebuild course.ph.com]] ### Personal **Objective**: Get back into a regular german practice. #### Key results _How you will achieve your objective._ ![[Learn 5 new words per week]] ![[Take 5 IRL classes]] ![[speak German for 10 minutes each day]] ## Weekly - [[2024-W01]] - [[2024-W02]] ## Quarterly review ### Have I completed my key results? ### If you haven’t completed key results, why was this? ### Did my key results lead to the overall objective? ### What did you learn this quarter? </code></pre><p>You’ll notice that each of my key results is actually a note in itself. I create the note for each key result using another template called <code>key-result</code>:</p> <h4 id="templateskey-resultmd">templates/key-result.md</h4> <pre tabindex="0"><code>--- tags: [&#34;okr&#34;] --- # {{name}} ## Initiatives - [ ] ... </code></pre><p>These are essentially projects notes, where I list initiatives (actions) that lead to completing the project and so achieving the key result.</p> <p>I aim to create no more than 3-4 key results per quarter, for each objective. I then embed each key result note into my quarterly note under either my <em>professional</em> or <em>personal</em> objective using the following format: <code>![[YEAR-QUARTER AREA PROJECTNAME]]</code>. Notice the exclamation mark at the beginning. This tells Obsidian to embed the contents of the note, rather than simply link to the note.</p> <p>Here’s an example of a recent key result.</p> <h4 id="projects24-q1-eryn-launch-scss-startermd">projects/24-Q1 ERYN Launch SCSS starter.md</h4> <pre tabindex="0"><code>--- tags: [&#34;okr&#34;] --- # Launch [[ERYN SCSS starter (cu.css)]] ## Initiatives - [x] Create blog post about project ([[Introducing cu.css]]) - [x] Make GitHub repo public - [x] Pin repo to GitHub profile - [x] Publish [[Introducing cu.css]] on personal site </code></pre><h3 id="the-weekly-note">The weekly note</h3> <p>At the beginning of each week I create a weekly note.</p> <p>To do this, do the same as before, by using the shortcut <code>Cmd+P</code> to open the command palette, then type <em>weekly</em> followed by <code>Enter</code>.</p> <p>This generates a new note for the week using my <code>weekly</code> template:</p> <h4 id="templatesweeklymd">templates/weekly.md</h4> <pre tabindex="0"><code># {{date:gggg [Week] ww}} ## Reminders - [ ] Add this weekly note to quarterly note - [ ] Write up initiatives for the week ## Initiatives for the week _Take a look at last weeks review and check in with OKRs_ - [ ] ... ## Weekly review ### What went well this week? - ### What didn’t go so well this week? - ### What&#39;s my biggest challenge right now? - ### What help do I need? - ### What did I learn? - ### What are my initiatives for next week? - </code></pre><p>I’ve added another reoccurring reminder in my calendar, this time every Monday, which tells me to set up a weekly note, so I never forget.</p> <p>I plan each week by looking at my key results for the quarter and picking out a few initiatives that I feel like working on. I then list these under a section called <em>Initiatives for the week</em>. I also check my weekly note from the previous week, for any outstanding initiatives which I didn’t manage to complete.</p> <p>Here’s an example of one of my weekly notes:</p> <h4 id="journalweekly2024-w01md">journal/weekly/2024-W01.md</h4> <pre tabindex="0"><code># 2024 Week 01 ## Reminders - [x] Add this weekly note to Quarterly note - [x] Write up initiatives for the week ## Initiatives for the week _Take a look at last weeks review_ - [[2023 in review]] - [ ] Finish and publish - [[24-Q1 ERYN Launch SCSS starter]] - [x] Finish and publish blog post about project: ([[Introducing cu.css]]) - [x] Make GitHub repo public - [x] Get Rebekka to proof read copywriting on https://cu.harrycresswell.com/ - [x] Pin repo to GitHub profile - [[24-Q1 B32 Hugo - Cloudcannon migration]] - [ ] Fix JavaScript issues - [x] Finish migrating content - [[24-Q1 MW Mewing app v2.0.4]] - [ ] Design lesson status functionality - Submit Tax return ## Weekly review ### What went well this week? - Finished and published [[2023 in review]] - Finished and published [[Introducing cu.css]] - Made good progress with [[24-Q1 B32 Hugo - Cloudcannon migration]] - Rebekka proof read https://cu.harrycresswell.com copywriting - I started reading The Warm Dry Home by Pete Ward. - Completed tax return ### What didn’t go so well this week? - Running as I still have a cold, hopefully I will get back into it next week - Didn’t study any German. I need to organise some lessons. ### What&#39;s my biggest challenge right now? - Studying German ### What help do I need? - Mew app lesson status UI design ### What did I learn? - Be patient with yourself, especially when you are sick. ### What are my initiatives for next week? - [[24-Q1 MW Mewing app v2.0.4]] - Design lesson status functionality - [[24-Q1 PH Complete module 1 (up and running) content]] - Reviewing where I’m with [[practical hugo]] - Edit styling basics lesson - [[OKR in Obsidian]] - Finish draft - [[hc.com]] - Open external links in new tab - [[24-Q1 ERYN Make SCSS starter post launch improvements]] - Open external links in new tab </code></pre><p>At the end of each week I do a <em>weekly review</em> of my OKR progress. In this review I answer a few questions about the week, such as <em>what went well</em>, <em>what didn’t go so well</em> and <em>what I need help with</em>. This helps me reflect on the week and check in to see if I’m making progress with my key results.</p> <p>Part of my weekly review involves thinking ahead to the initiatives I want to complete in the following week. Here I list any initiatives I didn’t manage to complete that week, which will carry over to the next week.</p> <p>I have another reoccurring reminder in my calendar, this time on Fridays, which reminds me to complete my weekly review at the end of each week.</p> <h3 id="the-daily-note">The daily note</h3> <p>Every morning, the first thing I do when I fire up my laptop is open Obsidian.</p> <p>With Obsidian open, I press <code>Cmd + P</code> to launch the command palette, then type <em>daily</em> and hit <code>Enter</code>. This creates a daily note from my <code>daily</code> template:</p> <h4 id="templatesdailymd">templates/daily.md</h4> <pre tabindex="0"><code># {{title}} ## Reminders - [ ] Complete 6-minute diary AM - [ ] Add morning routine to habit tracker - [ ] Check in with [[OKR]] quarterly and weekly note - [ ] Check in with calendar and time blocks - [ ] Write up tasks for the day - [ ] 30mins German practice - [ ] Flashcard daily review - [ ] Readwise daily review - [ ] Reading 5.30-6.30pm (Reader, RSS or kindle) - [ ] Complete 6-minute diary PM ## Tasks - [ ] ... ## 6-Minute Diary ### Morning 3 minutes in the morning. #### I am grateful for ... 1. 2. 3. #### What would make today wonderful? #### Positive self affirmation ### Evening 3 minutes in the evening. #### Something good I did for someone today... #### What will I do better tomorrow? #### Great things I experienced today... 1. 2. </code></pre><p>My daily note note consists of 3 main sections:</p> <ul> <li>Reminders</li> <li>Tasks</li> <li>6-minute diary</li> </ul> <p>The <em>Reminders</em> section is essentially a checklist of reoccurring tasks that I do every single day. <em>Check in with OKR quarterly and weekly note</em> is obviously the key one here. It reminds me to look at my OKRs and pick out some initiatives to work on that day. That way, (at least) I make some progress towards my key results every day.</p> <p>I also include general reminders which don’t relate to my OKRs, but are easy to forget without a daily reminder. Things like <em>Complete 6-minute diary</em>, <em>Add morning routine to habit tracker</em> and <em>Readwise daily review</em>,all fall into this category.</p> <p>The second section in my daily note is <em>Tasks</em>. This is where I list granular tasks for the day, most of which will come from my weekly initiatives. When I check in with my <em>quarterly</em> and <em>weekly</em> note each morning, I choose a few initiatives to work on and add tasks to this section which satisfy those initiatives.</p> <p>The final section in my daily note is called <em>6-minute diary</em>. This consists of a handful of questions that I ask myself each day. First in the morning and then again in the evening (when I remember or still have the energy). This is a fairly typical format for a gratitude practice, which I’m sure you may well be familiar with. I use it to help me stay positive and reflect each day.</p> <h3 id="the-okr-note">The OKR note</h3> <p>The final part of this workflow is The OKR note itself. This is just an index note where I lists each quarterly note by year. That way they’re all in one place and easy to access.</p> <p>My OKR index note also briefly explains OKR, in case I’m having a slow moment (which happens quite often).</p> <p>Here’s what my <code>OKR.md</code> note looks like:</p> <h4 id="areasokrmd">areas/okr.md</h4> <pre tabindex="0"><code># OKR Objectives and Key Results. - **Objectives** are the overall goals you want to achieve. Objectives should be aspirational and motivating, but usually not measurable. - **Key Results** are how you will achieve your objectives. They can be either quantifiable performance measures or deliverables (effort or projects). - **Initiatives** are actions which lead to key results. ## 2024 - [[2024-Q1]] ## 2023 - [[2023-Q1]] - [[2023-Q2]] - [[2023-Q3]] - [[2023-Q4]] </code></pre><p>Every quarter, when I create a new quarterly note, I manually add it to my OKR index note for reference.</p> <p>It’s worth mentioning, this note isn’t generated using the Periodic Notes plugin. It’s just a place to reference and easily retrieve my quarterly notes. It’s also the note I link to in the <em>Reminders</em> section of my daily notes.</p> <h3 id="organising-notes">Organising notes</h3> <p>The Periodic Notes plugin lets you set the folder where you’d like to keep your notes. I use the following structure to keep my notes organised:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>- journal/ - daily/ - 2024-01-11 - 2024-01-12 - ... - quarterly/ - 2023-Q3 - 2024-Q1 - ... - weekly/ - 2024-W01 - 2024-W02 - ... </code></pre><p>Another part of my workflow is <a href="https://fortelabs.com/blog/para/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the PARA method</a>, which you may have already realised from the file path of my notes. I use this to organise ongoing areas of responsibility in my life and projects I’m working on. These projects aren’t necessarily part of my OKR, but quite a few will be.</p> <p>My OKR index note fits nicely into my <code>/areas</code> folder and the key result notes I create for each OKR objective live inside my <code>/projects</code> folder. When I complete a project or key result, I move the note from the <code>/projects</code> folder into the <code>/archive</code> folder.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>archive/ 23-Q4 ERYN SCSS starter build ... areas/ hc.com OKR practical hugo ... journal/ daily/ quarterly/ weekly/ projects/ 24-Q1 PH Rebuild course website 24-Q2 CU launch v1.2.0 ... resources/ </code></pre><p>It might not always make sense to think of key results as dedicated projects, but I usually find this approach works well for my purposes.</p> <h3 id="improvements-to-the-workflow">Improvements to the workflow</h3> <p>Currently I list weekly initiatives in my weekly note by manually copying each initiative across from my key result notes. Perhaps I could embed these initiatives so I don’t have to repeat myself. Saying that, I really don’t mind writing out my initiatives over and over. It keeps things simple and helps to solidify what I’m trying to get done.</p> <p>I’ve seen a few other OKR workflows in Obsidian which use the <a href="https://github.com/liamcain/obsidian-calendar-plugin" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Calendar</a> and <a href="https://github.com/chhoumann/quickadd" target="_blank" rel="noopener">QuickAdd</a> plugins. I’ve considered using both and they probably would improve the workflow to some degree. But, again, I’m a stickler for keeping this simple and I’d rather keep the plugins I use to a minimum.</p> <p>If you have any suggestions for how I could improve this workflow further it would be great to hear from you.</p> <h2 id="final-thoughts">Final thoughts</h2> <p>These days I find myself using Obsidian for all sorts of things. From general note taking and habit tracking to <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/simple-project-management">project management</a> and pretty much anything else that involves writing or learning.</p> <p>But using Obsidian for goal settings with OKR has been the real game changer. It’s made a huge improvement to my focus and work.</p> <p>The Periodic Notes plugin, along with a handful of templates and a few simple reminders – either in the form of checklists or reoccurring reminders in my calendar – is, so far, what’s making all this work.</p> <p>As long as I remember to begin each day by creating a daily note, then the rest is laid out. It’s not perfect, by a long shot. There are still days when I struggle to stick with it. But, so far, this is the best way I‘ve found to consistently make progress with the things I want to achieve.</p> <p>Before I wrap this one up I’d like to give credit to Marcus Olsson’s <a href="https://marcus.se.net/how-i-set-and-track-goals-using-obsidian/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">How I set and track goals using Obsidian</a>. My journey with OKR in Obsidian was heavily inspired by Marcus’ approach. So a big thanks to Marcus for helping me get my head around all this stuff. Your hard work hasn’t gone unnoticed.</p>

item.title: Introducing cu.css
item.content:encoded: <p>It’s not always easy to keep the CSS you write consistent, particularly when you’re working on a variety of different projects. Things tend to get messy when you jump between projects, making arbitrary updates, without a clear approach. As your projects grow, so too does the complexity of your stylesheets and your CSS soon enough becomes a nightmare to maintain.</p> <p>The ultimate goal, I suppose, is to find a way to manage a growing number of projects somewhat systematically. All while keeping chaos to a minimum.</p> <p>One solution I’ve found is to adopt a CSS methodology. Something that helps to formalise the way you write the language with a solid, sensible approach. A good CSS methodology will help improve the consistency of your code and make you more efficient at building and maintaining websites.</p> <p>But while a CSS methodology is a great start, in reality, you’ll often need a little more than just guidance on how to structure and write your code. Most of the time, I find the best way to kick start my projects is with a methodology, plus a good bit of the CSS itself – already in place and ready to build upon.</p> <p><a href="https://cu.harrycresswell.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">cu.css</a> is a lightweight CSS framework I built with these things in mind. It uses modern CSS techniques and two popular methodologies and it’s designed to help you hit the ground running.</p> <p>In this post I want to share a little more about the project.</p> <h2 id="a-lightweight-css--framework-built-with-modern-techniques">A lightweight CSS framework built with modern techniques</h2> <p><em>cu.css</em> is a lightweight CSS framework that makes it quicker to start using CUBE CSS and Utopia fluid responsive design in your projects.</p> <p><a href="https://cube.fyi/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CUBE CSS</a>, if you’re new to it, is a CSS methodology that’s orientated towards simplicity, pragmatism and consistency. It helps bring structure to your styles, while respecting the powerful features of the CSS language.</p> <p><a href="https://utopia.fyi/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Utopia</a> is an approach to fluid responsive space, type and grid, which utilises modern CSS techniques, most notably the Clamp function.</p> <p><em>cu.css</em> wraps these two tools together into what is effectively a CSS starter project. Something you can use as a starting point to quickly get going with modern CSS techniques, sensible defaults and a solid CSS methodology. Think of it as <a href="https://moderncss.dev/contextual-spacing-for-intrinsic-web-design/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">intrinsic web design</a> in action, a base to build upon and a clear direction of travel.</p> <p>To the best of my knowledge, a CSS framework built using CUBE CSS and Utopia doesn’t exist. While <a href="https://cube.fyi/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">cube.fyi</a> helps you learn the methodology, there’s not much out there that helps you quickly put it into practice. The same is true for Utopia, so that’s why I decided to make this project public.</p> <p>Let’s rattle off a few features to give you an idea of what to expect from <em>cu.css</em>:</p> <ul> <li>Built using the CUBE CSS methodology.</li> <li>Utopia fluid responsive design for space and type.</li> <li>CSS Custom Properties over token-based CSS.</li> <li>Two flavours – choose from SCSS or CSS.</li> <li>Zero dependencies, no third-party tooling.</li> <li>Global styles making HTML elements look great.</li> <li>Automatic “user-preference” dark mode.</li> <li>Works with <a href="https://frankchimero.com/blog/2015/the-webs-grain/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the grain</a> of CSS, not against it.</li> <li>Simple, accessible and intuitive to work with.</li> <li>Lightweight: ~15kb (compressed)</li> </ul> <p>Ok. So why might you want to use <em>cu.css</em>, and when might be a good time to use it?</p> <h2 id="why-cucss">Why <em>cu.css</em>?</h2> <p><em>cu.css</em> will appeal, if like me, you prefer leaning on a lightweight CSS methodology, rather than reaching for an all signing all dancing framework, like Bootstrap or Tailwind.</p> <p>To me, Bootstrap is complete overkill, stuffed full of features that I really don’t need. Tailwind, with its all-in utility class approach, fights against the grain of CSS entirely. It’s a complete reinvention of the language, which isn’t how I prefer to write my CSS.</p> <p>A methodology, on the other hand, simply acts as a guide. It helps steer you in a sensible direction and offers a lightweight, flexible way to write and structure your CSS. A good methodology is pragmatic and respects the grain of the language.</p> <p>Building <em>cu.css</em> using two well recognised and respectable methodologies has other advantages, too. There’s plenty of documentation online that will help you learn both CUBE CSS and Utopia. Meaning anyone can pick up a project and know exactly how to work with it. With a clear approach, it’s much easier to build upon and expand on the foundations that <em>cu.css</em> provides. And do so in a consistent way.</p> <p>This seems like a sensible approach. I don’t pretend to be an expert in CSS. It’s not an easy language to master and <a href="https://andy-bell.co.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Andy</a>, <a href="https://www.trysmudford.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Trys</a> and <a href="https://www.hustlersquad.net/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">James</a>, the clever folk behind these projects, are far more knowledgable and experienced with the language than I’m sure I will ever be. So why try and come up with my own methodology when these fantastic tools already exist?</p> <p>I like to think of cu.css as a little bit more than a class-less CSS framework. Call it a low-class framework, if you will. Most the CSS in <em>cu</em> is applied to HTML elements, on a global level – just like with a class-less framework. Then, on top of that you have Utopia powering your space and type and the concepts that CUBE CSS brings with it – a handful of utility classes for dealing with common yet specific problems, blocks (otherwise known as components) and compositions (a.k.a layouts) to give you that little extra power.</p> <p>You may find <em>cu.css</em> a good fit for your next project, if:</p> <ul> <li>you like to write CSS the way it was intended to be written</li> <li>you prefer a lighter touch than your typical CSS framework</li> <li>you need a clear, consistent approach for writing your CSS</li> <li>you need that little bit more than a classless CSS framework</li> <li>you’d like to use a modern fluid approach to space and type</li> <li>you don’t have time to start your next project from scratch</li> </ul> <p>Have I sold it to you already?</p> <h2 id="how-to-get-started-with-cucss">How to get started with <em>cu.css</em></h2> <p>The best way to get started with <em>cu.css</em> is to head to <a href="https://cu.harrycresswell.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">https://cu.harrycresswell.com/</a> and read the <a href="https://cu.harrycresswell.com/getting-started/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">getting started</a> docs.</p> <p>Please keep in mind that this project is still very much in its infancy. Existing documentation, methods of installation, and so on, are all likely to change in the months ahead.</p> <p>You can also find <a href="https://github.com/harrycresswell/cu" target="_blank" rel="noopener">cu.css on Github</a> where you can find the entire Hugo project that powers the <em>cu.css</em> website.</p> <h2 id="whats-next-for-cucss">What’s next for <em>cu.css</em></h2> <p>I’m keen to keep <em>cu.css</em> as lightweight as possible, but there are a few features I’ve missed, that I’d like to add at some point in the future.</p> <ul> <li>Docs for <code>.prose</code> and <code>.skip-link</code> blocks</li> <li>Some of the compositions I’ve missed from <a href="https://every-layout.dev/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Every Layout</a>, for example <code>.sidebar</code> and <code>.reel</code>.</li> <li>Semantic heading classes: <code>.h1</code>, <code>.h2</code>, <code>.h3</code> and so on.</li> <li>A utility for visibility</li> </ul> <p>I also plan on improving the code comments in the CSS to explain some of the design decisions further. I also need to add a fancy header comment to the CSS file.</p> <p>Then there’s the matter of improving how you install <em>cu.css</em>. Currently you need to copy files into your project which seems rather rudimentary. Perhaps I will publish the project on NPM, so it can be installed that way or via a CDN.</p> <p>There are also certain improvements I’d like to make to the <em>cu.css</em> website itself. In no particular order, in the coming weeks I’m planning to add the following features:</p> <ul> <li>A <code>/changelog</code> page</li> <li>Heading anchor links</li> <li>Open external links in a new tab</li> <li>Next/previous links for the docs</li> <li>A better domain name (possibly)</li> </ul> <p>The docs could undoubtably do with a little more polish too. I’m also considering creating a Figma or Penpot file to help folks create design mockups which play nice with the project.</p> <p>At some point this year I plan to re-write the CSS on my personal website using CUBE CSS and a good bit of <em>cu.css</em>. I’ll probably do the same for the <a href="https://practicalhugo.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical Hugo</a> website and begin using <em>cu.css</em> or at least some iteration of it for most of my future projects. Hopefully, that way, I can create build things more efficiently and keep my code nice and consistent.</p> <h2 id="id-love-to-hear-from-you">I’d love to hear from you</h2> <p>If you have any feedback or suggestions I’d love to hear from you. Likewise if you end up using <em>cu.css</em> in a project, please let me know.</p> <p>I have a vague plan to add a “cu.css in use” page to the documentation site. I’ll begin by listing my own projects, but if you have one you end up using <em>cu.css</em> with, let me know and I’ll add a link to your project.</p>

item.title: 2023 in Review
item.content:encoded: <p>Although I’m ending 2023 with a stinking cold, overall it’s been a positive year and I‘m excited to pick things up again in 2024.</p> <p>There’s been some big changes for me, personally, this year – I moved house, which was a much bigger project than I ever expected. I also feel like I made good progress professionally. I worked hard on my business and it’s definitely a little bit closer to where I want it to be.</p> <p>Using <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/year-in-review/">the usual format</a>, this annual reflection is a chance to look back at what I got up to over the past 12 months – what went well, what didn’t go so well and what I learned by living it.</p> <h2 id="what-went-well">What went well?</h2> <h3 id="work">Work</h3> <p>In 2023 I freelanced as an independent web designer, as I have done for the past 7 years. It’s been a steady ride, consisting mostly of reoccurring work from a handful of clients, most of whom I’ve worked with for a number of years. With roughly a 60/40 split between designing and coding, the typical project I work on hasn’t changed a great deal, but I did make a number of changes to how I go about it.</p> <p>First up, I started collaborating on projects with <a href="https://rebekkawrites.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Rebekka</a> and <a href="https://benmclaren.xyz/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Ben</a>, both of whom have been a massive help and a great source of wisdom, particularly when things get busy.</p> <p>I also spent a good bit of time this year <a href="https://cu.harrycresswell.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">formalising my approach to CSS</a> (more on that coming soon), with the intention of improving consistency in the code I write and making it easier to maintain and scale projects.</p> <p>I fully committed to using <a href="https://gohugo.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo</a> together with <a href="https://cloudcannon.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cloudcannon</a>. It’s a simple but powerful stack that suits my way of working. Running a solo business means I don’t have endless hours to fix broken dependencies and deal with all the headaches that make other tech stacks a bore to work with. I need a reliable, low maintenance setup which I’ve found in both these tools. I’m currently working on migrating my final client sites over and I haven’t looked back.</p> <p>I started using <a href="https://obsidian.md/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Obsidian</a>, the markdown-based writing app, for all things project management. Easily my most used app in 2023, it’s helped me stay organised and simplify the way I plan and manage my work. A big part of that was introducing an OKR workflow to my Obsidian setup. Objectives and Key Results provide a very straight forward framework for defining goals and staying on track. It’s the best system I’ve found for mapping out plans, sticking with those plans and making progress. Another big part of making this work has been the use of daily, weekly and quarterly notes via the Periodic Notes plugin, though I won’t get into that now. This really deserves a dedicated post, which I will try and work on in the new year.</p> <h2 id="travel">Travel</h2> <p>In January I went on a ski trip to Les Arc, France with my brother and 12 of his friends. An unforgettable experience with an incredible bunch of people.</p> <p>In March I travelled to Sussex, for a short break in Rye. Lots of great cafes, pubs and restaurants – I’m sure I’ll be back soon. Later in the month I spent 4 nights in Hamburg, working and catching up with friends, before heading to Berlin for 3 nights, for a family birthday and to see more friends.</p> <p>In May we were back in Hamburg for a couple of days, before heading up North for Rebekka’s Opa’s 90th birthday party. A memorable day which was an honor to attend.</p> <p>In June I was in Cornwall for a week with family. We stayed in Portscatho and spent time in St Mawes, Falmouth, Mevagissey and at the Eden project (all well worth a visit). We braved the cold water a couple of times and at one point found ourselves swimming with a seal. Notable food and drink spots we discovered we The Hidden Hut, The Standard Inn and Knightor Winery.</p> <p>For two weeks in October we explored the Canary Islands. We spent time hiking in La Gomera, where we found some of the toughest routes we’ve hiked. From La Gomera we ferried over to La Palma for more hiking, black sand beaching and a memorable evening with an astronomer, looking at various objects in the night sky through a telescope. It was an experience I will never forget. We finished our trip kayaking in Tenerife and exploring the old town of Santa Cruz in the North. I could have easily stayed longer.</p> <p>In November we made our final trip of the year to Hamburg, mainly for a wedding but also to catch up with various friends and enjoy a few glühwein at the Christmas markets. It snowed most of the week which made it a little bit more magical. One of my favourite times of year to be in Germany.</p> <h3 id="moving">Moving</h3> <p>In April we bit the bullet and put our flat on the market. After 10 delightful years in Bermondsey, it was time for a change and a bit more space. We’ve both been working from home since the pandemic hit, so it was about time we moved our office out of the front room and into a dedicated room.</p> <p>Truth be told, selling a flat and buying a house has been a long old slog. The majority of this year felt like we had something property related to deal with pretty much every single day. But I’m not complaining. Yes, it felt like a rollercoaster at times. Yes, it was stressful and nearly fell through on a number of occasions. But we learned a huge amount in the process and dare I say it, for the most part, it’s was a fun experience. I just hope I don’t have to do it again, anytime soon.</p> <p>On December 1st we completed the purchase of a house in Lewisham. And we’re now able to close the door on our office at the end of each day. We’re thrilled to finally be here and we’re loving life in our new neck of the woods. Now we’re finally at the end of this journey, I’m looking forward to finding some time to focus on a few other things.</p> <h3 id="health">Health</h3> <p>I’m pleased to say my health is back on track. Whether that’s because the move is finally behind us or something completely different, I’m not entirely sure. Either way, I’m feeling good at the moment. For most of the year I struggled with heart palpitations. Following an “anxiety” diagnoses from various doctors and resulting test, I’ve worked hard to make changes in my life and improve my situation.</p> <p>I’m making time for exercise, with <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/2021-review/#health">the usual routine</a> and have been fairly consistent with both running and yoga. At the beginning of the year, I started yoga classes IRL with Rebekka. It was daunting at first but a big confidence boost when I realised it wasn’t that big a deal and my ability isn’t all that bad. All that home practice over the 10 or so years must have paid off.</p> <p>I bought an Apple Watch. Mostly to make life more comfortable whilst out running, but also to remind me to stand up and stay active. I did my best to <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/dumbing-down-apple-watch/">dumb it down</a> and I have to say it’s been a huge help and not nearly as much of a distraction as I was expecting. On Christmas day my sister introduced me to <a href="https://www.parkrun.org.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Park Run</a>, and it turns out there’s one just up the road from our new place, so no excuses now.</p> <p>I cut out caffeine almost completed, except for the odd cup of tea, usually when I’m with my family. For whatever reason I just don’t seem to get on with it. Cutting it out has made a huge difference. With the quality of decaffeinated coffee beans these days, I struggle to even tell the difference and enjoy the placebo just the same.</p> <p>Following our ski trip in January, I starting doing the odd freestyle skiing day in the UK with my brother. We began at <a href="https://www.thesnowcentre.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Snow Centre</a> in Hemel Hempstead, then discovered <a href="https://snozoneuk.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Snozone</a> in Milton Keynes. I’d like to make this more of a regular thing in 2024.</p> <p>In June I started the <a href="https://zoe.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Zoe</a> personalised nutrition study. It’s been a fascinating journey, where I’ve learned a ton about nutrition and started to get on top of what I should be eating. Discipline is the tough one here. It’s not always easy to eat healthy, particularly at weekends or when out with friends. But I definitely feel like things are moving in the right direction, so that’s something at least. I plan to retest in 3 months to find out if I’ve actually made any improvements.</p> <p>I still do weekly therapy sessions. Something I’ve been considering is whether I should keep going now that my health has improved. I’ve come to realise it’s incredibly helpful, regardless of how I’m feeling. Currently I use the 50 minutes to slow down and reflect on the week. Talking about your life with someone who is trained in helping you make sense of things is transformative. We often spend a portion of the time each week discussing “fun” things, too. The future of technology, metaphysics, parapsychology and the paranormal have all come up. These sorts of subjects have always fascinated me, but it’s only more recently that I’ve starting to give them more serious thought.</p> <h2 id="what-didnt-go-so-well">What didn’t go so well?</h2> <p>I didn’t read many books this year, but I did work on my process a good bit. I‘m using my Kindle a lot more, along with Readwise, which automatically imports my highlights and uses space repetition to organise them into a daily review. I hope to be more consistent with my reading in 2024.</p> <p>I struggled with my German, as I often do. I started creating flashcards using the spaced repetition plugin for Obsidian, but didn’t manage to make looking at them a habit. I think I really need to start German lessons again. A regular weekly commitment, perhaps IRL, that will help me to get back on track. I also need to consume more German content. I’ve had some success with podcasts in the past. I also want to try reading a German book on the Kindle, as it would work well with my Kindle – Readwise – flashcard set up.</p> <p>I didn’t study as much as I hoped in 2023, which bothers me. I mainly focused on JavaScript, but it ebbed and flowed. I learned a bunch of concepts and took a load of notes, but realise I probably need to build more things to really make progress.</p> <p>I wrote a fair amount, but only managed to publish 13 posts on my personal site. Not bad I suppose, but only a couple of those were technical articles. Most of the technical stuff I wrote was content for my Hugo course, none of which I have managed to publish yet. Now we’re done with our move, I’m hoping to have more time and head space for writing - particularly technical posts.</p> <p>I bouldered with friends on the odd occasion this year, but didn’t go regularly. I planned to do a ropes course with a friend at the beginning of the year, but that never happened. I enjoy climbing, but maybe it’s only ever going to be something I do from time to time. I guess that’s ok.</p> <h2 id="what-did-i-learn">What did I learn?</h2> <p>Inspired by <a href="https://carlbarenbrug.com/learning" target="_blank" rel="noopener">things I learned this year</a>, a wonderfully concise and to the point post from Carl Barenbrug, I thought I’d keep it simple this year and do something similar.</p> <p>In no particular order, here are a few things which come to mind, that I learned this year:</p> <ul> <li>Buying and selling property in the UK is a slow, complicated process.</li> <li>How you combine the foods you eat and the order in which you eat them, will effect both your blood sugar and fat response.</li> <li>Doing things in groups is fun and a massive confidence boost.</li> <li>Lower your expectations of yourself will reduce your stress and anxiety.</li> <li>OKR and periodic notes are an effective way to stay on track and make progress.</li> <li>Life is constant work, until you die. Don’t stop working at it.</li> <li>Enjoy the process, not the outcome.</li> <li>Say no to opportunities more often, prioritise less if you want to make progress.</li> <li>Be patient with yourself.</li> </ul> <p>I’ll leave it there for this year. Roll on 2024!</p>

item.title: App defaults
item.content:encoded: <p>I’m bit late to the party, but nevertheless, here are my app defaults at the end of 2023.</p> <ul> <li><strong>Mail Client:</strong> Tuta Mail</li> <li><strong>Mail Server:</strong> Tuta Mail</li> <li><strong>Notes:</strong> Obsidian</li> <li><strong>To-Do:</strong> Obsidian</li> <li><strong>Photo Shooting:</strong> Apple Camera</li> <li><strong>Photo Management:</strong> Apple Photos</li> <li><strong>Calendar:</strong> Tuta Calendar</li> <li><strong>Cloud File Storage:</strong> Sync, iCloud</li> <li><strong>RSS:</strong> NetNewsWire</li> <li><strong>Contacts:</strong> Tuta Mail</li> <li><strong>Browser:</strong> LibreWolf, Safari, Firefox Dev</li> <li><strong>Chat:</strong> WhatsApp, Apple Messages, Signal</li> <li><strong>Bookmarks:</strong> Anybox</li> <li><strong>Read It Later:</strong> Readwise Reader</li> <li><strong>Word Processing:</strong> Obsidian</li> <li><strong>Spreadsheets:</strong> Airtable</li> <li><strong>Presentations:</strong> n/a</li> <li><strong>Shopping Lists:</strong> Apple Reminders</li> <li><strong>Meal Planning:</strong> n/a</li> <li><strong>Budgeting and Personal Finance:</strong> n/a</li> <li><strong>News:</strong> BBC News</li> <li><strong>Music:</strong> Spotify, YouTube</li> <li><strong>Podcasts:</strong> Spotify, YouTube, Apple Podcasts</li> <li><strong>Password Management:</strong> Bitwarden</li> <li><strong>Code Editor:</strong> Visual Studio Code</li> <li><strong>Terminal:</strong> Hyper with ZSH and Oh My ZSH.</li> </ul> <p>Inspired by:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://defaults.rknight.me/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">App Defaults</a> by Robb Knight</li> <li><a href="https://manuelmoreale.com/app-defaults" target="_blank" rel="noopener">App Defaults</a> by Manuel Moreale</li> <li><a href="https://kevquirk.com/my-default-apps-at-the-end-of-2023" target="_blank" rel="noopener">My Default Apps at the End of 2023</a> by Kev Quirk</li> </ul> <p>And everyone else!</p>

item.title: Subscriptions
item.content:encoded: <p>Let’s be honest, subscriptions are one of those things in life we’d all rather live without. But they’re here to stay and <a href="https://manuelmoreale.com/on-subscriptions" target="_blank" rel="noopener">they’re getting more expensive</a>.</p> <p>The approach I’m taking is to cull as many as I can (duh). Typeform recently went. As did Strava. Notion will be on it’s way soon. But not just yet, as I was heavily invested and there’s much to undo.</p> <p>These days, if I can pay for software outright, then I will. Balance is great for that, as you can pay once for lifetime access. I switched from Adobe to Affinity, for the exact same reason. Adobe’s subscription fees are ridiculous, whereas Affinity is a reasonable one-off payment. One caveat is that Affinity now charge for updates, so although it’s nothing like the cost of Adobe, you may just be shifting the problem elsewhere.</p> <p>The truth is, it’s unlikely we’ll ever be able to ditch subscriptions entirely. So the next best thing is to keep them in check.</p> <p>With that in mind, here’s a breakdown of all my active subscriptions and how much I’m spending in total. All costs are monthly, except for domains which show the individual cost for the year (because I’m lazy), then a total, which includes a monthly breakdown.</p> <h2 id="streaming-services">Streaming services</h2> <ul> <li>Netflix (£4.99 / $6.32)</li> <li>Amazon Prime (£7.92 / $9.67)</li> </ul> <p><strong>Total:</strong> £12.91 / $15.99</p> <h2 id="work">Work</h2> <ul> <li>Figma (£12 / $15.20)</li> <li>Fathom Analytics (£9.48 / $11.58)</li> <li>Sync (£6.55 / $8)</li> <li>Obsidian (£7.89 / $10)</li> <li>Accountant (£120 / $146.53)</li> <li>Insurance (With Jack) (£24.95 / $32.35)</li> </ul> <p><strong>Total:</strong> £180.87* / $223.66</p> <p>*This doesn’t include expenses which get re-billed to clients.</p> <h2 id="domains">Domains</h2> <ul> <li>harrycresswell.com (£8.70 / $10.66)</li> <li>harrycresswell.co.uk (£7.74 / $9.48)</li> <li>harrycr.es (£17.94 / $21.98)</li> <li>practicalhugo.com (£7.40 / $9.06)</li> <li>typeservices.co (£23.65 / $28.98)</li> <li>locallondon.life (£26.25 / $32.16)</li> <li>studioeryn.com (£7.96 / $9.76)</li> </ul> <p><strong>Total:</strong> £99.64 / $122.08 per year (£8.30 / $10.17 per month)</p> <h2 id="privacy">Privacy</h2> <ul> <li>Tuta(nota) (£3 / $3.66)</li> <li>NordVPN (£3.66 / $4.47)</li> <li>Simplelogin (£2.04 / $2.5)</li> </ul> <p><strong>Total:</strong> £8.70 / $10.63</p> <h2 id="misc">Misc</h2> <ul> <li>Phone contract (£9.00 / $11.02)</li> <li>iCloud+ with 50 GB of storage (£0.99 / $1.21)</li> <li>Readwise and Reader (£6.54 / $7.99)</li> <li>Duolingo (£4.99 / $6.22)</li> <li>MoreYoga (£23.25 / $29.46)</li> </ul> <p><strong>Total:</strong> £44.77 / $55.92</p> <p>There you have it. All my active subscriptions in one place.</p> <p>The overall total comes to £255.55 / $316.37 a month, which, to be honest, isn’t as bad as I was expecting. A large chunk of that is the cost for my accountant, which I like to think is money well spent. Another expensive one is MoreYoga, but it’s much cheaper than a gym membership would cost.</p> <p>I decided not to included household expenses, such as insurance, utilities and council tax as I wouldn’t necessarily consider them subscriptions. They’re also shared costs.</p> <p>With everything now in check, I hope to give a little extra consideration to any new potential subscriptions.</p>

item.title: Plain text project management
item.content:encoded: <p>Since <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/notion-no-more/">falling out with Notion</a>, I’ve been on the hunt for a simple project management tool for managing projects, both client and personal.</p> <p>Working independently, I rarely find the need for collaboration features that a team may find useful. What I need is something that doesn’t get in the way of actually doing the work. Ideally something that meets following criteria:</p> <ul> <li>Simple, fast and reliable</li> <li>Easy to host wherever I want</li> <li>Works without an internet connection</li> <li>Will scale over the long term without any limits</li> <li>Stores data in text files (preferably Markdown) and folders</li> <li>No vendor lock-in, tying me in to using a certain application</li> <li>Private and secure</li> <li>Open-source</li> </ul> <p>I’m a massive fan of static site generators, which tend to support much of what I’ve listed above. Perhaps that’s how I ended up here?</p> <p>Either way, these requirements make sense to me. So I’ve begun to seek out sofware that meets this criteria. And, it seems there’s a new wave of software applications being built with these things in mind.</p> <p><a href="https://obsidian.md/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Obsidian</a> is one of these apps. And it ticks all the boxes.</p> <p>Under the hood, Obsidian is just a bunch of plain-text files and folders, much like any other file or folder on your system. This means it’s simple, fast and reliable. It works great without an internet connection and it will scale without any issues, over the long term.</p> <p>Content in Obsidian is stored in what’s known as a Vault. A vault is private and secure by default and can be hosted locally, or remotely in the cloud, so you’re always in full control of your content.</p> <p>Content is written in Markdown, which is a widely supported content format, meaning you’re not tied in to using the application. Should Obsidian disappear one day, or you choose to move to a different software in the future, it’s very easy to get hold of your content and take it elsewhere. Reading what Steph Ango, the founder of Obsidian, has to say, it sounds like <a href="https://stephango.com/file-over-app" target="_blank" rel="noopener">file over app</a> is very much part of the philosophy behind Obsidian.</p> <p>Using Obsidian is a lot like working with a static site generator, in a way. You have content files, you have content templates, you can even link between notes, like you would pages on a website.</p> <p>Although it’s marketed as a note-taking app for personal knowledge management, I’ve been using Obsidian for project management, to good effect, with a very simple workflow.</p> <ol> <li>Add a new note to a <em>projects</em> folder for every new project.</li> <li>Create a todo list of tasks to complete inside each project note.</li> <li>When all tasks are complete, move the project note to an archive folder.</li> </ol> <p>Plain text project management. It couldn’t be simpler.</p> <p>This is typically all I need to manage a project, these days. A plain text file, a content template and a simple todo list.</p> <p>Inevitably, at some point, I may find a client needs access to a kanban type project board, for a more collaborative experience. In this situation, something simple like Trello is probably now what I’d turn to.</p> <p>For everything else, Obsidian is exactly what I’ve been looking for.</p> <h2 id="further-reading">Further reading</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://obsidian.md/about" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Obsidian’s Manifesto</a></li> <li><a href="https://obsidian.md/blog/new-obsidian-icon/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The new Obsidian icon</a></li> </ul>

item.title: Dumbing down the Apple Watch
item.content:encoded: <p>I’ve been on the smart watch fence for a while now. My main concern is creating <em>one more distraction</em> in a growing list of distractions. A mini computer strapped to your wrist sounds like a terrible idea, particularly when focus is in short supply.</p> <p>Having worked hard to minimise my digital dependencies the past few years, is buying a smart watch about to undo all this good work? Probably.</p> <p>But I also like the idea of running without a smart phone stuck to my arm. I want to track runs comfortably, without sweating into my phone. So a smart watch seems like the obvious solution.</p> <p>But which one to choose? Garmin or Apple? Or one of those other ones?</p> <p>I went with an Apple Watch SE for a few simple reasons:</p> <ul> <li>An Apple Watch will most likely play nice with my iPhone and MacBookPro, with zero effort.</li> <li>The Apple Watch SE is affordable compared to some smart watches.</li> <li>I want to be able to plan routes and follow them whist running. This will be handy when running in new places that I’m not familiar with. An Apple Watch SE won’t do this be default, but you can download an app – RunGo or Footpath, for example – that will do this for you.</li> <li>To my knowledge, routable mapping is only available on the elite running Garmin watches. Meaning I’d have to spend at least £600, when I’d rather not.</li> </ul> <p>I’m no elite runner, so the Apple Watch SE is perfect for my needs. But it still does things that I’d rather it didn’t.</p> <p>Ideally, I only want to use my Apple Watch for tracking stuff and staying active. Other than that, I want it to be as dumb and distraction free as possible. That means restricting messages, emails, phone calls and notifications – unless they’re reminding me to be active.</p> <p>If you’ve read <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/40672036-digital-minimalism?from_search=true&amp;from_srp=true&amp;qid=m7BhQYVKfZ&amp;rank=4" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cal Newport’s Digital Minimalism</a>, then you’ll be familiar with the idea of dumbing down a smart phone. Whilst Cal focuses on the idea of switching to a dumber phone, there are still things you can do to make an existing device dumber. Clearly the same principles apply, whether the device in question is a smart phone or a smart watch.</p> <p>Here’s the steps I’m taking to dumb down my Apple Watch SE:</p> <ul> <li>Delete all unused apps</li> <li>Always keep it on silent</li> <li>Turn Work Focus on when I wake up</li> <li>Turn off non-activity related notifications</li> </ul> <p>And here’s what I’m (mostly) using my Watch for right now:</p> <ul> <li>Hourly reminders to stand up and move around.</li> <li>Waking me up in the morning via vibrate (so much nicer than an alarm).</li> <li>Tracking my activity, workouts, heart rate and sleep (and I’m sure more things I haven’t yet discovered).</li> <li>Using RunGo for directions on new running routes.</li> <li>Paying for things via Apple Pay.</li> </ul> <p>Importantly, all messages, phone calls and emails are restricted to my phone or laptop.</p> <p>So, is my dumb(ish) Apple Watch distracting? Less than I was expecting.</p> <p>Am I enjoying it? 100%.</p> <p>The only annoying thing is that I have to charge it every day. But it’s a small price to pay for the utility it offers.</p>

item.title: Notion (no more)
item.content:encoded: <p>The release of <a href="https://www.notion.so/projects" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Notion Projects</a> has made one thing very clear in my mind–it’s time to look elsewhere for a simpler project management tool.</p> <p>You can do incredible things with Notion, there’s no denying. It’s a powerful piece of software that I’ve used with varying degrees of success over the past 5 years. But recently I’ve found myself questioning whether I need all this power and complexity.</p> <p>Playing around with the Projects example project, I can’t help feel overwhelmed by the whole thing. I appreciate it’s aimed at teams and, as a freelancer, I’m not exactly the target audience, but there’s a lot going on, even for your savviest team member.</p> <p>With Notion I find myself clicking about aimlessly. Constantly switching between tables, kanbans and timelines. Creating different views is fun, but is it actually helpful? Do I really need to visualise this project in all these different ways? Or am I just procrastinating here?</p> <p>It the <em>infinitely configurable</em> sell that gives me the feeling I’m wasting my time in Notion. Sorting projects, filtering tasks, updating statuses, adding tags and due dates. I open a project, then a task within project, then a sub task within a task within a project. It’s <em>project management inception</em>, I’ve forgotten where I’m going and why I’m even here.</p> <p>Building an interconnected system for managing projects so often felt like a great idea. But when you’re deep in the weeds, at some point you make the realisation; <em>this isn’t work, this is just managing work</em>. And when you’re spending more time managing the work than actually doing the work itself, something desperately needs to change.</p> <p>Project management tools, by design, should make managing projects easier. Working with them shouldn’t feel like a project in itself. But with Notion, that’s exactly how it’s started to feel.</p> <p>I don’t doubt that some folks still find value in Notion, with its all-in-one, infinate configurability. But for me, personally, it’s time to return to the days of the humble text-based todo list. When project management was simple and the work got done.</p> <hr> <p><strong>Dec 2nd 24</strong>: This morning I found myself reading <a href="https://www.joanwestenberg.com/modern-work-fucking-sucks/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Modern Work Fucking Sucks.</a> where, on a similar note, Joan Westenberg highlights the empty promise made by productivity tools.</p>

item.title: Sleep on it
item.content:encoded: <p>Let me sleep on it – my go-to response when struggling to find solutions.</p> <p>I love this expression. It reminds me that a solution will invariably present itself when you’re well rested and a problem has been given satisfactory time and space. It also gives the recipient an idea of when you may have an answer. Win win.</p> <p>It seems absurd to write a note about such a simple idea, but it’s easy to forget the importance of sleep, time and space. With very little effort, these three tools combine to give you a fresh perspective on things. And, ultimately, help you to identify the most appropriate way to move forward.</p> <p>I rarely give these tools enough credit, particularly when it comes to work.</p> <p><strong>7/02/24</strong>: This morning I stumbled upon <a href="https://37signals.com/34" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sleep on it</a> from 37signals. A similar sentiment, summarised far more eloquently than I ever could:</p> <blockquote> <p>The end of the day has a way of convincing you what you’ve done is good, but the next morning has a way of telling you the truth. Even if you’re sure, sleep on it.</p> </blockquote>

item.title: Safer Internet Day
item.content:encoded: <p>Today is the 20th anniversary of <a href="https://www.saferinternetday.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Safer Internet Day</a>, a global campaign which brings together communities to promote the safe and positive use of digital technology, especially among children and young people.</p> <p>To celebrate and raise awareness, I want to share a few tips that will improve your digital experience and help you stay safe online.</p> <h2 id="use-a-password-manager">Use a password manager</h2> <p>Password managers help you create strong and unique passwords for each online account you create. This reduces the chance of hackers from guessing your password and prevents a successful hacker from easily accessing your other accounts.</p> <p>I highly recommend using <a href="https://bitwarden.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Bitwarden</a>, which is free and open source. <a href="https://1password.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">1Password</a>, <a href="https://www.dashlane.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Dashlane</a> and <a href="https://nordpass.com/download/windows/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">NordPass</a> are great paid options. Looking to self-host? Check out <a href="https://www.lesspass.com/#/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">LessPass</a>.</p> <h2 id="use-two-factor-authentication">Use two-factor authentication</h2> <p>Two-factor authentication (2FA) adds an extra layer of security to your account by way of a time-sensitive code which is used at login, in addition to your password.</p> <p>Always use a different manager for 2FA and passwords. This prevents a single point of failure should either be compromised.</p> <p>Check out <a href="https://2fas.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">2FAS</a> for MacOS and iOS. <a href="https://authy.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Authy</a> for both iOS and Android.</p> <h2 id="use-a-secure-private-email-provider">Use a secure, private email provider</h2> <p>A <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/privacy-focused-email/">secure, privacy focused email</a> provider will help you keep your email conversations private via end-to-end encryption.
