class="k">background-color</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">var</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">--</span><span class="kc">color</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">dark</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">box-shadow</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">0</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="kt">px</span> <span class="mi">28</span><span class="kt">px</span> <span class="nb">rgba</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">47</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">47</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">47</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">.3</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">transform</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nb">translateY</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">-2</span><span class="kt">px</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">Button--secondary</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="nd">focus</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">color</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nf">var</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">--</span><span class="kc">color</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="kc">white</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">outline</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="kt">px</span> <span class="kc">dotted</span> <span class="nf">var</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">--</span><span class="kc">color</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">dark</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This does the job.</p> <p>But, as I wrote about recently, exposing your email address in plain text is asking for trouble from email scraper scripts. Unless you’re a fan of spam, it’s worth taking a few extra steps to <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/prevent-email-scraping/">prevent email scraping</a> altogether.</p> <h2 id="final-thoughts">Final thoughts</h2> <p>The way I see it, nobody really cares what your email address is, as long as they can find a clear and easy way to contact you.</p> <p>Realising this, I now feel far less need for a dedicated email address on my website. Especially when it increases the chances of spam. A masked email address, which I can update from time to time and disguise behind a “Reply by email” button, is a good enough solution.</p> <p>I assume folks might end up saving the address in their contacts, and if I delete and update the address, then emails will start to bounce. But it’s easily enough to head back to my website and find a new way to contact me, if this happens.</p> <p>In any case, I still have <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/contact">a contact form</a>, so all bases are covered.</p> <p>Sidenote: I’m pretty sure I got the idea for this after reading <a href="https://blog.jim-nielsen.com/2022/saying-thank-you/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Saying Thank You</a> from Jim Nielsen.</p> <p><strong>27th May 2024</strong>: I added <code>role=&quot;button&quot;</code> to the anchor link used to create my reply by email button. This makes the link semantically a button, although it still behaves like a link, which is important for assistive technologies. I’ve also added a <code>draggable=&quot;false&quot;</code> based on Martin’s advice in <a href="https://www.tempertemper.net/blog/when-design-breaks-semantics" target="_blank" rel="noopener">When design breaks semantics</a>.</p> <p>Since <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/reducing-css/">refactoring my CSS</a>, I no longer use modifier classes, as suggested above. Instead, I create variant styles for buttons using data attributes. For example, <code>data-variant=&quot;secondary&quot;</code>.</p>

item.title: Newsletter subscriptions via RSS
item.content:encoded: <p>Newsletters in your inbox can be distracting to say the least. To solve the problem I’ve been sending them to Feedbin instead.</p> <p><a href="https://feedbin.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Feedbin</a> is an RSS reader, but it also provides you with an email address for this exact reason. Use it when you subscribe to a newsletter, then you can read the newsletter in Feedbin, just like any other RSS feed.</p> <p>For the past few years this is how I managed newsletters. That is, until I stumbled upon <a href="https://kill-the-newsletter.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Kill the Newsletter</a>. A clever little tool made by Leandro Facchinetti, which offers to roll any newsletter into an RSS feed, for free.</p> <p>By combining this tool with a basic RSS reader, there’s potential to ditch Feedbin, altogether. That might appeal, if like me, you’re only sticking with Feedbin for the email address feature.</p> <p>But let’s save RSS readers for another time. Instead I’d rather talk about killing the Newsletter and what it can do for you.</p> <h2 id="killing-the-newsletter">Killing the newsletter</h2> <p>Head to <a href="https://kill-the-newsletter.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">https://kill-the-newsletter.com</a> anytime you wish to sign up for a new newsletter. Give your newsletter a name and remember, this is the name that the newsletter will later appear as, in your RSS reader. So make sure it’s descriptive and memorable.</p> <p>Hit “Create inbox” to generate a unique email address and RSS feed. It’s important you do this for each newsletter you wish to subscribe to. That way you can easily unsubscribe to newsletters independently.</p> <p>Use the email address provided to sign up to the newsletter with. It will look something like this: <code>k05ft3le3bra9ac7@kill-the-newsletter.com</code></p> <p>Next, paste the URL provided into your RSS reader, so you can subscribe to the Atom feed. That URL will look something like this: <a href="https://kill-the-newsletter.com/feeds/k05ft3le3bra9ac7.xml" target="_blank" rel="noopener">https://kill-the-newsletter.com/feeds/k05ft3le3bra9ac7.xml</a>.</p> <p>As a little extra step, I decided to set up a Notion table to keep a record of each newsletter I’ve subscribed to. For each entry in the table I record the name of the newsletter, the email address I subscribed with and Atom feed URL, for reference. Now I can easily unsubscribe or remove the feed from my RSS reader.</p> <h2 id="doing-it-yourself">Doing it yourself</h2> <p>Turns out you might not even need Kill the Newsletter, either.</p> <p>Chris Hardie figured out how to <a href="https://tech.chrishardie.com/2020/email-newsletters-rss-feed/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">turn emails into RSS feeds using Zapier</a>. Who doesn’t love a bit of Zapier wizardry.</p> <p>Chris suggests an improvement to his approach would be to spin up email aliases for each newsletter. That way you can keep each newsletter as an independent feed and manage them easily.</p> <p>To help with this you might turn to an <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/masking-email/">email masking</a> tool like SimpleLogin. But I’ll leave that up to you to decide.</p> <h2 id="resources">Resources</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://kill-the-newsletter.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Kill the Newsletter</a> by Leandro Facchinetti</li> <li><a href="https://www.niemanlab.org/2022/12/this-is-the-year-of-the-rss-reader-really/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">This is the year of the RSS reader. (Really!)</a> from Nikki Usher</li> <li><a href="https://www.robinsloan.com/lab/new-avenues/#crates" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Go digging in creates</a> from Robin Sloan</li> <li><a href="https://tech.chrishardie.com/2020/email-newsletters-rss-feed/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Put all those email newsletters in an RSS feed</a> from Chris Hardie</li> </ul>

item.title: Preventing email scraping
item.content:encoded: <p>I’ve made all the mistakes to ensure my email receives a sickening amount of spam.</p> <p>A while back, my address somehow crept into the meta data of a client website. Now I’m constantly bombarded with industry specific spam relating to that particular client. Not the end of the world, but kind of annoying, nonetheless.</p> <p>Over the years I’ve exposed my address on numerous social channels, none of which is good news, either. And then, of course, there’s the most popular one of all – adding your email address to your website as a plain text <em>mailto:</em> link.</p> <p>All these mistakes make it extremely easy for email scraper scripts to crawl your website, find your email address and exploit the hell out of it.</p> <p>With this in mind, I want to share an approach I’m using to prevent email scraping altogether. Which drastically reduces the chance of spam ever reaching your inbox in the first place. The technique uses base64 encoding and a few simple lines of JavaScript.</p> <h2 id="base64-encoding-the-address">base64 encoding the address</h2> <p>The first step involves encoding your email address to throw off any scraper scripts. The idea is that when a script attempts to scape your website looking for an address, all it will find is a random encoded string, obfuscating the address.</p> <p>To make this happen, I’ve set up a variable called <code>$email</code> to hold my email address. This site is built using Hugo, so I’m using Hugo’s built in <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/base64/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">base64</a> function to encode the data. This is done by adding <code>base64Encode</code> as a pipe to the value.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ $email := .Site.Author.email | base64Encode }} </code></pre><p>Then, all I’m doing is referencing this variable from within the <code>href</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ $email := .Site.Author.email | base64Encode }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">data-decode</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;email&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Button Button--secondary&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;mailto:{{ $email }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> Reply by email </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Here’s how the encoded data looks in the final HTML output.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">data-decode</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;email&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Button Button--secondary&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;mailto:aGFycnkudXYxd2FAYWxlZWFzLmNvbQ==&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> Reply by email </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>First, notice the random string that replaces the email address. Now malicious scripts won’t be able to find an email address to scrape.</p> <p>Also, notice the custom data attribute I’ve added to the link – <code>data-decode=&quot;email&quot;</code>. Keep this in mind, we’ll need to use it later.</p> <p>At this point, if a human visitor were to click the link, their mail client might well launch, but the <code>to:</code> field will be filled with the random encoded string. Not exactly what we want. For humans, we want to replace the encoded string with the real email address.</p> <p>To solve this problem we can use those aforementioned lines of JavaScript.</p> <h2 id="decoding-the-address-for-humans-using-javascript">Decoding the address for humans using JavaScript</h2> <p>Scraper scripts generally won’t execute JavaScript, which means we can use it to decode the encoded data when the page loads. This will allow humans using a JavaScript enabled browser to access the real address, whilst scrapers and other bots will continue to see the encoded data.</p> <p>You’ll find a bunch of similar techniques out there for this particular step, but here’s how I happen to be doing it.</p> <p>First I set up a new function to contain the code I want to write.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">function</span> <span class="nx">decodeStringBase64</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Inside the function, I set up a variable to hold all elements in the DOM that contain <code>[data-decode=&quot;email&quot;]</code>. Remember that <code>data-decode=&quot;email&quot;</code> data attribute I added to the a tag?</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">function</span> <span class="nx">decodeStringBase64</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Grab Reply by email link tag </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">elemsToDecode</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelectorAll</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;[data-decode=&#34;email&#34;]&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next, using a <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/forEach" target="_blank" rel="noopener">forEach</a> method, I set up a function to run for any item returned in the array.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">function</span> <span class="nx">decodeStringBase64</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Grab Reply by email link tag </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">elemsToDecode</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelectorAll</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;[data-decode=&#34;email&#34;]&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// For each link found </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elemsToDecode</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">forEach</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">elem</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// do something... </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="p">});</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Inside the function I want to do a few things.</p> <p>First, I want to grab the data found in the <code>href</code>. Currently that consists of <em>mailto:</em> + the encoded string.</p> <p>Next, I want to extract only the encoded string from the <code>href</code> and ignore the <em>mailto:</em> part entirely. For this I use JavaScript’s <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/split" target="_blank" rel="noopener">split</a> method to split the value of <code>href</code> at the colon, <code>:</code>.</p> <p>This leaves me with the encoded string.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">function</span> <span class="nx">decodeStringBase64</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Grab Reply by email link tag </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">elemsToDecode</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelectorAll</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;[data-decode=&#34;email&#34;]&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// For each link found </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elemsToDecode</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">forEach</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">elem</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Grab href data </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">hrefData</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">elem</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Split the href data after the colon </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">splitData</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">hrefData</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="sr">/[:,]/</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">});</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The next step is to decode the encoded string using the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/atob" target="_blank" rel="noopener">atob function</a>, which is designed specifically for decoding <em>base64</em> encoded data.</p> <p>With the data decoded, I dump <code>decodedString</code> along with the <em>mailto:</em> back inside <code>href</code> to combine <em>mailto:</em> with the real email address.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">function</span> <span class="nx">decodeStringBase64</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Grab Reply by email link tag </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">elemsToDecode</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelectorAll</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;[data-decode=&#34;email&#34;]&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// For each link found </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elemsToDecode</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">forEach</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">elem</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Grab href data </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">hrefData</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">elem</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Split the href data after the colon </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">splitData</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">hrefData</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="sr">/[:,]/</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Decode the second item in the array </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">decodedString</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">atob</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">splitData</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Dump encodedString and “mailto:” in href </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elem</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">href</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;mailto:&#39;</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nx">decodedString</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">});</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The final step is to make the function call, so the function runs when the page loads.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">function</span> <span class="nx">decodeStringBase64</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Grab Reply by email link tag </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">elemsToDecode</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelectorAll</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;[data-decode=&#34;email&#34;]&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// For each link found </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elemsToDecode</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">forEach</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">elem</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Grab href data </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">hrefData</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">elem</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Split the href data after the colon </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">splitData</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">hrefData</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="sr">/[:,]/</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Decode the second item in the array </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">decodedString</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">atob</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">splitData</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Dump encodedString and “mailto:” in href </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">elem</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">href</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;mailto:&#39;</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nx">decodedString</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">});</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// Make the function call </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="nx">decodeStringBase64</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Whilst this does a nice job of preventing scraper scripts, it still depends on human visitors using a JavaScript enabled browser, which you can’t always rely on.</p> <p>Unfortunately, that means it’s not quite a perfect solution. Although it may well be worth implementing, depending on the depth of the problem and how much you can handle spam. In my case, I feel it’s worth it.</p> <p><strong>Update 17th May 2023</strong>: I’ve since discovered the handy <a href="https://github.com/martignoni/hugo-cloak-email" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo Cloak Email</a> shortcode by Nicolas Martignoni, which could be another option to consider.</p>

item.title: More newsletter changes
item.content:encoded: <p>The start of a new year typically seems to be the time I make improvements to <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/newsletter">my newsletter</a>. Those I introduced back in Jan ’21 turned out to be goods one, for the most part. And most I’ve stuck with.</p> <p>But, back then I wrote about <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/newsletter/newsletter-changes/#more-content-from-me">my plans to share more of my own content </a> and unfortunately I’ve struggled to do that. At least, in a way that I feel makes sense. So I’m going to give it another go. This time with a slightly different format. It’s been a good 5 years since I last changed the format and I feel a change might be what’s needed. Here’s how it will work.</p> <h2 id="a-new-format">A new format</h2> <p>Instead of using the usual format, where I share mostly content authored by others, arranged under the following categories:</p> <ul> <li>Thought provoking</li> <li>Design and code</li> <li>Performance and sustainability</li> <li>Privacy and security</li> <li>Typography</li> <li>Something to watch</li> </ul> <p>From now on, I will use the following structure for the newsletter:</p> <ul> <li>Highlights from last month</li> <li>Elsewhere on the web</li> <li>What I’m up to this month</li> </ul> <p><strong>Highlights from last month</strong> will contain personal highlights – what I was up to, how I spent my time, any news I may have, code I pushed live, content I published, and so on.</p> <p><strong>Elsewhere on the web</strong> will contain content from others that I enjoyed over the course of the previous month. Much like the content of my previous newsletters, but condensed into one section, with perhaps a smaller number of links. I may use categories to organise content, as I’ve been doing up until now, but that’s yet to be decided.</p> <p><strong>What I’m up to this month</strong> will provide a glimpse into the plans I have for the month ahead – what I’ll be working on, where I’ll be spending my time, and so on.</p> <p>I hope these changes will encourage more reflection and concision decision making. Above all I hope they will help me focus on creating work and sharing it. It’s not that I don’t enjoy hunting down content to populate my newsletter with, but it feels like the right time to take the next step and focus on sharing more of my ow work.</p> <p>Before I finish, I must give credit where credit is due. This format has been heavily inspired by <a href="https://www.philipithomas.com/posts/what-i-m-up-to-december-2022" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Philip I. Thomas’s newsletter</a>. I enjoyed learning about <a href="https://www.philipithomas.com/posts/sharing-a-project-i-built-postcard" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Philip’s vision for Postcard</a> and in particular, Philip‘s post <a href="https://www.philipithomas.com/posts/how-to-replace-social-media-with-a-personal-newsletter" target="_blank" rel="noopener">How to replace social media with a personal newsletter</a>. Well worth a read if you’re interested in how things may end up working, post Twitter.</p> <p>Oh, and there’s one more thing.</p> <h2 id="a-new-schedule">A new schedule</h2> <p>If you are an existing subscriber, newsletters will now land in your inbox (or RSS reader, if that’s more your thing) on the 1st of every month - starting from February this year.</p> <p>With the new structure in place, this small change should make much more sense. It certainly seems more logical than always having to check which date the last Friday of every month happens to fall – which is the way I’ve been doing it until now.</p> <p>I understand if these changes are no longer in line with the reasons you signed up to recieve me newsletters. If this is indeed the case, you’re more than welcome to <a href="https://harrycresswell.us14.list-manage.com/unsubscribe?u=4e8fba8d0ab4a857159c0104e&amp;id=d6ad2b65ca" target="_blank" rel="noopener">unsubscribe now</a>, or at any time in the future, for that matter.</p> <p>I’ll spend some time this month updating the welcome email new subscribers receive to reflect these changes.</p> <p>Thanks for reading and see you on 1st of each month.</p>

item.title: 2022 in Review
item.content:encoded: <p>2022, for the most part, has been a good one. I’m ending the year feeling fit and energised for the year ahead – I can’t ask for much more than that.</p> <p>As with every year there’s been highs and lows. Some of which I’ll try to summarise here in my annual reflection. As ever, I’m using my usual format; first what went well, then what didn’t go so well, followed by a few realisations I made along the way.</p> <p>To learn more about how I approach this thing, I wrote <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/year-in-review/">a year in review</a> a few years back, all about why I write this and the inspiration I borrow from for the structure. Make sure you take a look if it’s of interest to you.</p> <p>Ok, here it goes.</p> <h2 id="what-went-well">What went well</h2> <p>I feel I started to get a handle on things this year. Mostly surrounding work and organising my life, both online and off. It was also a great year for travel and celebration.</p> <h3 id="work">Work</h3> <p>I’ve been working hard on my business offering this year, spending a good amount of time building systems and creating SOP’s to guide my process.</p> <p>As a result, I have a much clearer idea of what I do, how I go about it and perhaps most important of all, what I don’t do. This lead me to said no to several opportunities this year. And, as hard as that can be at the time, I know it will be worth it over the long term.</p> <p>I’ve also doubled down on a what I believe to be a more sustainable approach to building content-focused websites. I’m confident this focus will allow me to scale my business and be more productive.</p> <p>Although I didn’t launch many new sites this year, I spent a good bit of time behind the scenes, working on existing projects. I’ve adopted new technologies, and let others go. I’ve become ruthless about cutting costs and ditching unnessary subscriptions. Where I can, my aim is to support projects that are open-source and prioritise the privacy and security of their customers.</p> <h3 id="travel">Travel</h3> <p>In March I was in Hamburg. We travelled up to Travemünde for a birthday weekend, then spent the following week back in the city, catching up with friends.</p> <p>In May I celebrated the wedding of two great friends in Ibiza. My third time on the island. This time we ventured across to Formentera, hired bikes and explored the beaches. Time well spent.</p> <p>In August we were back in Germany. Another week in Hamburg, before a train ride to Kappeln for the final wedding of the year – another two friends, who I got to know well when I first started visiting Germany all those years ago.</p> <p>In October we flew to Athens – one of my favourite places. We spent a weekend in the city, a week on Poros and another on Spetses, before heading back to Athens. I’m a big fan of Greece, it’s somewhere I can easily spend time.</p> <p>In November we travelled to South Africa. This was my first time south of the equator. I’m not really sure what I was expecting, to be honest, but whatever it was, my expectations were exceeded.</p> <p>We spent two weeks working from Cape Town. Then hired a car and drove the Garden Route to Addo Elephant Park, and back via Route 62. South Africa is an incredible country. It should be at the top of your list if it isn’t already. On our travels we made a bunch of new friends, all of whom I hope to see again.</p> <h3 id="privacy-and-security">Privacy and security</h3> <p>I’ve been working on <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/de-googling/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">De-Googling</a> – and generally trying to improve my quality of life online – for a while now.</p> <p>In March I moved my email from Google Workspace to privacy-focused Tutanota. Then I discovered <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/masking-email/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">email masking</a> and adopted the brilliant SimpleLogin, as part of my account sign-up workflow. Now I can seamlessly generate both usernames (masked emails) and passwords directly from Bitwarden, my password manager. Nerd stuff maybe, but I’m now in full control of the email I receive.</p> <p>This year I started using a VPN, at all times, whilst browsing the web. It’s not easy finding the perfect browser. Currently I’m using a mix of Brave, Vivaldi and Firefox. There are two extensions I can’t live without – uBlock Origin and SponsorBlock – which block ads on websites and YouTube videos, respectively.</p> <p>If you’re new to all this privacy and security stuff, <a href="https://brianlovin.com/security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Brian Lovin’s Secuirty Checklist</a> and <a href="https://thenewoil.org/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The New Oil</a> are two great places to start.</p> <h2 id="what-didnt-go-so-well">What didn’t go so well</h2> <p>Talking about what didn’t go well is never easy, but I’ve found in the past it’s a great way to identify either areas for improvement or what’s important and thus deserving of your time and attention.</p> <h3 id="health">Health</h3> <p>In June, out of nowhere, I started having panic attacks. I’m still not exactly sure what caused them, but my guess is a whole bunch of things coming together and boiling over.</p> <p>A panic attack is essentially anxiety manifesting as a variety of physical symptoms. I can best describe what I feel during a panic attack as something close to an out-of-body experience. It’s a feeling of disconnect from your mind, body or surroundings – something I’ve come to know as <a href="https://www.mind.org.uk/information-support/types-of-mental-health-problems/dissociation-and-dissociative-disorders/about-dissociation/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">dissociation</a> – making you feel like you’ve lost control or you’re going crazy. You may also experience feeling numb, shaking, your legs turning to jelly or struggling to breath. Whatever the symptoms, panic attacks can be extremely uncomfortable.</p> <p>Talking about it was the best thing I did to overcome my issues. I told as many people I could about what I was experiencing. I stopped being so hard on myself and took the final 6 months of the year at a much slower pace. I’ve had the occasional blip over the past few months, but I’m a world away from where I was in June and haven’t had a full-blown panic attack since.</p> <h3 id="side-projects">Side projects</h3> <p>Much of my energy this year I spent writing content for my Hugo course – <a href="https://practicalhugo.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical Hugo</a>. Focusing on a new project meant I didn’t publish a huge amount on my personal site.</p> <p>Practical Hugo got off to a good start, but, to be honest, I started to feel overwhelmed by the challenge of a full-blown course. Then I got sick and struggled to keep it up. To kick things off again, I might try to rework some of the lessons into an email course, or a humble blog of tips. Something that feels less daunting, that will allow me to get finished content out there. Anything to help get the ball rolling, again.</p> <p>I managed to work a couple of Hugo themes – <a href="https://github.com/harrycresswell/mood/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Mood</a> and Notes (which I plan on releasing soon). Progress has been slow, but I enjoy building themes and I’ve got loads of ideas. So thats another thing to explore in 2023.</p> <p>In short, although I haven’t released much into the wild this year, I am working on things. It’s all just taking longer than expected. And, as is often the case, this year, life happened to get in the way.</p> <h3 id="sticking-with-habits">Sticking with habits</h3> <p><strong>Exercise</strong> has ebbed and flowed this year. I was out of the habit of meditating for the first part of the year, but picked it up again when I got sick. Running was the exact opposite. Yoga I’ve been a bit more consistent with, I usually attribute this to it being fairly low intensity and easy to roll out a mat.</p> <p><strong>Writing</strong> is another one I struggled with. I was writing consistently and wrote a fair amount, up until I got sick at the beginning of June. Then I lost motivation and I’ve struggled to find it again, until the last few weeks that is. I guess my energy was elsewhere – focusing on my health, travel and generally taking a break from it all.</p> <p><strong>Studying</strong>. I dabbled with a number of courses this year – Jack Butcher’s <a href="https://visualizevalue.com/collections/courses/products/build-once-sell-twice-the-productization-playbook" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Build Once, Sell Twice</a> and Chris Ferdinandi’s <a href="https://vanillajsguides.com/complete-set/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Vanilla JS Pocket Guides</a> are the ones I’ve stuck at most, but I’m yet to completed either. I would like to be more disiplined in the new year. Perhaps blocking out time in my calander each week to focus on study, but I’m not going to stress if it doesn’t work out.</p> <h2 id="what-did-i-learn">What did I learn</h2> <p>I’m sure I learnt a bunch in 2022, but these are the things that come to mind.</p> <h3 id="talk-about-it">Talk about it</h3> <p>A problem shared is a problem halved. A age-old saying and well worth remembering. For good reason, too – there’s a lot of truth to it.</p> <p>Don’t bottle it up. Seek help if you’re struggling. Talk about your problems, as crazy as them may seem. You’ll be surprised how supportive family and friends can be.</p> <p>For those in the UK, if you can’t get an appointment with the NHS, go private, if you can. There’s plenty of drop in clinics that will see you on the same day. <a href="https://www.doctap.co.uk" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DocTap</a> is one.</p> <p>Your health comes first. Look after it. You can’t do much without it.</p> <h3 id="organise-your-chaos">Organise your chaos</h3> <p>Start using systems to organise the chaos in your digital life. It’s the best way I’ve found to stay focused and deal with the overwhelm of working online. It also feels really good to get on top of things.</p> <p>Use a <a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/notion-web-clipper/knheggckgoiihginacbkhaalnibhilkk" target="_blank" rel="noopener">web clipper</a> to save content to a <a href="https://leananki.com/fight-information-overload/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Reading Inbox</a>. Use Notion, Pocket, Instapaper or whatever – just make sure it’s all in one place and not spread across a bunch of different services.</p> <p>Use a method like <a href="https://fortelabs.com/blog/para/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">P.A.R.A</a> to assign open tabs to projects your working on. Then you can clean up your browser and confidently close it down at the end of each work session.</p> <p>Go through your password manager and close accounts you no longer use. Generate <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/masking-email/">a unique forwarding address</a> for every new account you create – dealing with spam will become a whole lot easier. It’s also great for security.</p> <p>Only keep a years worth of images and videos on your phone. Get yourself an external hard drive and stop paying Apple or whoever for yet more cloud storage. A cloud storage subscription is expensive, for you and for the planet. Only use it for recent things or projects you’re actively working on.</p> <h3 id="social-media-is-optional">Social media is optional</h3> <p>For a long time now, building a following on social media has felt somewhat mandatory for anyone looking to grow a thing – whether it be a business, a side project or some other venture you’re involved in.</p> <p>Since the recent demise of Twitter, it seems that sentiment is starting to change. I believe this is because, as Andy puts it in <a href="https://andy-bell.co.uk/2023-the-year-of-websites/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">2023, the year of websites</a>:</p> <blockquote> <p>“people are also realising—including me—that betting everything on a single place is not great, actually. The only place you really can bet on with confidence is a place that <strong>you created and that you own.</strong> No one can break it, but you.“</p> </blockquote> <p>As someone who has always found social media distracting, stressful, rather unenjoyable, and generally more harm than good, this shift excites me a great deal.</p> <p>I’ve always been weary about building followings on centralized platforms controlled by big tech. I’ve experienced <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/updates/moodboards/">the pitfalls of social media</a> first hand, in the past. And I don’t wish to repeat them. But until recently it has felt like few share this sentiment. Surely we haven’t all forgotten the fate of Bebo, Myspace and practically every other platform that was once <em>the</em> place to hang out?</p> <p>So it’s encouraging to see so many others sharing their concerns and suggesting suitable alternatives.</p> <p>For one, Ash and Ryan lanched <a href="https://bringback.blog/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Bring back blogging</a>, then <a href="https://chriscoyier.net/2022/12/26/bring-back-blogging/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Chris</a> and <a href="https://andy-bell.co.uk/bring-back-blogging/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Andy</a> both share their take on the whole thing. I’m right there too.</p> <p>The shift back to personal websites, microblogging on your own platform and good old RSS, is long over due, IMHO. But let’s not stop there.</p> <p>Jack, who you will likely know through Twitter or Instagram, realised (like many) the constant need to feed the algorithm isn’t sustainable. To put it bluntly – if you don’t post regularly, you disappear.</p> <p>Jack now leverages <a href="https://visualizevalue.com/blogs/feed/social-vs-search" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the benefits of SEO</a>, and for good reason. Jack even offers his personal playbook in his new course <a href="https://visualizevalue.com/collections/courses/products/compound-content" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Compound Content</a>.</p> <p>With this change in momentum, I now realise that <strong>social media is optional</strong>. In other words, don’t feel like you have to use it. It may even be better if you don’t.</p> <p>Let’s be honest, social media is short-term and kinda fickle, so probably not worth the effort. As Jack puts it:</p> <blockquote> <p>The longer you spend building a business on social media, the more you realize you are fighting an uphill battle.</p> </blockquote> <p>On the other hand, owning your own content, and focusing your efforts on SEO, is robust and long-term. Something worth investing your time and energy in.</p> <p>If you do decide to use social media, approach it with caution. Maybe use Mastodon? Just don’t go all-in and be sure as hell it isn’t the <em>source of truth</em> for your content. Instead, aim to own your content, <em>then</em> syndicate to social. There are plenty of ways to make a success without social media. Find what works for you. And don’t ever feel like you have to follow the crowd.</p> <h2 id="final-thoughts">Final thoughts</h2> <p>Just to recap 2022 was a year in which, I:</p> <ul> <li>Travelled to some amazing places and met some incredible people</li> <li>Found focus in my work, mainly by refining my business offering, saying no a lot and only pursuing what I’m into</li> <li>Learnt a lot about myself and managed to feel more comfortable than I’ve ever felt, in my mind and body</li> <li>Started to get on top of my digital footprint, mainly through the process of deleting stuff, which I like to call subtraction (and should write about more)</li> <li>Realised that social media is, in fact, optional and you might be better off without it</li> </ul> <p>Ok, that’s all I’ve got. Here’s to 2023!</p>

item.title: M1 web development setup
item.content:encoded: <p>I just picked up a MacBookPro M1.</p> <p>I held out for as long as I could. But with these summer temperatures, no amount of fan spinning could keep my MacBookPro 2015 from overheating and griding to a hault. It’s been a valiant servant over the years, but sadly its time has come.</p> <p>My aim with this M1 is to keep it as lean as possible. I’ve refrained from copying over my entire machine. Instead, most of it’s gone on to an external hard drive. Only projects I’m actively working are in the cloud with Sync or Github.</p> <p>App-wise, I’ve only installed the absolute essentials – design and web development tools that I use on a daily basis. Let’s hope I can keep it that way and make this beast last for another 7 years, if not longer.</p> <p>For those who are interesting, here are the steps I went through to get set up, including the apps I’ve installed and my general settings.</p> <h2 id="steps">Steps</h2> <ul> <li><a href="#install-homebrew">Install Homebrew</a></li> <li><a href="#install-shell-applications">Install shell applications</a></li> <li><a href="#install-gui-applications">Install GUI applications.</a></li> <li><a href="#setup-shell-with-oh-my-zsh">Setup shell with Oh My Zsh</a></li> <li><a href="#install-node-with-nvm">Install Node with nvm</a></li> <li><a href="#git-configuration">Git configuration</a></li> <li><a href="#github-cli-and-ssh-keys">GitHub CLI and SSH keys</a></li> <li><a href="#macos-settings">macOS settings</a></li> <li><a href="#application-settings">Application settings</a></li> </ul> <h2 id="install-homebrew">Install Homebrew</h2> <p>The <a href="https://brew.sh" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Homebrew</a> package manager allows you to install macOS software via the command line.</p> <p>Install it by pasting the following command in the terminal.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">/bin/bash -c <span class="s2">&#34;</span><span class="k">$(</span>curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh<span class="k">)</span><span class="s2">&#34;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You will be asked for your password.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">Checking <span class="k">for</span> <span class="sb">`</span>sudo<span class="sb">`</span> access <span class="o">(</span>which may request your password<span class="o">)</span>... </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">Password: </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Type in your macOS user account password. When you type, nothing will show on screen for security. Once you’ve typed your password, hit enter.</p> <p>When Homebrew finishes installing, check for any warnings.</p> <p>If you are using an M1 you will probably see the following warning:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">Warning: /opt/homebrew/bin is not in your PATH. </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Follow the instructions in the “Next steps” section to add Homebrew to your PATH:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nb">echo</span> <span class="s1">&#39;eval &#34;$(/opt/homebrew/bin/brew shellenv)&#34;&#39;</span> &gt;&gt; /Users/harrycresswell/.zprofile </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nb">eval</span> <span class="s2">&#34;</span><span class="k">$(</span>/opt/homebrew/bin/brew shellenv<span class="k">)</span><span class="s2">&#34;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Finally, make sure everything is up to date.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew update </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="install-shell-applications">Install shell applications</h2> <p>Install Shell applications using Homebrew.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-bash" data-lang="bash"><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install git </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install go </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install hugo </span></span></code></pre></div><ul> <li><a href="https://git-scm.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">git</a> (version control)</li> <li><a href="https://go.dev" target="_blank" rel="noopener">go</a> (programming)</li> <li><a href="https://gohugo.io" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo</a> (static site generator)</li> </ul> <h2 id="install-gui-applications">Install GUI applications.</h2> <p>Install GUI applications using Homebrew.</p> <p>Use <a href="https://formulae.brew.sh/cask/figma#default" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Homebrew Formulae</a> to find out if there is a cask available for the app you want to install.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-bash" data-lang="bash"><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask affinity-photo </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask affinity-designer </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask bitwarden </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask figma </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask firefox </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask glyphs </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask hyper </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask imageoptim </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask nordvpn </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask numi </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask obsidian </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask rectangle </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask signal </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask slack </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask spotify </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask sync </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask tutanota </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask typora </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask visual-studio-code </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install --cask vivaldi </span></span></code></pre></div><ul> <li><a href="https://affinity.serif.com/en-gb/photo/#top" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Affinity Photo</a> (Photo editing)</li> <li><a href="https://affinity.serif.com/en-gb/designer/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Affinity Designer</a> (Vector and illustration)</li> <li><a href="https://bitwarden.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Bitwarden</a> (Password manager)</li> <li><a href="https://www.figma.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Figma</a> (Web design)</li> <li><a href="https://www.mozilla.org/en-GB/firefox/new/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Firefox</a> (Browser for web development)</li> <li><a href="https://glyphsapp.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Glyphs</a> (Type design)</li> <li><a href="https://hyper.is" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hyper</a> (Terminal)</li> <li><a href="https://imageoptim.com/mac" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ImageOptim</a> (Image compression)</li> <li><a href="https://nordvpn.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">NordVPN</a> (VPN and malware blocker)</li> <li><a href="https://numi.app" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Numi</a> (Calculator)</li> <li><a href="https://obsidian.md" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Obsidian</a> (Note taking and second brain)</li> <li><a href="https://rectangleapp.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Rectangle</a> (Window manager)</li> <li><a href="https://www.signal.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Signal</a> (Encyrpted messaging)</li> <li><a href="https://slack.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Slack</a> (Team and community communication)</li> <li><a href="https://open.spotify.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Spotify</a> (Music)</li> <li><a href="https://www.sync.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sync</a> (Secure cloud storage)</li> <li><a href="https://tutanota.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Tutanota</a> (Secure email)</li> <li><a href="https://typora.io" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Typora</a> (Writing markdown)</li> <li><a href="https://code.visualstudio.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Visual Studio Code</a> (Code editor)</li> <li><a href="https://vivaldi.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Vivaldi</a> (Web browser for browsing)</li> </ul> <p>Apps without a cask to install manually:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/raivo-otp/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Raivo OTP</a> (2FA authenticator)</li> <li><a href="https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/developer/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Firefox developer edition</a> (Browser for web development)</li> </ul> <h2 id="setup-shell-with-oh-my-zsh">Setup shell with Oh My Zsh</h2> <p>Install <a href="https://ohmyz.sh" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Oh My Zsh</a> to configure Zsh shell with sensible defaults.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">sh -c <span class="s2">&#34;</span><span class="k">$(</span>curl -fsSL https://raw.github.com/ohmyzsh/ohmyzsh/master/tools/install.sh<span class="k">)</span><span class="s2">&#34;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="install-node-with-nvm">Install Node with nvm</h2> <p>Use Node Version Manager (nvm) to install Node.js. This will allow you to switch you version of Node easily.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">curl -o- https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nvm-sh/nvm/v0.39.1/install.sh <span class="p">|</span> bash </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now close your terminal, then reopen to start nvm.</p> <h3 id="install">Install</h3> <p>Install the latest version of Node.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">nvm install node </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Make sure you’re using nvm version of node.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">nvm use node </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Confirm you’re using the latest verison of nvm, Node and npm.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">nvm --version <span class="o">&amp;&amp;</span> node -v <span class="o">&amp;&amp;</span> npm -v </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="update">Update</h3> <p>If you need to update nvm in the future, use the following command:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">nvm install node --reinstall-packages-from<span class="o">=</span>node </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="change-version">Change version</h3> <p>Install new version.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">nvm install xx.xx </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Switch to new version.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">nvm use xx.xx </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="git-configuration">Git configuration</h2> <p>Set up your global name and email.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">git config --global user.name <span class="s2">&#34;Firstname Lastname&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">git config --global user.email you@example.com </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Set default branch name to <code>main</code> instead of master.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">git config --global init.defaultBranch main </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Check your global configurations.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">git config --list </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">user.name<span class="o">=</span>Firstname Lastname </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">user.email<span class="o">=</span>you@example.com </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">init.defaultBranch main </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Check specific values using the following command:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">git config &lt;key&gt; </span></span></code></pre></div><p>For example, to check your username:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">git config user.name </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">Firstname Lastname </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You can also use the following command to open and edit your global configurations, directly from your git config file.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">open ~/.gitconfig </span></span></code></pre></div><div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="o">[</span>user<span class="o">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">name</span> <span class="o">=</span> Firstname Lastname </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">email</span> <span class="o">=</span> you@example.com </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="o">[</span>github<span class="o">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">user</span> <span class="o">=</span> username </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="o">[</span>alias<span class="o">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">a</span> <span class="o">=</span> add </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">ca</span> <span class="o">=</span> commit -a </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">cam</span> <span class="o">=</span> commit -am </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">cm</span> <span class="o">=</span> commit -m </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">s</span> <span class="o">=</span> status </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">p</span> <span class="o">=</span> push </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">pom</span> <span class="o">=</span> push origin master </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">puom</span> <span class="o">=</span> pull origin master </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">cob</span> <span class="o">=</span> checkout -b </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">co</span> <span class="o">=</span> checkout </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">fp</span> <span class="o">=</span> fetch --prune --all </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">l</span> <span class="o">=</span> log --oneline --decorate --graph </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">lall</span> <span class="o">=</span> log --oneline --decorate --graph --all </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nv">ls</span> <span class="o">=</span> log --oneline --decorate --graph --stat </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="github-cli-and-ssh-keys">GitHub CLI and SSH keys</h2> <p>The <a href="https://cli.github.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Github CLI</a> allows you to interact with Github from the command line.</p> <p>Install it using Homebrew with the following command:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">brew install gh </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now login by copy and pasting the following command into the terminal.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">gh auth login -s <span class="s1">&#39;user:email&#39;</span> -w </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The Github CLI will ask you several questions.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">? What is your preferred protocol <span class="k">for</span> Git operations? </span></span></code></pre></div><p>With the arrows, choose <code>SSH</code> and press <code>Enter</code>. SSH is a protocol to log in using SSH keys instead of the well known username/password pair.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">Generate a new SSH key to add to your GitHub account? </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Press <code>Enter</code> to ask gh to generate the SSH keys for you.</p> <p>If you already have SSH keys, you will see instead: </p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">Upload your SSH public key to your GitHub account? </span></span></code></pre></div><p>With the arrows, select your public key file path and press <code>Enter</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">Enter a passphrase <span class="k">for</span> your new SSH key <span class="o">(</span>Optional<span class="o">)</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Then press <code>Enter</code> to leave this blank. Unless you want to enter a passphrase each time you commit and push changes to GitHub. In which case, enter a passphrase of your choice.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">Title <span class="k">for</span> your SSH key </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Choose something descriptive like MacBookPro (14-inch, 2021).</p> <p>You will then see the following, with a unqiue one-time code:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">! First copy your one-time code: 7270-8A57 </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">Press Enter to open github.com in your browser... </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Copy your one-time code, then press <code>enter</code>.</p> <p>Your browser will open and ask you to authorize GitHub CLI with your Github account.</p> <p>Once your account is authorized, you will see something like this in your terminal:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">Authentication complete. </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">- gh config <span class="nb">set</span> -h github.com git_protocol ssh </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">✓ Configured git protocol </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">✓ Uploaded the SSH key to your GitHub account: /Users/harrycresswell/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">✓ Logged in as harrycresswell </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You can check your connection using the following command:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-shell" data-lang="shell"><span class="line"><span class="cl">gh auth status </span></span></code></pre></div><p>If your configured and connected correctly, you will see the following:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>github.com ✓ Logged in to github.com as harrycresswell (oauth_token) ✓ Git operations for github.com configured to use ssh protocol. ✓ Token: ******************* </code></pre><h2 id="macos-settings">macOS settings</h2> <ul> <li>System Preferences: <ul> <li>Siri: - Disable <em>Ask Siri</em></li> <li>Dock &amp; Menu bar: <ul> <li>Remove all apps except Finder, System Preferences and Trash</li> <li>Reduce Dock size</li> <li>Turn on <em>Automatically hide and show the Dock</em></li> <li>Turn off <em>Show recent applications in Dock</em></li> <li>Battery &gt; Turn on <em>Show percentage</em></li> </ul> </li> <li>Notifications: <ul> <li>Turn off all notifications</li> </ul> </li> <li>Security &amp; Privacy: <ul> <li>FileVault &gt; <em>Turn FileVault On</em></li> <li>Apps that can control computer: <ul> <li>Privacy &gt; Accessibility &gt; Add Rectangle</li> <li>Privacy &gt; Camera &gt; Add browser</li> <li>Privacy &gt; Microphone &gt; Add browser</li> <li>Privacy &gt; Screen Recording &gt; Add browser</li> </ul> </li> </ul> </li> <li>Touch ID: <ul> <li>Enable</li> </ul> </li> <li>Bluetooth: <ul> <li>Pair Trackpad, Keyboard and Airpods Pro</li> </ul> </li> <li>Trackpad <ul> <li>Increase <em>Tracking speed</em></li> </ul> </li> <li>Keyboard <ul> <li>Text <ul> <li>Disable <em>Capitalise word automatically</em></li> <li>Disable <em>Add full stop with double space</em></li> <li>Disable <em>Use Smart quotes and dashes</em></li> </ul> </li> <li>Shortcuts <ul> <li>Enable <em>Use keyboard navigation to move focus between controls</em></li> </ul> </li> </ul> </li> <li>Displays <ul> <li>Night Shift &gt; Sunset to Sunrise</li> </ul> </li> <li>Sharing: <ul> <li>Disable file sharing</li> <li>Update <em>Computer Name</em></li> </ul> </li> </ul> </li> <li>Finder: <ul> <li>View &gt; Show status bar</li> <li>View &gt; Show path bar</li> <li>Sidebar: <ul> <li>Favourites <ul> <li>Disable Recents, Documents, Movies, Music and Pictures</li> </ul> </li> <li>General <ul> <li>Show these items on desktop: <ul> <li>External Disks</li> <li>CDs, DVDs and iPods</li> </ul> </li> </ul> </li> </ul> </li> </ul> </li> </ul> <h2 id="application-settings">Application settings</h2> <p>Here are my settings for the applications you’re most likely interested in.</p> <h3 id="visual-studio-code">Visual Studio Code</h3> <p>Press <code>CMD + SHIFT + P</code>, then search “Install code command in PATH” and click to start using <code>code .</code> to open files from the terminal in VSCode.</p> <p>VS Code has a feature called <a href="https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/settings-sync" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Settings Sync</a> which you can use sync your VSCode settings, keybindings and extensions with your new device. It makes the transition from one machine to another seamless.</p> <h4 id="extensions">Extensions</h4> <ul> <li><a href="https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=sdras.night-owl" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Night Owl</a></li> <li><a href="https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=bungcip.better-toml" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Better TOML</a></li> <li><a theme and settings, open the preferences file in VSCode.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>code ~/.hyper.js </code></pre><p>Then update the exports object with the following config and plugins.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">module</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">exports</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">config</span><span class="nx">borderColors</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;#fc1da7&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;#542bff&#39;</span><span Preferences</em></li> <li>Enable <em>Focus all controls</em></li> </ul> </li> <li>Keyboad Shortcuts <ul> <li>Enable <em>Keyboard Shortcuts</em></li> </ul> </li> </ul> </li> <li>Search <ul> <li>Set Default Seach Engine to DuckDuckGo</li> </ul> </li> <li>Webpages <ul> <li>Enable <em>Smooth Scrolling</em></li> <li>Webpage Focus <ul> <li>Enable <em>Focus All Controls and Links</em></li> </ul> </li> </ul> </li> </ul> </li> </ul> <h4 id="browser-extensions">Browser extensions</h4> <ul> <li><a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/bitwarden-free-password-m/nngceckbapebfimnlniiiahkandclblb" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Bitwarden</a></li> <li><a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/simpleloginreceive-send-e/dphilobhebphkdjbpfohgikllaljmgbn" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SimpleLogin</a></li> <li><a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/notion-web-clipper/knheggckgoiihginacbkhaalnibhilkk" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Notion Web Clipper</a></li> <li><a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/bubbles-screenshot-and-sc/ppbfhhgcdehhbjigifndnfmcihegokbb" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Bubbles</a></li> <li><a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/gofullpage-full-page-scre/fdpohaocaechififmbbbbbknoalclacl" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GoFullPage</a></li> <li><a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/fonts-ninja/eljapbgkmlngdpckoiiibecpemleclhh" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Fonts Ninja</a></li> </ul> <h2 id="summary">Summary</h2> <p>How you setup a new machine will always be a personal thing. But nonetheless, I hope you find some of this helpful for your own setup.</p> <p>This is actually the first time I’ve bothered to document this process. Seems kinda bizzare now I think of it, as I’m sure–like with most the words I write down–I’ll be grateful I did, when I return to them later.</p> <p>After all, setting up a new machine for web development can be a dauting process. But with a roadmap to follow, the process should be a whole lot easier.</p> <p>Whilst much of my setup was inspired by my previous one, I have to shout out the folk below. To some extent, their setups have inspired my own.</p> <h2 id="resources">Resources</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.swyx.io/new-mac-setup/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">My 2022 New Mac Setup</a> from swyx</li> <li><a href="https://www.robinwieruch.de/mac-setup-web-development/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Mac Setup for Web Development [2022]</a> from Robin Wieruch</li> <li><a href="https://www.taniarascia.com/setting-up-a-brand-new-mac-for-development/?ck_subscriber_id=591519942#homebrew" target="_blank" rel="noopener">macOS Monterey: Setting up a Mac for Development</a> from Tania Rascia</li> </ul>

item.title: Page, Site and Params
item.content:encoded: <p>Methods and parameters play a key role in storing, accessing and returning data in Hugo projects. So understanding how they work is critical.</p> <p>Page and Site are two categories of methods you’ll find yourself using in every project. Both exist for different reasons and give you access to different types of data.</p> <p>This post looks at the difference between the two, including how Params fit into the equation, and the nuances to look out for when working with each.</p> <h2 id="page-methods">Page methods</h2> <p>Page methods give you access to the Page object, which gathers all the data associated with content files into a single object.</p> <p>Most often that means any data found in the front matter of a content file. But it can also mean data derived from the content’s file location, or data extracted from the content body, itself.</p> <p>Consider the following <em>content/_index.md</em> file, for example. This file is reserved explictly for homepage content.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-markdown" data-lang="markdown"><span class="line"><span class="cl">--- </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">title: My new Hugo website </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">date: 2022-06-22T12:39:30+01:00 </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">--- </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">Some home page content </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice the file consists of both front matter (the structured data at the top), and body content, otherwise known as markdown.</p> <p>To render this content you might have a <em>layouts/index.html</em> template, that looks something like this.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">define</span> <span class="s">&#34;main&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">article</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">header</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">time</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Date</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">time</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">header</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Content</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">article</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Here you’ll find three Page Methods; <code>.Title</code>, <code>.Date</code> and <code>.Content</code>. Notice all of these Methods are prefixed with a dot.</p> <p>Before we go any further, it’s important to understand what that dot is doing and why it’s there.</p> <p>In Hugo, the dot holds the current context. Context or <em>scope</em>, as it’s often referred to, is the object of data available to you at certain points in your templates. Hugo stores this object of data in the dot, so it’s easy for you to get hold of.</p> <p>By default, the context of all layout templates is set to Page. Meaning, by default, the data you can access within your layout templates is Page data. Or, put simply, the data associated with the files in your content folder.</p> <p>So, to access this data, we use the dot, followed by the Page method that stores the data we want to return.</p> <p>Returning to the example above, the first Page method we encounter is <code>.Title</code>, which returns the title found in the front matter of the <em>content/_index.md</em> file.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>My new Hugo website<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p><code>.Date</code> is the next Page method, which returns the publish date of a piece of content. Notice that the <em>date</em> is also set in the front matter of the content file, just like the title.</p> <p><code>.Content</code> does something similar to these two methods. But rather than pull the data from the front matter, it returns the markdown from the body of the file.
