In other words, anything found in the page, that falls outside of the front matter.</p> <p>Using the example from earlier again, <code>.Content</code> returns the following:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Some homepage content<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In all of the scenarios above, we’re working with Page data, which is accessible using Page methods.</p> <h3 id="page-methods-are-pre-defined">Page Methods are pre-defined</h3> <p>It’s important to note that <code>.Title</code>, <code>.Date</code> and <code>.Content</code> are all pre-defined Page methods. In other words, these methods are built-in to Hugo. They serve a specific purpose and return specific data.</p> <p>You will notice pre-defined Page methods are written in camel case and all start with an uppercase letter.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>.Title // correct .title // incorrect .Content // correct .content // incorrect .RegularPages // correct .regularpages // incorrect </code></pre><p>There are many more pre-defined <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/page/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Page Methods</a> we can use to access data from content files. Let’s look at a few more examples.</p> <h4 id="access-certain-pages-with-pages">Access certain Pages with <code>.Pages</code></h4> <p><code>.Pages</code> is used to access data from content files, based on their location. In other words, files in certain folders, and the data they contain.</p> <p>As per the Hugo docs, <code>.Pages</code> returns:</p> <blockquote> <p>[a] collection of <em>regular</em> pages and <em>only first-level</em> section pages under the current <em>list</em> page.</p> </blockquote> <p>To make sense of this, consider the current structure of the content folder on my personal website:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>content/ learn-hugo/ index.md newsletter/ _index.md 01.md 02.md [...] page/ uses.md now.md contact.md [...] updates/ _index.md 21-12-06-sharing-more.md [...] writing/ _index.md 5-question-problem-solving-strategy.md [...] </code></pre><p>Let’s say I want to display a list of these sections on my homepage. I do this from my <em>layouts/index.html</em> template, where I pass <code>.Pages</code> into the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/range/#prose" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Range</a> function to loop through the data:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Pages</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">li</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>When I run <code>hugo server</code>, I find a list of only the first-level section pages on my homepage. But only the first-level pages, none of the pages inside these section.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">- Learn Hugo </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">- Updates </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">- Page </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">- Newsletter </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">- Writing </span></span></code></pre></div><p>At this point, I might use the <code>.Permalink</code> Page Method to return the path to a content file and create an anchor link.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Pages</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="nx">a</span> <span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Permalink }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Like <code>.Title</code>, <code>.Permalink</code> is another pre-defined Method. But, this time the data doesn’t need to be defined in the page front matter, as it’s formed using the name of the content file.</p> <p>For example, <code>my-latest-post.md</code> becomes:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>&lt;h2&gt;&lt;a href=&#34;my-latest-post&#34;&gt;My latest post&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h2&gt; </code></pre><p>With the Range over <code>.Pages</code> included, here’s what my <em>layouts/index.html</em> file looks like:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">define</span> <span class="s">&#34;main&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">article</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">header</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">time</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Date</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">time</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">header</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Content</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Pages</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">a</span> <span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Permalink }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">article</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice I’m using the <code>.Title</code> method twice in my <em>index.html</em> template. The one found in the <code>&lt;header&gt;</code> returns the value of <em>title</em>, found in my <em>content/_index.md</em> file. However, the one found inside the Range logic returns the title of each Page in the <code>.Pages</code> object.</p> <p>So, why is that?</p> <p>The simple answer is that Range changes the context (the data available to you) to whatever you pass into the function.</p> <p>In this case, we passed in <code>.Pages</code>, so <code>.Title</code> returns the title of each Page in the Pages object.</p> <p>It’s important to remember this when working with Page methods. The data you can access depends on where you happen to be in your templates, and what logic you happen to write.</p> <p>The With function is another example of a function that changes the context. But, we’ll leave that for another day, and instead, look at the Page Method you can use to access custom data.</p> <h3 id="using-the-params-method-to-access-custom-page-data">Using the Params Method to access custom Page data</h3> <p>There are times when you’ll want to add custom data to a page. You can do this by defining your own front matter in your content files.</p> <p>These are known as Page-level Parameters and to access this custom data you use a Page method called <code>.Params</code>, which returns a map of these custom parameters. Let’s take a look at an example.</p> <p>Here I’ve added my Twitter handle to the front matter of my <em>content/_index.md</em> file. The data consists of a key-value pair, just like <em>title</em> and <em>date</em>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-markdown" data-lang="markdown"><span class="line"><span class="cl">--- </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">title: My new Hugo website </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">date: Add a date </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">twitter: https://twitter.com/harrycresswell </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">--- </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">Some homepage content </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I’d like to return the value (the absolute URL to my Twitter profile) on my homepage, in the form of a link.</p> <p>To do this, I’ll return to my <em>layouts/index.html</em> template. Here I append my custom key (twitter, in this case) to the <code>.Params</code> Method.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ define &#34;main&#34; }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">article</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">header</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .Title }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">header</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ .Content }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">footer</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Params.twitter }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Twitter<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">footer</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">article</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice <code>.twitter</code> is written all in lowercase. It’s important to note that whereas Page methods are written using uppercase (e.g .Params), a custom parameter itself must always be written in lowercase.</p> <p>In the generated website, Hugo renders the URL value in the <code>href=&quot;&quot;</code> attribute of the anchor element, as expected.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">footer</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://twitter.com/harrycresswell&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Twitter<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">footer</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>It’s worth noting that custom parameters can also be nested.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>--- title: My new Hugo website date: Add a date social: twitter: https://twitter.com/harrycresswell github: https://github.com/harrycresswell polywork: https://www.polywork.com/harrycresswell --- Some homepage content </code></pre><p>Nested parameters are accessed by concatenating the field names together:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">footer</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Params.social.twitter }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Twitter<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Params.social.github }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Github<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Params.social.polywork }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Polywork<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">footer</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now you have a good grasp of Page methods and custom parameters. Let’s turn to Site Methods, so we can understand the differences.</p> <h2 id="site-methods">Site Methods</h2> <p>Site Methods give you access to global data that applies to your entire website. Global data is typically defined in the <em>config.toml</em> or <em>hugo.toml</em> file, but not always. Like Page Methods, there are various Site Methods which have been built-in to Hugo’s core, for convenience.</p> <p>Hugo provides <code>.Site</code> to give you access to this global object of data from a Page context. In other words, from inside your layout templates. So, <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/page/site/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">.Site is a Page Method</a>, in fact, that you use to get hold of Site Methods. Kinda confusing, right?</p> <p>The most important thing to remember is that <em><code>.Site</code> exposes your global Methods to the Page context</em>.</p> <p>To get a better understanding of <code>.Site</code>, let’s consider an example.</p> <p>Below you’ll find my <em>layouts/index.html</em> template, again.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ define &#34;main&#34; }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">article</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">header</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .Site.Title }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">header</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ .Content }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">article</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice I’ve updated the <code>&lt;h1&gt;</code> element, from <code>.Title</code> to <code>.Site.Title</code>.</p> <p>Now, my <em>index.html</em> template no longer returns the title from my <em>_index.md</em> file. But instead returns the title from the <em>config.toml</em> file, where site settings are stored.</p> <p><code>.Site.Title</code> is a pre-defined site method, meaning it’s built-in to Hugo and serves a specific purpose: to return the title of your website, as defined in your configuration file.</p> <h3 id="site-methods-are-pre-defined">Site Methods are pre-defined</h3> <p>Just like with Page Methods, there are many more pre-defined <a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/site/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Site Methods</a> you can use.</p> <p><code>.Site.baseURL</code>, for example, is returns the root URL of your website, as defined in the site configuration. You’ll find yourself using it to built absolute paths in your templates.</p> <p>Consider the following code found in the <code>&lt;head&gt;</code> of my personal site.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">link</span> <span class="na">rel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;apple-touch-icon&#34;</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://harrycresswell.com/img/apple-touch-icon.png&#34;</span> <span class="na">sizes</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;180x180&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">link</span> <span class="na">rel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;icon&#34;</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://harrycresswell.com/img/favicon-32x32.png&#34;</span> <span class="na">sizes</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;32x32&#34;</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/png&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">link</span> <span class="na">rel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;icon&#34;</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://harrycresswell.com/img/favicon-16x16.png&#34;</span> <span class="na">sizes</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;16x16&#34;</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/png&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">link</span> <span class="na">rel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;shortcut icon&#34;</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://harrycresswell.com/img/favicon.ico&#34;</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/x-icon&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice each <code>&lt;link&gt;</code> tag contains the root URL <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">https://harrycresswell.com/</a>. Similar code appears on most websites. But, as you’d expect, this root URL changes for each site.</p> <p>Updating this URL in many different places is inefficient. Ideally, you want to make it as easy to reuse as possible.</p> <p>To achieve this, it makes sense to store the URL in a variable and manage it from one place – the config file.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">baseURL</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;https://harrycresswell.com/&#34;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>With the baseURL stored in the config file, you can access the value in your templates using the <code>.Site.BaseURL</code> variable. Now you have a reusable piece of code, that you don’t need to update on each site.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">link</span> <span class="na">rel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;apple-touch-icon&#34;</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Site.BaseURL }}img/apple-touch-icon.png&#34;</span> <span class="na">sizes</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;180x180&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">link</span> <span class="na">rel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;icon&#34;</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Site.BaseURL }}img/favicon-32x32.png&#34;</span> <span class="na">sizes</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;32x32&#34;</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/png&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">link</span> <span class="na">rel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;icon&#34;</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Site.BaseURL }}img/favicon-16x16.png&#34;</span> <span class="na">sizes</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;16x16&#34;</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/png&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">link</span> <span class="na">rel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;shortcut icon&#34;</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Site.BaseURL }}img/favicon.ico&#34;</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/x-icon&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>It’s worth remembering there will be many more places in your templates where you will require your <code>baseURL</code>. And it might well change when you launch your site. So storing it in the config file, will make working with it trivial.</p> <h4 id="grab-menus-from-the-config-file-with-sitemenus">Grab menus from the config file with <code>.Site.Menus</code></h4> <p><code>.Site.Menus</code> is another pre-defined Site Method. It’s used to return the menus you define in your config file. As menus usually apply to an entire website, it makes sense to store this data with the rest of your site configuration.</p> <p>Consider the <strong>main</strong> menu I’ve defined in <a href="https://github.com/harrycresswell/harry/blob/master/config.toml" target="_blank" rel="noopener">my <em>config.toml</em></a>, as an example.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Index&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;/&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">5</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Writing&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;/writing/&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Newsletter&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;/newsletter/&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">15</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Topics&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;/topics/&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In my templates, I can loop through the data by passing <code>.Site.Menus</code> into the Range function.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">nav</span> <span class="nx">aria</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="nx">label</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Main Navigation&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">currentPage</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">a</span> <span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .URL }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Name</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now, to access my <strong>main</strong> menu data, all I need to do is append the name of the menu to the Method.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>.Site.Menus.main </code></pre><p>Notice the parameter “main” is written in lowercase. That’s because it’s user-defined. In other words, a custom definition, defined by me and not a Method in and of itself.</p> <p>Within the Range function, the context changes to main menu data and I now have access the <code>.Name</code> and <code>.URL</code> of each menu item.</p> <p> On a side note; I’ve written in detail about <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/menus-in-hugo/">Menus in Hugo</a>. </p> <h4 id="access-all-pages-with-sitepages">Access all pages with <code>.Site.Pages</code></h4> <p>Site doesn’t only expose settings defined in the <em>config.toml</em> file. It also gives you access to an array, or collection of certain content.</p> <p><code>.Site.Pages</code>, for example, returns a collection of <strong>all</strong> pages found in a site: <em>regular</em> pages, sections, taxonomies, etc.</p> <p>Pass it into the Range function, the same as you do with <code>.Pages</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ range .Site.Pages }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .Title }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>But, unlike <code>.Pages</code>, which can only be used in list templates (including the homepage) where the context is Page. You can access <code>.Site.Pages</code> from any context in your templates – a <em>single.html</em> templates or partial file, for example. This is because <code>.Site</code> exposes the global context.</p> <h4 id="access-all-taxonomies-with-sitetaxonomies">Access all taxonomies with <code>.Site.Taxonomies</code></h4> <p><code>.Site.Taxonomies</code> is another Site Method that exposes global data. But this time, an object of taxonomies (categories, tags and so on), found across your entire website.</p> <p>This object of taxonomies depends on what data you define in the front matter of each page. Let’s take a look at an example.</p> <p>Below you will find the front matter from a recent article I wrote about De-Googling.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>--- title: &#34;De-Googling&#34; date: 2022-05-13T16:00:14+01:00 description: &#34;I’m doing what I can to minimise my dependence on Google services.&#34; slug: &#34;de-googling&#34; topics: [&#34;Privacy&#34;, &#34;Tools&#34;] --- </code></pre><p>And, here’s another about working with data in Hugo.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>--- title: &#34;Working with Data in Hugo&#34; date: 2018-07-18T14:35:58+02:00 description: &#34;Learn how to utilise Data in Hugo to keep your code clean and your projects well organised.&#34; slug: &#34;data-hugo&#34; topics: [&#34;Hugo&#34;] --- </code></pre><p>In both cases you’ll find a <em>topics</em> key, with an array of values. Like any taxonomy, this attempts to organise the content into associated groups.</p> <p>Hugo natively supports two taxonomy types, <em>categories</em> and <em>tags</em>. However, in this case, <em>topics</em> is a custom taxonomy. For Hugo to recognise this custom taxonomy, I will need to tell Hugo about it by defining it in my <em>config.toml</em> file.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">taxonomies</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">topic</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;topics&#34;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>To create a list of all the topics found across my website, I’ve made a <em>layouts/taxonomy/list.html</em> template.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ range .Site.Taxonomies.topics }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .Page.Title }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>To loop through the data, I pass the method into a Range function and append the <em>topics</em> key to the end. To return the title of each topic I use <code>.Page.Title</code>, rather than <code>.Title</code> alone.</p> <p>Taking this further is perhaps outside the scope of this article, however it’s worth looking at my <a href="https://github.com/harrycresswell/harry/blob/master/themes/hc-starter/layouts/taxonomy/topic.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">topic single page template</a>, if you want to create a page for each topic and list the content pages within the taxonomy.</p> <h4 id="access-data-files-with-sitedata">Access Data files with <code>.Site.Data</code></h4> <p>As we’ve seen in the previous two examples, not all <code>.Site</code> Methods expose data from the config file. Some Site Methods are used to access data from elsewhere.</p> <p>One such method is <code>.Site.Data</code>, which is used to fetch data from the data folder. The data folder is a place to store data files that contain data associated with your website, which don’t necessarily require a dedicated page.</p> <p>The <em>data/settings/signup.yaml</em> file I use on my personal website is a good example of this.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>assets/ content/ data/ settings/ signup.yaml themes/ config.toml ... </code></pre><p>This file contains the text content and list URL associated with the newsletter sign up form, found in the footer of my site.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nn">---</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Monthly Newsletter</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">desc</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Once a month I curate a newletter for designers and developers interested in static sites, CSS and web performance. Check out [past issues](/newsletter) to get an idea.</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">list_url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">https://harrycresswell.us14.list-manage.com/subscribe/post?u=4e8fba8d0ab4a857159c0104e&amp;amp;id=d6ad2b65ca</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>In theory, I might have hardcoded this data directly into my <em>newsletter.html</em> partial template. But it’s much easier to manage this content, if the data is written in YAML and abstracted away from the template, to it’s own dedicated file.</p> <p>To access this data from my templates, I can use the <code>.Site.Data</code> method, then concatenate the folder name, followed by file name, and finally the title field.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Data</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">settings</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">signup</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">title</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">markdownify</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice how this approach follows a similar pattern to working with nested Page-level Params. Where all the parameter keys are written in lowercase, as, like Page parameters, they are custom data.</p> <h3 id="using-the-params-method-to-access-custom-site-data">Using the Params Method to access custom Site data</h3> <p>Just as you can create custom Page-level parameters, you can do the same on a Site-wide level, by defining custom parameters in your <em>config.toml</em> or <em>hugo.toml</em> file.</p> <p>These are often referred to as Site Params, and are handy for storing anything that applies to your entire website. Default SEO meta data is a good example.</p> <p>Consider my <code>config.toml</code> file.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">baseURL</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;https://harrycresswell.com/&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">title</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Harry Cresswell&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">params</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">description</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Harry Cresswell is a professional designer and front-end web developer from London, England.&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">strapline</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Design and front-end web development&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">location</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;London, UK&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">card_image</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;img/card-image.png&#34;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice these custom Site parameters are stored under the <code>[params]</code> keyword, whereas pre-defined Site parameters, such as <code>baseURL</code>, sit at the top level.</p> <p>For the sake of clarity, when working with TOML data I prefer to indent any params I add. However, it’s not necessary and won’t effect the structure of your data.</p> <p>To access Site parameters, Hugo provides the <a href="https://gohugo.io/variables/site/#the-siteparams-variable" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><code>.Site.Params</code> Method</a>.</p> <p>Consider the <em>layouts/partials/head.html</em> template below.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">head</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ .Site.Title }} – {{ .Site.Params.strapline }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">meta</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;description&#34;</span> <span class="na">content</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Site.Params.description }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">head</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Just like with Page-level Params, append the custom parameter (written in all lowercase) to the <code>.Site.Params</code> Method, to access a specfic value.</p> <h3 id="accessing-global-data-from-anywhere">Accessing global data from anywhere</h3> <p>There are times when you want to access global data, but, by default, you can’t. An example of this is from partial files, which have no context, by default.</p> <p>In this case, you have two options.</p> <h4 id="passing-the-context-and-using-the-site-method">Passing the context and using the .Site Method</h4> <p>You can either pass the Page context into the partial using the dot.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">partial</span> <span class="s">&#34;footer.html&#34;</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Remember: <strong>current context is stored in the dot</strong>. And, the default context of templates is set to Page. So the dot passes Page context into the partial, giving you access to Page data.</p> <p>Now, you can use <code>.Site</code> inside the partial to access Site variables. As mentioned, the reason for this that <code>.Site</code> is, in fact, a Page Method. And, so exposes a sites global data to the Page context.</p> <p>But there’s also another way to access global data, from anywhere.</p> <h4 id="using-the-global-site-function">Using the global <code>site</code> function</h4> <p>The global <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/global/site/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">site function</a> gives you access to your sites global data stored in the <code>config.toml</code> file, when the <code>Page</code> object isn’t available.</p> <p>To give you a similfied example of how this works, let’s say I include a partial inside one of my template, but this time without passing the Page context to it (notice the dot is left out).</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">partial</span> <span class="s">&#34;footer.html&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>By using the <code>site</code> function instead of <code>.Site</code>, I can still access global data inside my <code>layouts/partials/footer.html</code> file.</p> <p>Here I’m returing the title stored in my config.toml file:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="nx">site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice the lack of a dot before site and a lowercase “s” in the word site.</p> <p>If I tried to use the <code>.Site</code> variable instead, my title wouldn’t rended.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This is because <code>.Site</code> is a Page Method, which gives us access to Site Methods. But, in this case, I haven’t passed the Page context to the partial, so the variable isn’t available.</p> <h2 id="combining-site-and-page">Combining .Site and .Page</h2> <p>Remember my newsletter sign up form from earlier? At one point I decided I wanted to be able to change the content in this form on a page-by-page basis.</p> <p>To make sense of this, let’s consider a page I once had on this site called “Learn Hugo”, which has since been retired in favour of <a href="http://practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a website of its own</a>. On this now non-existant page, the title of the newsletter sign up said “Sign up for Hugo course”, whilst on every other page on this site it says “Monthly newsletter”. So how does this work?</p> <p>To acheive this I added key-value pairs to the front matter of my <em>learn-hugo/index.md</em> file. That way I could override the initial values found in <em>data/settings/signup.yaml</em>:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nn">---</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Learn Hugo&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">date</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="ld">2021-12-06T11:37:59Z</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">draft</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">false</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">description</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">slug</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;learn-hugo&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">layout</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;page&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">signup_title</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Sign up for Hugo course&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">signup_desc</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;If you’d like to be the first to receive content for my Hugo course by email, as it’s published, then please leave your details below.&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">signup_button_text</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Learn Hugo&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">signup_group</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;hugo&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nn">---</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>Inside my <em>newsletter.html</em> partial, I wrote some simple logic using the With function, which returns the Page-level data, should it exist.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ with .Params.signup_title | markdownify }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ . }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ else }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ .Site.Data.settings.signup.title | markdownify }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In cases where these Page-level params don’t exit (which is most cases), Hugo will be return data from <em>data/settings/signup.yaml</em>. But, for Pages where these Params do exist, Hugo will render this data from the content file.</p> <p>It’s worth noting, you can achieve the exact same results with a more structured front matter. To stay orgainsed, this might, in fact, be the better approach.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nn">---</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Learn Hugo&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">date</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="ld">2021-12-06T11:37:59Z</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">draft</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">false</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">description</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">slug</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;learn-hugo&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">layout</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;page&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">settings</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">signup</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Sign up for Hugo course&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">desc</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;If you’d like to be the first to receive content for my Hugo course by email, as it’s published, then please leave your details below.&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">button_text</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Learn Hugo&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">group</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;hugo&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nn">---</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice, the data structure now reflects the format of the data found in the data/settings/signup.yaml file. Meaning, you can return the data by concatenating the Method and the parameters in the exact same way.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">with</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Params</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">settings</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">signup</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">title</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">markdownify</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Data</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">settings</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">signup</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">title</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">markdownify</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Let’s look at one final example.</p> <p>Here I’m returning to the <code>head.html</code> partial, from earlier.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">head</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ .Site.Title }} | {{ .Site.Params.strapline }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">meta</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;description&#34;</span> <span class="na">content</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Site.Params.description }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">head</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This works great for the homepage. But, to improve SEO, you’d most likely want to change both the <em>title</em> and the <em>description</em> on a page-by-page basis.</p> <p>With some simple logic, you can look for a Page-level description, should it exist. Then fallback to your global site description Param, if not.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">head</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ if .IsHome -}} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ .Site.Title }} | {{ .Site.Params.strapline }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- else -}} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ .Title }} | {{ .Site.Title }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{- end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">meta</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;description&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">content</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34; </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ with .Params.description }} </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ . }} </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ else }} </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .Site.Params.description }} </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ end }} </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> &#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">head</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now for the <em>title</em>. If the current page is the homepage, we’ll show the <code>.Site.Title</code> from the <em>config.toml</em>. And, if not, we’ll return the Page-level title, followed by the Site title.</p> <p>Now my Homepage will display this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">head</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Harry Cresswell | Design and front end web development<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">meta</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;description&#34;</span> <span class="na">content</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Harry Cresswell is a professional designer and front-end web developer from London, England.&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">head</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Whereas a post page display something like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">head</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Masking email | Harry Cresswell<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">meta</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;description&#34;</span> <span class="na">content</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;How to protect your privacy, fight spam and reclaim control of your email address.&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">head</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I’ve shown you these examples to help illustrate how Page Methods, Site Methods and in both cases Params, are often used together. But there are no hard and fast rules here. How you combine Site and Page Methods depends on what you are trying to build and what data you want to access.</p> <h2 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping up</h2> <p><a href="https://gohugo.io/variables/page/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Page Methods</a> give you access to page data that Hugo stores in the Page object. That means any data associated with your content files, which are used to build the pages of your website.</p> <p><a href="https://gohugo.io/methods/site/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Site Methods</a> give you access global data that Hugo stores in Site objects. This often means data defined in your site configuration, but it can also mean data defined as custom data stored in Data files. Site Methods are nuanced because they are also used to access global objects of data, such as all pages and all taxonomies.</p> <p>Most Page and Site Methods are used for returning pre-determinded types of data. However the <code>.Page.Params</code> and <code>.Site.Params</code> Methods can be used for returning custom data.</p> <p>The former will give you access to custom data that you have defined in the front matter of content files. Whereas the latter will give you access to custom data stored in your configuration file. Both Methods are very useful when you have specific needs that Hugo doesn’t cater for, out of the box.</p>

item.title: Masking email
item.content:encoded: <p>I’ve started using email aliases. They help you stay anonymous when signing up for things, and give you control over who can send you email.</p> <p>Various terms are flying around for this technology, but I’ve been calling it email masking. Whatever you choose to call it, the concept is simple.</p> <p>With the click of a button, generate a random email address for every account you create. These disposable addresses are configured to forward email to your real email address. So you never have to reveal your private address.</p> <p>The idea is you create a unique, anonymous address for any app, website or newsletter you wish to sign up for.</p> <p>Adding an extra step to the signup process might seem convoluted. But, the advantages of doing so are well worth the extra effort.</p> <h2 id="taking-back-control-of-your-inbox">Taking back control of your inbox</h2> <p>When you reveal your real email address, there’s little you can do to prevent inbox abuse. Spam, phishing, data breaches, account hacks are all real problems. These problem only gets worse with time.</p> <p>The solution is to create accounts using a unique, anonymous forwarding address. That way, the integrity of your real address always remains intact. By “masking” your private email, your address remains a secret and stays safe from abuse. This is huge for privacy, but also security.</p> <p>Discovered a data breach or sick of spam? Delete the forwarding address for that account, and you’ll never hear from the offender again. Problem solved.</p> <p>Tracing the source of spam is also effortless. A quick look at the “sent to” address and you’ll identify exactly who shared, leaked or sold your address.</p> <p>When every account uses a random email address, your login details no longer follow a recognisable pattern. This makes it much harder to hack your account.</p> <p>When combined with a generated password and two-factor authentication (2FA), your accounts are almost impenetrable.</p> <h2 id="email-masking-services">Email masking services</h2> <p>There are many services can help you with email masking.</p> <p><a href="https://simplelogin.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Simple Login</a> premium allows you to create an unlimited number of email aliases. And use custom domains. The software is open source and very well documented. It’s also possible to add PGP Encryption to your aliases.</p> <p><a href="https://anonaddy.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AnonAddy</a> is another open source option. With unlimited aliases, their free tier is generous. If you’re not bothered about setting up a custom domain, then AnonAddy may be all you need.</p> <p><a href="https://support.apple.com/en-gb/HT210425" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Apple’s Hide my Email</a> is a great choice for Apple users. The service is a feature of Sign In with Apple and iCloud+. And allows you to spin up as many random email addresses as you need.</p> <p><a href="https://1password.com/fastmail/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">1Password + Fastmail</a> looks like a slick option. That is, if you’re lucky enough to use both of these services.</p> <p><a href="https://relay.firefox.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Firefox Relay</a> from the team at Mozilla offers unlimited aliases for $0.99/month.</p> <p><a href="https://burnermail.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">burnermail</a> and <a href="https://forwardemail.net/en" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Forward Email</a> are two more options worth looking into.</p> <p>I&rsquo;ve been using SimpleLogin for the past few months. Here’s how it works.</p> <h2 id="kicking-the-tires-with-simplelogin">Kicking the tires with SimpleLogin</h2> <p>Before generating forwarding addresses for all your accounts. You first need to set up a primary email address that all emails will forward to.</p> <p>You do this by adding a default Mailbox from inside the SimpleLogin app. This should be a private email address that you never reveal. So don’t give to anyone. The sole purpose of this address is for use as a forwarding address. And it should remain a secret, at all times.</p> <p>Now you’re ready to generate a forwarding address.</p> <p>SimpleLogin has a browser extension, available for <a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/simpleloginreceive-send-e/dphilobhebphkdjbpfohgikllaljmgbn" target="_blank" rel="noopener">blink-based browsers</a>, Safari and <a href="https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/simplelogin/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Firefox</a>.</p> <p>Whenever you land on a website and want to create an account, fire up the browser extension and generate a new forwarding address. Now use it to sign up with, instead of your real address. The process works the same as generating a password using a password manager.</p> <p>By default, SimpleLogin will create an email address based on the domain name of the website open in your current browser tab. To give you an example, let’s say you’re on the notion.so website. And you want to create an account. In this case, SimpleLogin might suggest: <a href="mailto:notion.ds5s@aleeas.com">notion.ds5s@aleeas.com</a>.</p> <p>You also have the option to use a random word or a random string of numbers. This is useful if you prefer a random forwarding address, which doesn’t contain the URL of the website you’re on.</p> <p><a href="mailto:biblen_acetylgalactosamine@aleeas.com">biblen_acetylgalactosamine@aleeas.com</a> is one I created to book a table last week. Once I’d received an email confirmation for the booking, and I’d been for dinner. The address had served its purpose, so I deleted it.</p> <p>Using a random forwarding address has its benefits. In particular, surrounding the name of the address. For example, a contact of mine recently asked if the email address I shared with him was correct. The address contained the name of his company, which isn’t typical for an external email address. He found this confusing, which is understandable.</p> <p>In this case, it may have been more sensible to create a random alias. Rather than creating one using the name of his company.</p> <h3 id="dealing-with-spam-phishing-and-data-breaches">Dealing with spam, phishing and data breaches</h3> <p>So how do you know when a forwarding address has been compromised? Well, as mentioned, you can cross-check the sender address with the reciepient address. Is something amiss? If so, delete the address.</p> <p>But SimpleLogin also puts other measures in place.</p> <p>The <a href="https://simplelogin.io/docs/getting-started/anti-phishing/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">anti-phishing feature</a> will do its best to check sender authenticity, before forwarding email to your mailbox. If authentication fails, the email will contain a warning or go into quarantine.</p> <p>SimpleLogin also includes an <a href="https://www.reddit.com/r/Simplelogin/comments/nn476w/haveibeenpwned_is_now_integrated_in_simplelogin/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">intergration with Haveibeenpwned</a>. This feature will notify you if one of your forwarding addresses has been part of a data breach. At which point you can delete the offending address and deal with the problem.</p> <h3 id="reverse-aliases">Reverse aliases</h3> <p>One aspect of email masking which can be confusing is how to send emails <em>from</em> a forwarding address.</p> <p>Most services handle this automatically. Where a reverse alias is set up for any email address that sends an email to one of your forwarding addresses. In my case, when I reply to one of these emails. My email is sent to the SimpleLogin server. Then forwarded to the recipient from my forwarding address.</p> <p>But, what if you’re composing a new email, to a new contact, and want to use a forwarding address as the sender address?</p> <p>In this case, you need to set up a reverse alias yourself. As far as I understand, this is a manual process.</p> <p>In SimpleLogin, you need to add your new contact to the forward address you want to send from. For example, let’s say I want to contact <a href="mailto:elon@tesla.com">elon@tesla.com</a> from a new forwarding address. First, I generate the forwarding address. Then, I add Elon’s email address as a contact of that forwarding address. This generates a reverse alias, which looks like a long string of random letters.</p> <p><a href="mailto:kutcaqldjyywoxyfrlsmneathjpnjjzpwqlgmqb@simplelogin.co">kutcaqldjyywoxyfrlsmneathjpnjjzpwqlgmqb@simplelogin.co</a>, for example.</p> <p>Now if I email the reverse alias, SimpleLogin will catch the email and send it to <a href="mailto:elon@tesla.com">elon@tesla.com</a> for me. It will send my email from the forwarding address I set up and assigned Elon as a contact for.</p> <p>It’s a little confusing at first, but you soon get the hang of it.</p> <p>The key is to generate a reverse alias for each contact you add. That way you can manage each one of your contacts independently.</p> <p>What you don’t want is to have a bunch of independent contacts all using the same forwarding address. Because at some point you might want to cut ties with one, but not the other. Then you’ll have a problem, as you can’t delete the address without loosing both contacts.</p> <p>If the contacts are all within the same company, then the chances are this won’t be such a problem. As you’ll most likely want to cut ties with the company rather than the individual.</p> <h3 id="random-alias-vs-custom-domain">Random alias vs custom domain</h3> <p>For most accounts, a random forwarding address is all you need. For your security and privacy, it’s the best approach. However, there might be occasions where you want to keep your identity visible. But still maintain control over who can email you.</p> <p>To give you an example, a couple of different estate agents recently valued my apartment. I decided to create a random forwarding address for each. But this time I used a custom domain (also set up with SimpleLogin) which contains my full name. That way they could take a look at the address and recognise it’s me.</p> <p>As soon as the valuation process was complete, I turned off the aliases I had set up for each agent. Now, I no longer receive the constant flow of emails about properties for sale in my area.</p> <p>Of course, this wouldn’t be possible if I had given these agents my private email address. If I had, I’d have to unsubscribe from each mailing lists, one by one. Not much fun.</p> <p>But, it’s also possible to do this without a custom domain. You can personalise a forwarding address using SimpleLogin’s default domain names. For example, <a href="mailto:harrycresswell.vv6j9@aleeas.com">harrycresswell.vv6j9@aleeas.com</a> achieves the same results.</p> <p>Notice the random string of letters and numbers before the @ sign. This creates a unique address. Meaning you can create as many personalised addresses as you like.</p> <p>With this approach, I reveal my identity, but maintain control over who has access to my inbox. The best part – I don’t need a custom domain name to do it.</p> <h2 id="its-all-the-same-thing">It’s all the same thing</h2> <p>I mentioned the various terms out there, that all attempt to make this technology approachable and descriptive.</p> <p>From a technical perspective, creating email aliases is what this <em>is</em>. But the term “alias” doesn’t exactly describe what it <em>does</em>. That is unless you’re a tech nerd and you really know your stuff.</p> <p>To appeal to the broadest range of people, this technology needs a better sales pitch. And, there are several attempts to do that.</p> <p>Here are some to look out for:</p> <ul> <li>Disguising email</li> <li>Anonymous emails</li> <li>Anonymous email forwarding</li> <li>Email masking</li> <li>Email forwarding</li> <li>Disposable email addresses</li> <li>Hidden emails</li> <li>Burner emails</li> </ul> <p>If you hear any of these terms, they most likely mean the same thing. No doubt there are more out there, but these are the ones I’m currently aware of.</p> <h2 id="the-hard-part">The hard part</h2> <p>How nice it would be to have zero footprint online. With a brand new email address, that we can mask from the start. In reality, most of us aren’t lucky enough to be in a position where we’re starting out fresh.</p> <p>Like me, you probably have a bunch of existing subscriptions and accounts. Most of which you’ll need to work your way through. Updating every username to a random forwarding address, one by one. It’s a manual process, which will take time.</p> <p>This isn’t about password managers. But using one will make the process of identifying all your accounts less painful. It also means you won’t have to remember all your forwarding addresses. Win win.</p> <p>I currently have 643 accounts stored in my password manager. Most of which I need to update using this email masking method. It’s going to take a while. But, it’s also a great chance to evaluate which services I no longer use and therefore which I can delete.</p> <p>Yes, I’m also looking at that number in disbelief. I’m not quite sure how it got to this, but I’m aiming to slice it in half by the end of the year.</p> <p> <a href="https://bitwarden.com/help/generator/" rel="noopener noreferrer">Bitwarden has a API intergration</a> with SimpleLogin, AnonAddy and Firefox Relay. So you can generate aliases directly from your password manager. </p> <h2 id="final-thoughts">Final thoughts</h2> <p>I’m sure you’ve grasped the basics of email masking by now. At least, you’ll have a good idea about the problem this technology solves and why it’s so exciting.</p> <p>So I’ll leave you with a few rules I’ve laid out for myself. A mindset, if you like.</p> <p>My aim is to adopt this mindset when creating accounts:</p> <ul> <li>Create a unique, anonymous forwarding address for every single account</li> <li>Always use a password manager to save your details</li> <li>Never reveal your real email address unless it’s a trusted contact</li> <li>Use <a href="https://haveibeenpwned.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Haveibeenpwned</a> to identify misuse of any forwarding address</li> <li>Use a tool like SimpleLogin to make the process above easier</li> </ul> <p>My final piece of advice is to be ruthless about which emails you allow into your inbox. Email can be tiring. It’s often the last thing you want to spend your time on. So the less you have of it, the less you have to manage.</p> <p>Personally, I’ve got a way to go before I have full control of my inbox. But, right now, email masking seems like the best way to get there.</p>

item.title: The web is for humans
item.content:encoded: <p>I just added <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/humans.txt" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a humans.txt file</a> to my personal site.</p> <p>It’s just a simple plain text file at the root of my site, which you probably wouldn’t ever find, unless you enjoy poking around in Github repos.</p> <p>Along with my contact info, and the technology used to build this site, this file contains a growing list of people who have influenced how I build websites.</p> <p>In the grand scheme of things, this isn’t all that important. But it’s been on my list of things to add to my site for a while, so I’m pleased to finally get it live.</p> <p>For those that are new to humans.txt files, I’ve written a short post about them – how they differ from robots.txt and how I’m approaching mine.</p> <p>Whilst at it, I jotted down a few thoughts about humans.txt files – how they differ from robots.txt and how I’m approaching mine.</p> <p>I’ve also included a quick 3 step tutorial to show you how to create one for yourself.</p> <h2 id="express-your-gratitude">Express your gratitude</h2> <p>Whereas <a href="https://www.cloudflare.com/en-gb/learning/bots/what-is-robots.txt/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a robots.txt file</a> is for search engines, a humans.txt file is for humans.</p> <p>It’s a small way to acknowledge the people who helped build your website, in one way or another. Even though few people will ever discover it, it’s one of those website easter eggs that makes the web that little bit more fun to be a part of.</p> <p>Typically, a <em>humans.txt</em> file includes a list of team members who have contributed to the project. However, you may prefer to list those who you’ve taking inspiration from, or who you’ve learnt most from over the years.
