The choice is yours, but its purpose remains the same.</p> <p>Personally, I’m using this as a chance to pause for a moment, reflect and express some gratitude towards the people who have helped me get to where I am today.</p> <h2 id="create-your-own-humanstxt-file">Create your own humans.txt file</h2> <p>If you’re interested in making a <em>humans.txt</em> file for your own site, here’s how it works. It’s very simple and you can put one together within a few minutes.</p> <h3 id="1-create-a-text-file-called-humanstxt">1. Create a text file called <code>humans.txt</code></h3> <p>First you need to create a text file called <em>humans.txt</em> and put something in it. Use whichever plain text editor you prefer.</p> <p>Here’s the format I’m using:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>/* TEAM */ Your title: your name. Site: email, link to a contact form, etc. Url: your website address Social: your social media handle. Location: City, Country. [...] /* THANKS */ Name: their name Twitter: their Twitter handle Url: their website address [...] /* SITE */ Last update: YYYY/MM/DD Standards: HTML5, CSS3,.. Components: Modernizr, jQuery, etc. Software: Software used for the development </code></pre><p>I pinched this from <a href="https://humanstxt.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"></a><a href="https://humanstxt.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">https://humanstxt.org/</a>. You’re welcome to do the same.</p> <h3 id="2-put-it-in-the-right-place">2. Put it in the right place</h3> <p>Now you need to make sure your <em>humans.txt</em> file is in the right place.</p> <p>If your site is built with Hugo, like mine, then put your <em>humans.txt</em> file in your <em>./static</em> folder and Hugo will do the rest when you build your site.</p> <p>Otherwise, make sure you add your <em>humans.txt</em> file to the root of your site. For example, <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/humans.txt" target="_blank" rel="noopener">https://harrycresswell.com/humans.txt</a>.</p> <h3 id="3-link-to-your-file">3. Link to your file</h3> <p>Finally, place a reference to the file in the <code>&lt;head&gt;</code>of the site like this:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>&lt;link rel=&#34;author&#34; href=&#34;humans.txt&#34; /&gt; </code></pre><p>You may also like to link to your <em>humans.txt</em> file from somewhere else on your website.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>&lt;a href=&#34;/humans.txt&#34;&gt;My humans.txt file&lt;/a&gt; </code></pre><p>Personally, I’ve decided against linking to my humans.txt file (except from within this short post). I rather like that it’s hidden and takes some digging to discover.</p> <p>Anyway, that’s it. You’re all done.</p> <h2 id="humanstxt-files-in-the-wild">humans.txt files in the wild</h2> <p>Given the nature of <em>humans.txt</em> files, they’re not always easy to discover. But here are some I’ve managed to find, which might help inspire your own.</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.dandevri.es/humans.txt" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Danny de Vries’s humans.txt file</a></li> <li><a href="https://actions.github.io/humans.txt/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GitHub Actions humans.txt file</a></li> <li><a href="https://thelovelygeek.com/humans.txt" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Lovely Geek’s humans.txt file</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.google.com/humans.txt" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Google’s humans.txt file</a></li> <li><a href="https://frontlinedev.com/humans.txt" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Jason Tipton’s humans.txt file</a></li> </ul> <p>If you have a humans.txt file, then please let me know. I’d love to take a look and add it to the list above.</p> <h2 id="final-thoughts">Final thoughts</h2> <p>To the best of my knowledge, a <em>humans.txt</em> file won’t get you more followers, help you grow your email list, improve your search ranking or increase your conversion rate. So what’s the point, I here you say?</p> <p>I like to think of my <em>humans.txt</em> file as a small reminder that <em>the web is for Humans</em>. When you’re caught up with SEO, algorithms and other ways to satify bots, it’s easy to forget that, sometimes.</p> <p>It’s also just a bit of fun, because sometimes that’s important, too.</p> <h2 id="resources">Resources</h2> <p>If you want to learn more about humans.txt files, here are a few places to start.</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://humanstxt.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Humans TXT: We Are People, Not Machines.</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.cloudhadoop.com/humans-txt-file-example/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">humans.txt file basic tutorials with example | Cloudhadoop</a></li> </ul>

item.title: De-Googling
item.content:encoded: <p>I’m doing what I can to minimise my dependence on Google services.</p> <p>This is by no means a new idea. You’ll find more than 75,000 members in the <a href="https://www.reddit.com/r/degoogle/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">r/DeGoogle</a> subreddit, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DeGoogle" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a Wikipedia page</a> all about the movement.</p> <p>My reasons for De-Googling are similar to most. I have growing concerns about privacy and the dominance of big tech. Google also has <a href="https://killedbygoogle.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a history of pulling the plug on well-loved products</a>. So going all-in with Google is probably a bad idea.</p> <p>If investing has taught me anything it’s that diversification is important.</p> <p><em>Don’t put all your eggs in one basket</em>, as the saying goes. It’s better to spread your bets, if you want to limit your risk.</p> <p>Intended as much for my reference, as, I hope, some insight and encouragement for others. Here’s where I’m at with the De-Googling process.</p> <h2 id="google-alternatives">Google alternatives</h2> <p>These days there are plenty of great alternatives to Google services. So it’s never been easier to start making better choices. Most have a much healthier approach to privacy and security.</p> <h3 id="google-workspace-8594-tutanota">Google Workspace → Tutanota</h3> <p>I wrote about <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/privacy-focused-email/">secure, privacy-focused email</a> recently. In the article, I explain why I’ve finally switched my business email over. Give it a read if you want the details about my experience.</p> <p>I’ve been with Tutanota for a few months now and I’m enjoying it.</p> <p>Sure, there are quirks to get used to. Such as images not loading by default (a privacy thing). Then there’s the counterintuitive feel when you delete an email. Tutanota marks the next email read, whether you want to read it or not.</p> <p>But, you get used to these things fast and the pros outweigh the cons.</p> <p>The interface is simple and distraction-free. It’s much cheaper than Google Workspace. And, for whatever reason, I’m finding it easier to stay on top of email.</p> <h3 id="google-calendar-8594-tutanota-calendar">Google Calendar → Tutanota Calendar</h3> <p>Tutanota includes an encrypted calendar. It’s not as feature-rich as Google Calendar, and there’s no seamless way to add a video call to an event, but I can deal with that. It does the basics well.</p> <p>Custom event colours are a subtle feature which I love. With Google Calendar you’re stuck with the Material Design colour palette.</p> <p>As I’ve mentioned, there’s something about how simple and stripped back Tutanota feels that appeals to me. The Calendar is a great example of this.</p> <h3 id="google-analytics-8594-netlify-analytics">Google Analytics → Netlify Analytics</h3> <p>There are a bunch of <a href="https://rigorousthemes.com/blog/open-source-google-analytics-alternatives/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">responsible analytics options</a> out there these days. Most are far easier to work with and much lighter in weight, when compared with Google Analytics.</p> <p>Most of the sites I manage are hosted by Netlify, so I’ve started using <a href="https://www.netlify.com/products/analytics/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Netlify Analytics</a>. It only takes a few clicks to add analytics to a site. Unlike many of the other options out there, Netlify Analytics runs on the server, rather than the client. Meaning there’s no third-party scripts to add to your website. If you’re looking for secure, performant analytics, then Netlify is tough to beat.</p> <p>The downside to this approach is that you need to host your sites with Netlify to use their Analytics.</p> <h3 id="google-authenticator-8594-raivo">Google Authenticator → Raivo</h3> <p>I discovered Raivo OTP (One Time Password) on <a href="https://www.privacytools.io/#2fa" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Privacy Tools</a>. Then I read a review on <a href="https://blog.thenewoil.org/ios-2fa-apps-review-2021-or-ravio-otp-the-only-ios-2fa-app-worth-recommending" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The New Oil</a> which convinced me to make the switch.</p> <p>Why Raivo? First of all, it’s <a href="https://github.com/raivo-otp" target="_blank" rel="noopener">open-source</a> and actively maintained. Second, you can sync the Raivo app across multiple devices and make local backups easily. Meaning that if you lose your phone, you’re far less likely to lose access to all the services you use. Neither of these things you can do with Authenticator.</p> <p>Switching from Google Authenticator involves disabling two-factor authentication (2FA) on all your accounts. You then need to re-enabling it using your new 2FA app, be it Raivo, or another. This is usually a manual process, so if you’re big on 2FA then expect it to take some time.</p> <p>If you’re coming from Authy, then you can follow the <a href="https://github.com/raivo-otp/ios-application#migrating" target="_blank" rel="noopener">migrating from Authy to Raivo OTP</a> guide.</p> <p><strong>27th May 2024</strong>: Since learning about <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z0IkcyGUqKc" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the suspicious circumstances surrounding Raivo’s takeover</a>, I’ve switched to using <a href="https://2fas.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">2FAS</a>, another popular open source one-time/2FA password generator.</p> <h3 id="google-chrome-8594-brave">Google Chrome → Brave</h3> <p>I switched my primary browser to <a href="https://brave.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Brave</a> a year or so ago. I still use Chrome for web development, but for everything else I use Brave.</p> <p>I currently have the <a href="https://www.ecosia.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Ecosia</a> search extension installed, but I’ve also used <a href="https://duckduckgo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DuckDuckGo</a> in the past. Both are great replacements for Google Search.</p> <p>By using Brave you can collect <a href="https://brave.com/brave-rewards/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Brave rewards</a> and the Basic Attention Token (BAT). In other words, you get paid to use the browser.</p> <p><strong>27th May 2024</strong>: Following a conversation with <a href="https://www.lkhrs.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Luke</a>, who pointed me in the direction of <a href="https://chromeisbad.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Chrome is bad</a>, I’ve since dropped Chrome entirely. I’m yet to settle on a replacement, so currently find myself using a combination of Brave, Librewolf and Safari. I use <a href="https://www.mozilla.org/en-GB/firefox/browsers/mobile/focus/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Firefox Focus</a> for iOS.</p> <h3 id="google-drive-8594-sync">Google Drive → Sync</h3> <p>These days I only use Google Drive when someone shares a Google Doc, or Sheet with me. For years my preference was Dropbox until I realised encryption isn’t <a href="https://www.cloudwards.net/what-exactly-is-zero-knowledge-in-the-cloud-and-how-does-it-work/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">zero-knowledge</a>. In other words, Dropbox retains the right to access your data.</p> <p>For the past two years, I’ve been using <a href="https://www.sync.com/secure-cloud-storage/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sync</a> and it ticks most of the boxes. But it’s not open source.</p> <p>Lately, I’ve been looking into <a href="https://mega.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Mega</a> and <a href="https://filen.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Filen</a> as possible alternatives to Sync. Saying that I’m pretty happy with Sync for the most part, so not in any mad rush to switch.</p> <p>Before moving to Sync, I looked into <a href="https://nextcloud.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Nextcloud</a>, a self-hosted solution. But, it seemed like a fair bit of work to set up and perhaps overkill for my needs. So I decided against it in the end.</p> <h3 id="google-docs-8594-notion--obsidian">Google Docs → Notion + Obsidian</h3> <p>I’ve never been a fan of Google Docs. I can’t handle the way you have to switch to Google Drive to organise your documents. Like Drive, I only use it when someone shares a Doc with me.</p> <p>I’ve tried various writing tools over the years, <a href="https://ia.net/writer" target="_blank" rel="noopener">iAWriter</a>, <a href="https://ulysses.app/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Ullyses</a> and <a href="https://www.dropbox.com/paper" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Dropox Paper</a>, to name a few. But, I find myself using Notion most of all, nowadays.</p> <p>I’ve been a paying Notion customer since 2019. I use it for most things. Journaling, long-form writing, project and task management, client CRM, bookmarking, and a whole lot more. It’s a brilliant all-in-one tool, but it’s not ideal for security or offline use.</p> <p>For that reason, I’ve started using <a href="https://obsidian.md/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Obsidian</a> for taking notes. Although its primary focus is on knowledge management, I’ve been using it to draft articles, too. There’s a certain resilience in creating a system based on a set of markdown files stored in a local folder. Store that folder in a secure cloud and you’ll have access via mobile. Even when offline.</p> <p>I’ve been toying with the idea of <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/simple-project-management/">using Obsidian for project management</a> and moving away from Notion. But, I fear that might be pushing Obsidian beyond its limits.</p> <p><a href="https://anytype.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Anytype</a> could well be the ultimate like-for-like Notion replacement. Currently, in beta, I’m keeping an eye out for the launch. The advantage of Anytype is that it works locally, encrypts all your data and is open source. It seems Anytype might take on Obsidian with their connected thought features. But, I haven’t used it, so I can’t say too much about that, yet.</p> <p><strong>27th May 2024</strong>: I briefly looked at Anytype when it launched, but couldn’t get on with it as the data you create is encrypted and files aren’t easy to access. I envisage issues with vendor lock-in sometime down the line. For this reason I’ve fully committed to Obsidian. Their <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/links/file-over-app/">file over app</a> philosophy makes a lot of sense. You store data as plain-text markdown files locally, which makes your content portable and easy to access. Furthermore, Obsidian’s community plugins make it extremely flexible. I’m currently using it for writing, project management, bookmarking, creating flashcards, <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/simple-project-management/">goal setting with OKR</a>, clipping quotes from the web and a bunch of other things.</p> <h3 id="google-sheets-8594-airtable">Google Sheets → Airtable</h3> <p>I&rsquo;m sure you can do most of what Google Sheets does with Notion. But I’ve been using Airtable as a like-for-like replacement for a while.</p> <p>I have a couple of big tables that I actively manage. One for dev resources and the other for <a href="https://locallondon.life/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Local London</a> content. I can’t see much point in moving these over to Notion, so I continue to use Airtable.</p> <p>I’d say Airtable feels more Notion-like than Sheets-like. But if you want a similar experience to Sheets, then <a href="https://cryptpad.fr/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cryptpad</a> has a suite of Google replacements. The software is open-source, with the addition of end-to-end encryption. Cryptpad also has a strong focus on collaboration.</p> <p><strong>27th May 2024</strong>: I’ve been testing out the <a href="https://rafaelgb.github.io/obsidian-db-folder/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Obsidian Database Folder</a> plugin for bookmarking content from the web. I can see this approach working well for my personal databases, like the one I use for dev resources which is currently in Airtable. Where Obsidian DB Folder won’t be such a good fit is for databases which are populated by others via form submissions, such as those on <a href="https://locallondon.life/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Local London</a>. For these sorts of needs I will continue to use Airtable.</p> <h3 id="google-maps-8594-apple-maps--citymapper">Google Maps → Apple Maps + Citymapper</h3> <p>Apple has a much healthier approach to privacy than Google, in general. It makes sense given that they don’t give their products away for free, or rely on Ad revenue.</p> <p><a href="https://www.apple.com/uk/legal/privacy/data/en/apple-maps/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Apple Maps</a> keeps your data in sync across all your devices using end-to-end encryption. This includes your favourites, history and guides. It will also hide your exact location after 24 hours.</p> <p>Living in London, I find myself using <a href="https://citymapper.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Citymapper</a> quite a bit for travel advice. It’s excellent for navigating public transport. The downside is that it only works in certain cities.</p> <p>I recently discovered <a href="https://maps.me/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Maps.me</a> and <a href="https://organicmaps.app/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Organic Maps</a>, both of which use open-source data from <a href="https://www.openstreetmap.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">OpenStreetMap</a>. It’s early days, but the ability to use these maps offline makes them very appealing.</p> <h2 id="google-dependencies">Google dependencies</h2> <p>Some Google services I’ve found more difficult to replace than others.</p> <h3 id="google-chrome">Google Chrome</h3> <p>Google Chrome is a tricky one. It’s no longer my primary browser since I replaced it with Brave. But, I still use it for web development and testing.</p> <p>In theory, I could do this testing with Brave. Like Chrome, Brave runs on top of Chromium, so it has the same UI and most of the same features, minus the spyware.</p> <p>I guess old habits die hard. I like to test sites on as many different browsers as I can, so I still use Chrome, from time to time.</p> <h3 id="google-search-console">Google Search Console</h3> <p>It seems unwise to neglect Search Console given the popularity of Google Search. And as far as I’m aware there’s no obvious replacement.</p> <p>Before closing my G-Suite/Workspace account, I decided to move the sites I manage over to my personal Gmail account. I guess this is the best solution for now.</p> <h3 id="youtube">YouTube</h3> <p>I’m a big fan of YouTube, and can’t see myself quitting anytime soon. Some of the best content creators post videos on YouTube, so it’s a difficult one to give up.</p> <p>For now, I’ve resubscribed to the subscriptions I still follow from my personal Gmail account. Same as I did for my Search Console accounts.</p> <p>I did a similar thing for playlists. It took a while, as I’ve created loads over the years. Most of which are music. YouTube is the best places to find all the old music I listened to as a kid. The stuff you can’t find anywhere else.</p> <h2 id="final-thoughts">Final thoughts</h2> <p>These days there are a bunch of privacy-focused alternatives to Google. So it’s never been easier to move away from Google and find a better experience.</p> <p>Saying that it doesn’t look like I’ll be going 100% Google free, any time soon.</p> <p>I still use Search Console and YouTube most days. I also use Chrome for web development and testing. For that reason, I’ve decided to keep my personal Gmail address for now. I can’t see much point in deleting my account, to sign up for these services again with a non-Google address. Whilst I understand it’s possible, it may be more effort than it’s worth.</p> <h2 id="inspiration">Inspiration</h2> <p>The piece was inspired by two fantastic articles:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://dev.to/kiraemclean/what-i-use-now-instead-of-google-56lf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">What I Use Now Instead Of Google</a> by Kira McLean</li> <li><a href="https://davesmyth.com/de-googling" target="_blank" rel="noopener">De-Googling</a> by Dave Smyth</li> </ul> <p>Before reading Kira’s article, I hadn’t given much thought to my dependency on Google services. So thanks to Kira for introducing me to all this stuff.</p> <p>H/t to Dave for all your good work on privacy and the title for this article.</p> <h2 id="resources">Resources</h2> <p>Here are the resources I used whilst researching alternatives to Google. Use them to inspire your move away from Google.</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://switching.software/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Switching.software</a>: Ethical, easy-to-use and privacy-conscious alternatives to well-known software</li> <li><a href="https://goodreports.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Good Reports</a>: Get off Big Tech tools. Use these instead</li> <li><a href="https://www.privacytools.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Privacy tools</a>. A brilliant resource</li> <li><a href="https://ethical.net/resources/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Ethical.net</a>. A collaborative, online directory of ethical companies of all kinds</li> <li><a href="https://privacysavvy.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Privacy Savy</a>. Learn to stay secure on the internet</li> </ul> <p>Still not sure how to get going with all this? <a href="https://www.reddit.com/r/degoogle/comments/huk4rp/why_you_should_degoogle_intro_degoogling/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Why You Should DeGoogle &amp; Intro DeGoogling Techniques</a> is a great place to start.</p> <p>Happy De-Googling.</p>

item.title: Menus in Hugo
item.content:encoded: <p>There are many ways to build a menu with Hugo. As is often the case, it’s this flexibility which makes Hugo one of the more powerful static site generators. But, it’s not always obvious which approach is best suited to your project. And, you’re often left scratching your head, wondering which approach to choose.</p> <p>This article will guide you through the different approaches. From a simple list of hard-coded links, right through to an advanced config menu. We’ll also cover some of the more challenging aspects of building menus. Including highlighting current items, working with sub-menus, and adding external links.</p> <p>I’ve done my best to highlight the nuances of each approach, where appropriate. And, provide some insight into how I prefer to do things.</p> <h2 id="creating-a-navhtml-partial">Creating a <code>nav.html</code> partial</h2> <p>Site navigation tends to look the same on most pages, so the obvious place to start is by creating a component for it. That way we can manage our menu code in one place, then add it to any template, wherever we like.</p> <p>In Hugo, components are known as <em>partials</em>, and they live in a dedicated folder at <em>layouts/partials</em>.</p> <p>I like to create a partial called <code>nav.html</code>, but you might prefer to call your partial <code>menu.html</code>, or something similar.</p> <p>Inside this new partial, one approach would be to hard code a list of links to our pages. Just like you would when creating a website with regular HTML.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;/&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Home<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;/about&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>About<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;/contact&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Contact<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This works well for a small site, or one you plan on managing yourself. But with non-technical stakeholders involved, managing a hard-coded menu isn’t usually the best solution.</p> <p>In this situation, using Hugo’s <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/menus/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Menus</a> feature would be a better approach.</p> <h2 id="working-with-sitemenus">Working with <code>.Site.Menus</code></h2> <p>The <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/menus/#what-is-a-menu-in-hugo" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo docs define a menu</a> as “a named array of menu entries accessible by name via the <code>.Site.Menus</code> <a href="https://gohugo.io/variables/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">site variable</a>. We’ll look at this in depth shortly, but for now, let’s focus on the <code>.Site</code> bit.</p> <p>If you’re familar with Hugo, you’ll know that the <code>.Site</code> object gives you access to global settings stored in the <em>config.toml</em> file. This tells us that we can manage menus from our site configuration.</p> <p>The easiest way to get started with “config menus” is by creating a Section Menu with a single line of code.</p> <h3 id="section-menus">Section menus</h3> <p><a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/menu-templates/#section-menu-for-lazy-bloggers" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Section Menus</a>, a.k.a “menu for Lazy bloggers”, allow you to create a simple menu, based on the section structure of your <em>/content</em> folder.</p> <p>The first thing to do is add the following line of code to the top of the <code>config.toml</code> file, found at the root of your Hugo project.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>sectionPagesMenu = &#34;main&#34; </code></pre><p>Here we’ve decided to call our menu “main”, but you could call your menu anything you wish.</p> <p>The next step is to open up your <code>nav.html</code> partial (or wherever you decide to keep the code for your menu), and replace those hard-coded links from earlier with the following.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range .Site.Menus.main }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .URL }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .Name }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>We’ll get to exactly what’s going on in this code a little later. But, that’s pretty much all we need.</p> <p>If we include this code somewhere in our templates, our Section Menu will <em>just</em> work. No need to add our menu items anywhere, or configure anything else in the config file. That’s because Section Menus are based on content structure.</p> <p>So. The benefit of Section Menus is that they’re quick and easy to build. But, they depend on our content structure, meaning we have to structure our content in a particular way. This creates certain limitations, which we’ll look at next.</p> <p>The first limitation is that we can’t structure pages as top level markdown files.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>├── content/ │ ├── about.md │ ├── contact.md </code></pre><p>I often do this, but, it won’t work with Section Menus.</p> <p>Instead, we need to make sure our pages are structured as content Sections.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>├── content/ │ ├── about/ │ │ ├── index.md │ ├── contact/ │ │ ├── index.md │ ├── posts/ │ │ ├── _index.md │ │ ├── first-post.md │ │ ├── second-post.md </code></pre><p>Sections require their own named folder, which contains either an <em>index.md</em> file, or a collection of pages, with or without an <em>index.md</em> file. As illustrated above.</p> <p>What’s the difference between <code>index.md</code> and <code>_index.md</code>? The former creates a <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/page-bundles/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Leaf Bundle</a> (used for single pages) and the latter a <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/page-bundles/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Branch Bundle</a> (used for section pages). But, I digress.</p> <p>More to the point, without Section folders, your Section Menu will not work.</p> <p>For a small site, we might decided to reorganise the content folder to get a Section Menu working. But, for a larger site, perhaps with a mature content structure, this process could take some time, and might not be worthwhile.</p> <p>The second limitation of Section Menus is that they only work for top level pages. To illustrate this, imagine we have a <em>projects</em> section with two projects inside.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>├── content/ │ ├── projects/ │ │ ├── _index.md │ │ ├── first-project.md │ │ ├── second-project/ │ │ ├── ├── index.md </code></pre><p><em>Projects</em> will display in our Section Menu, as it’s a top level page. But, notice <code>first project.md</code> and <code>second-project/</code> are pages within the section. These are known as a <em>shadow members</em> and they won’t display in our Section menu, as neither are top-level pages.</p> <p>For reasons outlined, it’s my view that Section Menus are best suited to small sites with a modest menu structure. Perhaps where you don’t need much control over how your menu is represented, or simply need a quick way to navigate between a handful of top-level pages.</p> <p>When you need granular control over each menu item. Or, you want to make changes to menu items without digging through your templates. That’s a good sign it’s time to build a custom menu.</p> <h3 id="managing-menus-from-the-configtoml-file">Managing menus from the <code>config.toml</code> file</h3> <p>Custom menus, or “Config Menus” are managed via the site configuration.</p> <p>Managing a menu from the <code>config.toml</code> file makes it easier to customise menu items and give editable access to non-developers. Perhaps via a content management system (CMS), should we decide to set one up, for those aforementioned stakeholders.</p> <p>Here’s what that might look like.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Home&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;About&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/about&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Contact&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/contact&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">30</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Before we continue, let’s take a moment to dissect the code above, to get a better understanding of what’s going on.</p> <p>Inside our <code>config.toml</code> file we’ve added some TOML data to create a menu with three menu items.</p> <p>At the top we initiate a menu using the <code>[menu]</code> key. For each item in our menu we add <code>[[menu.main]]</code>, where “main” is the name we choose for the menu. If, for example, we had a different menu in the footer, then we might decide to use <code>[[menu.footer]]</code>, instead.</p> <p>For each menu item we’re adding 3 key-value pairs:</p> <ul> <li><strong>name</strong> is use for the link text. That’s the bit that will display in our menu.</li> <li><strong>url</strong> should contain the relative path to the page you wish to link to.</li> <li><strong>weight</strong> specifies the order of the menu items, as they appear in the menu. Items with a lower weight value will appear earlier in the sequence of items.</li> </ul> <p>There’s no hard and fast rule about how you format the weight of each menu item, they just need to increase as you progress through the menu order. For example, the following weights would be just as valid, as above.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Home&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;About&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/about&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">2</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Contact&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/contact&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">3</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Increasing weight values by increments of 1 works. But, I tend to avoid doing this. That’s because anytime you want to add a new item somewhere in the middle of your menu, you usually end up having to update the weight of every menu item to accomodate the change.</p> <p>For this reason, my prefered method is using increments of 10. Doing so makes it much easier to add menu items later, anywhere in your menu.</p> <p>Consider the menu item with the name <em>Posts</em> in the example below.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Home&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;About&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/about&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Posts&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/posts&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">25</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Contact&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/contact&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">30</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>We can add the menu item in sequence by giving it a weight of 25. No need to update the weight of any other item in the menu.</p> <p>OK. Enough about weight. Let’s do something with this menu data.</p> <h3 id="rendering-our-config-menu">Rendering our config menu</h3> <p>With menu data now set in the site config, our ”main” menu is accessible using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/variables/site/#get-the-site-object-from-a-partial" target="_blank" rel="noopener">.Site.Menus</a> method.</p> <p>The next step is to open up <code>/layouts/partials/nav.html</code> and replace the code we added earlier with the following.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">nav</span> <span class="na">aria-label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Main Navigation&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range .Site.Menus.main }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .URL }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .Name }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Let’s run through this code to get a better idea of what’s going on.</p> <p>As mentioned earlier, <code>.Site</code> gives us access to data in the config file. <code>.Site</code> includes a bunch of different methods we can use, one of which is <em>Menus</em>.</p> <p>So. To access our menu data, we use <code>.Site.Menus</code> followed by the name of the menu. In our config, we called our menu <em>main</em>, so, in this case, we use <code>.Site.Menus.main</code>.</p> <p>By passing these variables into the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/range/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">range function</a>, we can iterate (or loop) through the array of menu items and return the data. The same sort of thing as using <em>forEach</em> statement in other programming languages.</p> <p>Range loops through our menu items, changing the context (the data available to us) to the data associated with each menu item. Now we have access to both the <em>url</em> and the <em>name</em>, found within the data of each menu item.</p> <p>We use the <code>.URL</code> variable to pass the <em>url</em> from each menu item to the <code>href</code> in the anchor tag. Then <code>.Name</code> to pass <em>name</em> as the link text.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .URL }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .Name }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p><em><strong>Note:</strong> <code>.Name</code> and <code>.URL</code> are predefined variables built into Hugo, so you’ll need capitalise the first letter of the variable for them to work as expected. As URL is an acronym (Uniform Resource Locator), in this case the whole variable is capitalised–as you’d expect from an acronym.</em></p> <p>It’s important to remember, when using the range function, we open logic. Whenever we open logic, we will need to end this logic to return to the default page context. We can do that with <code>{{ end }}</code>. If we fail to end the logic, Hugo will throw an error and our template will break.</p> <p>Here’s that code once again, so you can see it in full.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">nav</span> <span class="na">aria-label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Main Navigation&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range .Site.Menus.main }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .URL }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .Name }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice we’ve also added an <code>aria-label</code> to our opening <code>&lt;nav&gt;</code> tag. This tells screen readers and other assistive technologies to announce the navigation as “Main Navigation”. But, now we’re going down another road entirely, so I’ll leave it at that for now.</p> <p>Instead, let’s get our menu displaying on our website somewhere.</p> <h2 id="add-your-navhtml-partial-to-your-templates">Add your <code>nav.html</code> partial to your templates</h2> <p>With a menu set up in the <code>config.toml</code> file, and the code used to render the menu in a partial. The final thing left to do is to include the partial somewhere in your templates.</p> <p>The <code>_default/baseof.html</code> template might be the obvious place, as we want it to appear on all pages. But, if you have a <code>header.html</code> partial already included in your base template, then it might make more sense to add it here, instead.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">partial</span> <span class="s">&#34;nav.html&#34;</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Remember to pass the dot (<code>.</code>) into the partial, just before the closing curly brackets. The dot passes context to the partial. Without it, the partial won’t have access to the menu data.</p> <p>At this point we have a working menu. So let’s look at some other ways to add content to it.</p> <h2 id="front-matter-menus">Front matter menus</h2> <p>Managing menus from the <code>config.toml</code> file is typically the way I like to do things. But, we can also add content to a menu directly from the front matter of any content file.</p> <p>Assuming we have something similar to below in one of our templates.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">nav</span> <span class="na">aria-label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Main Navigation&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range .Site.Menus.main }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .URL }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .Name }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>We could add the following to the front matter of any content file, to add the page to our main menu.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">menu</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;main&#39;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>One advantage of front matter menus is that we can quickly add content to any number of menus.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">menu</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;main&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;footer&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The code above will add our content to both the <em>main</em> and <em>footer</em> menu. That is, assuming we also have a footer menu rendered somewhere in our templates.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">nav</span> <span class="na">aria-label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Footer Navigation&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range .Site.Menus.footer }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .URL }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .Name }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>But this doesn’t give us much control over how our content appears in the menu. For advanced control we can use the same approach as in the <code>config.toml</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">parent</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;About&#34;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Front matter menus won’t give quite the same level of control as you get from the <em>config.toml</em> file. But, you can order your content in a menu by adding a <em>weight</em>. Or, nest your content as sub menu, by adding a value for <em>parent</em>.</p> <p>Another advantage of controling menu items from the content is that when you delete a page, you delete the menu item along with it. There’s no chance of broken links in your menu.</p> <p>You may find reason to add content to a menu via front matter. However, I tend to avoid them, as I prefer to manage menu items all in one place–from the <code>config.toml</code> file.</p> <p>Now we’ve looked at rending menus, and the various ways to add content them, let’s look at some of the challenges we might face.</p> <h2 id="highlighting-the-current-menu-item">Highlighting the current menu item</h2> <p>Adding a visual indicator to the menu item of the current page is common practice. It’s a helpful way to show site visitors which page they are on.</p> <p>A typical way to do this is to add a class to the menu item which corresponds to the current page. That way, we can target the class with CSS, and style our active menu item to indicate the page is the current one.</p> <p>In HTML that might look like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;/&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Home<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;/about&#34;</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;is-active&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>About<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Contact<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>But, getting this working in Hugo hasn’t always been easy. The real challenge was finding a way to highlight sub menu items, whilst maintaining the highlight of the parent item. We’ll get to that shortly.</p> <p>Thanks to the Hugo team, <a href="https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/releases/tag/v0.86.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener">v0.86.0</a> makes highlighting current menu items a whole lot easier.</p> <p>In this section we‘ll run through the steps to get menu highlighting working for both top-level navigation and nested children, a.k.a sub menus.</p> <p>Let’s start by adding <code>class=&quot;is-active&quot;</code> to the anchor tag in our list item.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">nav</span> <span class="na">aria-label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Main Navigation&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range .Site.Menus.main }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;is-active&#34;</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .URL }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .Name }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The problem now is that <code>is-active</code> is being applied to every one of our menu items. That’s because range is looping through our menu items and adding the class to each one. We’ll need to use some logic to tell Hugo to only add the class if the menu item matches the current page.</p> <p>Hugo provides a method on the <code>Page</code> object called <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/ismenucurrent/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">.IsMenuCurrent</a> which can help us achieve this functionality.</p> <p><code>.IsMenuCurrent</code> will return <em>true</em> if the current page matches an item in our menu.</p> <p>Update your menu with the following code:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">nav</span> <span class="na">aria-label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Main Navigation&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range .Site.Menus.main }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ if .IsMenuCurrent &#34;</span><span class="na">main</span><span class="err">&#34;</span> <span class="err">.</span> <span class="err">}}</span><span class="na">is-active</span><span class="err">{{</span> <span class="na">end</span> <span class="err">}}&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>So. What’s going on in that class above?</p> <p>Using an if statement, we create a condition to check if the current page matches the menu item in our <em>main</em> menu. But, our code won’t work just yet, because now we have another problem.</p> <p>If you remember, <code>.IsMenuCurrent</code> is a method on the <code>Page</code> object. So, in order to use it, the context (the data available to us) needs to be Page.</p> <p>However, when we used the range function, we changed the context from Page to our menu data. We did this by passing <code>.Site.Menus.main</code> into the function. Subsequently, we no longer have access to <code>.IsMenuCurrent</code>.</p> <p>So, how do we access the <code>Page</code> context, so we can use <code>.IsMenuCurrent</code> from inside our range logic?</p> <p>The easiest way to do this is by creating a custom variable outside of our range logic, where the context is still <code>Page</code>. Then, we can assign the current context to this variable and access it from inside our range logic.</p> <p>In Hugo, current context is stored in the dot, and the default context of templates is set to <code>Page</code>. So, all we need to do is assign our variable with the dot (<code>.</code>).</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ $currentPage := . }} </code></pre><p>We can name this custom variable anything we like, we just need to remember to prefix the name with <code>$</code> and assign a value to the variable by using <code>:=</code>, rather than simply <code>=</code>.</p> <p>Let’s add our new variable just above the range function in our <code>nav.html</code> partial. We can add this anywhere, as long as it’s outside the range function where the context is still <code>Page</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">nav</span> <span class="na">aria-label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Main Navigation&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ $currentPage := . }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range .Site.Menus.main }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ if .IsMenuCurrent &#34;</span><span class="na">main</span><span class="err">&#34;</span> <span class="err">.</span> <span class="err">}}</span><span class="na">is-active</span><span class="err">{{</span> <span class="na">end</span> <span class="err">}}&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .URL }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ .Name }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now we can prefix <code>.IsMenuCurrent</code> with our new <code>$currentPage</code> variable and we will have access to the Page context from inside our range logic.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">nav</span> <span class="na">aria-label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Main </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ $currentPage := . }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range .Site.Menus.main }} </span></span><span class="line"><span <span class="err">}}&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .URL }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ .Name }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Head back to the browser and you’ll notice that Hugo still isn’t applying the <code>is-active</code> class to our menu items, yet. That’s because we need to make a slight change to each menu item in the config.</p> <p>In <a href="https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/releases/tag/v0.86.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener">v0.86.0</a> Hugo introduced the <a href="https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/releases/tag/v0.86.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener">pageRef</a> variable to make menu highlight much easier to work with. All we need to do is assign the value of <em>pageRef</em> for each item to the path of our page.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pageRef</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s2">&#34;/&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Home&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;/&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pageRef</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pageRef</span><span </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">30</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now Hugo adds our <code>is-active</code> to whichever page we navigate to.</p> <p>At this point, everything is working as intended. All that’s left to do is add some styling to our <code>is-active</code> class, to indicate that the current page is active.</p> <p>I’ve leave that part up to you. But a nice, simple place to begin, might be to style the active link with <code>text-decoration: underline</code>.</p> <p>Ok. Our current menu highlighting is working as expected. So, now let’s turn our attention to sub menus.</p> <h2 id="working-with-nested-children">Working with nested children</h2> <p>Not all menus will require nested children, a.k.a sub menus. But content heavy projects, such as documentation sites, often will.</p> <p>Let’s take a moment to clarify exactly what we mean when we talk about sub menus. So we’re all on the same page.</p> <p>What do sub menus look like?</p> <p>Here’s two examples of websites I’ve built with Hugo, both of which include menus with sub menus:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://nobainternational.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Noba International</a> displays a sub menu when you hover over an item in the header navigation.</li> <li>The <a href="https://design.angelinvestmentnetwork.co.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AIN Brand Guidelines</a> reveal sub menus when a parent item in the sidebar is clicked.</li> </ul> <p>Allthough the design in these examples varies, both the code, and the UX is very much the same–you hover or click on the top level menu item and a nested menu is revealed.</p> <p>Ok, now we’re on the same page, how do we build this functionality in Hugo?</p> <h3 id="addding-parent-keyword-to-sub-menu-items">Addding <code>parent</code> keyword to sub menu items</h3> <p>We can create child menu items (or nested items) by heading to <code>config.toml</code>, and assigning a menu item with the <em>parent</em> keyword.</p> <p>The value of <code>parent</code> must match the name of another item in our menu.
