Can we be more concise in the way we write our code?</p> <h3 id="refactoring-our-code">Refactoring our code</h3> <p>Turns out we can ditch that else statement altogether.</p> <p>All we need to do is move the <code>{{ if .HasChildren }}</code> logic to wrap the nested child <code>&lt;ul&gt;</code>, rather than the parent <code>&lt;li&gt;</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">nav</span> <span class="na">aria-label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Main Navigation&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ $currentPage := . }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range .Site.Menus.main }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ if or ($currentPage.IsMenuCurrent &#34;</span><span class="na">main</span><span class="err">&#34;</span> <span class="err">.)</span> <span class="err">($</span><span class="na">currentPage</span><span class="err">.</span><span class="na">HasMenuCurrent</span> <span class="err">&#34;</span><span class="na">main</span><span class="err">&#34;</span> <span class="err">.)</span> <span class="err">}}</span><span class="na">is-active</span><span class="err">{{</span> <span class="na">end</span> <span class="err">}}&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .URL }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ .Name }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ if .HasChildren }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range .Children }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ if $currentPage.IsMenuCurrent &#34;</span><span class="na">main</span><span class="err">&#34;</span> <span class="err">.</span> <span class="err">}}</span><span class="na">is-active</span><span class="err">{{</span> <span class="na">end</span> <span class="err">}}&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .URL }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ .Name }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now, we’re producing the exact same results in fewer lines of code.</p> <h2 id="using-params-for-external-links">Using <code>.Params</code> for external links</h2> <p>There are times when you’ll need to add external links to your menu. These could be any links to external websites, or your social media accounts.</p> <p>The easiest way to achieve this is to head to the <code>config.toml</code> file. Then use <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/menus/#params" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Params</a> to add custom data to our menu configuration.</p> <p>Params should be nested within the menu item you wish to turn into an external link. In TOML this is done by chaining menu with your menu name, followed by the params keyword: <code>[menu.main.params]</code>.</p> <p>Consider the following:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-toml" data-lang="toml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">]]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Hugo&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;&lt;https://gohugo.io/&gt;&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">weight</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">menu</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">params</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">external</span> <span class="p">=</span> <span class="kc">true</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>To specify that our link is to an external source we add a param key called <code>external</code> , with the value of <code>true</code>. We’ll also need to add the external link itself, as the the value of the <code>url</code> key in the menu item.</p> <p>Now we head back to our template, to update the code that renders our menu.</p> <p>When creating external links, it’s common practice to add the <code>target</code> attribute to a link with the value <code>_blank</code>. It’s also recommended to include <code>rel=&quot;noopener noreferrer</code> in the link, to provide better security for the page that links to an external source.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">nav</span> <span class="na">aria-label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Main Navigation&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ $currentPage := . }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range .Site.Menus.main }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ if $currentPage.IsMenuCurrent &#34;</span><span class="na">main</span><span class="err">&#34;</span> <span class="err">.</span> <span class="err">}}</span><span class="na">is-active</span><span class="err">{{</span> <span class="na">end</span> <span class="err">}}&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .URL }}&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">target</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;_blank&#34;</span> <span class="na">rel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;noopener noreferrer&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ .Name }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>If we add the code to our link as above, all our menu items will be treated as external links. But, this isn’t what we want. We only want to add this code to menu items where the param key called “external”, is set to <code>true</code> in our config.</p> <p>We’ll need to write some logic that checks if the Param <em>external</em> is set to <code>true</code> for any of our menu items. We can use the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/eq/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">eq function</a> to check the condition is met.</p> <p>We already changed context to our menu when we entered the range function, (<code>.Site.Menus.main</code>). So, all we need to do is pass <code>.Params.external</code> as the first argument and <code>true</code> as the second. If the the condition return <em>true</em>, then the code will be added to that particular menu item.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nx">eq</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Params</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">external</span> <span class="kc">true</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">target</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;_blank&#34;</span> <span class="nx">rel</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;noopener noreferrer&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In english you might read this as:</p> <blockquote> <p>“if <code>.Params.exteral</code> equals <code>true</code>”</p> </blockquote> <p>Now together with the rest of our menu code:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">nav</span> <span class="nx">aria</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="nx">label</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Main Navigation&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">currentPage</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Menus</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">main</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">a</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">class</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ if $currentPage.IsMenuCurrent &#34;</span><span class="nx">main</span><span class="s">&#34; . }}is-active{{ end }}&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .URL }}&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nx">eq</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Params</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">external</span> <span class="kc">true</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">target</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;_blank&#34;</span> <span class="nx">rel</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;noopener noreferrer&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Name</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">nav</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Run <code>hugo server</code> and you will find that the link of any menu item–which includes a Param called <code>external</code> that’s set to <code>true</code>–will open in a new browser tab, whilst all others links remain internal.</p> <h2 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping up</h2> <p>Setting up a menu in Hugo isn’t too difficult, but there are various approaches to consider. Which one you choose will depend on the size of your website, and the complexity of its content structure.</p> <p>The most challenging aspect is highlighting current menu items. But, since Hugo v0.86.0, the <a href="https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/releases/tag/v0.86.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener">pageRef</a> variable makes the process much easier. For that reason, I highly recommend keeping your Hugo version up-to-date.</p> <p>With the ability to assign Params, we can do all sorts of things to customise our menu items. From creating external links to adding custom icons which help illustrate your menu items. You might even decide to add custom classes, so you can change the style of a menu item based on a certain condition. I’ll leave that for you to explore.</p> <p>There’s lots more to cover on the topic of menus. Managing menus from a <code>config/menus.toml</code> file and dealing with multi-lingual site navigation both come to mind. But these topics could easily be articles in themselves, so I’ll leave it there for today.</p> <h2 id="resources">Resources</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/menus/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">https://gohugo.io/content-management/menus/</a></li> <li><a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/menu-templates/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">https://gohugo.io/templates/menu-templates/</a></li> </ul> <hr> <p><strong>08-07-25 update</strong>: This post was originally written in 2022, long before the Hugo starter theme (generated using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/commands/hugo_new_theme/#hugo-new-theme" target="_blank" rel="noopener">hugo new theme</a> command) was introduced and the <a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/menu/#example" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Menu Templates</a> docs were updated to include a different example, from those outlined in this post, of how to rendering a menu in Hugo.</p> <p>In my view, the latest example is quite a bit more complicated to wrap your head around, especially for Hugo beginners. I suspect it exists in its current form to show what <em>can</em> be done with menus, rather than to offer the simplest implementation. With this in mind, and given that the techniques outlined in this post are still perfectly valid, I have refrained from making any changes to this post.</p> <p>If you are interesting in learning more about the approach used in the starter theme and the Hugo docs, then I have explained all the code, in detail, in another post: <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/exploring-hugos-new-theme/#menus">Exploring Hugo’s new starter theme and updates to the <code>new site</code> command</a>.</p>

item.title: Slowing down
item.content:encoded: <p>It’s been a while since I wrote one of these updates. I’ve been busy with client work, so I haven’t found the time.</p> <p>I’ve also been travelling. We’re back in Hamburg for the week, visiting family and catching up with old friends. It’s hard to do it all.</p> <p>In these situations I try to remind myself to lower my expectations. Productivity ebbs and flows, and that’s ok. These <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/things/">projects</a> are long term games and there’s no rush to complete them.</p> <p>Just as important is slowing down and taking time off. Appreciating where you’re at and creating space makes work more sustainable.</p>

item.title: Secure, privacy focused email
item.content:encoded: <p>Escaping the clutches of Google in search of a secure, privacy focused email experience is something I’ve wanted to do for a while, but, I’ve lacked the motivation to do it. The thought of untangling the mess of accounts I’ve created as a free G-Suite user is overwhelming, so I’ve kept putting it off.</p> <p>Hearing Google’s plans to suspend all legacy accounts in July of this year was the push I needed. There’s nothing like a hard deadline to get you in gear.</p> <p>The past few weeks I’ve spent time researching my options–seeking out a suitable alternative to Google–and getting to grips with a new email provider.</p> <p>In the process I’ve managaged to consolidate my inboxes into one, regain control of my privacy (to an extent) and turn the lights out on my G-Suite account, once and for all. It’s a project that feels long overdue.</p> <h2 id="alternative-email-to-google">Alternative email to Google</h2> <p>There are a bunch of better email providers than Google these days. I spent a good while looking into each one and a handful stood out.</p> <p><a href="https://protonmail.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ProtonMail</a> is one of the most popular and reputable choices among the privacy community. Based in Switzerland, ProtonMail offers an encrypted email service that’s hard to beat. But, at €6.25/month for a pro account, it’s not the cheapest.</p> <p><a href="https://posteo.de/en" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Posteo</a> is listed on all the reviews you’ll read as another great option. Posteo is ad-free, can be used anonymously, and the company has a strong focus on sustainability. Following Pretty Good Privacy (PGP) encryption standards, it’s ticks a lot of the boxes and only costs €1/month. But, with no current support for custom domains, Posteo is perhaps better suited to use for personal email.</p> <p><a href="https://soverin.net/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Soverin</a> is an independent company based in Amsterdam offering a privacy focused mailbox for €3.25/month. For that you get unlimited domains and aliases using plus-notation. If you&rsquo;re likely to need lots of email addresses, then it’s one of the best options out there. I’ll add that Soverin’s servers also run on sustainable energy sources.</p> <p><a href="https://tutanota.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Tutanota</a> is a small company based in Hannover, Germany, who offer end-to-end encrypted email, calendar, and contacts. If you’re not already aware, Germany’s data privacy policy–the Federal Data Protection Act (Bundesdatenschutzgesetz)–is one of the strictest privacy laws in the world, making it a solid choice for privacy enthusiasts.</p> <p>Tutanota software is <a href="https://github.com/tutao/tutanota" target="_blank" rel="noopener">open source</a>, so you can hack around with code and spin up your own Tutanota web client, as you like. This says a lot about how the company approach software development and transparency. Tutanota <a href="https://tutanota.com/blog/posts/green-email" target="_blank" rel="noopener">servers run on 100% renewable energy</a>, making it another sustainable choice.</p> <p>Judging by <a href="https://tutanota.com/about/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Tutanota’s about page</a>, the team are clearly dedicated to protecting the privacy of their customers. It’s reassuring to know that there are no dependencies on external investors or owners, making it unlikely that the company will pivot from its values or sell out to the highest bidder.</p> <p>Private email, using a Tutanota address, is free, and premium email starts at €1/month per user, for which you get 1 custom domain and 5 aliases. To put this in perspective, with Google Workspace you’ll pay £4.14/month, per user.</p> <h2 id="switching-to-tutanota">Switching to Tutanota</h2> <p>I took the plunge a few weeks back, setting up a free <a href="https://tutanota.com/pricing/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">private account</a> with Tutanota to see if I could get along with it. My intention was always to upgrade to a paid business account if things went well.</p> <p>First I moved my calendar over from Google and sent the odd email to myself to test features. I sat with Tutanota all week, before giving away my new email address. I wanted to get a feel for the software before committing.</p> <p>The first thing that struck me about Tutanota is how different it feels to email with Google. The UI isn’t particularly fancy, but it’s clean and simple, which I like. One primary colour accents a modest palette of gray, it feels calm and focused.</p> <p>Looking back, Google feels bright and busy, packed full of labels and unused extras, all competing for your attention.</p> <p>I expect Tutanota’s three column desktop layout won’t be for everyone. Coming from Google products, it may feel dated, to some. Personally, I’m into it. The email list view in Tutanota is much less imposing, taking a fraction of the screen than that of Google. For heavy email users this may be a concern. But, if like me, you only receive a handful of emails a day, then it’s more than sufficient.</p> <p>The responsive layouts are also worth a mention. The app looks great in a browser at any size. At it’s slimmest in the browser, the layout mirrors the iOS app.</p> <p>Tutanota doesn’t load pictures automatically, which can feel weird at first. You can choose to show images when you open an email, but once you learn about the <a href="https://tutanota.com/faq/#load-images" target="_blank" rel="noopener">privacy concerns of images in email</a>, you will think twice about which images you decide to load.</p> <p><strong>Updated 2nd June, 2022</strong>: <a href="https://tutanota.com/blog/posts/most-secure-email-service/#no-tracking-allowed" target="_blank" rel="noopener">No tracking allowed</a> explains the problem with images further. I also recommend taking a look at Dave Smyth’s <a href="https://notospypixels.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">No to Spy Pixels</a>.</p> <h2 id="end-to-end-encryption">End-to-end encryption</h2> <p>Tutanota encrypts emails sent to other users by default, but it’s worth noting that <a href="https://tutanota.com/faq#encrypted-emails-external" target="_blank" rel="noopener">sending encrypted emails to an external recipient</a> will require a password. You will then need to share this password with the recipient via an encrypted messaging app, such as <a href="https://signal.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Signal</a> or <a href="https://telegram.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Telegram</a>. Using this password, the recipient will be able to access the email you’ve sent them on Tutanota’s encrypted servers.</p> <p>I’m pointing this out because it’s easy to think the “end-to-end encrypted email” thing happens automatically, as soon as you hit send. In reality, this is only the case when both the sender and recipient are using Tutanota. If full encryption is something that’s important to you, then you’ll have to get used to sharing passwords, as the large majority aren’t using Tutanota.</p> <p>The good news is that Tutanota still provides a high level of encryption in transit, and all the emails you receive remain encrypted on Tutanota’s servers. But, if the recipient uses Gmail, Outlook or another unencrypted email service, then any email they receive will be unencrypted at rest. That is, unless you use a password.</p> <h2 id="upgrading-to-tutanota-business">Upgrading to Tutanota business</h2> <p>Last week, I upgraded to Tutanota’s Business Premium subscription (€2/month). I might have gone for Private Premium, but I needed to set up a few different custom domains. One for <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">my personal site</a> and another for <a href="https://www.practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">practicalhugo.com</a>.</p> <p>Business Premium gives you unlimited custom domains and 5 aliases, which is more than enough for my needs. If in the future I require more aliases, then I can pick up a 20 pack for another €1/month.</p> <p>I read some concerns on Reddit about delays with account approval, but I didn’t experience any of this myself. Setting up custom domains was easy enough. I had visions of DNS settings taking forever to propagate, but all went smoothly and everything was working within a few minutes.</p> <p>This week I set up a separate user (a dedicated inbox) for <a href="https://locallondon.life/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Local London</a>, as there are a few of us sending emails. For €1/month, the three of us can share an inbox and send emails from our own alias. To put this in perspective, with G-Suite I’d set everyone up as a separate user, so email would have cost a minimum of £12.42/month, for this project alone. Plus, we’d be handing over all our data, in return.</p> <h2 id="final-thoughts">Final thoughts</h2> <p>Ditching my convoluted G-suite/Workspace set up is something I should have done years ago. Managing multiple inboxes ultimately came at a cost to my time and attention. Now, with one inbox, staying on top of emails is trivial.</p> <p>But, this project wasn’t just about simplifying my email setup. It was also about moving away from big tech and making more responsible software choices. I’m not 100% there yet, but switching email from Google to Tutanota feels like a huge step towards achieving this goal.</p> <p>It’s satisfying to know that I’m now backing an independent company, who puts the privacy and security of their customers first. This is the future I want to see, so there’s not much I’d rather invest in.</p> <p>With a cheaper price tag than Google, it turns out that switching to a secure, private focused email provider can also save you a good bit of money. So, although it took work, it’s was a bit of a no-brainer.</p> <h2 id="resources">Resources</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://restoreprivacy.com/email/secure/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">12 Best Private and Secure Email Services for 2022</a> from Sven Taylor</li> <li><a href="https://www.reddit.com/user/Tutanota/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">u/Tutanota</a> on Reddit</li> </ul>

item.title: Moodboards
item.content:encoded: <p>I’ve always been a huge fan of moodboards. <a href="http://www.haw-lin.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Haw-lin</a>–a collaboration between Hawaii native Nathan Cowen and Berlin based Jacob Klein–has been one of my favourites for years.</p> <p>For a long time it seemed like having a personal moodboard was all the rage–usually made with Tumblr or something similiar, but often self-hosted, if you had the skills to spin up your own. Then Instagram came along and all that changed.</p> <p>I’ve got nothing against Instagram per se, but it troubles me knowing Meta can pull the plug at any moment and all your content and is gone, along with the following you’ve worked so hard to build.</p> <p>I experienced this first hand back in 2012 when <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/ericsavitz/2012/09/06/ebay-buys-svpply/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Svpply was aquired by eBay</a> and that was that. We were given the chance to export data, but the network of 50k+ followers that I spent time building disapeared overnight.</p> <p>Since then I’ve always been cautious about becoming dependent on siloed networks, prefering instead to lean on open-source tools where possible.</p> <p>One example of this is choosing to build <a href="https://mood.harrycresswell.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">my personal moodboard</a> with the static site generator Hugo. Obviously when you roll it yourself it’s not as easy to build the social aspect which Instagram excels at. But at least you can sleep well at night knowing you’re in full control.</p> <p>Recently I’ve made some improvements to the theme and now I’m putting it out there, <a href="https://github.com/harrycresswell/mood" target="_blank" rel="noopener">free to download from Github</a>.</p> <p>I’m in the process of putting together more info on the features and how to use it. So for now, I hope this will encourage you to consider your own dependencies on tools that take control of your data. Perhaps I can even convince you to take some of the necessary steps back towards an open and independent web.</p>

item.title: Growing up
item.content:encoded: <p>I haven’t written in a while. Last week I got Covid (again), so I’ve been taking it pretty easy.</p> <p>I can never find the energy to write when I’m sick, let along think of anything good to say–I guess that’s normal. Before now I’d be stressing, but I’m trying to be less hard on myself. Where does stressing even get you, anyway?</p> <p>A few weeks back I mentioned I was thinking about <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/updates/building-themes/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">putting a few Hugo themes</a> out there. Then, whilst sick-scrolling I stumbled upon Max’s brilliant <a href="https://mxb.dev/blog/make-free-stuff/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Make Free Stuff</a>. Everything he writes is so damn good&hellip; Anyway, it’s inspired me to actually get on and do it. Just for fun.</p> <p>So I’ve been working on <a href="https://www.figma.com/file/BXnM3rhSC210Sxq4RDgdRa/themes.harrycresswell.com?node-id=0%3A1" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a super light micro site</a> to host these things on. I designed it the way I designed sites growing up, before I got caught up in the whole web business thing. One font, one font size. Simple, functional and probably all it needs.</p> <p>Maybe this is the start of something, but maybe not. Either way, you’ll be able to download these themes for free - no strings attached.</p>

item.title: Less CSS
item.content:encoded: <p>How little CSS is too little CSS? How few lines can get away with before a site starts to feel, well, unstyled? To what extent can we rely on default user-agent styles? Do you need anything more than a tiny CSS reset, these days?</p> <p>These are the questions I’ve been kicking around in my head lately, so I devised a little exercise to explore these ideas further.</p> <p>It’s nothing fancy, or new, for that matter. Rather rudimentary, in fact. It may even feel like we‘re going backwards, to some. What am I talking about? Inlining CSS directly in your HTML, of course. Here’s how it works&hellip;</p> <p>Start writing your styles inline, inside <code>&lt;style&gt;</code> tags in the <code>&lt;head&gt;</code>. How much CSS can you inline before things become unwieldy? At what point do you move your styles to an external stylesheet because you impact performance (TTFB)? Can you style an entire website without even getting to that point?</p> <p>When inlining CSS you have to keep styles to an absolute minimum. You’re forced you to rely on the cascade, prioritise what’s important and write lean code that does away with the superfluous. There’s no doubt in my mind that creative limitations like this can help us create more sustainable websites.</p> <p>I starting thinking about this stuff more actively when looking into <a href="https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2015/08/understanding-critical-css/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Critical CSS</a> as a way of improving site performance. But, why use a tool to extract your critical (above the fold) styles and inject them in the head, if you can make <em>all</em> your styles critical by writing less of them?</p> <p>Of course, this is easier said than done on anything larger than a simple personal site. But, it’s a fun little exercise that can encourage you to think more mindfully about how much code you write.</p>

item.title: Building themes
item.content:encoded: <p>This week I’ve been writing about building themes for a new module in <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical Hugo</a>. It’s made me think about my own. As a result I’ve spent time tidying up my personal site, pulling out unused styles, making small adjustments to the design and reducing complexity where I can.</p> <p>I’ve built a bunch of Hugo themes over the years, usually for clients or personal projects. But, I’ve never actually open-sourced one for others to use. I’m not sure why that is. It seems bizarre that I haven’t, now I come to think of it. This year I want to change that by sharing a couple of free themes with the community.</p> <p>The obvious place to start is with <a href="https://github.com/harrycresswell/harry" target="_blank" rel="noopener">my personal site</a>. I’ve given the theme away a few times in the past, when folk have emailed asking if they can use it. So perhaps it’s time to put it out there, for others to use.</p> <p>I’ve also been working on my old <a href="https://mood.harrycresswell.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">moodboard</a> theme. It’s not your typical Hugo theme given the content is mainly visual–single pages feel more like an old lightbox gallery, except there’s no JavaScript involved.</p> <p>I removed <a href="https://afarkas.github.io/lazysizes/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">lazysizes.js</a> to continue in this vain, opting for native lazy loading with <a href="https://cloudinary.com/blog/low_quality_image_placeholders_lqip_explained" target="_blank" rel="noopener">low quality image placeholders</a> instead. Now we’re 100% JavaScript free and there’s an air of <a href="https://www.bbc.com/travel/article/20181021-japans-unusual-way-to-view-the-world" target="_blank" rel="noopener">wabi-sabi</a> about it. No animation or any other non-essentials. It light and a little rough around the edges, which I’ve come to like.</p>

item.title: Creative constraints
item.content:encoded: <p>I’m writing on my phone more and more these days. I seem to find it much easier to keep my writing concise and to the point when working on a tiny screen.</p> <p>Perhaps it’s because there’s not so much empty page staring back at you. It’s less overwhelming when you can fill the page with a few short paragraphs.</p> <p>Typing with two thumbs is also a real effort, so there’s an incentive to pick your words wisely and say what you have to say in as few words as possible.</p> <p>I love these kind of constraints. They somehow make you more creative. They force you to slow down and think, before you take action.</p>

item.title: Working with data
item.content:encoded: <p>Last week I finally managed to get an early draft of the curriculum live on <a href="http://practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">practicalhugo.com</a>. It’s by no means a complete curriculum, just a rough outline of what I’ve figured out so far, including some of the lessons I’ve already written. As I mentioned before, the order is no way set in stone at this point. I’m still a long way off figuring out the final content structure, but it should give you a rough idea of where it’s heading.</p> <p>In the meantime, I thought it might be helpful to explain how I implemented this data on the site, so I will do my best to do that in the rest of this update.</p> <p>When thinking about how to deal with structured data like you see in the curriculum section of the <a href="http://practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">practicalhugo.com</a> homepage, it makes sense to first think about what you’re trying to achieve. Forgive me if that sounds obvious.</p> <p>For example, all I want to do is spit this data out on the homepage, I don’t need pages for the content. Remember, by default, Hugo will generate an HTML page for any content it finds in the content folder. Therefore, in this case it’s best to avoid the content folder altogether, and reach fo the data folder instead.</p> <p>I decided to store all this data in a single file in the data folder called <em>curriculum.yaml.</em> This should make it nice and easy to work with the data.</p> <p>At the time of writing this, here’s what that file looks like.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0"
