class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range .lessons }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="nt">strong</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .title }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">strong</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">article</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The first thing to do when working with slightly more complex data structures than usual, is to get hold of the data and store it in a variable. Notice I’ve done this for all the data in the curriculum file by assigning <code>.Site.Data.curriculum</code> to <code>$curriculum</code>.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ $curriculum := .Site.Data.curriculum }} </code></pre><p>To render the title in the <code>h2</code> tag, all I need to do now is append the key–in this case <em>title</em>–to the variable <code>$curriculum</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h2</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ $curriculum.title | urlize }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ $curriculum.title }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Without the variable, you would be forced to write <code>.Site.Data.curriculum.title</code> , which is the exact same thing, just a different way about it. Using the variable is quicker and the code less verbose.</p> <p>Notice the second variable below targets the module array from the data set. As we’ve already expressed the <code>$curriculum</code> variable, to get hold of the module array we can simply append the module key to the curriculum variable; <code>$curriculum.module</code>.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ $module := $curriculum.module }} </code></pre><p>Now we can loop through the array and return each module object by passing the module variable to the range function; <code>{{ range $module }}</code> . Note that any time we enter a statement of logic we need to close the statement using <code>{{ end }}</code>, otherwise Hugo will throw an error.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ range $module }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c">&lt;!-- loop through data in module array --&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Within our range function, context changes to the data found within the module array, so any data we want to return is accessible by prefixing the key with the dot; <code>.number</code>, <code>lesson_total</code> and so on.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ range $module }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">article</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;mt110 pb80&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">div</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;flex justify-between items-center&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">span</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Module {{ .number }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">span</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">span</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Badge&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .lesson_total }} Lessons<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">span</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h3</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;pt60 pb60&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .title }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h3</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .description }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">article</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This is because Hugo stores current context in the dot, and context changes as soon as you step into some logic. This explains why <code>.title</code> within our <code>$module</code> logic returns the module title, rather than the curriculum section title.</p> <p>This happens again when we use another range to access the nested array of <em>lessons</em>; <code>{{ range .lessons}}</code>. Notice we now have a range nested within a range.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ range $module }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range .lessons }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="nt">strong</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ .title }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">strong</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ end }} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>At this point Hugo will loop through the lessons array within each module. Now when we add <code>.title</code> within our lessons range, Hugo will return the lesson title rather than any other title in the data set, as context has now changed to the lessons array.</p> <p>We step out of our range logic using <code>{{ end }}</code>, just like did in the module range.</p>

item.title: Building interest
item.content:encoded: <p>I‘ve been thinking about new ways to build interest in <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical Hugo</a> and generally provide some value whilst I’m working on lesson material.</p> <p>My first idea was to release a couple of lesson previews, which I still plan on doing. This should give you an idea of my teaching style and the way lessons are structured. But lesson previews are only helpful if you already know about the course, or miraculously manage to land on the website, somehow. I really need content I can drip out regularly via Twitter, and so on. To raise awareness and drive traffic back to the site.</p> <p>I thought about creating short articles, once a week, something concise enough to build Twitter threads with. Quick tips to show you some of the lesser known features of Hugo. Perhaps I’ll also publish these tips on the site. Good for SEO, also good for subscribing via RSS. I’m a big fan of the latter, as you may well know.</p> <p>I’m also trying to be more active in the <a href="https://discourse.gohugo.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo discourse</a>, answering questions I can, whenever I have a spare moment.</p> <p>It’d be clever to add a callout to <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/topics/hugo/">Hugo articles</a> here on my personal site, which directs folk to the course site. My personal site gets a fair bit of traffic, and it wouldn’t be much effort, so that’s an easy win. One for tomorrow, perhaps.</p>

item.title: 0.029g per visit
item.content:encoded: <p>Yesterday I made a bunch of <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/changelog/2022/02/01/layout-type-improvements/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">improvements to practicalhugo.com</a>.</p> <p>For some reason I was using a super tight site wrapper, so the layout felt kinda puny, especially on on larger screens. So I switched to a wider wrapper and added a grid utility. Now the site feels more imposing; it fills the browser and I can create two-column layouts.</p> <p>I also improved the footer and added the carbon footprint score, using data from <a href="https://digitalbeacon.co/report/practicalhugo-com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Beacon</a>. It’s currently rated <em>amazing</em>, producing around 0.029g per page visit. Not too bad.</p> <p>I’ve been working on these design in Figma, which would usually come as no surprise. But, for personal projects I often jump straight into the browser and figure out the design on the go. I guess I have a pretty good idea already formed in my head of what I want to create, and there’s no client involvement other than myself, so it speeds up the process somewhat.</p> <p>So what’s changed? Well it‘s much quicker to play around with ideas in Figma and get them out of my head before I forget. I also like the idea of keeping track of the design progression, visually, rather than relying entirely on a bunch of Git commits. Now the live site will coexist with the Figma designs. I’ll keep <a href="https://www.figma.com/file/8uAfTwwIDuwepGbUXIGKHb/Practical-Hugo?node-id=0%3A1" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the Figma link</a> public, so you can jump in and see what’s coming up any time you like.</p> <p>Today <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/changelog/2022/02/02/links-text-size-adjust/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">I cleaned up a few things</a> I forgot yesterday. I added a <a href="https://css-tricks.com/how-to-create-a-skip-to-content-link/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">skip-link</a> and improved the link hover effect. Maybe I’m going overboard with the whole background colour change on :hover. I use it for most my projects. I just love how basic it feels, so I keep coming back to it.</p>

item.title: Fresh perspective
item.content:encoded: <p>Lately I’ve been spending my early mornings in Notion, writing this Hugo course. But I’ve also been in spending a good bit of time in Figma, working on <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the course website</a>.</p> <p>I was really struggling to nail down the lesson order whilst looking at it in Notion, perhaps it’s somewhat counterintuitive to constantly shift pages around.</p> <p>The funny thing is, as soon as I moved the curriculum into Figma to work on the design, it was much easier to make sense of. It sort of just fell into place.</p> <p>I guess a change of context gives you a fresh perspective on things.</p>

item.title: Facades
item.content:encoded: <p>Found some time to improve performance on <a href="https://roofsimple.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">roofsimple.com</a>. Now rather than rending video content directly in iFrames on page load, it’s now now lazy-loaded using <a href="https://github.com/paulirish/lite-youtube-embed" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a nice little facade technique from Paul Irish</a>.</p> <p>If all this is new to you, using a facade is just a fancy way of saying you’re replacing the actual embedded video with a static image that looks similar.</p> <p>Video is expensive in terms of performance, so it makes far more sense to render a static image on page load, then swap out the image for the iFrame, when a visitor clicks the play button. A simple but effective way to improve speed and user experience.</p> <p>The performance gains from such a quick enhancement make it well worth looking into, especially if your websites contain lots of video.</p> <p>For more on the various techniques I recommend checking out <a href="https://web.dev/third-party-facades/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Lazy load third-party resources with facades</a> from web.dev. And, of course, Paul’s <a href="https://github.com/paulirish/lite-youtube-embed" target="_blank" rel="noopener">lite-youtube-embed</a> repo.</p>

item.title: Interplanetary
item.content:encoded: <p>Woke up this morning to a power cut on our street and no running water. What else am I’m currently taking for granted, that I would miss if it were gone?</p> <p>No water meant no coffee, so booked at table through <a href="https://www.andco.life/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AndCo</a> and spent the morning working from the Dixon hotel. A change of scene is always good, but this time it threw <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/time-blocking/">my time blocks</a> out of sync – not exactly the best start.</p> <p>Started looking into hosting sites via <a href="https://ipfs.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">InterPlanetary File System</a> (IPFS). The whole open-source, decentralised peer-to-peer thing is a great fit for <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">building resilient websites</a>. Continuous deployment is made very easy with <a href="https://fleek.co/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Fleek</a>, the open-web’s answer to Netlify. Think I’ll have to add a new lesson to the <em>deploying your site to the web</em> module.</p> <p>This afternoon I found a spare few minutes, so bought back my <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/things">/things</a> page. It’s not much, but it will do for now. Somewhere to keep track of personal projects, tools I’ve built, things like that.</p> <p>Work related projects are now <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/topics/case-study/">case studies</a>. Still lots to add.</p>

item.title: Time blocking
item.content:encoded: <p>Felt like I needed more structure to my days, and <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/balance-everything/">balance between things</a> I’m working on, so I’m giving time blocking another go.</p> <p>I set them up in Google Calendar, as I did before. I’ll keep a browser tab open on MacBook, whilst I work on my monitor. That way they’re nice and visible and I’ll have more chance of staying on track. I like the way the red line reminds you where you are in the day, and what you should be focusing on.</p> <figure class="Image" data-layout="pull-right"> <div class="aspect-ratio-landscape"> <img sizes="(min-width: 37.5em) 55vw, 100vw" srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_70,w_256/v1642588888/hc/harry-cresswell-time-blocking.png 256w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_70,w_512/v1642588888/hc/harry-cresswell-time-blocking.png 512w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_70,w_768/v1642588888/hc/harry-cresswell-time-blocking.png 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_70,w_1024/v1642588888/hc/harry-cresswell-time-blocking.png 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_70,w_1280/v1642588888/hc/harry-cresswell-time-blocking.png 1280w" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_70,w_512/v1642588888/hc/harry-cresswell-time-blocking.png" alt="Latest attempt at time blocking" class="lazyload" /> </div> <figcaption>Latest attempt at time blocking</figcaption> </figure> <p>I know many people like to schedule their time blocks on a daily basis. Making each block specific to certain tasks for that day – what I like to call “active” time blocking. My approach is slightly different – what I’m calling “passive” time blocking.</p> <p>The passive approach is the <em>set up your time blocks once in a calendar and stick with them</em> approach. It’s low maintenance. They focus on general activities, rather than specific tasks. Good if you’re days or weeks follow a similar schedule, as mine do. I’m sure there’ll be things I’m forgetting, but I’ll give it a go this week and see how I get on. If all goes well then I might write an article about it. I started one a while back, but never finish it.</p> <p>In other news, I added a 404 page to <a href="http://practicalhugo.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">practicalhugo.com</a> because Google search console sent me one of those nice usability issue warnings. I actually did that yesterday but I didn’t get round to writing an update.</p> <p>Almost done with a first draft for a <em>Markdown basics</em> lesson. I think this will go in module 1 – <em>Up and running</em>.</p> <p>This afternoon I fixed the CMS for <a href="https://nobainternational.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Noba International</a>. We added multilingual support just before Christmas, which changed the content structure and messed up Forestry. Totally forgot to check it at the time, but all sorted now.</p> <p>Nearly done with some new UI mockups for AIN. We’re improving the affiliate marketing flow. Fairly happy with where it’s at. Maybe I’ll share some screenshots tomorrow.</p>

item.title: Balance everything
item.content:encoded: <p>Tried to rewrite the Practical Hugo course intro this morning, but failed to come up with anything notable.</p> <p>So I jumped ahead to module 2 and smashed out an ugly first draft of lesson one - <em>creating pages</em> (with the <code>hugo new</code> command). Way easier to write technical stuff – paste in the code, then pad it out with words. I can handle that.</p> <p><a href="https://practicalhugo.com/changelog/2022/02/09/curriculum-sticky-form/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Squashed a few bugs</a> on <a href="http://practicalhugo.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">practicalhugo.com</a>, but didn’t have much time after that. Client work was calling, so I switched modes. Worked on a design for this fun little award certificate and a few other bits.</p> <p>Last night I read <em>Balance Everything</em>, the final chapter in <a href="https://sive.rs/h" target="_blank" rel="noopener">How to Live by Derek Sivers</a>. Great book, recommended to me by <a href="https://www.robertjelenic.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Robert</a>.</p> <p>Now I’m thinking about balance in my life, and how I’m not always good at it. I’ve got a bad habit of going all in on one thing, and letting other stuff slip. Something else I need to work on.</p> <p>Derek has a helpful analogy:</p> <blockquote> <p>“Imagine the different aspects of your life as the spokes in a wheel: health, wealth, intellectual, emotional, spiritual, or however you divide it.<br> If any of these are lacking, it makes a lopsided, wobbly wheel, causing you to crash. But if you keep the parts of your life balanced, your wheel is round, and you roll easily.“</p> </blockquote> <p>Derek goes on to talk about how important it is to “schedule everything to ensure balance of your your time and effort.“</p> <p>It got me thinking about time blocking, again and how helpful it is to have a clear roadmap of how you spend your time. A reminder of whats important, an intentional plan for each day. No chance of getting the balance wrong if you’ve planned it all out up front.</p> <p>I’ve neglected my time blocks. Maybe I should try again.</p>

item.title: Another thing
item.content:encoded: <p>Feel like I should have got way more done with today, but my heads thumping, so it’s been hard to focus.</p> <p>I did managed to get a rough outline together for the second module of <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical Hugo</a>. Not sure it’s quite right yet, I’ll take another look tomorrow.</p> <p>Also started working on a little social strategy. If I have any chance of getting people signed up for this course, then I’m gonna need one. I’m useless at Twitter, but do love a good system.</p> <p>Had another idea. For each project in the course, I thought I might design the site in Figma first, then publish the design as a community template. A lot more work, but could be a nice way to loop back to the course. Perhaps via a simple plug; <em>learn how to build this template in code @practicalhugo</em>&hellip; or something along those lines.</p> <p>Another thing to think about.</p>

item.title: One task
item.content:encoded: <p>Gave myself one ”side project” task today – finished writing <em>building static output with the</em> <code>hugo</code> <em>command</em> lesson.</p> <p>Been struggling to find any kind of flow lately, but this morning I found some and got the task done. Maybe there’s something in this one task a day thing.</p> <p>Anyway, I now have a complete rough draft of every lesson in module 1. Pretty cool.</p> <p>Slow progress, but good progress. I’m starting to see it now.</p> <p>Also managed to make a couple of quick design improvements to <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/tiny-ideas">that changelog page I mentioned yesterday</a>. Added badges, used some <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Grid_Layout" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Grid</a>. Little bits, probably not that important, but it all adds up.</p> <p>Things are picking up after the holidays, so spent the rest of the day on “work projects”.</p> <p>All in all, not a bad day. Now I need one more task for tomorrow.</p> <p>I still need to get a curriculum together for the site. Maybe that’s it.</p>

item.title: Tiny ideas
item.content:encoded: <p>I added <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/changelog/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a Changelog</a> to practicalhugo.com, because I’ve been writing the past few days and, quite honestly, I needed a change of scene.</p> <p>I thought it might be helpful to treat this project like a SaaS product. Launch and keep iterating, or something like that. Anyway, the Changelog exists. Let’s see what happens.</p> <p>I’ve been keeping a list of all sorts of these tiny ideas, to implement in these exact moments.</p> <p>Easy wins to help you register something tangible, when your effort isn’t necessarily visible. A quick tweet, a short update like this or a simple feature, that you can add to your website with very little effort.</p> <p>Make it clear and obvious, so you end the day knowing you‘ve made progress.</p>

item.title: One of those weeks
item.content:encoded: <p>It’s been one of those weeks where I sat at my desk for far too long. Even in all that time it still felt like I’ve got nowhere. I’m sure it’s not true, but it’s hard to believe it.</p> <p>Whatever, I’m done with. Time for a pint. It’s the weekend.</p>

item.title: Minor freak out
item.content:encoded: <p>I had a minor freak out this morning. I think it was a combination of things that set me off.</p> <p>It’s been a quiet start to the year (work-wise), so I’ve had more than enough time to digest exactly how much work it’s going to take to create a course I’m actually happy with.</p> <p>Rebekka reminded not to panic – it’s only the 5th of January.</p> <p>At least I’ve got something to focus on. It’s feels good to have direction.</p> <p>I took a break from writing this afternoon and tried to replicate Regis’s good work in <a href="https://www.thenewdynamic.com/article/toward-using-a-headless-cms-with-hugo-part-2-building-from-remote-api/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Toward using a Headless CMS with Hugo: Building Pages from an API</a>. It went without a hitch.</p> <p>We can now build pages with data! This is an exciting evolution for Hugo.</p> <p>I’ll have to think up my own interpretation of this, it would be a mistake to leave it out. Full credit to Regis, of course.</p>

item.title: Early access
item.content:encoded: <p>I decided to try a thing.</p> <p>From now until launch, anyone who signs up for <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical Hugo</a> will get free access to course material in return for completing <a href="https://harrycresswell.typeform.com/to/drSopGck" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a short survey about their experience with Hugo</a>. I’m hoping this might help me gather some insight into why folks are signing up, and what they’re interested in learning most.</p> <p>From a technical perspective this was all very easy to implement.</p> <p>When new subscribers click the confirmation link in the double opt-in email, they’re redirected to <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/thanks/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a thankyou page</a>, where I explain the deal and provide a link to the survey.</p> <p>Using Buttondown, you can set up this redirect by heading to <strong>Settings &gt; Subscribing</strong>, then adding a link to a custom URL, underneath the <em>Customize my confirmation email</em> section.</p> <p>I put the survey together using Typeform. Nothing out of the ordinary there. It gets the job done and it makes it nice and easy to forward survey submissions to my email.</p>

item.title: Bank holiday
item.content:encoded: <p>It’s a bank holiday here today in the UK, so it was nice and quiet – a good chance to focus on developing this course outline. If all goes well I’ll get an early version up on <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">practicalhugo.com</a> by the end of the week, then look to get some feedback.</p> <p>I was thinking about whether I should include Git in the course. I don’t want to overcomplicate things, so I might leave it until I cover deploying a site to the web in a later module.</p> <p>Either way, I think it’s unavoidable. Continuous deployment is kinda fundamental to the Jamstack web development workflow, so I think I’ve answered my own question there – it would be a mistake to leave it out.</p> <p>Something else I just realised is I’m burying all <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/topics/hugo/">my Hugo articles</a> under all these updates, so I’ll try and figure out a better way to organise these soon.</p>

item.title: 2021 in Review
item.content:encoded: <p class="intro"> In what’s now become somewhat of a tradition, I spent the final few days of 2021 reflecting on what I’ve been up to over the past 12 months – what went well, what didn’t go well and what I learnt by living through it. </p> <p>If you’d like to know more about the way I approach writing this thing, a few years back I wrote <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/year-in-review/">A Year in Review</a>. Not a great deal has changed since then, so make sure you check it out. Ok, let’s get right to it.</p> <h2 id="what-went-well-this-year">What went well this year?</h2> <p>I’ll start with the good stuff. This has been a helpful exercise in the past – a great way to practice gratitude, get some perspective on things, appreciate where you’re at and end the year on a positive note. Hopefully the same is true this year.</p> <h3 id="writing">Writing</h3> <p>I published <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/">12 articles in total this year</a>. Certainly not my best year, but overall I’m pleased with most of what I put out there.</p> <p>I also published <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/heffernan-utilities/">my first project case study</a> in a while. I’d like to do more of these in 2022. It’s a great way to reflect on your process, figure out what worked, what didn’t and how you might do things differently in the future. I suppose it also gives folks a good idea of what you do.</p> <p><a href="https://harrycresswell.com/updates/">Updates</a> became a thing towards the end of the year. My aim with these is to share short daily insights into my process and what I’m working on. I’ve published 12 so far. It’s been tricky over the holidays, but I hope to pick things back up as we enter the new year.</p> <h3 id="work">Work</h3> <p>This year I worked on my first project with the team at <a href="https://www.kittoffices.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Kitt Offices</a> – a London based office space management company – to help build out their UI design system and client facing apps. It’s been fun working with the team to help push the business forward.</p> <p>2021 also saw lots of different projects with existing clients:</p> <ul> <li>A new website for <a href="https://buxtonthreetwo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">BuxtonThreeTwo</a></li> <li>Multilingual support for <a href="https://nobainternational.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Noba International</a></li> <li>A new identity and website for my good friend <a href="https://lauralucas.london/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Laura Lucas</a></li> <li>Various UI projects with Angel Investment Network and a new microsite for the <a href="https://design.angelinvestmentnetwork.co.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AIN brand guidelines</a></li> <li>An identity and website for McShurley Bros (yet to launch)</li> <li>A website and design system for Tuggs (yet to launch)</li> </ul> <p>I’m sure there’s probably more I’m forgetting.</p> <p>Lots of UI design work this year. I can’t complain as it pays the bills, but I’d like to pick up a few more web development projects in 2022. I’m excited by web performance and sustainability, so I’m going to try and tailor my offer around this focus, if I can.</p> <p>Anyway, I’m very grateful I get to work with so many different people on such a variety of different projects.</p> <h3 id="travel">Travel</h3> <p>In July we travelled to Greece for 10 full days – and what great days they were. Three nights in Athens, followed by a week or so on two different islands – Aegina, then Poros – both a short ferry ride from Athens. I can’t remember ever appreciating a holiday quite so much. The first time I’ve switched off in a while and the first time since catching Covid, so it was a real treat. I spent a good few hours on a beach reading Shoe Dog.</p> <p>In August we took a week off and drove the van from Oxfordshire to Dorset. Visiting the city of Bath, a great little car boot sale in Bradford on Avon, Stourhead House and Gardens, then a short stop in Sherborne. We spent the day hiking over Cheddar Gorge, then drove down to the south coast – Studland Bay, Durdle Door, then further along to Bridport, where we hiked up to Golden Cap and spent time on the beach in Seatown, enjoying a beautiful hot day. We found some great pubs on our travels, and a string of great spots for overnight stays. One of my favourites was an old quarry, just above Kimmeridge.</p> <p>In September I made it to Ibiza for a short weekend with a bunch of friends. We hired a super villa in the hills and took a boat trip to Formentera. A short, but memorable trip.</p> <p>I also spent time in Hamburg, when Covid restrictions allowed it. First in July and August, to pack up our flat and move back to the UK. Then, again in November to sell our German registered van. More on this next.</p> <h3 id="moving-back-to-london">Moving back to London</h3> <p>This year we packed up our life in Hamburg and moved back to London. We love Hamburg and it’s sad to leave, but it got to a point where our living arrangements – between two countries – were no longer working out. The pandemic and Brexit both had their part to play.</p> <p>It wasn’t easy to combine two flats in two different countries, into one flat, in one country, but the process has been hugely cathartic. It’s helped us evaluate what we have, versus what we actually need. Which triggered a massive clear out both online and offline.</p> <p><em>Clutter is costly</em>, as Cal Newport puts it. Possessions demand your attention and ultimately cost your time. Now with a lot less stuff we have a lot less to worry about, and more time to focus on what’s important.</p> <p>Clearing out and moving house teaches you the power of living with less. It leaves you feeling energised and focused. If you haven’t done it in a while I highly recommend giving it a try.</p> <h2 id="health">Health</h2> <p>My approach to health hasn’t really changed much the past year, I feel like I’ve found what works for me, so I stick with it.</p> <p>I have a fairly humble, well-oiled morning routine:</p> <ul> <li>30min run or yoga practice (alternate days)</li> <li>15min mediation</li> <li>1min headstand</li> <li>30 pushups</li> <li>45s cold shower</li> </ul> <p>These things give me energy, keep me calm, sane and healthy. I’m not much good at any of them, but I try and practice every day.</p> <p>I record each of these things in <a href="https://www.notion.so/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Notion</a>, as a daily journal entry, mainly so I can check in from time to time, to see where I’m slipping up. I find the only way to stick with this stuff is to make it as easy as possible. Don’t try and do too much of any one thing.</p> <p>Other than that, I go to the climbing gym with friends when I can, but not regularly enough – I’d like to climb more in 2022.</p> <p>I eat (mainly) vegetarian and try not to eat too much processed shit. I make my own kimchi and sauerkraut, mainly because it’s so damn expensive. But it’s fun and good for you, so I’ll continue to do it. I might even try and set up a blog of my recipes when I find the time.</p> <p>I feel pretty good right now, so I guess these consistent small bets must be counting towards something.</p> <h2 id="what-didnt-go-so-well">What didn’t go so well?</h2> <p>Reflecting on what didn’t go well can be a difficult exercise, particularly when you publish it online for everyone to see. But it’s a great way to figure out what you’re not happy with and identify areas in need of improvement. So here goes.</p> <h3 id="business-focus">Business focus</h3> <p>I found myself working on all sorts of different projects in 2021 – UX/UI, identity design, web design and development, across a range of different industries.</p> <p>Variety can be fun, but, when you’re jumping all over the place, it’s difficult to build systems and scale your business.</p> <p>I want to try and find a focus in 2022, clarify my offering and develop better processes. Currently I’m not doing a great job of articulating my services, so I’ll work on that and try to make my offer clear through my marketing efforts.</p> <p>As mentioned earlier, right now I’m excited by web performance, sustainability and building simple static websites, which all go hand-in-hand. I feel there’s a business focus in here somewhere, so I’ll keep explore these areas in 2022.</p> <h3 id="selling-our-van">Selling our van</h3> <p>In late September we decided to sell our Transporter van. It was a difficult decision, as we spent so much time and effort converting it into a home.</p> <p>But, keeping a van in London isn’t quite as easy as keeping one in Hamburg. At times it felt like everything was against us and we were fighting a loosing battle. First, the van didn’t meet London’s ever tightening low emission standards. Next it required several modifications to make it safe for UK roads. On top of all this, we didn’t have a suitable place to keep it, for the long term.</p> <p>Looking back the solution was obvious, but it can take a while to come to terms with the idea of parting ways with something you worked so hard on.</p> <p>But we got there eventually, seeing as we didn’t have much choice. Although it sucked, it all ended well now Catcher has a new owner and a new home.</p> <p>Catcher is called Harry, would you believe – so the legacy lives on! I’m told it’s a tradition to name your car after the previous owner. News to me, but whatever works. So long old friend, and now namesake.</p> <h3 id="side-projects">Side projects</h3> <p>This year I spent most of my time and energy on client projects and as a result, I had little time left over for side projects.</p> <p>The side projects I usually take on are quite ambitions, by my standards. Which often means I struggle to see them through.</p> <p>I did, however, end the year on a positive note – by committing to creating a course on building websites with Hugo. I set up <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">practialhugo.com</a> and I’m now in the early stages of developing content. This will be my single side project focus, for the first part of 2022.</p> <p>If all goes well, I plan on following up this project with a few slightly less ambitions projects. I have a few ideas, but that’s it for now.</p> <h3 id="german-practice">German practice</h3> <p>My German practice has been slipping the last few years, but I’m not ready to let go. I’m not sure I have much option, as my other half is German.</p> <p>I used to practice on the train, on the days I travelled to work in-house with clients. But that’s no longer a thing, so now I need a new plan.</p> <p>I’ve found time blocking helpful in the past, but I‘ve since got out of the habit. I’d like to give this another go in 2022, by giving myself a specific time and place to practice, each day.</p> <h2 id="what-did-i-learn-in-2021">What did I learn in 2021?</h2> <p>I’m sure I learnt all sorts of valuable lessons in 2021, but here’s a few things come to mind and might be of interest.</p> <h3 id="more-choice-less-action-do-more-by-doing-less">More choice, less action. Do more by doing less.</h3> <p>I stole that headline from <a href="https://tr.af/100" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Traf</a>, but it’s something I’ve consciously been practicing in 2021. Partly inspired by moving country and letting go of so many possessions.</p> <p>In the past, so much of my inaction stems from abundance of choice and lack of focus. As soon as you narrow your focus, commit to what’s important and let go of what’s not, a crazy thing starts happening – you start making progress.</p> <p>It’s not always easy, but try and get there, the upsides are well worth it. A good place to start is by saying no more often than you’re comfortable with. As Traf says (once again); “focus is repeatedly saying no to almost everything.”</p> <p>Pick one tool and stick with it – I use Notion for as much as possible. Pick one technology and stick with it – I went with Hugo, because it’s a pleasure to make websites with. Pick one colour, one typeface, you get where this is heading.</p> <p>Constraints, believe it or not, bread creativity.</p> <h3 id="sell-your-value-not-your-time">Sell your value, not your time.</h3> <p>This is not easy, especially for freelancers and contractors used to working on a day rate.</p> <p>But here’s the thing. You only have 5 days in a week, so unless you can keep increasing your day rate forever – there’s a clear limit to what you can earn with this method.</p> <p>The trick is to stop pricing projects based on how long you think they will take. Instead, start charging for the value of your expertise, and the potential value you create for your clients.</p> <p>Clients pay you for your experience. <a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/CSFIWtAJ683/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">You’re the person who knows which screw to turn</a> and that’s the experience they should be willing to pay you good money for.</p> <p>It’s more of a mindset shift, than anything else. It takes time and some confidence to get comfortable with. The main thing is to believe in your abilities, find the right clients who are prepared to pay well, and start charging your worth.</p> <h3 id="bespoke-is-only-scalable-when-you-have-a-good-system">Bespoke is only scalable when you have a good system.</h3> <p>I’ve done a lot of heavily custom design work over the years - 2021 had it’s fair share. It can really drain your time and your energy, if not done right.</p> <p>Maybe I’m late to the party, but I’m beginning to realise that the only way to make a scaleable business out of bespoke design work is to build well polished processes and systems of constraint.</p> <p>One of the easiest ways it seems is to have a well defined offer – <em>this is what I can offer your business, this is how it works, this is why you need it and this is how much it costs</em>.</p> <p>The rest is about fine tuning your systems, so your business runs like clockwork.</p> <p>Easier said than done, but I’m doing my best to put this into practice and I plan on spending a good amount of time working on this in 2022.</p> <h2 id="2021-recommendations">2021 recommendations</h2> <p>Reeling a few off, from the top of my head.</p> <ul> <li><strong>Books</strong>: <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/44767458-dune?from_search=true&amp;from_srp=true&amp;qid=Fb5ytXr0L5&amp;rank=1" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Dune</a>, <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/655627.Agent_Zigzag" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Agent Zigzag</a>, <a href="https://leanweb.dev/ebook/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Lean Web</a>, <a href="https://gerrymcgovern.com/books/world-wide-waste/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">World Wide Waste</a>, <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/27220736-shoe-dog" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Shoe Dog</a></li> <li><strong>Articles</strong>: <a href="https://shkspr.mobi/blog/2021/01/the-unreasonable-effectiveness-of-simple-html/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The unreasonable effectiveness of simple HTML</a> by Terence Eden</li> <li><strong>Films</strong>: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8g18jFHCLXk" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Dune</a>, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BIhNsAtPbPI" target="_blank" rel="noopener">No Time to Die</a></li> <li><strong>Series</strong>: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EzrLrUG2QVk" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Dopesick</a>, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ga0iTWXCGa0" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Lupin</a></li> <li><strong>Documentaries</strong>: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8QH5hBOoz08" target="_blank" rel="noopener">14 peaks: Nothing Is Impossible</a></li> <li><strong>Exhibitions</strong>: <a href="https://www.saatchigallery.com/exhibition/jr__chronicles" target="_blank" rel="noopener">JR: Chronicles</a> at the Saatchi Gallery</li> <li><strong>Albums</strong>: <a href="https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLb-HdPOj7NAna7-NzzoTe6PBbholDynPX" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Boavista</a> by Stephan Bodzin, <a href="https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLloMpDDjUdyMr6ews6hNLt_tCIrA5DCM8" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Promises</a> by Floating Points, Pharoah Sanders &amp; The London Symphony Orchestra</li> </ul> <h2 id="focus-for-2022">Focus for 2022</h2> <p>I want to avoid taking on too much in 2022. After all, focus is only possible when you make sacrifices and commit to as little as possible. So I’ll keep this short.</p> <p>Here’s just five things that I want to focus on in 2022:</p> <ul> <li>Develop and launch my course on Hugo</li> <li>Improve the systems I use for my design business</li> <li>Write more about the business benefits of web performance and sustainability (low-carbon websites, etc)</li> <li>Make better software choices (privacy first, open-source, transparent, green, where possible)</li> <li>Improve my approach to social media - learn to use Twitter for marketing and client acquisition, and less for entertainment</li> </ul> <p>Maybe that’s already too much. My priority is the top one.</p> <h2 id="final-words">Final words</h2> <p>There you have it. Another year, another review.</p> <p>For a year that began in bed with Covid, it really wasn’t all that bad, and it soon picked up.</p> <p>It was a year for letting go, simplifying life, finding focus, and prioritising what’s important – all of which I’m still working towards. Now I have a slightly clearer idea of what the hell I’m up to and where I might be heading in the year ahead.</p> <p>I hope you’ve found this as useful to read as I have to write. Thanks for you support over the past 12 months and I wish you a positive and productive start to 2022.</p>

item.title: Déjà Vu
item.content:encoded: <p>When you smash things out quickly – as I’m doing with these updates – it’s easy to forget what you’ve written, even from just a few weeks back.</p> <p>It happened yesterday, when I wrote about <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/resilient-research/">structing this course around a bunch of practical projects</a>. I had that funny feeling of Déjà Vu. Typically it happened right after I hit publish.</p> <p><em>Have I written this before?</em></p> <p>I soon realised <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/course-utility/">I shared these exact same ideas in a previous update</a>.</p> <p>But that’s ok. It’s all part of the process. Things take time, sometimes a few times to make sense of. What I like about these updates is they’re unpolished and real – you’re getting it as I’m getting it, exactly how it is.</p> <p>Anyway. Today I spent the day working on <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/2021-review/">my year end review</a>. I didn’t do much else. It felt good to find some flow and spend the whole day writing – getting thoughts out of your head and into some sort of order. It’s been a while since I’ve had the luxury of writing all day.</p> <p>One more day of that, please. It’s all I ask.</p>

item.title: Resilient research
item.content:encoded: <p>First day back since the holidays, so I wasn’t expecting much.</p> <p>Spent time adding custom CSS to my <a href="https://buttondown.email/practicalhugo" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Buttondown subscriber page</a>, to get it somewhat inline with the <a href="http://practicalhugo.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">practicalhugo.com</a> one-pager I’ve been work on.</p> <p>Then I took a break from building and starting re-reading <a href="https://resilientwebdesign.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Resilient Web Design</a> by Jeremy Keith. It’s a big inspiration for this course, so I’m reading it once more to see what it sparks.</p> <p>I guess I’m in the research phase, where I work on the curriculum and try to figure out how best to structure this course. I don’t have the answer yet, but maybe the name holds a clue?</p> <p><em>Practical Hugo</em> was the result of a question I’m often asked:</p> <blockquote> <p>“Can you point me in the direction of a decent tutorial that shows me how to build a site with Hugo – from start to finish?”</p> </blockquote> <p>This is usually followed by something along the lines of;</p> <blockquote> <p>“&hellip;there’s a lot going on in the Hugo docs&hellip; I’m struggling to piece it all together.”</p> </blockquote> <p>A few weeks back I jotted down a possible tagline for this course;</p> <blockquote> <p>“12 practical projects to help you learn Hugo.”</p> </blockquote> <p>Of course, the number 12 is arbitrary, at this stage, but here’s what I’m thinking.</p> <p>What if the course is built around several different projects? One website per project.</p> <p>Start small and beginner friendly – a one-pager perhaps, like the one I just mentioned.</p> <p>With each new project we introduce new concepts, new functionality, new ways of working with Hugo. You learn by doing, through a series of practical projects.</p> <p>Maybe I’m trying to run before I can walk. All just ideas at this stage.</p> <p>I expect slow progress with this, at least until the new year. We’re only just the other side of Christmas and I’m still working on my <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/topics/year-in-review/">year end review</a>.</p>

item.title: Micro Steps
item.content:encoded: <p>Feels like I’m making micro steps at the moment, but I’m heading in the right direction.</p> <p>I added a sign up form to <a href="https://practicalhugo.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">practicalhugo.com</a>, then spontaneously ditched Mailchimp in favour of Buttondown for the email list – hopefully this doesn’t turn out to be a bad decision. I know Mailchimp pretty well, which is why I tend to stick with it, but as they add new features it’s starting to feel like overkill for my basic needs.</p> <p>On the other hand, <a href="https://buttondown.email/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Buttondown</a> seems super simple and you can write emails in markdown – exactly what I’m looking for. I only hear positive things from those who use it, and this new project is a great chance to take it for a spin.</p> <p>So far I’ve managed to hook the form up to my new list. Tomorrow I’ll clean up the automated sign up emails, work on a some kind of welcome email and dig further into the docs.</p> <p>That’s it for today. Time to make some dinner then get those presents wrapped.</p>

item.title: Get something live
item.content:encoded: <p>Trying not to loose focus in the run up to Christmas, so today I set myself a simple goal – get something live on <a href="http://www.practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">practicalhugo.com</a> by the end of the day.</p> <p>It’s not much, but it’s something and I’m telling myself that’s all that matters – move fast with easy wins and make progress through iteration.</p> <p>I hoped to add a sign up form, but I was working on it between meetings. Then I went down a rabbit whole thinking about how to make the <em>leanest Hugo site possible</em>, as you so often do.</p> <p>Some very quick thoughts on this, before I switch off for th evening.</p> <p>What’s the least amount of code (Hugo templating, HTML, CSS, etc) it takes to build a website that works well and looks great? A <strong>minimum viable website</strong>, if you like.</p> <p>Something for an intro lesson perhaps.</p> <p>I’ll think more about this tomorrow, when I get on with that sign up form.</p>

item.title: More of a thing
item.content:encoded: <p>Now I have <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/practical-hugo/">a name for my Hugo course</a> it’s tempting to go all guns blazing with a whole new identity and website.</p> <p>Somehow I managed to convince myself that all I really need right now is a basic landing page and sign up form. But it’s hard not to do something to bring all this to life, so I ended up designing a simple color palette and logo mark.</p> <figure class="Image" data-layout="pull-right"> <div class="aspect-ratio-landscape"> <img sizes="(min-width: 37.5em) 55vw, 100vw" srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_70,w_256/v1639668140/hc/harry-cresswell-practical-hugo-identity-lite.png 256w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_70,w_512/v1639668140/hc/harry-cresswell-practical-hugo-identity-lite.png 512w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_70,w_768/v1639668140/hc/harry-cresswell-practical-hugo-identity-lite.png 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_70,w_1024/v1639668140/hc/harry-cresswell-practical-hugo-identity-lite.png 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_70,w_1280/v1639668140/hc/harry-cresswell-practical-hugo-identity-lite.png 1280w" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_70,w_512/v1639668140/hc/harry-cresswell-practical-hugo-identity-lite.png" alt="Practical Hugo identity lite" class="lazyload" /> </div> <figcaption>Practical Hugo identity lite</figcaption> </figure> <p>If you’re familiar with Hugo, then you might well recognise the mark as an abstraction of <a href="https://gohugo.io/img/hugo.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the Hugo logo</a>.</p> <p>Remove the color and the type, round the corners and tweaked the shape (to satisfy my obsession with the 8pt grid). Now I have something different, yet familiar – try and do me for plagiarism.</p> <p>I’ve been putting a curriculum outline together alongside this, as I know content is where I should focus my energy. But planning content is a lot more difficult than I was expecting. I’m used turning notes into articles, so this is a real mindset shift.</p> <p>Maybe I’m overthinking it, but that’s only because I want this course to be more than the typical tutorial. At least this <em>lite</em> branding exercise has helped make it feel like more of a thing.</p> <p>At some point I should share this course on Twitter and maybe I will in time. But it’s almost the holidays and I doubt many of you are listening. One thing at a time, I’m in no rush and I’m having fun with it.</p>

item.title: Practical Hugo
item.content:encoded: <p><a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/course-utility">Yesterdays update</a> really helped me clarify a few things about <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/learn-hugo">the Hugo course</a> I’m working on.</p> <p>I want the course to be as practical as possible, packed full of utility, to give whoever decides to take it a range of experience with Hugo and a number of different projects to show for it.</p> <p>So I picked up the domain name <a href="http://practicalhugo.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">practicalhugo.com</a> on a bit of a whim. It feels sort of right and anyway learnhugo.com was already taken. No surprises there. <a href="https://twitter.com/practicalhugo" target="_blank" rel="noopener">@practicalhugo</a> was also available on Twitter which is a bonus. Not sure I’ll even use it but I’ve got it, just in case.</p> <p>This is also a little nod to Gordon Zhu’s old course <a href="https://watchandcode.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical JavaScript</a>, which is one of the first courses I ever took on JavaScript. It was a good course, I learnt a lot, but it’s since been deprecated, so I thought I’d pinch the ‘practical’ part and see where I get with it.</p> <p>I realise this changes a few things and undoes some of the initial work I’ve done on setting up a mailing list and landing page for the course on this site, but it’s early days so I was half expecting this might happen.</p> <p>If you’ve been following these updates you’ll know my initial plan was to host course content on here my personal site, but in hindsight I think giving the course it’s own platform will give me more flexibility in the long run. It does mean I’ll have to create a new site, set up a new mailing list, etc. But it’s all good practice and means I can work on a whole new design.</p> <p>I have no plans to move these course related updates away from my personal site. They feel, well, personal, so it’s probably the best place to keep them. It just means I’ll have to update a few links to point to the new domain name, when I get round to launching a new site.</p> <p>Anyway, that’s where I’m at for now. I spent the morning writing some basic getting started bits – how to install Hugo and work with Hugo’s CLI. Not the most exciting stuff but important none the less, so I’m getting it done.</p>

item.title: Course utility
item.content:encoded: <p>I’ll be honest, I wasn’t expecting to get many of these updates out over weekends, and I’m fine with that. These days I’m not one to work myself into the ground, I’ve done it in the past and it doesn’t end well. I value time off, I think it’s important.</p> <p>I was actually away this weekend, in Sussex with family, so I didn’t give work much thought at all. It was nice to switch off and hear what everyone else has been up to for a change.</p> <p>Now back to it, I spent the morning thinking about how best to structure this course. To get the ball rolling a had a poke around in some of the courses I’ve taken recently.</p> <p>I like the way <a href="https://piccalil.li/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Andy</a> gets right to it in <a href="https://learneleventyfromscratch.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Learn Eleventy from Scratch</a>, he doesn’t over do it with the theory – it’s straight into the code. I’d like to do something similar. If past experience has taught me anything it’s that the best way to learn is to get in with the weeds and start building things as soon as you can. It’s easier to stay focused and a lot more fun than wading through pages and pages of endless theory, without ever putting what you learn into practice.</p> <p>So let’s jump right in with the basics and learn how to spin up a simple website quickly and efficiently, in the fewest lines of code possible. For some of you this may be enough. But Hugo is powerful, so why stop there? For those who want to go beyond the basics, we’ll take it further by adding functionality, exploring all the features Hugo has to offer in the process.</p> <p>Maybe I’m getting ahead of myself here, but I like the idea of using the course to build a few different projects across a few different modules. These could even be real world side projects – I’ve got a lot of ideas. Either way you learn how to use Hugo in a number of practical ways.</p> <p>What I like about this idea is that it gives the course utility – you come away a variety of different projects to add to your portfolio. In my mind that can only be a good thing.</p> <p>From my perspective, splitting the work into a series of small modules is far more manageable. It doesn’t feel quite so overwhelming, both to think about and plan. I can focus on each module one by one, and in time this course may even start building itself.</p>

item.title: Related updates
item.content:encoded: <p><em>⚠️ Things have changed since I originally wrote this post. Course updates are now part of my <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing">/writing</a> page, organised under <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/topics/side-projects/">Side Projects</a>. I have also retired the course landing page that onced lived at /learn-hugo, in favour of <a href="https://practicalhugo.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">practicalhugo.com</a>.</em></p> <hr> <p>I had the idea of displaying updates related to <a href="https://practicalhugo.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the Hugo course</a> I’m writing at <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/learn-hugo/#updates">the bottom of the course landing page</a>. Until I have some course material to share I figured I might as well get these updates on the page so you can see how I’m getting on.</p> <p>These updates live in their own directory and are marked with a specific tag. And I want to display them on a single page on my website. How do you do it?</p> <p>First I need to get hold of all the updates I’ve written. As mentioned, updates are a dedicated content type. In other words, they live in their own directory at content/updates. Each update has it’s own markdown file.</p> <p>Hugo refers to this type of content as <a href="https://gohugo.io/variables/site/#sitepages-compared-to-pages" target="_blank" rel="noopener">regular pages</a>. Think <em>post</em> or <em>content</em> page, as opposed to a taxonomy or section page. You can get hold of all regular pages from anywhere on your site using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/variables/site/#site-pages" target="_blank" rel="noopener">.Site.RegularPages</a> variable.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">RegularPages</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>But here’s the thing, using <code>.Site.RegularPages</code> on it’s own will return all regular pages. I have a few different content types on this site, so that includes any file in <em>content/writing</em> and <em>content/newsletter</em>. Not exactly what I want. I’m only interested in <em>content/updates.</em></p> <p>The solution is to filter by the Type associated with the content. Hugo automatically assigns a Type to all content types. The type is based on the name you give your content directory. For example, <em>content/writing</em> has the Type <em>writing</em> and <em>content/updates</em> has the Type <em>updates.</em></p> <p>Then you can use the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/where/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">where function</a> to filter the array.</p> <p>Putting this in practice my updates variable now looks like this.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">where</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">RegularPages</span> <span class="s">&#34;Type&#34;</span> <span class="s">&#34;updates&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next I’m need to loop through my updates. You can do this using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/range/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">range function</a>, which is the equivalent of using <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/forEach" target="_blank" rel="noopener">foreach</a> in other programming languages.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;!</span><span class="o">--</span> <span class="nx">grab</span> <span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="o">--</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">where</span> <span class="nx">site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">RegularPages</span> <span class="s">&#34;Type&#34;</span> <span class="s">&#34;updates&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;!</span><span class="o">--</span> <span class="nx">loop</span> <span class="nx">through</span> <span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="o">--</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// return something! </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now, what data should I return? Well, all I want to do is create a list of updates, so for each update I need the title, the date it was written and a link to it. That way you’ll be able to click the title and read the update.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;!</span><span class="o">--</span> <span class="nx">grab</span> <span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="o">--</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">where</span> <span class="nx">site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">RegularPages</span> <span class="s">&#34;Type&#34;</span> <span class="s">&#34;updates&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;!</span><span class="o">--</span> <span class="nx">loop</span> <span class="nx">through</span> <span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="o">--</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">a</span> <span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Permalink }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Date</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Format</span> <span class="s">&#34;Jan 2, 2006&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> <span class="err">–</span> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now I have updates showing on the page, but there’s a problem. I only want to show updates that have been assigned the topic “Hugo” in the frontmatter of the updates markdown file.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="o">---</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">title</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s">&#34;Learning exhaust&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">date</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">2021</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">12</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mo">07</span><span class="nx">T10</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">29</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">30</span><span class="nx">Z</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">slug</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s">&#34;learning-exhaust&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">topics</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s">&#34;Hugo&#34;</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="o">---</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>To check if an element is in a particular array you can use the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/in/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">in function</a>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;!</span><span class="o">--</span> <span class="nx">grab</span> <span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="o">--</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">where</span> <span class="nx">site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">RegularPages</span> <span class="s">&#34;Type&#34;</span> <span class="s">&#34;updates&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;!</span><span class="o">--</span> <span class="nx">loop</span> <span class="nx">through</span> <span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="o">--</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;!</span><span class="o">--</span> <span class="nx">render</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nx">topic</span> <span class="err">“</span><span class="nx">Hugo</span><span class="err">”</span> <span class="nx">returns</span> <span class="kc">true</span> <span class="o">--</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nx">in</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Params</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">topics</span> <span class="s">&#34;Hugo&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">a</span> <span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Permalink }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Date</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Format</span> <span class="s">&#34;Jan 2, 2006&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> <span class="err">–</span> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>What we’re saying here is; <em>only display updates if they have the topic “Hugo” assigned in their frontmatter and ignore all other pages</em>.</p> <p>There’s one last thing to do before I’m done here.</p> <p>Currently I’m writing this logic in <a href="https://github.com/harrycresswell/harry/blob/master/themes/hc-starter/layouts/_default/page.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a template called page.html</a> in my _default directory. The template is used by quite a few different pages, so these updates will show on all those different pages. Not exactly what I want. If you remember, I only want these updates to display on my Hugo course page.</p> <p>The simple solution is to check if the current page URL is the same as the URL of the page in question – in my case that’s /learn-hugo/. To do this you can use the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/eq/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">eq function</a> and the .URL variable to check if the statement evaluates <code>true</code>. Simply put, <em>if the current page URL equals /learn-hugo/, then run this code</em>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;!</span><span class="o">--</span> <span class="nx">render</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nx">permalink</span> <span class="nx">returns</span> <span class="kc">true</span> <span class="o">--</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="o">-</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nx">eq</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Permalink</span> <span class="s">&#34;/learn-hugo/&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span><span class="nx">Course</span> <span class="nx">updates</span><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;!</span><span class="o">--</span> <span class="nx">grab</span> <span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="o">--</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">where</span> <span class="nx">site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">RegularPages</span> <span class="s">&#34;Type&#34;</span> <span class="s">&#34;updates&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;!</span><span class="o">--</span> <span class="nx">loop</span> <span class="nx">through</span> <span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="o">--</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">updates</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;!</span><span class="o">--</span> <span class="nx">render</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nx">topic</span> <span class="nx">returns</span> <span class="kc">true</span> <span class="o">--</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nx">in</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Params</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">topics</span> <span class="s">&#34;Hugo&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">a</span> <span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Permalink }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Date</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Format</span> <span class="s">&#34;Jan 2, 2006&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> <span class="err">–</span> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice the final statement contains all the previous code. This is because I only want Hugo to execute all this logic <em>if</em> the page is /learn-hugo/. In other words, if the condition is met.</p> <p>That’s it. I now have course related updates displaying at the bottom of my Hugo course page. Hopefully you’ve learnt something here.</p> <p>I think that’s it for the technical stuff for now. I need to get my head down and focus on creating course content, otherwise I’ll never get this thing launched by Spring ‘22.</p>

item.title: Flexible data capture
item.content:encoded: <p>I just improved the sign up form in the footer of my site 👇. Now it can be modified on a page by page basis. What does this mean?</p> <p>Well, depending on the context of the page, I can now change the <em>title</em>, <em>description</em>, <em>list URL</em> and <em>group</em> to send subscribers to, <a href="https://github.com/harrycresswell/harry/blob/8eaca8ef17164109de8774839e87ec5440db3f80/content/learn-hugo/_index.md?plain=1#L8" target="_blank" rel="noopener">directly from the frontmatter of any page</a>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nn">---</span><span class="w"> you’d like to be the first to receive Hugo course content by email, as it’s published, then please leave your details below.&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">signup_group</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;hugo&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nn">---</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>If no ”signup” params are specified in the frontmatter, then the sign up form will default to capturing subscribers for my newsletter, as usual.
