Consider the example below.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h2</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Newsletter-title&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ with .Params.signup_title }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ . }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ else }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ .Site.Data.settings.signup.title | markdownify }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h2</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ with .Params.signup_desc }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ . | markdownify }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ else }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ .Site.Data.settings.signup.desc | markdownify }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">form</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;NewsletterForm validate&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">action</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34; </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ with .Params.signup_listURL }} </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ . }} </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ else }} </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .Site.Data.settings.signup.list_url }} </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ end }}&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">method</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;post&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;mc-embedded-subscribe-form&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">target</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;_blank&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">novalidate</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I decided to abstract the default <em>title</em>, <em>description</em>, and <em>list_url</em> text away from the template and into a signup data file located at <a href="https://github.com/harrycresswell/harry/blob/master/data/settings/signup.yaml" target="_blank" rel="noopener">data/settings/signup.yaml</a>. This isn’t 100% necessary, but it makes the template cleaner as the text is no longer hard coded into the template directly.</p> <p>Accessing this data is as simple as using <code>.Site.Data</code> followed by the directory name, the folder name and then the YAML key I’m looking to return the value of.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{{ .Site.Data.settings.signup.list_url }} </code></pre><p>Now I have control over the signup form from the frontmatter of a page, I can do some pretty cool stuff with it.</p> <p>For example, in the frontmatter of the page for <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/learn-hugo/">my Hugo course</a>, I’ve set <em>signup_group</em> to <code>hugo</code> .</p> <p>Now if you <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/learn-hugo/#signup">sign up to receive my Hugo course content</a>, you automatically get added to a group I set up in Mailchimp called “Learn Hugo”. That way I know you’re here for Hugo content and I will only send you emails related to the course. Clever huh?</p> <p>To make this work I’m using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/ne/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ne</a> (not equal) and <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/eq/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">eq</a> (equal) functions to check if <code>signup_group</code> is set to Hugo in the frontmatter. If this evaluates true, then the checkbox that represents the Learn Hugo group is checked and the subscriber is added to the group. If the condition returns false, then the subscriber will be added to my Newsletter group, as normal.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">div</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Form-options&#34;</span> <span class="na">style</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;display:none&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">strong</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Product<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">strong</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;checkbox&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">value</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;4&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;group[6417][4]&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;mce-group[6417]-6417-0&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span> <span class="na">if</span> <span class="na">ne</span> <span class="err">.</span><span class="na">Params</span><span class="err">.</span><span class="na">signup_group</span> <span class="err">&#34;</span><span class="na">hugo</span><span class="err">&#34;</span> <span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">checked</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span> <span class="na">end</span> <span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">label</span> <span class="na">for</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;mce-group[6417]-6417-0&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Newsletter<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;checkbox&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">value</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;8&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;group[6417][8]&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;mce-group[6417]-6417-1&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span> <span class="na">if</span> <span class="na">eq</span> <span class="err">.</span><span class="na">Params</span><span class="err">.</span><span class="na">signup_group</span> <span class="err">&#34;</span><span class="na">hugo</span><span class="err">&#34;</span> <span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">checked</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">{{</span> <span class="na">end</span> <span class="err">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">label</span> <span class="na">for</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;mce-group[6417]-6417-1&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Learn Hugo<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I might need to refactor this code if I ever want to add more groups in the future. But it does the job for now and that’s what matters.</p>

item.title: Doing the work
item.content:encoded: <p><em>⚠️ Things have changed since I originally wrote this post. Course updates are now part of my <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing">/writing</a> page, organised under <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/topics/hugo-course/">Hugo course</a>. The course landing page that onced lived at /learn-hugo has since been retired, in favour of <a href="https://practicalhugo.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">practicalhugo.com</a>. I have also scrapped the idea of a launch date due to other commitments. Practical Hugo is still in the works, however I’m taking my time with it.</em></p> <hr> <p>In <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/learning-exhaust/">my last update</a> I wrote about my intentions to write <strong>a course on building websites with Hugo</strong>, and explained why <strong>I’m documenting the process in public</strong>. I wrote about how I needed a better plan of action and some way of staying accountable – so I actually turn up and make progress each day.</p> <p>I’ve been doing the work and things are starting to take shape. Here’s where I’m at.</p> <p>Course material will live at harrycresswell.com/learn-hugo. At the time of writing the page exists but there’s not much on it. It will come together as I develop the course.</p> <p>I also added a banner to the top of the site, so there’s no hiding. I’m 100% doing this.</p> <p>I plan to post each chapter of the course as and when I write it. Each chapter will also go out to an email list and via RSS. I think that makes sense?</p> <p>As mentioned yesterday, I’m documenting my progress via updates like this one. You can find updates at harrycresswell.com/updates. To stay accountable, I’m aiming to write updates daily (first thing in the morning) or every few days, depending on my work commitments and how successful the project goes. I expect these will be short posts like this (ideally no more than 500 words). I might end up syndicating them from my website to Twitter, using Zapier or IFTTT, but right now I’m undecided. I’ll sit on it for now. I may well use these updates to share other things in future, but I expect they’ll stay course related for now.</p> <p>I’ve given myself a course <strong>launch date of Spring 2022</strong>. That gives me 3-6 months to get this done. Feels long enough to do the work around other commitments, but short enough to maintain focus and keep this thing from going stale.</p> <p>My next move is to start thinking about the course structure. What do we all expect from a course on Hugo? What can I offer you that others haven’t? I’ll start with a rough outline, try and map out the fundamentals and build it out from there. At this point all I’m looking for is a general sense of direction.</p>

item.title: Learning exhaust
item.content:encoded: <p>I’ve had this reminder on my task list for far too long. It says; “publicly commit to Hugo course so you’re accountable.” I’ve looked at it countless times and done nothing about it.</p> <p>A few nights back I realised my problem; I don’t have a decent strategy. I lack <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/implementation-intentions/">a concrete plan to implement my intentions</a> and a cue that will help me get on and do the work.</p> <p>It occurred to me that perhaps the solution is to write the whole course in public. In other words, I shouldn’t just tell you I’m writing a course on Hugo, but actually show you – by documenting the entire process with daily updates. If I commit to daily updates I’m going to have to get on and write the damn thing. What better way to hold myself accountable and stick with it?</p> <p>I remember <a href="https://twitter.com/frank_chimero" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Frank</a> sharing <a href="https://frankchimero.com/blog/2019/redesign/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the redesign of his website</a> in public a while back, although I think his reasons for doing so were somewhat different. Either way, it reminded me of <a href="https://twitter.com/swyx" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Shawn</a>’s article <a href="https://www.swyx.io/learn-in-public/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">learn in public</a> in which he talks about <strong>getting in the habit of creating learning exhaust</strong> – regular creative output in a content format of your choosing. I’m yet to hear an argument as to why this isn’t a great idea.</p> <p>By sharing the work in progress (not just the completed course), my hope is that we both learn something through the process. I get to clarify my approach to web development and escape the trap of endless editing, polishing and perfecting, before putting work out there. And you? My hope is that you learn an approach to building websites that involves a simple workflow with minimal friction. You get a solid understanding of how to build fast, resilient websites without the complexity you find in so many modern web development workflows. You also get to see how this speculative stuff comes together and if it does at all. What fun.</p> <p>I’ll be honest, I don’t know exactly where all this is heading yet, but by sharing the process I’m sure we’ll find out. What I can tell you is this; over the years I’ve built enough websites with Hugo to know a thing or two about how it’s done. I’m sure wherever this takes us there will be plenty to learn for all of us. Let’s see how we get on.</p>

item.title: Learn Hugo
item.content:encoded: <p>⚠️ <strong>This post has been deprecated</strong> but will remain here for reference purposes. You can now sign up for my Hugo course over at <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">practicalhugo.com</a> instead of using the form below. Read <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/practical-hugo/">my reasons for this change</a> if you’d like to learn more.</p> <hr> <p>Welcome the humble beginnings of my course on building websites with <a href="https://gohugo.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo</a>.</p> <p>Currently a work in progress, my aim is to share entire process through <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/topics/hugo-course/">daily updates</a>. If you’d like to join me on this journey you can <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing/feed.xml">subscribe via RSS</a>.</p> <p>I plan on publishing each chapter of the course on this page as I write it. If you would like to receive a copy of each chapter in your inbox when it goes live, then please <a href="https://practicalhugo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">sign up for course content by email</a>.</p> <p>I don’t have much information about the course yet as it’s still early days, no more than an intention at this stage. What I can tell you is I’m giving myself 3-6 months to write it. This seems like a reasonable amount of time given my other work commitments.</p>

item.title: Sharing more
item.content:encoded: <p>⚠️ <strong>This post has been depreciated.</strong> You can now find updates on my <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/writing">writing</a> page.</p> <hr> <p>Hello friend. Welcome to a new thing – updates.</p> <p>I’ve added <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/updates">an updates page</a> to my website so I can share short-form posts about what I’m currently working on and how I’m going about it.</p> <p>I have a tendency to go round in circles stuck in the editing process. Endlessly polishing and perfecting long-form articles before I finally hit publish. Maybe this sounds familiar?</p> <p>I hope these updates will help me change my mindset. I want to get in the habit of getting stuff out there and sharing more often.</p> <p>Don’t expect much editing going on round here. I want to keep these updates nice and short - somewhere between the length of a tweet and a short article. Short is good. Less to edit, less to sweat over – easier to publish.</p> <p>My aim is to write these updates as often as possible, ideally daily, at the very least weekly. I want to get this stuff out of my head and into the habit of posting regularly.</p> <p>I’ve just started working on a new project (the main reason this idea came about) so I should have plenty to test the water with and update you about. I’m short on time today, so I’ll share more on this tomorrow, if all goes to plan.</p>

item.title: Automate your newsletter with RSS
item.content:encoded: <p class="intro"> Earlier in the year I made <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/newsletter/">an archive of all my newsletters</a>, here on my website. My aim was to revive past issues from the abyss of many inboxes. Then came the power of RSS and automation. </p> <h2 id="owning-your-content">Owning your content</h2> <p>Whilst going through the tedious task of creating markdown files for all past issues, I realised hosting newsletters on my site also made a lot of sense from a content ownership perspective.</p> <p>Ok, I realise that might sound obvious, but hear me out.</p> <p>What if I didn’t just archive each issue, but actually posted each one on my site <em>first</em>, before sharing the link elsewhere? That way I’d actually <em>own</em> the original content, rather than handing it over to Mailchimp. I’d have that all important canonical URL. A single source of truth for, which I could link to from elsewhere – always bringing readers back to my website.</p> <p>If you’re a follower of the <a href="https://indieweb.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">IndieWeb</a>, you’ll know this approach as ‘Publish (on your) Own Site, Syndicate Elsewhere’, or simply; <a href="https://indieweb.org/POSSE" target="_blank" rel="noopener">POSSE</a>.</p> <p>When I shared the <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/newsletter/newsletter-changes/">changes I’m making to my newsletter</a> earlier this year, I briefly mentioned one of the benefits of POSSE is the ability to leverage <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RSS" target="_blank" rel="noopener">RSS</a>. But I didn’t go into any detail about how this works. Let me do that now.</p> <h2 id="the-power-of-rss">The power of RSS</h2> <p>By publishing on your website, you can create an RSS feed of your content with very little effort. In fact, most Static Site Generators either do this automatically or via a plugin.</p> <p>The next thing to realise is that most email newsletter providers include a feature that allows you to create campaigns directly from an RSS feed.</p> <p>That means you can automate the entire process of building your newsletter campaign.</p> <p>To give you a clear picture of how helpful this is, consider my original newsletter workflow, pre-RSS automation.</p> <p>Before now I would write each newsletter in <a href="https://www.notion.so/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Notion</a> (mainly because Notion docs copy over to Mailchimp without any formatting issues). Then I’d manually set up a new campaign in Mailchimp, before copying the content across from Notion. Once content was in Mailchimp I’d send a test email, check the links worked, then the hit schedule. The Mailchimp process initially took me a while, but I managed to get it down to 10-15 minutes by the end. Not too long, but still a reasonable amount of time.</p> <p>With an RSS workflow, I only have to set this up once. Mailchimp will take care of the rest automatically. No more copying each newsletter over to Mailchimp. I can now focus 100% on writing my newsletter, which I now write in Markdown, directly in a text editor. Just as if I’m writing a blog post, like this one.</p> <p>When I publish my newsletter (aka push to Github), my RSS feed updates. When the schedule time I set in Mailchimp comes around, Mailchimp will grab the new content from my RSS feed and send out the email. All this happens without me ever having to sign into Mailchimp to compose and test the campaign. Result.</p> <p>Thanks to RSS I now own my content <em>and</em> save myself a good bit of time.</p> <p>In the next part I’ll show you the steps to get set up. But first, let’s run through the concept once again so you know exactly what needs to be done.</p> <h2 id="a-simple-newsletter-workflow">A simple newsletter workflow</h2> <p>The concept is very simple and can be broken down into 3 steps.</p> <ol> <li><strong>Publish your newsletter on your personal website first</strong>. This part is critical. None of this will work if you don’t.</li> <li><strong>Create an RSS feed of your content</strong>. Make sure you have a dedicated feed for your Newsletter, this will prevent non-newsletter content from being sent out. If you’re using Hugo <a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/rss/#section-rss" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a feed is created automatically for any section content</a>. For example if write your newsletters in content/newsletter then you can find your RSS feed at <code>your-domain.com/newsletter/index.xml</code> unless you have made changes in your config file. For 11ty folk, check out the <a href="https://www.11ty.dev/docs/plugins/rss/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">RSS plugin</a>. There’s <a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/how-to/adding-common-features/adding-an-rss-feed/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a plugin for Gatsby</a>, too.</li> <li><strong>Set up an RSS automation with your newsletter provider</strong>. This will work differently depending on what service you use. Below you’ll find the steps for Mailchimp, as that‘s my current provider.</li> </ol> <h3 id="rss-automation-with-mailchimp">RSS automation with Mailchimp</h3> <p>In Mailchimp you want to head to <strong>Automations</strong> then in the top right click go to <strong>Classic Automations</strong>.</p> <p>From here you want to select <strong>Share blog updates</strong>, next choose your campaign name and audience, then hit <em>Begin</em>.</p> <p>At the next step you need to paste in your RSS feed (most likely <code>your-domain.com/newsletter/index.xml</code>) and set the send schedule.</p> <p>Run through the Campaign Info set up, tracking, etc, as usual.</p> <p>When you get to Template, <strong>choose a template built with blocks</strong>. In other words, not a ‘Code your own’ one. Now design your template how you want and <strong>include the RSS items block.</strong> This is important, without the block your email won’t render any content. If you just want your newsletter content and nothing else (like mine), then remove all the other blocks in the template, except for the RSS Items block you just added.</p> <p>Under the RSS Items settings, makes sure <em>Content &gt; RSS Items Style</em> is set to <strong>Custom</strong>. Now you can <a href="https://mailchimp.com/help/rss-merge-tags/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">edit the RSS Merge tags</a> as you like. When you’re done hit <strong>Save &amp; Close</strong>.</p> <p>Now click <strong>Preview &amp; Test,</strong> then <strong>Enter Preview Mode</strong>. The email should now pull in the most recent entry in your RSS feed.</p> <p>Click <strong>Start RSS</strong> when you’re ready to start the schedule.</p> <p> <strong>Note</strong>: Since writing this piece I discovered an article on the Mailchimp blog; <a href="https://mailchimp.com/help/share-your-blog-posts-with-mailchimp/" target="_blank">Share your blog posts with Mailchimp</a> which will walk you through the entire process. If my explanation above isn’t clear, then maybe you’ll have more luck with that. </p> <h2 id="summary">Summary</h2> <p>Publishing your content on your own website is a no-brainer from an ownership perspective. It also makes it much easier to automate the repetitive process of composing newsletter campaigns on third-party providers. The secret to all this is good old RSS. So learn to love it. RSS is very much your friend.</p> <p>I hope this has helped you get your head around some of the benefits of POSSE and working with RSS feeds. Now you should be well on your way to owning your content and automating your emails newsletters.</p>

item.title: Heffernan Utilities: visual identity and website for a multi-utility contractor
Responsive images and next-gen formats with Hugo
item.content:encoded: <p class="intro"> The HTTP Archive’s <a href="https://almanac.httparchive.org/en/2020/page-weight#fig-2" target="_blank" rel="noopener">2020 State of the Web</a> reports that images are still the most popular resource type on the web. Contributing more to page weight than JavaScript, CSS and HTML, combined. </p> <p>The problem is that many of these images remain unoptimised. Created heavier than necessary pages, which result in slower site speeds and lower conversion rates.</p> <p>According to <a href="https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/marketing-strategies/app-and-mobile/mobile-page-speed-new-industry-benchmarks/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Google</a>; “as page load time goes from one second to 10 seconds, the probability of a mobile site visitor bouncing increases 123%. Similarly, as the number of elements—text, titles, images—on a page goes from 400 to 6,000, the probability of conversion drops 95%.”</p> <p>So, if you want to make your website faster – and increase conversion – one of the best things you can do is optimise your images. Delivering only what’s necessary, and doing so in the lightest possible way.</p> <p>Whilst there are a number of different ways to optimise image delivery, today I want to focus on just two – responsive images and delivering next-gen formats. Specifically, I want to share the workflow I use when building websites with <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/topics/hugo">Hugo</a>. Where image content is hosted by Cloudinary and the website, itself, is managed via Forestry.</p> <p>It’s a popular stack and when it comes to web performance, these two optimisations are well documented. So, I was surprised to find little out there explaining how to tie all this good stuff together. My aim here is to fill those gaps and provide you with some insight.</p> <p>Let’s begin with the basics.</p> <h2 id="first-steps-towards-responsive-layout">First steps towards responsive layout</h2> <p>The following piece of CSS will no doubt look familiar. It’s the first step in making an image respect a responsive layout and resize as the width of the browser changes.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-css" data-lang="css"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nt">img</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">max-width</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">100</span><span class="kt">%</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">height</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">auto</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>We’re telling the browser to render images with a maximum width of 100% of the browser and set the height automatically. This allows images to resize with the browser, so they always fit the full viewport width, regardless of the browser width.</p> <p>In itself, the only real optimisation here is a visual one. But it’s an important first step in making images feel responsive.</p> <h2 id="responsive-images-using-srcset">Responsive images using srcset</h2> <p>In the past I’ve used JavaScript to load <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/articles/cloudinary/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">automatic responsive images with Cloudinary</a>, but it’s not without its drawbacks. JavaScript can be expensive on performance and if JavaScript is ever disabled, then you’ll run into problems where images don’t load. This doesn’t exactly qualify as <a href="https://resilientwebdesign.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">resilient web design</a>.</p> <p>Using <code>srcset</code> is a far better approach. At the time of writing <a href="https://caniuse.com/?search=srcset" target="_blank" rel="noopener">srcset has 96.48% browser support</a> and it doesn’t require any JavaScript to work.</p> <p>So what’s the deal with <code>srcset</code>?</p> <p>Unlike <code>src</code>, which only allows one image source, with the <code>srcset</code> attribute you can provide multiple image sources, as a comma separated list.</p> <p>For each image in the list, you tell the browser how wide it is in advance. The browsers can then determine which image is the most appropriate to load for the current viewport size.</p> <p>Consider the following example.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> <span class="na">srcset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;small.jpg 320w, medium.jpg 800w, large.jpg 1440w&#34;</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;small.jpg&#34;</span> <span class="na">alt</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Responsive Images!&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice each image in the <code>srcset</code> requires a width value, followed by the <code>w</code> descriptor; <code>[width]w</code>. This tells the browser the width of each image, before it loads.</p> <p>In the example above, typically the browser will load the small image at small viewport sizes (320px), the medium image at medium (800px) viewports and the large image at large viewports (1440px).</p> <p>However <a href="https://codereview.chromium.org/674923004/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">since Chrome 40</a>, if a higher density image is already in the memory cache, Chrome will only display the higher density image. This prevents unnecessary file downloads.</p> <p>Here we discover an important insight.</p> <p>The preferred image is always selected at the discretion of the browser, rather than the developer. In other words, you, as the developer, can only make suggestions as to which images should be used. But ultimately, the browser makes the final decision.</p> <p>This can often make it <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/28365079/do-latest-chrome-opera-get-srcset-wrong" target="_blank" rel="noopener">difficult to test srcset implementation</a> and validate the quality of your code.</p> <p>When using <code>srcset</code>, it’s important to include a <code>src</code> attribute containing your smallest image size. This will be used as a fallback for older browsers which don’t support <code>srcset</code>. Given older browsers are usually less performant, it makes sense to offer the smallest size.</p> <p>Now let’s turn to next-gen image formats and look at how to optimise image loading, by combining AVIF and WEBP formats with the responsive technique just discussed.</p> <h2 id="adopting-the-avif-image-format">Adopting the AVIF image format</h2> <p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AV1#AV1_Image_File_Format_%28AVIF%29" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AVIF</a> or AV Image Format is a next-gen image format based on the AV1 codec, which delivers images with better compression than both JPEG and WEBP. AVIF generally delivers smaller file sizes, without loosing image quality. However, at the time of writing, <a href="https://caniuse.com/?search=AVIF" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AVIF support is limited</a> to Firefox and Chrome.</p> <p>For browsers that support AVIF, you can start delivering AVIF assets with the <code>.avif</code> file extension. There are plenty of <a href="https://www.ecosia.org/search?q=jpg&#43;to&#43;avif&amp;addon=chrome&amp;addonversion=3.4.0&amp;method=topbar" target="_blank" rel="noopener">tools to convert JPG to AVIF</a> if you don’t have the AVIF format to begin with.</p> <p>For browsers that don’t support AVIF – which unfortunately is quite a few – you’ll need to deliver appropriate fallbacks. You can do this by using the <code>&lt;picture&gt;</code> element.</p> <p>Consider the following example.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">picture</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">source</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/avif&#34;</span> <span class="na">srcset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;path/to/image.avif&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">source</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/webp&#34;</span> <span class="na">srcset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;path/to/image.webp&#34;</span> <span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;path/to/image.jpg&#34;</span> <span class="na">alt</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;&#34;</span><span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">picture</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Within the <code>&lt;picture&gt;</code> element we reference two <code>&lt;source&gt;</code> elements. One to deliver an AVIF image and the other to deliver a WEBP image fallback. <code>&lt;img&gt;</code> is used to deliver a JPG or PNG fallback, for case where both AVIF and WEBP aren’t supported. Include the <code>type</code> attribute to specify each image <code>&lt;source&gt;</code> you deliver.</p> <p>In the example above, I’ve only included one image in the srcset attribute. I’ve done this to keep the example simple, but in reality you’ll want to apply the responsive image technique from earlier, to get the most performant images.</p> <p>Let’s tackle that next.</p> <h2 id="combining-next-gen-formats-and-srcset">Combining next-gen formats and srcset</h2> <p>To make next-gen formats responsive, you need to add a list of images, including width descriptors, to each <code>srcset</code> attribute in the <code>&lt;source&gt;</code> and <code>&lt;img&gt;</code> element. As we’re working with next-gen formats we need to use the <code>&lt;picture&gt;</code> element instead of using <code>&lt;img&gt;</code> alone. That way you can provide fallback formats.</p> <p>Consider the following code example.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">picture</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">source</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/avif&#34;</span> <span class="na">srcset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;small.avif 320w, medium.avif 800w, large.avif 1440w&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">source</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/webp&#34;</span> <span class="na">srcset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;small.webp 320w, medium.webp 800w, large.webp 1440w&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> <span class="na">srcset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;small.jpg 320w, medium.jpg 800w, large.jpg 1440w&#34;</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;small.jpg&#34;</span> <span class="na">alt</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">picture</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Remember to include a <code>src</code> image in the <code>&lt;img&gt;</code>, to use as a fallback for <a href="https://caniuse.com/?search=srcset" target="_blank" rel="noopener">browsers that don’t support <code>srcset</code></a>.</p> <h2 id="what-about-sizes">What about sizes?</h2> <p>If you’ve worked with <code>srcset</code> before you might be wondering why I haven’t included a sizes attribute. According to Chris Coyier; <a href="https://css-tricks.com/responsive-images-youre-just-changing-resolutions-use-srcset/#also-sizes" target="_blank" rel="noopener">if you’re just changing resolution, all you need is the srcset attribute</a>. This is because without the sizes attribute, the browser assumes the image will be 100% of the viewport width. In other words, omitting a sizes value is akin to adding <code>sizes=&quot;100vw</code>.</p> <p>So, unless you want to change the width of an image at a specific viewport, or your image doesn’t fill 100% of the viewport width – maybe it sits in one column of a two column layout – then the sizes attribute isn’t all that necessary.</p> <p>At this point we have responsive images and we’re providing next-gen image formats, for supporting browsers. But how does all this work with an asset management tool?</p> <p>I often use Cloudinary to host image content in the websites I build. So let’s look at how we can apply responsive images and next-gen image formats, when content is hosted by Cloudinary.</p> <h2 id="using-avif-and-webp-with-cloudinary">Using AVIF and WEBP with Cloudinary</h2> <p>Using the AVIF and WEBP formats with Cloudinary is very easy, essentially you have two options.</p> <p>Either you upload an image in each format and reference the full path. The path should include the file extension, as suggested above.</p> <p>Alternatively, you can upload any image format and use Cloudinary’s transformations feature in each of the image URLs. This will transform your images into the required format. Cloudinary makes this possible by automatically creating both an AVIF and a WEBP version, of any image you upload.</p> <p>Consider the following example.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">picture</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">source</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/avif&#34;</span> <span class="na">srcset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/f_avif,q_auto/dog/&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">source</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/webp&#34;</span> <span class="na">srcset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/f_webp,q_auto/dog/&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://o.img.rodeo/image/upload/f_auto,q_auto,w_800/dog&#34;</span> <span class="na">alt</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">picture</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>So, what’s going on here, exactly?</p> <p>Notice the initial <code>&lt;source&gt;</code> element includes the <code>f_avif</code> transformation. This tells Cloudinary to deliver an image in the .avif format, to be used by supporting browsers. In the second <code>&lt;source&gt;</code> we include the <code>f_webp</code> transformation. Here Cloudinary delivers the .webp format. If a browser doesn’t support AVIF but does support WebP, then this image will render. Finally, if neither AVIF or WebP are supported by the browser, the <code>&lt;img&gt;</code> will deliver a JPEG, or equivalent, depending on what file type Cloudinary decides is the smallest. This is achieved using the <code>f_auto</code> transformation. In each case we use the <code>q_auto</code> transformation to allow Cloudinary to set the image quality automatically.</p> <p>When using the file extension approach, there’s no need to include the transformations in the URL, but everything still works just fine if you do.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">picture</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">source</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/avif&#34;</span> <span class="na">srcset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/dog.avif&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">source</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/webp&#34;</span> <span class="na">srcset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/dog.webp&#34;</span> <span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/dog.jpg&#34;</span> <span class="na">alt</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;A dog chasing a ball&#34;</span><span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">picture</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice, again we use the <code>srcset</code> attribute in our <code>&lt;source&gt;</code> elements. As before, this gives us the ability to make our images responsive. Let’s turn to this next.</p> <h2 id="responsive-image-with-cloudinary-using-transformations">Responsive image with Cloudinary using transformations</h2> <p>When using Cloudinary, the technique is almost exactly the same as with regular responsive images. Except you will need to add a width transformation in each URL, as well as the [width]w descriptor, after the image path.</p> <p>Consider the following code example.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">picture</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">source</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/avif&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">srcset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34; </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/f_avif,q_auto,w_600/dogs/7 600w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/f_avif,q_auto,w_800/dogs/7 800w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/f_avif,q_auto,w_1400/dogs/7 1400w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/f_avif,q_auto,w_2000/dogs/7 2000w&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">source</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/webp&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">srcset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34; </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/f_webp,q_auto,w_600/dogs/7 600w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/f_webp,q_auto,w_800/dogs/7 800w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/f_webp,q_auto,w_1400/dogs/7 1400w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/f_webp,q_auto,w_2000/dogs/7 2000w&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">srcset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34; </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/f_auto,q_auto,w_600/dogs/7 600w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/f_auto,q_auto,w_800/dogs/7 800w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/f_auto,q_auto,w_1400/dogs/7 1400w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/f_auto,q_auto,w_2000/dogs/7 2000w&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/f_auto,q_auto,w_800/dogs/7&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">alt</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;A dog chasing a ball.&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">picture</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice we including 3 transformations, one each for format, quality and width. Again, we follow each image path with the width descriptor, which should match the width transformation. For example, <code>w_600</code> and <code>600w</code>, <code>w_800</code> and <code>800w</code>, and so on.</p> <p>Now the browser will load next-gen formats where possible, choosing the most appropriate size image for the current viewport width.</p> <p>This, of course, is a manual implementation. But what if we’re using a static site generator and a CMS?</p> <p>In the final few sections, I’ll show you how to create a responsive image partial to automate this task in Hugo. Then we’ll look at how to get this set up and working correctly with Forestry. So you can upload new image content directly from a CMS, without touching any code in your Hugo project.</p> <h2 id="building-a-next-gen-responsive-image-partial-in-hugo-for-cloudinary-hosted-content">Building a next-gen responsive image partial in Hugo for Cloudinary hosted content</h2> <p>For this next part I will assume you have a Cloudinary account and a Hugo site running locally, on your machine.</p> <p>First we need to add our Cloudiary base URL to our site params, in the config file. Most likely, this will be a <code>config.toml</code> file found at the root of your project.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="l">params]</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="l">cloudinary_url = &#34;https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>This will make it easier to manage the URL from one place, in the future. Make sure you update the URL to your own instance, rather than using mine.</p> <p>Next, create a new file at <code>layouts/partials/images/resposive.html</code>. We’ll keep the code in a partial to make it easier to reuse in different places throughout the website.</p> <p>Add the following code.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">picture</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">source</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/avif&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">srcset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34; </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_avif,q_auto,w_500/{{ .Params.image }} 500w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_avif,q_auto,w_710/{{ .Params.image }} 710w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_avif,q_auto,w_1000/{{ .Params.image }} 1000w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_avif,q_auto,w_1420/{{ .Params.image }} 1420w&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">source</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/webp&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">srcset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34; </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_webp,q_auto,w_500/{{ .Params.image }} 500w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_webp,q_auto,w_710/{{ .Params.image }} 710w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_webp,q_auto,w_1000/{{ .Params.image }} 1000w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_webp,q_auto,w_1420/{{ .Params.image }} 1420w&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">srcset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34; </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_jpg,w_500/{{ .Params.image }} 500w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_jpg,w_710/{{ .Params.image }} 710w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_jpg,w_1000/{{ .Params.image }} 1000w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_jpg,w_1420/{{ .Params.image }} 1420w&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .baseURL }}f_jpg,w_500/{{ .Params.image }}&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">alt</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Params.image_alt }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">picture</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You’ll notice the code is pretty much identical to our previous implementation of responsive next-gen images. However, there are two clear differences.</p> <p>Firstly, we’ve replaced the base URL with <code>{{ .baseURL }}</code>. This will represent our Cloudinary base URL.</p> <p>Secondly, we’ve replace the image path with <code>{{ .Params.image }}</code>. This is so we can render an image from the front matter of a markdown page, in our Hugo website.</p> <p>You’ll also notice a <code>{{ .Params.image_alt }}</code> in the image alt attribute. This allows us to set alternate text for the image, from the front matter of a page.</p> <h3 id="including-the-partial-in-a-page-template">Including the partial in a page template</h3> <p>To include the partial in a template, first you have to reference the partial with the path to the the <code>.html</code> file.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-js" data-lang="js"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">partial</span> <span class="s2">&#34;images/responsive.html&#34;</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This might go in your <code>single.html</code> template file, but it could just as easily go into a <code>list.html</code>, <code>index.html</code>, or any other template file for that matter.</p> <p>Next you need to pass the context into the partial, so the front matter Params and the Cloudinary base URL are accessible from inside the partial.</p> <p>To do this, you can use the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/dict/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">dict function</a>. Dict creates a dictionary from a list of key value pairs and can be used to pass context to partials.</p> <p>Consider the example below.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-js" data-lang="js"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">partial</span> <span class="s2">&#34;images/responsive.html&#34;</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">dict</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Params&#34;</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Params</span> <span class="s2">&#34;baseURL&#34;</span> <span class="nx">$</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Params</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">cloudinary_url</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice we’re using the keys – <code>Params</code> and <code>baseURL</code> surrounded by double quotes – to reference the context <code>.Params</code> and <code>$.Site.Params.cloudinary_url</code>, respectively. And we’re adding this dictonary to the partial include, in order to pass it to the partial. Without passing the context using dict, the partial will have no way of rendering the content, as the context will be stuck in the template in which we referenced the partial.</p> <p>Context can be a tricky concept to understand. If you’re struggling with this I highly recommend reading Regis Philibert’s <a href="https://www.regisphilibert.com/blog/2018/02/hugo-the-scope-the-context-and-the-dot/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo, the scope, the context and the dot</a>, in which Regis explains the concept very well.</p> <h3 id="add-an-image-to-the-front-matter-of-a-page">Add an image to the front matter of a page</h3> <p>With the partial set up, now we can add an image and image alt text to the front matter of a markdown file to validate our code and render an image on the page.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nn">---</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Performant images with Hugo, Cloudinary, Forestry and Netlify</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">date</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="ld">2021-09-24T17:23:17.000</span><span class="m">+01</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="m">00</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">image</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;/v1571674593/hc/image.jpg&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">image_alt</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">Dog chasing a ball</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nn">---</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>Make sure the page is using the template where you placed the partial code, otherwise you won’t see the image on the page.</p> <p>Now let’s get all this working with Forestry.</p> <h2 id="forestry-setup">Forestry setup</h2> <p>To set up Forestry we first need to connect our site from a Git repository, then connect a Cloudinary account, so Forestry knows where to store image content.</p> <p>Assuming you have connected your Git repository to Forestry, head to <em>Settings</em> from your site dashboard. Now click <em>Media</em> and change your <em>Media Storage Provider</em> to Cloudinary. If you want to upload content to a subdirectory in Cloudinary, make sure you add the directory name under <em>Upload Directory</em>. You can leave the <em>Public Path</em> empty for now. Next, scroll down to <em>Cloudinary Settings</em> and add your <em>Cloud name</em>, <em>API Key</em> and <em>API Secret</em>. You’ll find these details in your Cloudinary dashboard. At the bottom of the settings page under <em>Advanced</em>, make sure <em>File Path</em> is set to <code>:filename</code> and <em>Front Matter Path</em> override is checked. You can leave the path field empty.</p> <p>At this point Forestry should be configured. However, there’s one last problem we need to solve before uploaded images will render correctly. It’s all to do with file extensions and how to go about next-gen formats when working with Forestry.</p> <h3 id="dealing-with-next-gen-formats-in-forestry">Dealing with next-gen formats in Forestry</h3> <p>When you upload image content via Forestry, as you might expect, the image format is also stored. In other words, if you upload a JPEG, the image path will include the file extension.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-css" data-lang="css"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nt">image</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">jpg</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>When it comes to delivering next-gen image formats, this creates a problem. How do you deliver the correct format from Cloudinary, when the original file format extension is appended to the image path?</p> <p>We can solve this problem using Hugo’s built in <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/replacere" target="_blank" rel="noopener">replaceRE function</a>, to strip the file format from the image URL path, and add the correct one in its place.</p> <p>That way we can continue to upload any image format via Forestry and have Cloudinary deliver the correct format, in the correct places. This works because Cloudinary creates all the formats we need automatically, for every image you upload. Remember? So all we have to do is make sure we strip the original file extension from the URL, then replace it with the one we want.</p> <p>This is done by providing a pattern and replacement value, as a pipe on the <code>.Params.image</code> path in our <code>responsive.html</code> partial.</p> <p>Consider the following code.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-js" data-lang="js"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Params</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">image</span> <span class="o">|</span> <span class="nx">replaceRE</span> <span class="s2">&#34;.jpg|.jpeg|.JPG|.png|.PNG&#34;</span> <span class="s2">&#34;.avif&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In this case, the replaceRE function looks for the pattern of JPG and PNG, in their various permutations. And replaces any it finds with <code>.avif</code>.</p> <p>We can do the exact same thing for <code>.webp</code> images.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-js" data-lang="js"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Params</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">image</span> <span class="o">|</span> <span class="nx">replaceRE</span> <span class="s2">&#34;.jpg|.jpeg|.JPG|.png|.PNG&#34;</span> <span class="s2">&#34;.webp&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now consider the full responsive images implementation.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">picture</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">source</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">type</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/avif&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">srcset</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34; </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_avif,q_auto,w_500/{{ .Params.image | replaceRE &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">jpeg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">JPG</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">png</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">PNG</span><span class="s">&#34; &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">avif</span><span class="s">&#34; }} 500w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_avif,q_auto,w_710/{{ .Params.image | replaceRE &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">jpeg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">JPG</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">png</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">PNG</span><span class="s">&#34; &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">avif</span><span class="s">&#34; }} 710w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_avif,q_auto,w_1000/{{ .Params.image | replaceRE &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">jpeg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">JPG</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">png</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">PNG</span><span class="s">&#34; &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">avif</span><span class="s">&#34; }} 1000w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_avif,q_auto,w_1420/{{ .Params.image | replaceRE &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">jpeg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">JPG</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">png</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">PNG</span><span class="s">&#34; &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">avif</span><span class="s">&#34; }} 1420w&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">source</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">type</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image/webp&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">srcset</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34; </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_webp,q_auto,w_500/{{ .Params.image | replaceRE &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">jpeg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">JPG</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">png</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">PNG</span><span class="s">&#34; &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">webp</span><span class="s">&#34; }} 500w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_webp,q_auto,w_710/{{ .Params.image | replaceRE &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">jpeg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">JPG</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">png</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">PNG</span><span class="s">&#34; &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">webp</span><span class="s">&#34; }} 710w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_webp,q_auto,w_1000/{{ .Params.image | replaceRE &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">jpeg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">JPG</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">png</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">PNG</span><span class="s">&#34; &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">webp</span><span class="s">&#34; }} 1000w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_webp,q_auto,w_1420/{{ .Params.image | replaceRE &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">jpeg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">JPG</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">png</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">PNG</span><span class="s">&#34; &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">webp</span><span class="s">&#34; }} 1420w&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">img</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">srcset</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .baseURL }}f_jpg,w_500/{{ .Params.image | replaceRE &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpeg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">JPG</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">png</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">PNG</span><span class="s">&#34; &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpg</span><span class="s">&#34; }} 500w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_jpg,w_710/{{ .Params.image | replaceRE &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpeg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">JPG</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">png</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">PNG</span><span class="s">&#34; &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpg</span><span class="s">&#34; }} 710w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_jpg,w_1000/{{ .Params.image | replaceRE &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpeg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">JPG</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">png</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">PNG</span><span class="s">&#34; &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpg</span><span class="s">&#34; }} 1000w, </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s"> {{ .baseURL }}f_jpg,w_1420/{{ .Params.image | replaceRE &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpeg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">JPG</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">png</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">PNG</span><span class="s">&#34; &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpg</span><span class="s">&#34; }} 1420w&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">src</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .baseURL }}f_jpg,w_500/{{ .Params.image | replaceRE &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpeg</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">JPG</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">png</span><span class="p">|.</span><span class="nx">PNG</span><span class="s">&#34; &#34;</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">jpg</span><span class="s">&#34; }}&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">alt</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Params.image_alt }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">picture</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Although it may look chaotic, all we’re really doing is the same thing over and over. For each image size and each format, we look for all the possible formats it may have been uploaded as from Forestry. From here, we use replaceRE to replace the existing format extension, with the format extension that satisfies our responsive implementation.</p> <h2 id="summary">Summary</h2> <p>When it comes to web performance there’s no denying, <a href="https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/marketing-strategies/app-and-mobile/mobile-page-speed-new-industry-benchmarks/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">faster is better and less is more</a>. To increase speed and conversion the ideal thing to do is to <a href="https://almanac.httparchive.org/en/2019/page-weight#what-types-of-assets-does-the-http-archive-track-and-how-much-do-they-matter" target="_blank" rel="noopener">use fewer images</a>. But, I appreciate that’s not always realistic when many websites are built around image content. So, what can we do?</p> <p>As web developers and site owners, it’s our resposibility to optimise the images on the wesites we create. One of the easiest ways to do this is to use responsive image techniques, serving next-generation formats where possible.</p> <p>It’s true, the implementation of these techniques creates a fair amount of extra code in the DOM. But the benefits certainly outweigh the cost. Your <a href="https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Lighthouse audits</a> will prove as much.</p> <p>When combining Hugo, Cloudinary and Forestry, there’s a few moving parts involved. But, once you’ve done it once, the same rules apply for every website you build, thereafter. <a href="https://visualizevalue.com/blogs/feed/brain-dumps-build-once-sell-twice" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Build it once, sell it twice</a>, as the saying goes.</p> <p>From here there’s plenty of ways to optimise your images further.</p> <p>Lazy Loading images outside of the viewport, using image placeholders to reduce Cumulative Layout Shift, asynchronous decoding, lazy rendering and image caching come to mind.</p> <p>All these techniques are worth spending time on, and will help to further improve the speed, user experiene and search ranking of your website.</p>

item.title: Instagram on Hugo websites
item.content:encoded:
<hr> <p><strong>Please note</strong>: Profile Page Images Loader, as discussed in this post, is no longer operational. This post will remain here for reference purposes only.</p> <hr> <p class="intro"> Using Instagram’s API to build a feed of content on a website is often more effort than it’s worth. </p> <p>The set up involves authenticating with Facebook to get a long-lived access token which will give you access to a JSON file containing all the data associated with your images. However access is only temporary and your token will need to be renewed periodically, every 60 days.</p> <p>To solve this problem Companion Studio made <a href="https://github.com/companionstudio/instagram-token-agent" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Instagram Token Agent</a>, a clever little Heroku app that will keep your token up to date automatically. It’s designed to play well with Steven Schobert’s <a href="https://github.com/stevenschobert/instafeed.js" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Instafeed.js</a>, which you’ll be familiar with if you’ve attempted to build an Instagram feed before.</p> <p>But even this isn’t foolproof. To fetch your content you’re still required to make calls to the Instagram API. This raises concerns about privacy and GDPR compliancy. In short, depending on your locality you run the risk of your feed content being blocked by certain browsers.</p> <p>As Joost Va der Schee points out in <a href="https://www.usecue.com/blog/instagram-on-your-website/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Instagram on your website</a>, not only can you content be blocked but you also risk a potential fine.</p> <p>To combat this Joost has built a very slick solution which solves the problem of both expiring tokens and GDPR compliancy.</p> <h2 id="profile-page-images-loader">Profile Page Images Loader</h2> <p><a href="https://profilepageimages.usecue.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Profile Page Images Loader</a> or PPI Loader for short is a simple application that automates the process of downloading content from you instagram account. It does this on a daily basis, effectively creating a fresh feed of your content. When your token expires it will take care of the renewal for you.</p> <p>To avoid the issue of GDPR, PPI Loader hosts your content on it’s own servers, meaning you never need to make a request to the Instagram API.</p> <p>If you’re wondering whether this is allowed, the answer is yes. Instagram actually gives you the ability to download your data directly from the security settings in your Instagram account. Depending on your circumstances you may need to sign a DPA (Data Processing Agreement), so be sure to read <a href="https://profilepageimages.usecue.com/faq" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the FAQs</a> to find out more.</p> <p>What’s nice about PPI loader is that it also creates a JSON object of all your data, so you can work with your data just as you would if you were using the Instagram API.</p> <p>For those of us using Hugo to build websites this makes it very easy to create an Instagram feed using Hugo’s built in <a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/data-templates/#get-remote-data" target="_blank" rel="noopener">getJSON</a> function.</p> <p>In under 5 minutes you can have a lightweight GDPR compliant Instagram feed set up and working on a Hugo website. Let’s look at the steps required to make it happen.</p> <h2 id="sign-up-for-an-account-at-ppi-loader">Sign up for an account at PPI Loader</h2> <p>First you’ll need to follow <a href="https://profilepageimages.usecue.com/getting-started" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the getting started docs</a> to sign up for a PPI Loader account.</p> <p>During this process you’ll need to grant PPI permission to access your Instagram account. PPI Loader has <a href="https://profilepageimages.usecue.com/privacy" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a stringent approach to privacy</a> which should satisfy most, however if you’re concerned about sharing your data then make sure you do your own due diligence before using PPI Loader.</p> <p>Assuming you’re happy to share your data wih PPI Loader – you’ve signed up and granted access to your Instagram account – you’ll now be able to find all your images hosted on the PPI Loader servers and accessible via the following link:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>https://profilepageimages.usecue.com/images/[YOUR_USERNAME]/ </code></pre><p>This is great if you want to add images one by one to your website, however if you’d like to create a feed of your content, then for this you’ll need to use the JSON object containing all your posts, which PPI Loader creates for you.</p> <p>You can find this JSON file via following link:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>https://profilepageimages.usecue.com/images/[YOUR_URSERNAME]/images.json </code></pre><p>If you head to this URL in a browser you’ll struggle to make sense of the content as it hasn’t been formatted. Copy and paste the contents of the URL into <a href="https://jsonprettier.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">JSON Prettier</a> to format the JSON so it’s easier to read. Now you’ll be able to see what you’re working with.</p> <p>You should see a bunch of JSON objects in an array.
