Something that starts like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-json" data-lang="json"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nt">&#34;id&#34;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;17872665263392315&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nt">&#34;caption&#34;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Happy weekend yoginis and yogis. On Sunday we&#39;re offering 4 amazing Yoga sessions with Roxana. Register on our website and join our beautiful yoga-classes. You can expect powerful and energizing flows as well as relaxing and peaceful Yin classes. Practicing yoga can easily be one of the most beneficial gifts we can give to ourselves. A regular practice can increase your wellbeing, boost your energy level, and improve your posture.
May you obtain exactly what you need @laselvahotyoga 🙏🏽
Namaste🌿
.
.
.

class="s2">&#34;https://www.instagram.com/p/CQBwEndFrYV/&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nt">&#34;timestamp&#34;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;2021-06-12T16:47:05+0000&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nt">&#34;image&#34;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;https://profilepageimages.usecue.com/images/laselvahotyoga/0.jpg&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">},</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="err">...</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">]</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This is what we’ll need to build the feed in our Hugo project, so let’s turn to Hugo next. I’ll assume you have an existing Hugo project to work with.</p> <h2 id="building-an-instagram-feed-in-hugo">Building an Instagram feed in Hugo</h2> <p>Inside your Hugo project, open the partials directory or create one if it doesn’t exist and add a new file called <code>instafeed.html</code>. Now include the partial in your template somewhere.</p> <p>I’ve added mine to <code>index.html</code> at the root of my project.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-golang" data-lang="golang"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">partial</span> <span class="s">&#34;instagram.html&#34;</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Open up <code>instafeed.html</code> and assign your JSON feed URL to a variable at the top of the file. The variable can be named anything you like. Make sure you surround the URL in quotes and include the <a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/data-templates/#get-remote-data" target="_blank" rel="noopener">getJSON</a> function before the URL. Be sure to set the variable value using <code>:=</code>, rather than <code>=</code> which in Hugo is saved for updating a variable.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-golang" data-lang="golang"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">dataJ</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">getJSON</span> <span class="s">&#34;https://profilepageimages.usecue.com/images/laselvahotyoga/images.json&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now you can use the range function to map through a specified number of items in the JSON. In this case we’re returning the first 10 items.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ $dataJ := getJSON &#34;https://profilepageimages.usecue.com/images/laselvahotyoga/images.json&#34; }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;instafeed&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range first 10 $dataJ }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now head back to JSON Prettier to have another look at the JSON structure. If you’re new to JSON it’s essentially just structured data in the form of key value pairs. We’ll need to use these keys to return the values we want to render on our website.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-json" data-lang="json"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nt">&#34;id&#34;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;17872665263392315&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nt">&#34;caption&#34;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Happy weekend yoginis and yogis. On Sunday we&#39;re offering 4 amazing Yoga sessions with Roxana. Register on our website and join our beautiful yoga-classes. You can expect powerful and energizing flows as well as relaxing and peaceful Yin classes. Practicing yoga can easily be one of the most beneficial gifts we can give to ourselves. A regular practice can increase your wellbeing, boost your energy level, and improve your posture.

class="p">]</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Let’s take <code>caption</code>, <code>media_type</code>, <code>permalink</code> and <code>image_small</code> and assign each key to their own variable within the range. To keep things simple I’ve mirrored the key name for the variable name.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ $dataJ := getJSON &#34;https://profilepageimages.usecue.com/images/laselvahotyoga/images.json&#34; }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;instafeed&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range first 10 $dataJ }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ $media_type := .media_type | lower }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ $image_small := .image_small }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ $permalink := .permalink }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ $caption := .caption }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>As the <a href="https://profilepageimages.usecue.com/documentation" target="_blank" rel="noopener">PPI Loader documentation</a> suggests, the possible values of <code>media_type</code> are <code>IMAGE</code> , <code>CAROUSEL_ALBUM</code> or <code>VIDEO</code>.</p> <p>We can use Hugo’s <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/lower/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">lower</a> function to convert the values of <code>media_type</code> from uppercase to lowercase.</p> <p>Now create an <code>&lt;img&gt;</code> tag inside the <code>&lt;li&gt;</code> to render each image in the feed.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ $dataJ := getJSON &#34;https://profilepageimages.usecue.com/images/laselvahotyoga/images.json&#34; }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;instafeed&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range first 10 $dataJ }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ $media_type := .media_type | lower }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ $image_small := .image_small }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ $permalink := .permalink }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ $caption := .caption }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ $media_type }}&#34;</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ $image_small }}&#34;</span> <span class="err">{{</span> <span class="na">with</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="na">caption</span> <span class="err">}}</span><span class="na">alt</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ . }}&#34;</span><span class="err">{{</span> <span class="na">else</span> <span class="err">}}</span><span class="na">alt</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;&#34;</span><span class="err">{{</span> <span class="na">end</span> <span class="err">}}</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>By using <code>media_type</code> as the class name we allow for different CSS styling, depending on the media type.</p> <p><code>image_small</code> returns the URL of the image, so we can use it for the image src.</p> <p>We’ve used <code>caption</code> for the alt tag and included some logic to return an empty alt tag in cases where our Instagram post doesn’t have a caption. The empty alt tag will tell screen readers the image is for presentational purposes only.</p> <p>The final thing to do is wrap the image in an anchor tag so we can link the image back to instagram using the <code>permalink</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl">{{ $dataJ := getJSON &#34;https://profilepageimages.usecue.com/images/laselvahotyoga/images.json&#34; }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">ul</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;instafeed&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ range first 10 $dataJ }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ $media_type := .media_type | lower }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ $image_small := .image_small }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ $permalink := .permalink }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ $caption := .caption }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">a</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ $permalink }}&#34;</span> <span class="na">target</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;_blank&#34;</span> <span class="na">rel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;noopener noreferrer&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ $media_type }}&#34;</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ $image_small }}&#34;</span> <span class="err">{{</span> <span class="na">with</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="na">caption</span> <span class="err">}}</span><span class="na">alt</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ . }}&#34;</span><span class="err">{{</span> <span class="na">else</span> <span class="err">}}</span><span class="na">alt</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;&#34;</span><span class="err">{{</span> <span class="na">end</span> <span class="err">}}</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> {{ end }} </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>With your Hugo server running you should now see the latest 10 images from your Instagram displaying on whichever page or pages use the template you added the <code>instafeed.html</code> partial to. The advantage of using a partial is that you can now add your Instagram feed to any template without duplicating code.</p> <h2 id="styling-the-feed">Styling the feed</h2> <p>All that’s left to do now is to introduce some styling to your feed.</p> <p>Joost has put together two helpful demos; one <a href="https://codepen.io/joosts/pen/NWbdMLW?editors=1100" target="_blank" rel="noopener">simple</a> and one <a href="https://codepen.io/joosts/pen/bGBByOo" target="_blank" rel="noopener">advanced</a> which should give you some ideas and help you get started.</p> <h2 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping up</h2> <p>Since GDPR became a thing and Facebook introduced expiring tokens, Instagram feeds have been frustrating to build and maintain.</p> <p>Thanks to Joost’s hard work on PPI Loader, we now have a low-tech and easy to implement solution which also happens to be a perfect fit for Hugo websites. If you like to keep things simple whilst also adhering to GDPR regulations then this approach is a strong option. I’ll certainly be using it again in the future.</p> <p>All the code from this tutorial can be found over on <a href="https://github.com/harrycresswell/instagram-hugo" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Github</a>. I’ve also created <a href="https://instagram-hugo.netlify.app/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a simple demo site</a> of the final working implementation.</p> <p>If I’ve made a mistake or got something wrong at any point during this article then please <a href="#reply-by-email">drop me a message</a> or <a href="https://github.com/harrycresswell/instagram-hugo/pulls" target="_blank" rel="noopener">open a pull request</a>.</p> <h2 id="resources">Resources</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/stevenschobert/instafeed.js" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Instafeed.js</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/companionstudio/instagram-token-agent" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Instagram Token Agent</a></li> <li><a href="https://codepen.io/joosts/pen/bGBByOo" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced Instagram Feed (using PPI Loader)</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.usecue.com/blog/instagram-on-your-website/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Instagram on your website</a></li> <li><a href="https://profilepageimages.usecue.com/documentation" target="_blank" rel="noopener">PPI documentation</a></li> </ul>

item.title: Hugo and redirects
item.content:encoded: <p>With Hugo websites, the URL path of your pages mirrors the directory structure of your content folder. So when you make changes to where your markdown files live – let’s say by moving files to a subdirectory of the content folder – then you can expect the URL path for each piece of content to change too.</p> <p>A few days ago I did exactly this and moved all articles on this site from <code>./content/articles</code> to <code>/content/writing</code>. I did the same for <code>./content/notes</code>. The process was as simple as dragging all the markdown files from the original directory into a new one. It took less than a minute.</p> <p>Here’s what those paths looked like before the change, versus what they look like now.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>https://harrycresswell.com/articles/some-content // old path https://harrycresswell.com/notes/some-content // old path https://harrycresswell.com/writing/some-content // new path </code></pre><p>Although it’s easy to move content around in Hugo websites, before you do it’s worth considering the impact these changes will have. Arguably the most important thing to understand is that any change you make to a URL path will have a serious impact on both how your content appears in search results and backlinks to your content from other websites.</p> <h2 id="the-impact-of-url-changes-to-search-results-and-backlinks">The impact of URL changes to search results and backlinks</h2> <p>Let’s assume a search engine hasn’t had time to reindex your website since you made changes to the structure of your content. This is highly likely as you can’t predict when it will crawl your website, unless you manually tell it to.</p> <p>In this case your content will display in search results as you might expect, however if someone clicks on the link they’ll most likely find themselves staring at a 404 error page. This is because the browser is still pointing to the old path, rather than the new one. The link breaks as the browser is unaware of the changes you’ve made. It will remain this way until it reindexes your website. And that’s a real problem.</p> <p>Now consider the impact on backlinks. Unlike with search engines which will eventually re-crawl your website, with backlinks it’s impossible for a bot to tell every single website that links to your site that the URL paths have changed.</p> <p>So once you make the changes to the URL path, any pre-existing link to your content from another website will break and remain broken, effectively forever. You’d have to know about every single link to the content in question, then contact the admin of each website and ask them to manually update the link to the new URL path. Hardly realistic.</p> <p>Avoiding both these issues is simple. You can set up permanent redirects to tell the browser what to do when it tries to reach a dead link that no longer exists. In most cases, setting up redirects will take you less than 5 minutes. However there are a few different approaches to consider.</p> <p>What follows is my research into setting up redirects with Hugo and the approach I ended up using on this site.</p> <h2 id="hugo-aliases-or-netlify-redirects">Hugo Aliases or Netlify Redirects</h2> <p>If your site is built with Hugo then you might consider using <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/urls/#aliases" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo Aliases</a>. For those using Netlify, you have the option of <a href="https://docs.netlify.com/routing/redirects/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Netlify Redirects</a>. Both these approaches pretty much do the same thing, but there are some caveats.</p> <p>As <a href="https://discourse.gohugo.io/t/hugo-aliases-vs-netlify-redirect/19364/3?u=harrycresswell" target="_blank" rel="noopener">David points out on the Hugo Discourse</a>:</p> <blockquote> <p>Netlify redirects are redirects via header, Hugo redirects load the page first, then the page redirects. So you should always use Netlify redirects if you can, they will save some milliseconds.</p> </blockquote> <p>That being said, if you don’t use Netlify or think you might move away from their service in the future, then Hugo Aliases might be the better option as they are part of your website project and not dependent on Netlify.</p> <p>I’m currently using Netlify Redirects for the reasons David mentions.</p> <p>Next we have two more options.</p> <h2 id="_redirects-file-or-redirects-inside-netlifytoml">_redirects file or redirects inside netlify.toml</h2> <p>You can choose to either set up a <code>_redirects</code> file in the static folder of your Hugo project, so it’s passed through to the public folder when deploying. As Netlify point out, <a href="https://docs.netlify.com/routing/redirects/#syntax-for-the-redirects-file" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the _redirects file should end up in the folder you’re deploying</a>.</p> <p>Alternatively you might decide to add the redirects to a <a href="https://docs.netlify.com/configure-builds/file-based-configuration/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">netlify.toml</a> configuration file at the root of your project.</p> <p>Both approaches will result in the same outcome. However the benefit of the first option is that it’s portable and recognised outside of the Netlify ecosystem. This would make life much easier if you ever decide to move away from Netlify.</p> <p>The downside is you can’t configure quite as much as you can inside your <code>netlify.toml</code>. In my case I don’t need to do much more than the very basics. I know I can do everything I need to do with a <code>_redirects</code> file, so I decided to go with that.</p> <h2 id="understanding-the-_redirects-file-syntax">Understanding the _redirects file syntax</h2> <p>Ok, so here’s my <code>_redirects</code> file.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>/articles/* /writing/:splat 301 /notes/* /writing/:splat 301 /tags/* /topics/:splat 301 </code></pre><p>To break this down, picture the redirects above as a table. What follows will make more sense if you do.</p> <ul> <li>The first column (left) is the <em>from</em> rule, or the path you want to redirect.</li> <li>The second column (middle) is the <em>to</em> rule. In other words, the URL or path you want to redirect to.</li> <li>The third and final (right) column is the <em>status</em> rule, consisting of what’s called an <a href="https://docs.netlify.com/routing/redirects/redirect-options/#http-status-codes" target="_blank" rel="noopener">HTTP status code</a>. There are quite a few status codes you can use, but for now we’re interested in the 301 status. 301 stands for a permanent redirect. It tells the client (browser) that the address for this resource has permanently changed and the URL in the browser will show the new address.</li> </ul> <p>So what’s the asterisk (<code>*</code>) and <code>:splat</code> flag about?</p> <p>The asterisk will redirect all paths found inside the folder it follows. So in the case of <code>/articles/*</code> that’s all paths under <code>/articles/</code>. Just like the CSS * selector selects all elements.</p> <p><code>:splat</code> specifies the new path for all the content. In other words, it tells the browser to use the existing URL or slug (if you prefer), and just change the directory from <code>/articles/</code> directory to <code>/writing/</code>.</p> <p>As I mentioned earlier, make sure you put your <code>_redirects</code> file in your static folder. This is really important. That way, when you run the <code>hugo</code> build command, Hugo will copy the file over to the public folder and your redirects file will find itself at the root of your live site when you deploy. If it’s not, then your redirects won’t work.</p> <h2 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping up</h2> <p>Set up redirects when you want to make changes to your content structure without losing the integrity of the links to your content from around the web.</p> <p>With Hugo sites you have the option of using Hugo Aliases, but if you use Netlify to host and deploy your website, then it seems like Netlify Redirects is the more favoured approach.</p> <p>Setting up a <code>_redirects</code> file in the static folder is the most portable approach, however you’ll have more configuration options if you set up your redirects in a <code>netlify.toml</code> file at the root of your project.</p> <p>If the changes you’re making to your URL paths aren’t intended to be temporary, then make sure you use the 301 status for all your redirects. 301 stands for permanent redirect and will tell browsers that the changes are indeed permanent.</p> <p>All this can be done very quickly (5 mins or so), so it’s well worth doing to avoid any broken links you might encounter and maintain an optimal experience for those discovering and reading your content.</p> <h2 id="resources">Resources</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/urls/#aliases" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo Aliases</a></li> <li><a href="https://docs.netlify.com/routing/redirects/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Redirects with Netlify</a></li> <li><a href="https://docs.netlify.com/routing/redirects/redirect-options/#splats" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Using Splats to catch all cases</a></li> </ul>

item.title: Working with data which doesn’t require a page
item.content:encoded: <p class="intro"> You wont always want Hugo to generate a page for all your content. Here we look at what to do with content that doesn’t require a page, and how to display it on a list page. </p> <p>Hugo will create a standalone page for every markdown file you store in the content folder. Most of the time this is what you’ll want. But there are times when you need to display data that doesn’t require a dedicated page.</p> <p>For example, let’s say you want to display a list of projects in your list template. Where each project consists of a title, description and link to an external source on the web. There’s no long form content associated with these projects and they don’t need their own page, as the link takes you somewhere else on the web.</p> <p>So where do you put this type of data?</p> <p>You might think to put it in the front matter of a markdown file in the content folder. But then Hugo will generate a new page for each file and that’s not what you want.</p> <p>The data folder helps solve this problem.</p> <h2 id="the-data-folder">The data folder</h2> <p>Hugo won’t generate standalone pages for any data stored in <a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/data-templates/#the-data-folder" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the data folder</a>. So if your custom data doesn’t require it’s own page, then make sure you add it to the data folder.</p> <p>Let’s look at this in practice.</p> <p>Inside my data folder I have a file called <code>projects.yaml</code> which looks like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl">- <span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Type Services&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">description</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;A type foundry I set up in 2017 with a focus on hand drawn type and imperfection in type design.&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">link</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;https://typeservices.co/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span>- <span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Mood&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">description</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;A visual aid for creative projects – a moodboard of things I like. None of the content is my own. Built with Hugo, hosted with Netlify.&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">link</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;https://mood.harrycresswell.com/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span>- <span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Dark Sky&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">description</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;An electronic music project by Matt Benyayer. Since 2012 we’ve collaborated on artwork for most of Matts releases. You’ll find the music and artwork on my [Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/harrycresswell) page.&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">link</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;https://soundcloud.com/dark-sky&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>The file consists of a list of projects. Each project has a title, a brief description and a link to an external source where the project is hosted.</p> <p>For these projects, I don’t want a single page for each project as it will skew my site map with a bunch of empty pages. What I actually want to do is render the title and description for each project on my list page, along with the external link to the project.</p> <p>From within <code>layouts/_default/list.html</code> I loop through the data in the <code>projects.yaml</code> file and return the title, link and description for each project.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Data</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">projects</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">article</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h3</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">a</span> <span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .link }}&#34;</span> <span class="nx">target</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;_blank&#34;</span> <span class="nx">rel</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;noopener noreferrer&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h3</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">p</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">description</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">markdownify</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">article</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In Hugo we can do this using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/range/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Range</a> function, which is essentially the same as using a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/For_loop" target="_blank" rel="noopener">for loop</a> in other languages</p> <p>Don’t forget to close all functions using <code>{{ end }}</code>.</p> <p>Finally, I wrap the range in an if statement, using the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/eq/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">eq function</a> to target <code>.Type &quot;projects&quot;</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nx">eq</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Type</span> <span class="s">&#34;projects&#34;</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Data</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">projects</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">article</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h3</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">a</span> <span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .link }}&#34;</span> <span class="nx">target</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;_blank&#34;</span> <span class="nx">rel</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;noopener nofollow&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h3</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">p</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">description</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">markdownify</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">article</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now I can control which pages display my projects data by adding <code>type: projects</code> to the front matter of the page. In other words, what we’re saying here is;</p> <blockquote> <p>If <code>type: projects</code> exists in the front matter of a page, then render the data.</p> </blockquote> <p>Finally, I add this to the front matter of a page called <code>projects.md</code> in the content folder. This page uses the default list template, so my projects render on the page.</p> <h2 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping up</h2> <p>Rememeber, the data folder is the place to store data which doesn’t require a standalone page. Don’t add this type of data to the content folder, unless you want Hugo to generate a page for it. Hugo will create a page for all markdown files stored in the content folder.</p> <h2 id="further-reading">Further reading</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://harrycresswell.com/articles/passing-data-to-templates-hugo/">Passing data to templates and tables in Hugo</a></li> <li><a href="https://harrycresswell.com/articles/data-hugo/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Working with Data in Hugo</a></li> </ul>

item.title: Extending the Sanity Eleventy Blog Starter
Fixing breaking changes when upgrading Hugo
item.content:encoded: <p>Unless you want to use new features, or you’re working on a Hugo project built with a newer version, then it’s not absolutely necessary to upgrade your version of Hugo. You can run an old version of Hugo and everything will continue to work just fine.</p> <p>However, if you do find yourself needing or wanted to upgrade Hugo, then you’re probably wondering if anything is going to break in your existing projects when you upgrade to the latest version. It’s a reasonable concern.</p> <p>Last week I upgraded my Hugo version from <a href="https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/releases/tag/v0.55.6" target="_blank" rel="noopener">0.55.6</a> to Hugo <a href="https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/releases/tag/v0.80.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener">0.80</a>. I sort of expected everything to break, so I had a contingency plan in the form of <a href="https://www.fernandomc.com/posts/brew-install-legacy-hugo-site-generator/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Fernando Medina Corey’s article on using legacy versions</a>. But to my surprise, after the upgrade I was pleased to find very few errors.</p> <p>The main issue - which seems like a common one - concerns content from sections not rendering on a homepage. To be clear, what I mean by section content is content stored in a sub directory of the content directory. For example, <code>./content/supplier</code>.</p> <p>To render section specific content on a homepage in the past you might have nested a where clause in your range. Something like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-golang" data-lang="golang"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">where</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Pages</span> <span class="s">&#34;Type&#34;</span> <span class="s">&#34;supplier&#34;</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">first</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Content</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>But with Hugo 0.80 this no longer works.</p> <p>The easiest way to fix this (in plain english) is as follows:</p> <ul> <li>Add any sections you want to range over as Params in the config file, <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/where/#mainsections" target="_blank" rel="noopener">as explained here</a>.</li> <li>Then use <code>site.RegularPages</code> instead of <code>.Pages</code> , <a href="https://discourse.gohugo.io/t/pagination-doesnt-work-after-hugo-update-after-a-few-months/21332/2" target="_blank" rel="noopener">as Zachary Betz alludes suggests</a>.</li> <li>And move your <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/where/#nest-where-clauses" target="_blank" rel="noopener">nested where clause</a> from the range function into a variable. You can then range over the variable, applying any filters you might need.</li> </ul> <p>In Go templating that will look something like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-golang" data-lang="golang"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">pages</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">where</span> <span class="nx">site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">RegularPages</span> <span class="s">&#34;Type&#34;</span> <span class="s">&#34;in&#34;</span> <span class="nx">site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Params</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">supplierSection</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">pages</span> <span class="p">|</span> <span class="nx">first</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Content</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>If it wasn’t clear from this example, you can assign your section to any variable name you like in your config file. It doesn’t have to be in the <code>mainSections</code> array as suggested in the Hugo docs. Consider the below example.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-jsx" data-lang="jsx"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">//config.toml </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">params</span><span class="p">];</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">mainSections</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">&#34;blog&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">&#34;docs&#34;</span><span class="p">];</span> <span class="c1">// use an array as suggested in the Hugo docs </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="nx">supplierSection</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;supplier&#34;</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="c1">// this also works great </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="nx">interviewSection</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;interview&#34;</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="c1">// as does this </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>If you have a few different sections and don’t want to combine content from both sections into one array to range over, then the second option is probably the best way to go.</p> <p>I had similar issue on another project which involved paginating through pages in a section from on the homepage.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-golang" data-lang="golang"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">paginator</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nf">Paginate</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">where</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Pages</span> <span class="s">&#34;Type&#34;</span> <span class="s">&#34;writing&#34;</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="mi">6</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">ul</span> <span class="nx">class</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;PostList&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="p">(.</span><span class="nx">Paginator</span> <span class="mi">6</span><span class="p">).</span><span class="nx">Pages</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">partial</span> <span class="s">&#34;post-list-item.html&#34;</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">partial</span> <span class="s">&#34;pagination.html&#34;</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The fix was almost identical as before. But this time passing the <code>$pages</code> variable to <code>.Paginate</code> function stored in a second variable called <code>$paginator</code> and ranging over that instead.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-golang" data-lang="golang"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">pages</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">where</span> <span class="nx">site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">RegularPages</span> <span class="s">&#34;Type&#34;</span> <span class="s">&#34;in&#34;</span> <span class="nx">site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Params</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">mainSections</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">paginator</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Paginate</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">pages</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">ul</span> <span class="nx">class</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;PostList&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="err">$</span><span class="nx">paginator</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Pages</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">partial</span> <span class="s">&#34;post-list-item.html&#34;</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">ul</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">partial</span> <span class="s">&#34;pagination.html&#34;</span> <span class="p">.</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>It’s worth noting if you’re using pagination on a list page everything should still work as normal but if it’s not then it’s probably an issue with <code>.Pages</code> vs <code>.RegularPages</code>, as explained in <a href="https://github.com/gohugoio/hugoThemes/issues/682#issue-481516283" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Alexandros’s comment</a> about this.</p> <p>I’ll return to this article to document any errors I get the next time I upgrade, but that’s all for now.</p> <h2 id="further-reading">Further reading</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/where/#nest-where-clauses" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Nested where clauses</a></li> <li><a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/where/#mainsections" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Portable where filters</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/gohugoio/hugoThemes/issues/682" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Demos with empty homepage and/or wrong posts list</a></li> <li><a href="https://discourse.gohugo.io/t/pagination-doesnt-work-after-hugo-update-after-a-few-months/21332" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Pagination doesn’t work after Hugo update</a></li> </ul>

item.title: JavaScript and the DOM: Adding and removing classes
item.content:encoded: <p><em>This is a quick look at JavaScript interaction based on my notes from Beginner JavaScript by Wes Bos</em></p> <p>In our html we have an image element with a class attached to it. This could be any element but for the sake of this demonstration we’ll use an image.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;picture&#34;</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://picsum.photos/600&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In our JavaScript file we can get hold of the image by the class name using the <code>querySelector</code> method on our document.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-JavaScript" data-lang="JavaScript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">pic</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelector</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;.picture&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next we can log a DOM token list to the console with:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-JavaScript" data-lang="JavaScript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Open up the console and you should see the DOMTokenList:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-JavaScript" data-lang="JavaScript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">DOMTokenList</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">&#34;picture&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">value</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;picture&#34;</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="mi">0</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;picture&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">length</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">value</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;picture&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">__proto__</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">DOMTokenList</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The DOMTokenList is essentially just an array of all the classes on the element.</p> <p>Let’s add one more class called 600:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;picture 600&#34;</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://picsum.photos/600&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now the DOMTokenList is updated to include our new class:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-JavaScript" data-lang="JavaScript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">DOMTokenList</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">&#34;picture&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">&#34;600&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">value</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;picture 600&#34;</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="mi">0</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;picture&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="mi">1</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;600&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">length</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="mi">2</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">value</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;picture 600&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">__proto__</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">DOMTokenList</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>If you look inside <code>__proto__</code> you will see all the methods we can use on the DOMTokenList.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-JavaScript" data-lang="JavaScript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">__proto__</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">DOMTokenList</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">add</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">add</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">contains</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">contains</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">entries</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">entries</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">forEach</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">forEach</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">item</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">item</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">keys</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">keys</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">length</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">(...)</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">remove</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">remove</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">replace</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">replace</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">supports</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">supports</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toString</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">toString</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggle</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">toggle</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">value</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">(...)</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">values</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">values</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">constructor</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">DOMTokenList</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">Symbol</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">Symbol</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">iterator</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">values</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">Symbol</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">Symbol</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">toStringTag</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;DOMTokenList&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">get</span> <span class="nx">length</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">length</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">get</span> <span class="nx">value</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">value</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">set</span> <span class="nx">value</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">ƒ</span> <span class="nx">value</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">__proto__</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nb">Object</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Two of which are <code>add</code> and <code>remove</code>, which we can use to add and remove classes from our elements.</p> <p>Let’s add a class called “open”.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-JavaScript" data-lang="JavaScript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">pic</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelector</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;.picture&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;open&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Then remove the class called “600” which we added manually:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-JavaScript" data-lang="JavaScript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">pic</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelector</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;.picture&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;open&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">remove</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;600&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now let’s add some CSS so we can visually see what’s going on when we add or remove a class.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-css" data-lang="css"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">round</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">border-radius</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">50</span><span class="kt">%</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now back in our JavaScript:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-JavaScript" data-lang="JavaScript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">pic</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelector</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;.picture&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;open&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">remove</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;600&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;round&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now when we run our code the new round class is added and we can see the image change to round.</p> <p>Next we can add some animation:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-css" data-lang="css"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nt">img</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">transition</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">all</span> <span class="mf">0.2</span><span class="kt">s</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Add try the toggle method instead:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-JavaScript" data-lang="JavaScript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">pic</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelector</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;.picture&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;open&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">remove</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;600&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">toggle</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;round&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now whenever we run the code the class is removed if it exists and it is added if it doesn&rsquo;t.</p> <p>We could improve on this still by listening for a click event, and toggling the class when that happens.</p> <p>First create a function for our toggle:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-JavaScript" data-lang="JavaScript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">function</span> <span class="nx">toggleRound</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">toggle</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;round&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Then add the event listener and pass in the function:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-JavaScript" data-lang="JavaScript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">addEventListener</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;click&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">toggleRound</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Our final code will look like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-JavaScript" data-lang="JavaScript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">pic</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelector</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;.picture&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">function</span> <span class="nx">toggleRound</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">classList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">toggle</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;round&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">pic</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">addEventListener</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;click&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">toggleRound</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now anytime we click the image, our function will run.</p> <h2 id="summary">Summary</h2> <p>A lot of interaction in JavaScript is simply adding and removing classes, then using CSS to create various styles and transitions.</p> <p>If you haven’t taken Wes Bos’s Beginner JavaScript course go take it!</p>

item.title: Accessing HTML data attributes in JavaScript with dataSet
item.content:encoded: <p>You can easily add custom data to any HTML element using custom data attributes.</p> <p>Data attributes can be anything you like as long as you prefix your custom attribute with <code>data-</code>.</p> <p>As per the MDN web docs:</p> <blockquote> <p>“It must contain only letters, numbers, and the following characters: dash (-), dot (.), colon (:), underscore (_)—but NOT any ASCII capital letters (A to Z).”</p> </blockquote> <p>For example, say we have multiple images and we want to add some data to label their position in a slideshow, we could create a ‘position’ attribute like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image-1&#34;</span> <span class="na">data-position</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;1&#34;</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image-1.jpg&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image-2&#34;</span> <span class="na">data-position</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;2&#34;</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image-1.jpg&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image-3&#34;</span> <span class="na">data-position</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;3&#34;</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;image-1.jpg&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In our JavaScript we can use <code>dataset</code> to either get the data property or set the data property.</p> <p>Dataset returns an object containing all the property values on an element.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// Get the element </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">element</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelector</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&#34;.image-1&#34;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// Log position of the element </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">element</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">dataset</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In JavaScript the naming convention is converted from kebab-case to camelCase. In other words, any dashes in your attribute names will be converted to camelCase</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// Get attribute called “data-first-name“ </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">element</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">dataset</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">firstName</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Setting a data attribute value is very similar.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// Set value to something new </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="nx">element</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">dataset</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">firstName</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Harry&#34;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The data attribute of the element would now look like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">div</span> <span class="na">data-first-name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Harry&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="summary">Summary</h2> <p>Dataset is useful when you need to work with custom data attributes.</p> <h2 id="resources">Resources</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLOrForeignElement/dataset" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Mozilla Docs - dataSet</a></li> </ul>

item.title: Chasing the hype
item.content:encoded: <blockquote> <p>“There is no such thing as normal. Things change. People adapt. Everything is relative to everything else&hellip; There is no definitive list of skills to have. There is no mandatory technologies to look for. You don’t have to keep chasing the hype. At the end of the day, knowing HTML, CSS and some JavaScript should be enough to make do.“</p> </blockquote> <p><a href="https://css-tricks.com/there-is-no-normal/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">There is no normal</a> by Hugo Giraudel really resonated with me.</p> <p>For too long I felt I had to learn a JavaScript framework like React, because it’s what was expected of me. When all your LinkedIn messages are from recruiters looking for a React developer, it starts to feel like the only way to make it is to get on board.</p> <p>So I tried it for a while and now I know enough to build a site with Gatsby, or whatever. But that’s probably as far as I’ll take it. The thing is, I just don’t love writing React.</p> <p>In actual fact, I much prefer writing HTML, CSS and JavaScript the “traditional” way. So that’s what I spend the majority of my time doing. But it took a while to feel comfortable with that, because in the back of you’re mind you’re always thinking&hellip;</p> <blockquote> <p>“If I want to get anywhere as a web developer I really need to learn framework X”.</p> </blockquote> <p>Listen. You really don’t need to learn any frameworks to be a great developer.</p> <p>It’s perfectly ok to follow your interests and ignore what’s hot. There’s still plenty of work out there that doesn’t involve React or getting hired via LinkedIn for that matter.</p> <p>Just do good work and stop chasing the hype.</p>

item.title: Building a dynamic navigation component with Gatsby and Sanity
item.content:encoded: <p>In a previous post I wrote about <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/articles/sanity-building-naigation-schema/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">building a navigation schema in Sanity</a>.</p> <p>In this one we’ll look at how to query the data from the schema we created in that post and render it inside a React component, using the popular static site generator Gatsby. If you haven’t done so already, then head back and read the previous article to build out your schema, before continuing with this one.</p> <p>Styling the navigation falls outside the scope of the article, but I might cover it in a later one. Instead, our primary concern is learning how to consume the data we’ve added to Sanity Studio and render it in a Gatsby powered website.</p> <p>Before we begin it’s worth mentioning exactly what I mean when I say “dynamic navigation”. A dynamic navigation in this case is essentially just a list of links which haven’t been hard coded directly into the component. Instead, a content admin will have the power to make changes to the navigation on the front-end via Sanity studio, just like any other piece of content. And they can do this whenever they like, adding and removing links as they wish.</p> <p>Ok, let’s get going.</p> <h2 id="where-were-at-with-sanity-and-gatsby">Where we’re at with Sanity and Gatsby</h2> <p>I assume you already have a Gatsby project set up and you have the <a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.com/plugins/gatsby-source-sanity/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">gatsby-source-sanity</a> installed. If you haven’t done this yet you can find out how to do it in <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/notes/new-gatsby-site-sanity-cms/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Setting up a Gatsby project with Sanity</a>.</p> <p>At this point you should also have a Sanity studio project set up, if you haven’t head over to <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/notes/new-sanity-project/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Starting a new Sanity project</a> for more.</p> <p>Finally, make sure you <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/articles/sanity-building-naigation-schema/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">create your navigation schema in Sanity</a> before continuing, without it you’ll struggle to make progress.</p> <h2 id="adding-navigation-content-in-sanity-studio">Adding navigation content in Sanity Studio</h2> <p>The first thing we need to do is add some data in Sanity using our new navigation schema. That way we’ll have some data to consume in our Gatsby website. We’re going to create two navigations; one to dislay in the header of our website and one to display in the footer.</p> <p>If everything is set up as per <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/articles/sanity-building-naigation-schema/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the previous article</a> then you should see ‘Navigation‘ listed in the content panel on the left hand side of your Sanity project.</p> <p>Inside the Navigation content type, create a new naviation by clicking the plus button to the right of the title in the middle column.</p> <p>Give your new navigation a <em>name</em> and an <em>id</em>. Make sure you create a memorable name. I’ll use ‘Header nav’ and make sure the <em>id</em> reflects the name. Your <em>id</em> should be lowercase with words separated by a dash. For example, <code>header-nav</code>.</p> <p>Now we’re ready to add some navigation items. Add the <em>text</em> you want to show as the link on the front-end and the <em>link url</em> to the page. If it’s not entirely obvious the <em>link url</em> is the URL you want to link the text to. Be sure to check ‘Content is from an external source’ if the page is external. In other words, if it’s not a page on your Gatsby site.</p> <p>Once you are happy with your navigation items hit publish to save your new navigation.</p> <p>Now follow the exact same steps to create your footer navigation. Replacing “Header” in the name and id with ”Footer”.</p> <h2 id="deploy-the-graphql-api">Deploy the graphQL API</h2> <p>Once you’ve added your navigation content to Sanity you’ll need to deploy the GraphQL API.
