And one I’ve started to use with more conscious attention is called <em>implementation intentions</em>.</p> <h2 id="implementation-intentions">Implementation Intentions</h2> <p>In research conducted by psychologist Peter Gollwitzer on goal striving, results showed that by assigning specific situational cues to a goal – a strategy know as ”implementation intentions” – you enhance the rate of goal attainment.</p> <p>Implementation intentions uses something called the ”goal-specificity effect”, which shows that a person will perform better when set goals are challenging and specific, compared to those that are challenging but vague.</p> <p>In other words, you’re more likely to act on your intentions, <em>if</em> you form a concrete plan involving specific situational cues. These situational cues define the <em>when</em>, <em>where</em>, and <em>how</em> you plan to act on your intentions.</p> <p>Peter Gollwitzer calls this an “if-then plan”; where you select an “if” cue, that’s linked to a “then” response.</p> <p>With this idea in mind, let’s look at a few examples.</p> <h2 id="implementation-intentions-in-action">Implementation intentions in action</h2> <p>Say your goal is to <em>write a book</em>. To achieve your goal you might decide to <em>build a daily writing habit</em>. Makes sense. It’s less intimidating to focus on a regular commitment, than fixating on an end goal, which feels impossible to achieve.</p> <p>To build your daily writing habit, you might employ an “if-then plan,” to increase your chances of staying committed and achieving your goal.</p> <p>Your ”if-then plan” may look something like this:</p> <blockquote> <p><em>If</em> the time is 6 am, <em>then</em> I will sit down to write in the study.</p> </blockquote> <p>In this case, 6 am is the <em>cue</em>, which prompts a <em>response</em> – sitting down to write in the study.</p> <p>Let’s take a look at another example.</p> <p>This time, lets say your goal is to run a marathon. To help you schedule your training and stay committed, again, you might use an ”if-then plan”.</p> <blockquote> <p><em>If</em> the time is 8 am, <em>then</em> I will put on my running gear and go for a run outside.</p> </blockquote> <p>By defining the when, where, and how you want to act on your goal intentions, you affirm a concrete strategy to make your goals more attainable and your behaviour easier to stick with.</p> <p>Now let’s look at a slightly different formula for applying implementation intentions.</p> <h2 id="a-simple-formula-for-implementation-intentions">A simple formula for implementation intentions</h2> <p>In his book Atomic Habits, James Clear suggests that an implementation intention is ”a plan you make beforehand about when and where to act. That is, how you <em>intend to implement</em> a particular habit.”</p> <p>James’ formula for creating implementation intentions makes use of two of the most common cues that help trigger a habit; <em>time</em> and <em>location</em>.</p> <p>The formula looks like this:</p> <blockquote> <p>I will [BEHAVIOUR] at [TIME] in [LOCATION].</p> </blockquote> <p>This is a simple, easy to remember way of expressing our “if-then plan”. So let’s revisit our previous example for absolute clarity, but this time apply James’ formula instead.</p> <blockquote> <p>I will write at 6 am in the study.</p> </blockquote> <p>In this case, <em>write</em> is our chosen behaviour. It defines <em>how</em> we will act. The time <em>6 am</em> specifies ‘when’ we will act. And <em>the study</em> provides a location. It clarifies ’where’ we will act.</p> <p>What I like most about James’ formula is that it makes it so simple and clear. It literally spells it out for you and makes your commitment feel so easy to accomplish.</p> <p>But ‘feeling easy’ isn’t exactly a great explanation for why implementation intentions work. So now, let’s put these fomulas to one side, and talk about at what make this strategy such a powerful tool for goal attainment.</p> <h2 id="why-implementation-intentions-work">Why implementation intentions work</h2> <p>By defining a concrete plan of when, where, and how to act, you improve your mental representation of a situation, making it highly active and accessible.</p> <p>In other words, by using cues to trigger your actions, you improve your perception, attention and memory concerning the situation. You create a strong associative link between a cue and the response, making your behaviour more likely to occur in the given situation.</p> <p>This associative link helps make your behaviour automatic and you begin to perform your actions with very little conscious effort. Your behaviour becomes subconscious, making it easier to show up and practice often.</p> <p>Without the need for decision making about your next actions, you’re left with plenty of energy for what really matters.</p> <h3 id="keep-in-mind">Keep in mind</h3> <p>Goal attainment is down to having a good strategy.</p> <p>Creating situational cues – for when and where you will act – improves your chances of sticking with your commitments and reaching your goals.</p> <p>Assigning specific cues to a chosen behaviour, creates clarity in your mind and a concrete plan of action. This is a strategy know as <em>implementation intentions</em>.</p> <p>Having a concrete plan for your commitments makes your decision making autonomous. You spend less time thinking about your actions or fixating on the end goal, and more time being productive. You make things easy.</p> <h3 id="further-reading">Further reading</h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://psych.nyu.edu/oettingen/Gollwitzer,%20P.%20M.,%20&amp;%20Oettingen,%20G.%20%282013%29.%20In%20%20M.%20Gellman%20&amp;%20J.%20R.%20Turner%20%28Eds.%29.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Implementation Intentions</a>, Peter M. Gollwitzer and Gabriele Oettingen</li> <li><a href="https://jamesclear.com/implementation-intentions" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Achieve Your Goals</a> from James Clear</li> <li><a href="https://daringtolivefully.com/implementation-intentions" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Key To Goal Success</a> by Marelisa Fabrega</li> <li><a href="https://www.thinkinglifter.com/implementation-intentions/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Implementation Intentions: How to Get Consistent Results</a> Philip Stefanov</li> </ul>

item.title: Understanding JavaScript Arrow Function syntax
item.content:encoded: <p><em>Notes based on <a href="https://beginnerjavascript.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Beginner JavaScript by Wes Bos</a>.</em></p> <p>To get a good grasp of the arrow function syntax, first you need to get an understanding of a few different ways of expressing a function in JavaScript.</p> <h2 id="a-few-ways-to-make-a-function">A few ways to make a function</h2> <p>Understanding these different methods of expressing a function will help you get your head around the newer ES6 Arrow Function syntax.</p> <h3 id="method-1-using-the-function-keyword">Method 1: Using the function keyword</h3> <p>Use the <code>function</code> keyword, followed by the name of the function. In this case the function name is <em>doctorize</em>.</p> <p>Next set a parameter. That’s the placeholder for whatever data you want to pass into your function. In this case <em>firstname</em>.</p> <p>Finally use a <code>return</code> statement to return the data however you wish.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">function</span> <span class="nx">doctorize</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">firstname</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="sb">`Dr. </span><span class="si">${</span><span class="nx">firstname</span><span class="si">}</span><span class="sb">`</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>That’s using the function keyword.</p> <h3 id="method-2-anonymous-functions">Method 2: Anonymous functions</h3> <p>An anonymous function is simple a function without a name.</p> <p>An anonymous functions isn’t valid JavaScript in it’s own right. However, there are certain ways of using anonymous functions which makes them valid. Such as in callback functions.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">function</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">firstname</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="sb">`Dr. </span><span class="si">${</span><span class="nx">firstname</span><span class="si">}</span><span class="sb">`</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>That’s declaring an anonymous function.</p> <h3 id="method-3-function-expressions">Method 3: Function expressions</h3> <p>A function expression is when you store a function as a value in a variable.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">doctorize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">firstname</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="sb">`Dr. </span><span class="si">${</span><span class="nx">firstname</span><span class="si">}</span><span class="sb">`</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">};</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>All we’re doing here is taking an anonymous function and sticking it into a variable. Although this is technically still an anonymous function, the browser will use the variable name as the name of the function.</p> <p>When you hear someone say “functions are first class citizens”, what they really mean is that you can store functions as variables.</p> <p>Function expressions differ from functions created with the function keyword in that the aren’t hoisted.</p> <p>Functions created with the function keyword are ‘hoisted’ to the top of the document, which allows you to call the function from anywhere in your document. This isn’ true for function expressions which are <em>not</em> hoisted.</p> <p>Now let’s look at arrow functions.</p> <h2 id="arrow-functions">Arrow functions</h2> <p>Arrow functions offer a concise syntax. They also don’t have their own scope, in reference to the <code>this</code> keyword. Arrow functions are anonymous functions.</p> <p>These are the steps to create an arrow function:</p> <h3 id="step-1-take-a-regular-function">Step 1: Take a regular function</h3> <p>Here’s a regular function.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">function</span> <span class="nx">inchToCM</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">inches</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">cm</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">inches</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mf">2.54</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="nx">cm</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>4 lines of code?! Bit lengthy.</p> <h3 id="step-2-return-the-value-itself">Step 2: Return the value itself</h3> <p>To make the function shorter you can return the value instead.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">function</span> <span class="nx">inchToCM</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">inches</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="nx">inches</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mf">2.54</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="step-3-convert-it-to-an-anonymous-function">Step 3: Convert it to an anonymous function</h3> <p>To convert the function to an anonymous function we remove the function name and store it in a variable. Now we have a function expression.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">inchToCM</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">inches</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="nx">inches</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mf">2.54</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">};</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="step-4-convert-to-an-arrow-function">Step 4: Convert to an arrow function</h3> <p>Now delete the function keyword, because it’s long and we don’t like that. Then add a fat arrow.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">inchToCM</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">inches</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="nx">inches</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mf">2.54</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">};</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="step-5-switch-from-explicit-to-implicit-return">Step 5: Switch from explicit to implicit return</h3> <p>Move the function to 1 line.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">inchToCM</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">inches</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="nx">inches</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mf">2.54</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">};</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Delete the curly brackets.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">inchToCM</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">inches</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="nx">inches</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mf">2.54</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Then remove the <code>return</code> keyword.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">inchToCM</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">inches</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> <span class="nx">inches</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mf">2.54</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now we’ve totally removed the function block. However this is optional.</p> <p>If there is only one parameter, you can also remove the parentheses.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">inchToCM</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">inches</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> <span class="nx">inches</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mf">2.54</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now we have an arrow function.</p> <p>Keep in mind, you will have to keep the parentheses if you have more than one parameter.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// ✅ will work! </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">add</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">b</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> <span class="nx">a</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nx">b</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// ⛔️ won’t work! </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">add</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">b</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">3</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> <span class="nx">a</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nx">b</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div>

item.title: Understanding data types: boolean and equality
item.content:encoded: <p><em>These notes are taken from <a href="https://beginnerjavascript.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Beginner JavaScript</a> by Wes Bos. Go buy it!</em></p> <p>A boolean value is either <code>true</code> or <code>false</code>. Like a light switch it’s either on or off.</p> <p>Booleans are used for logic, such as if statements. They can be calculated or manually set.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">isDrawing</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">false</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In this case we have a manually set flag variable which might describe the users actions on a page.</p> <p>We can also calculate booleans:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// set the age </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">age</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">18</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// age is greater than 19 </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">ofAge</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">age</span> <span class="o">&gt;</span> <span class="mi">19</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// returns boolean value of false </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">ofAge</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="understanding-equality">Understanding equality</h2> <p>We use one equal sign operator (=) to set a variable.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">age</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>We also have double equals (<mark>) and triple equals (</mark>=). But, what’s the difference? And which one should we use?</p> <p>Double equals (==) checks the value of the left and right are the same. However it will ignore differences in type.</p> <p>Take this example. Both left and right values equal 10, however even though the left value is of type string and the right is a number it still returns <code>true</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s2">&#34;10&#34;</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kc">true</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In contrast, triple equals (===) will always check that both the value <em>and</em> the type of the left and right equal the same</p> <p>The example below returns <code>true</code> as the value of the left and right is 10. And both data types are the same. In this case they are both numbers.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="mi">10</span> <span class="o">===</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kc">true</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next take the following example:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="s2">&#34;10&#34;</span> <span class="o">===</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kc">false</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Here the values are the same, but the types differ. The left is a string and the right is a number. So <code>false</code> is returned.</p> <p>You should almost always use triple equals.</p>

item.title: Formatting dates in Gatsby with GraphQL
item.content:encoded: <p>Perhaps the easiest way to format dates in Gatsby is at query-time using Gatsby’s GraphQL layer.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-graphql" data-lang="graphql"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="py">date</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="py">formatString</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s">&#34;MMMM Do, YYYY&#34;</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="p">}</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p><code>cmd + click</code> on the <code>formatString</code> function in your query to open the schema documentation explorer.</p> <p>You’ll see the date is formatted using Moment.js date tokens.</p> <p>Head to <a href="https://momentjs.com/docs/#/displaying/format/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the MomentJS docs</a> to see the various format options.</p> <p>For a current project I’m using a fairly minimal config.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-graphql" data-lang="graphql"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="py">date</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="py">formatString</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s">&#34;DD MMM&#34;</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="p">}</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>Which prints out something along the lines of:</p> <p><code>25 Jul</code>.</p> <h2 id="adding-the-time">Adding the time</h2> <p>For another project I needed to grab the time, not just the date.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-graphql" data-lang="graphql"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="py">date</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="py">formatString</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s">&#34;dddd MMMM Do, YYYY hh:mma&#34;</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="p">}</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>This returns something along the lines of:</p> <p><code>Thursday January 16th, 2020</code></p> <h2 id="further-reading">Further reading</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.org/docs/graphql-concepts/#formatting-dates" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GraphQL Concepts – Formatting dates</a> from Gatsby Docs.</li> <li><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.org/docs/graphql-reference/#format" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GraphQL Reference - Dates</a> from Gatsby Docs.</li> <li><a href="https://momentjs.com/docs/#/displaying/format/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Moment.js Display formats</a></li> </ul>

item.title: Understanding data types: null vs undefined
item.content:encoded: <p><em>These notes are taken from <a href="https://beginnerjavascript.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Beginner JavaScript</a> by Wes Bos. Go buy it!</em></p> <p>There are two ways to express nothing in JavaScript; <code>null</code> and <code>undefined</code>. But how do they differ?</p> <h2 id="understanding-undefined">Understanding undefined</h2> <p>If we create a variable but don’t set anything to it, the value returned will be <code>undefined</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">dog</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">dog</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p><code>undefined</code> is something that has been created, like a variable, but does not yet have a value set to it. In other words, <em>it is not yet defined</em>.</p> <p>The browser sets this missing value to <code>undefined</code> because no value exists and so there is nothing to return.</p> <p>If we then give the variable a value:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">dog</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;snickers&#34;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The browser will return the new value:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">dog</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&#34;snickers&#34;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>And the value is no longer <code>undefined</code>.</p> <h2 id="understanding-null">Understanding null</h2> <p><code>null</code> is a value of nothing that has to be explicitly set before it can be returned as <code>null</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">somethingNull</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">null</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In this case the value is <code>null</code>, unlike our example above which is <code>undefined</code> because it literally has no value.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">let</span> <span class="nx">somethingUndefined</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This example returned <code>undefined</code> as we have yet to give it a value.</p> <h2 id="a-practical-example">A practical example</h2> <p>We can use the example of a mononymous person (someone known by a single name). In this case we’ll use the singer <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cher</a>, who we know only as Cher.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">cher</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">first</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;cher&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">};</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>We don’t know Cher’s last name so <code>.last</code> will return <code>undefined</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">cher</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">last</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kc">undefined</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now on to our example of <code>null</code>.</p> <p>The comedian and illusionist <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teller_%28magician%29" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Teller</a>, the silent half of the duo Penn &amp; Teller, legally changed his original polynym, Raymond Joseph Teller, to the mononym &ldquo;Teller&rdquo; and possesses a United States passport issued in that single name.</p> <p>In JavaScript we can represent his original name like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">teller</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">first</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Raymond&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">last</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Teller&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">};</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>To represent his legally changed polynym we might update the value of <code>last</code> to <code>null</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">teller</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">first</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Teller&#34;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">teller</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">last</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">null</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>That’s it.</p>

item.title: Intentions 2020
item.content:encoded: <p>No unrealistic goals for this year. Instead, all I want to do is outline the things I’m keen to focus regular time and energy on in 2020. I’ve also chosen a set of principles which I plan to use on a daily basis, to help guide my behaviour throughout the year.</p> <p>I’m sure not all this will work out, and I’m ok with that. This exercise is about finding clarity in how I wish to spend my time. It’s a rough plan of action that provides myself with a sense of direction, and ensures I make some progress towards positive long-term results.</p> <p>To kick things off, here are the areas I’ll focus on.</p> <h2 id="client-work">Client Work</h2> <p>Client work is still the source of most of my income and this will stay the same for 2020.</p> <p>This will be the first year working exclusively with JAMStack technology. That means a lot more Hugo, Gatsby, Netlify and Sanity, which I’m pretty excited about. I’m keen to give 11ty a go too. I’ll do my best to record and share what I can.</p> <p>I’m keeping my client list small. Working on longer projects with fewer clients seems to be the sweet spot. It keeps the quality of work high and the stress levels low.</p> <h3 id="in-detail">In Detail</h3> <p>We worked hard on the evolution of <a href="https://indtl.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">In Detail</a> last year. This will continue. We’re launching quite a few changes to the website later this month and plan to focus on three things:</p> <ul> <li>Content creation</li> <li>Client acquisition</li> <li>Marketing funnel</li> </ul> <p>We plan to work on internal tooling to improve the efficiency of our process and spend time working on our inbound marketing strategy. I’m excited to see what else is in store for In Detail this year.</p> <h2 id="learning">Learning</h2> <p>This year I’m allocating specific blocks in my week dedicated to studying and taking courses. Work-related subjects that I’m choosing to focus on are:</p> <ul> <li>Vanilla JavasScript</li> <li>JAMstack</li> <li>IndieWeb</li> <li>Accessibility</li> </ul> <p>New technologies I’m interested in exploring include Svelte, Vue and KeystoneJS.</p> <p>Other non-work related subjects I’m interested in include:</p> <ul> <li>German (I’m on the hunt for an online tutor to supplement my Duolingo practice)</li> <li>Designing variable fonts</li> <li>Generative art / p5.js / Processing</li> <li>Abelton Live</li> </ul> <h2 id="reading">Reading</h2> <p>I’m going to read more books on design in 2020. A few books I’m particularly interested in reading are:</p> <ul> <li>Every Layout by Andy Bell and Haydon Pickering</li> <li>Inclusive Components by Haydon Pickering</li> <li>Ruined by Design by Mike Monteiro</li> </ul> <p>I also have a few on my non-design related list:</p> <ul> <li>Factfulness by Hans Rosling</li> <li>12 Rules for Life by Jordan B. Peterson</li> <li>Future Ethics by Cennydd Bowles</li> </ul> <p>I’d like to read more non-fiction, it’s something I’m not very good at. I promised Rebekka I’ll give Harry Potter a shot (in German) a while back, so it’s time to fulfill that promise.</p> <h2 id="writing">Writing</h2> <p>I didn’t write enough in 2019. I want to change that in 2020 and get back into a daily writing habit. Here are some rough plans for my writing:</p> <ul> <li>Make part of my morning routine</li> <li>Block out at least 1 hour each day</li> <li>Document as I learn new things</li> <li>keep writing simple and concise</li> <li>Avoid long convoluted articles, which are easy to lose interest in</li> <li>Focus on short, insightful reads</li> <li>Break longer articles into a series of shorter posts</li> <li>Consider writing a course (a few people have suggested Hugo might be a good place to start)</li> <li>Share new articles on social media</li> <li>Re-post coding tutorials on dev.to</li> <li>Provide an article image for RSS feeds and social</li> </ul> <h2 id="newsletter">Newsletter</h2> <p>I plan on keeping my newsletter much the same for now. I am keen to work on a microsite that archives past issues. I find myself referring back to old emails often, so this will be a useful tool. I’m sure it might be useful for everyone subscribing too.</p> <p>I’d like to pick up where I left off with the spreadsheet that accompanies the newsletter. The aim is to index all the content into a searchable format. It’s time-consuming to build but will be a powerful addition to the newsletter.</p> <h2 id="health">Health</h2> <p>In 2019 I managed to stick to a regular weekly routine of running, meditation and yoga. I plan to keep this up in 2020, with the addition of a few new plans:</p> <ul> <li>Climb more</li> <li>Get better at batch meal prep</li> <li>Increase my headstand practice to 2min/day</li> <li>Fermentation (I started making my own Sauerkraut last year, which is good fun and much cheaper than buying it)</li> <li>Find a new meditation app (I’ve used Headspace for years so it’s time for a change). Right now I’m trying out Waking Up by Sam Harris and Insight Timer.</li> </ul> <h2 id="travel">Travel</h2> <p>I’m going for 4 countries this year. That’s two on top of the usual (UK and Germany), which will include France and I expect one other (?).</p> <p>Rebekka and I have a few summer road trip ideas. We’re thinking of driving the van either down to the Alps or possibly to Slovenia, Denmark or Sweden. We’re still undecided.</p> <h2 id="networking">Networking</h2> <p>I’d like to make more of an effort to meet up with other designers and developers this year. Finding an interesting Meetup to join is a top priority. I’d also like to make it to an industry conference. I’ve not done much of this in the past, so need to work on this.</p> <h2 id="side-projects">Side projects</h2> <p>I’m trying to be more conscious about the time I spend on side projects in 2020. I’ve dedicated specific time blocks for side projects on Mondays and Fridays. I failed to do this in 2019, so the time I spent on side projects suffered.</p> <p>A few of the projects I’m interested in pursuing this year are:</p> <h3 id="type-design">Type Design</h3> <p>It’s time to evolve <a href="https://typeservices.co/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Type Services</a> in a new direction to better reflect my current interests in typography.</p> <p>This year I’d like to create at least one new typeface. Something simple like a geometric monospaced font could be a good place to start. I’ll stick to Latin letters for now, but I’d like to build something systematic, which I can expand in the future.</p> <p>Something else I’m keen to look into more is variable fonts. I haven’t found much out there in the way of learning material, but I’m up for the challenge.</p> <p>I expect this will include rebranding the project and building a new website.</p> <h3 id="generative-art">Generative Art</h3> <p><a href="https://soundcloud.com/dark-sky" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Matt</a> and I had a few discussions about generative art towards the end of last year. We talked about making graphics that connect with the music he creates, in the literal sense. Coding graphics that interface with music is something that interests me a lot.</p> <p>Lately I’ve been playing around with <a href="https://p5js.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">P5.js</a>, following videos from <a href="https://www.youtube.com/thecodingtrain/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Daniel Shiffman</a>, who I discover through <a href="https://daneden.me/2016/11/02/drawing-with-numbers/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Dan Eden</a>. Daniel’s videos are a great introduction to processing and I’m keen to see how this evolves.</p> <h3 id="moodboard">Moodboard</h3> <p>I used to create personal mood boards to spot themes in my interests. I’ve not been doing this so much lately and I’d like to get back into it. A while back I set up a <a href="https://mood.harrycresswell.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">mood board</a> but have since let it fall by the wayside. It’s time to pick this up again and start posting some ideas.</p> <h3 id="music">Music</h3> <p>If time permits I’d like to get back into making some music. It’s been over 10 years since I made anything notable. I dug out a few old tracks towards the end of last year which reminded me how much fun it is to play around with sound.</p> <h3 id="other-ideas">Other ideas</h3> <ul> <li>Course creation. This is something I will be considering more in 2020. Particularly when I find myself tempted to write long articles. I’ll ask myself whether I can make a series of articles or whether it would make sense to create a course.</li> <li>Aggregation sites. I have a few spreadsheets collating tools, open-source fonts, and UX resources. I figured it could be helpful to build these out into searchable websites.</li> <li>Printmaking. I used to screen print and I have to say I miss it a lot. Mono printing might be a simple alternative that I could do at home without needing a studio.</li> </ul> <h2 id="principles-for-2020">Principles for 2020</h2> <p>Ok, on to the principles. To recap, this year I’m setting myself a few principles to follow over the next 12 months.</p> <p>I’ll use these simple ways of thinking to guide my process and apply to various aspects of my commitments. By affirming these principles I hope to make some progress towards the person I wish to become.</p> <h3 id="keep-it-simple">Keep it simple</h3> <p>Avoid complexity when it makes sense to do so. This could mean any number of things such as:</p> <ul> <li>focus on less</li> <li>reduce to only what’s necessary</li> <li>make writing more concise</li> <li>subtract not add</li> <li>simplify</li> </ul> <p>Through simplification we remove things standing in the way of progression. By simplifying we find clarity in our thoughts. Focusing on less can reduce cognitive load and lead to an increase in productivity.</p> <p>A few question I’ve been asking myself a lot lately; “What constraints are preventing you from getting X done?” and “What can you remove to make things easier?”</p> <p>To be clear, constraints of this type shouldn’t be confused with design constraints, which often have the opposite effect.</p> <p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occam%27s_razor" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Occam’s Razor</a> is a useful mental model to apply to this way of thinking. To paraphrase; “the simplest solution is more likely to be the correct than the complicated one”.</p> <h3 id="be-consistent">Be Consistent</h3> <p>Consistency comes up for a second year running. Ironic maybe, but important nonetheless. Generally speaking, the more consistent I am with commitments, the more I seem to create good habits. With time, good habits result in positive improvement.</p> <p>I continue to remind myself each day that “consistency is key”.</p> <h3 id="consider-the-impact">Consider the impact</h3> <p>“Are the things you’re doing having a positive impact on the people around you and the world we live in?”</p> <p>It’s an important time to consider the impact of the work we create. I will be more conscious of my actions in 2020.</p> <h2 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping up</h2> <p>This was a rough outline of how I wish to spend my time in 2020, and the principles I have chosen to keep myself on track. It’s a simple way of improving my chances of living the life I want to lead over the next 12 months.</p> <p>I decided against setting any fixed outcome goals this year. Strict weekly, monthly or even quarterly planning seems to stress me out. Instead, I’ll follow whatever course my energy chooses to take me and keep these affirmations at the front of my mind.</p> <p>This way I remain flexible with my commitments, as things change throughout the year. Providing I put regular time and effort into a few of these things, I’ll make good progress in the right direction.</p>

item.title: 2019 in Review
item.content:encoded: <p>With 2019 almost over, it’s time to reflect on what have been another busy 12 months. This is a chance to take note of my successes and failures and pinpoint potential areas for improvement. I’ll do so by asking three simple questions:</p> <ul> <li>What went well this year?</li> <li>What didn’t go so well this year?</li> <li>What did I learn this year?</li> </ul> <p>If you’ve ever read Atomic Habits by James Clear, then these questions will sound familiar.</p> <p>By reflecting on these questions I hope to better understand where I need to focus my time and energy in the year ahead. Life moves fast and I find time and time again that slowing down is the best way to stay ahead.</p> <h2 id="what-went-well-this-year">What went well this year?</h2> <p>Ok, let’s start with the good stuff that has happened this year.</p> <h3 id="work">Work</h3> <p>This year I’ve been lucky enough to work with a select few clients who allow me to work on the things I’m most interesting in and learn new technologies whilst doing so.</p> <p>I built two new websites I’m particularly pleased with – <a href="https://hub.seedtribe.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SeedTribe Hub</a> and <a href="https://www.jobs.angelinvestmentnetwork.co.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AIN Jobs</a> – both using a new tech stack (React, Gatsby, GraphQL and Sanity). I’ve learned much more about programming in JavaScript in the process.</p> <p>I really wasn’t expecting to pick up basic React concepts and GraphQL so quickly. Testament to the Gatsby and Sanity docs and the many Slack channels I’ve joined this year. Everyone in the Sanity Slack Group and in particular <a href="https://twitter.com/kmelve" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Knut</a> from the Sanity core team have been incredibly helpful.</p> <h3 id="newsletter">Newsletter</h3> <p>I had a good year with <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/newsletter/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">my weekly newsletter</a> which I published consistently, only missing four weeks due to holiday. I’ve started to notice the impact of this commitment. Although the number of you subscribing is still modest that number has increased substantially. I haven’t done much at all in the way of marketing, so I’m pleased so many of you are enjoying it.</p> <p><a href="https://twitter.com/ashleyo_brien/status/1180073230809419776?s=20" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Ash was kind enough to Tweet about it</a> and several of you have emailed with positive feedback and questions. I’ve no doubt it’s been a great way to connect with other designers and developers and start conversations about common interests.</p> <h3 id="in-detail">In Detail</h3> <p>Last year one of my intentions was to move In Detail forward and together with <a href="https://www.instagram.com/beaniemajor/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Beanie</a> and <a href="https://lukeharvey.co.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Luke</a> we’ve successfully done that.</p> <p>We made a big decision to pivot the business model by narrowing our focus to helping our clients collaborate with designers to design bespoke engagement rings. It’s was a bit of a no brainer, as this is what most of our clients are coming to us for help with. It just took some courage to drop the jewellery box content which we’d become well known for and change direction.</p> <p>Our transition was heavily inspired by a simple idea – ‘do one thing and do it well’ – which we borrowed from a concept called <a href="https://www.ted.com/talks/rory_sutherland_perspective_is_everything" target="_blank" rel="noopener">goal dilution</a>.</p> <p>With the business modal simplified, we have clarity in our focus and a clear direction for our content. The business now feels more aligned with our current values concerning consumerism and the environment – buy less and make what you do buy last a lifetime.</p> <h3 id="health">Health</h3> <p>This years been a good year for health. Since last year I’ve doubled my number of runs and I’m now tracking all my sessions. Alternating run days with yoga days has reduced the strain on my body and keep my knees happy. By tracking sessions I can now spot where I’m doing well and where I need to focus more time and effort.</p> <p>I also started climbing again which feels good. It’s fun to solve problems unrelated to design and code for a change. For me climbing creates mind space, it’s calming and methodical, which I like. I’m sure it must improve capacity to work in some way too.</p> <p>On that note I continued to meditate most mornings. I’ve no doubt meditation helps with focus and improves my ability to think clearly, particularly in more stressful situations or when I’ve had a lot on my plate.</p> <h3 id="travel-and-family">Travel and family</h3> <p>In February I spent a few days in France skiing with my dad and sister. It’s not often we spend time together so it was a real treat. We also took a family trip to Corfu in the summer which was a lot of fun. It’s the first time we’ve all been away together since I was small.</p> <p>Rebekka and I took the van to England for a road trip and headed up to Northumberland and The Lake District. I have to admit, after initially feeling slightly underwhelmed by the idea of a holiday in my own country I couldn&rsquo;t have enjoyed it more. England is a magical place, full of history, incredible people and beautiful landscapes. I’m proud to call it my home country.</p> <h3 id="finance">Finance</h3> <p>I finally paid off my student loan. I should have done it years ago but kept putting it off. It feels good to be debt free.</p> <p>Because of this I also took the time to set up a self invested personal pension (SIPP). I’ve realised how important it is to think about your future when you work for yourself. After all, nobody else will do it for you. With the power of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compound_interest" target="_blank" rel="noopener">compound interest</a> it makes sense to do this stuff sooner rather than later. The more time you have the more your money can make.</p> <h3 id="dark-sky-collab">Dark Sky Collab</h3> <p>Matt and I collaborated again on <a href="https://soundcloud.com/dark-sky/sets/cold-harbour-ep" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the latest Dark Sky release</a>. Really pleased with how this one turned out. It’s been 8 years since we first joined forces for Black Rainbows EP and we’ve worked on pretty much every release since.</p> <p>Matt’s music is the source of so much inspiration and I’m proud to work on this project together with him. It’s given me a platform to think more conceptually, work with complete creative freedom and do something totally different from building websites, for a change.</p> <h2 id="what-didnt-go-so-well-this-year">What didn’t go so well this year?</h2> <p>Now for the things that didn’t quite go to plan.</p> <h3 id="writing">Writing</h3> <p>I wrote a fair amount this year but didn’t publish much of it, particularly in the way of articles. I felt the pressure to replicate and improve the writing I had some success with in 2018.</p> <p>I also began thinking more about the impact of my writing. I questioned the quality of what I had written and wondered if I was just adding to the noise with transient words of little value.</p> <p>Overthinking can hold you back but at the same time I feel it’s important to be responsible for what we put out into the world and make a conscious contribution for the right reasons.</p> <p>I felt more comfortable writing short technical notes that do away with design opinions. It’s felt more like keeping a wiki and they’re much easier to write. I’d like to write more about design in 2020 but most likely from more of a technical/coding perspective.</p> <h3 id="courses">Courses</h3> <p>I dipped in and out of a few courses but didn’t get fully into anything, so I want to make this a priority for 2020. This year felt busier than most and because of that I found less time for structured learning.</p> <p>To start the year on the right foot I picked up <a href="https://beginnerjavascript.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Beginner JavaScript by Wes Bos</a> which I hope to use it to fill the gaps in some of my knowledge, particularly on ES6 and practice building more with vanilla JavaScript.</p> <p>I also bought <a href="https://scrimba.com/g/greact" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced React Bootcamp</a> on Scrimba for the same reason. Although I’ve been working with React quite a bit this year, some of the more advanced concepts still leave me scratching my head. This is something else I need to work on in 2020.</p> <h3 id="german">German</h3> <p>I thought having a German girlfriend might help me pick up the language relatively quickly, but it turns out it’s far more difficult than I had anticipated. Potentially more so than JavaScript, for me anyway! I found the basics pretty easy but the conjugations and incessant changing of words caused by the article completely throw me.</p> <p>Although I’ve stuck with my daily 30 minutes of Duolingo this year, I need to work on my understanding of the grammar and find an environment where I can speak more.</p> <p>I didn’t make that happen this year so I’m planning on finding an online tutor, perhaps from <a href="https://preply.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Preply</a> to help me out. It seems more realistic than going back to to the classroom to study as it takes up less time in the day. Either way I’m committed, my progress is just much slower than expected.</p> <h3 id="type-design">Type design</h3> <p>It’s not been a great year for my side project Type Services. I haven’t worked on the project at all this year and I’ve been trying to pin-point why that is.</p> <p>I realise that perhaps I’ve moved on from the style of type I was creating and feel the world of variable fonts and type designed for screens is more where I’m at. It’s certainly more in line with the rest of my work.</p> <p>With that it feels like a good time to re-align my aim for the project and evolve it into something new. I think about typography and type design a lot so I’ve no plans to stop designing type, I just think a new direction might help reignite my passion for it.</p> <h3 id="networking">Networking</h3> <p>I’ve never been a great one for networking. I’m quite happy spending time on my own which can be both good and bad. This year was the first time I’ve felt like my lack of networking might be holding me back.</p> <p>I’d like to get out there a bit more next year by joining a Meetup or making at least one industry event. I plan to make more of an effort in 2020 and hope to meet more creative folk in the real world.</p> <h3 id="social-media">Social media</h3> <p>I’m a big fan of Twitter but I still can’t seem to make a habit of posting regularly. It always comes as an afterthought and I rarely feel I have anything interesting to add to the conversation. Like a lot of things I’m sure this is down to my own lack of self confidence.</p> <p>Generally I find it helps to plan content ahead, but with social media that somehow feels a bit contrived and not spontaneous enough. Perhaps some form of scheduling could help. Or some sort of content plan where I stick to <a href="https://twitter.com/harrycresswell/status/1200881854703972352?s=20" target="_blank" rel="noopener">sharing helpful tips</a> and leave it at that.</p> <p>I’ve found my feet more in Slack channels this year. I feel more comfortable asking questions and helping others in that format. Perhaps that’s because it feels slightly more private and less like the whole world is watching.</p> <h2 id="what-did-i-learn-in-2019">What did I learn in 2019?</h2> <p>Technical skills aside, next I’ll outline some of the helpful ways of thinking I adopted this year which I feel have made a big impact to my progress.</p> <h3 id="simplify-to-avoid-setbacks">Simplify to avoid setbacks</h3> <p>Some of my biggest setbacks came from complexity. I spent far too much time fixing things like broken dependencies, trying to write monster articles then loosing interest, or using too many different tools that I didn’t actually need. That really held me back.</p> <p>I learned that by making things as easy as possible it’s far more likely you’ll achieve your goals. Often this comes from simplifying your process, taking on less obligations or focusing on fewer things. It’s well worth taking the time to think about what you can <a href="https://sivers.org/subtract" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Subtract</a> in order to improve.</p> <p>With this in mind I made a number of big changes to my design and productivity workflow. I switched to Figma for UI prototyping, which allowed me to ditch 3 tools in Sketch, Invision and Abstract. I also jumped on the Notion bandwagon which replaces Evernote, Airtable, Trello and Pocket. Notion, is literally an all-in-one tool, it’s fantastic. Because of these changes I’m now far more focused and productive and I save money too.</p> <p>I also went back to basics with my build process, replacing Gulp in many of my project starters with NPM scripts. In the case of Hugo I switched to using the built in assets pipeline. I’m trying to think more consciously about dependencies and whether they are absolutely necessary.</p> <p>This has reduced the number of issue I’m having. It’s saved me time as it’s made my build times quicker. And it’s allowed me to focus more on doing stuff and less on fixing things. Taking the time to think about ways I can improve my processes instead of jumping in with little thought has been invaluable.</p> <h3 id="consistency-is-still-the-key">Consistency is still the key</h3> <p>Consistency is an amazing thing. Whilst its importance is arguably be over played in UI design, it’s incredibly powerful for making improvements to your daily life and work.</p> <p>Most of the improvements I made this year – particularly in my health, my newsletter and through learning new skills – were down to one thing, I was more consistent. I kept track of my habits and workouts in Notion and kept an eye on areas I was falling down so I could make improvements. A little bit each day definitely seems to go a long way.</p> <h3 id="the-power-of-inversion">The power of inversion</h3> <p><a href="https://fs.blog/2013/10/inversion/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Inversion</a> is a powerful mental model which I’ve begun using more consciously. The idea is you turn a problem on its head, start with the desired outcome and work backwards to find the solution.</p> <p>This is a great way to remove obstacles which may be standing in the way, and avoid obvious stupid mistakes. Often it starts with the simple question – ”what is my goal?” Then, consider the question - “what is preventing me from achieving this goal?”.</p> <p>Thinking about what you want to avoid can be more effective for making progress than simply asking asking yourself – “what can I do to solve this problem?”</p> <h3 id="you-are-what-you-eat">You are what you eat</h3> <p>It’s been a long time since my body has felt as good as it has this year. I’ve spent a lot of time on my health and my diet and I’ve finally started to master what I need to put into my body and how to look after it properly.</p> <p>For me, much of this is based on the gut. IBS has plagued me for years, but since discovering the power of fermented foods, by reading <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/23013953-gut?from_search=true&amp;qid=mVZRHNHpBT&amp;rank=5" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Gut</a> and <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/24886264-cultured-food-for-health?ac=1&amp;from_search=true&amp;qid=FT9nTVtfqm&amp;rank=2" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cultured Food for Health</a>, I’ve started to get a hold of these issue.</p> <p>The 3 K’s (as I like to call them) – Kimchi, Kombucha and Kefir – have been a real game changer. And whilst this might not work for everyone they’ve certainly helped me. I only wish I’d discovered this stuff sooner.</p> <p>In 2020 I’d like to spend more time learning about fermentation and giving it a go myself.</p> <h2 id="2019-in-numbers">2019 in numbers</h2> <p>Now for the numbers. I wish I’d recorded more but it’s not always easy to keep track of everything. Here’s what I have managed to keep track off this year.</p> <h3 id="health-stats">Health stats</h3> <ul> <li>104 recorded runs</li> <li>217 recorded yoga sessions</li> <li>33 hours and 92 minutes meditated</li> <li>9,580 press-ups</li> <li>131.5 recorded minutes in a headstand</li> </ul> <h3 id="work-stats">Work stats</h3> <ul> <li>48 newsletters sent</li> <li>4 articles published</li> <li>12 notes published</li> </ul> <h3 id="learning-stats">Learning stats</h3> <ul> <li>18 books read</li> <li>56 hours of German on Duolingo</li> </ul> <h3 id="environment-stats">Environment stats</h3> <ul> <li>23.87 trees planted via Ecosia</li> <li>18 trees planted via donation to TreesforCities</li> </ul> <h3 id="travel-stats">Travel stats</h3> <ul> <li>6 countries visited – England, Germany, Netherlands, Belgium, France and Greece (Corfu)</li> </ul> <h2 id="recommendations-for-2019">Recommendations for 2019</h2> <ul> <li><strong>Best Documentary</strong>: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aCv29JKmHNY" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Inside Bill’s Brain: Decoding Bill Gates</a></li> <li><strong>Best Documentary runner-up</strong>: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iX8GxLP1FHo" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Great Hack</a></li> <li><strong>Favourite article</strong>: <a href="https://ethanmarcotte.com/wrote/the-world-wide-work/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The World-Wide Work</a> by Ethan Marcotte</li> <li><strong>Favourite book</strong>: <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/48419903-brief-answers-to-the-big-questions" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Brief answers to the big questions</a> by Stephen Hawking</li> <li><strong>Favourite book runner-up</strong>: <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/21083719-human-universe" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Human Universe</a> by Brian Cox</li> <li><strong>Favourite Series</strong>: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XrC4vDcWmxk" target="_blank" rel="noopener">One Strange Rock</a> by Darren Aronofsky</li> <li><strong>Favourite Series runner-up</strong>: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s9APLXM9Ei8" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Chernobyl</a></li> <li><strong>Favourite quote</strong>: “The only thing I know is that I know nothing” - Socrates</li> <li><strong>Music most listened to</strong>: <a href="https://soundcloud.com/dark-sky/sets/cold-harbour-ep" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cold Harbour EP</a> by Dark Sky</li> <li><strong>Favourite exhibition</strong>: <a href="https://www.barbican.org.uk/whats-on/2019/event/ai-more-than-human" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AI: More than Human</a> at the Barbican</li> </ul> <h2 id="final-words">Final words</h2> <p>This was my second time <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/articles/year-in-review/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">writing a year in review</a> and once again it’s been a valuable exercise. It’s helped me to put my foot on the brakes and take stock of my accomplishments or lack thereof. In some way or another it’s helped me better understand myself, in terms of what I care most about, what no longer serves me, where I can improve and where I should focus my efforts.</p> <p>I referred to my <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/articles/2018-review/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">2018 in review</a> throughout this year, using it to keep tabs on my progress. In 2020 I hope to do the same with this one, using it to move more consciously through life, make better decisions and practice gratitude wherever possible.</p> <p>To that end I’d like to say thanks to everyone who has helped make this year a great success, I’m grateful to you all. Wishing you all a very happy new year and here’s to the next decade. Thanks for reading!</p>

item.title: Performant syntax highlighting in Hugo
item.content:encoded: <p>The quickest way to use syntax highlighting in Hugo is with <a href="https://github.com/alecthomas/chroma" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Chroma</a>, the default syntax highlighter. Without any config, you can wrap a code block in the built in <code>highlight</code> Shortcode, pass in the language as a variable and you’re code will be highlighted:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{&lt; highlight go &gt;} // Html code to highlight {&lt; / highlight &gt;} </code></pre><p><em>Note: to render the example above on the page I have used single curly braces. You will need to use double curly braces.</em></p> <p>The advantage of using Chroma over other JavaScript libraries like <a href="https://highlightjs.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Highlight.js</a> or <a href="https://prismjs.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Prisma.js</a> is that it’s built right into Hugo and doesn’t require any external dependencies. This make it extremely fast and reliable.</p> <p>Out of the box, however, Chroma doesn’t give us much control over the style of our highlighted code. To change that all we need to do is add one line of code to the top level of our <code>config.toml</code> file:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c"># Enable for syntax highlighting</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="l">pygmentsUseClasses = true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p><em>Note: It’s important you add this line to the top level and not under <code>[params]</code> if you want it to work. Something like this should do it:</em></p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="l">baseurl = &#34;http://localhost:1313/&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="l">theme=&#34;theme name&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="l">languageCode = &#34;en&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="l">title = &#34;your site title&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="c"># Enable for syntax highlighting</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="l">pygmentsUseClasses = true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="adding-option-for-code-fencing">Adding option for code fencing</h2> <p>It is also possible to add syntax highlighting to code within code fences. To enable this add the following to your <code>config.toml</code> file:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="l">pygmentsCodefences = true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now you can wrap your code in two sets of triple backticks (```) and specify the language after the opening set to highlight the code correctly. Make sure you check the <a href="https://github.com/alecthomas/chroma#supported-languages" target="_blank" rel="noopener">list of supported langauges</a>.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>(```) yaml pygmentsUseClasses = true pygmentsCodeFences = true (```) </code></pre><p><em>Note: Make sure you omit the parentheses as seen above. This is just to show you the code without it rendering.</em></p> <p>Now you can highlight any syntax inside of code fences:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="cp">&lt;!doctype html&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">html</span> <span class="na">lang</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;en&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">head</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">meta</span> <span class="na">charset</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;utf-8&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">meta</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;viewport&#34;</span> <span class="na">content</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;width=device-width, initial-scale=1, shrink-to-fit=no&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Hello, world!<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">head</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">body</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Hello, world!<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">h1</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">body</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">html</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="customising-your-syntax-theme">Customising your syntax theme</h2> <p>To change the theme of your syntax highlighting generate <code>chromastyles</code>. Then set the name of the theme you want using the <code>--style</code> flag.</p> <p>From the command line run:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>hugo gen chromastyles --style=lovelace &gt; syntax.css </code></pre><p>This will generate the <code>syntax.css</code> file at the root of your project.</p> <p>See <a href="https://xyproto.github.io/splash/docs/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">https://xyproto.github.io/splash/docs/</a> for available themes. You can also run <code>hugo gen chromastyles -h</code> to see more options.</p> <p>Don’t forget to link to the stylesheet from the <!-- raw HTML omitted --> of your document otherwise your theme won’t work!</p>

item.title: Expert and beginner
item.content:encoded: <p class="intro"> What excites me most about building things for the web is that it’s constantly evolving and because of this, we’re continuously learning better ways to solve familiar problems. </p> <p>It seems like every day there’s an exciting new approach to get the job done and it’s almost always an improvement on the techniques we know or that we’ve relied on for years.</p> <p>Often you find yourself learning these techniques from someone just starting out. Someone you might otherwise think of as a beginner. But regardless of their inexperience, you can guarantee they know something you don’t. Just as they might be keen to learn from you, you can learn something just as valuable from them, becoming a better developer in the process.</p> <p>Rachel Andrew summed this up perfectly in <a href="https://twitter.com/rachelandrew/status/1096807596462403584" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a recent tweet</a>:</p> <blockquote> <p>“I love that in this industry you get to be an expert and a beginner at the same time. Learning new things, being a beginner, reminds me what that is like and makes me a better teacher of the things I am expert in.”</p> </blockquote> <p>The constant need to learn and start over can feel overwhelming at times, we all feel it, regardless of our experience, or lack there of. But it’s our mindset and approach which is the most important thing to master.</p> <p>Some people let it get to them, becoming despondent with their attitude and outdated in their beliefs. They form what you might like to call a “fixed” mindset, thinking they already know it all, which prevents them from making progress and developing further.</p> <p>Others choose a “growth” mindset, seeing the gaps in their knowledge as an exciting opportunity to learn and improve. They embrace the attitude of a life long learner and learn continuously, from whoever they can.</p> <p>As inexperienced developers it’s important to value what little we may know. Be confident knowing that though we may refer to ourselves as beginners, we are in fact experts alike. We have something just as important to teach, as we have to learn, regardless of how long we’ve been building things on the web.</p> <p>The vastness and complexity of this industry means it’s impossible know it all. There’s a very good chance what we decided to focus on is totally different to that of a more experienced co-worker. We must use this to our advantage, every way we can.</p> <p>This reminds me of Frank Chimero’s <a href="https://frankchimero.com/blog/2018/everything-easy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Everything easy is hard again</a> where he writes:</p> <blockquote> <p>”In one way, it is easier to be inexperienced: you don’t have to learn what is no longer relevant. Experience, on the other hand, creates two distinct struggles: the first is to identify and unlearn what is no longer necessary (that’s work, too). The second is to remain open-minded, patient, and willing to engage with what’s new, even if it resembles a new take on something you decided against a long time ago.”</p> </blockquote> <p>As experienced developers we must maintain the desire to learn and reinvent. We must listen, observe, and keep an open-mind about who we learn from. Embracing <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shoshin" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Shoshin</a>, otherwise know as <em>Beginners Mind</em> can help us overcome our egos. Whilst teaching can help us remain humble, learn patience and let go of our preconceptions. As we teach something new, we learn to approach each problem as if it was for the first time.</p> <p>No matter how much we think we know, we must never think we know it all or believe we’re better, simple because we have more experience. We must challenge our techniques when challenged and reinvent our methods when it’s time to do so. We must learn to unlearn what’s no longer necessary.</p> <h2 id="further-resources">Further resources</h2> <ul> <li>Rachel Andrew on <a href="https://twitter.com/rachelandrew/status/1096807596462403584" target="_blank" rel="noopener">being an expert and a beginning</a> at the same time.</li> <li><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shoshin" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Shoshin</a>, the Zen Buddhism teachings of Beginners Mind.</li> <li><a href="https://frankchimero.com/writing/everything-easy-is-hard-again/%7c" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Everything easy is hard again</a> by Frank Chimero</li> </ul>

item.title: Albion: designing a weather app and eCommerce store for a UK cycling brand
Using CSS Media Queries in React
item.content:encoded: <p>Being more comfortable with HTML and CSS, than JavaScript and React, I still like the idea of using good ol&rsquo; media queries to show and hide content at certain viewport widths. But how do media queries work with React?</p> <p>I found a library called <a href="https://github.com/ReactTraining/react-media" target="_blank" rel="noopener">React Media</a> which is essentially a media query component for React that listens for matches to a CSS media query and renders stuff based on whether the query matches or not.</p> <h2 id="getting-started">Getting started</h2> <p>Install from the root of your project using NPM.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>npm install --save react-media </code></pre><p>Using <code>react-media</code> within <code>create-react-app</code>:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-jsx" data-lang="jsx"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">import</span> <span class="nx">React</span> <span class="nx">from</span> <span class="s1">&#39;react&#39;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// Import the media component into your project using ES modules </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="kr">import</span> <span class="nx">Media</span> <span class="nx">from</span> <span class="s1">&#39;react-media&#39;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">class</span> <span class="nx">App</span> <span class="kr">extends</span> <span class="nx">React</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Component</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">render</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="p">(</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Render a media component with a query prop whose value is a valid CSS media query. </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">Media</span> <span class="na">query</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;(max-width: 599px)&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// The children prop should be a function whose only argument will be a boolean flag that indicates whether the media query matches or not. </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="nx">matches</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">matches</span> <span class="o">?</span> <span class="p">(</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span><span class="nx">The</span> <span class="nb">document</span> <span class="nx">is</span> <span class="nx">less</span> <span class="nx">than</span> <span class="mi">600</span><span class="nx">px</span> <span class="nx">wide</span><span class="p">.&lt;/</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">(</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span><span class="nx">The</span> <span class="nb">document</span> <span class="nx">is</span> <span class="nx">at</span> <span class="nx">least</span> <span class="mi">600</span><span
