class="nx">px</span> <span class="nx">wide</span><span class="p">.&lt;/</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">)</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">Media</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>So what’s going on here? React Media uses a conditional operator to determine what to display based on the query prop, in this case whether the viewport is less than 600px or at least 600px wide.</p> <p>This is helpful for rendering different components at different viewports. For example you might have a hamburger icon you want to show on smaller screens but hide on larger screens and an inline navigation which you want to hide on smaller screens but show on larger screens.</p> <p>React Media provides a quick solution to help solve this problem.</p> <h2 id="further-resources">Further Resources</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/ReactTraining/react-media" target="_blank" rel="noopener">React Media</a> from React Training.</li> </ul>

item.title: Real-time updates with Sanity watch mode
item.content:encoded: <p>Watch mode allows you to see realtime updates without having to manually restart the build process.</p> <p>Set <code>watchMode: true</code> in your <code>gatsby-sanity-source</code> plugin options, to set up a listener which watches your project for changes.</p> <p>Take it further by setting <code>overlayDrafts: true</code> to immediately apply any changes you make to draft content.</p> <p>You will then need to generate a token from the Sanity manage console.</p> <p>Navigate to <code>manage.sanity.io</code> &gt; settings &gt; API &gt; Add New Token.</p> <p>Create a Read token called Gatsby and add to your <code>gatsby-config.js.</code></p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">resolve</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;gatsby-source-sanity&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">options</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">projectId</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;your_project_id&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">dataset</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;your_dataset_name&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">overlayDrafts</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kc">true</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">watchMode</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kc">true</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">token</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">&#39;your_token_id&#39;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Restart <code>gatsby develop</code>.</p> <p>Now when you edit content in the Studio CMS you will see changes occur in Gatsby in realtime.</p>

item.title: Query data from Sanity using GraphQL
Set up a Gatsby project with Sanity
item.content:encoded: <h2 id="step-1-create-new-gatsby-project">Step 1: Create new Gatsby project</h2> <p>Create new folder for new Gatsby site.</p> <p><code>mkdir gatsby-sanity-frontend</code></p> <p>Move into that folder and create a fresh Gatsby project using the default Gatsby starter.</p> <p><code>cd gatsby-sanity-frontend &amp;&amp; gatsby new .</code></p> <h2 id="step-2-install-sanity-dependency">Step 2: Install Sanity dependency</h2> <p>Install Gatsby Source Sanity plugin to your project.</p> <p><code>npm install --save gatsby-source-sanity</code></p> <p>Inside <code>gatsby-config.js</code> add plugin:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">resolve</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">&#39;gatsby-source-sanity&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">options</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">projectId</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">&#39;&lt;yourProjectId&gt;&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">dataset</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">&#39;&lt;yourDatasetName&gt;&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">},</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You will find your <code>projectId</code> and <code>dataset</code> inside <code>sanity.json</code> found within your studio project.</p> <p>If you chose to make your dataset private you will also need to add a permissions token like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">resolve</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">&#39;gatsby-source-sanity&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">options</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">projectId</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">&#39;&lt;yourProjectId&gt;&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">dataset</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">&#39;&lt;yourDatasetName&gt;&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1">// a token with read permissions is required </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="c1">// if you have a private dataset </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">token</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">process</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">env</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">MY_SANITY_TOKEN</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">},</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="step-3-optional-enable-gatsby-watch-mode-for-drafts">Step 3: (optional) Enable Gatsby watch mode for drafts</h2> <p>Sanity has a cool feature which allows for realtime content updates in local development. So if you have your content studio and front end side-by-side in two different browser windows, you will see any changes you make to the content in the studio change in realtime in Gatsby.</p> <p>To get this set up correctly</p> <ul> <li>go to <code>manage.sanity.io</code> and find your project (or run the command <code>sanity manage</code> in the studio folder).</li> <li>Head to <code>Settings &gt; API</code>, then scroll down to the Tokens section</li> <li>Add a new token and give it read privileges.</li> <li>Back in the root of your <code>/web</code> project locate <code>.env.development.template</code> and rename it to <code>.env.development</code>.</li> <li>Add your new token to the key: <code>SANITY_READ_TOKEN=&quot;&lt;token here&gt;&quot;</code></li> <li>Inside <code>gatsby-config.js</code> make sure you have <code>token: process.env.SANITY_READ_TOKEN,</code> as one of the options in your <code>gatsby-source-sanity</code> plugin config.</li> </ul> <p>Restart your development environment for the changes to propagate. Make some changes in your studio and watch them appear in realtime in Gatsby.</p> <h2 id="further-resources">Further resources</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.org/blog/2019-01-25-blazing-fast-development-with-gatsby-and-sanity-io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Blazing fast development with Gatsby and Sanity.io</a> from Knut Melvær.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/sanity-io/example-company-website-gatsby-sanity-combo#enable-gatsby-watch-mode-for-drafts" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Enable Gatsby Watchmode for Drafts</a> from Sanity.io</li> </ul>

item.title: Deploy a GraphQL API for a Sanity project
item.content:encoded: <p>If you want to consume your Sanity dataset from a front-end the you will need to set up an API. You can do this using Sanity’s custom query language GROQ or GraphQL. These notes focus on the latter.</p> <p>With an API set up you will be able to query your data in any application you create.</p> <p><strong>Note: Anytime you make changes to your content schema, you will need to redeploy the GraphQL API</strong></p> <h2 id="deploying-the-graphql-api">Deploying the GraphQL API</h2> <p>First make sure your running the latest version of Sanity: <code>sanity upgrade</code></p> <p>Run <code>sanity graphql deploy</code> to deploy a GraphQL API for the dataset configured in <code>sanity.json</code>.</p> <p>You will then be asked the following:</p> <p><code>Do you want to enable a GraphQL playground? (Y/n)</code></p> <p>Hit <code>Y</code> and you’ll be able to explore the Schema in a GraphQL Playground.</p> <h2 id="explore-the-schema-from-a-gatsby-project">Explore the Schema from a Gatsby project</h2> <p>Explore <code>￼http://localhost:8000/___graphql</code> after running <code>gatsby develop</code> to understand the created data and create a new query and checking available collections and fields by typing <code>CTRL + SPACE</code>.</p> <h2 id="further-resources">Further Resources</h2> <p>For more on this step <a href="https://www.sanity.io/docs/data-store/graphql#deploying-the-graph-ql-api" target="_blank" rel="noopener">check out the docs</a>.</p>

item.title: Content schema in Sanity
item.content:encoded: <p>This is the bit where you define your data model, meaning the way you structure your content.</p> <p>The Sanity team recommend “you start by modelling your data logically, without thinking too much about how it&rsquo;s going to be presented.”</p> <p>When modelling your data try and think about your content not as ‘pages’ but as content ‘types’ and establish what fields each of those content types will need.</p> <p>So instead of creating a content type called <code>Homepage</code>, think about the type of content that might exist <em>on</em> your homepage, and potentially elsewhere on your site.</p> <p>For example, your homepage might feature latest posts and you might also have a dedicated page for these posts too. In this case it makes sense to create a content type called <code>post</code>.</p> <p>Next we need to consider the fields associated with our new content type. Think of these as the data attached to the content type. Things like <code>title</code>, <code>slug</code>, <code>excerpt</code> and <code>publishedAt</code> are fairly typical requirements for a post.</p> <p>It’s also worth thinking about the relationships between different data types and modelling your content according to what they mean.</p> <p>For example the <code>post</code> content type may also have an author and perhaps a category attached to it. Maybe in the future you decide to add another content type called <code>note</code>, which also requires an author and a category. This is a good reason to create a content type for both <code>author</code> and <code>category</code> and make a reference it from both content types.</p> <p>Thinking about your content in this way creates a more flexible data model, as you’re not associating content too tightly to the presentation layer.</p> <p>It’s worth reading <a href="https://www.sanity.io/docs/the-schema/donts-and-dos" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Dont’s and Dos</a> in the Sanity docs for more on this. Next we’ll put this into practice in a Sanity project.</p> <h2 id="understanding-schemajs">Understanding schema.js</h2> <p>To begin, fire open <code>schemas/schema.js</code> from inside your Sanity project. The first import you see is the <code>createSchema</code> function which allows us to create a schema.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>import createSchema from &#39;part:@sanity/base/schema-creator </code></pre><p>Next you’ll see <code>schemaTypes</code> which imports any schema types required from plugins. To see what plugins are used head to <code>sanity.json</code>.</p> <p>The part we’re most concerned with is the <code>createSchema</code> object. The array inside this object called <code>types</code> is where we define content types.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">export</span> <span class="k">default</span> <span class="nx">createSchema</span><span class="p">({</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// We name our schema </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">name</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;default&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Then proceed to concatenate our document type </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="c1">// to the ones provided by any plugins that are installed </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">types</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">schemaTypes</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">concat</span><span class="p">([</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// The following are document types which will appear </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="c1">// in the studio. </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">post</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">author</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">category</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// When added to this list, object types can be used as </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="c1">// { type: &#39;typename&#39; } in other document schemas </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">blockContent</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">]),</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">});</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You can see we have 3 content types <code>post</code>, <code>author</code>, and <code>category</code>. As we started this project using the Blog template these are already defined. If you started with a blank template you won’t see any content types defined.</p> <p>Above this block of code you’ll see each content type is stored in an external file and then imported. As our schema grows this will keep our project well organised.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// We import object and document schemas </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="kr">import</span> <span class="nx">blockContent</span> <span class="nx">from</span> <span class="s2">&#34;./blockContent&#34;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">import</span> <span class="nx">category</span> <span class="nx">from</span> <span class="s2">&#34;./category&#34;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">import</span> <span class="nx">post</span> <span class="nx">from</span> <span class="s2">&#34;./post&#34;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">import</span> <span class="nx">author</span> <span class="nx">from</span> <span class="s2">&#34;./author&#34;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The comment tell us that we are importing both <code>object</code> and <code>document</code> schemas. We’ll get to this next.</p> <h2 id="building-a-basic-schema">Building a basic schema</h2> <p>Let’s create a new content type for notes. Create a new file <code>schemas/note.js</code> and create a new object. We’ll also need to export the object so we can use it elsewhere.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">export</span> <span class="k">default</span> <span class="p">{};</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next we need to name our content type and define what type of content it is. In this case it’s a <code>document</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">export</span> <span class="k">default</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;note&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">type</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;document&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">};</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now we need to import our new content type to the <code>schema.js</code> file and add it to the types array so Sanity can see it.</p> <p>Back in <code>schema.js</code> add the following below the <code>author</code> import:</p> <p><code>import note from './note</code></p> <p>Then we need to update the types array to include the <code>note</code> content type:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">export</span> <span class="k">default</span> <span class="nx">createSchema</span><span class="p">({</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// We name our schema </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">name</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;default&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Then proceed to concatenate our document type </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="c1">// to the ones provided by any plugins that are installed </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">types</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">schemaTypes</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">concat</span><span class="p">([</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// The following are document types which will appear </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="c1">// in the studio. </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">post</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">author</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">category</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">note</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// When added to this list, object types can be used as </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="c1">// { type: &#39;typename&#39; } in other document schemas </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nx">blockContent</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">]),</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">});</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now run the studio locally, head to the browser and you’ll notice a few errors. We need a title for our new content type and an array of fields.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">export</span> <span class="k">default</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;note&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">type</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;document&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">title</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Note&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">fields</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">[],</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">};</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Our notes will need a <code>title</code>, which will be a basic text string type and of course a title so we can identity the field in the studio.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">export</span> <span class="k">default</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;note&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">type</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;document&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">title</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Note&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">fields</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">[</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;title&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">type</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;string&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">title</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Title&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">},</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">],</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">};</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Hit save and studio should reload and we can now see our new content type. We can create a new Note and fill in the note Title field.</p> <h2 id="referencing-other-document-content-types">Referencing other document content types.</h2> <p>Earlier I mentioned creating relationships between content types. The <code>reference</code> type make this possible.</p> <p>Inside <code>note.js</code> let’s add a reference that points to the <code>author</code> content type, <code>author</code> should already exist if you started with the Blog template.</p> <p>To specific what content type we want author to reference we can use the <code>to</code> field. This takes one rule, that the type is <code>author</code>. Now author will only allow references to the author content type.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">export</span> <span class="k">default</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;note&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">type</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;document&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">title</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Note&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">fields</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">[</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;title&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">type</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;string&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">title</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Title&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">},</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;author&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">title</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Author&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">type</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;reference&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">to</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">[{</span> <span class="nx">type</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;author&#34;</span> <span class="p">}],</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">},</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">],</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">};</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Back in Sanity studio we can see a new field titled Author which allows us to select an Author. If you haven’t added an author yet you’ll need to do this in the Author type first.</p> <h2 id="further-resources">Further resources</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.sanity.io/docs/content-studio/the-schema" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Schema</a> from the Sanity Docs</li> </ul>

item.title: Starting a new Sanity project
item.content:encoded: <p><a href="https://www.sanity.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sanity.io</a> is a headless CMS that allows you to structure your content by building custom schemas and deliver it as a flexible API, which you can then query using the front-end technology of your choice.</p> <h2 id="install-sanity">Install Sanity</h2> <p>Install Sanity studio globally:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>npm install -g @sanity/cli </code></pre><p>This will allow you to use the <code>sanity</code> CLI and scaffold new projects directly from the command line.</p> <h2 id="create-a-new-project">Create a new project</h2> <p>To start a new project create a new project directory and move into it:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>mkdir new-project &amp;&amp; cd new-project </code></pre><p>Run <code>sanity init</code> to log in Sanity, set up a dataset, and generate the files needed to run the editing environment locally.</p> <p>If this is your first project choose <code>Create new project</code>, then give your project a name and name your dataset, this can be anything you like. If you leave blank it will be given the default name <code>production</code>.</p> <p>Next select dataset visibility, choose the output path and select a template. It’s a good idea to choose <code>blog</code> if this is your first project as it will give you a clue how to structure your schema. You can always delete the default schema later.</p> <p>Sanity will resolve dependencies then you will be ready to start the project.</p> <h2 id="next-steps">Next steps</h2> <p>Launch the project in VSCode, using <code>code .</code> from the root directory, then use <code>sanity start</code> to run a locally instance of the studio in your browser.</p> <p>Now you‘re ready to start building your content schema.</p> <h2 id="further-reading">Further reading</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.sanity.io/docs/introduction/getting-started" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Getting started with Sanity</a> from the Sanity Docs.</li> </ul>

item.title: Destroy all for loops
Click to delete
item.content:encoded: <p>In version 10 of our todo list app we create a way to delete todo items by added a todo button to each todo item. These are my notes from Gordon Zhu’s free course <a href="https://watchandcode.com/p/practical-javascript" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical JavaScript</a>, which teaches you how to create a todo app in vanilla JavaScript.</p> <h2 id="the-return-statement">The &lsquo;return&rsquo; statement</h2> <p>The return statement allows you to return a value from a function.</p> <p>Say, for example, you have a variable which produces the value of 2 and 10. The variable calls a function which multiplies the 2 numbers.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">theProductOf2And10</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">multiplyTwoNumbers</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>As <code>multiplyTwoNumbers</code> doesn’t yet exist we will need to create that function. The obvious way to do this is to create a function that takes two values as parameters. Then create a variable that stores the result of the calculation. The calculaton being <code>a * b</code>, using an asterisk to represent multiplication.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">function</span> <span class="nx">multiplyTwoNumbers</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">b</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">result</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">a</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="nx">b</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">theProductOf2And10</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">multiplyTwoNumbers</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>What we expect to get from this is the multiplication of 2 and 10, which is 20. But when we run <code>theProductOf2And10</code>, the console returns <code>undefined</code>.</p> <p>The reason the value is undefined if because we haven’t returned the value.</p> <p>We can easily change this to work the way we want by adding a <code>return</code> statement, which returns the value of our <code>result</code> variable.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">function</span> <span class="nx">multiplyTwoNumbers</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">b</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">result</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">a</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="nx">b</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="nx">result</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">theProductOf2And10</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">multiplyTwoNumbers</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>To recap, if you want to return a value from a function, as in this case, you need to <code>return</code> the value you want. If you don’t <code>return</code> the value, the value will be <code>undefined</code>.</p> <h2 id="requirements">Requirements</h2> <p>In version 10 we want to give each todo item a delete button. Instead of having to enter the number of the item in the todos array to delete a todo item, we can then delete an item with a simple click.</p> <ul> <li>There should be a way to create delete buttons</li> <li>There should be a delete button for each todo</li> <li>Each li shold have an id that has the todo position</li> <li>Delete buttons should have access to the todo id</li> <li>Clicking delete should update todoList.todos and the DOM</li> </ul> <h2 id="there-should-be-a-way-to-create-delete-buttons">There should be a way to create delete buttons</h2> <p>In our JavaScript file, we want to create a new method on our <code>view</code> object. The reason we’re doing this in the <code>view</code> object is because the delete button another DOM element – a visible piece of UI in our application.</p> <p>We can call the new method <code>createDeleteButton</code>, and set it to an empty function.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">createDeleteButton</span> <span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next we want to have a variable called <code>deleteButton</code>, which is returned by the function.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">createDeleteButton</span> <span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">deleteButton</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="nx">deleteButton</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This helps us get the structure for how this function will work – create a button, then return the button. Later we’ll use this method inside <code>displayTodos</code> to create buttons for us.</p> <p>Now we can set the variable to create a button element.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">createDeleteButton</span> <span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">deleteButton</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">createElement</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;button&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="nx">deleteButton</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next we need to give the button some text content, so we know what it is. We can use the <code>textContent</code> property and set it to ‘delete’.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">createDeleteButton</span> <span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">deleteButton</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">createElement</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;button&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">deleteButton</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">textContent</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;delete&#39;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="nx">deleteButton</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next we’ll need a way to access these different delete button elements. We can use a class in this case, as unlike <code>id</code>, which will only work for unqiue elements, classes can be reused. This is important as we will need a delete button for every item in our todo list. We can use the <code>className</code> property to identify the elements.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">createDeleteButton</span> <span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">deleteButton</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">createElement</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;button&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">deleteButton</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">textContent</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Delete&#39;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">dleteButton</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">className</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;deleteButton&#39;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="nx">deleteButton</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="ther-should-be-a-delete-button-for-each-todo">Ther should be a delete button for each todo</h2> <p>The next requirement is to get the delete button to show up for each todo item.</p> <p>We can do this by appending our createDeleteButton function to the <code>li</code> element that contains the todo item.</p> <p>Inside the <code>displayTodos</code> method, go to the second to last line and create a new line. That should look like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todoLi</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">textContent</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">todoTextWithCompletion</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todosUl</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">appendChild</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">todoLi</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now we can use the <code>appendChild</code> property on <code>todoLi</code>, so we can add the button element.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todoLi</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">textContent</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">todoTextWithCompletion</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todoLi</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">appendChild</span><span class="p">()</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todosUl</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">appendChild</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">todoLi</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>As <code>createDeleteButton</code> is available on the same object, we can use <code>this</code> to access it. Now when the method runs it will return a delete button, and append it to the todo <code>li</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todoLi</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">textContent</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">todoTextWithCompletion</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todoLi</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">appendChild</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">createDeleteButton</span><span class="p">());</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todosUl</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">appendChild</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">todoLi</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now we can head to our app and add a few items to see if the code worked. You should see a delete button appear for every item you add. Right now the delete buttons dont’t work when you click them, we’ll get to that next.</p> <h2 id="each-li-should-have-an-id-that-has-the-todo-position">Each li should have an id that has the todo position</h2> <p>Now we have a delete button, we’re no longer able to tell the app the position of the item in the array which we want to delete. So now we need a way to give each todo item a unique reference.</p> <p>This reference will represent the items postion in the array and we can use it later to grab the position of the item we want to delete. The easiest way to make this happen is using an <code>id</code>.</p> <p>For example, the first item should have an <code>id</code> of 1, the second an <code>id</code> of 2 and so on.</p> <p>We can do this in a single line of code. Right above the last section of code, grab <code>todoLi</code> and set its <code>id</code> property to <code>i</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todoLi</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">id</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">i</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todoLi</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">textContent</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">todoTextWithCompletion</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todoLi</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">appendChild</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">createDeleteButton</span><span class="p">());</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todosUl</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">appendChild</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">todoLi</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This works because our <code>for</code> loop iterates over every item in our todos, so <code>i</code> is equal to each position in the array. And we can use it to set the <code>id</code> to the postion.</p> <p>We’re using an <code>id</code> in this case as we need a unqiue identifier. There should only every be one <code>id</code> value for each postion. For example there should only be one 1, one 2, one 3 and so on.</p> <p>To see how this works, in the app add 3 new items, then Inspect the elements console and see the <code>id</code>’s attached to each of your <code>li</code>’s.</p> <p>Now when delete is clicks we have a way to reference the particular item we want to delete.</p> <h2 id="delete-buttons-should-have-access-to-the-todo-id">Delete buttons should have access to the todo id</h2> <p>Delete buttons should have access to the todo <code>id</code> so it knows which todo in the array to delete.</p> <p>The first thought might be to add events listeners to each of the delete buttons however this can cause memory problems if there are too many event listeners.</p> <p>A better way is to use a single event listener. To conceptulise this let’s add 3 items to our todo list. Inspect Element on those items and notice that all the <code>li</code>’s are contained in a single unordered list (<code>ul</code>).</p> <p>Here, instead of adding several event listeners on the delete buttons, we can add a single event listener on the unordered list. This is because if we you click anything inside the <code>ul</code>, the event listener will know about it. We can handle the events from the parent element, and listen for when a delete button inside the unordered list is clicked.</p> <p>Back in our code we can start by saving a reference to the unordered list using <code>document.querySelector</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">todosUL</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelector</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;ul&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>From here we want to add an event listener to the <code>ul</code> which listens for <code>click</code> events. Then run a callback function as we want to do something when the click happens</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">todosUL</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelector</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;ul&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todosUL</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">addEventListener</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;click&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">});</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>To recap from the functions inside of functions module, this new function which happens after the click event is the callback function. Whereas <code>addEventListener</code> is the higher order function. It’s the function which takes other functions. And <code>addEventListener</code> will run this function for us, whenever a click event happens on the <code>todosUl</code> element.</p> <p>What’s most important is that when it runs the function, it will pass in an event. To get access to that event we need to add it as a parameter.</p> <p>Finally, we can log out the event to the console using <code>console.log</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">todosUL</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">querySelector</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;ul&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todosUL</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">addEventListener</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;click&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">event</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">event</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">});</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now let’s add an item to the todo list, then click the delete button on the item to see if the event is logged to the console.</p> <p>You should now see a <code>MouseEvent</code> object logged to the console, which includes several properties. We can ignore most of these for now as we’re only interested in the <code>target</code> property. <code>target</code> tells us which element we actually clicked on, in this case <code>button.deleteButton</code>.</p> <p>From here we need to access the <code>id</code>, but they are attached to the <code>li</code> element. We can access the <code>li</code> from the delete button by using the <code>parentNode</code> property, as delete button is a child element of the <code>li</code> parent.</p> <p>If you expand the <code>target</code> property you can see the <code>parentNode</code> property. Notice it has a value of <code>li#0</code>. This is the <code>li</code> followed by the corresponding <code>id</code> value, where the <code>#</code> symbol represents <code>id</code>.
