As before we’ll need a <code>button</code> and this time only one <code>input</code>.</p> <p>We want to run a function inside our JavaScript when the button is clicked so we can use <code>onclick</code> and parse in the method on our <code>handlers</code> object. This method doesn’t actually exist yet but we’ll make it a bit later.</p> <p>We then need to add information to the <code>input</code>. First a descriptive <code>id</code> as before, this will allow us to access the data in our JavaScript. Then we add <code>type=&quot;number&quot;</code> so we can collect a number, representing the position of the todo which needs to be deleted.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">button</span> <span class="na">onclick</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;handlers.deleteTodo()&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Delete<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">button</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;deleteTodoPositionInput&#34;</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;number&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In our JavaScript we’ll need to write a new method on our <code>handlers</code> object.</p> <p>The pattern is very similar as before. We first need to grab the input for the position of the item to delete. We can do this with <code>getElementById</code>, parsing in the <code>id</code> and storing this in a variable.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">deleteTodo</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">deleteTodoPositionInput</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">getElementById</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;deleteTodoPositionInput&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next we want to run the <code>deleteTodo</code> method on our <code>todoList</code> object.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">deleteTodo</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">deleteTodoPositionInput</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">getElementById</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;deleteTodoPositionInput&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">todoList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">deleteTodo</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>If we take a look back at the <code>deleteTodo</code> method we can see it takes a <code>position</code> parameter. In this case can use the number value from our <code>input</code>. As it has to be a number we need to use <code>.valueAsNumber</code> to grab the data.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">deleteTodo</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">deleteTodoPositionInput</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">getElementById</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;deleteTodoPositionInput&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">todoList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">deleteTodo</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">deleteTodoPositionInput</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">valueAsNumber</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Finally we will need to clear the <code>input</code> once the code has run, so the previous value doesn’t remain in the <code>input</code> box. We do this using an empty string.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">deleteTodo</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">deleteTodoPositionInput</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">getElementById</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;deleteTodoPositionInput&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">todoList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">deleteTodo</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">deleteTodoPositionInput</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">valueAsNumber</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">deleteTodoPositionInput</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Value</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;&#39;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>We can check our code is working by adding a new todo item then deleting it.</p> <p>Hopefully now you can see a pattern forming with our code.</p> <p>We start by building the user interface, then write the method in our JavaScript. In this case our <code>deleteTodo</code> method grabs the input, and parses the input value into our <code>deleteTodo</code> method on our <code>todoList</code>object. Then it clears the input field when it’s done.</p> <h2 id="there-should-be-a-button-for-toggling-a-todo">There should be a button for toggling a todo</h2> <p>The <code>toggleCompleted</code> feature will almost be the same as <code>deleteTodo</code>.</p> <p>First we start with the user interface. So in the <code>html</code> we need a <code>button</code> and an <code>input</code>.</p> <p>As before we need an <code>onclick</code> attribute on our button. We haven’t written the method yet but it will be on our <code>handlers</code> object and be called <code>toggleCompleted</code>.</p> <p>Our <code>input</code> needs an <code>id</code> and a <code>type</code> of <code>number</code>. This is because <code>toggleCompleted</code> takes a position of the item you want to toggle.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">button</span> <span class="na">onclick</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;handlers.toggleCompleted&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Toggle Completed<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">button</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;toggleCompletedPositionInput&#34;</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;number&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now we can move into our JavaScript. We start with a new method; <code>toggleCompleted</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleCompleted</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>First we want to grab the <code>input</code> and store in a variable.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleCompleted</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">toggleCompletedPositionInput</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">getElementById</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;toggleCompletedPositionInput&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next we want to make a call to the method on our <code>todoList</code> object. Parsing the number value from our <code>input</code> to set the postion.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleCompleted</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">toggleCompletedPositionInput</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">getElementById</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;toggleCompletedPositionInput&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">todoList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">toggleCompleted</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">toggleCompletedPositionInput</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">valueAsNumber</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Finally we need to clear the <code>input</code>, which we can do by setting the value to an empty string.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleCompleted</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">toggleCompletedPositionInput</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">getElementById</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;toggleCompletedPositionInput&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">todoList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">toggleCompleted</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">toggleCompletedPositionInput</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">valueAsNumber</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">toggleCompletedPositionInput</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">value</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;&#39;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now we can add an item to see if it works. Enter the position of the item and hit the toggle completed button. If all went well we should see the following output in the console.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>My Todos: (x) new todo item </code></pre><p>Hit the button again and we should see:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>My Todos: ( ) new todo item </code></pre><h2 id="review-v8">Review v8</h2> <p>In version 8 of our application we looked at how we can effectively use <code>input</code>’s and get data from users. So we can use that data in our application.</p> <p>We learnt how to access different both <code>text</code> and <code>number</code> data types using <code>.value</code> and <code>.valueAsNumber</code> properties.</p> <p>We’re starting to see how using objects is an effective way of organising our code. Now we have all of our handler methods on a <code>handlers</code> object. This is a good way to group code related to our user interface.</p>

item.title: 2018 in Review
item.content:encoded: <p class="intro"> With 2018 drawing to a close, I’ve decided to share my first Year in Review. </p> <p>This is a chance to reflect and review my successes and failures over the past year, in a conscious effort to evaluate my progress, make improvements and insure I stay focused on the right stuff in the year ahead.</p> <p>Having struggled with the pressures of a goal setting approach in previous years, I was drawn to this method after reading <a href="https://jamesclear.com/atomic-habits" target="_blank" rel="noopener">James Clear’s Atomic Habits</a>.</p> <p>The format of my Year in Review is almost the same as James’. Nothing new, but new for me. I hope it will help refine my processes and set myself up for a productive year ahead.</p> <p>My Year in Review will answer the following three questions:</p> <ol> <li>What went well this year?</li> <li>What didn’t go so well this year?</li> <li>What did I learn?</li> </ol> <p>My review will also include my intentions for 2019 and the areas I wish to focus on, which I plan to use as a guide in the year to come.</p> <h2 id="1-what-went-well-this-year">1. What went well this year?</h2> <p><strong>Writing.</strong> I managed to write 13 articles across <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/">harrycresswell.com</a> and <a href="https://medium.com/@harrycresswell" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Medium</a>, and record notes on most of what I’ve learnt from courses (some of which I’ve published). My weekly Newsletter has been one of my most consistent projects this year, with the audience growing steadily and the content starting to show a clear direction. If I can continue on this path in 2019 I’ll be very happy.</p> <p><strong>In Detail.</strong> Perhaps the most successful project I work on, undoubtably down to the incredible mix of people involved. We all bring a different skill set and continue to use it as a vehicle to learn, experiment and collaborate. 2019 is set to be another good year for <a href="https://indtl.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">In Detail</a> with more energy focused on creating useful content for our readers, providing a service and doing what we can to make the jewellery industry more sustainable.</p> <p><strong>JavaScript.</strong> I finally got my act together and began to learn programming. Having made several attempts in the past I found taking some time out to focus on one thing, along with <a href="https://watchandcode.com/p/practical-javascript" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Gordon Zhu’s Practical JavaScript course</a> to be the key.</p> <p>I’m starting to see how the value gained in understanding a logical language like JavaScript can transcend and make improvements in other areas of my life.</p> <p><strong>Yoga and running.</strong> Although I didn’t track my yoga sessions this year, they were consistent. I think the fear of back pain drives my practice, as I’m all too aware how bad health makes everything else impossible. I’ve found a pattern of practicing yoga and running on alternate days to work best for me.</p> <p><strong>Travel.</strong> In 2018 I spent time in 7 different countries: England, Germany, United States, Portugal, Luxembourg, France and Austria. Luxembourg being the only new addition to the list.</p> <p>Notable places I enjoyed spending time this year were Lisbon for its food, people and good weather, Strasbourg for its architecture and amazing clash of cultures and New York for its relentless energy.</p> <p>I continued to spend much of my time in Hamburg which I now consider my home for part of the year.</p> <h3 id="year-in-numbers">Year in Numbers</h3> <ul> <li>Published Articles: 13</li> <li>Published Notes: 10</li> <li>Sent Newsletters: 40</li> <li>Runs: 52 (147.2 Miles)</li> <li>Books Read: 12</li> </ul> <h2 id="2-what-didnt-go-so-well-this-year">2. What didn’t go so well this year?</h2> <p><strong>Loss of family.</strong> In January I lost my Grandpa to Dementia. Although his final years were difficult, he had a long and happy life. I always admired his positive outlook on the world and fantastic ability to ignore what’s not important. I must remember him for how he was when I was growing up and try and forget those final years. I will miss him greatly.</p> <p><strong>Meditation and Climbing.</strong> I’ve put these two together as they share one thing in common – I failed miserably at both. In 2017 these two disciplines where a real lifeline for me. Climbing helped me with problem solving and taught me how to be more methodical with my approach to every day challenges. For building physical strength it’s one of the best practices I’ve found.</p> <p>Meditation, meanwhile, helped me with my composure, stress and focus. For one reason or another both fell by the wayside in 2018. I’d like to get back into a regular habit and disapline of practicing both next year.</p> <p><strong>Type Services.</strong> After a successful end to 2017 – where I released my first 3 typefaces in as many months – in 2018 I failed to release a single font. I must remind myself that good things take time, and whilst I have been slowing working away on a couple of new typefaces, I haven’t dedicated nearly enough time to the project. In 2019 I’m planning to change that and hope to deliver products more consistently.</p> <p><strong>Car Accident.</strong> Following 3 solid weeks of work converting our van to a camper, a car slammed into the back of us on the autobahn. It was our first day in a 2.5 month journey around Europe.</p> <p>Mentally this was a huge challenge, having rented out our apartments and facing life without a home whilst we waited for our van to be fixed. But looking back we’re fortunate we survived the crash. And the experience certainly helped us to face challenges head on and grow in ourselves. I’m glad to report the van is now back on the road.</p> <p><strong>Learning German.</strong> I had a positive start to the year, beginning A1.2 German at Deutsch Akademie in Hamburg. Sadly I failed to keep this up throughout the year, although my German girlfriend assures me my conversational German is improving – albeit slowly. 2019 Los geht’s!</p> <h2 id="3-what-did-i-learn">3. What did I learn?</h2> <p>I learned a lot in 2018. Here are some of the most important takeaways.</p> <p><strong>The best way to learn something new is to do a bit each day.</strong> Before now I had ‘Learn JavaScript‘ somewhere on my todo list. It wasn’t until I stuck with Gordon Zhu’s Practical JavaScript course that I realised how ridiculous this must sound.</p> <p>JavaScript is hard. Like any language it’s something you need to work at, on a daily basis if possible. To make this happen I took 2 solid months off work towards the end of this year and worked on my JavaScript every day, following Gordon‘s course almost exclusively. I’ve by no means got the language in its entirety, but it’s starting to click.</p> <p>For this reason my biggest achievement this year may have been ‘learning how to learn‘ – by sticking with it and showing up regularly. I realise this approach applies to any practice in life or anything you wish to improve at.</p> <p>In my case with JavaScript, rather than saying “Learn JavaScript” it might be be more useful to say “Practice your JavaScript each day” or “Spend 10 minutes a day building something with JavaScript”.</p> <p><strong>It’s important to step away from what you know and do something completely different.</strong> In September I took 3 weeks off work and converted a 2013 VW Transporter panel van into a camper, together with my girlfriend.</p> <p>It’s been over 10 years since I last worked with wood and the first time I’ve ever modified a vehicle or worked with electrics. There’s something incredibly cleansing about working with your hands. It was a welcome break from my usual day-to-day in front of a computer.</p> <p>The process taught me the importance of stepping away from a screen and applying myself to new problems, in different ways to those I’m used to. It also taught me the importance of action. No matter how much research you put in before hand, there’s something to be said for just getting started. Every situation will present its own set of problems which often are impossible to predict.</p> <p><strong>How to deal with setbacks and a change of plans.</strong> Life doesn’t always run smoothly. It often happens the way you least expect it. And you’ll sometimes find yourself living outside of your own control and well beyond the scope of your plans. This year this manifested itself in the form of the car crash I mentioned earlier.</p> <p>So what important lessons did I take from this? Setbacks are unavoidable. Plans will inevitably change, it’s how you react that’s most important. Even if you try to, it’s wasted energy trying to control everything. A better way is to focus on how you respond to the situation you find yourself in. If you can find the positives in a challenging situation, then you will thrive in life. No matter what the challenge, there are lessons to take away.</p> <p><strong>Success is the result of compound investment.</strong> Over the years I’ve started countless projects and failed to stick at them. The problem was, I struggled to realise that success takes time and regular input.</p> <p>Recently my good friend told me he was thinking about chucking in his music career to do something else, I said to him “It’s too late to stop now.” What I meant was; I could see how far he’s come with his sound and how much work he’s put in. It’s only a matter of time before all that time and effort pays off.</p> <p>This year I learnt the importance of seeing things through from start to finish and that success is the result of compound investment, not necessarily just some great idea or a moment of luck.</p> <h3 id="top-recommendations-in-2018">Top Recommendations in 2018</h3> <ul> <li><strong>Best Book:</strong> Atomic Habits by James Clear</li> <li><strong>Best (free) Course:</strong> Practical JavaScript by Gordon Zhu</li> <li><strong>Best article:</strong> Using Sketch Libraries to build a better UI design system</li> <li><strong>Best Documentary:</strong> Free Solo by Elizabeth Chai Vasarhelyi and Jimmy Chin</li> </ul> <h2 id="intentions-for-2019">Intentions for 2019</h2> <p>Rather than goal setting for any fixed outcome – which I’ve had little success with in past years – I’m using an intentional approach which focuses more on how I carry myself through each day, how I practice and how I conduct myself during my commitments.</p> <p>I’m treating these as a set of principles which I can use to guide my process and apply to various aspects of my life and work. The idea is to make lots of small improvements that I hope will have a big impact in the long run.</p> <p>My guiding principles for 2019 are:</p> <ul> <li>Be consistent</li> <li>Slow down</li> <li>Focus on less</li> <li>Document what you learn</li> <li>Give back what you can</li> </ul> <p><strong>Be Consistant.</strong> Consistency is everything. For me being consistent means showing up regularly (ideally daily) to practice the things I do. This is the best way I know how to form good habits and improve any chance of success I might have.</p> <p>Doing a little bit each day to compound long term returns not only applies to financial investment but investments in your health, education, work, relationships and progress in life. This is an important concept I try to take with me into yoga and meditation practice, running, learning JavaScript, German or whatever it may be.</p> <p><strong>Slow Down.</strong> I find I’m the most productive in life when I slow down and take time to reflect on whatever it is I’ve been doing. I find myself picking up concepts faster when I take the time to fully understand what’s in front of me. I retain more when I take on less.</p> <p>In 2019 I want to continue this philosophy. Using various methods such as note taking, habit tracking and writing from memory, to recall the things I’m learning, be more methodical and slow down the fast pace of life. This is the best way I found to prevent myself from speeding through life on auto-pilot.</p> <p><strong>Focus on less.</strong> In 2019 I’m challenging myself to open fewer browser tabs, spend less time on social media, commit to fewer obligations and add less items to my todo list.</p> <p>Instead, I want to focus my energy on a select few projects that I see as having the most potential and designate specific time blocks in my day to lower value tasks, like reading articles online, opening emails, use social media, etc.</p> <p>My aim is to find a deeper approach to work and get more done each day by focusing on fewer things. Like most people I’m increasingly aware of how my online consumption is effecting my ability to concentrate.</p> <p><strong>Document what you learn.</strong> My intention is to do a better job of documenting processes, recording workouts and improving habit tracking.</p> <p>Having little success with the various apps out there to help you do this, I’ve adopted a manual process of entering my daily workouts in an Airtable base, using the calendar view to record my workout sessions. I also make it a priority to document things I’m learning which I feel are important.</p> <p>I hope this will help me form daily habits and meeting my goal of becoming more consistent in the things I do.</p> <p><strong>Giving back what you can.</strong> In a world full of mindless consumption and little care for the environment, I feel it’s more important than ever to create and share great work that educates, to give back and strive for positive change in the world. Positive contribution has become the centre of everything I want to achieve.</p> <p>A question I’ll be asking myself regularly this year is; ”Am I having a positive impact on the people around me and the world we live in?”</p> <p>In 2019 my aim is to be more mindful about my consumption, continue with donations to <a href="https://onetreeplanted.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">onetreeplanted.org</a> and seek out new ways to support positive change in any way I can.</p> <h2 id="areas-of-focus-for-2019">Areas of Focus for 2019</h2> <p>With my intentions set, I want to briefly outline the key areas I wish to apply my focus, whilst keeping these intentions in mind.</p> <p>In previous years I’d make a list of specific things I want to achieve each quarter, though often by the 4th quarter I’d find myself with much of my list remaining. So this year I want to avoid that kind of pressure.</p> <p>Specific areas I wish to focus on:</p> <ol> <li><strong>Health:</strong> Resume a regular climbing and meditation practice. Continue running and practicing yoga on alternate days of the week.</li> <li><strong>Writing:</strong> Publish at least 15 well researched articles. Stick with my weekly newsletters.</li> <li><strong>Learning:</strong> My primary focus is on JavaScript programming and pursuing my interest in JAMStack technology. From a personal stand point I’d also like to continue improving my conversational German.</li> <li><strong>Design/Development:</strong> Move In Detail forward. Build more in ReactJS and with Gatsby. Get more creative with my type design.</li> <li><strong>Travel:</strong> I had a good year for travel in 2018 so I’d like to continue this and try and make it to at least 4 different countries. Travel is the best way I know to keep a broad and open mindset.</li> </ol> <h2 id="final-words">Final words</h2> <p>Thanks for reading my first Year in Review. I hope you’ve found this helpful in some capacity. It’s been a great chance to be more mindful and reflect on this past year whilst creating a plan for an intentional year ahead.</p> <p>If you’re not yet writing your own Year in Review, perhaps after reading this one you might consider writing one.</p> <p>If you have any questions or comments you can reach me on <a href="https://twitter.com/harrycresswell" target="_blank" rel="noopener">twitter</a>, I’d be happy to hear from you. Likewise, please consider sharing this with anyone you feel might find it useful.</p> <p>All the best for 2019. Here’s to a productive and prosperous new year.</p>

item.title: A Year in Review
item.content:encoded: <p>Whilst writing my <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/tags/year-in-review/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">year in review</a> this year it seemed like a good idea, and perhaps a useful exercise, to outline exactly what this means to me – why I write one and the approach I use to write it. I hope this may in some way be helpful for you, too.</p> <p>This is very much my own take on what has become an annual practice for many and I follow a format that has, so far, worked well for me. Here’s everything I can tell you about it.</p> <h2 id="why-i-write-a-review-of-my-year">Why I write a review of my year</h2> <p>I was drawn to the idea of writing an annual review after reading Atomic Habits by James Clear, in which he proposes that habits are the compound interest of self-improvement, and that success is the product of good daily habits. In other words, the effects of your habits multiply as you repeat them.</p> <p>James writes the following:</p> <blockquote> <p>“Improvement is not just about learning new habits, it’s also about fine-tuning them. Reflection and review ensures that you spend your time on the right things and make course corrections whenever necessary.“</p> </blockquote> <p>You might boil this down to the following:</p> <ol> <li>Build good daily habits.</li> <li>Reflect to identify what’s working and what isn’t.</li> <li>Fine-tune, drop ineffective habits, re-focus.</li> <li>Improve and become the person you wish to be</li> </ol> <p>I’ve found that writing an annual review is a great chance to work on points 2. and 3. from the list above.</p> <p>Reflection helps gives you a better perspective on things. It helps you become more self-aware and identify areas in your life that are in need of improvement. By making changes to whatever isn’t working, you re-focus, re-align and stay on track with whatever it is you are trying to achieve.</p> <h2 id="how-i-write-a-review-of-my-year">How I write a review of my year</h2> <p>I use the same format as James for my own review, it’s simple and works well, so I see no reason to change it. By review my progress, I aim to answer the following three questions:</p> <ol> <li>What went well this year?</li> <li>What didn’t go so well this year?</li> <li>What did I learn this year?</li> </ol> <p>James has his own reasons for asking these three questions, which I encourage you to explore further, however I’d like to outline what these questions mean to me.</p> <p>By asking “what went well this year” I ensure the year ends on a positive note.</p> <p>It’s so easy to focus on the bad stuff and forget the good things that have happened throughout the year. This question realigns those negative thoughts, encourages a positive mindset and confirms a successful year. It’s important to acknowlegde and celebrate those things that have gone well.</p> <p>By asking “What didn’t go so well this year?“ I hope to identify the areas I need to improve, so I can begin the year ahead with clear purpose and intention.</p> <p>As Shane Parish writes in <a href="https://fs.blog/tgmm/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Great Mental Models</a>;</p> <blockquote> <p>“You can’t improve if you don’t know what you‘re doing wrong. Admitting to your failures is the hardest part. But by doing so we can learn from them and avoid making them again.”</p> </blockquote> <p>Finally, by asking “What did I learn this year?” I remind myself that I’m making progress and heading in the right direction.</p> <p>It’s easy to fall into the trap of thinking you haven’t achieved much or that you haven’t made progress. The answers to this question help prevent these insecurities from manifesting and help give you a much needed boost for the year ahead.</p> <h2 id="final-words">Final words</h2> <p>Whatever you choose to call it, taking the time to reflect on your achievements by writing a year in review is a helpful exercise. The process will help you learn more about yourself and identify areas in your life that are in need of improvement.</p> <p>Reflection can bring a sense of perspective and writing a review each year can help you identify whether you are on track to becoming the person you wish to be.</p> <p>For more on this check out my <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/tags/year-in-review/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">year in review archive</a> and pick up a copy of <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/40121378-atomic-habits" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Atomic Habits</a> if you haven’t read it already. It’s an important book full of actionable advice.</p>

item.title: Working with the Debugger
item.content:encoded: <p>The process of going through your JavaScript and fixing issues with your code is called ‘debugging’.</p> <p>The ‘debugger’ is a powerful tool we can use to assist us in the debugging process. Debugger is built into the browser and can be found in the chrome dev tools.</p> <p>We can use the debugger to step through our methods in order to see what’s happening line by line.</p> <p>To do this we need to add <code>debugger;</code> to the first line within our method.</p> <p>Now when we call the method, Debugger will pause the program as it’s running, so we can step though and see what’s happening, at every stage of the method.</p> <h2 id="todolistdisplaytodos">todoList.displayTodos</h2> <p>In our displayTodos method, we can add <code>debugger;</code> to the first line of the function:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">displayTodos</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">debugger</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">length</span> <span class="o">===</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;Your todo list is empty!&#39;</span><span class="p">)</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;My Todos:&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">&lt;</span> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">length</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span><span class="o">++</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">i</span><span class="p">].</span><span class="nx">completed</span> <span class="o">===</span> <span class="kc">true</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;(x)&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">i</span><span class="p">].</span><span class="nx">todoText</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;( )&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">i</span><span class="p">].</span><span class="nx">todoText</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">},</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now when we run <code>todoList.displayTodos();</code> in the console, the program will pause and debugger will launch in the Sources panel of Inspect.</p> <p>At the top of the screen we see ‘Paused in debugger’ and notice the script in highlighted on the <code>debugger;</code> statement.</p> <p>From here we can inspect the different elements of our program to help us debug our code.</p> <p>On the right side, we can see the different variables in our program. Expand <code>this</code> and see that it’s an Object, with all our different methods on it.</p> <h3 id="stepping-through-the-code">Stepping through the code</h3> <p>On the right side you will see a button ‘Step over next function call’, when pressed this will go to the next line of our program, you’ll see the highlighted line changes too the one below.</p> <p>If you hover over the values in the program, you can see what they are.</p> <p>We can hit the Step button again to run the next line and step through the program to the end. Hit the blue button; ‘Resume script execution’ to get back to the console and run the script again.</p> <p>Remember to remove <code>debugger;</code> from your program so the code works as it did before.</p> <h3 id="todolistaddtodo">todoList.addTodo</h3> <p>For our <code>addTodo</code> method we can do the exact same thing as before and add <code>debugger;</code> to the first line inside the method.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">addTodo</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">todoText</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">debugger</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">push</span><span class="p">({</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">todoText</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">todoText</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">completed</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kc">false</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">});</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">displayTodos</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">},</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h4 id="step-1-run-debugger">Step 1: run debugger</h4> <p>Now run the method <code>todoList.addTodo('runnin the debugger');</code></p> <p>The debugger will pause the program and launch. We can see debugger has paused on the line we added <code>debugger;</code>.</p> <h4 id="step-2-stepping-over">Step 2: Stepping over</h4> <p>Step over the line with the ‘Step over next function call’ button. Here we can hover over <code>this.todos</code> and see the value is currently 0.</p> <p>Step over once more and here we’re pushing an item to the <code>todos</code> array. You can also see the value of the parameter <code>todoText</code> which equals ‘runnin the debugger’.</p> <p>Step over again. Now we’ve pushed an item to <code>todos</code>. on the right side we expand the <code>this</code> object, and the <code>todos</code> property will now show us an array with 1 item. If you expand the first item, you will see ‘runnin the debugger’ as the value of <code>todoText</code>.</p> <p>Step over to complete the function. Then hit ‘resume script execution’ to exit the debugger.</p> <p>Now you will see ‘runnin the debugger’ printed to the console.</p> <h4 id="step-3-stepping-into-a-function-call">Step 3: Stepping into a function call</h4> <p>Now add another todo item.</p> <p><code>todoList.addTodo('adding something extra');</code></p> <p>The debugger will pause as expected. Next, keep stepping through until you reach the last section of the method; <code>this.displayTodos();</code>.</p> <p>Here we can click the down arrow; ’step into the next function call’, to inspect <code>displayTodos</code>. Now we’re in the <code>displayTodos</code>.</p> <p>As we now have 2 items in our <code>todos</code> array, <code>todos.length</code> is not equal to 0, so when we step through the function it skips the next line. Instead it enters our <code>else</code> statement.</p> <p>Here we can see step through our <code>for</code> loop to see how it works.</p> <h4 id="step-4-stepping-through-a-for-loop">Step 4: Stepping through a for loop</h4> <p>If we step through, we can see how the value of <code>i</code> (our initialisation variable) increases each time the loop is run.</p> <p>It does this until we reach the <code>todos.length</code> condition, which in this case is 2.</p> <p>When it hits 2, and the condition is no longer true, so we exit the <code>for</code> loop. And our script ends.</p> <p>We can hit the blue button to resume our script. Don’t forget to remove <code>debugger;</code> for the script to run as normal.</p> <h2 id="todolistchangetodo">todoList.changeTodo</h2> <p>Now let’a do the same with the <code>changeTodo</code> method by adding <code>debugger</code> to our script.</p> <p>Add a new item so we can change it <code>todoList.addTodo('something to change');</code></p> <p>Next, run the <code>changeTodo</code> method, <code>todoList.changeTodo(0, 'changed');</code>. Now the debugger will pause the program.</p> <p>From here you can see the arguments we entered in yellow; position is 0 and <code>todoText</code> is ‘changed’.</p> <p>Now step over to the next line. Then if we go into Scope on the right hand side, expand the <code>this</code> object, then expand the <code>todos</code> array and you will see the object in the 0 position has a <code>todoText</code> property with the value <code>'something to change'</code>.</p> <p>Step over again and we will see this value update to <code>'changed'</code>.</p> <p>We’ve now reach the <code>displayTodos</code> method.</p> <h2 id="todolistdeletetodo">todoList.deleteTodo</h2> <p>Move <code>debugger;</code> to the <code>deleteTodos</code> method, then add a todo item:</p> <p><code>todoList.addTodo('delete this');</code></p> <p>Next run <code>todoList.deleteTodo(0);</code> to pause the script and run the debugger.</p> <p>Now we’re in the debugger and we can see the position is 0, as that’s what we set. Step over to the next line.</p> <p><code>this.todos.splice(postion, 1);</code></p> <p>This is going to delete whatever is at position 0 and delete 1 item, in our case the value <code>'delete this'</code>.</p> <p>In the Scope panel on the right, watch the value of <code>todos</code> Array go from <code>todos: Array[1]</code> to <code>todos: Array[0]</code>, as you step over to the next line.</p> <p>Now we can resume our script.</p> <h2 id="todolisttogglecompleted">todoList.toggleCompleted</h2> <p>Move the debugger statement into <code>toggleCompleted</code>.</p> <p>Add a new todo item; <code>todoList.addTodo('to be toggled');</code> then toggle the item to enter debugger.</p> <p><code>todoList.toggleCompleted(0);</code></p> <p>Step over to see we’re grabbing <code>this.todos</code> item in position 0. Now <code>todo</code> is undefined.</p> <p>Step over again, now <code>todo</code> is defined. And if you hover over you can see <code>completed: false</code> and <code>todoText: 'to be toggled'</code>. This is the item we’re adding.</p> <p>When we step over the next line you’ll see <code>completed: true</code>.</p> <h2 id="todolisttoggleall">TodoList.toggleAll</h2> <p>Start by moving the <code>debugger;</code> statement to the beginning of the <code>toggleAll</code> method, as we’ve done before.</p> <p>Next we’ll need to add some data, so we have something to toggle.</p> <p><code>todoList.addTodo('this is true');</code></p> <p>Next make the item true. We can do this using the <code>toggleCompleted</code> method, parsing in 0, for the position of our new item.</p> <p><code>todoList.toggleCompleted(0);</code></p> <p>The console should return:</p> <p><code>My Todos:(x) this is true</code></p> <p>Now we can use <code>todoList.toggleAll();</code> to pause the script and run the debugger.</p> <h3 id="stepping-through-code-with-debugger">Stepping through code with debugger</h3> <p>Step over the first line and you’ll see we’re saving the length of our todos array to the variable <code>totalTodos</code>. This should show our 1 item.</p> <p>Next we start <code>completedTodos</code> at 0, so we can count up the number. In other words, each time we find a completed item in the array, we can increase <code>completedTodos</code> by 1.</p> <p>This time when we step over we reach the <code>for</code> loop. Step over again to set the undefined <code>i</code> to 0. As 0 is less than <code>totalTodos</code> of 1, we go into the <code>for</code> loop when we step over.</p> <p>Here we have a condition that states <code>if</code> the completed property of our todos item is set to <code>true</code> (which in our case it is), we enter the <code>if</code> statement and increase <code>completedTodos</code> by 1. We’re using the value of <code>i</code> to grab the todo item at position 0.</p> <p>Step over once more and you’ll see <code>completedTodos</code> is now set to 1.</p> <p>At this point we return to the start of the <code>for</code> loop, where our final expression <code>i++</code> increases <code>i</code> by 1. As 1 is no longer less than 1, but equal to 1, we leave the <code>for</code> loop and arrive at Case 1.</p> <p>In Case 1 we check if everything is true, in which case we will make everything false.</p> <p>We do this by checking if <code>completedTodos</code> is equals to <code>totalTodos</code>. In our case they are both 1, so the condition is <code>true</code>.</p> <p>As the condition is true, we go into the <code>if</code> statement and we reach a <code>for</code> loop. Here <code>i</code> is reset to 0. Which is less than <code>totalTodos</code>, currently 1. So we go into the <code>for</code> loop when we step over again.</p> <p>Now we grab the only item we have, in position 0, and set completed to <code>false</code>.</p> <p>Finally, we return to the start of the <code>for</code> loop and increment <code>i</code> by 1. When we evaluate the condition again it’s no longer true, as 1 is not less than our <code>totalTodos</code> which is 1. Now we exit the <code>for</code> loop.</p> <p>This time we skip our <code>else</code> statement in case 2 because case 1 was true.</p> <h2 id="use-the-debugger-all-the-time">Use the debugger all the time</h2> <p>Debugger helps you solve problems with your code before you start asking questions. Use debugger to understand your code even if theres nothing wrong with it.</p> <p>If you have a question like what is this line of code doing, use the debugger.</p> <p>Don’t ask questions that the debugger can answer.</p> <h2 id="focus-on-understanding-not-building-from-scratch">Focus on understanding, not building from scratch</h2> <p>Focus on understanding code, not building from scratch. Use the debugger to understand the code deeply. Then forget about it.</p>

item.title: HTML and the DOM
item.content:encoded: <p>This is Part 7 of my notes on Gordon Zhu’s <a href="https://watchandcode.com/p/practical-javascript" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical JavaScript</a>. In this part we learn about the Document Object Model and begin building the front-end HTML to allow users to interface with our application.</p> <h2 id="building-a-todo-app-v70">Building a todo app v.7.0</h2> <p>In version 7, we want to start building a user interface that people can interact with, type into, click on etc, so they don’t have to work on the console. We’ll start by creating 2 buttons which run 2 of our methods.</p> <h2 id="requirements">Requirements</h2> <ul> <li>There should be a “Display todos” button and a “Toggle all” button in the app.</li> <li>Clicking “Display todos” should run <code>todoList.displayTodos</code></li> <li>Clicking “Toggle all” should run <code>todoList.toggleAll</code></li> </ul> <h2 id="what-is-the-dom">What is the DOM?</h2> <p>Where HTML is plain text which gives the browser information about whats on the page. The Document Object Modal (DOM) is the browsers interpretation of the HTML.</p> <p>The browser uses the information in your HTML to build an understanding of what the document looks like.</p> <p>If you’ve ever right clicked on your website and hit Inspect Element, you will see how the browser has interpreted your document. The code the browser reveals is the DOM.</p> <p>In other words, the DOM represents the HTML code you write and provides a way to interact with the HTML objects.</p> <p>The DOM tree is how the nodes in each HTML document are organised. Think of this as a family tree, full of parents, siblings and children. The nodes are essentially the HTML tags you write. When you Inspect Element and drill down through the different levels of your HTML code you are moving through the DOM tree.</p> <p>The distinction between plain HTML and the DOM is subtle but it’s important to understand the difference.</p> <h2 id="step-1-there-should-be-display-todos-and-toggle-all-buttons-in-the-app">Step 1: There should be “Display todos” and “Toggle all” buttons in the app</h2> <p>First we need to go into our HTML document and create 2 buttons, one for displaying todos and one for toggling all todos.</p> <p>Inside the body tags, we can write:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">button</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Display Todos<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">button</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">button</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Toggle All<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">button</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="step-2-clicking-display-todos-should-run-todolistdisplaytodos">Step 2: Clicking “Display todos” should run todoList.displayTodos</h2> <p>Next we need our new display todos button to run the <code>todoList.displayTodos</code> method we made previously.</p> <p>In our JavaScript code we can start by writing out some comments for what we want to happen.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>// 1. We want to get access to the display todos button. // 2. We want to run displayTodos method, when someone clicks the display todos button </code></pre><h3 id="creating-a-reference-to-the-button">Creating a reference to the button</h3> <p>Starting with the first requirement, we can create a new variable called <code>displayTodosButton</code> so we can reference the button.</p> <p>Then, in order to access the DOM, we can use the <code>document</code> object, which is built into JavaScript. The <code>document</code> object has methods on it that allow you to select a specific element. One of these methods is called <code>getElementById</code> which will grab an <code>id</code> on an element.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// 1. We want to get access to the display todos button. </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">displayTodosButton</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">getElementById</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In order for the <code>getElementById</code> method to run we will need to head back to our HTML and add an <code>id</code> to our display todos button.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">button</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;displayTodosButton&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Display Todos </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">button</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This will allow us to reference this specific button in our JavaScript:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// 1. We want to get access to the display todos button. </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">displayTodosButton</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">getElementById</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;displayTodosButton&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="moving-scriptjs-references-to-the-end-of-the-page">Moving script.js references to the end of the page</h3> <p>Now our code will grab the button we want. Let’s add a <code>console.log</code> to our code to check it‘s working correctly.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// 1. We want to get access to the display todos button. </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">displayTodosButton</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">getElementById</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;displayTodosButton&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> <span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">displayTodosButton</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>If we run our code you might well see an error, this is likely because of how we’re loading the JavaScript. Check to see if your link to <code>script.js</code> is inside the <code>&lt;head&gt;</code> of your document. If it is, remove it from the head and move it just above the closing <code>&lt;/body&gt;</code> tag.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">script</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;script.js&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">script</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">body</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now the browser can see the <code>id</code> in the HTML document before it runs the JavaScript code. Whereas before, we were loading the JavaScript before the browser parsed the HTML, which is no good.</p> <p>This time when we run the code, our error should have disappeared and instead we see</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">button</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;displayTodosButton</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Display Todos<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">button</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Great, our code is working as expected.</p> <h3 id="run-displaytodos-method">run displayTodos method</h3> <p>Now we can focus on our second requirement. Here we want to run the display todos method when someone clicks the displays todo button.</p> <p>First, we grab our <code>displayTodosButton</code> variable, then add an event listener, which allows us to do something when an even happens. We can use the <code>addEventListener</code> method for this.</p> <p>In this case we’re listening for anytime someone clicks the button, and when that happens it runs a function which runs the <code>displayTodos</code> method.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// 1. We want to get access to the display todos button. </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">displayTodosButton</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">getElementById</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;displayTodosButton&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">displayTodosButton</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// 2. We want to run displayTodos method, when someone clicks the display todos button. </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">displayTodosButton</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">addEventListener</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;click&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">todoList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">displayTodos</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">});</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now we can run our code to make sure its working. If all went well the console should return <code>“Your todo list is empty!”</code></p> <p>Now we can clean up our code by removing the comments and the <code>console.log</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">displayTodosButton</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">getElementById</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;displayTodosButton&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">displayTodosButton</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">addEventListener</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;click&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">todoList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">displayTodos</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">});</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="step-3-clicking-toggle-all-should-run-todolisttoggleall">Step 3: Clicking “Toggle all” should run todoList.toggleAll</h2> <p>The toggle all button will work exactly the same.</p> <p>First we need to get a reference to the toggle all button via an <code>id</code>, so we start by giving the button an <code>id</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">button</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;toggleAllButton&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Toggle All<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">button</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next we need to grab the button, so create the variable <code>toggleAllButton</code> and use the <code>getElementById</code> method as before and parse in the <code>id</code> we just created.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">toggleAllButton</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">getElementById</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;toggleAllButton&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next we need to add the event listener to it, to listen for clicks.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">toggleAllButton</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">document</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">getElementById</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;toggleAllButton&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleAllButton</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">addEventListener</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;click&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kd">function</span> <span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">todoList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">toggleAll</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">});</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now try adding some todo items to your todo list with:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>todoList.addTodo(‘first’); todoList.addTodo(‘second’); </code></pre><p>Now try clicking the toggle all button to change the todos to completed, then click again to make incomplete.</p> <h2 id="v70-review">v.7.0 Review</h2> <p>In version 7 we started moving away from the console and into the actual webpage, where people can interface with our todo app.</p> <p>We learnt about the DOM and the structure of HTML and where we need to put our JavaScript link.</p> <p>Then we learnt about how we can access the DOM using the <code>document</code> method and then grab the buttons on our page via an <code>id</code> using the <code>getElementById</code> method.</p> <p>We also learnt about event listeners and the <code>addEventListener</code> method, using a <code>click</code> event, which allows us to run some code when someone clicks a button. The <code>click</code> is just one of many types of events you can use to handle events inside of the DOM.</p>

item.title: Data Types and Comparisons
item.content:encoded: <p>In JavaScript there are 2 categories of data types:</p> <ul> <li>Objects</li> <li>Primitives</li> </ul> <h2 id="objects">Objects</h2> <p>Objects can be as complicated as you want. Objects use curly braces.</p> <ul> <li><code>{} // todoList, arrays, functions</code></li> </ul> <h2 id="primitives">Primitives</h2> <p>Primitives are the simple building blocks of JavaScript, they only have 1 form. You can’t make them complicated.</p> <ul> <li>String (formal name for text, in between quotes, very limited data type) // ‘This is a string!’</li> <li>Number (same as in math) // 1, 2, 3, 4 …</li> <li>Boolean (super limited data type) // true, false</li> <li>Undefined // Value that hasn’t yet been set</li> <li>Null // ‘Nothing’</li> </ul> <h3 id="difference-between-undefined-and-null">Difference between &lsquo;undefined&rsquo; and &rsquo;null&rsquo;</h3> <p>Undefined is simply a value which hasn’t yet been set, whereas null literally means nothing. For example if you have a variable but haven’t given it a value yet it will be <code>undefined</code>.</p> <p>Null can be used to represent say a variable for someones test score, where the score is marked from 0-100, but they haven’t yet taken the test. In this case the test score would be equal to <code>null</code>. Null means explicitly nothing.</p> <h2 id="is-it-a-primitive-or-an-object">Is it a primitive or an object?</h2> <p>If you’re unsure if something is an Object or a Primitive, ask yourself it it fits into one of the primitive categories above. If it doesn’t then it’s an Object.</p> <h2 id="comparisons-with-primitive-data-types">Comparisons with primitive data types</h2> <p>Primitive comparisons work just like in Math. General rule, if they look the same they probably are the same.</p> <h3 id="comparisons-with-strings">Comparisons with Strings</h3> <p>For example:</p> <ul> <li><code>'harry' === 'harry'</code> would return <code>true</code> they are the same thing</li> <li><code>'harry1' === 'harry'</code> would return <code>false</code>, they are different</li> </ul> <h3 id="comparisons-with-numbers">Comparisons with Numbers</h3> <p>For example:</p> <ul> <li><code>0 &lt; 10</code> is <code>true</code>.</li> <li><code>0 = 0</code> is the same thing so it’s also <code>true</code></li> <li><code>1 === 1</code> is <code>true</code></li> <li>Whereas <code>1 === 2</code> would return <code>false</code>.</li> <li><code>100 === 100</code> would return <code>true</code></li> </ul> <p>Number comparisons work as you would expect.</p> <h3 id="comparisons-with-booleans">Comparisons with Booleans</h3> <p>For example:</p> <ul> <li><code>true === true</code> returns <code>true</code></li> <li><code>true === false</code> returns <code>false</code></li> <li><code>false === false</code> returns <code>true</code></li> </ul> <h3 id="comparisons-of-undefined-and-null">Comparisons of Undefined and Null</h3> <p>For example:</p> <ul> <li><code>undefined === undefined</code> will return <code>true</code></li> <li><code>null === null</code> will also return <code>true</code></li> </ul> <p>To summarise, primitive comparisons work exactly as you would expect.</p> <h2 id="comparisons-with-object-data-types">Comparisons with Object data types</h2> <p>Comparisons with Objects works completely different from primitive comparisons, the behaviour is unexpected.</p> <p>For example, the comparison between 2 empty objects returns false:</p> <p><code>{} === {}</code> returns <code>false</code></p> <p>As does the comparison of 2 arrays which appear the same:</p> <p><code>[1, 2, 3] === [1, 2, 3]</code> returns <code>false</code>.</p> <h3 id="understanding-why-object-comparisons-behave-differently">Understanding why Object comparisons behave differently</h3> <p>In object comparisons JavaScript is actually comparing the addresses it assigns to the objects.</p> <p>In our example from before, imagine our 2 empty objects are actually houses:</p> <p><code>{} === {}</code></p> <p>JavaScript sees these as 2 separate houses in 2 different locations; <code>house1</code> and <code>house2</code>. Much like houses in the real world have different addresses, these are actuallu 2 separate objects, with 2 separate addresses. Although they might look the same they in fact different.</p> <p>When you create an object in JavaScript, it saves that object at unique location in memory.</p> <p>In this case, 3 objects – all identical in the fact they are empty – are saved at different memory addresses.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>{} // Memory Address 1 {} // Memory Address 2 {} // Memory Address 3 </code></pre><p>When JavaScript is comparing the first object to the second, it’s actually comparing the memory addresses. It’s doing this to understand if we’re looking at the exact same object or 2 separate objects.</p> <p>A general rule of thumb, if you’re comparing 2 objects it will be <code>false</code>. The only time you can have an object comparison equal is if you assign the object to a variable and compare those variables.</p> <p>&rsquo;&rsquo; var houseA = {}; houseA === houseAtrue</p> <p>As you see in the example above, this comparison returns <code>true</code>.</p> <h2 id="comparisons-review">Comparisons review</h2> <p>Primitive comparisons work just as you expect.</p> <p><code>2 == 2</code> returns <code>true</code>, because 2 is 2. JavaScript is comparing the value of the data. It doesn’t care about the memory address or location of where its stored.</p> <p>Objects are references, memory addresses of where an object is saved. When you save an Object, Javascript is not looking at the values between the curly brackets, it’s actually saving a reference so it can refer to the value.</p> <p>So although the value might appear the same, JavaScript is actually looking at the memory address which is different.</p> <p>So remember, when you’re comparing objects you’re actually comparing 2 memory addresses.</p> <h2 id="code-example-1">Code example 1</h2> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">myPrimitive</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">myObject</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="nx">name</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">&#39;harry&#39;</span><span class="p">};</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Let’s try and understand what’s going on in the example above. In line 1, JavaScript creates the variable <code>myPrimitive</code>, then stores the number <code>10</code> as the value inside the variable.</p> <p>In line 2, first we’re telling JavaScript creates the variable <code>myObject</code>. Then we tell JavaScript to create a new object with the name property <code>harry</code>. JavaScript creates the new object and gives it a memory address. It’s that memory address thats actually stored inside the <code>myObject</code> variable.</p> <p>The diagram below should help illustrate how this works.</p> <figure> <video autoplay loop muted="muted" poster="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1542885381/hc/practical-javascript-data-types-comparisons-harry-cresswell-example-1.jpg"> <source type="video/mp4" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1542885381/hc/practical-javascript-data-types-comparisons-harry-cresswell-example-1.mp4"> <source type="video/webm" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1542885381/hc/practical-javascript-data-types-comparisons-harry-cresswell-example-1.webm"> Your browser does not support HTML5 video tag. <a href="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1542885381/hc/practical-javascript-data-types-comparisons-harry-cresswell-example-1.gif">Click here to view original GIF</a> </video> <figcaption>Understanding how data is stored in objects example 1</figcaption> </figure> <h2 id="code-example-2">Code example 2</h2> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">myHouse</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="nx">color</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">&#39;blue&#39;</span><span class="p">};</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">myHouse</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">color</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;red&#39;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In line 1 of the example above, JavaScript starts by creating a variable called <code>myHouse</code>. Then it creates an object which has the color property equal to <code>blue</code>. Once it’s created it’ll have a memory address which is stored inside the variable.</p> <p>In line 2, we’re modifying the color property on the <code>myHouse</code> object.</p> <p>First JavaScript looks at <code>myHouse</code>, it sees there’s a memory address, so it travels to that memory address and finds the <code>myHouse</code> object. The next thing we’re doing is telling JavaScript to look at the <code>color</code> property. That completes the left hand side of line 2.</p> <p>On the right hand side of line 2, we’re telling JavaScript to change the value of the color property on the <code>myHouse</code> object to <code>'red'</code>.</p> <p>The diagram below should help illustrate how this works.</p> <figure> <video autoplay loop muted="muted" poster="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1542887659/hc/practical-javascript-data-types-comparisons-harry-cresswell-example-2.jpg"> <source type="video/mp4" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1542887659/hc/practical-javascript-data-types-comparisons-harry-cresswell-example-2.mp4"> <source type="video/webm" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1542887659/hc/practical-javascript-data-types-comparisons-harry-cresswell-example-2.webm"> Your browser does not support HTML5 video tag. <a href="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1542887659/hc/practical-javascript-data-types-comparisons-harry-cresswell-example-2.gif">Click here to view original GIF</a> </video> <figcaption>Understanding how data is stored in objects example 2</figcaption> </figure> <h2 id="code-example-3">Code example 3</h2> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">myHouse</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="nx">color</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">&#39;blue&#39;</span><span class="p">};</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">color</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">myHouse</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">color</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">color</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;red&#39;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Here in line 1, we’re telling JavaScript to create a variable called <code>myHouse</code>. Then we’re creating an object with the color property value of blue. Next JavaScript will create a memory address and store that in the variable.</p> <p>In line 2, we’re creating another variable, this time called <code>color</code>, and telling JavaScript to look at the color property on the <code>myHouse</code> object. JavaScript sees the memory address stored in the <code>myHouse</code> variable, travels to the object, and finds the color property. JavaScript then stores the value of the color property; in this case <code>'blue</code>, inside the <code>color</code> variable.</p> <p>In line 3, all we’re doing is telling JavaScript to change the value store in the <code>color</code> variable to <code>'red'</code>.</p> <p>The diagram below should help illustrate how this works.</p> <figure> <video autoplay loop muted="muted" poster="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1542888475/hc/practical-javascript-data-types-comparisons-harry-cresswell-example-3.jpg"> <source type="video/mp4"
