src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1542888475/hc/practical-javascript-data-types-comparisons-harry-cresswell-example-3.webm"> Your browser does not support HTML5 video tag. <a href="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1542888475/hc/practical-javascript-data-types-comparisons-harry-cresswell-example-3.gif">Click here to view original GIF</a> </video> <figcaption>Understanding how data is stored in objects example 3</figcaption> </figure> <h2 id="code-example-4">Code example 4</h2> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">myHouse1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="nx">color</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">&#39;blue&#39;</span><span class="p">};</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">myHouse2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">myHouse1</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">myHouse2</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">color</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;red&#39;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In this example, on the left of line 1 JavaScript creates a variable called <code>myHouse1</code>. On the right side JavaScript creates an object that has the color property blue. JavaScript then saves a memory address pointing to the object inside the variable <code>myHouse1</code>.</p> <p>In line 2, we create a new variable called <code>myHouse2</code>, and set the value to the same value stored in the <code>myHouse1</code> variable. In this case; the same memory address which leads to the object created in line 1.</p> <p>In line 3, on the left side we’re telling JavaScript to go to the <code>myHouse2</code> variable. In the <code>myHouse2</code> variable JavaScript finds the memory address, follows the memory address to the object associated with that memory address.</p> <p>On the right side, we’re telling JavaScript to update the value it finds in the object to <code>red</code>.</p> <p>The diagram below should help illustrate how this works.</p> <figure> <video autoplay loop muted="muted" poster="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1542888888/hc/practical-javascript-data-types-comparisons-harry-cresswell-example-4.jpg"> <source type="video/mp4" class="p">{</span><span class="nx">color</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">&#39;blue&#39;</span><span class="p">};</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span Then we create an object with the color property <code>‘blue’</code>. Then JavaScript creates a memory address associated with this object and stores it in the variable <code>myHouse1</code>.</p> <p>In line 2, we create a new variable called <code>myHouse2</code>. Then we create another object with the color property <code>blue</code>. Javascript then stores a new memory address inside <code>myHouse2</code>. This time leading to the second object.</p> <p>We now have 2 objects and 2 memory addresses.</p> <p>In line 3, on the left side we’re telling JavaScript to look at the value stored inside <code>myHouse2</code>. In this case that’s the memory address leading to our second object. JavaScript follows this memory address and finds the color property <code>blue</code>. In the right side of line 3 we’re telling JavaScript to change the value of this color property to <code>red</code>.</p> <p>The diagram below should help illustrate how this works.</p> <figure> <video autoplay loop muted="muted" poster="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1542889069/hc/practical-javascript-data-types-comparisons-harry-cresswell-example-5.jpg"> <source type="video/mp4" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1542889069/hc/practical-javascript-data-types-comparisons-harry-cresswell-example-5.mp4"> <source type="video/webm" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1542889069/hc/practical-javascript-data-types-comparisons-harry-cresswell-example-5.webm"> Your browser does not support HTML5 video tag. <a href="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1542889069/hc/practical-javascript-data-types-comparisons-harry-cresswell-example-5.gif">Click here to view original GIF</a> </video> <figcaption>Understanding how data is stored in objects example 4</figcaption> </figure>

item.title: Thinking in Code
item.content:encoded: <p>This is Part 6 of my notes on Gordon Zhu’s <a href="https://watchandcode.com/p/practical-javascript" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical JavaScript</a>.</p> <h2 id="building-a-todo-app-v60">Building a todo app v.6.0</h2> <p>In version 6 we’ll work on 1 feature which toggles todos as complete or incomplete.</p> <p>You can see how this works in the finished app <a href="http://todomvc.com/examples/vanillajs/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">here</a>.</p> <p>In the example, use the chevron to the left of the input box to toggle the todos you create.</p> <p>You’ll notice a few cases, if everything is <code>false</code> (items are incomplete) and you click toggle, everything will be <code>true</code>. If some of the items are <code>true</code> (complete), toggle will make the rest <code>true</code> too.</p> <p>The only case it will make every todo <code>false</code> (incomplete) is when all items are <code>true</code> (complete). In every other case, clicking the toggle button will make all todo items <code>true</code>.</p> <p>We can represent this in our requirements.</p> <h2 id="requirements">Requirements</h2> <ul> <li><code>.toggleAll</code>: If everything’s true, make everything false.</li> <li><code>.toggleAll</code>: Otherwise, make everything true.</li> </ul> <h2 id="step-1-if-everythings-true-make-everything-false">Step 1: If everything’s true, make everything false</h2> <p>Our first step is to work on a solution where if everything is <code>true</code> make everything <code>false</code>.</p> <p>We want to do this in a new method called <code>toggleAll</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleAll</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// If everything’s true, make everything false </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="comparing-completedtodos-to-totaltodos">Comparing completedTodos to totalTodos</h3> <p>To make this happen we could use an <code>if</code> statement and count the the number of <code>completedTodos</code>, to see if it equals the number of <code>totalTodos</code>.</p> <p>If that returns <code>true</code>, we’d know we we’d met the first condition.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleAll</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// If everything’s true </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">completedTodos</span> <span class="o">===</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Make everything false </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="setting-the-required-variables">Setting the required variables</h3> <p>The problem now is that the variables <code>completedTodos</code> and <code>totalTodos</code> don’t exist yet, so we need to create those next.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleAll</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">length</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">completedTodos</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// If everything’s true </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">completedTodos</span> <span class="o">===</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Make everything false </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>For our <code>totalTodos</code> variable, we can use <code>this.todos.length</code> to check the number of items in our todo list, so this works great.</p> <p><code>completedTodos</code> is harder to get. So it’s a safe assumption to start with 0, meaning we have zero completed todos. Then we can look through all the items in our todo list to see how many are completed. If we see a todo is completed we can increase the value of <code>completedTodos</code> by 1. To make this happen we can use a <code>for</code> loop, which loops through all our items.</p> <h3 id="looping-through-todos">Looping through todos</h3> <p>In the first part of our <code>for</code> loop we can use a variable <code>i = 0</code> again as a counter. We want to keep going whilst <code>i</code> is less than the <code>totalTodos</code>, then increment <code>i</code> by 1 using <code>i++</code>. This will loop through our todos.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleAll</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">length</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">completedTodos</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Count number of completed todos </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">&lt;</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span><span class="o">++</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// If everything’s true </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">completedTodos</span> <span class="o">===</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Make everything false </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="check-if-todo-is-completed-update-completedtodos-variable">Check if todo is completed, update completedTodos variable</h3> <p>Then we want to look at each todo item in our array. Using <code>if</code> we can check to see if a specific todo is completed with <code>this.todos[i].completed === true</code>.</p> <p>And then with <code>completedTodos++</code>, increment completedTodos by 1 if the statement is <code>true</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleAll</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">length</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">completedTodos</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Count number of completed todos </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">&lt;</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span><span class="o">++</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">i</span><span class="p">].</span><span class="nx">completed</span> <span class="o">===</span> <span class="kc">true</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">completedTodos</span><span class="o">++</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// If everything’s true </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">completedTodos</span> <span class="o">===</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Make everything false </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This code will go through and return the number of todos that are completed, updating the value in our <code>completedTodos</code> variable with the number of completed todos.</p> <h3 id="make-false-if-all-todos-are-true">Make false if all todos are true</h3> <p>To make everything <code>false</code> if all our todos are set to <code>true</code>, we can use the exact same <code>for</code> loop as before.</p> <p>This time using <code>this.todos[i].completed = false;</code> to set all todos to <code>false</code>, if the number of <code>completedTodos</code> is equal to the number of <code>totalTodos</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleAll</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">length</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">completedTodos</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Count number of completed todos </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">&lt;</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span><span class="o">++</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">i</span><span class="p">].</span><span class="nx">completed</span> <span class="o">===</span> <span class="kc">true</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">completedTodos</span><span class="o">++</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Case 1: If everything’s true, make everything false </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">completedTodos</span> <span class="o">===</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">&lt;</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span><span class="o">++</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">i</span><span class="p">].</span><span class="nx">completed</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">false</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="understanding-the-code">Understanding the code</h3> <p>So first we check to see if the number of completedTodos is the same as the number of totalTodos. If that returns <code>true</code>, then we’ll go through and make all the items false.</p> <p>In order to get the number of completedTodos in the first place, we use a <code>for</code> loop to count through our todos and check to see if completed is set to <code>true</code>, in which case we would update the number in our <code>completedTodos</code> variable.</p> <h3 id="test-the-code-in-the-console">Test the code in the console</h3> <p>Now we can test the code to see if it’s working correctly. In the console add 2 new todos.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todoList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">addTodo</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;first&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todoList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">addTodo</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;second&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This will return:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">My</span> <span class="nx">Todos</span><span class="o">:</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">(</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="nx">first</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">(</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="nx">second</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now toggle those 2 todos to completed with <code>todoList.toggleCompleted(0);</code> and <code>todoList.toggleCompleted(1);</code> to return:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">My</span> <span class="nx">Todos</span><span class="o">:</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="nx">first</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="nx">second</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Finally, use <code>todoList.toggleAll();</code> to toggle both todos to <code>false</code>, in other words back to incompleted:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">My</span> <span class="nx">Todos</span><span class="o">:</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">(</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="nx">first</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">(</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="nx">second</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>That wraps up the first requirement of our v.6.0 app.</p> <h2 id="step-2-otherwise-make-everything-true">Step 2: Otherwise, make everything true</h2> <p>The last requirement of version 6 is pretty simple as we’ve done most of the work already.</p> <p>A big tip here; if you ever find yourself saying “Otherwise”, it’s the perfect time to use an <code>else</code> statement.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleAll</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">length</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">completedTodos</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Count number of completed todos </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">&lt;</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span><span class="o">++</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">i</span><span class="p">].</span><span class="nx">completed</span> <span class="o">===</span> <span class="kc">true</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">completedTodos</span><span class="o">++</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Case 1: If everything’s true, make everything false </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">completedTodos</span> <span class="o">===</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">&lt;</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span><span class="o">++</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">i</span><span class="p">].</span><span class="nx">completed</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">false</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Case 2: Otherwise, make everything true </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="p">}</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">&lt;</span> <span class="nx">totalTodos</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span><span class="o">++</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">i</span><span class="p">].</span><span class="nx">completed</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">true</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You’ll notice our <code>else</code> statement is almost identical to our <code>if</code> statement, except in this case we’re making everything <code>true</code> instead of <code>false</code>.</p> <p>First we use the <code>for</code> loop to count through the todos, and then <code>this.todos[i].completed = true;</code> to set the todos to <code>true</code>.</p> <h3 id="test-the-code-in-the-console-1">Test the code in the console</h3> <p>As we did before, add some todo items:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todoList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">addTodo</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;first&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todoList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">addTodo</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;second&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Then run <code>todoList.toggleAll();</code>. This should make everything <code>true</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">My</span> <span class="nx">Todos</span><span class="o">:</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="nx">first</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="nx">second</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Run <code>todoList.toggleAll();</code> again and it should make everything <code>false</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">My</span> <span class="nx">Todos</span><span class="o">:</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">(</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="nx">first</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">(</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="nx">second</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now test the final case, where some are <code>true</code> and some <code>false</code> to see if <code>toggleAll</code> sets all items to <code>true</code>.</p> <p>So use <code>todoList.toggleCompleted(0);</code> to toggle the first item to <code>true</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">My</span> <span class="nx">Todos</span><span class="o">:</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="nx">first</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">(</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="nx">second</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now, run <code>todoList.toggleAll();</code> again to toggle all to <code>true</code>:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">My</span> <span class="nx">Todos</span><span class="o">:</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="nx">first</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="nx">second</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Great, our code is working as expected.</p> <h3 id="v60-review">v.6.0 Review</h3> <p>In this version we’ve had practice with <code>for</code> loops, accessing different properties on an object, going through items in an array. And linking functions together with <code>this.displayTodos();</code>.</p> <p>We’ve also looked at keeping track of different variables we need inside <code>for</code> loops. This pulls a lot of the programming concepts we’ve learnt already together into one method.</p> <p>This version should have given you a better idea of how you think about a program, think like a programer and figure out a feature to systematically write your code.</p> <p>As we’ve done here you might start by writing out comments, then cases to help guide you as you’re coding.</p> <p>Commenting your code will help you and others understand it better when you go back to it at a later date.</p>

item.title: Loops for Logic
item.content:encoded: <p>This is Part 5 of my notes on Gordon Zhu’s <a href="https://watchandcode.com/p/practical-javascript" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical JavaScript</a>. In this part we changed the structure of an array from a text value to an object, modify a method to work with a text property and learn about Booleans.</p> <h2 id="building-a-todo-app-v50">Building a todo app v.5.0</h2> <p>Using <code>for</code> loops and <code>if else</code> statements.</p> <h2 id="understanding-the-for-loop">Understanding the for loop</h2> <p>The <code>for</code> loop allows you to repeat a certain amount of code, any number of times. For example, if you wanted to tell a computer in english to say “hey” 3 times, this is how you might do it in 3 steps:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">Say</span> <span class="s2">&#34;hey&#34;</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">&lt;</span> <span class="mi">3</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">Increase</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="nx">by</span> <span class="mi">1</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>So whats going on here?</p> <ul> <li>Keep track of variable called <code>i</code>, which is zero first</li> <li>say “hey” if <code>i</code> is less than 3</li> <li>After that, increase <code>i</code> by 1</li> </ul> <p>This might result in the following:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="mi">0</span> <span class="s2">&#34;hey&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="mi">1</span> <span class="s2">&#34;hey&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="s2">&#34;hey&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="mi">3</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="whats-going-on-here">Whats going on here?</h3> <ul> <li>“hey” because zero is less than 3</li> <li>Then it would increase <code>i</code> by 1, and return 1 followed by “hey”, because 1 is still less than 3</li> <li>Then <code>i</code> would increase again by 1 and return 2, followed by “hey”, as 2 is still less than 3</li> <li>When <code>i</code> is increased by 1 and the value is 3, the computer stops returning “hey”, as <code>i</code> is no longer less than 3, it’s now equal to 3</li> </ul> <h3 id="in-javascript-these-steps-have-specific-names">In Javascript these steps have specific names</h3> <p>In Javascript, the 3 steps outlined above have specific names.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span> <span class="c1">// Initialization </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="nx">Say</span> <span class="s2">&#34;hey&#34;</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">&lt;</span> <span class="mi">3</span> <span class="c1">// Condition </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="nx">Increase</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="nx">by</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="c1">// Final-expression </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>The first step is the <strong>Initialization</strong>, this is essentially a variable we create to keep track of how many times we want to do something. In this case we use zero to keep track of how many times we want to print “hey”.</p> <p>The second step is known as the <strong>Condition</strong>. For example, if this is true, then keep going, otherwise stop. In the code above, the condition is “if <code>i</code> is less than 3”.</p> <p>The third step is the <strong>Final Expression</strong>, this is what happens after each round. So after saying “hey” the first time, we’ll increase <code>i</code> by 1, after we increase <code>i</code> the second time, increase <code>i</code> by 1 and so on.</p> <h3 id="structuring-in-code">Structuring in code</h3> <p>We can use the <code>for</code> loop to make this work in code:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">initialization</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">condition</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="kr">final</span> <span class="nx">expression</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&#34;hey&#34;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>With our steps from before, this looks something like:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">&lt;</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&#34;hey&#34;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>As it’s a common occurrence in Javascript, we can shorthand the final expression to <code>i++</code>, meaning <code>i = i + 1</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">&lt;</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span><span class="o">++</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&#34;hey&#34;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="looping-over-arrays">Looping over Arrays</h2> <p>Carrying on with the example from the last video, instead of printing “hey”, with <code>console.log</code>, we can actually just <code>console.log</code> our variable. In this case, <code>i</code>:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">&lt;</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span><span class="o">++</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">i</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now our code will return the following:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="mi">0</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="mi">1</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="mi">2</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next, let’s create a new array:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">testArray</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;item 1&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 2&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 3&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Remember, you can access specific items in an array using the square brackets:</p> <p><code>testArray[0]</code>, for the first item, <code>testArray[1]</code> for the second, and so on. We can use this inside our <code>for</code> loop.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">&lt;</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span><span class="o">++</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">testArray</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">i</span><span class="p">]);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>By console logging our <code>testArray</code> with <code>i</code> as the parameter, we can loop through the 3 items in the array:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">item</span> <span class="mi">1</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">item</span> <span class="mi">2</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">item</span> <span class="mi">3</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The problem now is that using 3 in our <code>for</code> loop condition will only return the first 3 items.</p> <p>It would be better to make the condition dynamic and return as many items as are in our array. We can do this with the <code>.length</code> property. <code>Length</code> will tell us how many items are in the array.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">&lt;</span> <span class="nx">testArray</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">length</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="nx">i</span><span class="o">++</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">testArray</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">i</span><span class="p">]);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now if we add an item to <code>testArray</code>, so there’s 4 items in the array, it will be returned. If we kept using 3 as the condition, the fourth item wouldn’t be returned.</p> <p>For example, add a new item with <code>testArray.push('extra item');</code>. Then run the original code and <code>extra item</code> will not be returned.</p> <p>However run the updated code with <code>testArray.length</code> instead of the value 3 and <code>length</code> will check the number of items then return those items.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">item</span> <span class="mi">1</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">item</span> <span class="mi">2</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">item</span> <span class="mi">3</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">extra</span> <span class="nx">item</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now, our code will work with <code>testArray</code> no matter how many items are in the array.</p> <h2 id="requirements">Requirements</h2> <p>Version 5 will put show .completed</h2> <p>The final requirement for v5 is for <code>displayTodos</code> to show whether a todo has been completed or not.</p> <p>We could represent that like this:</p> <pre represents a todo which is incomplete.</p> <p>We can do this inside our <code>for</code> loop:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span id="translating-this-to-javascript">Translating this to Javascript</h3> <p>We can translate our notes into JavaScript like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">i</span> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In the first part we check if <code>this.todos</code>.</p> <p>Using <code>i</code>, we can look at the specific todo in this iteration of the loop.</p> <p>Then, we check the completed property, to see if it’s <code>true</code>. We can use the triple equals to do this.</p> <h3 id="representing-complete-and-incomplete-todos">Representing complete and incomplete todos</h3> <p>Lastly we need to print out the todo text for the specific object, with an <code>(x)</code> if completed is <code>true</code> and <code>( )</code> when completed is <code>false</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;(x)&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">i</span><span class="p">].</span><span class="nx">todoText</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;( )&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">i</span><span class="p">].</span><span class="nx">todoText</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>To do this we can <code>console.log(this.todos[i].todotext)</code>, just like we did at the top of the <code>for</code> loop.</p> <p>We’ll just need to add the string values before hand. <code>(x)</code> for the first instance and the empty parenthesises; <code>( )</code>, in the <code>else</code> statement.</p> <p>Now we can get rid of <code>console.log(this.todos[i].todotext)</code> at the top of the <code>for</code> loop as we’re now doing this work inside the <code>if else</code> statement.</p> <h3 id="testing-our-work-in-the-console-1">Testing our work in the console</h3> <p>Now we can add a few todos.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todoList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">addTodo</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;first&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todoList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">addTodo</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;second&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todoList</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">addTodo</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;third&#39;</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You should see these print out with an empty parenthesises as none of them have been completed.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>My Todos: ( ) first ( ) second ( ) third </code></pre><p>Now we can use <code>toggleCompleted</code> to see if we can change some of our todo items to complex.</p> <p>To toggle our second todo we can use:</p> <p><code>todoList.toggleCompleted(1);</code></p> <p>Which will return:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>My Todos: ( ) first (x) second ( ) third </code></pre><p>We can toggle it again by repeating the same step.</p> <p><code>todoList.toggleCompleted(1);</code> will now return:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>My Todos: ( ) first ( ) second ( ) third </code></pre><h3 id="interesting-observations">Interesting observations</h3> <p>This step combined <code>for</code> loops with <code>if else</code> statements.</p> <p>For each <code>for</code> loop we used logic to check if <code>todo.completed</code> is <code>true</code> – in which case we do one thing – or if it’s <code>false</code>, in which case we do something else.</p> <h2 id="v50-review">v.5.0 Review</h2> <p><code>.displayTodos</code> now shows <code>todoText</code> and not just the objects like before. It also tells us if our todo list is empty with a helpful message. And whether or not a todo has been completed.</p> <p>We wrote all our code in this version inside one method, <code>displayTodos</code>.</p> <p>We combined <code>for</code> loops with <code>if</code> statements, so we can use logic in our program.</p> <h2 id="next-steps">Next Steps</h2> <p>Head over to <a href="https://watchandcode.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Watchandcode.com</a> to take the course that these notes are based on.</p>

item.title: Booleans
item.content:encoded: <p>This is Part 4 of my notes on Gordon Zhu’s <a href="https://watchandcode.com/p/practical-javascript" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical JavaScript</a>. In this part we changed the structure of an array from a text value to an object, modify a method to work with a text property and learn about Booleans.</p> <h2 id="building-a-todo-app-v40---understanding-booleans">Building a todo app v4.0 - Understanding Booleans</h2> <p>Booleans are a representation of <code>true</code> or <code>false</code>.</p> <h2 id="requirements">Requirements</h2> <ul> <li><code>todoList.addTodo</code> should add objects</li> <li><code>todoList.changeTodo</code> should change the todoText property</li> <li><code>todoList.toggleCompleted</code> should change the completed property</li> </ul> <h2 id="step-1-todolistaddtodo-should-add-objects">Step 1: todoList.addTodo should add objects</h2> <p>First we need to change the addTodo method from adding text items like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;item 1&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 2&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 3&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>…to adding objects like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{</span> <span class="nx">todoText</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 1&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">completed</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kc">false</span> <span class="c1">// Boolean true or false} </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>We want to do this so we can add as many properties as we like. The first property we want is a text value, for example the text we want to add.</p> <p>The second property is our Boolean value. This will tell us whether the todo has been completed on not. When you first add a todo it most likely won’t be done yet so we can use <code>false</code> as the default stated of <code>completed</code>.</p> <p>Later when we go through our todos and mark as completed this value will change to <code>true</code>. As this data requires a <code>true</code> or <code>false</code> value, representing it with a Boolean is the way to go.</p> <h3 id="updating-our-code-from-v30">Updating our code from v.3.0</h3> <p>This is where we left off in our version 3 app.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">todoList</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">todos</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;item 1&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 2&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 3&#39;</span><span class="p">],</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">displayTodos</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;My Todos&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">},</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">addTodo</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">todo</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">push</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">todo</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">displayTodos</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">},</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">changeTodo</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">newValue</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">newValue</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">displayTodos</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">},</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">deleteTodo</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">splice</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">displayTodos</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">};</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>First step is to remove the items in our existing array, as we now want to use an object instead.</p> <p>In the code above, change:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;item 1&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 2&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 3&#39;</span><span class="p">],</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>to the following:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">[],</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next we need to modify our <code>addTodo</code> function. Find the code which reads:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">addTodo</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">todo</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">push</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">todo</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">displayTodos</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">},</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>And change it to:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">addTodo</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">todoText</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">push</span><span class="p">({</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">todoText</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">todoText</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">completed</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kc">false</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">});</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">displayTodos</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">},</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>A few things to note in our new code:</p> <ul> <li>We’re now using <code>todoText</code> as our parameter instead of <code>todo</code>. This will will also be a text value but more representative of the data in our object, which is next.</li> <li>Now instead of using the <code>push</code> method to add <code>todo</code>, we’re adding the object with 2 properties; <code>todoText</code> and <code>completed</code> which is our Boolean value.</li> <li>Remember; first <code>todoText</code> is the name of the property, whereas the second <code>todoText</code> is referring to the <code>todoText</code> parameter, which will change depending on what we parse in when we use the method.</li> </ul> <p>For example if we write <code>addTodo('hi');</code> the value of <code>todoText</code> will be <code>'hi'</code>:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">push</span><span class="p">({</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">todoText</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">&#39;&#39;</span><span class="nx">hi</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">completed</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kc">false</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">});</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="using-todolistaddtodo">Using todoList.addTodo</h3> <p>Typing <code>todoList.addTodo('this is an object')</code> will now represent the data in an object. Where <code>todoText</code> is given the value <code>'this is an object'</code> and <code>completed</code> has the value of <code>false</code>.</p> <h3 id="why-are-we-doing-this">Why are we doing this?</h3> <p>We want our todos to show more data, we want to have a text description; the <code>todoText</code> property and also another property to show whether the todo has be done or not; <code>completed</code>. We’re using a Boolean value to represent that.</p> <h2 id="step-2-todolistchangetodo-should-change-to-todotext-property">Step 2: todoList.changeTodo should change to todoText property</h2> <p>Now we need to make sure the <code>changeTodo</code> method only changes the <code>todoText</code> property on each todo object.</p> <p>This is because <code>addTodo</code> now adds objects to our array, and those objects have 2 properties; <code>todoText</code> and <code>completed</code> – the boolean true or false value.</p> <h3 id="updating-the-newvalue-parameter">Updating the newValue parameter</h3> <p>First, we need to update the <code>newValue</code> parameter to something more descriptive, so its more clear whats happening. As we just want to change the todoText property, we can call it <code>todotext</code>.</p> <p>So, find the <code>newValue</code> parameter in the code and change it to <code>todoText</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">changeTodo</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">newValue</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">newValue</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">displayTodos</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">},</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Your code should now look like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">changeTodo</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">todoText</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">newValue</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">displayTodos</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">},</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="update-thistodo-position-to-reference-the-todotext-property-in-the-object">update this.todo position to reference the todoText property in the object</h3> <p>Next we need to modify <code>this.todo[position] = newValue</code>.</p> <p>This is because <code>newValue</code> is no longer the parameter parsed in, it’s now <code>todoText</code>.</p> <p>As <code>todoText</code> is now a property on the object (in addTodo), we can get at it using the dot notation:</p> <p><code>this.todo[postion].todoText = todoText</code></p> <p>In our changes above, <code>.todoText</code> grabs the <code>todoText</code> property on the object, and assigns it to the new value which is parsed in; <code>todoText</code>.</p> <p>Our new code should look like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">changeTodo</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">todoText</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">].</span><span class="nx">todoText</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">todoText</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">displayTodos</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">},</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>So to recap, the reason we’re doing this is because the structure of our data has changed from simple text values to an object structure.</p> <h2 id="step-3-todolisttogglecompleted-should-change-value-of-completed-property">Step 3: todoList.toggleCompleted should change value of completed property</h2> <p>Now we need to add a new method called toggleCompleted which switches the value of the completed property.</p> <p>Remember, completed is a Boolean value, so if it’s set to <code>false</code> (as default), toggleCompleted will change it to <code>true</code>, and if it’s <code>true</code> it should change to <code>false</code>.</p> <h3 id="the-bang-operator">The Bang Operator</h3> <p>In Javascript, the Bang Operator (!) takes the opposite of whatever comes after it.</p> <p>For example:</p> <p>We can get the opposite of <code>true</code> with <code>!true</code>, which returns <code>false</code>. Where <code>!false</code> returns <code>true</code>.</p> <p>We can take this a step further:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">harryBoolean</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">false</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In this case <code>!harryBoolean</code> will return <code>true</code>. What if we set <code>harryBoolean</code> to the opposite of itself:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">harryBoolean</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">!</span><span class="nx">harryBoolean</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>With the exclamation point we can take the current value of a variable and switch it to the opposite value. We can use this technique in our <code>toggleCompleted</code> method.</p> <p>### Adding the toggleCompleted method</p> <p>Now let’s put this into practice and write a new method for <code>toggleCompleted</code>:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleCompleted</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">todo</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">postion</span><span class="p">];</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">todo</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">completed</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">!</span><span class="nx">todo</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">completed</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">displayTodos</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>So, whats going on here?</p> <h2 id="breaking-down-the-code">Breaking down the code</h2> <p>First we add our new method fo <code>toggleCompleted</code>, and give it a position so we can target the specific todo we want to modify:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleCompleted</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next, we create a reference to our <code>todo</code> in the form of a variable. This will save us from having to write this repetitive code in 2 different places. You’ll see what I mean in the line that will follow.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleCompleted</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">todo</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">];</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now, we flip the value of <code>todo.completed</code>, by grabbing the value of <code>todo.completed</code> and setting it to the opposite of the current value using the bang operator. So if the value is <code>false</code> it will be <code>true</code> and if it’s <code>true</code> it will be <code>false</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleCompleted</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">todo</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">];</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">todo</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">completed</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">!</span><span class="nx">todo</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">completed</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Finally we add the ability to display our updated changes with <code>displayTodos</code>, again using <code>this</code> to target the displayTodos method.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">toggleCompleted</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">todo</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">position</span><span class="p">];</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">todo</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">completed</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">!</span><span class="nx">todo</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">completed</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">this</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">displayTodos</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="v40-review">v.4.0 Review</h2> <p>In <code>todoList.addTodo</code> we changed the structure of the array to be an array of objects, rather than text, this allowed for a text value and a boolean value, to specify whether the todo has been completed.</p> <p>Next, we modified the <code>todoList.changeTodo</code> method so it only modifies the <code>todoText</code> property on each todo object.</p> <p>Lastly we learnt about Booleans and how to take the opposite of a boolean value in our new <code>toggleComplete</code> method.</p> <h2 id="next-steps">Next Steps</h2> <p>Head over to <a href="https://watchandcode.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Watchandcode.com</a> to take the course that these notes are based on.</p>

item.title: Hugo SEO: Unique, Accurate Page Titles
item.content:encoded: <!-- raw HTML omitted --> <p>According to <a href="https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/7451184?hl=en#uniquepagetitles" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Google’s SEO starter guide</a>, “Each page on your site should ideally have a unique title, which helps Google know how the page is distinct from the others on your site.”</p> <p>At all costs avoid default, vague titles which have no relation to the content on the page and never use a single title across all pages on your site.</p> <p>This piece is for those building sites with Hugo. It introduces a common mistake, often seen in <a href="https://themes.gohugo.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo starter themes</a> – where the <code>&lt;title&gt;</code> tag renders generic page titles – and offers a simple concise solution to get your pages into Google’s good books and ranking properly.</p> <h2 id="the-big-mistake-with-page-titles">The big mistake with page titles</h2> <p>When building a theme for your new Hugo site, you might be tempted to dig through the <code>_default</code> templates of a Hugo starter theme for some tips on where to begin.</p> <p>No bad thing, it’s a great way to learn, but approach this method with caution, starter themes can also contain bad practices.</p> <p>In many cases, a quick look inside the <code>&lt;head&gt;</code> will often reveal the following seemly simple but potentially harmful code:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>{{ $.Site.Title }}<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>So what’s going on here?</p> <p>Here we’re taking the title of our site directly from our <code>config.toml</code> file and applying it to each and every page on our site. That means every page on our site now has the same name.</p> <p>In terms of SEO this is bad news, as we now know.</p> <h2 id="a-simple-elegant-solution">A simple elegant solution</h2> <p>A better solution would be to use the conditional <code>if</code> statement and reach for the title set in the front matter of each page when possible.
