You should now have an InstantSearch results page working with your blog posts on a Hugo static site.</p> <p>Of course you can use InstantSearch with any static site generator, or on any webpage, it doesn’t have to be Hugo. There’s a ton of great resources and tutorials to help you get going on the <a href="https://community.algolia.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Algolia Community</a> page .</p> <p>A great place to begin is the <a href="https://community.algolia.com/instantsearch.js/v2/getting-started.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Getting Started with InstantSearch.js</a> tutorial. I’ll also list some resources I found helpful below.</p> <h2 id="further-reading">Further reading</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://community.algolia.com/instantsearch.js/v2/getting-started.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Getting Started with InstantSearch.js</a></li> <li><a href="https://community.algolia.com/instantsearch.js/v1/documentation/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Instant Search v1 Documentation</a></li> <li><a href="https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=16502918" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Thread on Hacker News</a> which gave me reason to write this article.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/regisphilibert/benmerde/blob/search/themes/benmerde/src/js/main.js" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Regis Philibert’s Github repo</a> helped me get my head around <code>hitTemplate</code></li> </ul>

item.title: Automating responsive images with Cloudinary
item.content:encoded: <p class="intro"> Responsive images are crucial part of improving website performance. But that doesn’t just mean globally setting images to 100% width, height ‘auto’, then calling it a day. </p> <p>Ideally we want to create multiple versions of each image, sending users the version which best suits their viewing context. If, for example, visitors are using 3G on a mobile device, then we should serve the appropriately scaled images, for the best possible experience.</p> <p><a href="https://cloudinary.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cloudinary</a>, a cloud based image solution makes this laborious task somewhat simple, by automatically adapting images for delivery in any context.</p> <p>The article presents a problem Cloudinary helps solve, then provides a quickstart guide to help you get set up. This is particularly suited to those working with static or serverless sites, where hosting images directly within a repository can lead to performance issues down the line.</p> <h2 id="the-problem">The Problem</h2> <p>When building static sites, in the past I’ve used the <a href="https://www.npmjs.com/package/gulp-responsive" target="_blank" rel="noopener">gulp-responsive</a> Gulp task to find the original image in the <code>src</code> folder and auto generate multiple sizes at build time. Perhaps this sounds familiar?</p> <p>Using <code>srcset</code> and a Hugo shortcode, I can serve up the different sizes when required.</p> <p>Flawless workflow, until deployment. Now I’m committing multiple images for every image on my site to my repository. For sites with lots of images this doesn’t really work out. Build times take forever. You get the picture.</p> <p>The solution to all this is fairly simple, abstract images assets away from your repo and let a service like Cloudinary take care of your media storage.</p> <h2 id="introducing-cloudinary">Introducing Cloudinary</h2> <p><em>“Cloudinary simplifies responsive images by dynamically adapting image properties — dimensions, crop, format, quality — on-the-fly and delivering the optimal version based on the content and viewing context.”</em></p> <p>By adding transformations – custom parameters set in the URL which we’ll look at later – you can customise your image in any number of ways. Think automatic Photoshopping in the cloud.</p> <p>Using a CDN, Cloudinary delivers media faster based on your visitors location, and now images are out of the repo, build times are back to optimum speeds. Portable also makes total sense. No more syncing your media library when you change environment or make changes down the line.</p> <p>The next part will look at getting Cloudinary set up to auto generate responsive images.</p> <h2 id="getting-started-with-cloudinary-js-setup">Getting started with Cloudinary: JS setup</h2> <p>There are a few ways to set up Cloudinary but the Javascript option is perhaps the most straight forward.</p> <h3 id="step-1-create-an-account-with-cloudinary">Step 1: Create an account with Cloudinary</h3> <p>First, <a href="https://cloudinary.com/users/register/free" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Create an Account</a> at Cloudinary.com, then upload a single high-resolution version of any image. Cloudinary with auto generate responsive sizes for you. Pretty cool.</p> <h3 id="step-2-include-cloudinary-in-your-project">Step 2: Include Cloudinary in your project</h3> <p>Add Cloudinary to your project by including <code>cloudinary-core-shrinkwrap.js</code> in the footer of your page, right before the closing <code>&lt;body&gt;</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">script</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/cloudinary-core/2.3.0/cloudinary-core-shrinkwrap.min.js&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">script</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="step-3-include-images-with-data-src">Step 3: Include images with data-src</h3> <p>Head to your Media Library in Cloudinary and hover over your image thumbnail to reveal the link icon. Click the icon to copy the URL.</p> <p>Now we have the URL for an image we can add it to an <code>&lt;img&gt;</code> tag in our HTML using <code>data-src</code>. It’s important you use the <code>data-src</code> attribute and not <code>src</code> as Cloudinary will dynamically create the <code>src</code> images using JavaScript.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">data-src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/naming-artboards-in-sketch-01.png&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">alt</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;cld-responsive&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next we need to add the <code>cld-responsive</code> class to our image, this will allow <code>cloudinary-core-shrinkwrap.js</code> to find the image in our HTML and perform the necessary transformations, which we’ll get into a bit later. Remember you’ll need to do this for all images on your site hosted by Cloudinary.</p> <p>The final thing we need to do to get this working is to add the JavaScript call.</p> <h3 id="step-4-adding-the-javascript-call">Step 4: Adding the Javascript call</h3> <p>To initialise the Cloudinary instance, call the responsive method in your JavaScript file:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-js" data-lang="js"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kr">const</span> <span class="nx">cl</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">cloudinary</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Cloudinary</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="k">new</span><span class="p">({</span> <span class="nx">cloud_name</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;YOUR_CLOUD_NAME&#34;</span> <span class="p">});</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">cl</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">responsive</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You can find your <code>YOUR_CLOUD_NAME</code> in your Cloudinary Dashboard under Account Details.</p> <p>At this point you should now be seeing you Cloudinary hosted image. But right now Cloudinary is just devilering the image. We still need to set up some image transformations on the URL the make it responsive.</p> <h2 id="step-5-responsive-image-transformations">Step 5: Responsive image transformations</h2> <p>In the image URL, right after <code>upload/</code>, include <code>w_auto,c_scale</code> this will ensure basic responsive images. Now we have something like this.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">img</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">data-src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload/w_auto,c_scale/naming-artboards-in-sketch-01.png&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">alt</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;cld-responsive&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>So what’s going on here?</p> <p>The <a href="https://cloudinary.com/documentation/responsive_images#automatic_image_width" target="_blank" rel="noopener">w_auto</a> transformation will deliver an image automatically scaled to a width that matches the width available in the responsive layout of your site.</p> <p><a href="https://cloudinary.com/documentation/image_transformation_reference#crop_parameter" target="_blank" rel="noopener">c_scale</a> is the default crop transformation, which will change the size of the image exactly to the given width and height of its container.</p> <h2 id="taking-it-further">Taking it further</h2> <p>There are a number of ways you might want to improve this workflow, such as adding more image transformations, to find out what transformations would work best it’s worth analysis your current image performance.</p> <h3 id="running-a-web-speed-test">Running a Web Speed Test</h3> <p>Using Cloudinary’s <a href="https://webspeedtest.cloudinary.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Web Speed Test</a> we can gather detailed optimisation insights on how changes to image size, format, quality and encoding parameters can improve performance.</p> <p>Chances are you could make improvements on your image compression. Cloudinary recommends 2 transformations for this.</p> <h3 id="useful-transformations">Useful transformations</h3> <p>Adding <code>q_auto</code> to the string of transformations in your URL will handle automatic image <a href="https://cloudinary.com/blog/the_holy_grail_of_image_optimization_or_balancing_visual_quality_and_file_size" target="_blank" rel="noopener">quality</a>.</p> <p>Including <code>f_auto</code> will analyse the image content and select the best <a href="https://cloudinary.com/documentation/image_optimization#how_to_optimize_image_format" target="_blank" rel="noopener">format</a> to deliver.</p> <p>For optimal image performance on <a href="https://cloudinary.com/blog/how_to_automatically_adapt_website_images_to_retina_and_hidpi_devices" target="_blank" rel="noopener">retina</a> displays use <code>dpr_auto</code>.</p> <h3 id="using-a-hugo-shortcode">Using a Hugo Shortcode</h3> <p>If you built your site with Hugo, like this one, you’ll likely want to create a <a href="https://gohugo.io/content-management/shortcodes/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Shortcode</a> so you can easily add Cloudinary hosted images to any Markdown file.</p> <p>Inside <code>site/layouts/shortcodes</code>, create a new file to store your shortcode. I named mine <code>cld.html</code> (as in Cloudinary) as it’s nice and short and easy to remember. Inside the HTML file I added the following:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">div</span> <span class="nx">class</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Image&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">img</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">data</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="nx">src</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Site.Params.cloudinary_url }}/w_auto,dpr_auto,c_scale,f_auto,q_auto/{{ .Get &#34;</span><span class="nx">src</span><span class="s">&#34; }}&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">class</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;cld-responsive&#34;</span> <span class="nx">alt</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Get &#34;</span><span class="nx">alt</span><span class="s">&#34; }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Get</span> <span class="s">&#34;caption&#34;</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">figure</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Get</span> <span class="s">&#34;caption&#34;</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">figcaption</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Get</span> <span class="s">&#34;caption&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">figcaption</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">figure</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Inside your <code>config.toml</code> file, add the following line, remembering to updated <code>YOUR_CLOUD_NAME</code> accordingly.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c"># Set Cloudinary URL for image hosting</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="l">cloudinary_url = &#34;https://res.cloudinary.com/YOUR_CLOUD_NAME/image/upload&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>To access your new Shortcode in any markdown file use the following:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="err">#</span> <span class="nx">Hugo</span> <span class="nx">Shortcode</span> <span class="nx">to</span> <span class="nx">use</span> <span class="nx">in</span> <span class="nx">markdown</span> <span class="nx">files</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{</span> <span class="p">{&lt;</span> <span class="nx">cld</span> <span class="nx">src</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;naming-artboards-in-sketch-organised-albion-03.jpg&#34;</span> <span class="nx">alt</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;&#34;</span> <span class="nx">caption</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Your Caption&#34;</span> <span class="p">&gt;}</span> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Here <code>src</code> is the last part of your image URL and caption is optional and takes a string of plain text for the image caption.</p> <p><em>Note: In the example above I have spaces between the curly brackets to prevent Hugo from rendering the image. You will want to make sure yours are written without spaces</em></p> <h3 id="cloudinary-with-forestry-cms">Cloudinary with Forestry CMS</h3> <p>If you’re building a site for a client, you’ve likely considered using a Git based CMS like <a href="https://forestry.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Forestry</a>. Forestry is great for content editors who don’t want to mess around with code, instead prefering to use an interface in the browser.</p> <p>Unlike a traditional CMS where updates to content are near instantaneous, Forestry needs to re-build your site each time content changes. So for content editors to view their changes quickly, we need to ensure build times are as fast as possible. This is where Cloudinary comes in.</p> <p>Cloudinary mitigates the need to store media inside a Git repository – the primary cause of slow build times – by storing your media on their own servers. This makes Cloudinary a great option combined with a Forestry workflow.</p> <p>To get Cloudinary and Forestry playing well together you’ll need to change a few settings in your Forestry dashboard.</p> <p>Assuming you’ve imported your site to Forestry, you will need to update your website Media configuration which you can find inside Settings on the sidebar:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Update your Media Storage Provider to Cloudinary</strong></li> <li><strong>Add your Cloud Name, API key and API Secret.</strong> You can find these details in your Cloudinary dashboard. Once you’ve added these you should see anything uploaded to cloudinary appear in the Media folder inside Forestry. Likewise when you upload new media via Forestry, it‘ll be hosted by Cloudinary.</li> </ul> <p>One final thing to note, if you find yourself setting up a Front Matter Template in Forestry, and use the ‘Image/File Upload’ field, you might need to override the public path for front matter fields, to get your images working. You can do this in the Advanced Media Settings under ‘Front Matter Path’. Depending on how you’ve set things up in your layout templates you might want to include any transformations in the URL you provide.</p> <p>For more on Forestry head over to the <a href="https://forestry.io/docs/media/cloudinary/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Forestry Docs</a> for more on getting started.</p> <h2 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping up</h2> <p>Responsive images are imperative for both website performance and good user experience. But often the work which goes into making images responsive and not just adaptable or flexible is enough not to bother.</p> <p>Cloudinary tackles this pain point with a JavaScript method which provides automatic responsive images along with a simple solution to optimise and edit your images with URL transformations.</p> <p>For more on Cloudinary, head over to <a href="https://cloudinary.com/documentation" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the docs</a> to see what else is possible. Below you’ll find a list of resources referenced in the configuration above.</p> <h2 id="further-reading">Further reading</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://cloudinary.com/features/responsive_images" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Responsive images</a> on Cloudinary</li> <li><a href="https://forestry.io/blog/master-image-delivery-with-cloudinary/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Mastering Image Delivery with Cloudinary</a> by DJ Walker</li> <li><a href="https://forestry.io/docs/media/cloudinary/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cloud Media Storage with Cloudinary</a>, Forestry Docs</li> <li><a href="https://cloudinary.com/blog/how_to_automatically_adapt_website_images_to_retina_and_hidpi_devices" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Automatically adapt website images to Retina and HiDPI devices</a> by Nadav Soferman</li> </ul>

item.title: Arrays
item.content:encoded: <p>These are my notes from Gordon Zhu’s course <a href="https://watchandcode.com/p/practical-javascript" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Practical JavaScript</a>.</p> <p>JavaScript always been my weakest link so lately I’ve been taking the time to revisit many concepts I’ve otherwise skipped in the past.</p> <p>I highly recommend the course if you’re just getting started or looking to brush up on your Javascript programming. It’s video based and 100% free! This first part looks at working with Arrays directly from the console in the browser.</p> <p>For those new to this stuff; from any webpage <em>right click &gt; Inspect Element</em> to open the console.</p> <h2 id="project-requirements">Project Requirements</h2> <p>Creating a requirement list will help you focus on one specific thing at a time. It’s easy to get side-tracked if you don’t do this.</p> <p>This will help you debug and test your app and think in a more modular manner. Breaking large tasks into smaller pieces will make programming your app more manageable. The more specific you can make your requirements the better.</p> <ul> <li>It should have a place to store todos</li> <li>It should have a way to display todos</li> <li>It should have a way to add new todos</li> <li>It should have a way to change a todo</li> <li>It should have a way to delete a todo</li> </ul> <h2 id="app-version-10--arrays">App Version 1.0 – Arrays</h2> <p>In programming, lists are called Arrays. From the console in Chrome:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;item 1&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 2&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 3&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="storing-todos">Storing todos</h3> <p>Create a variable to store the array so we can call it again and reuse it.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">todos</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;item 1&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 2&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 3&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="displaying-todos">Displaying todos</h3> <p>Display the Array with <code>todos</code>.</p> <p>Now pass the variable into the <code>Console.log</code> function.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">)</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p><em>Note: variables don’t require quotes. Surronding todos in quotes; ‘todos’ would print the string <strong>todos</strong></em></p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;My Todos:&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">)</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="add-new-todos">Add new todos</h3> <p>By binding the variable with the command <code>push</code> we can add new items to an Array.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">push</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;item 4&#39;</span><span class="p">)</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Console will display the number of items.</p> <p><code>todos</code> will now display <code>['item 1', 'item 2', 'item 3', 'item 4']</code></p> <h3 id="change-a-todo">Change a todo</h3> <p>To change a todo we need to first get hold of the specific item we want to change.</p> <p><code>todos[0]</code> will get hold of <code>'item 1'</code>, <code>todos[4]</code> will get hold of <code>'item 4'</code> and so on.</p> <p><em>Note: Unlike humans who start from 1, computers start counting from 0.</em></p> <p>Add a new value in the specific todo item, use <code>=</code> followed baby the new value.</p> <p><code>todos[0] = 'item 1 updated'</code> will update <code>'item 1'</code> in the Array.</p> <p><code>todos</code> will now display the update Array showing the new value for <code>item 1</code>:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;item 1 updated&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 2&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 3&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 4&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="deleting-a-todo">Deleting a todo</h3> <p>To delete an item in an Array you can use the command <code>splice</code>, similar to how we used the <code>push</code> command to add an item.</p> <p><code>todos.splice()</code></p> <p>To delete the first item in the Array use <code>0</code> again.</p> <p><code>todos.splice(0)</code></p> <p>Then tell <code>splice</code> the number of items you want to delete. In this case it’s 1.</p> <p><code>todos.splice(0, 1)</code></p> <h2 id="v10-review">v1.0 Review</h2> <ul> <li><del>It should have a place to store todos</del></li> <li><del>It should have a way to display todos</del></li> <li><del>It should have a way to add new todos</del></li> <li><del>It should have a way to change a todo</del></li> <li><del>It should have a way to delete a todo</del></li> </ul> <p>What We’ve learnt so far:</p> <ul> <li>Store Arrays using Variables:</li> </ul> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">todos</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;item1&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 2&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 3&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;item 4&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><ul> <li>Display Array with <code>console.log</code>:</li> </ul> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">console</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;My Todos:&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">)</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><ul> <li>Add todos:</li> </ul> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">todos</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">push</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;new todo item&#39;</span><span class="p">)</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><ul> <li>Change a todo:</li> </ul> <p><code>todos[0] = </code> changed todo!`</p> <ul> <li>Delete todos:</li> </ul> <p><code>todos.splice(0, 1)</code> Where <code>0</code> specifies the particular item and <code>1</code> specifies the number of items to delete.</p> <h2 id="next-steps">Next steps</h2> <p><a href="notes/parctical-javascript-functions">Part 2</a> looks at improving the app using Functions.</p> <p>These notes are based on Practical Javascript by Gordo Zhu. head over to <a href="https://watchandcode.com/p/practical-javascript" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Watchandcode.com</a> to enroll for free.</p>

item.title: Working with Data in Hugo
item.content:encoded: <p class="intro"> This articles demonstrates a practical use case of working with data files in Hugo. It will show you where to store your data and how to call your data into a template in order to render it on your site. </p> <p>Whilst front-end prototyping the design of a <a href="http://www.harrycresswell.co.uk/client/ain/ain-filters/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">system of content search filters</a>, I found myself in a situation where I needed to list the major countries in each inhabited Continent. The countries would take the form of checkboxes in a filter dropdown.</p> <p>A basic solution might be to list each country manually in an unordered list on the page. But that sound like a time consuming task and unnecessarily repetitive. No one wants a cluttered template with a verbose amount of code.</p> <p>Ideally I could abstract the data away from the page and leave my template clean and concise. Instead, storing the data in a separate data file which I could call in my template wherever needed.</p> <p>Enter Data files.</p> <h2 id="data-files-and-the-data-folder">Data files and the data folder</h2> <p>In Hugo, <a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/data-templates/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">data files</a> are stored in the data folder. Think of the data folder as a mini database where you can keep lists of data to use in your pages.</p> <p>Inside the data folder you can organise files into any number of sub-folders.</p> <p>Hugo accepts <code>JSON</code>, <code>YAML</code> and <code>TOML</code> files, just like the front matter in your posts and pages.</p> <h3 id="data-structure">Data structure</h3> <p>In my data folder I have a sub-folder called <code>countries</code> and inside that folder I have a another folder called <code>continent</code> where I keep 5 <code>YAML</code> files: <code>africaa.yaml</code>, <code>asia.yaml</code>, <code>europe.yaml</code>, <code>northamerica.yaml</code> and <code>southamerica.yaml</code>.</p> <p>For all the geography nerds out there; I combined Australia with Asia as it didn’t make sense to have a data file containing one country.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>└── countries └── continent ├── africa.yaml ├── asia.yaml ├── europe.yaml └── northamerica.yaml └── southamerica.yaml </code></pre><p>I called the top level sub-folder countries so the data type was clearly organised and easy to understand.</p> <h3 id="inside-the-data-file">Inside the data file</h3> <p>Inside each continent <code>YAML</code> file, I listed the countries in that continent under <code>country</code>, using an object <code>name</code> where the value is the country name.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nt">country</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span>- <span class="nt">name</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span href="https://gohugo.io/functions/range/#readout" target="_blank" rel="noopener">range</a> function you can loop through the content, accessing the data folder with <code>.Site.Data</code> followed by the name of the file and the nested data structure.</p> <p>To retrieve data from my <code>africa.yaml</code> data file I used the following code:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Data</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">countries</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">continent</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">africa</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">country</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">input</span> <span class="nx">class</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;material-icons&#34;</span> <span class="kd">type</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;checkbox&#34;</span> <span class="o">/</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">label</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">name</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">input</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">li</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Where <code>{{ .name }}</code> prints out the name of the country.</p> <p>To see this in action <a href="http://www.harrycresswell.co.uk/client/ain/ain-filters/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">check out this prototype</a> and hit the filter button above the search called <code>country</code>.</p> <p>If you are applying this to your own data be sure to update <code>countries.continent.africa.country</code> with your specific data structure.</p> <h2 id="conclusion">Conclusion</h2> <p>Data files in Hugo make working with large amounts of data a whole lot less cumbersome. Abstracting repetitive code away from templates keeps file clean and lightweight and managing content a somewhat easier task.</p> <p>For more on data in Hugo head to the docs, where you can learn about “data-driven content” data features, which lets you load any <code>JSON</code> or <code>CSV</code> file from nearly any resource.</p> <h2 id="further-reading">Further reading</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/data-templates/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Data Templates</a> fro the Hugo Docs</li> </ul>

item.title: Static search with Algolia and Hugo
item.content:encoded: <!-- raw HTML omitted --> <p class="intro"> We’re about to walk through setting up Algolia search on a Hugo static site with a Forestry CMS, so you can search your posts instantaneously and edit content directly from the browser. </p> <p>This first part is heavily based on <a href="https://forestry.io/blog/search-with-algolia-in-hugo/#creating-the-json-template" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Chris Macrae’s awesome article on Forestry.io</a>, with some adaptations to fit my specific needs. In the second article we’ll implement Instantsearch.js on the front end, which aims to pick up where the Chris’s article left off.</p> <h2 id="whats-algolia">What’s Algolia?</h2> <p><a href="https://www.algolia.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Algolia</a> is a search API (SaSS; as in <em>Search</em> as a Service) which allows you to index data and server it up at lightning speeds.</p> <p>If you’re running a <a href="https://jamstack.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">JAMStack</a> build – a Hugo static site like this one perhaps – Algolia will allow you to implement rapid fire, instantaneous search, like you’ve seen on <a href="https://www.smashingmagazine.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Smashing Magazine</a> and all those JS framework sites (think Vue, Gatsby, React).</p> <p>This stuff isn’t really possible on static sites without using a 3rd party API like Algolia, largely because we don’t have a database to query. But lucky for us Aloglia takes care of all this backend stuff for us.</p> <p>With that said, let’s break down the plan so you know what’s coming up.</p> <h2 id="what-are-trying-to-do">What are trying to do?</h2> <ul> <li>Send a search index to Algolia when a new post is added (via <a href="https://forestry.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Forestry</a> or a <code>git push</code> from the CLI).</li> <li>Update the search index on our site with a <a href="https://webtask.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">webtask function</a>, whenever the index is update on Algolia.</li> <li>Build a front end search using Algolia’s <a href="https://community.algolia.com/instantsearch.js/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Instantsearch.js</a> library, so visitors can interface with our content (we’ll do this bit in the second article).</li> </ul> <p>For a very basic prototype of what we’re building, <a href="https://heuristic-hoover-2ec537.netlify.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">head over here</a>.</p> <p>I’m assuming you already have a Hugo site set up. If not, I recommend starting out with the <a href="https://github.com/forestryio-templates/hugo-boilerplate" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Forestry’s Hugo boilerplate</a>. Here’s <a href="https://forestry.io/blog/up-and-running-with-hugo/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a great how-to guide</a> which will help you get off on the right foot.</p> <h2 id="step-1-generate-json-search-index">Step 1: Generate JSON search index</h2> <p>Algolia deals with JSON, so we’ll need set up Hugo to output our content as JSON. We can do this with <a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/output-formats/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Custom Output Formats</a>.</p> <p>Inside your <code>config.toml</code> file add the following:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="l">outputFormats.Algolia]</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">baseName = &#34;algolia&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">isPlainText = true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">mediaType = &#34;application/json&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">notAlternative = true</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="p">[</span><span class="l">params.algolia]</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">vars = [&#34;title&#34;, &#34;summary&#34;, &#34;date&#34;, &#34;publishdate&#34;, &#34;expirydate&#34;, &#34;permalink&#34;]</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">params = [&#34;categories&#34;, &#34;tags&#34;]</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>You’ll notice we also specified the <code>params</code> we want Algolia to work with – Categories and Tags.</p> <h2 id="step-2-build-a-json-template">Step 2: Build a JSON template</h2> <p>A JSON template will allow Hugo to render the custom JSON output. This will replace the typical <code>_default/list.html</code> page.</p> <p>Create a new file at <code>layouts/_default/list.algolia.json</code> and add the following:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-js" data-lang="js"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* Generates a valid Algolia search index */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="o">-</span> <span class="nx">$hits</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">slice</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="o">-</span> <span class="nx">$section</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">$</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Site</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">GetPage</span> <span class="s2">&#34;section&#34;</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Section</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="o">-</span> <span class="nx">$validVars</span> <span class="o">:=</span> <span class="nx">$</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Param</span> <span class="s2">&#34;algolia.vars&#34;</span> <span class="o">|</span> <span class="k">default</span> <span class="nx">slice</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="cm">/* range $i, $hit := .Site.AllPages */</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">Path</span> <span class="nx">$key</span> <span class="nx">$param</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span><span class="o">-</span> <span class="nx">$</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Scratch</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">SetInMap</span> <span class="s2">&#34;hits&#34;</span> <span class="nx">$hit</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">File</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Path</span> <span class="p">(.</span><span class="nx">Scratch</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Get</span> <span class="nx">$hit</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">File</span><span class="p">.</span><span
