<span class="nx">end</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="o">-</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span><span class="o">-</span> <span class="nx">jsonify</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">$</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Scratch</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">GetSortedMapValues</span> <span class="s2">&#34;hits&#34;</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Here we loop through all of content inside of <code>content/posts</code>. So if, let’s say, your posts folder is called ‘articles’, make sure you update your code to reflect that. Chris’s tutorial loops through all content including pages, so I modified this to serve only post content as I didn’t want to include pages.</p> <h2 id="step-3-output-the-index">Step 3: Output the Index</h2> <p>Now we have our custom output layout, variables and page-level params configured, we need to tell Hugo to create the actual JSON index.</p> <p>Back inside your <code>config.toml</code> file, add the following:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">[</span><span class="l">outputs]</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"> </span><span class="l">home = [&#34;HTML&#34;, &#34;RSS&#34;, &#34;Algolia&#34;]</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>This tells Hugo to output the HTML document, the RSS Feed, and an Algolia index for your site’s homepage, which contain our list of content.</p> <p>Build your site with <code>npm run build</code> and you should now find <code>algolia.json</code> in the root directory. We can use this to update our index in Algolia.</p> <h2 id="step-4-create-an-index-in-algolia">Step 4: Create an index in Algolia</h2> <p><a href="https://www.algolia.com/users/sign_up" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Create an account</a> on Algolia and click <em>New Application</em>. Make sure you choose a memorable application name. Next select the region closest to you. Then you’ll be redirected to the app dashboard.</p> <p>Click the <em>Indices</em> tab, and choose <em>Add New Index</em>. Give your new Index a unique name. I used ’hugolia’ for the hell of it, but you can use what you like; your domain name will do.</p> <p>Finally, select the <em>API Keys</em> tab, and copy your <em>Application ID</em> and <em>Admin API Key</em>. We’ll need these later, to update the index.</p> <h2 id="step-5-send-search-index-to-algolia">Step 5: Send search index to Algolia</h2> <p>To send our search index to Algolia, we can use <a href="https://www.npmjs.com/package/atomic-algolia" target="_blank" rel="noopener">atomic-algolia</a>, an NPM package that does atomic updates to an Algolia index. This will insure our search index is always in-sync with our website’s content.</p> <p>Run <code>npm install atomic-algolia --save</code></p> <p>This installs the atomic-algolia package to our local <code>node_modules</code> folder.</p> <p>Next, open the newly created <code>package.json</code> file, find &ldquo;scripts&rdquo;, and add the following:</p> <p><code>&quot;algolia&quot;: &quot;atomic-algolia&quot;</code></p> <p>Now create a <code>.env</code> file at the root of your project to store our environment variables. Add the following:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-js" data-lang="js"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">ALGOLIA_APP_ID</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">YOUR_APP_ID</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">ALGOLIA_ADMIN_KEY</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">YOUR_ADMIN_KEY</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">ALGOLIA_INDEX_NAME</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">YOUR_INDEX_NAME</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">ALGOLIA_INDEX_FILE</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">PATH</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">TO</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">algolia</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">json</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Grab those details from your Algolia Dashboard (See Step 4). If you’re using a different theme the path to your Algolia index file might be in <code>dist/algolia.json</code>. Others might find the file in their public folder.</p> <p>Now update your index by running:</p> <p><code>npm run algolia</code></p> <p>If all went well you should now have an index in Algolia synced with the content on your site.</p> <h2 id="step-6-updating-your-index-with-serverless-functions">Step 6: Updating your index with serverless functions</h2> <p>Using Forestry’s <a href="https://github.com/forestryio-templates/serverless-atomic-algolia" target="_blank" rel="noopener">open-source serverless Webtask Function</a> we can automatically update our Algolia index each time our site is updated. That way we don’t have to run the NPM script above, each time we make changes.</p> <p>To get started, clone the template to your local machine by running:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>git clone https://github.com/forestryio-templates/serverless-atomic-algolia.git </code></pre><p>Then install the dependencies:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>cd serverless-atomic-algolia npm install serverless -g &amp;&amp; npm install </code></pre><h3 id="configuration">Configuration</h3> <p>Next, set up a Webtasks profile if you don’t already have one. This can be done directly from the command line with:</p> <p><code>serverless config credentials --provider webtasks</code></p> <p>You’ll be asked for an email and you’ll immediately receive a verification code. Enter the verification code and your profile will be ready to use.</p> <p>Next, you’ll need to configure the function with your Indices and Algolia app information.</p> <p>First, copy <code>config/secrets.yml.stub</code> to <code>config/secrets.yml</code> and then open it up in your text editor.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-js" data-lang="js"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">ALGOLIA_APP_ID</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">YOUR_APP_ID</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">ALGOLIA_ADMIN_KEY</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">YOUR_ADMIN_KEY</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">DEBOUNCE</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Then, open <code>config/index.js</code> and update name to the name of your index that you set up earlier, and url to <code>yourdomain.com/algola.json</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-js" data-lang="js"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nx">module</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">exports</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">=&gt;</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">indexes</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">name</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;YOUR_INDEX_NAME&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;PUBLIC_URL_OF_INDEX&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">},</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">];</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="nx">JSON</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">stringify</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">indexes</span><span class="p">);</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">};</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="deploying-the-function">Deploying the function</h3> <p>Now deploy the function by running:</p> <p><code>serverless deploy</code></p> <p>In the terminal, you should receive an output for the success of your deployment, including the public URL for your new function.</p> <p>We’ll need this URL for when we trigger a web hook when changes are made to the site.</p> <h3 id="setting-up-a-webhook-in-forestry">Setting up a Webhook in Forestry</h3> <p>All that’s left to do before we move on to the front end is set up a post-deployment web hook with Forestry. This will trigger the serverless deploy when you make a change.</p> <p>If this is new to you, <a href="https://forestry.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Forestry</a> is a lightweight CMS for Jekyll and Hugo sites which is very easy to set up, you just link your Git Repository and you’re good to go.</p> <p>Once your connected to Forestry, find the <em>Settings</em> page of your site and scroll down to the <em>Webhook URL</em> setting.</p> <p>Enter the URL you received when deploying your function and click <em>Save Settings</em>.</p> <p>Now each time Forestry finishes deploying your site, your function will be invoked to update your Algolia index.</p> <p><em>Note: you can still make updates locally and push changes from the CLI, just make sure you do a <code>git pull</code> so you’re up-to-date with your production site.</em></p> <h2 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping up</h2> <p>At this point should have a working search index, which watches for any content changes you push to Git then re-indexes Algolia and updates our site.</p> <p>If you need more details on this whole set up, I highly recommend reading <a href="https://forestry.io/blog/search-with-algolia-in-hugo/?q=&amp;hPP=10&amp;idx=blog&amp;p=0" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Chris’s tutorial on Forestry</a> which goes into far more depth in certain places I raced through. Props to Chris for explaining in such detail.</p> <p>I wrote this down as much for my own understanding as I hope it has been helpful for your own. This was my first real venture using serverless functions and I’m still wrapping my head around them.</p> <p>With that said, any feedback you might have would be very welcome. <a href="https://twitter.com/harrycresswell" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Drop me a tweet</a> or <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/contact/">send me a message</a>. I’d be happy to hear from others exploring the world of serverless.</p> <p><em>Note: In <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/articles/hugo-algolia-2/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">part 2 of this article</a> we’ll build the front end, so users can interface with our content and see the power of Algolia on a Hugo static site.</em></p> <!-- raw HTML omitted --> <h2 id="further-reading">Further reading</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://forestry.io/blog/search-with-algolia-in-hugo/?q=&amp;hPP=10&amp;idx=blog&amp;p=0" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Static site search with Hugo + Algolia</a> by Chris Macrae</li> <li><a href="https://code.luasoftware.com/tutorials/algolia/add-algolia-search-to-hugo-static-website/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Add Algolia Search To Hugo Static Website</a> by Desmond Lua</li> </ul>

item.title: Better design systems in Sketch 2
item.content:encoded: <p> This article was originally posted (with supporting imagery) on <a href="https://medium.com/sketch-app-sources/using-sketch-libraries-to-build-a-better-ui-design-system-part-2-8de6cef5adc5">Medium.com</a> </p> <p><em>Prerequisite: This article requires <a href="https://www.sketch.com/updates/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sketch 47</a> as it make use of the long awaited new ‘Libraries’ feature.</em></p> <p>Where <a href="https://blog.usejournal.com/using-sketch-libraries-to-build-a-better-ui-design-system-part-1-26f5660f3c98" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the first part</a> gives you an intro to building ‘primitive’ Libraries to use in a UI design system, this article focuses on using the Symbols stored in these Libraries to build a highly flexible Atom level component.</p> <p>For those new to these concepts, the term primitives is used to describe subatomic properties; the lowest level ‘particles’ from which everything else in a system is composed. These ideas are explored in depth in Dan Eden’s work on <a href="https://daneden.me/2018/01/05/subatomic-design-systems/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Subatomic Design Systems</a>.</p> <figure> <blockquote class="PullQuote PullQuote--right"> <p> “Rather than creating a limited and vast set of UI elements, you define the system in terms of its particle properties, thus limiting the available styles but opening potentially unlimited avenues of creativity for the actual pieces of UI.” </p> <figcaption>&mdash; Dan Eden</figcaption> </blockquote> </figure> <p>We can use the concept of ‘particles’ to better understand the Libraries created in the first article. As the process involves identifying or extracting the core properties from our work and storing them in Libraries for reuse.</p> <p>But why do this? Our intention is to reference these particles when building pieces of UI. As our components will share properties they’ll remain consistent, yet flexible enough to allow for creativity in their construction.</p> <p>The particular pieces of UI we’ll focus on here are commonly known as Atoms. Atoms are the smallest identifiable components in a system, taken from <a href="http://bradfrost.com/blog/post/atomic-web-design/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Brad Frost’s Atomic Design</a> which you’ll likely be familiar with.</p> <p>As Atomic Design is widely understood we might use it as the principle guide for our component structures, borrowing the concept of ‘particles’ from Subatomic Design to help explain properties composing an Atom.</p> <p><a href="https://miro.medium.com/max/4440/1*h4vUVzQL5iDd4BEE6dUCyw.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener">This diagram</a> illustrates where we are on a scale of UI complexity. At this stage we’re primarily concerned with subatomic properties and how we can use them to build Atoms.</p> <p>By storing these properties (particles per Subatomic Design) as a collection Symbols and Symbol Overrides in Sketch Libraries, we can build a highly flexible system of low level UI components (Atoms per Atomic Design). And with these components, rapid prototype complex structures with minimal cognitive load.</p> <p>Before we get onto the practical stuff ahead, here’s a few reasons why you might consider ditching the ‘single file UI Kit’ approach in favour of breaking your UI system into multiple files. And how Sketch Libraries can take your UI design system process to the next level.</p> <h2 id="how-libraries-improve-our-design-systems">How Libraries improve our design systems</h2> <p>Fundamentally, Libraries help reduce complexity and inconsistency in our work and increase portability and reuse of UI assets. In other words, Libraries help us create useful work which serves our needs for the long term. As design systems thinker <a href="https://medium.com/@nathanacurtis" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Nathan Curtis</a> puts it:</p> <figure> <blockquote class="PullQuote PullQuote--right"> <p> “Focusing on style guide delivery as the climax is the wrong story to tell. A system isn’t a project with an end, it’s the origin story of a living and evolving product that’ll serve other products.” </p> <figcaption>&mdash; Nathan Curtis</figcaption> </blockquote> </figure> <p>Benefits of using Libraries to create systems that last:</p> <ul> <li> <p><strong>Organised, maintainable projects:</strong> More files, fewer moving parts per file. Sync changes from a single source of truth.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Reduced design debt and redundancy:</strong> No more broken Symbols and inconsistencies as you’ll be building comps using shared properties stored in ‘primitive’ Libraries.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Scaleable, flexible systems:</strong> Make changes, sync updates and evolve your system with relative ease. Symbol Overrides allows for fewer Symbols and flexible components.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Portable design assets:</strong> Libraries are independent files and so can be used across multiple Sketch files and reused in other projects.</p> </li> </ul> <p>Where you may have struggled to maintain a system in the past, Sketch Libraries help you build lightweight systems which are easier to manage as your product grows and evolves.</p> <p>By organising Symbols in multiple Library files, we can nest a Symbols from one file within another and keep those files both light in complexity and small in size. With Libraries, our assets become portable and updates easier to sync across entire projects.</p> <p>That means no more redundant design mockups post developer hand-off, no more battling to keep your designs up to date and generally a stress free time with Sketch.</p> <p>So how can you adopt this approach to UI design systems with Libraries?</p> <h2 id="using-libraries-for-a-ui-design-system">Using Libraries for a UI design system</h2> <p>Theory aside, building a design systems with Libraries is fairly simple. A high level overview might look like this:</p> <ol> <li>Decouple reoccurring properties found in your designs.</li> <li>Store properties as Symbols in a series of Library files.</li> <li>Use Libraries to build identifiable components.</li> <li>Use components to rapid prototype design comps</li> </ol> <p>I cover the first 2 parts above in <a href="https://blog.usejournal.com/using-sketch-libraries-to-build-a-better-ui-design-system-part-1-26f5660f3c98" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the first article</a>. The third part is where we’ll focus from here. Let’s get on with that now.</p> <h2 id="building-an-atom-using-sketch-libraries">Building an Atom using Sketch Libraries</h2> <p>Now we’re all familiar with Atomic Design, we have a good understanding of how we can use primitive or particle properties to build an Atom. Then in future cases Atoms to build Molecules, Molecules to build Organisms etc.</p> <p>As I’ve shared <a href="https://medium.com/sketch-app-sources/using-sketch-libraries-and-primitives-to-build-an-even-better-system-of-buttons-ecc8f25486ac" target="_blank" rel="noopener">my process for building buttons</a>, we’ll look at building a flexible Avatar component, another low level Atom. Later we’ll use this Avatar inside a card component. Expect to read about that in a future article.</p> <p>With some design system methodology in mind, we will start by identifying the properties needed to build the component.</p> <h2 id="step-1-audit-your-work">Step 1: Audit your work</h2> <p>Call it what you like, Brad frost refers to this as a <a href="http://bradfrost.com/blog/post/interface-inventory/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Interface Inventory</a>, but ‘Audit’ is nice and short so lets go with that for now.</p> <figure> <blockquote class="PullQuote PullQuote--right"> <p> “An interface inventory is a comprehensive collection of the bits and pieces that make up your interface.” </p> <figcaption>&mdash; Brad Frost</figcaption> </blockquote> </figure> <p>However you choose to do it — whether using a spreadsheet, in Evernote, on a piece of paper—just do it. Taking a holistic view of your entire product will help you identify patterns and relationships between different UI components.</p> <p>In our case this means potential cases of reusability among properties, which we can decouple from our design and store in Libraries.</p> <p>When auditing my work on the <a href="https://ainlabs.netlify.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AIN design system</a>, I realised many design patterns in the product were made from variables of a handful of property types: <code>color</code>, <code>icon</code>, <code>shape</code>, <code>border</code>, <code>text</code>.</p> <p>In theory, this meant I could build the majority of any component (Avatars included) using variables of these 5 primitive properties. This made a good starting point when considering what to store in primitive Libraries.</p> <h3 id="adding-missing-libraries">Adding missing Libraries</h3> <p>If you read <a href="https://blog.usejournal.com/using-sketch-libraries-to-build-a-better-ui-design-system-part-1-26f5660f3c98" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the first part</a> you’ll know I already built Libraries for 2 out of the 5 primitive properties used in my system: <code>colors</code>, and <code>icons</code>.</p> <p>I’ve since built Libraries for <code>shape</code> and <code>border</code>, which contain all instances of these properties used in my designs.</p> <p>At this point you might be thinking; why not use Layer Styles?</p> <p>New for Sketch 51 (currently in Beta): Both Text Styles and Layer Styles defined in Libraries will be available in all documents, just like Symbols are. This is a huge update and will help us solve inconsistencies across Styles which currently we have to recreate for each Library.</p> <p>Layer Styles, however, still don’t maintain shape, meaning we have no way to control border radius when using Layer Styles.</p> <p>For this reason, I chose to ditch Layer Styles altogether, instead creating Symbols for all instances of shape, storing them in Libraries which can be used across the entire system.</p> <p>By doing this I could reduce the number of unique Symbols created on a component level and reduce the complexity of each component.</p> <h3 id="handling-text-on-a-component-level">Handling text on a component level</h3> <p>Typography in Sketch, as you’ll know, is no easy beast to tame. For this reason, I decided against creating a <code>text</code> Library. Instead I handle all instances of text on a ‘per component’ basis, meaning any text required will live in same file as the component itself.</p> <p>This isn’t a big deal if you set your text using a <a href="https://www.modularscale.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">modular scale</a> or create shared Text Styles with <a href="http://www.textstyl.es/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Text Styles plugin</a> to avoid inconsistency. But keep in mind you won’t need the plugin come Sketch 51.</p> <p>Now I have 4 primitive Libraries which I can use to build components. As the majority of components will reference these Libraries, component files will become smaller, less complex and easier to manage. Components will contain only a very few unique symbols, native to their file.</p> <p>Fewer unique parts means components remain ultra lightweight. Using Symbols store in my Libraries, I can now utilise Overrides to build highly flexible components.</p> <p>Let’s leave these 4 Library files for now. We’ll come back to them later when it’s time to construct the component.</p> <h2 id="step-2-identify-component-variables">Step 2: Identify component variables</h2> <p>Before building your component, aim to identify the requirements of the particular component. In other words, what are the unique attributes comprising the component?</p> <p>For the <a href="https://ainlabs.netlify.com/components.html#avatars" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AIN Design System</a> it made sense to build 2 styles of Avatar, to differentiate between the 2 different user types in the product:</p> <ul> <li>People — in the form of a profile image.</li> <li>Projects — in the form of a company logo.</li> </ul> <p>To make these 2 user types noticeably different, a design decision was taken to use 2 visually different styles: <code>round</code> for users and <code>square</code> for companies.</p> <p>The next variable to consider was whether or not a user uploads an image or not. This meant we would have to create 2 component states, one <code>with an image</code> and one <code>without an image</code>, for both <code>round</code> and <code>square</code> styles.</p> <p>We decided to fallback to the users initials for cases when an image isn’t uploaded. This meant <code>text</code> would also have to be considered for both styles.</p> <p>The final variable to consider was the <code>size</code> of the Avatar. This was tricky to get exactly right before we knew all the potential use cases. It required some fine tuning after we began using the system, however the sizing scale remained true to the <a href="https://builttoadapt.io/intro-to-the-8-point-grid-system-d2573cde8632" target="_blank" rel="noopener">8pt grid</a>, which we used for all components and spacing in the final system. If you’re new to the 8pt grid, this means all spacing units are multiples of 8, which helps ensure a consistent rhythm in your work.</p> <p>Ok that’s a lot to remember! Let’s break down these component requirements so they’re more manageable and we have a clear direction to take.</p> <h3 id="breaking-down-the-requirements">Breaking down the requirements</h3> <p>Avatars will need to have Override states for:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Round</strong>: (99px radius) for user avatars</li> <li><strong>Square</strong>: (4px radius) for company logos avatars</li> <li><strong>With an image</strong>: for when a user uploads one</li> <li><strong>With initials and a colour background</strong>: for when a user doesn’t upload an image</li> <li><strong>5 sizes</strong>: xl, l, m, s and xs</li> </ul> <h2 id="step-3-identify-cases-of-reusability">Step 3: Identify cases of reusability</h2> <p>Now we know the requirements for the component, let’s come back to those 4 primitive Libraries. Which of these existing Libraries can we use to build our Avatar component?</p> <p>As identified in my audit, Avatars in the system are made up of 5 primitive properties:</p> <p><code>Color</code>, <code>Shape</code>, <code>Border</code>, <code>Text</code> and <code>Image</code></p> <p>3 of which can make use of the Libraries we made:</p> <p><code>Color</code>, <code>Shape</code> and <code>Border</code></p> <p><code>Text</code> and in this case <code>Image</code>, are both specific to the Avatar component, meaning these have little to no re-use elsewhere in my system. So it makes sense to handle these specificities directly within the Avatar Sketch file.</p> <h2 id="step-4-build-the-avatar-component">Step 4: Build the avatar component</h2> <p>Now we know the requirements, it’s time to create a new Sketch file and build our component. In my case I called the file <code>AIN-avatars</code>, where <code>AIN–</code> is the project name prefix. Useful for if you decide to create more than one system.</p> <p>From here I updated my folder structure from a flat system to organising Libraries by Atomic Design principles. This step isn’t crucial but it may help you think about the parts to your system in order of complexity.</p> <h3 id="method-using-abstract-for-version-control">Method using Abstract for version control</h3> <p>If you are using Abstract to keep track of revisions and changes, files set up is slightly different. You will want to <strong>create your file from within Abstract</strong>: <em>Add File &gt; Create Sketch file as Library</em>. This will prevent you running into problems where Abstract doesn’t recognise Symbols you made previously.</p> <p><em>Pro tips for Abstract: Always open files from within Abstract via the ‘Edit in Sketch’ button and not from Sketch. This will ensure the changes you make to your files are tracked by Abstract.</em></p> <h3 id="create-symbol-overrides-for-avatar-images">Create Symbol Overrides for avatar images</h3> <p>Inside my new file I created 5 Artboards, at my <code>xl</code> size (120px x 120px), giving me 5 override options to use for user profile images.</p> <p>Remembering the shape of my user profile images, I named these Artboards <code>avatar / image / rounded / 1</code> (1 through to 5) and created a 120px circle to fill each Artboard. Then I turned each shape into a mask: ctrl + click on the layer, then select Mask.</p> <p>I used the <a href="https://uifaces.co/sketch-plugin" target="_blank" rel="noopener">UI Faces Sketch Plugin</a> to auto generate my 5 images. Of course, you don’t have to stick to 5 images here, you could create as many user image overrides as you need. Once this is done turn each Artboard into a Symbol.</p> <p>From here, I created 5 more Artboards, again at my <code>xl</code> size for my 5 company logo overrides. I names these Artboards <code>avatar / image / 4px / 1</code> (1 through to 5). Next I added a shape layer with 4px radius, changed the color fill and added a different logo option for each. In my case I used logos from our other products, but you can use whichever Logos or graphics you wish.</p> <p>Don’t forget to turn your new Artboards into symbols once you’re done.</p> <p>Great! Now I have a total of 10 new symbols to use as Overrides for user profile images and company logos.</p> <h3 id="create-master-symbol-for-each-component-size">Create master Symbol for each component size</h3> <p>Building the master component is where the real Library magic happens. Here we’ll make use of our <code>border</code>, <code>shape</code> and <code>color</code> Libraries from earlier. I call it a ‘master’ component as this is the Avatar component we’ll place into designs when building larger components and design comps.</p> <p>To make the master components, I made 5 more Artboards, at the 5 different sizes determined using the 8pt grid system:</p> <ul> <li><code>xl</code>: 120px</li> <li><code>l</code>: 96px</li> <li><code>m</code>: 80px</li> <li><code>s</code>: 64px</li> <li><code>xs</code>: 40px</li> </ul> <h3 id="adding-symbol-overrides-from-libraries">Adding Symbol Overrides from Libraries</h3> <p>Now we need to insert our <code>Shape</code> Library. Do this for each of the 5 Artboard sizes: <em>Insert &gt; AIN-shapes &gt; shape/radius &gt; rounded</em>. This will allow us to change the Avatar shape from round to square for company logos.</p> <p>As my Color Library is nested inside my shape Library, that kills two birds with one stone. We now have control of our Avatar shape and color in the form of Symbol Overrides.</p> <p>Make sure the shape layer sits at the bottom, and you’ve renamed the layer <code>shape</code> for clean naming in your Override options.</p> <p>Now let’s do the same for the border. Our border will be handy for when the Avatar contains an image which clashes with the background colour of its container. Insert a border for each Artboard size now: <em>Insert &gt; AIN-borders &gt; border/radius &gt; rounded &gt; white</em>.</p> <p>Once you’ve placed your border library and it matches the shape, make sure the new layer sits at the top of the layer stack and you’ve renamed the layer to <code>border</code>. Again, this will keep your Overrides panel clean and easy to read.</p> <h3 id="adding-the-image-override-symbol-to-master-component">Adding the image Override Symbol to master component</h3> <p>Now let’s insert those image overrides we created earlier. Providing you named your Artboards sequentially, following the same naming convention, you should be able to override your image with any of the 5 options we made earlier: <em>Insert &gt; Symbols &gt; avatar &gt; image &gt; rounded &gt; 1</em>.</p> <p>Make sure you do this for each size. Again, rename the new layer to <code>image</code> for clean override names. Your image layer should sit above your shape layer.</p> <h3 id="adding-text-for-users-initials">Adding text for users initials</h3> <p>The final stage is to add the text used to write the initials of our user or company name. Initials only show in the component if a user fails to upload an image, for both user profile images and company logos.</p> <p>As mentioned, you can create text styles based on your typography scale, or use the <a href="http://www.textstyl.es/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Textstyl.es plugin</a> to synced your shared text styles* from another sketch file to your Avatar component file.</p> <p>*Shared text styles will become a native Sketch feature called ‘Library Styles’ in Sketch 51.</p> <p>Using the type scale used throughout my design system, I chose 3 font sizes: <code>20px</code>, <code>16px</code>, <code>14px</code> which fit all 5 component sizes.</p> <p>I made a new text layer for each Symbol size, placing it below the image layer. Now the text will be hidden from view whenever an image is selected.</p> <h2 id="step-5-using-component-overrides">Step 5: using component overrides</h2> <p>You should now have a flexible <code>Avatar</code> component, built using the fewest number of unique symbols possible.</p> <p>In order to test out your new component and its Overrides, insert a master symbol at the size of your choice: <em>Insert &gt; Symbol &gt; Avatar &gt; xlarge</em>.</p> <p>Providing you have the symbol selected, in the Inspector window on the right you will see all the possible overrides including those from your external Libraries.</p> <p>To make sense of all my Override options I made a page called <code>Avatars</code> where I keep a visual reference of all possible instances of Avatars used in my design.</p> <p>You should now have a complete Avatar component stored in a Library which can be nested in other Sketch files. We’ll take a look at how this works when we make a card component in the next article.</p> <h2 id="taking-it-further">Taking it further</h2> <p>There are a number of ways you can improve your workflow from here. I’ll start with a few essentials and let you run with it from there. You may well have specific requirements for your project which I haven’t accounted for.</p> <h3 id="using-sketch-runner-to-improve-speed-and-efficiency">Using Sketch Runner to improve speed and efficiency</h3> <p>Sketch runner is a valuable tool when it comes to using your Symbols and Libraries. Insert your components with <code>cmd + '</code>, then start typing the name of your symbol. This will become the fastest way to build mockups using your components as you start to remember all your various component names.</p> <h3 id="versioning-and-collaborating-on-libraries-using-abstract">Versioning and collaborating on Libraries using Abstract</h3> <p>I touched earlier on using Abstract for versioning your work.</p> <p>When you follow a component based workflow using multiple Libraries, Abstract will help you stay on top of all your files as your system grows or if you’re working as part of a team.</p> <p><em>Protip: Add your files to Abstract from the start. This will prevent you from having to comb through your files updating Symbols in order for Abstract to track them. I had to do this, and it wasn’t much fun!</em></p> <h3 id="sharing-libraries-with-your-team-via-sketch-cloud">Sharing Libraries with your team via Sketch Cloud</h3> <p>Sketch 49 saw the release of Sketch Cloud. Native sharing and collaborating on your Libraries with other designers is now possible, so no need for Dropbox or Google Drive.</p> <p>Personally I’ve been working as a solo design on the design systems I’ve created so haven’t used Sketch Cloud but would be interested in hearing from anyone who has.</p> <h2 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping up</h2> <p>In this article we’ve looked at how adopting principles from both Atomic and Subatomic Design can help us better understand how to build highly flexible Atom level components, using Sketch Libraries and Symbol Overrides.</p> <p>By building components primarily using Symbols from Libraries, we can reduce redundancy and design debt. Whilst Symbol Overrides allow us to maintain maximum flexibility in our components. Storing our components in Libraries keeps files lightweight, making our system easier to maintenance and less of a hassle to update.</p> <p>These components will become an integral part of our component based UI design system, as we use them as building blocks to rapid prototype larger parts of UI faster and with fewer inconsistencies.</p> <p>In the next part we’ll look at using Atom level components — the Avatars built here along with buttons — to build more complex component patterns, such as cards. You might categorise these larger components as Molecules, as per Atomic Design, but of course that’s totally your call.</p> <h2 id="further-resources">Further resources</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://daneden.me/2018/01/05/subatomic-design-systems/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Subatomic Design Systems</a> by Daniel Eden</li> <li><a href="http://atomicdesign.bradfrost.com/chapter-5/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Maintaining Design Systems</a> by Brad Frost</li> <li><a href="https://www.invisionapp.com/inside-design/guide-to-design-systems/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">A Comprehensive Guide to Design Systems</a> by Will Fanguy</li> <li><a href="https://medium.com/sketch-app-sources/using-sketch-libraries-and-primitives-to-build-an-even-better-system-of-buttons-ecc8f25486ac" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sketch Libraries: Building a better system of buttons</a> by me.</li> <li><a href="https://medium.com/ux-power-tools/sketch-libraries-how-they-work-and-the-crazy-stuff-you-can-do-with-them-fc10f142ac80" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sketch Libraries: How they work, and the crazy stuff you can do with them</a> by Jon Moore.</li> <li><a href="https://medium.com/sketch-app-sources/text-system-mastery-with-shared-styles-9931bea7d085" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Text System Mastery with Shared Styles</a> by Bunin Dmitriy</li> <li>Exporting text styles with <a href="http://www.textstyl.es/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Textstyl.es</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/zeroheight/library-styles-sync" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Library Styles Sync plugin</a> to sync shared styles from Library to doc</li> </ul>

item.title: Static site form handling with Netlify
item.content:encoded: <p><em>Note: This tutorial requires you have a static site which you deploy using <a href="https://www.netlify.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Netlify</a>. If you don‘t use Netlify, read on as you might well be convinced to switch.</em></p> <p>Chances are you might have read <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/articles/form-data-with-zapier/">Using Zapier to send form data</a>. I used Zapier to handle form submissions on the previous incarnation of this site. And it worked great. I was very happy with the fact I could by-pass subscription based static site form services like <a href="https://formspree.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Formspree</a> and <a href="https://formkeep.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Formkeep</a>, just by using Zapier Webhooks and a bit of AJAX to tidy things up.</p> <p>If you’re also running a static site and wondering how best to go about collecting form submissions without a backend, then <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/articles/form-data-with-zapier/">I’d highly recommend using Zapier</a>, everytime. There is however one exception, and the reason I made the switch. And that reason is Netlify.</p> <p>If you use Netlify to deploy your static site, there’s an even easier way to handle your form submissions. This article looks at how to get set up.</p> <p>In case you’re interested in seeing how this form we’re about to build works, then head over to <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/contact/">my contact page</a> for a quick demo. Feel free to test it out.</p> <h2 id="why-use-netlify-for-your-form-submissions">Why use Netlify for your form submissions</h2> <p>Before we get into the code, let’s run through why Netlify is an awesome option for static form handling.</p> <ul> <li>No need for any API calls</li> <li>No JS required</li> <li>Less code</li> <li>Built-in email and slack notification options for form submissions</li> <li>Optional integrate with <a href="https://zapier.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Zapier</a></li> <li>Receive file upload submissions</li> <li>Export form submissions to a CSV file</li> <li>Automatic spam filtering, reCAPTCHA 2 and honeypot field options</li> <li>Optional AJAX submissions</li> </ul> <p>That’s a fair amount of cool stuff we can do with Netlify Forms already.</p> <h2 id="so-whats-the-deal">So What’s the deal?</h2> <p>Netlify’s ’Forms Free’ includes up to 100 form submissions per month, if you hit the limit, Netlify will upgrade you to ’Forms Pro’, which includes 1000 submissions per month. Perfect for small business and personal websites.</p> <p>With that said, let’s take a look at how to set up a form to work with Netlify. I’ll be using my own setup as an example.</p> <h2 id="how-i-set-up-netlify-to-handle-forms">How I set up Netlify to handle forms</h2> <p>First, I created a new page on my site to host my new contact form. From the command line that looks something like this:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>cd site hugo new page/contact.html </code></pre><p>Notice I’m using <code>.html</code> and not <code>.md</code> as my contact page will contain the HTML needed for my form. Using the <code>.html</code> extension for pages is perfectly valid in Hugo.</p> <p>Inside my <code>contact.html</code> page I added some basic markup for my form:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">form</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;contact&#34;</span> <span class="na">method</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;POST&#34;</span> <span class="na">netlify</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>What is your name? </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;full-name&#34;</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;text&#34;</span> <span class="na">placeholder</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Your full name&#34;</span> <span class="na">required</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>What is your email address? </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;email-address&#34;</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;email&#34;</span> <span class="na">placeholder</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Your email&#34;</span> <span class="na">required</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>What your message? </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">textarea</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;message&#34;</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;text&#34;</span> <span class="na">placeholder</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Your message...&#34;</span> <span class="na">required</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">textarea</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">button</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;submit&#34;</span> <span class="na">value</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Submit&#34;</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Form-submit&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Submit<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">button</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">form</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p><em>Note: I’ve removed class names to make it easier to read, you will want to add some in order to style your form.</em></p> <p>For Netlify to start receiving my form submissions, it’s as simple as adding the <code>netlify</code> attribute to the <code>&lt;form&gt;</code> tag.</p> <p>Next go ahead and add a <code>name</code> attribute, so Netlify knows what to call the form in the Netlify web app. If you have more than one form on your site you will need to use unique names. I’ve called mine <code>name=&quot;contact&quot;</code>.</p> <p>That’s it! Once you push your new form page to your production site, Netlify will start receiving form submissions.</p> <h2 id="extending-your-form-for-spam-filtering">Extending your form for Spam filtering</h2> <p>Netlify runs a spam filter by default when a form is submitted, but you might want to add an extra layer of security by using a “Honeypot” field. This will keep bots from hammering your inbox with junk submissions.</p> <p>In the words of Netlify:</p> <p><em>”‘Honeypot‘ fields are hidden form fields that lure bot users into completing a field that human users can’t see. A form submitted with a completed honeypot field can be rejected as spam, because only a bot would see and complete the field.“</em></p> <p>Sounds like a good idea to me, so let’s get this set up now.</p> <p>All you need to do is add <code>netlify-honeypot=&quot;bot-field&quot;</code> to your <code>&lt;form&gt;</code> tag, then add a new input field in your form to catch those bots, <code>name=&quot;bot-field&quot;</code>.</p> <p>With that done your form should now look something like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">form</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;contact&#34;</span> <span class="na">netlify-honeypot</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;bot-field&#34;</span> <span class="na">method</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;POST&#34;</span> <span class="na">netlify</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">p</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">“u-visually-hidden&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Don’t fill this out if you&#39;re human: <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;bot-field&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">p</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>What is your name? </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;full-name&#34;</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;text&#34;</span> <span class="na">placeholder</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Your full name&#34;</span> <span class="na">required</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>What is your email address? </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;email-address&#34;</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;email&#34;</span> <span class="na">placeholder</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Your email&#34;</span> <span class="na">required</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>What your message? </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">textarea</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;message&#34;</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;text&#34;</span> <span class="na">placeholder</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Your message...&#34;</span> <span class="na">required</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">textarea</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">button</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;submit&#34;</span> <span class="na">value</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Submit&#34;</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Form-submit&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Submit<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">button</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">form</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>As you can see I’ve added <code>class=&quot;u-visually-hidden&quot;</code> to the <code>&lt;p&gt;</code> tag containing the “Honeypot” field. This is a reusable utility class which will hide the field with some simple CSS. Now bots will find the field but reader won’t.</p> <p>At this point Netlify is set up to collect form data and any spam will be filter out. The final thing to do is add some finesse with a custom page redirect.</p> <h2 id="adding-a-custom-success-page">Adding a custom success page</h2> <p>By default, when someone completes your form, they will see a generically styled success message with a link back to the form page, that’s fine but you might want something custom.</p> <p>I chose to replace this with <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/success/">a success page</a>, to inform visitors their message was submitted successfully and to say thanks.</p> <p>To do something similar create a new page, for example <code>/success/</code> and add an <code>action</code> attribute to your <code>&lt;form&gt;</code> tag.</p> <p>If all’s well and good, your form tag should now look something like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">form</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;contact&#34;</span> <span class="na">netlify-honeypot</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;bot-field&#34;</span> <span class="na">method</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;POST&#34;</span> <span class="na">action</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;/success/&#34;</span> <span class="na">netlify</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Make sure the path is relative, and starts with a <code>/</code>.</p> <p>Great, now we have a success page. The final thing to do is set up a way to receive our form submissions.</p> <h2 id="receiving-form-submissions">Receiving form submissions</h2> <p>Netlify has a few different notification options for form submissions, including email and Slack notifications.</p> <p>This is handled from within the Netlify web app. You can find the options in <strong>Settings &gt; Forms &gt; Form notifications</strong>. Select the <strong>Add notification</strong> dropdown to see your options. I chose to keep things simple for now, receiving a notification by email.</p> <h2 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping up</h2> <p>In this article we’ve looked at setting up static site form submissions using Netlify. If you’ve followed along you should now have a functioning contact form on your site which sends notifications to your email.</p> <p>From here you might consider adding more fields to your form or building a success alert using AJAX and ditching the success page.</p> <p>Perhaps you’re thinking about adding a few automation steps with Zapier, to send your submission data to other apps in your workflow. Whether that be updating your mailing list in Mailchimp or adding data to a google sheet. The possibilities are almost endless so I’ll leave you to decide where to take it next.</p> <p>Finally, if you haven’t seen it already, make sure you check out the article below from the Netlify blog, which goes into more detail on what can be done with form data using Netlify.</p> <h2 id="further-reading">Further reading</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.netlify.com/docs/form-handling/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Netlify Docs: Form Handling</a></li> </ul>

item.title: Adding external articles to a list page
item.content:encoded: <p> This solution will create a page for each external article which may effect your sitemap. If this is a problem then consider the approach in <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/articles/data-no-page/">Working with data which doesn’t require a page</a>. </p> <p class="intro"> Lately I’ve been publishing articles both here on my personal site and on Medium. It seems to be fairly common practice these days. </p> <p>In order to stay organised, as I publish on various sites, it seems logical to try and keep track of everything I’m writing in one place, and that means here on my personal site.</p> <p>To do this I came up with a super simple solution which extends the typical <a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/lists/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo List template</a> to include posts from external sources (in this case Medium). You’ll find this useful if like me you publish articles on multiple sites and want to link to all of them from one posts page on your <a href="https://gohugo.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hugo</a> site, without having to duplicate articles.</p> <h2 id="solution">Solution</h2> <p>All that’s needed to add external post links to your post list page, is one line of front matter, and some logic in the form of an If statement which uses the <a href="https://gohugo.io/functions/isset/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">isset function</a>.</p> <h2 id="step-1-create-new-post-with-specific-front-matter">Step 1: Create new post with specific front matter</h2> <p>First you’ll need to create a new post for your external article.</p> <p>In my case I do this by moving into the site folder within my Hugo site. From the command line: <code>cd site</code>, then <code>hugo new articles/external-article-name.md</code>. If you haven’t changed the name of your content type then you will use <code>hugo new posts/external-article-name.md</code>.</p> <p>You should now have a new article in <code>site &gt; content &gt; articles</code> with basic front matter included.</p> <p>Inside the front matter of your new post, include a new param for your external article. I called mine <code>affiliatelink</code>, but you could use something like <code>externallink</code> if you prefer. Add the URL of your external article as the value.</p> <p>Your posts should now look something like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nn">---</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;Sketch Libraries and primitives to build buttons&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">date</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="ld">2018-01-26T21:29:52</span><span class="m">+01</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="m">00</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">affiliatelink</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;https://medium.com/@harrycresswell/using-sketch-libraries-and-primitives-to-build-an-even-better-system-of-buttons-ecc8f25486ac&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nn">---</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>This is all you need to do in the post.</p> <h2 id="step-2-extending-the-list-page-template">Step 2: Extending the List page template</h2> <p>In order to get external articles showing on your <a href="https://gohugo.io/templates/lists/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">list page</a>, jump back into your <code>list.html</code> layout. In most cases you’ll find this in <code>layouts &gt; _default</code>.</p> <p>If you haven’t made any major changes your list page should look something like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">define</span> <span class="s">&#34;main&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Data</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Pages</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h3</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="nx">a</span> <span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Permalink }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h3</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Pretty simple stuff. All we’re doing here is looping through our posts and printing out the post title. In this case clicking the title will take you do to the single post url. This should look familiar.</p> <p>Now we need to extend this to include links to our external articles within the same loop:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">define</span> <span class="s">&#34;main&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Data</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Pages</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">h3</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;!</span><span class="o">--</span> <span class="nx">If</span> <span class="nx">external</span> <span class="nx">link</span> <span class="nx">exists</span> <span class="nx">in</span> <span class="nx">post</span> <span class="nx">matter</span> <span class="o">--</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nx">isset</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Params</span> <span class="s">&#34;affiliatelink&#34;</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">a</span> <span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Params.affiliatelink }}&#34;</span> <span class="nx">target</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;_blank&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="nx">span</span><span class="p">&gt;</span><span class="o">&amp;</span><span class="err">#</span><span class="mi">8599</span><span class="p">;&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">span</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;!</span><span class="o">--</span> <span class="nx">Else</span> <span class="nx">show</span> <span class="nx">internal</span> <span class="nx">post</span> <span class="nx">page</span> <span class="o">--</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span><span class="k">else</span><span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nx">a</span> <span class="nx">href</span><span class="p">=</span><span class="s">&#34;{{ .Permalink }}&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;{{</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Title</span> <span class="p">}}&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">a</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nx">h3</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="nx">end</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>So what’s going on here?</p> <p>First Hugo looks for <code>affiliatelink</code> in the front matter of our post. If the parameter exists, <code>isset</code> returns true and replaces our usual permalink with the URL value from our post front matter. If a value for <code>affiliatelink</code> doesn’t exist, our list behaves as normal. We handle this with an <code>else</code> statement.</p> <h2 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping up</h2> <p>Hopefully you’ve now implemented a simple bit of logic which serves up both external and internal links on your website.</p> <p>On a final note, if you want to differentiate between the different post types try using the <code>↗</code> icon and wrap in a <!-- raw HTML omitted --> positioned after your title. I also added a <code>target='_blank'</code> to the <code>a</code> tag. It’s not essential but it’s a quick and easy way to show your readers that the post is from an external source and the link will open in a new window</p> <p>I hope you’ve found this helpful. Any questions <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/contact/">leave me a message</a> or <a href="https://twitter.com/harrycresswell/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">shoot me a tweet</a>!</p>

item.title: Type Emoji’s on Mac shortcut
item.content:encoded: <p class="intro"> It’s hard to avoid Emojis. Whether you like using them on not they’re a great way to help visually communicate your thoughts and ideas. </p> <p>We all know how to use Emoji’s on a phone but do you know how to access the Emoji panel on a mac?</p> <p>The Mac Emoji keyboard shortcut is really easy to remember, whilst your cursor is in type mode, use the shortcut: <code>Command + Control + Spacebar</code> to bring up the Emoji character panel.</p> <p>Then select the Emoji to type it. The panel works exactly the way it does on an iPhone. Easy peasy! 🤙</p>

item.title: Building With Your Users
item.content:encoded: <p>”Build with your users, get quick feedback loops, and iterate after. We are so biased and imperfect as humans that it&rsquo;s impossible to get it right from the start. Also, you might get it right, but you might miss other bigger opportunities. Focus, start quickly, and put your product in front of users and let the free market destroy it or love it.”</p> <p><em>This was taken from an interview with <a href="https://twitter.com/vinrob" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Robin Vander Heyden</a> on <a href="https://www.indiehackers.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Indie hackers</a> where he discusses the success of his company <a href="https://www.manypixels.co/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ManyPixels</a>.</em></p> <h2 id="resources">Resources</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.indiehackers.com/interview/finding-inspiration-abroad-shipping-fast-and-growing-to-50k-mo-e55f6feafd" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Finding Inspiration Abroad, Shipping Fast, and Growing to $50k/mo</a></li> </ul>

item.title: Page content on your Hugo homepage
item.content:encoded: <p class="intro"> A simple Hugo snippet for displaying content from a specific page on your site homepage. </p> <p>Say for example I wanted to add the title and content from a page called “How it works” on my homepage.</p> <p>First I’d need to create a page called how it works.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>$ hugo new page/how-it-works.md </code></pre><p>In the page front matter add a parameter called <code>type</code> and give it a value which makes sense.</p> <p>That might look something like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-yaml" data-lang="yaml"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="nn">---</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">title</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;How It Works&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">date</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="ld">2018-03-02T14:58:10</span><span class="m">+01</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="m">00</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nt">type</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&#34;how&#34;</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="w"></span><span class="nn">---</span><span class="w"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><p>Then in your <code>index.html</code> add the following:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-go" data-lang="go"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;!</span><span class="o">--</span> <span class="nx">show</span> <span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="k">range</span> <span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Data</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">Pages</span> <span class="p">}}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">{{</span><span class="k">if</span> <span class="nx">look</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="kd">type</span> <span class="nx">in</span> <span class="nx">the</span> <span class="nx">front</span> <span class="nx">matter</span> <span class="nx">of</span> <span class="nx">page</span> <span class="o">--</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span item.title: Better design systems in Sketch
item.content:encoded: <p> This article was originally posted on <a href="https://medium.com/@harrycresswell/using-sketch-libraries-to-build-a-better-ui-design-system-part-1-26f5660f3c98">Medium.com</a> </p> <figure> <blockquote class="PullQuote PullQuote--right"> <p> “Design is just problem solving within a set of constraints. In the grand scheme of things, it rarely has anything to do with graphics.” </p> <figcaption>&mdash; Adam Morse</figcaption> </blockquote> </figure> <p>Designers who have worked with <a href="https://airbnb.design/building-a-visual-language/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a design system</a> before will understand constraints as the various elements in a visual language, constructed to guide our every decision. Colors, icons and buttons are just some of these elements which together, form a unified system of tools to work with.</p> <p>Systems of constraint help us pave a path in which to follow, improving the efficiency and speed of our process. Promoting reusability and consistency in our work, they enable us to design better digital products. When used effectively, our projects are scalable and maintaining them easier.</p> <p>That being said, often the reality of managing these systems is quite different. Whilst Sketch has made the process easier, it’s still not without it’s quirks.</p> <h2 id="the-problem">The Problem</h2> <p>Before the arrival of Sketch Libraries we had <a href="https://www.sketch.com/docs/symbols/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Symbols</a>— the biggest leap forward to date, in the world of design systems. Symbols helped solve issues concerning consistency, making parts of our interface re-usable. However Symbols were document dependent. Until now, there was no native way for Symbols to transcend the Sketch files they lived in.</p> <h3 id="why-is-this-a-problem">Why is this a problem?</h3> <p>For small projects this wasn’t a big deal. You could keep your entire design in one Sketch document. Mockups, wireframes, userflows, UI Kit, the lot. Symbols worked fine as all your project required was in one document.</p> <p>But what happens when you’re designing bigger projects? Perhaps you want Sketch to run fast and free of bloat, so you split your project into multiple sketch files, surely it will be easier to manage? It will. That is until you want these various files to reference one set of symbols.</p> <p>At <a href="https://www.angelinvestmentnetwork.co.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AIN</a> we have 3 different products which all utilise one design system (or set of symbols). The challenge has been working out how to use the same set of symbols simultaneously, for all 3 projects. Bare in mind these projects are big, each one containing hundreds of Artboards. Using one Sketch document for everything just wouldn’t make sense—the file size would be unmanageable.</p> <h3 id="the-old-way-of-doing-it">The old way of doing it</h3> <p>My old process involved using a Sketch Template for my Symbols, which I picked up from <a href="https://blog.marvelapp.com/creating-maintaining-marvel-style-guide-sketch/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Yavor Punchev’s awesome process for the Marvel style guide</a>. I extended Yavor’s method by pulling Symbols into different Sketch documents using the Shared Library feature of Craft plugin by Invision. Maybe this process sounds familiar?</p> <p>Truth be told, this is a hacky process which I don’t recommend using. Yes my files were bloat free, and I could insert Symbols into multiple documents, but I had no way of syncing updates to those Symbols already in use across different files.</p> <p>Symbols are designed to make projects easier to maintain. Whilst this method allowed for re-usability, it made maintaining and updating existing symbols impossible.</p> <p><em>Side note: I couldn’t use Sketch Runner to search for and insert symbols on the fly using this process. Nothing major but still annoying as Runner is a huge time saver.</em></p> <p>Luckily, the solution arrives with Libraries, new for Sketch 47.</p> <h2 id="the-solution">The Solution</h2> <p><a href="https://blog.sketchapp.com/libraries-an-in-depth-look-56b147022e1f" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sketch Libraries</a> allow you to create a Library of Symbols, which can be use across multiple documents. We’re talking SASS partials for the developers out there. On top of that, you can also nest Libraries within Libraries. This is big news.</p> <p>Essentially, you can now keep different groups of symbols in their own Sketch file. That means different document for your buttons, colours, icons, form elements, and whatever else you might use in your system. Other documents in your project can then reference the symbols in these source files, and at the click of a button sync when you make any updates to those symbols.</p> <p>Simply put; you now have one source of truth for all your different UI element, which, in turn, all your other Sketch files reference. The advantages to doing this will soon become clear:</p> <ul> <li>Smaller file sizes</li> <li>Faster Sketch performance</li> <li>Reusable components</li> <li>Maintainable projects</li> </ul> <p><a href="https://medium.com/@pablostanley" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Pablo Stanley</a> summed it up pretty well: “This is like the holy grail of product design”. You can watch Pablo getting excited about Libraries here.</p> <p>Libraries explained by the Sketch team:</p> <p>_“A Library is just an ordinary Sketch document that contains Symbols which you can then use in any other Sketch document. If you update any of those Symbols in your Library file, documents containing instances of those Symbols will receive a notification telling you that they can be updated. Here you can preview, check, and confirm changes — and by doing so, you can always ensure your documents are using the up-to-date copies of those components.” _</p> <h2 id="putting-sketch-libraries-into-practice-to-build-a-component-library">Putting Sketch Libraries into practice to build a component library</h2> <p>The next part of this article will look how I’m using Sketch Libraries to maintain a system of UI components. But first, there are a few things to keep in mind:</p> <p><strong>Think like a developer</strong> Adopting the developer mindset when designing systems is imperative. There are many lessons we can learn.</p> <p><strong>D.R.Y — Don’t repeat yourself</strong> The idea is to create re-usable components. This keeps our files lightweight and our design consistent.</p> <p><strong>Think in Primitives</strong> Every component we create is made up of a certain set of properties. These properties are the most ‘primitive’ elements, used throughout a design system. A developer would create variables for these properties to prevent duplicates in the code. We can do the same, by creating a Library files for all primitives which we can utilise when we build larger components.</p> <p><strong>Atomic Design Methodology</strong> I’m following <a href="http://bradfrost.com/blog/post/atomic-web-design/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Brad Frost’s Atomic Design Methodology</a> for building scaleable interfaces. Primarily because it’s easy follow and everyone understands the principles.</p> <p>In a nutshell, Atomic Design takes inspiration from the molecular structure of the natural word. Where Atoms; the basic building blocks or in our case the smallest parts of a visibly recognisable UI, combine to form Molecules; the larger parts of our interface. Organisms are the assemblies of these Molecules and represent even larger, more complex parts of our interface.</p> <h3 id="separate-sketch-documents-for-all-groups-of-symbols">Separate Sketch documents for all groups of symbols</h3> <p>Of course, you can still create one file for all your components if you prefer—and reference Symbols from that file in other documents—however my suggestion (and the way we’ll be doing it here) is to create individual documents for each group of Symbols.</p> <p>Again, this is similar to how a developer might use Sass partials. Using lots of smaller documents make our design system easier to manage. The other advantage is our Library files will be re-useable in other projects and importantly, it will be scaleable.</p> <p>By thinking in primitives, we can start by creating Libraries for the core elements which will be used across our entire design system. These basic properties will make up all Atoms, Molecules and Organisms.</p> <p>Let’s start by creating a new Sketch document for the colors in our system. Colors are highly reusable and found throughout our UI—a sensible place to start.</p> <h2 id="step-1-create-a-new-sketch-document-for-your-colors">Step 1: create a new Sketch document for your colors</h2> <p>I started by prefixing the name of my sketch document with AIN- so not to confuse them with any other ‘non AIN’ projects I’m currently working on. For example AIN-colors and so fourth.</p> <p><em>Note: Obviously this part is totally optional but you might find it useful if, like me, you work on several different unrelated projects and like to be organised.</em></p> <p>Following this, I made a Shared Style for each colour in our design system and organised them into categories: brand, greyscale and ui by using a ‘/’ in the name, to build the folder structure.</p> <p>Then I made each color style into a Symbol, and arranged them on my Symbols page using the <a href="https://github.com/sonburn/symbol-organizer" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Symbol Organiser</a> plugin. My category naming convention from the previous step made this process nice and straight forward.
