Now all my Symbols are clearly labeled and organised.</p> <h2 id="step-2-turn-your-colors-document-into-a-library">Step 2: turn your colors document into a Library</h2> <p>The next step is to turn your file to a Sketch Library. We will need to do this each time we want to use a Sketch file into a Library.</p> <p>In <em>Sketch &gt; Preferences</em>, you’ll find the new Libraries tab. Click Add Library and locate your new file.</p> <p>Using my example from above, I made my AIN-colors document into my first Library. As my colors document is now a Library, I can nest my colors inside of other Sketch files. This is where the power of Libraries comes in. We will see how helpful this is when I create the next Library document in the system – for my icons.</p> <h2 id="step-3-create-a-new-sketch-file-for-your-icons">Step 3: create a new Sketch file for your icons</h2> <p>Next I did the same thing as I just did for my colors, but this time for icons.</p> <p>First create a file for your all your icons. This time I named the document AIN-icons and saved it in the same folder as my AIN-colors file. This is the start of my ‘folder of truth’—the directory that all the components in my design system will live in.</p> <p>I then created a 24x24px Artboard and placed the icon. I made a 24x24px transparent container below the icon shape (if your using Google’s Material Icons this will already be in place), then I inserted the brand color Symbol from my AIN-colors Library (Insert &gt; AIN-colors) on top of my icon shape. Resizing the Symbol to 24x24px after.</p> <p><em>Note: the purple Symbol icon in the layer view is now a link, instead of the usual rotating arrows. This means your Symbol is from an external library which your file is referencing. So don’t expect to find it on the Symbols page in your current document.</em></p> <p>Next I turned my icon shape into a mask (Ctrl + Click &gt; Mask), which reveals the original icon shape below. Now our icon shape is masking the color Symbol from our Color Library.</p> <p>Awesome, I’ve used my first Library. That means I can now change the color of my icons throughout my system, to any color in my color Library. If I need to make changes to my AIN-color file, those changes will also occur in my icons file or anywhere else I reference my colors Library.</p> <p>Next, be sure to turn each icon Artboard into a Symbol, this is important if you want to use your icons document as a Library—which we do.</p> <p><em>Pro tip: When creating your icon Symbols, make sure you check “Adjust content on resize” and set “pin object to all edges on re-size”, this will ensure you icon scales, should you wish to use it at bigger or smaller sizes than the base size of 24px. Also make sure your size dimensions are locked so the whole Symbol scales correctly.</em></p> <p>I repeated this process for all icons used in the AIN design system, each set at a base size of 24px. Then I organised my Symbols using the Symbols Organizer plugin, as before.</p> <h2 id="step-4-turn-your-icons-file-into-a-library">Step 4: turn your icons file into a Library</h2> <p>This is the same process as Step 2 above, so follow that again, but this time for your icons.</p> <p>At this point you should have 2 Library files. In my case I have AIN-colors and AIN-icons. Now our icons are ready to use in other documents.</p> <h2 id="step-5-repeat-the-process-for-your-atoms">Step 5: repeat the process for your atoms</h2> <p>Hopefully this has been enough to help you get the gist of this workflow.</p> <p>Continue with your own system by creating Library files for all the different Atoms in your design system. Build your Atoms from the Primitive Library files you’ve created. Nesting them as you go. For the design system at AIN, I made Libraries for my buttons, form elements, avatars and so on, until I had a folder of truth containing all the atom level elements in our system. I can now reference these Libraries in other documents, where I’m designing even larger components of the interface and hi-fidelity mockups.</p> <h3 id="updating-your-library-files">Updating your Library files</h3> <p>Inevitably, you will at some point need to make changes to Symbols in your core Library files. Luckily this is pretty straight forward, just make your changes as normal. When changes are made, any other documents containing the updated Symbols will show an alert in the top right corner of the Sketch document which needs updating.</p> <p>When you see this, make sure you click it. Sketch will show you the outdated symbols and the new versions which will replace them. Click Update Symbols to sync the changes across documents. That’s it, pretty simple.</p> <h2 id="taking-it-further">Taking it further</h2> <p>Once you’ve built your Atoms, you’re ready to start building more complex parts of your UI; your ‘Molecules’ if you like, and following that, your ‘Organisms’. Each time making use of the Libraries you’ve created by nesting them inside one another.</p> <p>As your system become more complex and you build out your interface, you can utilise these Libraries you’ve created. In essence, you will now have a Sketch design system to work with, usable in any document or any project.</p> <p>In the second part we’ll look at putting our system to use, by building out the more complex components, for now here are a few ideas of where to go next:</p> <p><strong>Possible ideas for Molecules:</strong> Navigation, Hero, Banner.</p> <p><strong>Possible ideas for Organisms:</strong> Cards, Media, Header, Footer.</p> <p><em>Note: The Atomic Design Methodology is just a guideline, there are no set rules. If your navigation is complex it might be more suited to being an Organism. In that case go with it. Use the method as you see fit. Alternatively come up with a method of your own.</em></p> <h3 id="sharing-libraries-across-different-devices">Sharing Libraries across different devices</h3> <p>One thing I haven’t looked at is how Libraries work with Dropbox or Google Drive. I’m guessing this isn’t a big deal, but I haven’t tried it yet. This would be super useful for remote workers or teams looking to share design assets or work with a system across multiple devices. Perhaps you know more about this than I do?</p> <h2 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping Up</h2> <p>We just looked at using <a href="https://www.sketch.com/docs/libraries/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Libraries</a> new for <a href="https://blog.sketchapp.com/introducing-libraries-and-smooth-corners-in-sketch-47-2abc5dfc1fb3" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sketch 47</a> to create a modular system or component library to use in our design projects. Hopefully by now it’s clear how powerful the feature is.</p> <p>If you’re working in a team of designers, sharing design elements or working independently and looking for a better way to manage on-going projects then try incorporating Libraries into your workflow. Libraries are easily the biggest leap forward for Sketch users since Symbols when it comes to the challenging process of maintaining a design system.</p> <p><a href="https://www.dropbox.com/home/harrycresswell/05_writing/graphics%20and%20images/medium%20articles/sketch-libraries-part-1/sample%20project%20for%20download/folder%20of%20truth" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Download the example project</a> for reference, it includes files for colors, icons and buttons, plus a quick example project which uses these Library files. I hope it helps you to see how I’ve set things up. Bare in mind you’ll need a copy of Sketch 47 for all this stuff to work.</p> <p>If you found this article helpful, please share it with any friends who would benefit. Thanks for reading!</p> <p>Looking for part 2? You can <a href="https://medium.com/sketch-app-sources/using-sketch-libraries-to-build-a-better-ui-design-system-part-2-8de6cef5adc5" target="_blank" rel="noopener">find it here</a>.</p> <h2 id="resources">Resources</h2> <ul> <li><a href="https://blog.sketchapp.com/libraries-an-in-depth-look-56b147022e1f" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Libraries, an in depth look</a> by Sketch</li> <li><a href="https://medium.com/ux-power-tools/sketch-libraries-how-they-work-and-the-crazy-stuff-you-can-do-with-them-fc10f142ac80" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sketch Libraries</a> by Jon Moore</li> <li>Brad Frost’s <a href="http://atomicdesign.bradfrost.com/chapter-2/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Atomic Design Methodology</a></li> <li>Pablo Stanley on <a href="http://atomicdesign.bradfrost.com/chapter-2/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sketch Libraries</a></li> <li><a href="https://blog.sketchapp.com/introducing-libraries-and-smooth-corners-in-sketch-47-2abc5dfc1fb3" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Introducing Libraries</a> by Sketch</li> <li><a href="https://airbnb.design/building-a-visual-language/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Airbnb: Building a Visual Language</a> from Karri Saarinen</li> </ul>

item.title: Launching successful side projects
item.content:encoded: <p class="intro"> Starting a new project can be a daunting process. Often we start with an idea in our head, then picture the final outcome – a finely polished product, the ideal scenario. </p> <p>At this early stage it might feel like an impossible task to get there, like you’re at the foot of a mountain unable to see the summit.</p> <p>This is the point where a lot of us give up or start feeling overwhelmed by the task ahead. It’s so easy to feel like this. You’ve imagined up this big idea and you have no idea where to start.</p> <p>If you manage to get past that first stage, congratulations, you’re half way there. But maybe now you’re working tirelessly around the clock to perfect your product in time for launch. Then you launch, expecting great things to happen and an unmanageable stream of interest to come flooding in.</p> <p>In reality it’s often the complete opposite. Maybe this sounds familiar or at least you know someone who’s been there. I feel like we all have in some form at some point in our lives. Be it when launching new a business, working on an article, writing a book or whatever.</p> <p>Here’s some ideas I’ve picked up along the way, to give you the best possible chance of launching products that don’t fall flat on their face, leaving you feeling disheartened and ready to chuck it all in.</p> <h2 id="get-your-ideas-out-there">Get your ideas out there</h2> <p>If you don’t have a product yet, don’t let that stop you. Launch your ideas instead. Before you even entertain the idea of building a product, get your ideas out there in their rawest form. This is a very low risk way of proving a concept and validating the potential of your ideas.</p> <p>It’s the easiest way to test the water and see if people like what you’re building. The worst thing you can do is waste your time and energy working on something no one wants. If you’re building something interesting, then start telling people about it. What’s the worst that can happen? Maybe you’ll start a few more conversations and open a few more doors. Whatever it is, trust that only good things will happen.</p> <h2 id="launch-before-youre-ready">Launch before you’re ready</h2> <p>I’ve read a lot lately on why we should in fact be launching polished products from day one, but I remain firmly rooted in the camp that says <strong>launch your product before it’s ready</strong>. If you know what’s what you will have already launched when it was just an idea in it’s infancy.</p> <p>As we all know, products and business are a constant work in progress, inevitably they evolve and change in time. Like our own lives, they take a great deal of iteration and fine tuning, they require us to listen to ourselves and our audience, in order to truly understand the direction to take.</p> <p>So if you’re waiting for the perfect time to launch, know that day will never come. If your work is never be done, then there is no perfect time to launch. Don’t make the mistake of waiting until you perfect it, before you release it. Launch now, perfect later.</p> <h2 id="always-work-on-more-than-one-thing">Always work on more than one thing</h2> <p>When I said launch ideas I didn’t mean ’launch an idea’. The cold reality is most projects will fail, so don’t go put all your energy into just one. Launch as many ideas as you can, then see which sticks. That way you won’t get hung up if one fails, as more than likely you will just shift your focus to the one with more potential.</p> <p>Think about how all todays great companies started for a second. A lot of them were side projects or just simple far flung ideas. At least they were nothing like they do today. Think Air Bed and Breakfast, Apple when it had the Newton logo, or when Elon Musk was laughed out of Russia when he tried to buy an ex-Soviet rocket. Who’s laughing now.</p> <p>Hunt down your target audience and start collecting feedback. Send out a questionnaire, a tweet, pick up the phone and find out if theres any interest in your ideas.</p> <h2 id="dont-be-too-precious">Don&rsquo;t be too precious</h2> <p>9 times out of 10, someone has already had your idea, or nobody really cares to try and built it. So forget the NDA&rsquo;s and secrecy, it’s all in the execution after all, not the idea. Even if someone else steals your idea, the end result will be quite different. After all, as much as we try and copy each other, human nature doesn’t allow for this level of perfection. <a href="https://www.tesla.com/blog/all-our-patent-are-belong-you" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Did anyone build Tesla when Elon Musk released the patents?</a> It takes more than an idea to build products. The more open you are, the more interest you will attract.</p> <h2 id="listen-to-your-audience">Listen to your audience</h2> <p>Always gather feedback from your audience and work with real data. Collecting data as your product evolves is invaluable. Whether it be analytics or feedback from users and customers, it’s absolutely vital. This is the best way to learn about what works and what doesn’t. If your product is out to solve problems then you ought to find out what the problems are that need solving. If you’ve build a website, you probably want to reach out to your audience to find out what they are struggling with or what new featured they would like to see added.</p> <p>By doing this you can safely make iterations to your product without a negative impact, because you know you’re are doing the right thing. If you do this you will find yourself creating the product that people want. No second guessing. No building products based on assumption. You know <a href="https://blog.kissmetrics.com/how-netflix-uses-analytics/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Netflix creates series based on the data they collect</a>, now we all know why they are so successfully. This is user centered design at it’s best. Essentially they pre-empt a shows success before they’ve even made it, because they know they have an audience which matches the criteria.</p> <h2 id="always-back-up-assumptions-with-real-data">Always back up assumptions with real data</h2> <p>Ok so I’m kind of repeating myself here but that’s only to stress the importance of data. Don’t build products you think people want. Build products you know there is already a demand for. It’s never been easier to reach an audience and ask for feedback, so before you start building your product start collecting data to work with. It can be as simple as <a href="https://www.typeform.com/blog/guides/minimum-viable-product/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sending out a survey or a questionnaire</a> or building <a href="https://blog.bufferapp.com/idea-to-paying-customers-in-7-weeks-how-we-did-it" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a clever product landing page</a>. It doesn’t get more straight forward than creating a new Instagram page and seeing what posts get the most engagement. Think about where your audience hangs out. Start conversations and share what you’re working on. Always try and look for quick and easy ways test your ideas before you dive in head first.</p> <p>As long as you get the worst, most unpolished version of your product out there first, and then improve it based on the data you collect, you will set yourself up for the best chance of success.</p> <p><em>Note: These thoughts were initially sparked after reading a post by Joel Gascoigne of Buffer fame (link below), many years ago. I apply this same mentality to writing. Get it out there even if it sucks. Then go back and improve it later.</em></p> <h3 id="resources">Resources</h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.tesla.com/blog/all-our-patent-are-belong-you" target="_blank" rel="noopener">All Our Patents Belong to You</a> by Elon Musk, CEO Tesla</li> <li><a href="https://blog.kissmetrics.com/how-netflix-uses-analytics/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">How Netflix uses analytics</a> by Zach Bulygo, Kissmetrics blog.</li> <li><a href="https://blog.bufferapp.com/idea-to-paying-customers-in-7-weeks-how-we-did-it" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Idea to Paying Customers in 7 Weeks: How We Did It</a> by Joel Gascoigne, CEO Buffer</li> <li><a href="https://www.typeform.com/blog/guides/minimum-viable-product/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">How to validate your next big idea</a> from the Typeform Blog.</li> </ul>

item.title: Naming Artboards for responsive web design
item.content:encoded: <p class="intro"> Naming Artboards might not be the most exciting subject, but non the less, it&rsquo;s an important one. If it&rsquo;s not already, a solid Artboard naming system should be a critical part of your design process. </p> <p>A year or so ago I started thinking more about how best to name Artboards in Sketch. After a fair bit of trial and error, I arrived at a particular technique which just works. <strong>I&rsquo;ve used this method extensively for a year</strong> or so now without having to revisit it.</p> <p>More recently, I decided to find out if anyone else had approached the subject of naming Artboards, but I found very little. Seeing as not much had been written, I figured it was time to share my method.</p> <p><strong>This technique is best suited to Responsive Web Design (RWD)</strong>. That being said, if your focus is on design for mobile the principles still remain the same and it should work just as well.</p> <p>I&rsquo;ve used this technique both for personal projects and in production working with teams. It has helped us to clean up (and stay on top of) otherwise complex and unmanageable Sketch files. Without much thought, we&rsquo;re now producing <strong>well organised, scaleable mockups which are easy to maintain</strong>. At the very least, using this technique should help you avoid the numerous headaches caused by messy Sketch files, when you’re working on big projects or as part of a team.</p> <p>Before I get into explaining the technique, let&rsquo;s first look at why you might want to consider using a system to name your Artboards in the first place.</p> <figure class="Image"> <div class="aspect-ratio-landscape"> <img srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_256/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-organised-albion-03.jpg 256w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-organised-albion-03.jpg 512w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_768/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-organised-albion-03.jpg 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1024/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-organised-albion-03.jpg 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1280/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-organised-albion-03.jpg 1280w" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-organised-albion-03.jpg" alt="A well organised Sketch file" class="lazyload" /> </div> <figcaption>A well organised Sketch file</figcaption> </figure> <h2 id="maintainability">Maintainability</h2> <p>We&rsquo;re designers. We like to be organised.</p> <p>Nobody wants to fire open a sketch file in 6 months time and find a mess of arbitrarily named Artboards. I certainly don&rsquo;t, i&rsquo;m sure you don&rsquo;t either. <strong>It pays to be organised, and that goes for your Artboards too</strong>.</p> <p>So the point is this; we want to be able to know exactly what state, in what stage, of what flow any given Artboard belongs to. In order to do this we need a system. A system that is quick to understand — by anyone in our team — and efficient in its implementation. No nonsense. Minimal fuss.</p> <p>I&rsquo;m sure you&rsquo;ll agree with me here. The sketch file above — where the Artboards are clearly named and numbered — will be easier to manage than the Sketch file below – which will become a nightmare to deal with as the number of Artborards grows.</p> <figure class="Image"> <div class="aspect-ratio-landscape"> <img srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_256/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-unorganised.jpg 256w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-unorganised.jpg 512w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_768/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-unorganised.jpg 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1024/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-unorganised.jpg 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1280/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-unorganised.jpg 1280w" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-unorganised.jpg" alt="A badly organised Sketch file" class="lazyload" /> </div> <figcaption>A badly organised Sketch file</figcaption> </figure> <h2 id="scalability">Scalability</h2> <p><strong>Does it scale?</strong> We&rsquo;re not talking about front end frameworks here (let&rsquo;s leave that for another one). Instead, we&rsquo;re trying to solve the problem you have when you need to add in an extra step (or stage) to a flow you created last week, let&rsquo;s say.</p> <p><strong>Does your system allow you to add in extra Artboards — anywhere in the sequence</strong> — without you having to go through and rename the rest of your Artboards to maintain some sort of order?</p> <figure class="Image"> <div class="aspect-ratio-landscape"> <img srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_256/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-organised-albion-02.jpg 256w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-organised-albion-02.jpg 512w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_768/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-organised-albion-02.jpg 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1024/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-organised-albion-02.jpg 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1280/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-organised-albion-02.jpg 1280w" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-organised-albion-02.jpg" alt="Another well organised Sketch file" class="lazyload" /> </div> <figcaption>Another well organised Sketch file</figcaption> </figure> <h2 id="communication">Communication</h2> <p>In most cases the design process tends to involve a few more people than just one designer.</p> <p>So the question is; <strong>does the rest of your team understand what&rsquo;s going on in the Sketch file?</strong></p> <p>Ok, I doubt all team members will need access to our Sketch files, but they will have to see them at some point. Without a naming system, the problems will start to show when you start using a prototyping tool like Invison. Unless your working on a side project, your team, your client or whoever will need to feedback on your designs. Sure they can comment on Invision, but all too often you&rsquo;ll find you need a simple way to verbally discuss an Artboard. Which is much easier when you have a reference code.</p> <p><strong>Giving your team a quick and easy way to reference Artboards will make your life a lot easier</strong>, particularly as your project grows. We like our team right? Let&rsquo;s introduce a system which is great for them and not just ourselves.</p> <figure class="Image"> <div class="aspect-ratio-landscape"> <img srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_256/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-invision.jpg 256w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-invision.jpg 512w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_768/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-invision.jpg 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1024/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-invision.jpg 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1280/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-invision.jpg 1280w" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264893/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-invision.jpg" alt="Prefixing Artboard names with a reference short code makes discussion and organisation easier" class="lazyload" /> </div> <figcaption>Prefixing Artboard names with a reference short code makes discussion and organisation easier</figcaption> </figure> <p>Ok enough of the reasoning, I&rsquo;m sure you get the idea by now. Let&rsquo;s look take a look at the system and explain how it works.</p> <h2 id="how-the-system-works">How the system works</h2> <p>Ok, the basic idea is this:</p> <ul> <li>Make sure you use a 4 level sequence.</li> <li>Use both a reference code and a description.</li> <li>Pick a clear and descriptive, sequential structure (i.e Breakpoint, Flow, Stage, State).</li> </ul> <h3 id="using-a-4-level-sequence">Using a 4 level sequence</h3> <p>I&rsquo;m using <strong>a 4 level numerical sequence followed by a description</strong>, where the purpose of the description is to explain the numerical sequence in a more verbose manner.</p> <figure class="Image"> <div class="aspect-ratio-landscape"> <img srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_256/v1550264882/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-01.jpg 256w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264882/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-01.jpg 512w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_768/v1550264882/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-01.jpg 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1024/v1550264882/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-01.jpg 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1280/v1550264882/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-01.jpg 1280w" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264882/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-01.jpg" alt="4 level sequence — Breakpoint, Flow, Stage, State" class="lazyload" /> </div> <figcaption>4 level sequence — Breakpoint, Flow, Stage, State</figcaption> </figure> <p>The four levels represent the <strong>Breakpoint, the flow, the stage and the state</strong> of our design.</p> <p>I will come to exactly what I mean by this a bit later, but first let&rsquo;s look at why we&rsquo;re using a code and a description.</p> <h3 id="use-a-reference-code-and-a-description">Use a reference code and a description</h3> <p><strong>Using both a code and a description makes our Artboards easy to understand and equally as easy to reference</strong> — and not just by us — by the whole of our team.</p> <p>On it&rsquo;s own, the description (let&rsquo;s call it the <code>Unique Identifying Description</code> or <code>UID</code> for short) isn&rsquo;t exactly quick to reference, and it doesn&rsquo;t help us order our Artboards in any way, but it is still important as it accurately explains the contents of our Artboard.</p> <p>By prefixing the <code>UID</code> with a numerical sequence, we now have a quick and easy reference code, if you like. By adding this code (let&rsquo;s call it the <code>Unique Identifier Code</code> or <code>UIC</code> for short) we now have a clear system for ordering our Artboards. <strong>This is particularly useful when we start using tools like Invision</strong> and you or another team member needs to pin point a particular Artboard to discuss.</p> <p>Likewise, using the <code>UIC</code> alone won&rsquo;t make much sense — it&rsquo;s not descriptive of the Artboards contents. But add the two together and you have a quick shortcode (the <code>UIC</code>) used for reference purposes, and a more descriptive text version (the <code>UID</code>), which helps us further identify the design on our Artboard.</p> <figure class="Image"> <div class="aspect-ratio-landscape"> <img srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_256/v1550264891/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-02.jpg 256w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264891/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-02.jpg 512w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_768/v1550264891/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-02.jpg 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1024/v1550264891/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-02.jpg 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1280/v1550264891/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-02.jpg 1280w" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264891/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-02.jpg" alt="Using a unique identifying code and description" class="lazyload" /> </div> <figcaption>Using a unique identifying code and description</figcaption> </figure> <h2 id="the-sequential-structure">The sequential structure</h2> <p>Ok. So why use four levels, isn&rsquo;t that over kill? Surely one level is enough? Can&rsquo;t we just use something like <code>1 - homepage</code>, <code>2 - checkout</code> etc, and be done with it? And, <strong>what exactly does the Breakpoint, Flow, Stage and State represent?</strong></p> <p>Let&rsquo;s look at that now — it will help us understand why having four levels in the sequence is important.</p> <h3 id="the-breakpoint">The Breakpoint</h3> <p>In RWD, the Breakpoint is very important, so we will consider this first. <strong>The breakpoint is the screen resolution you are designing for</strong>, in case you didn&rsquo;t know. Think <code>1200px</code>, <code>960px</code>, <code>768px</code>, <code>320px</code> or if you prefer Desktop HD, Desktop, Tablet, Mobile etc. This should be the deciding factor that determines what Artboard size you choose for your design.</p> <p>If you are design a responsive website you&rsquo;re design will most likely change at different screen sizes. We&rsquo;ll need a different Artboard to show how the design looks for each size.</p> <p>Let&rsquo;s say our design isn&rsquo;t a mockup of the large desktop view (like in the example above), but in fact a regular desktop view or a mockup of our website at a breakpoint of <code>960px</code>. In this case we would create a new Artboard and change the breakpoint in our Artboard name to reflect that.</p> <p>In the example below you can see the Breakpoint is <code>960</code>. This, of course, stands for 960 pixels (our desktop size) and suggests how our website will look on a Desktop browser.</p> <figure class="Image"> <div class="aspect-ratio-landscape"> <img srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_256/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-03.jpg 256w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-03.jpg 512w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_768/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-03.jpg 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1024/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-03.jpg 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1280/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-03.jpg 1280w" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-03.jpg" alt="Breaking down the identifier code" class="lazyload" /> </div> <figcaption>Breaking down the identifier code</figcaption> </figure> <h3 id="the-flow">The Flow</h3> <p>Flow is second in the sequence. This is <strong>the particular user flow you are designing</strong>. An obvious example would be, let&rsquo;s say, the <code>Checkout</code> flow. Think UX here. <strong>A flow is the journey a user takes around a site to complete a particular action</strong>. A flow will most likely consist of a number of pages or stages, if you like.</p> <p>Ok, so you&rsquo;ve got the hang of it now.</p> <figure class="Image"> <div class="aspect-ratio-landscape"> <img srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_256/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-04.jpg 256w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-04.jpg 512w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_768/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-04.jpg 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1024/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-04.jpg 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1280/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-04.jpg 1280w" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-04.jpg" alt="The checkout (or second) flow at a breakpoint of 960px" class="lazyload" /> </div> <figcaption>The checkout (or second) flow at a breakpoint of 960px</figcaption> </figure> <p>This tells us that the Artboard shows our design at a breakpoint of <code>960px</code> (i.e desktop) and the design is part of the checkout flow. Which is the second flow in our website. Notice the second number in the sequence has now changed to 2.</p> <h3 id="the-stage">The Stage</h3> <p>Third in the sequence is the stage. <strong>The stage represents the part or step within in a flow</strong>. If we think back to our example <code>checkout</code> flow, a familiar stage in this flow might be <code>payment details</code>, as opposed to <code>shipping details</code>, or <code>checkout complete</code>. These are all stages, which might make up our <code>checkout</code> flow.</p> <p>Updating our example above might result in something like this:</p> <figure class="Image"> <div class="aspect-ratio-landscape"> <img srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_256/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-05.jpg 256w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-05.jpg 512w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_768/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-05.jpg 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1024/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-05.jpg 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1280/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-05.jpg 1280w" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-05.jpg" alt="The payment details stage in the checkout flow" class="lazyload" /> </div> <figcaption>The payment details stage in the checkout flow</figcaption> </figure> <p>This Artboard shows our design for the <code>Payment Details</code> stage in the <code>checkout</code> flow of our website. And this is how our design should look on a desktop monitor, or there abouts.</p> <h3 id="the-state">The State</h3> <p>Last in the four level sequence is the state. <strong>States are used to show different versions of the same stage in a flow</strong>. For example, you might need to design certain error states in a form. Perhaps a particular user action changes the look of a specific stage, and you need to show this in your design. A success notification would be a good example. Or if we think back to our example; when a user enters the incorrect card details. We might need to design the error message for this.</p> <p>Think of the state as the same page — if you like — as the stage, only the users action has modified the view of the stage in some way. So for this case we would add a new Artboard into our sequence and use it to mockup the state.</p> <p>If we update our example above, it might result in this:</p> <figure class="Image"> <div class="aspect-ratio-landscape"> <img srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_256/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-06.jpg 256w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-06.jpg 512w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_768/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-06.jpg 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1024/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-06.jpg 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1280/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-06.jpg 1280w" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-06.jpg" alt="Form errors on the checkout stage" class="lazyload" /> </div> <figcaption>Form errors on the checkout stage</figcaption> </figure> <p>This tells us that <code>Form error</code> is the second state we have designed this particular state in the flow (the payment details stage which is part of the checkout flow). In this case the first state was the normal page.</p> <p><em>Side note: having said all this, I don&rsquo;t always use states. The reason being, I tend to work with a UI kit or front end framework, where the states have already been determined. If this is the case, (as you&rsquo;ve probably noticed in the example) I will just leave a 1 on the end of the sequence. This suggests that the current Artboard is the first and only state.</em></p> <p>In some other cases I use the last number in the sequence not for a state but as a quick and dirty way to fudge in an extra Artboard, half way through a sequence.</p> <p>This happens quite a lot when you return to past projects and you need to add Artboard into the flow. It&rsquo;s hacky but it will prevent you from having to go through and re-jig all your other Artboard names to make your Artboard sequence run in order.</p> <figure class="Image"> <div class="aspect-ratio-landscape"> <img srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_256/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-07.jpg 256w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-07.jpg 512w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_768/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-07.jpg 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1024/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-07.jpg 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1280/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-07.jpg 1280w" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264892/hc/naming-artboards-in-sketch-07.jpg" alt="The text description explains the identifier code in more detail" class="lazyload" /> </div> <figcaption>The text description explains the identifier code in more detail</figcaption> </figure> <h2 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping up</h2> <p>Ok, this technique might seem a little over the top for a small project. But if like me you work on big ongoing website projects, then then having an Artboard naming system is very helpful, and will save your skin 10 times over.</p> <p>Whatever system you use, the most important thing is that <strong>your Artboards names are descriptive of the design that is on it</strong>. Now this might sound obvious, but you&rsquo;d be surprised. I&rsquo;ve seen some strange Artboards names before now, which give you no indication of what the design consists of and are totally illegible to a team. Furthermore, <strong>Artboards should be quick and easy to understand and reference</strong>.</p> <p><strong>Always discuss a new system with your team</strong>, so that everyone understands it and is on the same page. Above all, this will allow you to communicate any design decision you make effectively and with minimal fuss.</p> <p>If you have any thoughts on this approach or ways to improve it, I’d love to hear from you. Likewise, if you have any questions I will do my best to provide you with an answer.</p> <p>Heres to a stress free time with Artboards.</p>

item.title: Send form data to an inbox using Zapier
item.content:encoded: <p class="intro"> Have you ever felt overwhelmed by the amount of code it takes to get a simple contact form working on a website? </p> <p>Part of the reason I built my site static was because I didn’t want the hassle of having a to deal with a database, a server and PHP. Dealing with all that stuff adds a layer of complexity to a website, particularly when it comes to processing form data, if it’s not a necessity I’d rather avoid it.</p> <p>But where do you even start with processing form data on a static site?</p> <p>At times the options can feel limited, like the only way is to pay for a form provider and embed a form into your site. Whilst there’s nothing wrong with this solution you might want to consider another way, which you have full control over and you don’t have to pay for.</p> <p> I now use <a href="https://harrycresswell.com/articles/forms-with-netlify/">Netlify to handle form submissions</a> on this site. Saying that, this Zapier solution still works great if you’re not using Netlify. </p> <p><a href="https://harrycresswell.com/contact/">On this site</a> I’m using <a href="https://zapier.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Zapier</a> to collect form data and send it directly to my email. No servers, no database, no PHP. In this article we’ll look at how you can use the same technique to build a simple contact form for your own website, using Webhooks to collect data submitted and automatically send it to you in an email.</p> <p><em>If you’re building a static website with a generator like Jekyll, Hugo, Middleman or even just in vanilla HTML, then this is a great solution to get a form working on your site with minimal fuss.</em></p> <p>The good news is it’s pretty simple to implement and it’s free.</p> <h2 id="why-zapier">Why Zapier</h2> <p><a href="https://zapier.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Zapier</a> is an awesome tool which allows you to connect different apps in order to automate tasks. Using an automation tool like Zapier can save you a ton of time and make boring admin tasks a whole lot more fun.</p> <p>Zapier recommends several workflows you can use to integrate different apps, but there’s really no limitation to what you can do with it. Your only limitation is what you can think up, so you can get quite creative with what you do with it.</p> <h3 id="what-are-webhooks">What are Webhooks</h3> <p><a href="https://zapier.com/zapbook/webhook/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Webhooks</a> are a powerful Zapier feature which collect <code>POST</code> or <code>JSON</code> data and send it to a URL. You can then process this data pretty much however you like.</p> <p>If you are a developer then you might be familiar with endpoints. Webhooks are pretty much the same thing. If you have no idea what I’m talking about, don’t worry, it’s really quite straight forward to implement.</p> <h3 id="why-not-use-a-static-form-provider-instead">Why not use a static form provider instead</h3> <p>I initially looked into a few different ways to process form data on static sites before deciding to go with Zapier. The main two I looked at were FormKeep and Formspree.</p> <p><a href="https://formkeep.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">FormKeep</a> looks like a great solution, but it’s not cheap. Formkeep might be worth considering for client projects but for a personal website I’d rather keep my costs to a minimum.</p> <p><a href="https://formspree.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Formspree</a> is another great option. One I really quite like in fact. It’s free and does exactly what we are trying to achieve, it is probably even quicker to implement. Although Formspree and our Zapier method are very similar, in the end I choose to go with Zapier for a couple of reasons:</p> <h3 id="familiarity">Familiarity</h3> <p>I kept coming back to Zapier because it’s familiar. I already use Zapier for several other automated sequences in my business — for social media, for my email list and a whole bunch of other stuff. It’s also super quick and easy to set up automation connecting different apps.</p> <h3 id="flexibility">Flexibility</h3> <p>Zapier is the most flexible solution.</p> <p>Although the form we’re about to build is a very simple one, if we wanted to add further steps to process our form data, then Zapier makes this easy.</p> <p>Say for example, we wanted to send the data via an email and then afterwards add the form submitter to our mailing list (pretty cool right?). We can do this easily with <a href="https://zapier.com/learn/getting-started-guide/multi-step-zaps/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">multi-step Zaps</a>.</p> <p>Then, let’s say, we wanted to send an automated email response, or send a “Getting started with the service” PDF when someone fills out our form. Zapier makes this possible too.</p> <p>With Zapier our form can trigger any series of automated occurrences we want and connect our form up to a variety of different apps.</p> <p>As cool as this stuff is, it’s not something we’ll be covering right now. But hopefully it gives you an idea of the power and possibilities Zapier can bring to a contact form.</p> <h2 id="building-the-form">Building the form</h2> <p>We’re almost ready to start building our form, but first lets take a moment to break down what we would like to do. Here are the steps:</p> <ul> <li>Build a simple HTML form for our static website.</li> <li>Collect the data submitted and store it in a URL using a Zapier Webhook.</li> <li>Use Zapier to automagically send ourselves the data in an email, any time someone submits the form.</li> <li>Finally, redirect the user to a success page after they complete the form.</li> </ul> <p>Before we get started, you might want to <a href="http://harrycresswell.co.uk/tutorials/zapier-contact/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">jump over here</a> to see the end result.</p> <h2 id="step-1-writing-the-html">Step 1: Writing the HTML</h2> <p>Let’s take a look at the HTML we’re going to use to build the form.</p> <p> If you’d rather skip ahead you can get hold of the source code for this tutorial on <a href="https://github.com/harrycresswell/zapier-contact-form">Github</a>. </p> <p>For the purpose of this tutorial our form will have two input fields — one for a name and one for an email address — and a button to submit the data.</p> <p>The end result should look something like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">form</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;myForm&#34;</span> <span class="na">action</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;#&#34;</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;POST&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;text&#34;</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;full-name&#34;</span> <span class="na">placeholder</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;What&#39;s your name?&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;email&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;email-address&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">placeholder</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;What&#39;s your email address?&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;submit&#34;</span> <span class="na">value</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Submit&#34;</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Form-submit&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">form</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Let’s break this down. First make sure you give your form a suitable <code>id</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">form</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;myForm&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">form</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>We’re using <code>id=&quot;myForm&quot;</code> here to keep things nice and simple. We’ll need this later when we use some Ajax to redirect the page.</p> <p>Next, make sure you add an <code>action</code> attribute. Leave it blank for now, we will come back to this later.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">form</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;myForm&#34;</span> <span class="na">action</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;#&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">form</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Finally add <code>type=&quot;POST&quot;</code>. This is our HTTP request which submits the data to Zapier to be processed.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">form</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;myForm&#34;</span> <span class="na">action</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;#&#34;</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;POST&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">form</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id="adding-name-attributes">Adding name attributes</h3> <p>Remember to assign a <code>name=&quot;&quot;</code> attribute to all the form elements you want to collect data from <em>(that pretty much means all of them)</em>. You can name them however you like, but just make sure they are there.</p> <p>Let’s add one for our name input and one for our email input:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;text&#34;</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;full-name&#34;</span> <span class="na">placeholder</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;What&#39;s your name?&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Here I’ve used <code>name=&quot;full-name&quot;</code> and <code>email=&quot;email-address&quot;</code>.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;email&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;email-address&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">placeholder</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;What&#39;s your email address?&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Zapier will look out for the <code>name=&quot;&quot;</code> attribute when it tries to grab the values inputed by the user, so it’s important you remember to add them or your form won’t work.</p> <h3 id="add-a-submit-button">Add a submit button</h3> <p>Finally we’ll need to add a very basic button, so the user can submit their data. Let’s give our button an <code>id</code> of <code>Form-submit</code>:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;submit&#34;</span> <span class="na">value</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Submit&#34;</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Form-submit&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The rest should be fairly obvious — <code>type=&quot;submit&quot;</code> declares what type of <code>input</code> we would like to use, and the value declares the text shown on our button. In this case <code>Submit</code>.</p> <p><em>Note: I’ve removed all CSS classes used to style the form for this tutorial, however you would probably want to add some classes to style your form elements otherwise they won’t look all that pretty.</em></p> <h2 id="step-2-setting-up-zapier-to-collect-the-data">Step 2: Setting up Zapier to collect the data</h2> <p>If you haven’t already got a Zapier account, then before you do anything else you will need to <a href="https://zapier.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">sign up for a free account</a>.</p> <h3 id="create-a-new-zap">Create a new Zap</h3> <p>Next you will need to make a new Zap. Give your new Zap a name, then search for the <strong>Webhooks by Zapier</strong> trigger.</p> <figure> <video autoplay loop muted="muted" poster="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988549/hc/zapier-contact-form-create-a-zap.jpg"> <source type="video/mp4" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988549/hc/zapier-contact-form-create-a-zap.mp4"> <source type="video/webm" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988549/hc/zapier-contact-form-create-a-zap.webm"> Your browser does not support HTML5 video tag. <a href="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988549/hc/zapier-contact-form-create-a-zap.gif">Click here to view original GIF</a> </video> <figcaption>Create a Zap</figcaption> </figure> <p>Make sure you select <strong>Catch Hook</strong>, then hit <strong>save and continue</strong>.</p> <p>As we want to collect all the data submitted in our form, we’ll leave <strong>Pick off a child key</strong> blank and then hit <strong>continue</strong>.</p> <figure> <video autoplay loop muted="muted" poster="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988543/hc/zapier-contact-form-webhook-url.jpg"> <source type="video/mp4" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988543/hc/zapier-contact-form-webhook-url.mp4"> <source type="video/webm" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988543/hc/zapier-contact-form-webhook-url.webm"> Your browser does not support HTML5 video tag. <a href="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988543/hc/zapier-contact-form-webhook-url.gif">Click here to view original GIF</a> </video> <figcaption>Grab your webhook URL</figcaption> </figure> <p>Zapier then generates a custom webhook URL. Copy this URL to your clipboard. We will need to add it in our form so that Zapier can store any data submitted.</p> <h3 id="update-form-with-webhook-url-and-test">Update form with webhook URL and test</h3> <p>Head back to your form and replace the <strong>#</strong> symbol in <code>action=&quot;#&quot;</code> with the Webhook URL Zapier just generated for you.</p> <p>Your form should now look something like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">form</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;myForm&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">action</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://hooks.zapier.com/hooks/catch/1707140/msf6zi/&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;POST&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;text&#34;</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;full-name&#34;</span> <span class="na">placeholder</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;What&#39;s your name?&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;email&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;email-address&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">placeholder</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;What&#39;s your email address?&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;submit&#34;</span> <span class="na">value</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Submit&#34;</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Form-submit&#34;</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">form</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now we need to test our form to see if it’s working. Fill out your form and hit submit.</p> <p>If all went well your browser window should be redirected to the Zapier Webhook URL. You’ll see a string of data. Something like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-json" data-lang="json"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nt">&#34;status&#34;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;success&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nt">&#34;attempt&#34;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;58b94713-f62a-4f1b-a418-9a4a992774c0&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nt">&#34;id&#34;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;a0139409-2c05-4adb-a33c-111dd0e3e895&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nt">&#34;request_id&#34;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;Nx5Ew2eUJxPBY1p5&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now let’s head back to Zapier to see if our data was received.</p> <p>Hit <strong>Ok I did this</strong> to test the connection. You should now see a nice green banner confirming your test was successful. Great job!</p> <figure> <video autoplay loop muted="muted" poster="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988545/hc/zapier-contact-form-webhook-succesful.jpg"> <source type="video/mp4" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988545/hc/zapier-contact-form-webhook-succesful.mp4"> <source type="video/webm" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988545/hc/zapier-contact-form-webhook-succesful.webm"> Your browser does not support HTML5 video tag. <a href="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988545/hc/zapier-contact-form-webhook-succesful.gif">Click here to view original GIF</a> </video> <figcaption>Test Succesfull. Woohoo!</figcaption> </figure> <h2 id="step-3-automate-an-email-response">Step 3: Automate an email response</h2> <p>By now we should have a fully functional form, which sends the data to Zapier each time our form is submitted.</p> <p>The next step is to automate an email to our inbox, which sends every time someone fills out our form. We want this email to contain the name and email address of the person who submitted our form. Let’s do this now.</p> <h3 id="create-an-outbound-email-action">Create an outbound email action</h3> <p>Search for <strong>Email by Zapier</strong> in the &ldquo;Choose an action app&rdquo; step.</p> <p>Hit <strong>save and continue</strong> on Send an outbound email. This will create your action step sequence and bring up the email template where we can decide what our automated email will say.</p> <figure> <video autoplay loop muted="muted" poster="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988549/hc/zapier-contact-form-add-outbound-email-action-step.jpg"> <source type="video/mp4" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988549/hc/zapier-contact-form-add-outbound-email-action-step.mp4"> <source type="video/webm" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988549/hc/zapier-contact-form-add-outbound-email-action-step.webm"> Your browser does not support HTML5 video tag. <a href="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988549/hc/zapier-contact-form-add-outbound-email-action-step.gif">Click here to view original GIF</a> </video> <figcaption>Add outbound email action step</figcaption> </figure> <h3 id="build-the-email-template">Build the email template</h3> <p>This is the part where we add the data Zapier received via the webhook to our automated email.</p> <p>We will need to specify an email address which we would like the data sent to. You’ll most likely want to make this your own email address.</p> <p>Then we want to create a subject line and pull the data into the body of the email.</p> <p>Hit continue once you are happy. Zapier will summarise your email template then fire off a test.</p> <figure> <video autoplay loop muted="muted" poster="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988550/hc/zapier-contact-form-set-up-email-template.jpg"> <source type="video/mp4" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988550/hc/zapier-contact-form-set-up-email-template.mp4"> <source type="video/webm" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988550/hc/zapier-contact-form-set-up-email-template.webm"> Your browser does not support HTML5 video tag. <a href="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//v1531988550/hc/zapier-contact-form-set-up-email-template.gif">Click here to view original GIF</a> </video> <figcaption>Build the automated email template</figcaption> </figure> <h3 id="check-your-inbox-for-the-email">Check your inbox for the email</h3> <p>Now go check your inbox. You should have received an email containing the data, nicely laid out in the template you just set up.</p> <figure class="Image"> <div class="aspect-ratio-landscape"> <img srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_256/v1550264893/hc/zapier-contact-form-automated-email-inbox.jpg 256w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264893/hc/zapier-contact-form-automated-email-inbox.jpg 512w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_768/v1550264893/hc/zapier-contact-form-automated-email-inbox.jpg 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1024/v1550264893/hc/zapier-contact-form-automated-email-inbox.jpg 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_1280/v1550264893/hc/zapier-contact-form-automated-email-inbox.jpg 1280w" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/harrycresswell/image/upload//f_auto,q_80,w_512/v1550264893/hc/zapier-contact-form-automated-email-inbox.jpg" alt="Zapier is now sending us an automated email" class="lazyload" /> </div> <figcaption>Zapier is now sending us an automated email</figcaption> </figure> <p>You might want to filter your automated emails from Zapier by marking them with a label. This way you can easily identify where they have come from. I’ve called my label Zapier and coloured it orange so it’s easy to spot.</p> <p>At this point everything should be set up correctly, so that Zapier sends an automated email to your inbox when someone fills out your form.</p> <h2 id="step-4-using-ajax-to-redirect-the-url">Step 4: Using Ajax to redirect the URL</h2> <p>The final step is to redirect the user when they fill out our form.</p> <p>Right now, anyone who submits the form is redirected to a nasty Webhook URL showing the string on data.</p> <p>Ideally we’d like to be able to tell the person who submits the form that their information was submitted successfully, and keep them on our website, rather than directing them away from it.</p> <p>We can do this with a few lines of Ajax.</p> <p>Before the closing <code>&lt;/body&gt;</code> tag in the footer of your page, load a copy of jQuery.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c">&lt;!-- Load jquery --&gt;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">script</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.1.0/jquery.min.js&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">script</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Beneath that you will need the following Javascript:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-javascript" data-lang="javascript"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1">// POST form data to zapier on submit </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span><span class="nx">$</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&#34;#myForm&#34;</span><span class="p">).</span><span class="nx">submit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">e</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">e</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">preventDefault</span><span class="p">();</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">$</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">ajax</span><span class="p">({</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">url</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;YOUR_ZAPIER_WEBHOOK_URL_GOES_HERE&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">type</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s2">&#34;post&#34;</span><span class="p">,</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">data</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="nx">$</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&#34;#myForm&#34;</span><span class="p">).</span><span class="nx">serialize</span><span class="p">(),</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="nx">success</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">{</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="c1">// Redirect to another success page </span></span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="c1"></span> <span class="nb">window</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">location</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">&#34;http://google.com&#34;</span><span class="p">;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">}</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">});</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">});</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Make sure you replace the Webhook URL with the one Zapier generated for you and the redirect URL with the page you want the submitted form to redirect to. For this example I’ve just used Google which is probably not what you want.</p> <p>Finally, let’s head back to our form and remove the <code>action=&quot;&quot;</code> and <code>type=&quot;&quot;</code> attributes from the html. We don’t need this anymore as Ajax is now taking care of posting our form data to Zapier.</p> <p>The HTML for our form should now look something like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">form</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><!-- raw HTML omitted --> <h2 id="taking-it-further">Taking it further</h2> <p>In this article we’ve looked at submitting form data to an email address using Zapier. This is an ideal low cost solution for static sites, where you want to avoid writing server side code or paying for a form provider. There are of course ways we can make this better.</p> <h3 id="validation">Validation</h3> <p>Something I haven’t tackled in this article is form validation. Validating your form with success or error prompts would require some extra Javascript and a bit more HTML markup, but it&rsquo;s perfectly possible.</p> <p>However you might find a very basic bit of validation is enough. By adding the <code>required</code> attribute to the end of any required form elements, you can ensure the form submitter is warned of those fields that are required, in order to submit the form.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="line"><span class="cl"><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;email&#34;</span> <span class="na">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;email-address&#34;</span> <span class="na">required</span> <span class="p">/&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This will prevent a user from submitting your form without inputting the necessary data.</p> <h3 id="accessibility">Accessibility</h3> <p>To make sure your forms are accessible to everyone and to prevent your site from getting penalised by Google, you will want to add labels to your form elements. Make sure you add a <code>for</code> attribute equal to the <code>id</code> attribute of the related element to each label. This will bind them together.</p> <p>With this in mind, our might look like this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" class="chroma"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span class="s">&#34;email&#34;</span> </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Form-email&#34;</span> </span></span><span </span></span><span class="line"><span class="cl"> <span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">label</span> <span class="na">for</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Form-submit&#34;</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;u-visually-hidden&#34;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>Submit<span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;submit&#34;</span> <span class="na">value</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&#34;Submit&#34;</span> <span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">form</span><span class="p">&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Notice I’m using a class called <code>u-visually-hidden</code> to hide the button label from everyone except screen readers and crawlers.</p> <h3 id="adding-more-fields">Adding more fields</h3> <p>Although I only used a first name and an email address in this example, you might want to process a whole lot more data with your form. Just remember to include a <code>name</code> attribute on every form element in order for Zapier to catch the data.</p> <p>I hope this has been a helpful introduction into using Zapier to process form data on static sites.
